text: VOLUME I
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER I
title: Emma

text: Emma Woodhouse, handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home and
title: Emma

text: happy disposition, seemed to unite some of the best blessings of
title: Emma

text: existence; and had lived nearly twenty-one years in the world with very
title: Emma

text: little to distress or vex her.
title: Emma

text: She was the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate,
title: Emma

text: indulgent father; and had, in consequence of her sister’s marriage,
title: Emma

text: been mistress of his house from a very early period. Her mother had
title: Emma

text: died too long ago for her to have more than an indistinct remembrance
title: Emma

text: of her caresses; and her place had been supplied by an excellent woman
title: Emma

text: as governess, who had fallen little short of a mother in affection.
title: Emma

text: Sixteen years had Miss Taylor been in Mr. Woodhouse’s family, less as a
title: Emma

text: governess than a friend, very fond of both daughters, but particularly
title: Emma

text: of Emma. Between _them_ it was more the intimacy of sisters. Even
title: Emma

text: before Miss Taylor had ceased to hold the nominal office of governess,
title: Emma

text: the mildness of her temper had hardly allowed her to impose any
title: Emma

text: restraint; and the shadow of authority being now long passed away, they
title: Emma

text: had been living together as friend and friend very mutually attached,
title: Emma

text: and Emma doing just what she liked; highly esteeming Miss Taylor’s
title: Emma

text: judgment, but directed chiefly by her own.
title: Emma

text: The real evils, indeed, of Emma’s situation were the power of having
title: Emma

text: rather too much her own way, and a disposition to think a little too
title: Emma

text: well of herself; these were the disadvantages which threatened alloy to
title: Emma

text: her many enjoyments. The danger, however, was at present so
title: Emma

text: unperceived, that they did not by any means rank as misfortunes with
title: Emma

text: her.
title: Emma

text: Sorrow came—a gentle sorrow—but not at all in the shape of any
title: Emma

text: disagreeable consciousness.—Miss Taylor married. It was Miss Taylor’s
title: Emma

text: loss which first brought grief. It was on the wedding-day of this
title: Emma

text: beloved friend that Emma first sat in mournful thought of any
title: Emma

text: continuance. The wedding over, and the bride-people gone, her father
title: Emma

text: and herself were left to dine together, with no prospect of a third to
title: Emma

text: cheer a long evening. Her father composed himself to sleep after
title: Emma

text: dinner, as usual, and she had then only to sit and think of what she
title: Emma

text: had lost.
title: Emma

text: The event had every promise of happiness for her friend. Mr. Weston was
title: Emma

text: a man of unexceptionable character, easy fortune, suitable age, and
title: Emma

text: pleasant manners; and there was some satisfaction in considering with
title: Emma

text: what self-denying, generous friendship she had always wished and
title: Emma

text: promoted the match; but it was a black morning’s work for her. The want
title: Emma

text: of Miss Taylor would be felt every hour of every day. She recalled her
title: Emma

text: past kindness—the kindness, the affection of sixteen years—how she had
title: Emma

text: taught and how she had played with her from five years old—how she had
title: Emma

text: devoted all her powers to attach and amuse her in health—and how nursed
title: Emma

text: her through the various illnesses of childhood. A large debt of
title: Emma

text: gratitude was owing here; but the intercourse of the last seven years,
title: Emma

text: the equal footing and perfect unreserve which had soon followed
title: Emma

text: Isabella’s marriage, on their being left to each other, was yet a
title: Emma

text: dearer, tenderer recollection. She had been a friend and companion such
title: Emma

text: as few possessed: intelligent, well-informed, useful, gentle, knowing
title: Emma

text: all the ways of the family, interested in all its concerns, and
title: Emma

text: peculiarly interested in herself, in every pleasure, every scheme of
title: Emma

text: hers—one to whom she could speak every thought as it arose, and who had
title: Emma

text: such an affection for her as could never find fault.
title: Emma

text: How was she to bear the change?—It was true that her friend was going
title: Emma

text: only half a mile from them; but Emma was aware that great must be the
title: Emma

text: difference between a Mrs. Weston, only half a mile from them, and a
title: Emma

text: Miss Taylor in the house; and with all her advantages, natural and
title: Emma

text: domestic, she was now in great danger of suffering from intellectual
title: Emma

text: solitude. She dearly loved her father, but he was no companion for her.
title: Emma

text: He could not meet her in conversation, rational or playful.
title: Emma

text: The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and Mr. Woodhouse had
title: Emma

text: not married early) was much increased by his constitution and habits;
title: Emma

text: for having been a valetudinarian all his life, without activity of mind
title: Emma

text: or body, he was a much older man in ways than in years; and though
title: Emma

text: everywhere beloved for the friendliness of his heart and his amiable
title: Emma

text: temper, his talents could not have recommended him at any time.
title: Emma

text: Her sister, though comparatively but little removed by matrimony, being
title: Emma

text: settled in London, only sixteen miles off, was much beyond her daily
title: Emma

text: reach; and many a long October and November evening must be struggled
title: Emma

text: through at Hartfield, before Christmas brought the next visit from
title: Emma

text: Isabella and her husband, and their little children, to fill the house,
title: Emma

text: and give her pleasant society again.
title: Emma

text: Highbury, the large and populous village, almost amounting to a town,
title: Emma

text: to which Hartfield, in spite of its separate lawn, and shrubberies, and
title: Emma

text: name, did really belong, afforded her no equals. The Woodhouses were
title: Emma

text: first in consequence there. All looked up to them. She had many
title: Emma

text: acquaintance in the place, for her father was universally civil, but
title: Emma

text: not one among them who could be accepted in lieu of Miss Taylor for
title: Emma

text: even half a day. It was a melancholy change; and Emma could not but
title: Emma

text: sigh over it, and wish for impossible things, till her father awoke,
title: Emma

text: and made it necessary to be cheerful. His spirits required support. He
title: Emma

text: was a nervous man, easily depressed; fond of every body that he was
title: Emma

text: used to, and hating to part with them; hating change of every kind.
title: Emma

text: Matrimony, as the origin of change, was always disagreeable; and he was
title: Emma

text: by no means yet reconciled to his own daughter’s marrying, nor could
title: Emma

text: ever speak of her but with compassion, though it had been entirely a
title: Emma

text: match of affection, when he was now obliged to part with Miss Taylor
title: Emma

text: too; and from his habits of gentle selfishness, and of being never able
title: Emma

text: to suppose that other people could feel differently from himself, he
title: Emma

text: was very much disposed to think Miss Taylor had done as sad a thing for
title: Emma

text: herself as for them, and would have been a great deal happier if she
title: Emma

text: had spent all the rest of her life at Hartfield. Emma smiled and
title: Emma

text: chatted as cheerfully as she could, to keep him from such thoughts; but
title: Emma

text: when tea came, it was impossible for him not to say exactly as he had
title: Emma

text: said at dinner,
title: Emma

text: “Poor Miss Taylor!—I wish she were here again. What a pity it is that
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston ever thought of her!”
title: Emma

text: “I cannot agree with you, papa; you know I cannot. Mr. Weston is such a
title: Emma

text: good-humoured, pleasant, excellent man, that he thoroughly deserves a
title: Emma

text: good wife;—and you would not have had Miss Taylor live with us for
title: Emma

text: ever, and bear all my odd humours, when she might have a house of her
title: Emma

text: own?”
title: Emma

text: “A house of her own!—But where is the advantage of a house of her own?
title: Emma

text: This is three times as large.—And you have never any odd humours, my
title: Emma

text: dear.”
title: Emma

text: “How often we shall be going to see them, and they coming to see us!—We
title: Emma

text: shall be always meeting! _We_ must begin; we must go and pay wedding
title: Emma

text: visit very soon.”
title: Emma

text: “My dear, how am I to get so far? Randalls is such a distance. I could
title: Emma

text: not walk half so far.”
title: Emma

text: “No, papa, nobody thought of your walking. We must go in the carriage,
title: Emma

text: to be sure.”
title: Emma

text: “The carriage! But James will not like to put the horses to for such a
title: Emma

text: little way;—and where are the poor horses to be while we are paying our
title: Emma

text: visit?”
title: Emma

text: “They are to be put into Mr. Weston’s stable, papa. You know we have
title: Emma

text: settled all that already. We talked it all over with Mr. Weston last
title: Emma

text: night. And as for James, you may be very sure he will always like going
title: Emma

text: to Randalls, because of his daughter’s being housemaid there. I only
title: Emma

text: doubt whether he will ever take us anywhere else. That was your doing,
title: Emma

text: papa. You got Hannah that good place. Nobody thought of Hannah till you
title: Emma

text: mentioned her—James is so obliged to you!”
title: Emma

text: “I am very glad I did think of her. It was very lucky, for I would not
title: Emma

text: have had poor James think himself slighted upon any account; and I am
title: Emma

text: sure she will make a very good servant: she is a civil, pretty-spoken
title: Emma

text: girl; I have a great opinion of her. Whenever I see her, she always
title: Emma

text: curtseys and asks me how I do, in a very pretty manner; and when you
title: Emma

text: have had her here to do needlework, I observe she always turns the lock
title: Emma

text: of the door the right way and never bangs it. I am sure she will be an
title: Emma

text: excellent servant; and it will be a great comfort to poor Miss Taylor
title: Emma

text: to have somebody about her that she is used to see. Whenever James goes
title: Emma

text: over to see his daughter, you know, she will be hearing of us. He will
title: Emma

text: be able to tell her how we all are.”
title: Emma

text: Emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas, and
title: Emma

text: hoped, by the help of backgammon, to get her father tolerably through
title: Emma

text: the evening, and be attacked by no regrets but her own. The
title: Emma

text: backgammon-table was placed; but a visitor immediately afterwards
title: Emma

text: walked in and made it unnecessary.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, a sensible man about seven or eight-and-thirty, was not
title: Emma

text: only a very old and intimate friend of the family, but particularly
title: Emma

text: connected with it, as the elder brother of Isabella’s husband. He lived
title: Emma

text: about a mile from Highbury, was a frequent visitor, and always welcome,
title: Emma

text: and at this time more welcome than usual, as coming directly from their
title: Emma

text: mutual connexions in London. He had returned to a late dinner, after
title: Emma

text: some days’ absence, and now walked up to Hartfield to say that all were
title: Emma

text: well in Brunswick Square. It was a happy circumstance, and animated Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse for some time. Mr. Knightley had a cheerful manner, which
title: Emma

text: always did him good; and his many inquiries after “poor Isabella” and
title: Emma

text: her children were answered most satisfactorily. When this was over, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse gratefully observed, “It is very kind of you, Mr. Knightley,
title: Emma

text: to come out at this late hour to call upon us. I am afraid you must
title: Emma

text: have had a shocking walk.”
title: Emma

text: “Not at all, sir. It is a beautiful moonlight night; and so mild that I
title: Emma

text: must draw back from your great fire.”
title: Emma

text: “But you must have found it very damp and dirty. I wish you may not
title: Emma

text: catch cold.”
title: Emma

text: “Dirty, sir! Look at my shoes. Not a speck on them.”
title: Emma

text: “Well! that is quite surprising, for we have had a vast deal of rain
title: Emma

text: here. It rained dreadfully hard for half an hour while we were at
title: Emma

text: breakfast. I wanted them to put off the wedding.”
title: Emma

text: “By the bye—I have not wished you joy. Being pretty well aware of what
title: Emma

text: sort of joy you must both be feeling, I have been in no hurry with my
title: Emma

text: congratulations; but I hope it all went off tolerably well. How did you
title: Emma

text: all behave? Who cried most?”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! poor Miss Taylor! ’Tis a sad business.”
title: Emma

text: “Poor Mr. and Miss Woodhouse, if you please; but I cannot possibly say
title: Emma

text: ‘poor Miss Taylor.’ I have a great regard for you and Emma; but when it
title: Emma

text: comes to the question of dependence or independence!—At any rate, it
title: Emma

text: must be better to have only one to please than two.”
title: Emma

text: “Especially when _one_ of those two is such a fanciful, troublesome
title: Emma

text: creature!” said Emma playfully. “That is what you have in your head, I
title: Emma

text: know—and what you would certainly say if my father were not by.”
title: Emma

text: “I believe it is very true, my dear, indeed,” said Mr. Woodhouse, with
title: Emma

text: a sigh. “I am afraid I am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome.”
title: Emma

text: “My dearest papa! You do not think I could mean _you_, or suppose Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley to mean _you_. What a horrible idea! Oh no! I meant only
title: Emma

text: myself. Mr. Knightley loves to find fault with me, you know—in a
title: Emma

text: joke—it is all a joke. We always say what we like to one another.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, in fact, was one of the few people who could see faults
title: Emma

text: in Emma Woodhouse, and the only one who ever told her of them: and
title: Emma

text: though this was not particularly agreeable to Emma herself, she knew it
title: Emma

text: would be so much less so to her father, that she would not have him
title: Emma

text: really suspect such a circumstance as her not being thought perfect by
title: Emma

text: every body.
title: Emma

text: “Emma knows I never flatter her,” said Mr. Knightley, “but I meant no
title: Emma

text: reflection on any body. Miss Taylor has been used to have two persons
title: Emma

text: to please; she will now have but one. The chances are that she must be
title: Emma

text: a gainer.”
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said Emma, willing to let it pass—“you want to hear about the
title: Emma

text: wedding; and I shall be happy to tell you, for we all behaved
title: Emma

text: charmingly. Every body was punctual, every body in their best looks:
title: Emma

text: not a tear, and hardly a long face to be seen. Oh no; we all felt that
title: Emma

text: we were going to be only half a mile apart, and were sure of meeting
title: Emma

text: every day.”
title: Emma

text: “Dear Emma bears every thing so well,” said her father. “But, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley, she is really very sorry to lose poor Miss Taylor, and I am
title: Emma

text: sure she _will_ miss her more than she thinks for.”
title: Emma

text: Emma turned away her head, divided between tears and smiles. “It is
title: Emma

text: impossible that Emma should not miss such a companion,” said Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley. “We should not like her so well as we do, sir, if we could
title: Emma

text: suppose it; but she knows how much the marriage is to Miss Taylor’s
title: Emma

text: advantage; she knows how very acceptable it must be, at Miss Taylor’s
title: Emma

text: time of life, to be settled in a home of her own, and how important to
title: Emma

text: her to be secure of a comfortable provision, and therefore cannot allow
title: Emma

text: herself to feel so much pain as pleasure. Every friend of Miss Taylor
title: Emma

text: must be glad to have her so happily married.”
title: Emma

text: “And you have forgotten one matter of joy to me,” said Emma, “and a
title: Emma

text: very considerable one—that I made the match myself. I made the match,
title: Emma

text: you know, four years ago; and to have it take place, and be proved in
title: Emma

text: the right, when so many people said Mr. Weston would never marry again,
title: Emma

text: may comfort me for any thing.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley shook his head at her. Her father fondly replied, “Ah! my
title: Emma

text: dear, I wish you would not make matches and foretell things, for
title: Emma

text: whatever you say always comes to pass. Pray do not make any more
title: Emma

text: matches.”
title: Emma

text: “I promise you to make none for myself, papa; but I must, indeed, for
title: Emma

text: other people. It is the greatest amusement in the world! And after such
title: Emma

text: success, you know!—Every body said that Mr. Weston would never marry
title: Emma

text: again. Oh dear, no! Mr. Weston, who had been a widower so long, and who
title: Emma

text: seemed so perfectly comfortable without a wife, so constantly occupied
title: Emma

text: either in his business in town or among his friends here, always
title: Emma

text: acceptable wherever he went, always cheerful—Mr. Weston need not spend
title: Emma

text: a single evening in the year alone if he did not like it. Oh no! Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston certainly would never marry again. Some people even talked of a
title: Emma

text: promise to his wife on her deathbed, and others of the son and the
title: Emma

text: uncle not letting him. All manner of solemn nonsense was talked on the
title: Emma

text: subject, but I believed none of it.
title: Emma

text: “Ever since the day—about four years ago—that Miss Taylor and I met
title: Emma

text: with him in Broadway Lane, when, because it began to drizzle, he darted
title: Emma

text: away with so much gallantry, and borrowed two umbrellas for us from
title: Emma

text: Farmer Mitchell’s, I made up my mind on the subject. I planned the
title: Emma

text: match from that hour; and when such success has blessed me in this
title: Emma

text: instance, dear papa, you cannot think that I shall leave off
title: Emma

text: match-making.”
title: Emma

text: “I do not understand what you mean by ‘success,’” said Mr. Knightley.
title: Emma

text: “Success supposes endeavour. Your time has been properly and delicately
title: Emma

text: spent, if you have been endeavouring for the last four years to bring
title: Emma

text: about this marriage. A worthy employment for a young lady’s mind! But
title: Emma

text: if, which I rather imagine, your making the match, as you call it,
title: Emma

text: means only your planning it, your saying to yourself one idle day, ‘I
title: Emma

text: think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor if Mr. Weston were
title: Emma

text: to marry her,’ and saying it again to yourself every now and then
title: Emma

text: afterwards, why do you talk of success? Where is your merit? What are
title: Emma

text: you proud of? You made a lucky guess; and _that_ is all that can be
title: Emma

text: said.”
title: Emma

text: “And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?—I
title: Emma

text: pity you.—I thought you cleverer—for, depend upon it a lucky guess is
title: Emma

text: never merely luck. There is always some talent in it. And as to my poor
title: Emma

text: word ‘success,’ which you quarrel with, I do not know that I am so
title: Emma

text: entirely without any claim to it. You have drawn two pretty pictures;
title: Emma

text: but I think there may be a third—a something between the do-nothing and
title: Emma

text: the do-all. If I had not promoted Mr. Weston’s visits here, and given
title: Emma

text: many little encouragements, and smoothed many little matters, it might
title: Emma

text: not have come to any thing after all. I think you must know Hartfield
title: Emma

text: enough to comprehend that.”
title: Emma

text: “A straightforward, open-hearted man like Weston, and a rational,
title: Emma

text: unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their
title: Emma

text: own concerns. You are more likely to have done harm to yourself, than
title: Emma

text: good to them, by interference.”
title: Emma

text: “Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others,” rejoined
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse, understanding but in part. “But, my dear, pray do not
title: Emma

text: make any more matches; they are silly things, and break up one’s family
title: Emma

text: circle grievously.”
title: Emma

text: “Only one more, papa; only for Mr. Elton. Poor Mr. Elton! You like Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton, papa,—I must look about for a wife for him. There is nobody in
title: Emma

text: Highbury who deserves him—and he has been here a whole year, and has
title: Emma

text: fitted up his house so comfortably, that it would be a shame to have
title: Emma

text: him single any longer—and I thought when he was joining their hands
title: Emma

text: to-day, he looked so very much as if he would like to have the same
title: Emma

text: kind office done for him! I think very well of Mr. Elton, and this is
title: Emma

text: the only way I have of doing him a service.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very good
title: Emma

text: young man, and I have a great regard for him. But if you want to shew
title: Emma

text: him any attention, my dear, ask him to come and dine with us some day.
title: Emma

text: That will be a much better thing. I dare say Mr. Knightley will be so
title: Emma

text: kind as to meet him.”
title: Emma

text: “With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time,” said Mr. Knightley,
title: Emma

text: laughing, “and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much better
title: Emma

text: thing. Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the best of the fish
title: Emma

text: and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife. Depend upon it, a
title: Emma

text: man of six or seven-and-twenty can take care of himself.”
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER II
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston was a native of Highbury, and born of a respectable family,
title: Emma

text: which for the last two or three generations had been rising into
title: Emma

text: gentility and property. He had received a good education, but, on
title: Emma

text: succeeding early in life to a small independence, had become indisposed
title: Emma

text: for any of the more homely pursuits in which his brothers were engaged,
title: Emma

text: and had satisfied an active, cheerful mind and social temper by
title: Emma

text: entering into the militia of his county, then embodied.
title: Emma

text: Captain Weston was a general favourite; and when the chances of his
title: Emma

text: military life had introduced him to Miss Churchill, of a great
title: Emma

text: Yorkshire family, and Miss Churchill fell in love with him, nobody was
title: Emma

text: surprized, except her brother and his wife, who had never seen him, and
title: Emma

text: who were full of pride and importance, which the connexion would
title: Emma

text: offend.
title: Emma

text: Miss Churchill, however, being of age, and with the full command of her
title: Emma

text: fortune—though her fortune bore no proportion to the family-estate—was
title: Emma

text: not to be dissuaded from the marriage, and it took place, to the
title: Emma

text: infinite mortification of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, who threw her off
title: Emma

text: with due decorum. It was an unsuitable connexion, and did not produce
title: Emma

text: much happiness. Mrs. Weston ought to have found more in it, for she had
title: Emma

text: a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper made him think every thing
title: Emma

text: due to her in return for the great goodness of being in love with him;
title: Emma

text: but though she had one sort of spirit, she had not the best. She had
title: Emma

text: resolution enough to pursue her own will in spite of her brother, but
title: Emma

text: not enough to refrain from unreasonable regrets at that brother’s
title: Emma

text: unreasonable anger, nor from missing the luxuries of her former home.
title: Emma

text: They lived beyond their income, but still it was nothing in comparison
title: Emma

text: of Enscombe: she did not cease to love her husband, but she wanted at
title: Emma

text: once to be the wife of Captain Weston, and Miss Churchill of Enscombe.
title: Emma

text: Captain Weston, who had been considered, especially by the Churchills,
title: Emma

text: as making such an amazing match, was proved to have much the worst of
title: Emma

text: the bargain; for when his wife died, after a three years’ marriage, he
title: Emma

text: was rather a poorer man than at first, and with a child to maintain.
title: Emma

text: From the expense of the child, however, he was soon relieved. The boy
title: Emma

text: had, with the additional softening claim of a lingering illness of his
title: Emma

text: mother’s, been the means of a sort of reconciliation; and Mr. and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Churchill, having no children of their own, nor any other young
title: Emma

text: creature of equal kindred to care for, offered to take the whole charge
title: Emma

text: of the little Frank soon after her decease. Some scruples and some
title: Emma

text: reluctance the widower-father may be supposed to have felt; but as they
title: Emma

text: were overcome by other considerations, the child was given up to the
title: Emma

text: care and the wealth of the Churchills, and he had only his own comfort
title: Emma

text: to seek, and his own situation to improve as he could.
title: Emma

text: A complete change of life became desirable. He quitted the militia and
title: Emma

text: engaged in trade, having brothers already established in a good way in
title: Emma

text: London, which afforded him a favourable opening. It was a concern which
title: Emma

text: brought just employment enough. He had still a small house in Highbury,
title: Emma

text: where most of his leisure days were spent; and between useful
title: Emma

text: occupation and the pleasures of society, the next eighteen or twenty
title: Emma

text: years of his life passed cheerfully away. He had, by that time,
title: Emma

text: realised an easy competence—enough to secure the purchase of a little
title: Emma

text: estate adjoining Highbury, which he had always longed for—enough to
title: Emma

text: marry a woman as portionless even as Miss Taylor, and to live according
title: Emma

text: to the wishes of his own friendly and social disposition.
title: Emma

text: It was now some time since Miss Taylor had begun to influence his
title: Emma

text: schemes; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth on youth, it
title: Emma

text: had not shaken his determination of never settling till he could
title: Emma

text: purchase Randalls, and the sale of Randalls was long looked forward to;
title: Emma

text: but he had gone steadily on, with these objects in view, till they were
title: Emma

text: accomplished. He had made his fortune, bought his house, and obtained
title: Emma

text: his wife; and was beginning a new period of existence, with every
title: Emma

text: probability of greater happiness than in any yet passed through. He had
title: Emma

text: never been an unhappy man; his own temper had secured him from that,
title: Emma

text: even in his first marriage; but his second must shew him how delightful
title: Emma

text: a well-judging and truly amiable woman could be, and must give him the
title: Emma

text: pleasantest proof of its being a great deal better to choose than to be
title: Emma

text: chosen, to excite gratitude than to feel it.
title: Emma

text: He had only himself to please in his choice: his fortune was his own;
title: Emma

text: for as to Frank, it was more than being tacitly brought up as his
title: Emma

text: uncle’s heir, it had become so avowed an adoption as to have him assume
title: Emma

text: the name of Churchill on coming of age. It was most unlikely,
title: Emma

text: therefore, that he should ever want his father’s assistance. His father
title: Emma

text: had no apprehension of it. The aunt was a capricious woman, and
title: Emma

text: governed her husband entirely; but it was not in Mr. Weston’s nature to
title: Emma

text: imagine that any caprice could be strong enough to affect one so dear,
title: Emma

text: and, as he believed, so deservedly dear. He saw his son every year in
title: Emma

text: London, and was proud of him; and his fond report of him as a very fine
title: Emma

text: young man had made Highbury feel a sort of pride in him too. He was
title: Emma

text: looked on as sufficiently belonging to the place to make his merits and
title: Emma

text: prospects a kind of common concern.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Frank Churchill was one of the boasts of Highbury, and a lively
title: Emma

text: curiosity to see him prevailed, though the compliment was so little
title: Emma

text: returned that he had never been there in his life. His coming to visit
title: Emma

text: his father had been often talked of but never achieved.
title: Emma

text: Now, upon his father’s marriage, it was very generally proposed, as a
title: Emma

text: most proper attention, that the visit should take place. There was not
title: Emma

text: a dissentient voice on the subject, either when Mrs. Perry drank tea
title: Emma

text: with Mrs. and Miss Bates, or when Mrs. and Miss Bates returned the
title: Emma

text: visit. Now was the time for Mr. Frank Churchill to come among them; and
title: Emma

text: the hope strengthened when it was understood that he had written to his
title: Emma

text: new mother on the occasion. For a few days, every morning visit in
title: Emma

text: Highbury included some mention of the handsome letter Mrs. Weston had
title: Emma

text: received. “I suppose you have heard of the handsome letter Mr. Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill has written to Mrs. Weston? I understand it was a very
title: Emma

text: handsome letter, indeed. Mr. Woodhouse told me of it. Mr. Woodhouse saw
title: Emma

text: the letter, and he says he never saw such a handsome letter in his
title: Emma

text: life.”
title: Emma

text: It was, indeed, a highly prized letter. Mrs. Weston had, of course,
title: Emma

text: formed a very favourable idea of the young man; and such a pleasing
title: Emma

text: attention was an irresistible proof of his great good sense, and a most
title: Emma

text: welcome addition to every source and every expression of congratulation
title: Emma

text: which her marriage had already secured. She felt herself a most
title: Emma

text: fortunate woman; and she had lived long enough to know how fortunate
title: Emma

text: she might well be thought, where the only regret was for a partial
title: Emma

text: separation from friends whose friendship for her had never cooled, and
title: Emma

text: who could ill bear to part with her.
title: Emma

text: She knew that at times she must be missed; and could not think, without
title: Emma

text: pain, of Emma’s losing a single pleasure, or suffering an hour’s ennui,
title: Emma

text: from the want of her companionableness: but dear Emma was of no feeble
title: Emma

text: character; she was more equal to her situation than most girls would
title: Emma

text: have been, and had sense, and energy, and spirits that might be hoped
title: Emma

text: would bear her well and happily through its little difficulties and
title: Emma

text: privations. And then there was such comfort in the very easy distance
title: Emma

text: of Randalls from Hartfield, so convenient for even solitary female
title: Emma

text: walking, and in Mr. Weston’s disposition and circumstances, which would
title: Emma

text: make the approaching season no hindrance to their spending half the
title: Emma

text: evenings in the week together.
title: Emma

text: Her situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston, and of moments only of regret; and her satisfaction—her more
title: Emma

text: than satisfaction—her cheerful enjoyment, was so just and so apparent,
title: Emma

text: that Emma, well as she knew her father, was sometimes taken by surprize
title: Emma

text: at his being still able to pity ‘poor Miss Taylor,’ when they left her
title: Emma

text: at Randalls in the centre of every domestic comfort, or saw her go away
title: Emma

text: in the evening attended by her pleasant husband to a carriage of her
title: Emma

text: own. But never did she go without Mr. Woodhouse’s giving a gentle sigh,
title: Emma

text: and saying, “Ah, poor Miss Taylor! She would be very glad to stay.”
title: Emma

text: There was no recovering Miss Taylor—nor much likelihood of ceasing to
title: Emma

text: pity her; but a few weeks brought some alleviation to Mr. Woodhouse.
title: Emma

text: The compliments of his neighbours were over; he was no longer teased by
title: Emma

text: being wished joy of so sorrowful an event; and the wedding-cake, which
title: Emma

text: had been a great distress to him, was all eat up. His own stomach could
title: Emma

text: bear nothing rich, and he could never believe other people to be
title: Emma

text: different from himself. What was unwholesome to him he regarded as
title: Emma

text: unfit for any body; and he had, therefore, earnestly tried to dissuade
title: Emma

text: them from having any wedding-cake at all, and when that proved vain, as
title: Emma

text: earnestly tried to prevent any body’s eating it. He had been at the
title: Emma

text: pains of consulting Mr. Perry, the apothecary, on the subject. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Perry was an intelligent, gentlemanlike man, whose frequent visits were
title: Emma

text: one of the comforts of Mr. Woodhouse’s life; and upon being applied to,
title: Emma

text: he could not but acknowledge (though it seemed rather against the bias
title: Emma

text: of inclination) that wedding-cake might certainly disagree with
title: Emma

text: many—perhaps with most people, unless taken moderately. With such an
title: Emma

text: opinion, in confirmation of his own, Mr. Woodhouse hoped to influence
title: Emma

text: every visitor of the newly married pair; but still the cake was eaten;
title: Emma

text: and there was no rest for his benevolent nerves till it was all gone.
title: Emma

text: There was a strange rumour in Highbury of all the little Perrys being
title: Emma

text: seen with a slice of Mrs. Weston’s wedding-cake in their hands: but Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse would never believe it.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER III
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse was fond of society in his own way. He liked very much to
title: Emma

text: have his friends come and see him; and from various united causes, from
title: Emma

text: his long residence at Hartfield, and his good nature, from his fortune,
title: Emma

text: his house, and his daughter, he could command the visits of his own
title: Emma

text: little circle, in a great measure, as he liked. He had not much
title: Emma

text: intercourse with any families beyond that circle; his horror of late
title: Emma

text: hours, and large dinner-parties, made him unfit for any acquaintance
title: Emma

text: but such as would visit him on his own terms. Fortunately for him,
title: Emma

text: Highbury, including Randalls in the same parish, and Donwell Abbey in
title: Emma

text: the parish adjoining, the seat of Mr. Knightley, comprehended many
title: Emma

text: such. Not unfrequently, through Emma’s persuasion, he had some of the
title: Emma

text: chosen and the best to dine with him: but evening parties were what he
title: Emma

text: preferred; and, unless he fancied himself at any time unequal to
title: Emma

text: company, there was scarcely an evening in the week in which Emma could
title: Emma

text: not make up a card-table for him.
title: Emma

text: Real, long-standing regard brought the Westons and Mr. Knightley; and
title: Emma

text: by Mr. Elton, a young man living alone without liking it, the privilege
title: Emma

text: of exchanging any vacant evening of his own blank solitude for the
title: Emma

text: elegancies and society of Mr. Woodhouse’s drawing-room, and the smiles
title: Emma

text: of his lovely daughter, was in no danger of being thrown away.
title: Emma

text: After these came a second set; among the most come-at-able of whom were
title: Emma

text: Mrs. and Miss Bates, and Mrs. Goddard, three ladies almost always at
title: Emma

text: the service of an invitation from Hartfield, and who were fetched and
title: Emma

text: carried home so often, that Mr. Woodhouse thought it no hardship for
title: Emma

text: either James or the horses. Had it taken place only once a year, it
title: Emma

text: would have been a grievance.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Bates, the widow of a former vicar of Highbury, was a very old
title: Emma

text: lady, almost past every thing but tea and quadrille. She lived with her
title: Emma

text: single daughter in a very small way, and was considered with all the
title: Emma

text: regard and respect which a harmless old lady, under such untoward
title: Emma

text: circumstances, can excite. Her daughter enjoyed a most uncommon degree
title: Emma

text: of popularity for a woman neither young, handsome, rich, nor married.
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates stood in the very worst predicament in the world for having
title: Emma

text: much of the public favour; and she had no intellectual superiority to
title: Emma

text: make atonement to herself, or frighten those who might hate her into
title: Emma

text: outward respect. She had never boasted either beauty or cleverness. Her
title: Emma

text: youth had passed without distinction, and her middle of life was
title: Emma

text: devoted to the care of a failing mother, and the endeavour to make a
title: Emma

text: small income go as far as possible. And yet she was a happy woman, and
title: Emma

text: a woman whom no one named without good-will. It was her own universal
title: Emma

text: good-will and contented temper which worked such wonders. She loved
title: Emma

text: every body, was interested in every body’s happiness, quicksighted to
title: Emma

text: every body’s merits; thought herself a most fortunate creature, and
title: Emma

text: surrounded with blessings in such an excellent mother, and so many good
title: Emma

text: neighbours and friends, and a home that wanted for nothing. The
title: Emma

text: simplicity and cheerfulness of her nature, her contented and grateful
title: Emma

text: spirit, were a recommendation to every body, and a mine of felicity to
title: Emma

text: herself. She was a great talker upon little matters, which exactly
title: Emma

text: suited Mr. Woodhouse, full of trivial communications and harmless
title: Emma

text: gossip.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Goddard was the mistress of a School—not of a seminary, or an
title: Emma

text: establishment, or any thing which professed, in long sentences of
title: Emma

text: refined nonsense, to combine liberal acquirements with elegant
title: Emma

text: morality, upon new principles and new systems—and where young ladies
title: Emma

text: for enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity—but a
title: Emma

text: real, honest, old-fashioned Boarding-school, where a reasonable
title: Emma

text: quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price, and where
title: Emma

text: girls might be sent to be out of the way, and scramble themselves into
title: Emma

text: a little education, without any danger of coming back prodigies. Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Goddard’s school was in high repute—and very deservedly; for Highbury
title: Emma

text: was reckoned a particularly healthy spot: she had an ample house and
title: Emma

text: garden, gave the children plenty of wholesome food, let them run about
title: Emma

text: a great deal in the summer, and in winter dressed their chilblains with
title: Emma

text: her own hands. It was no wonder that a train of twenty young couple now
title: Emma

text: walked after her to church. She was a plain, motherly kind of woman,
title: Emma

text: who had worked hard in her youth, and now thought herself entitled to
title: Emma

text: the occasional holiday of a tea-visit; and having formerly owed much to
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse’s kindness, felt his particular claim on her to leave her
title: Emma

text: neat parlour, hung round with fancy-work, whenever she could, and win
title: Emma

text: or lose a few sixpences by his fireside.
title: Emma

text: These were the ladies whom Emma found herself very frequently able to
title: Emma

text: collect; and happy was she, for her father’s sake, in the power;
title: Emma

text: though, as far as she was herself concerned, it was no remedy for the
title: Emma

text: absence of Mrs. Weston. She was delighted to see her father look
title: Emma

text: comfortable, and very much pleased with herself for contriving things
title: Emma

text: so well; but the quiet prosings of three such women made her feel that
title: Emma

text: every evening so spent was indeed one of the long evenings she had
title: Emma

text: fearfully anticipated.
title: Emma

text: As she sat one morning, looking forward to exactly such a close of the
title: Emma

text: present day, a note was brought from Mrs. Goddard, requesting, in most
title: Emma

text: respectful terms, to be allowed to bring Miss Smith with her; a most
title: Emma

text: welcome request: for Miss Smith was a girl of seventeen, whom Emma knew
title: Emma

text: very well by sight, and had long felt an interest in, on account of her
title: Emma

text: beauty. A very gracious invitation was returned, and the evening no
title: Emma

text: longer dreaded by the fair mistress of the mansion.
title: Emma

text: Harriet Smith was the natural daughter of somebody. Somebody had placed
title: Emma

text: her, several years back, at Mrs. Goddard’s school, and somebody had
title: Emma

text: lately raised her from the condition of scholar to that of
title: Emma

text: parlour-boarder. This was all that was generally known of her history.
title: Emma

text: She had no visible friends but what had been acquired at Highbury, and
title: Emma

text: was now just returned from a long visit in the country to some young
title: Emma

text: ladies who had been at school there with her.
title: Emma

text: She was a very pretty girl, and her beauty happened to be of a sort
title: Emma

text: which Emma particularly admired. She was short, plump, and fair, with a
title: Emma

text: fine bloom, blue eyes, light hair, regular features, and a look of
title: Emma

text: great sweetness, and, before the end of the evening, Emma was as much
title: Emma

text: pleased with her manners as her person, and quite determined to
title: Emma

text: continue the acquaintance.
title: Emma

text: She was not struck by any thing remarkably clever in Miss Smith’s
title: Emma

text: conversation, but she found her altogether very engaging—not
title: Emma

text: inconveniently shy, not unwilling to talk—and yet so far from pushing,
title: Emma

text: shewing so proper and becoming a deference, seeming so pleasantly
title: Emma

text: grateful for being admitted to Hartfield, and so artlessly impressed by
title: Emma

text: the appearance of every thing in so superior a style to what she had
title: Emma

text: been used to, that she must have good sense, and deserve encouragement.
title: Emma

text: Encouragement should be given. Those soft blue eyes, and all those
title: Emma

text: natural graces, should not be wasted on the inferior society of
title: Emma

text: Highbury and its connexions. The acquaintance she had already formed
title: Emma

text: were unworthy of her. The friends from whom she had just parted, though
title: Emma

text: very good sort of people, must be doing her harm. They were a family of
title: Emma

text: the name of Martin, whom Emma well knew by character, as renting a
title: Emma

text: large farm of Mr. Knightley, and residing in the parish of Donwell—very
title: Emma

text: creditably, she believed—she knew Mr. Knightley thought highly of
title: Emma

text: them—but they must be coarse and unpolished, and very unfit to be the
title: Emma

text: intimates of a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and
title: Emma

text: elegance to be quite perfect. _She_ would notice her; she would improve
title: Emma

text: her; she would detach her from her bad acquaintance, and introduce her
title: Emma

text: into good society; she would form her opinions and her manners. It
title: Emma

text: would be an interesting, and certainly a very kind undertaking; highly
title: Emma

text: becoming her own situation in life, her leisure, and powers.
title: Emma

text: She was so busy in admiring those soft blue eyes, in talking and
title: Emma

text: listening, and forming all these schemes in the in-betweens, that the
title: Emma

text: evening flew away at a very unusual rate; and the supper-table, which
title: Emma

text: always closed such parties, and for which she had been used to sit and
title: Emma

text: watch the due time, was all set out and ready, and moved forwards to
title: Emma

text: the fire, before she was aware. With an alacrity beyond the common
title: Emma

text: impulse of a spirit which yet was never indifferent to the credit of
title: Emma

text: doing every thing well and attentively, with the real good-will of a
title: Emma

text: mind delighted with its own ideas, did she then do all the honours of
title: Emma

text: the meal, and help and recommend the minced chicken and scalloped
title: Emma

text: oysters, with an urgency which she knew would be acceptable to the
title: Emma

text: early hours and civil scruples of their guests.
title: Emma

text: Upon such occasions poor Mr. Woodhouse’s feelings were in sad warfare.
title: Emma

text: He loved to have the cloth laid, because it had been the fashion of his
title: Emma

text: youth, but his conviction of suppers being very unwholesome made him
title: Emma

text: rather sorry to see any thing put on it; and while his hospitality
title: Emma

text: would have welcomed his visitors to every thing, his care for their
title: Emma

text: health made him grieve that they would eat.
title: Emma

text: Such another small basin of thin gruel as his own was all that he
title: Emma

text: could, with thorough self-approbation, recommend; though he might
title: Emma

text: constrain himself, while the ladies were comfortably clearing the nicer
title: Emma

text: things, to say:
title: Emma

text: “Mrs. Bates, let me propose your venturing on one of these eggs. An egg
title: Emma

text: boiled very soft is not unwholesome. Serle understands boiling an egg
title: Emma

text: better than any body. I would not recommend an egg boiled by any body
title: Emma

text: else; but you need not be afraid, they are very small, you see—one of
title: Emma

text: our small eggs will not hurt you. Miss Bates, let Emma help you to a
title: Emma

text: _little_ bit of tart—a _very_ little bit. Ours are all apple-tarts. You
title: Emma

text: need not be afraid of unwholesome preserves here. I do not advise the
title: Emma

text: custard. Mrs. Goddard, what say you to _half_ a glass of wine? A
title: Emma

text: _small_ half-glass, put into a tumbler of water? I do not think it
title: Emma

text: could disagree with you.”
title: Emma

text: Emma allowed her father to talk—but supplied her visitors in a much
title: Emma

text: more satisfactory style, and on the present evening had particular
title: Emma

text: pleasure in sending them away happy. The happiness of Miss Smith was
title: Emma

text: quite equal to her intentions. Miss Woodhouse was so great a personage
title: Emma

text: in Highbury, that the prospect of the introduction had given as much
title: Emma

text: panic as pleasure; but the humble, grateful little girl went off with
title: Emma

text: highly gratified feelings, delighted with the affability with which
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse had treated her all the evening, and actually shaken
title: Emma

text: hands with her at last!
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Emma

text: Harriet Smith’s intimacy at Hartfield was soon a settled thing. Quick
title: Emma

text: and decided in her ways, Emma lost no time in inviting, encouraging,
title: Emma

text: and telling her to come very often; and as their acquaintance
title: Emma

text: increased, so did their satisfaction in each other. As a walking
title: Emma

text: companion, Emma had very early foreseen how useful she might find her.
title: Emma

text: In that respect Mrs. Weston’s loss had been important. Her father never
title: Emma

text: went beyond the shrubbery, where two divisions of the ground sufficed
title: Emma

text: him for his long walk, or his short, as the year varied; and since Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston’s marriage her exercise had been too much confined. She had
title: Emma

text: ventured once alone to Randalls, but it was not pleasant; and a Harriet
title: Emma

text: Smith, therefore, one whom she could summon at any time to a walk,
title: Emma

text: would be a valuable addition to her privileges. But in every respect,
title: Emma

text: as she saw more of her, she approved her, and was confirmed in all her
title: Emma

text: kind designs.
title: Emma

text: Harriet certainly was not clever, but she had a sweet, docile, grateful
title: Emma

text: disposition, was totally free from conceit, and only desiring to be
title: Emma

text: guided by any one she looked up to. Her early attachment to herself was
title: Emma

text: very amiable; and her inclination for good company, and power of
title: Emma

text: appreciating what was elegant and clever, shewed that there was no want
title: Emma

text: of taste, though strength of understanding must not be expected.
title: Emma

text: Altogether she was quite convinced of Harriet Smith’s being exactly the
title: Emma

text: young friend she wanted—exactly the something which her home required.
title: Emma

text: Such a friend as Mrs. Weston was out of the question. Two such could
title: Emma

text: never be granted. Two such she did not want. It was quite a different
title: Emma

text: sort of thing, a sentiment distinct and independent. Mrs. Weston was
title: Emma

text: the object of a regard which had its basis in gratitude and esteem.
title: Emma

text: Harriet would be loved as one to whom she could be useful. For Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston there was nothing to be done; for Harriet every thing.
title: Emma

text: Her first attempts at usefulness were in an endeavour to find out who
title: Emma

text: were the parents, but Harriet could not tell. She was ready to tell
title: Emma

text: every thing in her power, but on this subject questions were vain. Emma
title: Emma

text: was obliged to fancy what she liked—but she could never believe that in
title: Emma

text: the same situation _she_ should not have discovered the truth. Harriet
title: Emma

text: had no penetration. She had been satisfied to hear and believe just
title: Emma

text: what Mrs. Goddard chose to tell her; and looked no farther.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Goddard, and the teachers, and the girls and the affairs of the
title: Emma

text: school in general, formed naturally a great part of the
title: Emma

text: conversation—and but for her acquaintance with the Martins of
title: Emma

text: Abbey-Mill Farm, it must have been the whole. But the Martins occupied
title: Emma

text: her thoughts a good deal; she had spent two very happy months with
title: Emma

text: them, and now loved to talk of the pleasures of her visit, and describe
title: Emma

text: the many comforts and wonders of the place. Emma encouraged her
title: Emma

text: talkativeness—amused by such a picture of another set of beings, and
title: Emma

text: enjoying the youthful simplicity which could speak with so much
title: Emma

text: exultation of Mrs. Martin’s having “_two_ parlours, two very good
title: Emma

text: parlours, indeed; one of them quite as large as Mrs. Goddard’s
title: Emma

text: drawing-room; and of her having an upper maid who had lived
title: Emma

text: five-and-twenty years with her; and of their having eight cows, two of
title: Emma

text: them Alderneys, and one a little Welch cow, a very pretty little Welch
title: Emma

text: cow indeed; and of Mrs. Martin’s saying as she was so fond of it, it
title: Emma

text: should be called _her_ cow; and of their having a very handsome
title: Emma

text: summer-house in their garden, where some day next year they were all to
title: Emma

text: drink tea:—a very handsome summer-house, large enough to hold a dozen
title: Emma

text: people.”
title: Emma

text: For some time she was amused, without thinking beyond the immediate
title: Emma

text: cause; but as she came to understand the family better, other feelings
title: Emma

text: arose. She had taken up a wrong idea, fancying it was a mother and
title: Emma

text: daughter, a son and son’s wife, who all lived together; but when it
title: Emma

text: appeared that the Mr. Martin, who bore a part in the narrative, and was
title: Emma

text: always mentioned with approbation for his great good-nature in doing
title: Emma

text: something or other, was a single man; that there was no young Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Martin, no wife in the case; she did suspect danger to her poor little
title: Emma

text: friend from all this hospitality and kindness, and that, if she were
title: Emma

text: not taken care of, she might be required to sink herself forever.
title: Emma

text: With this inspiriting notion, her questions increased in number and
title: Emma

text: meaning; and she particularly led Harriet to talk more of Mr. Martin,
title: Emma

text: and there was evidently no dislike to it. Harriet was very ready to
title: Emma

text: speak of the share he had had in their moonlight walks and merry
title: Emma

text: evening games; and dwelt a good deal upon his being so very
title: Emma

text: good-humoured and obliging. He had gone three miles round one day in
title: Emma

text: order to bring her some walnuts, because she had said how fond she was
title: Emma

text: of them, and in every thing else he was so very obliging. He had his
title: Emma

text: shepherd’s son into the parlour one night on purpose to sing to her.
title: Emma

text: She was very fond of singing. He could sing a little himself. She
title: Emma

text: believed he was very clever, and understood every thing. He had a very
title: Emma

text: fine flock, and, while she was with them, he had been bid more for his
title: Emma

text: wool than any body in the country. She believed every body spoke well
title: Emma

text: of him. His mother and sisters were very fond of him. Mrs. Martin had
title: Emma

text: told her one day (and there was a blush as she said it,) that it was
title: Emma

text: impossible for any body to be a better son, and therefore she was sure,
title: Emma

text: whenever he married, he would make a good husband. Not that she
title: Emma

text: _wanted_ him to marry. She was in no hurry at all.
title: Emma

text: “Well done, Mrs. Martin!” thought Emma. “You know what you are about.”
title: Emma

text: “And when she had come away, Mrs. Martin was so very kind as to send
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Goddard a beautiful goose—the finest goose Mrs. Goddard had ever
title: Emma

text: seen. Mrs. Goddard had dressed it on a Sunday, and asked all the three
title: Emma

text: teachers, Miss Nash, and Miss Prince, and Miss Richardson, to sup with
title: Emma

text: her.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Martin, I suppose, is not a man of information beyond the line of
title: Emma

text: his own business? He does not read?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh yes!—that is, no—I do not know—but I believe he has read a good
title: Emma

text: deal—but not what you would think any thing of. He reads the
title: Emma

text: Agricultural Reports, and some other books that lay in one of the
title: Emma

text: window seats—but he reads all _them_ to himself. But sometimes of an
title: Emma

text: evening, before we went to cards, he would read something aloud out of
title: Emma

text: the Elegant Extracts, very entertaining. And I know he has read the
title: Emma

text: Vicar of Wakefield. He never read the Romance of the Forest, nor The
title: Emma

text: Children of the Abbey. He had never heard of such books before I
title: Emma

text: mentioned them, but he is determined to get them now as soon as ever he
title: Emma

text: can.”
title: Emma

text: The next question was—
title: Emma

text: “What sort of looking man is Mr. Martin?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! not handsome—not at all handsome. I thought him very plain at
title: Emma

text: first, but I do not think him so plain now. One does not, you know,
title: Emma

text: after a time. But did you never see him? He is in Highbury every now
title: Emma

text: and then, and he is sure to ride through every week in his way to
title: Emma

text: Kingston. He has passed you very often.”
title: Emma

text: “That may be, and I may have seen him fifty times, but without having
title: Emma

text: any idea of his name. A young farmer, whether on horseback or on foot,
title: Emma

text: is the very last sort of person to raise my curiosity. The yeomanry are
title: Emma

text: precisely the order of people with whom I feel I can have nothing to
title: Emma

text: do. A degree or two lower, and a creditable appearance might interest
title: Emma

text: me; I might hope to be useful to their families in some way or other.
title: Emma

text: But a farmer can need none of my help, and is, therefore, in one sense,
title: Emma

text: as much above my notice as in every other he is below it.”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure. Oh yes! It is not likely you should ever have observed
title: Emma

text: him; but he knows you very well indeed—I mean by sight.”
title: Emma

text: “I have no doubt of his being a very respectable young man. I know,
title: Emma

text: indeed, that he is so, and, as such, wish him well. What do you imagine
title: Emma

text: his age to be?”
title: Emma

text: “He was four-and-twenty the 8th of last June, and my birthday is the
title: Emma

text: 23rd just a fortnight and a day’s difference—which is very odd.”
title: Emma

text: “Only four-and-twenty. That is too young to settle. His mother is
title: Emma

text: perfectly right not to be in a hurry. They seem very comfortable as
title: Emma

text: they are, and if she were to take any pains to marry him, she would
title: Emma

text: probably repent it. Six years hence, if he could meet with a good sort
title: Emma

text: of young woman in the same rank as his own, with a little money, it
title: Emma

text: might be very desirable.”
title: Emma

text: “Six years hence! Dear Miss Woodhouse, he would be thirty years old!”
title: Emma

text: “Well, and that is as early as most men can afford to marry, who are
title: Emma

text: not born to an independence. Mr. Martin, I imagine, has his fortune
title: Emma

text: entirely to make—cannot be at all beforehand with the world. Whatever
title: Emma

text: money he might come into when his father died, whatever his share of
title: Emma

text: the family property, it is, I dare say, all afloat, all employed in his
title: Emma

text: stock, and so forth; and though, with diligence and good luck, he may
title: Emma

text: be rich in time, it is next to impossible that he should have realised
title: Emma

text: any thing yet.”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure, so it is. But they live very comfortably. They have no
title: Emma

text: indoors man, else they do not want for any thing; and Mrs. Martin talks
title: Emma

text: of taking a boy another year.”
title: Emma

text: “I wish you may not get into a scrape, Harriet, whenever he does
title: Emma

text: marry;—I mean, as to being acquainted with his wife—for though his
title: Emma

text: sisters, from a superior education, are not to be altogether objected
title: Emma

text: to, it does not follow that he might marry any body at all fit for you
title: Emma

text: to notice. The misfortune of your birth ought to make you particularly
title: Emma

text: careful as to your associates. There can be no doubt of your being a
title: Emma

text: gentleman’s daughter, and you must support your claim to that station
title: Emma

text: by every thing within your own power, or there will be plenty of people
title: Emma

text: who would take pleasure in degrading you.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, to be sure, I suppose there are. But while I visit at Hartfield,
title: Emma

text: and you are so kind to me, Miss Woodhouse, I am not afraid of what any
title: Emma

text: body can do.”
title: Emma

text: “You understand the force of influence pretty well, Harriet; but I
title: Emma

text: would have you so firmly established in good society, as to be
title: Emma

text: independent even of Hartfield and Miss Woodhouse. I want to see you
title: Emma

text: permanently well connected, and to that end it will be advisable to
title: Emma

text: have as few odd acquaintance as may be; and, therefore, I say that if
title: Emma

text: you should still be in this country when Mr. Martin marries, I wish you
title: Emma

text: may not be drawn in by your intimacy with the sisters, to be acquainted
title: Emma

text: with the wife, who will probably be some mere farmer’s daughter,
title: Emma

text: without education.”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure. Yes. Not that I think Mr. Martin would ever marry any body
title: Emma

text: but what had had some education—and been very well brought up. However,
title: Emma

text: I do not mean to set up my opinion against yours—and I am sure I shall
title: Emma

text: not wish for the acquaintance of his wife. I shall always have a great
title: Emma

text: regard for the Miss Martins, especially Elizabeth, and should be very
title: Emma

text: sorry to give them up, for they are quite as well educated as me. But
title: Emma

text: if he marries a very ignorant, vulgar woman, certainly I had better not
title: Emma

text: visit her, if I can help it.”
title: Emma

text: Emma watched her through the fluctuations of this speech, and saw no
title: Emma

text: alarming symptoms of love. The young man had been the first admirer,
title: Emma

text: but she trusted there was no other hold, and that there would be no
title: Emma

text: serious difficulty, on Harriet’s side, to oppose any friendly
title: Emma

text: arrangement of her own.
title: Emma

text: They met Mr. Martin the very next day, as they were walking on the
title: Emma

text: Donwell road. He was on foot, and after looking very respectfully at
title: Emma

text: her, looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at her companion. Emma was
title: Emma

text: not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey; and walking a few
title: Emma

text: yards forward, while they talked together, soon made her quick eye
title: Emma

text: sufficiently acquainted with Mr. Robert Martin. His appearance was very
title: Emma

text: neat, and he looked like a sensible young man, but his person had no
title: Emma

text: other advantage; and when he came to be contrasted with gentlemen, she
title: Emma

text: thought he must lose all the ground he had gained in Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: inclination. Harriet was not insensible of manner; she had voluntarily
title: Emma

text: noticed her father’s gentleness with admiration as well as wonder. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Martin looked as if he did not know what manner was.
title: Emma

text: They remained but a few minutes together, as Miss Woodhouse must not be
title: Emma

text: kept waiting; and Harriet then came running to her with a smiling face,
title: Emma

text: and in a flutter of spirits, which Miss Woodhouse hoped very soon to
title: Emma

text: compose.
title: Emma

text: “Only think of our happening to meet him!—How very odd! It was quite a
title: Emma

text: chance, he said, that he had not gone round by Randalls. He did not
title: Emma

text: think we ever walked this road. He thought we walked towards Randalls
title: Emma

text: most days. He has not been able to get the Romance of the Forest yet.
title: Emma

text: He was so busy the last time he was at Kingston that he quite forgot
title: Emma

text: it, but he goes again to-morrow. So very odd we should happen to meet!
title: Emma

text: Well, Miss Woodhouse, is he like what you expected? What do you think
title: Emma

text: of him? Do you think him so very plain?”
title: Emma

text: “He is very plain, undoubtedly—remarkably plain:—but that is nothing
title: Emma

text: compared with his entire want of gentility. I had no right to expect
title: Emma

text: much, and I did not expect much; but I had no idea that he could be so
title: Emma

text: very clownish, so totally without air. I had imagined him, I confess, a
title: Emma

text: degree or two nearer gentility.”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure,” said Harriet, in a mortified voice, “he is not so genteel
title: Emma

text: as real gentlemen.”
title: Emma

text: “I think, Harriet, since your acquaintance with us, you have been
title: Emma

text: repeatedly in the company of some such very real gentlemen, that you
title: Emma

text: must yourself be struck with the difference in Mr. Martin. At
title: Emma

text: Hartfield, you have had very good specimens of well educated, well bred
title: Emma

text: men. I should be surprized if, after seeing them, you could be in
title: Emma

text: company with Mr. Martin again without perceiving him to be a very
title: Emma

text: inferior creature—and rather wondering at yourself for having ever
title: Emma

text: thought him at all agreeable before. Do not you begin to feel that now?
title: Emma

text: Were not you struck? I am sure you must have been struck by his awkward
title: Emma

text: look and abrupt manner, and the uncouthness of a voice which I heard to
title: Emma

text: be wholly unmodulated as I stood here.”
title: Emma

text: “Certainly, he is not like Mr. Knightley. He has not such a fine air
title: Emma

text: and way of walking as Mr. Knightley. I see the difference plain enough.
title: Emma

text: But Mr. Knightley is so very fine a man!”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Knightley’s air is so remarkably good that it is not fair to
title: Emma

text: compare Mr. Martin with _him_. You might not see one in a hundred with
title: Emma

text: _gentleman_ so plainly written as in Mr. Knightley. But he is not the
title: Emma

text: only gentleman you have been lately used to. What say you to Mr. Weston
title: Emma

text: and Mr. Elton? Compare Mr. Martin with either of _them_. Compare their
title: Emma

text: manner of carrying themselves; of walking; of speaking; of being
title: Emma

text: silent. You must see the difference.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh yes!—there is a great difference. But Mr. Weston is almost an old
title: Emma

text: man. Mr. Weston must be between forty and fifty.”
title: Emma

text: “Which makes his good manners the more valuable. The older a person
title: Emma

text: grows, Harriet, the more important it is that their manners should not
title: Emma

text: be bad; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness, or coarseness, or
title: Emma

text: awkwardness becomes. What is passable in youth is detestable in later
title: Emma

text: age. Mr. Martin is now awkward and abrupt; what will he be at Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston’s time of life?”
title: Emma

text: “There is no saying, indeed,” replied Harriet rather solemnly.
title: Emma

text: “But there may be pretty good guessing. He will be a completely gross,
title: Emma

text: vulgar farmer, totally inattentive to appearances, and thinking of
title: Emma

text: nothing but profit and loss.”
title: Emma

text: “Will he, indeed? That will be very bad.”
title: Emma

text: “How much his business engrosses him already is very plain from the
title: Emma

text: circumstance of his forgetting to inquire for the book you recommended.
title: Emma

text: He was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing
title: Emma

text: else—which is just as it should be, for a thriving man. What has he to
title: Emma

text: do with books? And I have no doubt that he _will_ thrive, and be a very
title: Emma

text: rich man in time—and his being illiterate and coarse need not disturb
title: Emma

text: “I wonder he did not remember the book”—was all Harriet’s answer, and
title: Emma

text: spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which Emma thought might be
title: Emma

text: safely left to itself. She, therefore, said no more for some time. Her
title: Emma

text: next beginning was,
title: Emma

text: “In one respect, perhaps, Mr. Elton’s manners are superior to Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley’s or Mr. Weston’s. They have more gentleness. They might be
title: Emma

text: more safely held up as a pattern. There is an openness, a quickness,
title: Emma

text: almost a bluntness in Mr. Weston, which every body likes in _him_,
title: Emma

text: because there is so much good-humour with it—but that would not do to
title: Emma

text: be copied. Neither would Mr. Knightley’s downright, decided, commanding
title: Emma

text: sort of manner, though it suits _him_ very well; his figure, and look,
title: Emma

text: and situation in life seem to allow it; but if any young man were to
title: Emma

text: set about copying him, he would not be sufferable. On the contrary, I
title: Emma

text: think a young man might be very safely recommended to take Mr. Elton as
title: Emma

text: a model. Mr. Elton is good-humoured, cheerful, obliging, and gentle. He
title: Emma

text: seems to me to be grown particularly gentle of late. I do not know
title: Emma

text: whether he has any design of ingratiating himself with either of us,
title: Emma

text: Harriet, by additional softness, but it strikes me that his manners are
title: Emma

text: softer than they used to be. If he means any thing, it must be to
title: Emma

text: please you. Did not I tell you what he said of you the other day?”
title: Emma

text: She then repeated some warm personal praise which she had drawn from
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton, and now did full justice to; and Harriet blushed and smiled,
title: Emma

text: and said she had always thought Mr. Elton very agreeable.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton was the very person fixed on by Emma for driving the young
title: Emma

text: farmer out of Harriet’s head. She thought it would be an excellent
title: Emma

text: match; and only too palpably desirable, natural, and probable, for her
title: Emma

text: to have much merit in planning it. She feared it was what every body
title: Emma

text: else must think of and predict. It was not likely, however, that any
title: Emma

text: body should have equalled her in the date of the plan, as it had
title: Emma

text: entered her brain during the very first evening of Harriet’s coming to
title: Emma

text: Hartfield. The longer she considered it, the greater was her sense of
title: Emma

text: its expediency. Mr. Elton’s situation was most suitable, quite the
title: Emma

text: gentleman himself, and without low connexions; at the same time, not of
title: Emma

text: any family that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of Harriet.
title: Emma

text: He had a comfortable home for her, and Emma imagined a very sufficient
title: Emma

text: income; for though the vicarage of Highbury was not large, he was known
title: Emma

text: to have some independent property; and she thought very highly of him
title: Emma

text: as a good-humoured, well-meaning, respectable young man, without any
title: Emma

text: deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of the world.
title: Emma

text: She had already satisfied herself that he thought Harriet a beautiful
title: Emma

text: girl, which she trusted, with such frequent meetings at Hartfield, was
title: Emma

text: foundation enough on his side; and on Harriet’s there could be little
title: Emma

text: doubt that the idea of being preferred by him would have all the usual
title: Emma

text: weight and efficacy. And he was really a very pleasing young man, a
title: Emma

text: young man whom any woman not fastidious might like. He was reckoned
title: Emma

text: very handsome; his person much admired in general, though not by her,
title: Emma

text: there being a want of elegance of feature which she could not dispense
title: Emma

text: with:—but the girl who could be gratified by a Robert Martin’s riding
title: Emma

text: about the country to get walnuts for her might very well be conquered
title: Emma

text: by Mr. Elton’s admiration.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER V
title: Emma

text: “I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston,” said Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley, “of this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but
title: Emma

text: I think it a bad thing.”
title: Emma

text: “A bad thing! Do you really think it a bad thing?—why so?”
title: Emma

text: “I think they will neither of them do the other any good.”
title: Emma

text: “You surprize me! Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her with
title: Emma

text: a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good. I have
title: Emma

text: been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure. How very
title: Emma

text: differently we feel!—Not think they will do each other any good! This
title: Emma

text: will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels about Emma, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley.”
title: Emma

text: “Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you, knowing
title: Emma

text: Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here, for he
title: Emma

text: thinks exactly as I do on the subject. We were speaking of it only
title: Emma

text: yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma, that there
title: Emma

text: should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case. You
title: Emma

text: are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value of a
title: Emma

text: companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort a
title: Emma

text: woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used to
title: Emma

text: it all her life. I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith. She is
title: Emma

text: not the superior young woman which Emma’s friend ought to be. But on
title: Emma

text: the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed, it will be an
title: Emma

text: inducement to her to read more herself. They will read together. She
title: Emma

text: means it, I know.”
title: Emma

text: “Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve years
title: Emma

text: old. I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at various times
title: Emma

text: of books that she meant to read regularly through—and very good lists
title: Emma

text: they were—very well chosen, and very neatly arranged—sometimes
title: Emma

text: alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule. The list she drew up
title: Emma

text: when only fourteen—I remember thinking it did her judgment so much
title: Emma

text: credit, that I preserved it some time; and I dare say she may have made
title: Emma

text: out a very good list now. But I have done with expecting any course of
title: Emma

text: steady reading from Emma. She will never submit to any thing requiring
title: Emma

text: industry and patience, and a subjection of the fancy to the
title: Emma

text: understanding. Where Miss Taylor failed to stimulate, I may safely
title: Emma

text: affirm that Harriet Smith will do nothing.—You never could persuade her
title: Emma

text: to read half so much as you wished.—You know you could not.”
title: Emma

text: “I dare say,” replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, “that I thought so
title: Emma

text: _then_;—but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma’s omitting
title: Emma

text: to do any thing I wished.”
title: Emma

text: “There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as _that_,”—said
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done. “But I,”
title: Emma

text: he soon added, “who have had no such charm thrown over my senses, must
title: Emma

text: still see, hear, and remember. Emma is spoiled by being the cleverest
title: Emma

text: of her family. At ten years old, she had the misfortune of being able
title: Emma

text: to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen. She was
title: Emma

text: always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident. And ever since
title: Emma

text: she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house and of you all. In
title: Emma

text: her mother she lost the only person able to cope with her. She inherits
title: Emma

text: her mother’s talents, and must have been under subjection to her.”
title: Emma

text: “I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on _your_
title: Emma

text: recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse’s family and wanted another
title: Emma

text: situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for me to
title: Emma

text: any body. I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said he, smiling. “You are better placed _here_; very fit for a
title: Emma

text: wife, but not at all for a governess. But you were preparing yourself
title: Emma

text: to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield. You might
title: Emma

text: not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would seem to
title: Emma

text: promise; but you were receiving a very good education from _her_, on
title: Emma

text: the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will, and
title: Emma

text: doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend him a
title: Emma

text: wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor.”
title: Emma

text: “Thank you. There will be very little merit in making a good wife to
title: Emma

text: such a man as Mr. Weston.”
title: Emma

text: “Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away, and
title: Emma

text: that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing to be borne.
title: Emma
