text: We will not despair, however. Weston may grow cross from the wantonness
title: Emma

text: of comfort, or his son may plague him.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope not _that_.—It is not likely. No, Mr. Knightley, do not
title: Emma

text: foretell vexation from that quarter.”
title: Emma

text: “Not I, indeed. I only name possibilities. I do not pretend to Emma’s
title: Emma

text: genius for foretelling and guessing. I hope, with all my heart, the
title: Emma

text: young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.—But
title: Emma

text: Harriet Smith—I have not half done about Harriet Smith. I think her the
title: Emma

text: very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have. She knows
title: Emma

text: nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing. She is a
title: Emma

text: flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse, because undesigned.
title: Emma

text: Her ignorance is hourly flattery. How can Emma imagine she has any
title: Emma

text: thing to learn herself, while Harriet is presenting such a delightful
title: Emma

text: inferiority? And as for Harriet, I will venture to say that _she_
title: Emma

text: cannot gain by the acquaintance. Hartfield will only put her out of
title: Emma

text: conceit with all the other places she belongs to. She will grow just
title: Emma

text: refined enough to be uncomfortable with those among whom birth and
title: Emma

text: circumstances have placed her home. I am much mistaken if Emma’s
title: Emma

text: doctrines give any strength of mind, or tend at all to make a girl
title: Emma

text: adapt herself rationally to the varieties of her situation in
title: Emma

text: life.—They only give a little polish.”
title: Emma

text: “I either depend more upon Emma’s good sense than you do, or am more
title: Emma

text: anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance.
title: Emma

text: How well she looked last night!”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you? Very
title: Emma

text: well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma’s being pretty.”
title: Emma

text: “Pretty! say beautiful rather. Can you imagine any thing nearer perfect
title: Emma

text: beauty than Emma altogether—face and figure?”
title: Emma

text: “I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have seldom
title: Emma

text: seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers. But I am a partial
title: Emma

text: old friend.”
title: Emma

text: “Such an eye!—the true hazle eye—and so brilliant! regular features,
title: Emma

text: open countenance, with a complexion! oh! what a bloom of full health,
title: Emma

text: and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure!
title: Emma

text: There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head, her
title: Emma

text: glance. One hears sometimes of a child being ‘the picture of health;’
title: Emma

text: now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete picture of
title: Emma

text: grown-up health. She is loveliness itself. Mr. Knightley, is not she?”
title: Emma

text: “I have not a fault to find with her person,” he replied. “I think her
title: Emma

text: all you describe. I love to look at her; and I will add this praise,
title: Emma

text: that I do not think her personally vain. Considering how very handsome

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Very well; I will not plague you any more. Emma shall be an angel, and
title: Emma

text: I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John and
title: Emma

text: Isabella. John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore not a blind
title: Emma

text: affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does; except when he is not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind;
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: possible good can arise from Harriet Smith’s intimacy being made a
title: Emma

text: matter of much discussion among you. Pray excuse me; but supposing any
title: Emma

text: little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy, it cannot be
title: Emma

text: expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father, who perfectly
title: Emma

text: approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it, so long as it is a
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: give advice, that you cannot be surprized, Mr. Knightley, at this
title: Emma

text: little remains of office.”
title: Emma

text: “Not at all,” cried he; “I am much obliged to you for it. It is very
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Mrs. John Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy about
title: Emma

text: her sister.”
title: Emma

text: “Be satisfied,” said he, “I will not raise any outcry. I will keep my
title: Emma

text: ill-humour to myself. I have a very sincere interest in Emma. Isabella
title: Emma

text: does not seem more my sister; has never excited a greater interest;
title: Emma

text: perhaps hardly so great. There is an anxiety, a curiosity in what one
title: Emma

text: feels for Emma. I wonder what will become of her!”
title: Emma

text: “So do I,” said Mrs. Weston gently, “very much.”
title: Emma

text: “She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just
title: Emma

text: nothing at all. But I have no idea that she has yet ever seen a man she
title: Emma

text: cared for. It would not be a bad thing for her to be very much in love
title: Emma

text: with a proper object. I should like to see Emma in love, and in some
title: Emma

text: doubt of a return; it would do her good. But there is nobody hereabouts
title: Emma

text: to attach her; and she goes so seldom from home.”
title: Emma

text: “There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break her
title: Emma

text: resolution at present,” said Mrs. Weston, “as can well be; and while
title: Emma

text: she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be forming any
title: Emma

text: attachment which would be creating such difficulties on poor Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s account. I do not recommend matrimony at present to Emma,
title: Emma

text: though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Emma

text: Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet’s fancy a proper
title: Emma

text: direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity to a very good
title: Emma

text: purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible than before of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s being a remarkably handsome man, with most agreeable manners;
title: Emma

text: and as she had no hesitation in following up the assurance of his
title: Emma

text: admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon pretty confident of
title: Emma

text: creating as much liking on Harriet’s side, as there could be any
title: Emma

text: occasion for. She was quite convinced of Mr. Elton’s being in the
title: Emma

text: fairest way of falling in love, if not in love already. She had no
title: Emma

text: scruple with regard to him. He talked of Harriet, and praised her so
title: Emma

text: warmly, that she could not suppose any thing wanting which a little
title: Emma

text: time would not add. His perception of the striking improvement of
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s manner, since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of
title: Emma

text: the least agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
title: Emma

text: “You have given Miss Smith all that she required,” said he; “you have
title: Emma

text: made her graceful and easy. She was a beautiful creature when she came
title: Emma

text: to you, but, in my opinion, the attractions you have added are
title: Emma

text: infinitely superior to what she received from nature.”
title: Emma

text: “I am glad you think I have been useful to her; but Harriet only wanted
title: Emma

text: drawing out, and receiving a few, very few hints. She had all the
title: Emma

text: natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness in herself. I have
title: Emma

text: done very little.”
title: Emma

text: “If it were admissible to contradict a lady,” said the gallant Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton—
title: Emma

text: “I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character, have
title: Emma

text: taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her way before.”
title: Emma

text: “Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me. So much superadded
title: Emma

text: decision of character! Skilful has been the hand!”
title: Emma

text: “Great has been the pleasure, I am sure. I never met with a disposition
title: Emma

text: more truly amiable.”
title: Emma

text: “I have no doubt of it.” And it was spoken with a sort of sighing
title: Emma

text: animation, which had a vast deal of the lover. She was not less pleased
title: Emma

text: another day with the manner in which he seconded a sudden wish of hers,
title: Emma

text: to have Harriet’s picture.
title: Emma

text: “Did you ever have your likeness taken, Harriet?” said she: “did you
title: Emma

text: ever sit for your picture?”
title: Emma

text: Harriet was on the point of leaving the room, and only stopt to say,
title: Emma

text: with a very interesting naïveté,
title: Emma

text: “Oh! dear, no, never.”
title: Emma

text: No sooner was she out of sight, than Emma exclaimed,
title: Emma

text: “What an exquisite possession a good picture of her would be! I would
title: Emma

text: give any money for it. I almost long to attempt her likeness myself.
title: Emma

text: You do not know it I dare say, but two or three years ago I had a great
title: Emma

text: passion for taking likenesses, and attempted several of my friends, and
title: Emma

text: was thought to have a tolerable eye in general. But from one cause or
title: Emma

text: another, I gave it up in disgust. But really, I could almost venture,
title: Emma

text: if Harriet would sit to me. It would be such a delight to have her
title: Emma

text: picture!”
title: Emma

text: “Let me entreat you,” cried Mr. Elton; “it would indeed be a delight!
title: Emma

text: Let me entreat you, Miss Woodhouse, to exercise so charming a talent in
title: Emma

text: favour of your friend. I know what your drawings are. How could you
title: Emma

text: suppose me ignorant? Is not this room rich in specimens of your
title: Emma

text: landscapes and flowers; and has not Mrs. Weston some inimitable
title: Emma

text: figure-pieces in her drawing-room, at Randalls?”
title: Emma

text: Yes, good man!—thought Emma—but what has all that to do with taking
title: Emma

text: likenesses? You know nothing of drawing. Don’t pretend to be in
title: Emma

text: raptures about mine. Keep your raptures for Harriet’s face. “Well, if
title: Emma

text: you give me such kind encouragement, Mr. Elton, I believe I shall try
title: Emma

text: what I can do. Harriet’s features are very delicate, which makes a
title: Emma

text: likeness difficult; and yet there is a peculiarity in the shape of the
title: Emma

text: eye and the lines about the mouth which one ought to catch.”
title: Emma

text: “Exactly so—The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth—I have
title: Emma

text: not a doubt of your success. Pray, pray attempt it. As you will do it,
title: Emma

text: it will indeed, to use your own words, be an exquisite possession.”
title: Emma

text: “But I am afraid, Mr. Elton, Harriet will not like to sit. She thinks
title: Emma

text: so little of her own beauty. Did not you observe her manner of
title: Emma

text: answering me? How completely it meant, ‘why should my picture be
title: Emma

text: drawn?’”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes, I observed it, I assure you. It was not lost on me. But still
title: Emma

text: I cannot imagine she would not be persuaded.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet was soon back again, and the proposal almost immediately made;
title: Emma

text: and she had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: beginnings were displayed. Miniatures, half-lengths, whole-lengths,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: she would ever submit to. She played and sang;—and drew in almost every
title: Emma

text: style; but steadiness had always been wanting; and in nothing had she
title: Emma

text: approached the degree of excellence which she would have been glad to
title: Emma

text: command, and ought not to have failed of. She was not much deceived as
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: unwilling to have others deceived, or sorry to know her reputation for
title: Emma

text: accomplishment often higher than it deserved.
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: most; her style was spirited; but had there been much less, or had
title: Emma

text: there been ten times more, the delight and admiration of her two
title: Emma

text: companions would have been the same. They were both in ecstasies. A
title: Emma

text: likeness pleases every body; and Miss Woodhouse’s performances must be
title: Emma

text: capital.

text: “No great variety of faces for you,” said Emma. “I had only my own

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Emma

text: The very day of Mr. Elton’s going to London produced a fresh occasion
title: Emma

text: for Emma’s services towards her friend. Harriet had been at Hartfield,
title: Emma

text: as usual, soon after breakfast; and, after a time, had gone home to
title: Emma

text: return again to dinner: she returned, and sooner than had been talked
title: Emma

text: of, and with an agitated, hurried look, announcing something
title: Emma

text: extraordinary to have happened which she was longing to tell. Half a
title: Emma

text: minute brought it all out. She had heard, as soon as she got back to
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Goddard’s, that Mr. Martin had been there an hour before, and
title: Emma

text: finding she was not at home, nor particularly expected, had left a
title: Emma

text: little parcel for her from one of his sisters, and gone away; and on
title: Emma

text: opening this parcel, she had actually found, besides the two songs
title: Emma

text: which she had lent Elizabeth to copy, a letter to herself; and this
title: Emma

text: letter was from him, from Mr. Martin, and contained a direct proposal
title: Emma

text: of marriage. “Who could have thought it? She was so surprized she did
title: Emma

text: not know what to do. Yes, quite a proposal of marriage; and a very good
title: Emma

text: letter, at least she thought so. And he wrote as if he really loved her
title: Emma

text: very much—but she did not know—and so, she was come as fast as she
title: Emma

text: could to ask Miss Woodhouse what she should do.—” Emma was half-ashamed
title: Emma

text: of her friend for seeming so pleased and so doubtful.
title: Emma

text: “Upon my word,” she cried, “the young man is determined not to lose any
title: Emma

text: thing for want of asking. He will connect himself well if he can.”
title: Emma

text: “Will you read the letter?” cried Harriet. “Pray do. II’d rather you
title: Emma

text: would.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was not sorry to be pressed. She read, and was surprized. The
title: Emma

text: style of the letter was much above her expectation. There were not
title: Emma

text: merely no grammatical errors, but as a composition it would not have
title: Emma

text: disgraced a gentleman; the language, though plain, was strong and
title: Emma

text: unaffected, and the sentiments it conveyed very much to the credit of
title: Emma

text: the writer. It was short, but expressed good sense, warm attachment,
title: Emma

text: liberality, propriety, even delicacy of feeling. She paused over it,
title: Emma

text: while Harriet stood anxiously watching for her opinion, with a “Well,
title: Emma

text: well,” and was at last forced to add, “Is it a good letter? or is it
title: Emma

text: too short?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, indeed, a very good letter,” replied Emma rather slowly—“so good
title: Emma

text: a letter, Harriet, that every thing considered, I think one of his
title: Emma

text: sisters must have helped him. I can hardly imagine the young man whom I
title: Emma

text: saw talking with you the other day could express himself so well, if
title: Emma

text: left quite to his own powers, and yet it is not the style of a woman;
title: Emma

text: no, certainly, it is too strong and concise; not diffuse enough for a
title: Emma

text: woman. No doubt he is a sensible man, and I suppose may have a natural
title: Emma

text: talent for—thinks strongly and clearly—and when he takes a pen in hand,
title: Emma

text: his thoughts naturally find proper words. It is so with some men. Yes,
title: Emma

text: I understand the sort of mind. Vigorous, decided, with sentiments to a
title: Emma

text: certain point, not coarse. A better written letter, Harriet (returning
title: Emma

text: it,) than I had expected.”

text: “Well,” said the still waiting Harriet;—“well—and—and what shall I do?”
title: Emma

text: “What shall you do! In what respect? Do you mean with regard to this
title: Emma

text: letter?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes.”
title: Emma

text: “But what are you in doubt of? You must answer it of course—and
title: Emma

text: speedily.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes. But what shall I say? Dear Miss Woodhouse, do advise me.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh no, no! the letter had much better be all your own. You will
title: Emma

text: express yourself very properly, I am sure. There is no danger of your
title: Emma

text: not being intelligible, which is the first thing. Your meaning must be
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: disappointment.”

text: “You think I ought to refuse him then,” said Harriet, looking down.
title: Emma

text: “Ought to refuse him! My dear Harriet, what do you mean? Are you in any
title: Emma

text: doubt as to that? I thought—but I beg your pardon, perhaps I have been
title: Emma

text: under a mistake. I certainly have been misunderstanding you, if you
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: were consulting me only as to the wording of it.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet was silent. With a little reserve of manner, Emma continued:
title: Emma

text: “You mean to return a favourable answer, I collect.”
title: Emma

text: “No, I do not; that is, I do not mean—What shall I do? What would you
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: do.”
title: Emma

text: “I shall not give you any advice, Harriet. I will have nothing to do
title: Emma

text: with it. This is a point which you must settle with your feelings.”
title: Emma

text: “I had no notion that he liked me so very much,” said Harriet,
title: Emma

text: contemplating the letter. For a little while Emma persevered in her
title: Emma

text: silence; but beginning to apprehend the bewitching flattery of that
title: Emma

text: letter might be too powerful, she thought it best to say,
title: Emma

text: “I lay it down as a general rule, Harriet, that if a woman _doubts_ as
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: refuse him. If she can hesitate as to ‘Yes,’ she ought to say ‘No’
title: Emma

text: directly. It is not a state to be safely entered into with doubtful
title: Emma

text: feelings, with half a heart. I thought it my duty as a friend, and
title: Emma

text: older than yourself, to say thus much to you. But do not imagine that I
title: Emma

text: want to influence you.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no, I am sure you are a great deal too kind to—but if you would
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: hesitating—It is a very serious thing.—It will be safer to say ‘No,’
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Not for the world,” said Emma, smiling graciously, “would I advise you
title: Emma

text: either way. You must be the best judge of your own happiness. If you
title: Emma

text: prefer Mr. Martin to every other person; if you think him the most
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Emma

text: Harriet slept at Hartfield that night. For some weeks past she had been
title: Emma

text: spending more than half her time there, and gradually getting to have a
title: Emma

text: bed-room appropriated to herself; and Emma judged it best in every
title: Emma

text: respect, safest and kindest, to keep her with them as much as possible
title: Emma

text: just at present. She was obliged to go the next morning for an hour or
title: Emma

text: two to Mrs. Goddard’s, but it was then to be settled that she should
title: Emma

text: return to Hartfield, to make a regular visit of some days.
title: Emma

text: While she was gone, Mr. Knightley called, and sat some time with Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse and Emma, till Mr. Woodhouse, who had previously made up his
title: Emma

text: mind to walk out, was persuaded by his daughter not to defer it, and
title: Emma

text: was induced by the entreaties of both, though against the scruples of
title: Emma

text: his own civility, to leave Mr. Knightley for that purpose. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley, who had nothing of ceremony about him, was offering by his
title: Emma

text: short, decided answers, an amusing contrast to the protracted apologies
title: Emma

text: and civil hesitations of the other.
title: Emma

text: “Well, I believe, if you will excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if you will not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley. We invalids think we are privileged people.”
title: Emma

text: “My dear sir, do not make a stranger of me.”
title: Emma

text: “I leave an excellent substitute in my daughter. Emma will be happy to
title: Emma

text: entertain you. And therefore I think I will beg your excuse and take my
title: Emma

text: three turns—my winter walk.”
title: Emma

text: “You cannot do better, sir.”
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: you have another long walk before you, to Donwell Abbey.”
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: the garden door for you.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Some minutes passed in this unpleasant silence, with only one attempt
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Robert Martin has no great loss—if he can but think so; and I hope it
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma laughed and disclaimed. He continued,
title: Emma

text: “Depend upon it, Elton will not do. Elton is a very good sort of man,
title: Emma

text: and a very respectable vicar of Highbury, but not at all likely to make
title: Emma

text: an imprudent match. He knows the value of a good income as well as any
title: Emma

text: body. Elton may talk sentimentally, but he will act rationally. He is
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: sixpence of it; and nobody is afraid of her: that is a great charm.”
title: Emma

text: “Dear me! but what shall you do? how shall you employ yourself when you
title: Emma

text: grow old?”
title: Emma

text: “If I know myself, Harriet, mine is an active, busy mind, with a great
title: Emma

text: many independent resources; and I do not perceive why I should be more
title: Emma

text: in want of employment at forty or fifty than one-and-twenty. Woman’s
title: Emma

text: usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to me then as they
title: Emma

text: are now; or with no important variation. If I draw less, I shall read
title: Emma

text: more; if I give up music, I shall take to carpet-work. And as for
title: Emma

text: objects of interest, objects for the affections, which is in truth the
title: Emma

text: great point of inferiority, the want of which is really the great evil
title: Emma

text: to be avoided in _not_ marrying, I shall be very well off, with all the
title: Emma

text: children of a sister I love so much, to care about. There will be
title: Emma

text: enough of them, in all probability, to supply every sort of sensation
title: Emma

text: that declining life can need. There will be enough for every hope and
title: Emma

text: every fear; and though my attachment to none can equal that of a
title: Emma

text: parent, it suits my ideas of comfort better than what is warmer and
title: Emma

text: blinder. My nephews and nieces!—I shall often have a niece with me.”
title: Emma

text: “Do you know Miss Bates’s niece? That is, I know you must have seen her
title: Emma

text: a hundred times—but are you acquainted?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes; we are always forced to be acquainted whenever she comes to
title: Emma

text: Highbury. By the bye, _that_ is almost enough to put one out of conceit
title: Emma

text: with a niece. Heaven forbid! at least, that I should ever bore people
title: Emma

text: half so much about all the Knightleys together, as she does about Jane
title: Emma

text: Fairfax. One is sick of the very name of Jane Fairfax. Every letter
title: Emma

text: from her is read forty times over; her compliments to all friends go
title: Emma

text: round and round again; and if she does but send her aunt the pattern of
title: Emma

text: a stomacher, or knit a pair of garters for her grandmother, one hears
title: Emma

text: of nothing else for a month. I wish Jane Fairfax very well; but she
title: Emma

text: tires me to death.”
title: Emma

text: They were now approaching the cottage, and all idle topics were
title: Emma

text: superseded. Emma was very compassionate; and the distresses of the poor
title: Emma

text: were as sure of relief from her personal attention and kindness, her
title: Emma

text: counsel and her patience, as from her purse. She understood their ways,
title: Emma

text: could allow for their ignorance and their temptations, had no romantic
title: Emma

text: expectations of extraordinary virtue from those for whom education had
title: Emma

text: done so little; entered into their troubles with ready sympathy, and
title: Emma

text: always gave her assistance with as much intelligence as good-will. In
title: Emma

text: the present instance, it was sickness and poverty together which she
title: Emma

text: came to visit; and after remaining there as long as she could give
title: Emma

text: comfort or advice, she quitted the cottage with such an impression of
title: Emma

text: the scene as made her say to Harriet, as they walked away,
title: Emma

text: “These are the sights, Harriet, to do one good. How trifling they make
title: Emma

text: every thing else appear!—I feel now as if I could think of nothing but
title: Emma

text: these poor creatures all the rest of the day; and yet, who can say how
title: Emma

text: soon it may all vanish from my mind?”
title: Emma

text: “Very true,” said Harriet. “Poor creatures! one can think of nothing
title: Emma

text: else.”
title: Emma

text: “And really, I do not think the impression will soon be over,” said
title: Emma

text: Emma, as she crossed the low hedge, and tottering footstep which ended
title: Emma

text: the narrow, slippery path through the cottage garden, and brought them
title: Emma

text: into the lane again. “I do not think it will,” stopping to look once
title: Emma

text: more at all the outward wretchedness of the place, and recall the still
title: Emma

text: greater within.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! dear, no,” said her companion.
title: Emma

text: They walked on. The lane made a slight bend; and when that bend was
title: Emma

text: passed, Mr. Elton was immediately in sight; and so near as to give Emma
title: Emma

text: time only to say farther,
title: Emma

text: “Ah! Harriet, here comes a very sudden trial of our stability in good
title: Emma

text: thoughts. Well, (smiling,) I hope it may be allowed that if compassion
title: Emma

text: has produced exertion and relief to the sufferers, it has done all that
title: Emma

text: is truly important. If we feel for the wretched, enough to do all we
title: Emma

text: can for them, the rest is empty sympathy, only distressing to
title: Emma

text: ourselves.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet could just answer, “Oh! dear, yes,” before the gentleman joined
title: Emma

text: them. The wants and sufferings of the poor family, however, were the
title: Emma

text: first subject on meeting. He had been going to call on them. His visit
title: Emma

text: he would now defer; but they had a very interesting parley about what
title: Emma

text: could be done and should be done. Mr. Elton then turned back to
title: Emma

text: accompany them.
title: Emma

text: “To fall in with each other on such an errand as this,” thought Emma;
title: Emma

text: “to meet in a charitable scheme; this will bring a great increase of
title: Emma

text: love on each side. I should not wonder if it were to bring on the
title: Emma

text: declaration. It must, if I were not here. I wish I were anywhere else.”
title: Emma

text: Anxious to separate herself from them as far as she could, she soon
title: Emma

text: afterwards took possession of a narrow footpath, a little raised on one
title: Emma

text: side of the lane, leaving them together in the main road. But she had
title: Emma

text: not been there two minutes when she found that Harriet’s habits of
title: Emma

text: dependence and imitation were bringing her up too, and that, in short,
title: Emma

text: they would both be soon after her. This would not do; she immediately
title: Emma

text: stopped, under pretence of having some alteration to make in the lacing
title: Emma

text: of her half-boot, and stooping down in complete occupation of the
title: Emma

text: footpath, begged them to have the goodness to walk on, and she would
title: Emma

text: follow in half a minute. They did as they were desired; and by the time
title: Emma

text: she judged it reasonable to have done with her boot, she had the
title: Emma

text: comfort of farther delay in her power, being overtaken by a child from
title: Emma

text: the cottage, setting out, according to orders, with her pitcher, to
title: Emma

text: fetch broth from Hartfield. To walk by the side of this child, and talk
title: Emma

text: to and question her, was the most natural thing in the world, or would
title: Emma

text: have been the most natural, had she been acting just then without
title: Emma

text: design; and by this means the others were still able to keep ahead,
title: Emma

text: without any obligation of waiting for her. She gained on them, however,
title: Emma

text: involuntarily: the child’s pace was quick, and theirs rather slow; and
title: Emma

text: she was the more concerned at it, from their being evidently in a
title: Emma

text: conversation which interested them. Mr. Elton was speaking with
title: Emma

text: animation, Harriet listening with a very pleased attention; and Emma,
title: Emma

text: having sent the child on, was beginning to think how she might draw
title: Emma

text: back a little more, when they both looked around, and she was obliged
title: Emma

text: to join them.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton was still talking, still engaged in some interesting detail;
title: Emma

text: and Emma experienced some disappointment when she found that he was
title: Emma

text: only giving his fair companion an account of the yesterday’s party at
title: Emma

text: his friend Cole’s, and that she was come in herself for the Stilton
title: Emma

text: cheese, the north Wiltshire, the butter, the celery, the beet-root, and
title: Emma

text: all the dessert.
title: Emma

text: “This would soon have led to something better, of course,” was her
title: Emma

text: consoling reflection; “any thing interests between those who love; and
title: Emma

text: any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart. If I
title: Emma

text: could but have kept longer away!”
title: Emma

text: They now walked on together quietly, till within view of the vicarage
title: Emma

text: pales, when a sudden resolution, of at least getting Harriet into the
title: Emma

text: house, made her again find something very much amiss about her boot,
title: Emma

text: and fall behind to arrange it once more. She then broke the lace off
title: Emma

text: short, and dexterously throwing it into a ditch, was presently obliged
title: Emma

text: to entreat them to stop, and acknowledged her inability to put herself
title: Emma

text: to rights so as to be able to walk home in tolerable comfort.
title: Emma

text: “Part of my lace is gone,” said she, “and I do not know how I am to
title: Emma

text: contrive. I really am a most troublesome companion to you both, but I
title: Emma

text: hope I am not often so ill-equipped. Mr. Elton, I must beg leave to
title: Emma

text: stop at your house, and ask your housekeeper for a bit of ribband or
title: Emma

text: string, or any thing just to keep my boot on.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton looked all happiness at this proposition; and nothing could
title: Emma

text: exceed his alertness and attention in conducting them into his house
title: Emma

text: and endeavouring to make every thing appear to advantage. The room they
title: Emma

text: were taken into was the one he chiefly occupied, and looking forwards;
title: Emma

text: behind it was another with which it immediately communicated; the door
title: Emma

text: between them was open, and Emma passed into it with the housekeeper to
title: Emma

text: receive her assistance in the most comfortable manner. She was obliged
title: Emma

text: to leave the door ajar as she found it; but she fully intended that Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton should close it. It was not closed, however, it still remained
title: Emma

text: ajar; but by engaging the housekeeper in incessant conversation, she
title: Emma

text: hoped to make it practicable for him to chuse his own subject in the
title: Emma

text: adjoining room. For ten minutes she could hear nothing but herself. It
title: Emma

text: could be protracted no longer. She was then obliged to be finished, and
title: Emma

text: make her appearance.
title: Emma

text: The lovers were standing together at one of the windows. It had a most
title: Emma

text: favourable aspect; and, for half a minute, Emma felt the glory of
title: Emma

text: having schemed successfully. But it would not do; he had not come to
title: Emma

text: the point. He had been most agreeable, most delightful; he had told
title: Emma

text: Harriet that he had seen them go by, and had purposely followed them;
title: Emma

text: other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt, but nothing
title: Emma

text: serious.
title: Emma

text: “Cautious, very cautious,” thought Emma; “he advances inch by inch, and
title: Emma

text: will hazard nothing till he believes himself secure.”
title: Emma

text: Still, however, though every thing had not been accomplished by her
title: Emma

text: ingenious device, she could not but flatter herself that it had been
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: them forward to the great event.

text: CHAPTER XI
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton must now be left to himself. It was no longer in Emma’s power
title: Emma

text: to superintend his happiness or quicken his measures. The coming of her
title: Emma

text: sister’s family was so very near at hand, that first in anticipation,
title: Emma

text: and then in reality, it became henceforth her prime object of interest;
title: Emma

text: and during the ten days of their stay at Hartfield it was not to be
title: Emma

text: expected—she did not herself expect—that any thing beyond occasional,
title: Emma

text: fortuitous assistance could be afforded by her to the lovers. They
title: Emma

text: might advance rapidly if they would, however; they must advance somehow
title: Emma

text: or other whether they would or no. She hardly wished to have more
title: Emma

text: leisure for them. There are people, who the more you do for them, the
title: Emma

text: less they will do for themselves.
title: Emma

text: Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley, from having been longer than usual absent
title: Emma

text: from Surry, were exciting of course rather more than the usual
title: Emma

text: interest. Till this year, every long vacation since their marriage had
title: Emma

text: been divided between Hartfield and Donwell Abbey; but all the holidays
title: Emma

text: of this autumn had been given to sea-bathing for the children, and it
title: Emma

text: was therefore many months since they had been seen in a regular way by
title: Emma

text: their Surry connexions, or seen at all by Mr. Woodhouse, who could not
title: Emma

text: be induced to get so far as London, even for poor Isabella’s sake; and
title: Emma

text: who consequently was now most nervously and apprehensively happy in
title: Emma

text: forestalling this too short visit.
title: Emma

text: He thought much of the evils of the journey for her, and not a little
title: Emma

text: of the fatigues of his own horses and coachman who were to bring some
title: Emma

text: of the party the last half of the way; but his alarms were needless;
title: Emma

text: the sixteen miles being happily accomplished, and Mr. and Mrs. John
title: Emma

text: Knightley, their five children, and a competent number of
title: Emma

text: nursery-maids, all reaching Hartfield in safety. The bustle and joy of
title: Emma

text: such an arrival, the many to be talked to, welcomed, encouraged, and
title: Emma

text: variously dispersed and disposed of, produced a noise and confusion
title: Emma

text: which his nerves could not have borne under any other cause, nor have
title: Emma

text: endured much longer even for this; but the ways of Hartfield and the
title: Emma

text: feelings of her father were so respected by Mrs. John Knightley, that
title: Emma

text: in spite of maternal solicitude for the immediate enjoyment of her
title: Emma

text: little ones, and for their having instantly all the liberty and
title: Emma

text: attendance, all the eating and drinking, and sleeping and playing,
title: Emma

text: which they could possibly wish for, without the smallest delay, the
title: Emma

text: children were never allowed to be long a disturbance to him, either in
title: Emma

text: themselves or in any restless attendance on them.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. John Knightley was a pretty, elegant little woman, of gentle,
title: Emma

text: quiet manners, and a disposition remarkably amiable and affectionate;
title: Emma

text: wrapt up in her family; a devoted wife, a doating mother, and so
title: Emma

text: tenderly attached to her father and sister that, but for these higher
title: Emma

text: ties, a warmer love might have seemed impossible. She could never see a
title: Emma

text: fault in any of them. She was not a woman of strong understanding or
title: Emma

text: any quickness; and with this resemblance of her father, she inherited
title: Emma

text: also much of his constitution; was delicate in her own health,
title: Emma

text: over-careful of that of her children, had many fears and many nerves,
title: Emma

text: and was as fond of her own Mr. Wingfield in town as her father could be
title: Emma

text: of Mr. Perry. They were alike too, in a general benevolence of temper,
title: Emma

text: and a strong habit of regard for every old acquaintance.
title: Emma

text: Mr. John Knightley was a tall, gentleman-like, and very clever man;
title: Emma

text: rising in his profession, domestic, and respectable in his private
title: Emma

text: character; but with reserved manners which prevented his being
title: Emma

text: generally pleasing; and capable of being sometimes out of humour. He
title: Emma

text: was not an ill-tempered man, not so often unreasonably cross as to
title: Emma

text: deserve such a reproach; but his temper was not his great perfection;
title: Emma

text: and, indeed, with such a worshipping wife, it was hardly possible that
title: Emma

text: any natural defects in it should not be increased. The extreme
title: Emma

text: sweetness of her temper must hurt his. He had all the clearness and
title: Emma

text: quickness of mind which she wanted, and he could sometimes act an
title: Emma

text: ungracious, or say a severe thing.
title: Emma

text: He was not a great favourite with his fair sister-in-law. Nothing wrong
title: Emma

text: in him escaped her. She was quick in feeling the little injuries to
title: Emma

text: Isabella, which Isabella never felt herself. Perhaps she might have
title: Emma

text: passed over more had his manners been flattering to Isabella’s sister,
title: Emma

text: but they were only those of a calmly kind brother and friend, without
title: Emma

text: praise and without blindness; but hardly any degree of personal
title: Emma

text: compliment could have made her regardless of that greatest fault of all
title: Emma

text: in her eyes which he sometimes fell into, the want of respectful
title: Emma

text: forbearance towards her father. There he had not always the patience
title: Emma

text: that could have been wished. Mr. Woodhouse’s peculiarities and
title: Emma

text: fidgetiness were sometimes provoking him to a rational remonstrance or
title: Emma

text: sharp retort equally ill-bestowed. It did not often happen; for Mr.
title: Emma

text: John Knightley had really a great regard for his father-in-law, and
title: Emma

text: generally a strong sense of what was due to him; but it was too often
title: Emma

text: for Emma’s charity, especially as there was all the pain of
title: Emma

text: apprehension frequently to be endured, though the offence came not. The
title: Emma

text: beginning, however, of every visit displayed none but the properest
title: Emma

text: feelings, and this being of necessity so short might be hoped to pass
title: Emma

text: away in unsullied cordiality. They had not been long seated and
title: Emma

text: composed when Mr. Woodhouse, with a melancholy shake of the head and a
title: Emma

text: sigh, called his daughter’s attention to the sad change at Hartfield
title: Emma

text: since she had been there last.
title: Emma

text: “Ah, my dear,” said he, “poor Miss Taylor—It is a grievous business.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh yes, sir,” cried she with ready sympathy, “how you must miss her!
title: Emma

text: And dear Emma, too!—What a dreadful loss to you both!—I have been so
title: Emma

text: grieved for you.—I could not imagine how you could possibly do without
title: Emma

text: her.—It is a sad change indeed.—But I hope she is pretty well, sir.”
title: Emma

text: “Pretty well, my dear—I hope—pretty well.—I do not know but that the
title: Emma

text: place agrees with her tolerably.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. John Knightley here asked Emma quietly whether there were any
title: Emma

text: doubts of the air of Randalls.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no—none in the least. I never saw Mrs. Weston better in my
title: Emma

text: life—never looking so well. Papa is only speaking his own regret.”
title: Emma

text: “Very much to the honour of both,” was the handsome reply.
title: Emma

text: “And do you see her, sir, tolerably often?” asked Isabella in the
title: Emma

text: plaintive tone which just suited her father.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse hesitated.—“Not near so often, my dear, as I could wish.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! papa, we have missed seeing them but one entire day since they
title: Emma

text: married. Either in the morning or evening of every day, excepting one,
title: Emma

text: have we seen either Mr. Weston or Mrs. Weston, and generally both,
title: Emma

text: either at Randalls or here—and as you may suppose, Isabella, most
title: Emma

text: frequently here. They are very, very kind in their visits. Mr. Weston
title: Emma

text: is really as kind as herself. Papa, if you speak in that melancholy
title: Emma

text: way, you will be giving Isabella a false idea of us all. Every body
title: Emma

text: must be aware that Miss Taylor must be missed, but every body ought
title: Emma

text: also to be assured that Mr. and Mrs. Weston do really prevent our
title: Emma

text: missing her by any means to the extent we ourselves anticipated—which
title: Emma

text: is the exact truth.”
title: Emma

text: “Just as it should be,” said Mr. John Knightley, “and just as I hoped
title: Emma

text: it was from your letters. Her wish of shewing you attention could not
title: Emma

text: be doubted, and his being a disengaged and social man makes it all
title: Emma

text: easy. I have been always telling you, my love, that I had no idea of
title: Emma

text: the change being so very material to Hartfield as you apprehended; and
title: Emma

text: now you have Emma’s account, I hope you will be satisfied.”
title: Emma

text: “Why, to be sure,” said Mr. Woodhouse—“yes, certainly—I cannot deny
title: Emma

text: that Mrs. Weston, poor Mrs. Weston, does come and see us pretty
title: Emma

text: often—but then—she is always obliged to go away again.”
title: Emma

text: “It would be very hard upon Mr. Weston if she did not, papa.—You quite
title: Emma

text: forget poor Mr. Weston.”
title: Emma

text: “I think, indeed,” said John Knightley pleasantly, “that Mr. Weston has
title: Emma

text: some little claim. You and I, Emma, will venture to take the part of
title: Emma

text: the poor husband. I, being a husband, and you not being a wife, the
title: Emma

text: claims of the man may very likely strike us with equal force. As for
title: Emma

text: Isabella, she has been married long enough to see the convenience of
title: Emma

text: putting all the Mr. Westons aside as much as she can.”
title: Emma

text: “Me, my love,” cried his wife, hearing and understanding only in part.—
title: Emma

text: “Are you talking about me?—I am sure nobody ought to be, or can be, a
title: Emma

text: greater advocate for matrimony than I am; and if it had not been for
title: Emma

text: the misery of her leaving Hartfield, I should never have thought of
title: Emma

text: Miss Taylor but as the most fortunate woman in the world; and as to
title: Emma

text: slighting Mr. Weston, that excellent Mr. Weston, I think there is
title: Emma

text: nothing he does not deserve. I believe he is one of the very
title: Emma

text: best-tempered men that ever existed. Excepting yourself and your
title: Emma

text: brother, I do not know his equal for temper. I shall never forget his
title: Emma

text: flying Henry’s kite for him that very windy day last Easter—and ever
title: Emma

text: since his particular kindness last September twelvemonth in writing
title: Emma

text: that note, at twelve o’clock at night, on purpose to assure me that
title: Emma

text: there was no scarlet fever at Cobham, I have been convinced there could
title: Emma

text: not be a more feeling heart nor a better man in existence.—If any body
title: Emma

text: can deserve him, it must be Miss Taylor.”
title: Emma

text: “Where is the young man?” said John Knightley. “Has he been here on
title: Emma

text: this occasion—or has he not?”
title: Emma

text: “He has not been here yet,” replied Emma. “There was a strong
title: Emma

text: expectation of his coming soon after the marriage, but it ended in
title: Emma

text: nothing; and I have not heard him mentioned lately.”
title: Emma

text: “But you should tell them of the letter, my dear,” said her father. “He
title: Emma

text: wrote a letter to poor Mrs. Weston, to congratulate her, and a very
title: Emma

text: proper, handsome letter it was. She shewed it to me. I thought it very
title: Emma

text: well done of him indeed. Whether it was his own idea you know, one
title: Emma

text: cannot tell. He is but young, and his uncle, perhaps—”
title: Emma

text: “My dear papa, he is three-and-twenty. You forget how time passes.”
title: Emma

text: “Three-and-twenty!—is he indeed?—Well, I could not have thought it—and
title: Emma

text: he was but two years old when he lost his poor mother! Well, time does
title: Emma

text: fly indeed!—and my memory is very bad. However, it was an exceeding
title: Emma

text: good, pretty letter, and gave Mr. and Mrs. Weston a great deal of
title: Emma

text: pleasure. I remember it was written from Weymouth, and dated Sept.
title: Emma

text: 28th—and began, ‘My dear Madam,’ but I forget how it went on; and it
title: Emma

text: was signed ‘F. C. Weston Churchill.’—I remember that perfectly.”
title: Emma

text: “How very pleasing and proper of him!” cried the good-hearted Mrs. John
title: Emma

text: Knightley. “I have no doubt of his being a most amiable young man. But
title: Emma

text: how sad it is that he should not live at home with his father! There is
title: Emma

text: something so shocking in a child’s being taken away from his parents
title: Emma

text: and natural home! I never could comprehend how Mr. Weston could part
title: Emma

text: with him. To give up one’s child! I really never could think well of
title: Emma

text: any body who proposed such a thing to any body else.”
title: Emma

text: “Nobody ever did think well of the Churchills, I fancy,” observed Mr.
title: Emma

text: John Knightley coolly. “But you need not imagine Mr. Weston to have
title: Emma

text: felt what you would feel in giving up Henry or John. Mr. Weston is
title: Emma

text: rather an easy, cheerful-tempered man, than a man of strong feelings;
title: Emma

text: he takes things as he finds them, and makes enjoyment of them somehow
title: Emma

text: or other, depending, I suspect, much more upon what is called society
title: Emma

text: for his comforts, that is, upon the power of eating and drinking, and
title: Emma

text: playing whist with his neighbours five times a week, than upon family
title: Emma

text: affection, or any thing that home affords.”
title: Emma

text: Emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on Mr. Weston, and
title: Emma

text: had half a mind to take it up; but she struggled, and let it pass. She
title: Emma

text: would keep the peace if possible; and there was something honourable
title: Emma

text: and valuable in the strong domestic habits, the all-sufficiency of home
title: Emma

text: to himself, whence resulted her brother’s disposition to look down on
title: Emma

text: the common rate of social intercourse, and those to whom it was
title: Emma

text: important.—It had a high claim to forbearance.

text: Mr. Knightley was to dine with them—rather against the inclination of
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: She hoped they might now become friends again. She thought it was time
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: nearer?”
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: one or the other.
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: eagerness.

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: round the country. I suppose there is not a man in such practice
title: Emma

text: “And Mrs. Perry and the children, how are they? do the children grow? I
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is quite
title: Emma

text: a mistake, sir.—We all had our health perfectly well there, never found
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Ah! my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: ill-judged measure.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XIII
title: Emma

text: There could hardly be a happier creature in the world than Mrs. John
title: Emma

text: Knightley, in this short visit to Hartfield, going about every morning
title: Emma

text: among her old acquaintance with her five children, and talking over
title: Emma

text: what she had done every evening with her father and sister. She had
title: Emma

text: nothing to wish otherwise, but that the days did not pass so swiftly.
title: Emma

text: It was a delightful visit;—perfect, in being much too short.
title: Emma

text: In general their evenings were less engaged with friends than their
title: Emma

text: mornings; but one complete dinner engagement, and out of the house too,
title: Emma

text: there was no avoiding, though at Christmas. Mr. Weston would take no
title: Emma

text: denial; they must all dine at Randalls one day;—even Mr. Woodhouse was
title: Emma

text: persuaded to think it a possible thing in preference to a division of
title: Emma

text: the party.
title: Emma

text: How they were all to be conveyed, he would have made a difficulty if he
title: Emma

text: could, but as his son and daughter’s carriage and horses were actually
title: Emma

text: at Hartfield, he was not able to make more than a simple question on
title: Emma

text: that head; it hardly amounted to a doubt; nor did it occupy Emma long
title: Emma

text: to convince him that they might in one of the carriages find room for
title: Emma

text: Harriet also.
title: Emma

text: Harriet, Mr. Elton, and Mr. Knightley, their own especial set, were the
title: Emma

text: only persons invited to meet them;—the hours were to be early, as well
title: Emma

text: as the numbers few; Mr. Woodhouse’s habits and inclination being
title: Emma

text: consulted in every thing.

text: The evening before this great event (for it was a very great event that
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: called on her the next day, and found her doom already signed with
title: Emma

text: regard to Randalls. She was very feverish and had a bad sore throat:
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: excluded her from this delightful engagement, though she could not
title: Emma

text: speak of her loss without many tears.
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: unavoidable absences, and raise her spirits by representing how much
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: most comfortless visit, and of their all missing her very much. She had
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Why does not Perry see her?”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma
