text: care of such a fair lady, and not liking to resist any advice of her’s,
title: Emma

text: he had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;—but Emma,
title: Emma

text: too eager and busy in her own previous conceptions and views to hear
title: Emma

text: him impartially, or see him with clear vision, was very well satisfied
title: Emma

text: with his muttering acknowledgment of its being “very cold, certainly
title: Emma

text: very cold,” and walked on, rejoicing in having extricated him from
title: Emma

text: Randalls, and secured him the power of sending to inquire after Harriet
title: Emma

text: every hour of the evening.
title: Emma

text: “You do quite right,” said she;—“we will make your apologies to Mr. and
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston.”
title: Emma

text: But hardly had she so spoken, when she found her brother was civilly
title: Emma

text: offering a seat in his carriage, if the weather were Mr. Elton’s only
title: Emma

text: objection, and Mr. Elton actually accepting the offer with much prompt
title: Emma

text: satisfaction. It was a done thing; Mr. Elton was to go, and never had
title: Emma

text: his broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than at this moment;
title: Emma

text: never had his smile been stronger, nor his eyes more exulting than when
title: Emma

text: he next looked at her.
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said she to herself, “this is most strange!—After I had got him
title: Emma

text: off so well, to chuse to go into company, and leave Harriet ill
title: Emma

text: behind!—Most strange indeed!—But there is, I believe, in many men,
title: Emma

text: especially single men, such an inclination—such a passion for dining
title: Emma

text: out—a dinner engagement is so high in the class of their pleasures,
title: Emma

text: their employments, their dignities, almost their duties, that any thing
title: Emma

text: gives way to it—and this must be the case with Mr. Elton; a most
title: Emma

text: valuable, amiable, pleasing young man undoubtedly, and very much in
title: Emma

text: love with Harriet; but still, he cannot refuse an invitation, he must
title: Emma

text: dine out wherever he is asked. What a strange thing love is! he can see
title: Emma

text: ready wit in Harriet, but will not dine alone for her.”
title: Emma

text: Soon afterwards Mr. Elton quitted them, and she could not but do him
title: Emma

text: the justice of feeling that there was a great deal of sentiment in his
title: Emma

text: manner of naming Harriet at parting; in the tone of his voice while
title: Emma

text: assuring her that he should call at Mrs. Goddard’s for news of her fair
title: Emma

text: friend, the last thing before he prepared for the happiness of meeting
title: Emma

text: her again, when he hoped to be able to give a better report; and he
title: Emma

text: sighed and smiled himself off in a way that left the balance of
title: Emma

text: approbation much in his favour.
title: Emma

text: After a few minutes of entire silence between them, John Knightley
title: Emma

text: began with—
title: Emma

text: “I never in my life saw a man more intent on being agreeable than Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton. It is downright labour to him where ladies are concerned. With
title: Emma

text: men he can be rational and unaffected, but when he has ladies to
title: Emma

text: please, every feature works.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton’s manners are not perfect,” replied Emma; “but where there
title: Emma

text: is a wish to please, one ought to overlook, and one does overlook a
title: Emma

text: great deal. Where a man does his best with only moderate powers, he
title: Emma

text: will have the advantage over negligent superiority. There is such
title: Emma

text: perfect good-temper and good-will in Mr. Elton as one cannot but
title: Emma

text: value.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said Mr. John Knightley presently, with some slyness, “he seems
title: Emma

text: to have a great deal of good-will towards you.”
title: Emma

text: “Me!” she replied with a smile of astonishment, “are you imagining me
title: Emma

text: to be Mr. Elton’s object?”
title: Emma

text: “Such an imagination has crossed me, I own, Emma; and if it never
title: Emma

text: occurred to you before, you may as well take it into consideration
title: Emma

text: now.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton in love with me!—What an idea!”
title: Emma

text: “I do not say it is so; but you will do well to consider whether it is
title: Emma

text: so or not, and to regulate your behaviour accordingly. I think your
title: Emma

text: manners to him encouraging. I speak as a friend, Emma. You had better
title: Emma

text: look about you, and ascertain what you do, and what you mean to do.”
title: Emma

text: “I thank you; but I assure you you are quite mistaken. Mr. Elton and I
title: Emma

text: are very good friends, and nothing more;” and she walked on, amusing
title: Emma

text: herself in the consideration of the blunders which often arise from a
title: Emma

text: partial knowledge of circumstances, of the mistakes which people of
title: Emma

text: high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into; and not very
title: Emma

text: well pleased with her brother for imagining her blind and ignorant, and
title: Emma

text: in want of counsel. He said no more.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse had so completely made up his mind to the visit, that in
title: Emma

text: spite of the increasing coldness, he seemed to have no idea of
title: Emma

text: shrinking from it, and set forward at last most punctually with his
title: Emma

text: eldest daughter in his own carriage, with less apparent consciousness
title: Emma

text: of the weather than either of the others; too full of the wonder of his
title: Emma

text: own going, and the pleasure it was to afford at Randalls to see that it
title: Emma

text: was cold, and too well wrapt up to feel it. The cold, however, was
title: Emma

text: severe; and by the time the second carriage was in motion, a few flakes
title: Emma

text: of snow were finding their way down, and the sky had the appearance of
title: Emma

text: being so overcharged as to want only a milder air to produce a very
title: Emma

text: white world in a very short time.
title: Emma

text: Emma soon saw that her companion was not in the happiest humour. The
title: Emma

text: preparing and the going abroad in such weather, with the sacrifice of
title: Emma

text: his children after dinner, were evils, were disagreeables at least,
title: Emma

text: which Mr. John Knightley did not by any means like; he anticipated
title: Emma

text: nothing in the visit that could be at all worth the purchase; and the
title: Emma

text: whole of their drive to the vicarage was spent by him in expressing his
title: Emma

text: discontent.
title: Emma

text: “A man,” said he, “must have a very good opinion of himself when he
title: Emma

text: asks people to leave their own fireside, and encounter such a day as
title: Emma

text: this, for the sake of coming to see him. He must think himself a most
title: Emma

text: agreeable fellow; I could not do such a thing. It is the greatest
title: Emma

text: absurdity—Actually snowing at this moment!—The folly of not allowing
title: Emma

text: people to be comfortable at home—and the folly of people’s not staying
title: Emma

text: comfortably at home when they can! If we were obliged to go out such an
title: Emma

text: evening as this, by any call of duty or business, what a hardship we
title: Emma

text: should deem it;—and here are we, probably with rather thinner clothing
title: Emma

text: than usual, setting forward voluntarily, without excuse, in defiance of
title: Emma

text: the voice of nature, which tells man, in every thing given to his view
title: Emma

text: or his feelings, to stay at home himself, and keep all under shelter
title: Emma

text: that he can;—here are we setting forward to spend five dull hours in
title: Emma

text: another man’s house, with nothing to say or to hear that was not said
title: Emma

text: and heard yesterday, and may not be said and heard again to-morrow.
title: Emma

text: Going in dismal weather, to return probably in worse;—four horses and
title: Emma

text: four servants taken out for nothing but to convey five idle, shivering
title: Emma

text: creatures into colder rooms and worse company than they might have had
title: Emma

text: at home.”
title: Emma

text: Emma did not find herself equal to give the pleased assent, which no
title: Emma

text: doubt he was in the habit of receiving, to emulate the “Very true, my
title: Emma

text: love,” which must have been usually administered by his travelling
title: Emma

text: companion; but she had resolution enough to refrain from making any
title: Emma

text: answer at all. She could not be complying, she dreaded being
title: Emma

text: quarrelsome; her heroism reached only to silence. She allowed him to
title: Emma

text: talk, and arranged the glasses, and wrapped herself up, without opening
title: Emma

text: her lips.
title: Emma

text: They arrived, the carriage turned, the step was let down, and Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton, spruce, black, and smiling, was with them instantly. Emma
title: Emma

text: thought with pleasure of some change of subject. Mr. Elton was all
title: Emma

text: obligation and cheerfulness; he was so very cheerful in his civilities
title: Emma

text: indeed, that she began to think he must have received a different
title: Emma

text: account of Harriet from what had reached her. She had sent while
title: Emma

text: dressing, and the answer had been, “Much the same—not better.”
title: Emma

text: “_My_ report from Mrs. Goddard’s,” said she presently, “was not so
title: Emma

text: pleasant as I had hoped—‘Not better’ was _my_ answer.”
title: Emma

text: His face lengthened immediately; and his voice was the voice of
title: Emma

text: sentiment as he answered.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no—I am grieved to find—I was on the point of telling you that
title: Emma

text: when I called at Mrs. Goddard’s door, which I did the very last thing
title: Emma

text: before I returned to dress, I was told that Miss Smith was not better,
title: Emma

text: by no means better, rather worse. Very much grieved and concerned—I had
title: Emma

text: flattered myself that she must be better after such a cordial as I knew
title: Emma

text: had been given her in the morning.”
title: Emma

text: Emma smiled and answered—“My visit was of use to the nervous part of
title: Emma

text: her complaint, I hope; but not even I can charm away a sore throat; it
title: Emma

text: is a most severe cold indeed. Mr. Perry has been with her, as you
title: Emma

text: probably heard.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—I imagined—that is—I did not—”
title: Emma

text: “He has been used to her in these complaints, and I hope to-morrow
title: Emma

text: morning will bring us both a more comfortable report. But it is
title: Emma

text: impossible not to feel uneasiness. Such a sad loss to our party
title: Emma

text: to-day!”
title: Emma

text: “Dreadful!—Exactly so, indeed.—She will be missed every moment.”
title: Emma

text: This was very proper; the sigh which accompanied it was really
title: Emma

text: estimable; but it should have lasted longer. Emma was rather in dismay
title: Emma

text: when only half a minute afterwards he began to speak of other things,
title: Emma

text: and in a voice of the greatest alacrity and enjoyment.
title: Emma

text: “What an excellent device,” said he, “the use of a sheepskin for
title: Emma

text: carriages. How very comfortable they make it;—impossible to feel cold
title: Emma

text: with such precautions. The contrivances of modern days indeed have
title: Emma

text: rendered a gentleman’s carriage perfectly complete. One is so fenced
title: Emma

text: and guarded from the weather, that not a breath of air can find its way
title: Emma

text: unpermitted. Weather becomes absolutely of no consequence. It is a very
title: Emma

text: cold afternoon—but in this carriage we know nothing of the matter.—Ha!
title: Emma

text: snows a little I see.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said John Knightley, “and I think we shall have a good deal of
title: Emma

text: it.”
title: Emma

text: “Christmas weather,” observed Mr. Elton. “Quite seasonable; and
title: Emma

text: extremely fortunate we may think ourselves that it did not begin
title: Emma

text: yesterday, and prevent this day’s party, which it might very possibly
title: Emma

text: have done, for Mr. Woodhouse would hardly have ventured had there been
title: Emma

text: much snow on the ground; but now it is of no consequence. This is quite
title: Emma

text: the season indeed for friendly meetings. At Christmas every body
title: Emma

text: invites their friends about them, and people think little of even the
title: Emma

text: worst weather. I was snowed up at a friend’s house once for a week.
title: Emma

text: Nothing could be pleasanter. I went for only one night, and could not
title: Emma

text: get away till that very day se’nnight.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. John Knightley looked as if he did not comprehend the pleasure, but
title: Emma

text: said only, coolly,
title: Emma

text: “I cannot wish to be snowed up a week at Randalls.”
title: Emma

text: At another time Emma might have been amused, but she was too much
title: Emma

text: astonished now at Mr. Elton’s spirits for other feelings. Harriet
title: Emma

text: seemed quite forgotten in the expectation of a pleasant party.
title: Emma

text: “We are sure of excellent fires,” continued he, “and every thing in the
title: Emma

text: greatest comfort. Charming people, Mr. and Mrs. Weston;—Mrs. Weston
title: Emma

text: indeed is much beyond praise, and he is exactly what one values, so
title: Emma

text: hospitable, and so fond of society;—it will be a small party, but where
title: Emma

text: small parties are select, they are perhaps the most agreeable of any.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston’s dining-room does not accommodate more than ten
title: Emma

text: comfortably; and for my part, I would rather, under such circumstances,
title: Emma

text: fall short by two than exceed by two. I think you will agree with me,
title: Emma

text: (turning with a soft air to Emma,) I think I shall certainly have your
title: Emma

text: approbation, though Mr. Knightley perhaps, from being used to the large
title: Emma

text: parties of London, may not quite enter into our feelings.”
title: Emma

text: “I know nothing of the large parties of London, sir—I never dine with
title: Emma

text: any body.”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed! (in a tone of wonder and pity,) I had no idea that the law had
title: Emma

text: been so great a slavery. Well, sir, the time must come when you will be
title: Emma

text: paid for all this, when you will have little labour and great
title: Emma

text: enjoyment.”
title: Emma

text: “My first enjoyment,” replied John Knightley, as they passed through
title: Emma

text: the sweep-gate, “will be to find myself safe at Hartfield again.”
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XIV
title: Emma

text: Some change of countenance was necessary for each gentleman as they
title: Emma

text: walked into Mrs. Weston’s drawing-room;—Mr. Elton must compose his
title: Emma

text: joyous looks, and Mr. John Knightley disperse his ill-humour. Mr. Elton
title: Emma

text: must smile less, and Mr. John Knightley more, to fit them for the
title: Emma

text: place.—Emma only might be as nature prompted, and shew herself just as
title: Emma

text: happy as she was. To her it was real enjoyment to be with the Westons.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston was a great favourite, and there was not a creature in the
title: Emma

text: world to whom she spoke with such unreserve, as to his wife; not any
title: Emma

text: one, to whom she related with such conviction of being listened to and
title: Emma

text: understood, of being always interesting and always intelligible, the
title: Emma

text: little affairs, arrangements, perplexities, and pleasures of her father
title: Emma

text: and herself. She could tell nothing of Hartfield, in which Mrs. Weston
title: Emma

text: had not a lively concern; and half an hour’s uninterrupted
title: Emma

text: communication of all those little matters on which the daily happiness
title: Emma

text: of private life depends, was one of the first gratifications of each.
title: Emma

text: This was a pleasure which perhaps the whole day’s visit might not
title: Emma

text: afford, which certainly did not belong to the present half-hour; but
title: Emma

text: the very sight of Mrs. Weston, her smile, her touch, her voice was
title: Emma

text: grateful to Emma, and she determined to think as little as possible of
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton’s oddities, or of any thing else unpleasant, and enjoy all
title: Emma

text: that was enjoyable to the utmost.
title: Emma

text: The misfortune of Harriet’s cold had been pretty well gone through
title: Emma

text: before her arrival. Mr. Woodhouse had been safely seated long enough to
title: Emma

text: give the history of it, besides all the history of his own and
title: Emma

text: Isabella’s coming, and of Emma’s being to follow, and had indeed just
title: Emma

text: got to the end of his satisfaction that James should come and see his
title: Emma

text: daughter, when the others appeared, and Mrs. Weston, who had been
title: Emma

text: almost wholly engrossed by her attentions to him, was able to turn away
title: Emma

text: and welcome her dear Emma.
title: Emma

text: Emma’s project of forgetting Mr. Elton for a while made her rather
title: Emma

text: sorry to find, when they had all taken their places, that he was close
title: Emma

text: to her. The difficulty was great of driving his strange insensibility
title: Emma

text: towards Harriet, from her mind, while he not only sat at her elbow, but
title: Emma

text: was continually obtruding his happy countenance on her notice, and
title: Emma

text: solicitously addressing her upon every occasion. Instead of forgetting
title: Emma

text: him, his behaviour was such that she could not avoid the internal
title: Emma

text: suggestion of “Can it really be as my brother imagined? can it be
title: Emma

text: possible for this man to be beginning to transfer his affections from
title: Emma

text: Harriet to me?—Absurd and insufferable!”—Yet he would be so anxious for
title: Emma

text: her being perfectly warm, would be so interested about her father, and
title: Emma

text: so delighted with Mrs. Weston; and at last would begin admiring her
title: Emma

text: drawings with so much zeal and so little knowledge as seemed terribly
title: Emma

text: like a would-be lover, and made it some effort with her to preserve her
title: Emma

text: good manners. For her own sake she could not be rude; and for
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s, in the hope that all would yet turn out right, she was even
title: Emma

text: positively civil; but it was an effort; especially as something was
title: Emma

text: going on amongst the others, in the most overpowering period of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s nonsense, which she particularly wished to listen to. She heard
title: Emma

text: enough to know that Mr. Weston was giving some information about his
title: Emma

text: son; she heard the words “my son,” and “Frank,” and “my son,” repeated
title: Emma

text: several times over; and, from a few other half-syllables very much
title: Emma

text: suspected that he was announcing an early visit from his son; but
title: Emma

text: before she could quiet Mr. Elton, the subject was so completely past
title: Emma

text: that any reviving question from her would have been awkward.
title: Emma

text: Now, it so happened that in spite of Emma’s resolution of never
title: Emma

text: marrying, there was something in the name, in the idea of Mr. Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill, which always interested her. She had frequently
title: Emma

text: thought—especially since his father’s marriage with Miss Taylor—that if
title: Emma

text: she _were_ to marry, he was the very person to suit her in age,
title: Emma

text: character and condition. He seemed by this connexion between the
title: Emma

text: families, quite to belong to her. She could not but suppose it to be a
title: Emma

text: match that every body who knew them must think of. That Mr. and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston did think of it, she was very strongly persuaded; and though not
title: Emma

text: meaning to be induced by him, or by any body else, to give up a
title: Emma

text: situation which she believed more replete with good than any she could
title: Emma

text: change it for, she had a great curiosity to see him, a decided
title: Emma

text: intention of finding him pleasant, of being liked by him to a certain
title: Emma

text: degree, and a sort of pleasure in the idea of their being coupled in
title: Emma

text: their friends’ imaginations.
title: Emma

text: With such sensations, Mr. Elton’s civilities were dreadfully ill-timed;
title: Emma

text: but she had the comfort of appearing very polite, while feeling very
title: Emma

text: cross—and of thinking that the rest of the visit could not possibly
title: Emma

text: pass without bringing forward the same information again, or the
title: Emma

text: substance of it, from the open-hearted Mr. Weston.—So it proved;—for
title: Emma

text: when happily released from Mr. Elton, and seated by Mr. Weston, at
title: Emma

text: dinner, he made use of the very first interval in the cares of
title: Emma

text: hospitality, the very first leisure from the saddle of mutton, to say
title: Emma

text: to her,
title: Emma

text: “We want only two more to be just the right number. I should like to
title: Emma

text: see two more here,—your pretty little friend, Miss Smith, and my
title: Emma

text: son—and then I should say we were quite complete. I believe you did not
title: Emma

text: hear me telling the others in the drawing-room that we are expecting
title: Emma

text: Frank. I had a letter from him this morning, and he will be with us
title: Emma

text: within a fortnight.”
title: Emma

text: Emma spoke with a very proper degree of pleasure; and fully assented to
title: Emma

text: his proposition of Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Smith making their
title: Emma

text: party quite complete.
title: Emma

text: “He has been wanting to come to us,” continued Mr. Weston, “ever since
title: Emma

text: September: every letter has been full of it; but he cannot command his
title: Emma

text: own time. He has those to please who must be pleased, and who (between
title: Emma

text: ourselves) are sometimes to be pleased only by a good many sacrifices.
title: Emma

text: But now I have no doubt of seeing him here about the second week in
title: Emma

text: January.”
title: Emma

text: “What a very great pleasure it will be to you! and Mrs. Weston is so
title: Emma

text: anxious to be acquainted with him, that she must be almost as happy as
title: Emma

text: yourself.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, she would be, but that she thinks there will be another put-off.
title: Emma

text: She does not depend upon his coming so much as I do: but she does not
title: Emma

text: know the parties so well as I do. The case, you see, is—(but this is
title: Emma

text: quite between ourselves: I did not mention a syllable of it in the
title: Emma

text: other room. There are secrets in all families, you know)—The case is,
title: Emma

text: that a party of friends are invited to pay a visit at Enscombe in
title: Emma

text: January; and that Frank’s coming depends upon their being put off. If
title: Emma

text: they are not put off, he cannot stir. But I know they will, because it
title: Emma

text: is a family that a certain lady, of some consequence, at Enscombe, has
title: Emma

text: a particular dislike to: and though it is thought necessary to invite
title: Emma

text: them once in two or three years, they always are put off when it comes
title: Emma

text: to the point. I have not the smallest doubt of the issue. I am as
title: Emma

text: confident of seeing Frank here before the middle of January, as I am of
title: Emma

text: being here myself: but your good friend there (nodding towards the
title: Emma

text: upper end of the table) has so few vagaries herself, and has been so
title: Emma

text: little used to them at Hartfield, that she cannot calculate on their
title: Emma

text: effects, as I have been long in the practice of doing.”
title: Emma

text: “I am sorry there should be any thing like doubt in the case,” replied
title: Emma

text: Emma; “but am disposed to side with you, Mr. Weston. If you think he
title: Emma

text: will come, I shall think so too; for you know Enscombe.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—I have some right to that knowledge; though I have never been at
title: Emma

text: the place in my life.—She is an odd woman!—But I never allow myself to
title: Emma

text: speak ill of her, on Frank’s account; for I do believe her to be very
title: Emma

text: fond of him. I used to think she was not capable of being fond of any
title: Emma

text: body, except herself: but she has always been kind to him (in her
title: Emma

text: way—allowing for little whims and caprices, and expecting every thing
title: Emma

text: to be as she likes). And it is no small credit, in my opinion, to him,
title: Emma

text: that he should excite such an affection; for, though I would not say it
title: Emma

text: to any body else, she has no more heart than a stone to people in
title: Emma

text: general; and the devil of a temper.”
title: Emma

text: Emma liked the subject so well, that she began upon it, to Mrs. Weston,
title: Emma

text: very soon after their moving into the drawing-room: wishing her joy—yet
title: Emma

text: observing, that she knew the first meeting must be rather alarming.—
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston agreed to it; but added, that she should be very glad to be
title: Emma

text: secure of undergoing the anxiety of a first meeting at the time talked
title: Emma

text: of: “for I cannot depend upon his coming. I cannot be so sanguine as
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston. I am very much afraid that it will all end in nothing. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston, I dare say, has been telling you exactly how the matter
title: Emma

text: stands?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—it seems to depend upon nothing but the ill-humour of Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Churchill, which I imagine to be the most certain thing in the world.”
title: Emma

text: “My Emma!” replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, “what is the certainty of
title: Emma

text: caprice?” Then turning to Isabella, who had not been attending
title: Emma

text: before—“You must know, my dear Mrs. Knightley, that we are by no means
title: Emma

text: so sure of seeing Mr. Frank Churchill, in my opinion, as his father
title: Emma

text: thinks. It depends entirely upon his aunt’s spirits and pleasure; in
title: Emma

text: short, upon her temper. To you—to my two daughters—I may venture on the
title: Emma

text: truth. Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe, and is a very odd-tempered
title: Emma

text: woman; and his coming now, depends upon her being willing to spare
title: Emma

text: him.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh, Mrs. Churchill; every body knows Mrs. Churchill,” replied
title: Emma

text: Isabella: “and I am sure I never think of that poor young man without
title: Emma

text: the greatest compassion. To be constantly living with an ill-tempered
title: Emma

text: person, must be dreadful. It is what we happily have never known any
title: Emma

text: thing of; but it must be a life of misery. What a blessing, that she
title: Emma

text: never had any children! Poor little creatures, how unhappy she would
title: Emma

text: have made them!”
title: Emma

text: Emma wished she had been alone with Mrs. Weston. She should then have
title: Emma

text: heard more: Mrs. Weston would speak to her, with a degree of unreserve
title: Emma

text: which she would not hazard with Isabella; and, she really believed,
title: Emma

text: would scarcely try to conceal any thing relative to the Churchills from
title: Emma

text: her, excepting those views on the young man, of which her own
title: Emma

text: imagination had already given her such instinctive knowledge. But at
title: Emma

text: present there was nothing more to be said. Mr. Woodhouse very soon
title: Emma

text: followed them into the drawing-room. To be sitting long after dinner,
title: Emma

text: was a confinement that he could not endure. Neither wine nor
title: Emma

text: conversation was any thing to him; and gladly did he move to those with
title: Emma

text: whom he was always comfortable.
title: Emma

text: While he talked to Isabella, however, Emma found an opportunity of
title: Emma

text: saying,
title: Emma

text: “And so you do not consider this visit from your son as by any means
title: Emma

text: certain. I am sorry for it. The introduction must be unpleasant,
title: Emma

text: whenever it takes place; and the sooner it could be over, the better.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; and every delay makes one more apprehensive of other delays. Even
title: Emma

text: if this family, the Braithwaites, are put off, I am still afraid that
title: Emma

text: some excuse may be found for disappointing us. I cannot bear to imagine
title: Emma

text: any reluctance on his side; but I am sure there is a great wish on the
title: Emma

text: Churchills’ to keep him to themselves. There is jealousy. They are
title: Emma

text: jealous even of his regard for his father. In short, I can feel no
title: Emma

text: dependence on his coming, and I wish Mr. Weston were less sanguine.”
title: Emma

text: “He ought to come,” said Emma. “If he could stay only a couple of days,
title: Emma

text: he ought to come; and one can hardly conceive a young man’s not having
title: Emma

text: it in his power to do as much as that. A young _woman_, if she fall
title: Emma

text: into bad hands, may be teased, and kept at a distance from those she
title: Emma

text: wants to be with; but one cannot comprehend a young _man_’s being under
title: Emma

text: such restraint, as not to be able to spend a week with his father, if
title: Emma

text: he likes it.”
title: Emma

text: “One ought to be at Enscombe, and know the ways of the family, before
title: Emma

text: one decides upon what he can do,” replied Mrs. Weston. “One ought to
title: Emma

text: use the same caution, perhaps, in judging of the conduct of any one
title: Emma

text: individual of any one family; but Enscombe, I believe, certainly must
title: Emma

text: not be judged by general rules: _she_ is so very unreasonable; and
title: Emma

text: every thing gives way to her.”
title: Emma

text: “But she is so fond of the nephew: he is so very great a favourite.
title: Emma

text: Now, according to my idea of Mrs. Churchill, it would be most natural,
title: Emma

text: that while she makes no sacrifice for the comfort of the husband, to
title: Emma

text: whom she owes every thing, while she exercises incessant caprice
title: Emma

text: towards _him_, she should frequently be governed by the nephew, to whom
title: Emma

text: she owes nothing at all.”
title: Emma

text: “My dearest Emma, do not pretend, with your sweet temper, to understand
title: Emma

text: a bad one, or to lay down rules for it: you must let it go its own way.
title: Emma

text: I have no doubt of his having, at times, considerable influence; but it
title: Emma

text: may be perfectly impossible for him to know beforehand _when_ it will
title: Emma

text: be.”
title: Emma

text: Emma listened, and then coolly said, “I shall not be satisfied, unless
title: Emma

text: he comes.”
title: Emma

text: “He may have a great deal of influence on some points,” continued Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston, “and on others, very little: and among those, on which she is
title: Emma

text: beyond his reach, it is but too likely, may be this very circumstance
title: Emma

text: of his coming away from them to visit us.”
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XV
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse was soon ready for his tea; and when he had drank his tea
title: Emma

text: he was quite ready to go home; and it was as much as his three
title: Emma

text: companions could do, to entertain away his notice of the lateness of
title: Emma

text: the hour, before the other gentlemen appeared. Mr. Weston was chatty
title: Emma

text: and convivial, and no friend to early separations of any sort; but at
title: Emma

text: last the drawing-room party did receive an augmentation. Mr. Elton, in
title: Emma

text: very good spirits, was one of the first to walk in. Mrs. Weston and
title: Emma

text: Emma were sitting together on a sofa. He joined them immediately, and,
title: Emma

text: with scarcely an invitation, seated himself between them.
title: Emma

text: Emma, in good spirits too, from the amusement afforded her mind by the
title: Emma

text: expectation of Mr. Frank Churchill, was willing to forget his late
title: Emma

text: improprieties, and be as well satisfied with him as before, and on his
title: Emma

text: making Harriet his very first subject, was ready to listen with most
title: Emma

text: friendly smiles.
title: Emma

text: He professed himself extremely anxious about her fair friend—her fair,
title: Emma

text: lovely, amiable friend. “Did she know?—had she heard any thing about
title: Emma

text: her, since their being at Randalls?—he felt much anxiety—he must
title: Emma

text: confess that the nature of her complaint alarmed him considerably.” And
title: Emma

text: in this style he talked on for some time very properly, not much
title: Emma

text: attending to any answer, but altogether sufficiently awake to the
title: Emma

text: terror of a bad sore throat; and Emma was quite in charity with him.
title: Emma

text: But at last there seemed a perverse turn; it seemed all at once as if
title: Emma

text: he were more afraid of its being a bad sore throat on her account, than
title: Emma

text: on Harriet’s—more anxious that she should escape the infection, than
title: Emma

text: that there should be no infection in the complaint. He began with great
title: Emma

text: earnestness to entreat her to refrain from visiting the sick-chamber
title: Emma

text: again, for the present—to entreat her to _promise_ _him_ not to venture
title: Emma

text: into such hazard till he had seen Mr. Perry and learnt his opinion; and
title: Emma

text: though she tried to laugh it off and bring the subject back into its
title: Emma

text: proper course, there was no putting an end to his extreme solicitude
title: Emma

text: about her. She was vexed. It did appear—there was no concealing
title: Emma

text: it—exactly like the pretence of being in love with her, instead of
title: Emma

text: Harriet; an inconstancy, if real, the most contemptible and abominable!
title: Emma

text: and she had difficulty in behaving with temper. He turned to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston to implore her assistance, “Would not she give him her
title: Emma

text: support?—would not she add her persuasions to his, to induce Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse not to go to Mrs. Goddard’s till it were certain that Miss
title: Emma

text: Smith’s disorder had no infection? He could not be satisfied without a
title: Emma

text: promise—would not she give him her influence in procuring it?”
title: Emma

text: “So scrupulous for others,” he continued, “and yet so careless for
title: Emma

text: herself! She wanted me to nurse my cold by staying at home to-day, and
title: Emma

text: yet will not promise to avoid the danger of catching an ulcerated sore
title: Emma

text: throat herself. Is this fair, Mrs. Weston?—Judge between us. Have not I
title: Emma

text: some right to complain? I am sure of your kind support and aid.”
title: Emma

text: Emma saw Mrs. Weston’s surprize, and felt that it must be great, at an
title: Emma

text: address which, in words and manner, was assuming to himself the right
title: Emma

text: of first interest in her; and as for herself, she was too much provoked
title: Emma

text: and offended to have the power of directly saying any thing to the
title: Emma

text: purpose. She could only give him a look; but it was such a look as she
title: Emma

text: thought must restore him to his senses, and then left the sofa,
title: Emma

text: removing to a seat by her sister, and giving her all her attention.
title: Emma

text: She had not time to know how Mr. Elton took the reproof, so rapidly did
title: Emma

text: another subject succeed; for Mr. John Knightley now came into the room
title: Emma

text: from examining the weather, and opened on them all with the information
title: Emma

text: of the ground being covered with snow, and of its still snowing fast,
title: Emma

text: with a strong drifting wind; concluding with these words to Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse:
title: Emma

text: “This will prove a spirited beginning of your winter engagements, sir.
title: Emma

text: Something new for your coachman and horses to be making their way
title: Emma

text: through a storm of snow.”
title: Emma

text: Poor Mr. Woodhouse was silent from consternation; but every body else
title: Emma

text: had something to say; every body was either surprized or not surprized,
title: Emma

text: and had some question to ask, or some comfort to offer. Mrs. Weston and
title: Emma

text: Emma tried earnestly to cheer him and turn his attention from his
title: Emma

text: son-in-law, who was pursuing his triumph rather unfeelingly.
title: Emma

text: “I admired your resolution very much, sir,” said he, “in venturing out
title: Emma

text: in such weather, for of course you saw there would be snow very soon.
title: Emma

text: Every body must have seen the snow coming on. I admired your spirit;
title: Emma

text: and I dare say we shall get home very well. Another hour or two’s snow
title: Emma

text: can hardly make the road impassable; and we are two carriages; if one
title: Emma

text: is blown over in the bleak part of the common field there will be the
title: Emma

text: other at hand. I dare say we shall be all safe at Hartfield before
title: Emma

text: midnight.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston, with triumph of a different sort, was confessing that he
title: Emma

text: had known it to be snowing some time, but had not said a word, lest it
title: Emma

text: should make Mr. Woodhouse uncomfortable, and be an excuse for his
title: Emma

text: hurrying away. As to there being any quantity of snow fallen or likely
title: Emma

text: to fall to impede their return, that was a mere joke; he was afraid
title: Emma

text: they would find no difficulty. He wished the road might be impassable,
title: Emma

text: that he might be able to keep them all at Randalls; and with the utmost
title: Emma

text: good-will was sure that accommodation might be found for every body,
title: Emma

text: calling on his wife to agree with him, that with a little contrivance,
title: Emma

text: every body might be lodged, which she hardly knew how to do, from the
title: Emma

text: consciousness of there being but two spare rooms in the house.
title: Emma

text: “What is to be done, my dear Emma?—what is to be done?” was Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s first exclamation, and all that he could say for some time.
title: Emma

text: To her he looked for comfort; and her assurances of safety, her
title: Emma

text: representation of the excellence of the horses, and of James, and of
title: Emma

text: their having so many friends about them, revived him a little.
title: Emma

text: His eldest daughter’s alarm was equal to his own. The horror of being
title: Emma

text: blocked up at Randalls, while her children were at Hartfield, was full
title: Emma

text: in her imagination; and fancying the road to be now just passable for
title: Emma

text: adventurous people, but in a state that admitted no delay, she was
title: Emma

text: eager to have it settled, that her father and Emma should remain at
title: Emma

text: Randalls, while she and her husband set forward instantly through all
title: Emma

text: the possible accumulations of drifted snow that might impede them.
title: Emma

text: “You had better order the carriage directly, my love,” said she; “I
title: Emma

text: dare say we shall be able to get along, if we set off directly; and if
title: Emma

text: we do come to any thing very bad, I can get out and walk. I am not at
title: Emma

text: all afraid. I should not mind walking half the way. I could change my
title: Emma

text: shoes, you know, the moment I got home; and it is not the sort of thing
title: Emma

text: that gives me cold.”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed!” replied he. “Then, my dear Isabella, it is the most
title: Emma

text: extraordinary sort of thing in the world, for in general every thing
title: Emma

text: does give you cold. Walk home!—you are prettily shod for walking home,
title: Emma

text: I dare say. It will be bad enough for the horses.”
title: Emma

text: Isabella turned to Mrs. Weston for her approbation of the plan. Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston could only approve. Isabella then went to Emma; but Emma could
title: Emma

text: not so entirely give up the hope of their being all able to get away;
title: Emma

text: and they were still discussing the point, when Mr. Knightley, who had
title: Emma

text: left the room immediately after his brother’s first report of the snow,
title: Emma

text: came back again, and told them that he had been out of doors to
title: Emma

text: examine, and could answer for there not being the smallest difficulty
title: Emma

text: in their getting home, whenever they liked it, either now or an hour
title: Emma

text: hence. He had gone beyond the sweep—some way along the Highbury
title: Emma

text: road—the snow was nowhere above half an inch deep—in many places hardly
title: Emma

text: enough to whiten the ground; a very few flakes were falling at present,
title: Emma

text: but the clouds were parting, and there was every appearance of its
title: Emma

text: being soon over. He had seen the coachmen, and they both agreed with
title: Emma

text: him in there being nothing to apprehend.
title: Emma

text: To Isabella, the relief of such tidings was very great, and they were
title: Emma

text: scarcely less acceptable to Emma on her father’s account, who was
title: Emma

text: immediately set as much at ease on the subject as his nervous
title: Emma

text: constitution allowed; but the alarm that had been raised could not be
title: Emma

text: appeased so as to admit of any comfort for him while he continued at
title: Emma

text: Randalls. He was satisfied of there being no present danger in
title: Emma

text: returning home, but no assurances could convince him that it was safe
title: Emma

text: to stay; and while the others were variously urging and recommending,
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley and Emma settled it in a few brief sentences: thus—
title: Emma

text: “Your father will not be easy; why do not you go?”
title: Emma

text: “I am ready, if the others are.”
title: Emma

text: “Shall I ring the bell?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, do.”
title: Emma

text: And the bell was rung, and the carriages spoken for. A few minutes
title: Emma

text: more, and Emma hoped to see one troublesome companion deposited in his
title: Emma

text: own house, to get sober and cool, and the other recover his temper and
title: Emma

text: happiness when this visit of hardship were over.
title: Emma

text: The carriage came: and Mr. Woodhouse, always the first object on such
title: Emma

text: occasions, was carefully attended to his own by Mr. Knightley and Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston; but not all that either could say could prevent some renewal of
title: Emma

text: alarm at the sight of the snow which had actually fallen, and the
title: Emma

text: discovery of a much darker night than he had been prepared for. “He was
title: Emma

text: afraid they should have a very bad drive. He was afraid poor Isabella
title: Emma

text: would not like it. And there would be poor Emma in the carriage behind.
title: Emma

text: He did not know what they had best do. They must keep as much together
title: Emma

text: as they could;” and James was talked to, and given a charge to go very
title: Emma

text: slow and wait for the other carriage.
title: Emma

text: Isabella stept in after her father; John Knightley, forgetting that he
title: Emma

text: did not belong to their party, stept in after his wife very naturally;
title: Emma

text: so that Emma found, on being escorted and followed into the second
title: Emma

text: carriage by Mr. Elton, that the door was to be lawfully shut on them,
title: Emma

text: and that they were to have a tête-à-tête drive. It would not have been
title: Emma

text: the awkwardness of a moment, it would have been rather a pleasure,
title: Emma

text: previous to the suspicions of this very day; she could have talked to
title: Emma

text: him of Harriet, and the three-quarters of a mile would have seemed but
title: Emma

text: one. But now, she would rather it had not happened. She believed he had
title: Emma

text: been drinking too much of Mr. Weston’s good wine, and felt sure that he
title: Emma

text: would want to be talking nonsense.
title: Emma

text: To restrain him as much as might be, by her own manners, she was
title: Emma

text: immediately preparing to speak with exquisite calmness and gravity of
title: Emma

text: the weather and the night; but scarcely had she begun, scarcely had
title: Emma

text: they passed the sweep-gate and joined the other carriage, than she
title: Emma

text: found her subject cut up—her hand seized—her attention demanded, and
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton actually making violent love to her: availing himself of the
title: Emma

text: precious opportunity, declaring sentiments which must be already well
title: Emma

text: known, hoping—fearing—adoring—ready to die if she refused him; but
title: Emma

text: flattering himself that his ardent attachment and unequalled love and
title: Emma

text: unexampled passion could not fail of having some effect, and in short,
title: Emma

text: very much resolved on being seriously accepted as soon as possible. It
title: Emma

text: really was so. Without scruple—without apology—without much apparent
title: Emma

text: diffidence, Mr. Elton, the lover of Harriet, was professing himself
title: Emma

text: _her_ lover. She tried to stop him; but vainly; he would go on, and say
title: Emma

text: it all. Angry as she was, the thought of the moment made her resolve to
title: Emma

text: restrain herself when she did speak. She felt that half this folly must
title: Emma

text: be drunkenness, and therefore could hope that it might belong only to
title: Emma

text: the passing hour. Accordingly, with a mixture of the serious and the
title: Emma

text: playful, which she hoped would best suit his half and half state, she
title: Emma

text: replied,
title: Emma

text: “I am very much astonished, Mr. Elton. This to _me_! you forget
title: Emma

text: yourself—you take me for my friend—any message to Miss Smith I shall be
title: Emma

text: happy to deliver; but no more of this to _me_, if you please.”
title: Emma

text: “Miss Smith!—message to Miss Smith!—What could she possibly mean!”—And
title: Emma

text: he repeated her words with such assurance of accent, such boastful
title: Emma

text: pretence of amazement, that she could not help replying with quickness,
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton, this is the most extraordinary conduct! and I can account
title: Emma

text: for it only in one way; you are not yourself, or you could not speak
title: Emma

text: either to me, or of Harriet, in such a manner. Command yourself enough
title: Emma

text: to say no more, and I will endeavour to forget it.”
title: Emma

text: But Mr. Elton had only drunk wine enough to elevate his spirits, not at
title: Emma

text: all to confuse his intellects. He perfectly knew his own meaning; and
title: Emma

text: having warmly protested against her suspicion as most injurious, and
title: Emma

text: slightly touched upon his respect for Miss Smith as her friend,—but
title: Emma

text: acknowledging his wonder that Miss Smith should be mentioned at all,—he
title: Emma

text: resumed the subject of his own passion, and was very urgent for a
title: Emma

text: favourable answer.
title: Emma

text: As she thought less of his inebriety, she thought more of his
title: Emma

text: inconstancy and presumption; and with fewer struggles for politeness,
title: Emma

text: replied,
title: Emma

text: “It is impossible for me to doubt any longer. You have made yourself
title: Emma

text: too clear. Mr. Elton, my astonishment is much beyond any thing I can
title: Emma

text: express. After such behaviour, as I have witnessed during the last
title: Emma

text: month, to Miss Smith—such attentions as I have been in the daily habit
title: Emma

text: of observing—to be addressing me in this manner—this is an unsteadiness
title: Emma

text: of character, indeed, which I had not supposed possible! Believe me,
title: Emma

text: sir, I am far, very far, from gratified in being the object of such
title: Emma

text: professions.”
title: Emma

text: “Good Heaven!” cried Mr. Elton, “what can be the meaning of this?—Miss
title: Emma

text: Smith!—I never thought of Miss Smith in the whole course of my
title: Emma

text: existence—never paid her any attentions, but as your friend: never
title: Emma

text: cared whether she were dead or alive, but as your friend. If she has
title: Emma

text: fancied otherwise, her own wishes have misled her, and I am very
title: Emma

text: sorry—extremely sorry—But, Miss Smith, indeed!—Oh! Miss Woodhouse! who
title: Emma

text: can think of Miss Smith, when Miss Woodhouse is near! No, upon my
title: Emma

text: honour, there is no unsteadiness of character. I have thought only of
title: Emma

text: you. I protest against having paid the smallest attention to any one
title: Emma

text: else. Every thing that I have said or done, for many weeks past, has
title: Emma

text: been with the sole view of marking my adoration of yourself. You cannot
title: Emma

text: really, seriously, doubt it. No!—(in an accent meant to be
title: Emma

text: insinuating)—I am sure you have seen and understood me.”
title: Emma

text: It would be impossible to say what Emma felt, on hearing this—which of
title: Emma

text: all her unpleasant sensations was uppermost. She was too completely
title: Emma

text: overpowered to be immediately able to reply: and two moments of silence
title: Emma

text: being ample encouragement for Mr. Elton’s sanguine state of mind, he
title: Emma

text: tried to take her hand again, as he joyously exclaimed—
title: Emma

text: “Charming Miss Woodhouse! allow me to interpret this interesting
title: Emma

text: silence. It confesses that you have long understood me.”
title: Emma

text: “No, sir,” cried Emma, “it confesses no such thing. So far from having
title: Emma

text: long understood you, I have been in a most complete error with respect
title: Emma

text: to your views, till this moment. As to myself, I am very sorry that you
title: Emma

text: should have been giving way to any feelings—Nothing could be farther
title: Emma

text: from my wishes—your attachment to my friend Harriet—your pursuit of
title: Emma

text: her, (pursuit, it appeared,) gave me great pleasure, and I have been
title: Emma

text: very earnestly wishing you success: but had I supposed that she were
title: Emma

text: not your attraction to Hartfield, I should certainly have thought you
title: Emma

text: judged ill in making your visits so frequent. Am I to believe that you
title: Emma

text: have never sought to recommend yourself particularly to Miss
title: Emma

text: Smith?—that you have never thought seriously of her?”
title: Emma

text: “Never, madam,” cried he, affronted in his turn: “never, I assure you.
title: Emma

text: _I_ think seriously of Miss Smith!—Miss Smith is a very good sort of
title: Emma

text: girl; and I should be happy to see her respectably settled. I wish her
title: Emma

text: extremely well: and, no doubt, there are men who might not object
title: Emma

text: to—Every body has their level: but as for myself, I am not, I think,
title: Emma

text: quite so much at a loss. I need not so totally despair of an equal
title: Emma

text: alliance, as to be addressing myself to Miss Smith!—No, madam, my
title: Emma

text: visits to Hartfield have been for yourself only; and the encouragement
title: Emma

text: I received—”
title: Emma

text: “Encouragement!—I give you encouragement!—Sir, you have been entirely
title: Emma

text: mistaken in supposing it. I have seen you only as the admirer of my
title: Emma

text: friend. In no other light could you have been more to me than a common
title: Emma

text: acquaintance. I am exceedingly sorry: but it is well that the mistake
title: Emma

text: ends where it does. Had the same behaviour continued, Miss Smith might
title: Emma

text: have been led into a misconception of your views; not being aware,
title: Emma

text: probably, any more than myself, of the very great inequality which you
title: Emma

text: are so sensible of. But, as it is, the disappointment is single, and, I
title: Emma

text: trust, will not be lasting. I have no thoughts of matrimony at
title: Emma

text: present.”
title: Emma

text: He was too angry to say another word; her manner too decided to invite
title: Emma

text: supplication; and in this state of swelling resentment, and mutually
title: Emma

text: deep mortification, they had to continue together a few minutes longer,
title: Emma

text: for the fears of Mr. Woodhouse had confined them to a foot-pace. If
title: Emma

text: there had not been so much anger, there would have been desperate
title: Emma

text: awkwardness; but their straightforward emotions left no room for the
title: Emma

text: little zigzags of embarrassment. Without knowing when the carriage
title: Emma

text: turned into Vicarage Lane, or when it stopped, they found themselves,
title: Emma

text: all at once, at the door of his house; and he was out before another
title: Emma

text: syllable passed.—Emma then felt it indispensable to wish him a good
title: Emma

text: night. The compliment was just returned, coldly and proudly; and, under
title: Emma

text: indescribable irritation of spirits, she was then conveyed to
title: Emma

text: Hartfield.
title: Emma

text: There she was welcomed, with the utmost delight, by her father, who had
title: Emma

text: been trembling for the dangers of a solitary drive from Vicarage
title: Emma

text: Lane—turning a corner which he could never bear to think of—and in
title: Emma

text: strange hands—a mere common coachman—no James; and there it seemed as
title: Emma

text: if her return only were wanted to make every thing go well: for Mr.
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: attention; and so particularly solicitous for the comfort of her
title: Emma

text: father, as to seem—if not quite ready to join him in a basin of
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma
