title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVI
title: Emma

text: The hair was curled, and the maid sent away, and Emma sat down to think
title: Emma

text: and be miserable.—It was a wretched business indeed!—Such an overthrow
title: Emma

text: of every thing she had been wishing for!—Such a development of every
title: Emma

text: thing most unwelcome!—Such a blow for Harriet!—that was the worst of
title: Emma

text: all. Every part of it brought pain and humiliation, of some sort or
title: Emma

text: other; but, compared with the evil to Harriet, all was light; and she
title: Emma

text: would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken—more in
title: Emma

text: error—more disgraced by mis-judgment, than she actually was, could the
title: Emma

text: effects of her blunders have been confined to herself.
title: Emma

text: “If I had not persuaded Harriet into liking the man, I could have borne
title: Emma

text: any thing. He might have doubled his presumption to me—but poor
title: Emma

text: Harriet!”
title: Emma

text: How she could have been so deceived!—He protested that he had never
title: Emma

text: thought seriously of Harriet—never! She looked back as well as she
title: Emma

text: could; but it was all confusion. She had taken up the idea, she
title: Emma

text: supposed, and made every thing bend to it. His manners, however, must
title: Emma

text: have been unmarked, wavering, dubious, or she could not have been so
title: Emma

text: misled.
title: Emma

text: The picture!—How eager he had been about the picture!—and the
title: Emma

text: charade!—and an hundred other circumstances;—how clearly they had
title: Emma

text: seemed to point at Harriet. To be sure, the charade, with its “ready
title: Emma

text: wit”—but then the “soft eyes”—in fact it suited neither; it was a
title: Emma

text: jumble without taste or truth. Who could have seen through such
title: Emma

text: thick-headed nonsense?
title: Emma

text: Certainly she had often, especially of late, thought his manners to
title: Emma

text: herself unnecessarily gallant; but it had passed as his way, as a mere
title: Emma

text: error of judgment, of knowledge, of taste, as one proof among others
title: Emma

text: that he had not always lived in the best society, that with all the
title: Emma

text: gentleness of his address, true elegance was sometimes wanting; but,
title: Emma

text: till this very day, she had never, for an instant, suspected it to mean
title: Emma

text: any thing but grateful respect to her as Harriet’s friend.
title: Emma

text: To Mr. John Knightley was she indebted for her first idea on the
title: Emma

text: subject, for the first start of its possibility. There was no denying
title: Emma

text: that those brothers had penetration. She remembered what Mr. Knightley
title: Emma

text: had once said to her about Mr. Elton, the caution he had given, the
title: Emma

text: conviction he had professed that Mr. Elton would never marry
title: Emma

text: indiscreetly; and blushed to think how much truer a knowledge of his
title: Emma

text: character had been there shewn than any she had reached herself. It was
title: Emma

text: dreadfully mortifying; but Mr. Elton was proving himself, in many
title: Emma

text: respects, the very reverse of what she had meant and believed him;
title: Emma

text: proud, assuming, conceited; very full of his own claims, and little
title: Emma

text: concerned about the feelings of others.
title: Emma

text: Contrary to the usual course of things, Mr. Elton’s wanting to pay his
title: Emma

text: addresses to her had sunk him in her opinion. His professions and his
title: Emma

text: proposals did him no service. She thought nothing of his attachment,
title: Emma

text: and was insulted by his hopes. He wanted to marry well, and having the
title: Emma

text: arrogance to raise his eyes to her, pretended to be in love; but she
title: Emma

text: was perfectly easy as to his not suffering any disappointment that need
title: Emma

text: be cared for. There had been no real affection either in his language
title: Emma

text: or manners. Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance; but she
title: Emma

text: could hardly devise any set of expressions, or fancy any tone of voice,
title: Emma

text: less allied with real love. She need not trouble herself to pity him.
title: Emma

text: He only wanted to aggrandise and enrich himself; and if Miss Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: of Hartfield, the heiress of thirty thousand pounds, were not quite so
title: Emma

text: easily obtained as he had fancied, he would soon try for Miss Somebody
title: Emma

text: else with twenty, or with ten.
title: Emma

text: But—that he should talk of encouragement, should consider her as aware
title: Emma

text: of his views, accepting his attentions, meaning (in short), to marry
title: Emma

text: him!—should suppose himself her equal in connexion or mind!—look down
title: Emma

text: upon her friend, so well understanding the gradations of rank below
title: Emma

text: him, and be so blind to what rose above, as to fancy himself shewing no
title: Emma

text: presumption in addressing her!—It was most provoking.
title: Emma

text: Perhaps it was not fair to expect him to feel how very much he was her
title: Emma

text: inferior in talent, and all the elegancies of mind. The very want of
title: Emma

text: such equality might prevent his perception of it; but he must know that
title: Emma

text: in fortune and consequence she was greatly his superior. He must know
title: Emma

text: that the Woodhouses had been settled for several generations at
title: Emma

text: Hartfield, the younger branch of a very ancient family—and that the
title: Emma

text: Eltons were nobody. The landed property of Hartfield certainly was
title: Emma

text: inconsiderable, being but a sort of notch in the Donwell Abbey estate,
title: Emma

text: to which all the rest of Highbury belonged; but their fortune, from
title: Emma

text: other sources, was such as to make them scarcely secondary to Donwell
title: Emma

text: Abbey itself, in every other kind of consequence; and the Woodhouses
title: Emma

text: had long held a high place in the consideration of the neighbourhood
title: Emma

text: which Mr. Elton had first entered not two years ago, to make his way as
title: Emma

text: he could, without any alliances but in trade, or any thing to recommend
title: Emma

text: him to notice but his situation and his civility.—But he had fancied
title: Emma

text: her in love with him; that evidently must have been his dependence; and
title: Emma

text: after raving a little about the seeming incongruity of gentle manners
title: Emma

text: and a conceited head, Emma was obliged in common honesty to stop and
title: Emma

text: admit that her own behaviour to him had been so complaisant and
title: Emma

text: obliging, so full of courtesy and attention, as (supposing her real
title: Emma

text: motive unperceived) might warrant a man of ordinary observation and
title: Emma

text: delicacy, like Mr. Elton, in fancying himself a very decided favourite.
title: Emma

text: If _she_ had so misinterpreted his feelings, she had little right to
title: Emma

text: wonder that _he_, with self-interest to blind him, should have mistaken
title: Emma

text: hers.
title: Emma

text: The first error and the worst lay at her door. It was foolish, it was
title: Emma

text: wrong, to take so active a part in bringing any two people together. It
title: Emma

text: was adventuring too far, assuming too much, making light of what ought
title: Emma

text: to be serious, a trick of what ought to be simple. She was quite
title: Emma

text: concerned and ashamed, and resolved to do such things no more.
title: Emma

text: “Here have I,” said she, “actually talked poor Harriet into being very
title: Emma

text: much attached to this man. She might never have thought of him but for
title: Emma

text: me; and certainly never would have thought of him with hope, if I had
title: Emma

text: not assured her of his attachment, for she is as modest and humble as I
title: Emma

text: used to think him. Oh! that I had been satisfied with persuading her
title: Emma

text: not to accept young Martin. There I was quite right. That was well done
title: Emma

text: of me; but there I should have stopped, and left the rest to time and
title: Emma

text: chance. I was introducing her into good company, and giving her the
title: Emma

text: opportunity of pleasing some one worth having; I ought not to have
title: Emma

text: attempted more. But now, poor girl, her peace is cut up for some time.
title: Emma

text: I have been but half a friend to her; and if she were _not_ to feel
title: Emma

text: this disappointment so very much, I am sure I have not an idea of any
title: Emma

text: body else who would be at all desirable for her;—William Coxe—Oh! no, I
title: Emma

text: could not endure William Coxe—a pert young lawyer.”
title: Emma

text: She stopt to blush and laugh at her own relapse, and then resumed a
title: Emma

text: more serious, more dispiriting cogitation upon what had been, and might
title: Emma

text: be, and must be. The distressing explanation she had to make to
title: Emma

text: Harriet, and all that poor Harriet would be suffering, with the
title: Emma

text: awkwardness of future meetings, the difficulties of continuing or
title: Emma

text: discontinuing the acquaintance, of subduing feelings, concealing
title: Emma

text: resentment, and avoiding eclat, were enough to occupy her in most
title: Emma

text: unmirthful reflections some time longer, and she went to bed at last
title: Emma

text: with nothing settled but the conviction of her having blundered most
title: Emma

text: dreadfully.
title: Emma

text: To youth and natural cheerfulness like Emma’s, though under temporary
title: Emma

text: gloom at night, the return of day will hardly fail to bring return of
title: Emma

text: spirits. The youth and cheerfulness of morning are in happy analogy,
title: Emma

text: and of powerful operation; and if the distress be not poignant enough
title: Emma

text: to keep the eyes unclosed, they will be sure to open to sensations of
title: Emma

text: softened pain and brighter hope.
title: Emma

text: Emma got up on the morrow more disposed for comfort than she had gone
title: Emma

text: to bed, more ready to see alleviations of the evil before her, and to
title: Emma

text: depend on getting tolerably out of it.
title: Emma

text: It was a great consolation that Mr. Elton should not be really in love
title: Emma

text: with her, or so particularly amiable as to make it shocking to
title: Emma

text: disappoint him—that Harriet’s nature should not be of that superior
title: Emma

text: sort in which the feelings are most acute and retentive—and that there
title: Emma

text: could be no necessity for any body’s knowing what had passed except the
title: Emma

text: three principals, and especially for her father’s being given a
title: Emma

text: moment’s uneasiness about it.
title: Emma

text: These were very cheering thoughts; and the sight of a great deal of
title: Emma

text: snow on the ground did her further service, for any thing was welcome
title: Emma

text: that might justify their all three being quite asunder at present.
title: Emma

text: The weather was most favourable for her; though Christmas Day, she
title: Emma

text: could not go to church. Mr. Woodhouse would have been miserable had his
title: Emma

text: daughter attempted it, and she was therefore safe from either exciting
title: Emma

text: or receiving unpleasant and most unsuitable ideas. The ground covered
title: Emma

text: with snow, and the atmosphere in that unsettled state between frost and
title: Emma

text: thaw, which is of all others the most unfriendly for exercise, every
title: Emma

text: morning beginning in rain or snow, and every evening setting in to
title: Emma

text: freeze, she was for many days a most honourable prisoner. No
title: Emma

text: intercourse with Harriet possible but by note; no church for her on
title: Emma

text: Sunday any more than on Christmas Day; and no need to find excuses for
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton’s absenting himself.
title: Emma

text: It was weather which might fairly confine every body at home; and
title: Emma

text: though she hoped and believed him to be really taking comfort in some
title: Emma

text: society or other, it was very pleasant to have her father so well
title: Emma

text: satisfied with his being all alone in his own house, too wise to stir
title: Emma

text: out; and to hear him say to Mr. Knightley, whom no weather could keep
title: Emma

text: entirely from them,—
title: Emma

text: “Ah! Mr. Knightley, why do not you stay at home like poor Mr. Elton?”
title: Emma

text: These days of confinement would have been, but for her private
title: Emma

text: perplexities, remarkably comfortable, as such seclusion exactly suited
title: Emma

text: her brother, whose feelings must always be of great importance to his
title: Emma

text: companions; and he had, besides, so thoroughly cleared off his
title: Emma

text: ill-humour at Randalls, that his amiableness never failed him during
title: Emma

text: the rest of his stay at Hartfield. He was always agreeable and
title: Emma

text: obliging, and speaking pleasantly of every body. But with all the hopes
title: Emma

text: of cheerfulness, and all the present comfort of delay, there was still
title: Emma

text: such an evil hanging over her in the hour of explanation with Harriet,
title: Emma

text: as made it impossible for Emma to be ever perfectly at ease.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: Emma

text: Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley were not detained long at Hartfield. The
title: Emma

text: weather soon improved enough for those to move who must move; and Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse having, as usual, tried to persuade his daughter to stay
title: Emma

text: behind with all her children, was obliged to see the whole party set
title: Emma

text: off, and return to his lamentations over the destiny of poor
title: Emma

text: Isabella;—which poor Isabella, passing her life with those she doated
title: Emma

text: on, full of their merits, blind to their faults, and always innocently
title: Emma

text: busy, might have been a model of right feminine happiness.
title: Emma

text: The evening of the very day on which they went brought a note from Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton to Mr. Woodhouse, a long, civil, ceremonious note, to say, with
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton’s best compliments, “that he was proposing to leave Highbury
title: Emma

text: the following morning in his way to Bath; where, in compliance with the
title: Emma

text: pressing entreaties of some friends, he had engaged to spend a few
title: Emma

text: weeks, and very much regretted the impossibility he was under, from
title: Emma

text: various circumstances of weather and business, of taking a personal
title: Emma

text: leave of Mr. Woodhouse, of whose friendly civilities he should ever
title: Emma

text: retain a grateful sense—and had Mr. Woodhouse any commands, should be
title: Emma

text: happy to attend to them.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was most agreeably surprized.—Mr. Elton’s absence just at this
title: Emma

text: time was the very thing to be desired. She admired him for contriving
title: Emma

text: it, though not able to give him much credit for the manner in which it
title: Emma

text: was announced. Resentment could not have been more plainly spoken than
title: Emma

text: in a civility to her father, from which she was so pointedly excluded.
title: Emma

text: She had not even a share in his opening compliments.—Her name was not
title: Emma

text: mentioned;—and there was so striking a change in all this, and such an
title: Emma

text: ill-judged solemnity of leave-taking in his graceful acknowledgments,
title: Emma

text: as she thought, at first, could not escape her father’s suspicion.
title: Emma

text: It did, however.—Her father was quite taken up with the surprize of so
title: Emma

text: sudden a journey, and his fears that Mr. Elton might never get safely
title: Emma

text: to the end of it, and saw nothing extraordinary in his language. It was
title: Emma

text: a very useful note, for it supplied them with fresh matter for thought
title: Emma

text: and conversation during the rest of their lonely evening. Mr. Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: talked over his alarms, and Emma was in spirits to persuade them away
title: Emma

text: with all her usual promptitude.
title: Emma

text: She now resolved to keep Harriet no longer in the dark. She had reason
title: Emma

text: to believe her nearly recovered from her cold, and it was desirable
title: Emma

text: that she should have as much time as possible for getting the better of
title: Emma

text: her other complaint before the gentleman’s return. She went to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Goddard’s accordingly the very next day, to undergo the necessary
title: Emma

text: penance of communication; and a severe one it was.—She had to destroy
title: Emma

text: all the hopes which she had been so industriously feeding—to appear in
title: Emma

text: the ungracious character of the one preferred—and acknowledge herself
title: Emma

text: grossly mistaken and mis-judging in all her ideas on one subject, all
title: Emma

text: her observations, all her convictions, all her prophecies for the last
title: Emma

text: six weeks.
title: Emma

text: The confession completely renewed her first shame—and the sight of
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s tears made her think that she should never be in charity with
title: Emma

text: herself again.
title: Emma

text: Harriet bore the intelligence very well—blaming nobody—and in every
title: Emma

text: thing testifying such an ingenuousness of disposition and lowly opinion
title: Emma

text: of herself, as must appear with particular advantage at that moment to
title: Emma

text: her friend.
title: Emma

text: Emma was in the humour to value simplicity and modesty to the utmost;
title: Emma

text: and all that was amiable, all that ought to be attaching, seemed on
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s side, not her own. Harriet did not consider herself as having
title: Emma

text: any thing to complain of. The affection of such a man as Mr. Elton
title: Emma

text: would have been too great a distinction.—She never could have deserved
title: Emma

text: him—and nobody but so partial and kind a friend as Miss Woodhouse would
title: Emma

text: have thought it possible.
title: Emma

text: Her tears fell abundantly—but her grief was so truly artless, that no
title: Emma

text: dignity could have made it more respectable in Emma’s eyes—and she
title: Emma

text: listened to her and tried to console her with all her heart and
title: Emma

text: understanding—really for the time convinced that Harriet was the
title: Emma

text: superior creature of the two—and that to resemble her would be more for
title: Emma

text: her own welfare and happiness than all that genius or intelligence
title: Emma

text: could do.
title: Emma

text: It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple-minded and
title: Emma

text: ignorant; but she left her with every previous resolution confirmed of
title: Emma

text: being humble and discreet, and repressing imagination all the rest of
title: Emma

text: her life. Her second duty now, inferior only to her father’s claims,
title: Emma

text: was to promote Harriet’s comfort, and endeavour to prove her own
title: Emma

text: affection in some better method than by match-making. She got her to
title: Emma

text: Hartfield, and shewed her the most unvarying kindness, striving to
title: Emma

text: occupy and amuse her, and by books and conversation, to drive Mr. Elton
title: Emma

text: from her thoughts.
title: Emma

text: Time, she knew, must be allowed for this being thoroughly done; and she
title: Emma

text: could suppose herself but an indifferent judge of such matters in
title: Emma

text: general, and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton in particular; but it seemed to her reasonable that at Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: age, and with the entire extinction of all hope, such a progress might
title: Emma

text: be made towards a state of composure by the time of Mr. Elton’s return,
title: Emma

text: as to allow them all to meet again in the common routine of
title: Emma

text: acquaintance, without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing
title: Emma

text: them.
title: Emma

text: Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the non-existence
title: Emma

text: of any body equal to him in person or goodness—and did, in truth, prove
title: Emma

text: herself more resolutely in love than Emma had foreseen; but yet it
title: Emma

text: appeared to her so natural, so inevitable to strive against an
title: Emma

text: inclination of that sort _unrequited_, that she could not comprehend
title: Emma

text: its continuing very long in equal force.
title: Emma

text: If Mr. Elton, on his return, made his own indifference as evident and
title: Emma

text: indubitable as she could not doubt he would anxiously do, she could not
title: Emma

text: imagine Harriet’s persisting to place her happiness in the sight or the
title: Emma

text: recollection of him.
title: Emma

text: Their being fixed, so absolutely fixed, in the same place, was bad for
title: Emma

text: each, for all three. Not one of them had the power of removal, or of
title: Emma

text: effecting any material change of society. They must encounter each
title: Emma

text: other, and make the best of it.
title: Emma

text: Harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of her companions at Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Goddard’s; Mr. Elton being the adoration of all the teachers and great
title: Emma

text: girls in the school; and it must be at Hartfield only that she could
title: Emma

text: have any chance of hearing him spoken of with cooling moderation or
title: Emma

text: repellent truth. Where the wound had been given, there must the cure be
title: Emma

text: found if anywhere; and Emma felt that, till she saw her in the way of
title: Emma

text: cure, there could be no true peace for herself.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVIII
title: Emma

text: Mr. Frank Churchill did not come. When the time proposed drew near,
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston’s fears were justified in the arrival of a letter of
title: Emma

text: excuse. For the present, he could not be spared, to his “very great
title: Emma

text: mortification and regret; but still he looked forward with the hope of
title: Emma

text: coming to Randalls at no distant period.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston was exceedingly disappointed—much more disappointed, in
title: Emma

text: fact, than her husband, though her dependence on seeing the young man
title: Emma

text: had been so much more sober: but a sanguine temper, though for ever
title: Emma

text: expecting more good than occurs, does not always pay for its hopes by
title: Emma

text: any proportionate depression. It soon flies over the present failure,
title: Emma

text: and begins to hope again. For half an hour Mr. Weston was surprized and
title: Emma

text: sorry; but then he began to perceive that Frank’s coming two or three
title: Emma

text: months later would be a much better plan; better time of year; better
title: Emma

text: weather; and that he would be able, without any doubt, to stay
title: Emma

text: considerably longer with them than if he had come sooner.
title: Emma

text: These feelings rapidly restored his comfort, while Mrs. Weston, of a
title: Emma

text: more apprehensive disposition, foresaw nothing but a repetition of
title: Emma

text: excuses and delays; and after all her concern for what her husband was
title: Emma

text: to suffer, suffered a great deal more herself.
title: Emma

text: Emma was not at this time in a state of spirits to care really about
title: Emma

text: Mr. Frank Churchill’s not coming, except as a disappointment at
title: Emma

text: Randalls. The acquaintance at present had no charm for her. She wanted,
title: Emma

text: rather, to be quiet, and out of temptation; but still, as it was
title: Emma

text: desirable that she should appear, in general, like her usual self, she
title: Emma

text: took care to express as much interest in the circumstance, and enter as
title: Emma

text: warmly into Mr. and Mrs. Weston’s disappointment, as might naturally
title: Emma

text: belong to their friendship.
title: Emma

text: She was the first to announce it to Mr. Knightley; and exclaimed quite
title: Emma

text: as much as was necessary, (or, being acting a part, perhaps rather
title: Emma

text: more,) at the conduct of the Churchills, in keeping him away. She then
title: Emma

text: proceeded to say a good deal more than she felt, of the advantage of
title: Emma

text: such an addition to their confined society in Surry; the pleasure of
title: Emma

text: looking at somebody new; the gala-day to Highbury entire, which the
title: Emma

text: sight of him would have made; and ending with reflections on the
title: Emma

text: Churchills again, found herself directly involved in a disagreement
title: Emma

text: with Mr. Knightley; and, to her great amusement, perceived that she was
title: Emma

text: taking the other side of the question from her real opinion, and making
title: Emma

text: use of Mrs. Weston’s arguments against herself.
title: Emma

text: “The Churchills are very likely in fault,” said Mr. Knightley, coolly;
title: Emma

text: “but I dare say he might come if he would.”
title: Emma

text: “I do not know why you should say so. He wishes exceedingly to come;
title: Emma

text: but his uncle and aunt will not spare him.”
title: Emma

text: “I cannot believe that he has not the power of coming, if he made a
title: Emma

text: point of it. It is too unlikely, for me to believe it without proof.”
title: Emma

text: “How odd you are! What has Mr. Frank Churchill done, to make you
title: Emma

text: suppose him such an unnatural creature?”
title: Emma

text: “I am not supposing him at all an unnatural creature, in suspecting
title: Emma

text: that he may have learnt to be above his connexions, and to care very
title: Emma

text: little for any thing but his own pleasure, from living with those who
title: Emma

text: have always set him the example of it. It is a great deal more natural
title: Emma

text: than one could wish, that a young man, brought up by those who are
title: Emma

text: proud, luxurious, and selfish, should be proud, luxurious, and selfish
title: Emma

text: too. If Frank Churchill had wanted to see his father, he would have
title: Emma

text: contrived it between September and January. A man at his age—what is
title: Emma

text: he?—three or four-and-twenty—cannot be without the means of doing as
title: Emma

text: much as that. It is impossible.”
title: Emma

text: “That’s easily said, and easily felt by you, who have always been your
title: Emma

text: own master. You are the worst judge in the world, Mr. Knightley, of the
title: Emma

text: difficulties of dependence. You do not know what it is to have tempers
title: Emma

text: to manage.”
title: Emma

text: “It is not to be conceived that a man of three or four-and-twenty
title: Emma

text: should not have liberty of mind or limb to that amount. He cannot want
title: Emma

text: money—he cannot want leisure. We know, on the contrary, that he has so
title: Emma

text: much of both, that he is glad to get rid of them at the idlest haunts
title: Emma

text: in the kingdom. We hear of him for ever at some watering-place or
title: Emma

text: other. A little while ago, he was at Weymouth. This proves that he can
title: Emma

text: leave the Churchills.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, sometimes he can.”
title: Emma

text: “And those times are whenever he thinks it worth his while; whenever
title: Emma

text: there is any temptation of pleasure.”
title: Emma

text: “It is very unfair to judge of any body’s conduct, without an intimate
title: Emma

text: knowledge of their situation. Nobody, who has not been in the interior
title: Emma

text: of a family, can say what the difficulties of any individual of that
title: Emma

text: family may be. We ought to be acquainted with Enscombe, and with Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Churchill’s temper, before we pretend to decide upon what her nephew
title: Emma

text: can do. He may, at times, be able to do a great deal more than he can
title: Emma

text: at others.”
title: Emma

text: “There is one thing, Emma, which a man can always do, if he chuses, and
title: Emma

text: that is, his duty; not by manoeuvring and finessing, but by vigour and
title: Emma

text: resolution. It is Frank Churchill’s duty to pay this attention to his
title: Emma

text: father. He knows it to be so, by his promises and messages; but if he
title: Emma

text: wished to do it, it might be done. A man who felt rightly would say at
title: Emma

text: once, simply and resolutely, to Mrs. Churchill—‘Every sacrifice of mere
title: Emma

text: pleasure you will always find me ready to make to your convenience; but
title: Emma

text: I must go and see my father immediately. I know he would be hurt by my
title: Emma

text: failing in such a mark of respect to him on the present occasion. I
title: Emma

text: shall, therefore, set off to-morrow.’—If he would say so to her at
title: Emma

text: once, in the tone of decision becoming a man, there would be no
title: Emma

text: opposition made to his going.”
title: Emma

text: “No,” said Emma, laughing; “but perhaps there might be some made to his
title: Emma

text: coming back again. Such language for a young man entirely dependent, to
title: Emma

text: use!—Nobody but you, Mr. Knightley, would imagine it possible. But you
title: Emma

text: have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly opposite
title: Emma

text: to your own. Mr. Frank Churchill to be making such a speech as that to
title: Emma

text: the uncle and aunt, who have brought him up, and are to provide for
title: Emma

text: him!—Standing up in the middle of the room, I suppose, and speaking as
title: Emma

text: loud as he could!—How can you imagine such conduct practicable?”
title: Emma

text: “Depend upon it, Emma, a sensible man would find no difficulty in it.
title: Emma

text: He would feel himself in the right; and the declaration—made, of
title: Emma

text: course, as a man of sense would make it, in a proper manner—would do
title: Emma

text: him more good, raise him higher, fix his interest stronger with the
title: Emma

text: people he depended on, than all that a line of shifts and expedients
title: Emma

text: can ever do. Respect would be added to affection. They would feel that
title: Emma

text: they could trust him; that the nephew who had done rightly by his
title: Emma

text: father, would do rightly by them; for they know, as well as he does, as
title: Emma

text: well as all the world must know, that he ought to pay this visit to his
title: Emma

text: father; and while meanly exerting their power to delay it, are in their
title: Emma

text: hearts not thinking the better of him for submitting to their whims.
title: Emma

text: Respect for right conduct is felt by every body. If he would act in
title: Emma

text: this sort of manner, on principle, consistently, regularly, their
title: Emma

text: little minds would bend to his.”
title: Emma

text: “I rather doubt that. You are very fond of bending little minds; but
title: Emma

text: where little minds belong to rich people in authority, I think they
title: Emma

text: have a knack of swelling out, till they are quite as unmanageable as
title: Emma

text: great ones. I can imagine, that if you, as you are, Mr. Knightley, were
title: Emma

text: to be transported and placed all at once in Mr. Frank Churchill’s
title: Emma

text: situation, you would be able to say and do just what you have been
title: Emma

text: recommending for him; and it might have a very good effect. The
title: Emma

text: Churchills might not have a word to say in return; but then, you would
title: Emma

text: have no habits of early obedience and long observance to break through.
title: Emma

text: To him who has, it might not be so easy to burst forth at once into
title: Emma

text: perfect independence, and set all their claims on his gratitude and
title: Emma

text: regard at nought. He may have as strong a sense of what would be right,
title: Emma

text: as you can have, without being so equal, under particular
title: Emma

text: circumstances, to act up to it.”
title: Emma

text: “Then it would not be so strong a sense. If it failed to produce equal
title: Emma

text: exertion, it could not be an equal conviction.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh, the difference of situation and habit! I wish you would try to
title: Emma

text: understand what an amiable young man may be likely to feel in directly
title: Emma

text: opposing those, whom as child and boy he has been looking up to all his
title: Emma

text: life.”
title: Emma

text: “Our amiable young man is a very weak young man, if this be the first
title: Emma

text: occasion of his carrying through a resolution to do right against the
title: Emma

text: will of others. It ought to have been a habit with him by this time, of
title: Emma

text: following his duty, instead of consulting expediency. I can allow for
title: Emma

text: the fears of the child, but not of the man. As he became rational, he
title: Emma

text: ought to have roused himself and shaken off all that was unworthy in
title: Emma

text: their authority. He ought to have opposed the first attempt on their
title: Emma

text: side to make him slight his father. Had he begun as he ought, there
title: Emma

text: would have been no difficulty now.”
title: Emma

text: “We shall never agree about him,” cried Emma; “but that is nothing
title: Emma

text: extraordinary. I have not the least idea of his being a weak young man:
title: Emma

text: I feel sure that he is not. Mr. Weston would not be blind to folly,
title: Emma

text: though in his own son; but he is very likely to have a more yielding,
title: Emma

text: complying, mild disposition than would suit your notions of man’s
title: Emma

text: perfection. I dare say he has; and though it may cut him off from some
title: Emma

text: advantages, it will secure him many others.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; all the advantages of sitting still when he ought to move, and of
title: Emma

text: leading a life of mere idle pleasure, and fancying himself extremely
title: Emma

text: expert in finding excuses for it. He can sit down and write a fine
title: Emma

text: flourishing letter, full of professions and falsehoods, and persuade
title: Emma

text: himself that he has hit upon the very best method in the world of
title: Emma

text: preserving peace at home and preventing his father’s having any right
title: Emma

text: to complain. His letters disgust me.”
title: Emma

text: “Your feelings are singular. They seem to satisfy every body else.”
title: Emma

text: “I suspect they do not satisfy Mrs. Weston. They hardly can satisfy a
title: Emma

text: woman of her good sense and quick feelings: standing in a mother’s
title: Emma

text: place, but without a mother’s affection to blind her. It is on her
title: Emma

text: account that attention to Randalls is doubly due, and she must doubly
title: Emma

text: feel the omission. Had she been a person of consequence herself, he
title: Emma

text: would have come I dare say; and it would not have signified whether he
title: Emma

text: did or no. Can you think your friend behindhand in these sort of
title: Emma

text: considerations? Do you suppose she does not often say all this to
title: Emma

text: herself? No, Emma, your amiable young man can be amiable only in
title: Emma

text: French, not in English. He may be very ‘amiable,’ have very good
title: Emma

text: manners, and be very agreeable; but he can have no English delicacy
title: Emma

text: towards the feelings of other people: nothing really amiable about
title: Emma

text: him.”
title: Emma

text: “You seem determined to think ill of him.”
title: Emma

text: “Me!—not at all,” replied Mr. Knightley, rather displeased; “I do not
title: Emma

text: want to think ill of him. I should be as ready to acknowledge his
title: Emma

text: merits as any other man; but I hear of none, except what are merely
title: Emma

text: personal; that he is well-grown and good-looking, with smooth,
title: Emma

text: plausible manners.”
title: Emma

text: “Well, if he have nothing else to recommend him, he will be a treasure
title: Emma

text: at Highbury. We do not often look upon fine young men, well-bred and
title: Emma

text: agreeable. We must not be nice and ask for all the virtues into the
title: Emma

text: bargain. Cannot you imagine, Mr. Knightley, what a _sensation_ his
title: Emma

text: coming will produce? There will be but one subject throughout the
title: Emma

text: parishes of Donwell and Highbury; but one interest—one object of
title: Emma

text: curiosity; it will be all Mr. Frank Churchill; we shall think and speak
title: Emma

text: of nobody else.”
title: Emma

text: “You will excuse my being so much over-powered. If I find him
title: Emma

text: conversable, I shall be glad of his acquaintance; but if he is only a
title: Emma

text: chattering coxcomb, he will not occupy much of my time or thoughts.”
title: Emma

text: “My idea of him is, that he can adapt his conversation to the taste of
title: Emma

text: every body, and has the power as well as the wish of being universally
title: Emma

text: agreeable. To you, he will talk of farming; to me, of drawing or music;
title: Emma

text: and so on to every body, having that general information on all
title: Emma

text: subjects which will enable him to follow the lead, or take the lead,
title: Emma

text: just as propriety may require, and to speak extremely well on each;
title: Emma

text: that is my idea of him.”
title: Emma

text: “And mine,” said Mr. Knightley warmly, “is, that if he turn out any
title: Emma

text: thing like it, he will be the most insufferable fellow breathing! What!
title: Emma

text: at three-and-twenty to be the king of his company—the great man—the
title: Emma

text: practised politician, who is to read every body’s character, and make
title: Emma

text: every body’s talents conduce to the display of his own superiority; to
title: Emma

text: be dispensing his flatteries around, that he may make all appear like
title: Emma

text: fools compared with himself! My dear Emma, your own good sense could
title: Emma

text: not endure such a puppy when it came to the point.”
title: Emma

text: “I will say no more about him,” cried Emma, “you turn every thing to
title: Emma

text: evil. We are both prejudiced; you against, I for him; and we have no
title: Emma

text: chance of agreeing till he is really here.”
title: Emma

text: “Prejudiced! I am not prejudiced.”
title: Emma

text: “But I am very much, and without being at all ashamed of it. My love
title: Emma

text: for Mr. and Mrs. Weston gives me a decided prejudice in his favour.”
title: Emma

text: “He is a person I never think of from one month’s end to another,” said
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, with a degree of vexation, which made Emma immediately
title: Emma

text: talk of something else, though she could not comprehend why he should
title: Emma

text: be angry.
title: Emma

text: To take a dislike to a young man, only because he appeared to be of a
title: Emma

text: different disposition from himself, was unworthy the real liberality of
title: Emma

text: mind which she was always used to acknowledge in him; for with all the
title: Emma

text: high opinion of himself, which she had often laid to his charge, she
title: Emma

text: had never before for a moment supposed it could make him unjust to the
title: Emma

text: merit of another.

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER I
title: Emma

text: Emma and Harriet had been walking together one morning, and, in Emma’s
title: Emma

text: opinion, had been talking enough of Mr. Elton for that day. She could
title: Emma

text: not think that Harriet’s solace or her own sins required more; and she
title: Emma

text: was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject as they
title: Emma

text: returned;—but it burst out again when she thought she had succeeded,
title: Emma

text: and after speaking some time of what the poor must suffer in winter,
title: Emma

text: and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive—“Mr. Elton is so
title: Emma

text: good to the poor!” she found something else must be done.
title: Emma

text: They were just approaching the house where lived Mrs. and Miss Bates.
title: Emma

text: She determined to call upon them and seek safety in numbers. There was
title: Emma

text: always sufficient reason for such an attention; Mrs. and Miss Bates
title: Emma

text: loved to be called on, and she knew she was considered by the very few
title: Emma

text: who presumed ever to see imperfection in her, as rather negligent in
title: Emma

text: that respect, and as not contributing what she ought to the stock of
title: Emma

text: their scanty comforts.
title: Emma

text: She had had many a hint from Mr. Knightley and some from her own heart,
title: Emma

text: as to her deficiency—but none were equal to counteract the persuasion
title: Emma

text: of its being very disagreeable,—a waste of time—tiresome women—and all
title: Emma

text: the horror of being in danger of falling in with the second-rate and
title: Emma

text: third-rate of Highbury, who were calling on them for ever, and
title: Emma

text: therefore she seldom went near them. But now she made the sudden
title: Emma

text: resolution of not passing their door without going in—observing, as she
title: Emma

text: proposed it to Harriet, that, as well as she could calculate, they were
title: Emma

text: just now quite safe from any letter from Jane Fairfax.
title: Emma

text: The house belonged to people in business. Mrs. and Miss Bates occupied
title: Emma

text: the drawing-room floor; and there, in the very moderate-sized
title: Emma

text: apartment, which was every thing to them, the visitors were most
title: Emma

text: cordially and even gratefully welcomed; the quiet neat old lady, who
title: Emma

text: with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner, wanting even to
title: Emma

text: give up her place to Miss Woodhouse, and her more active, talking
title: Emma

text: daughter, almost ready to overpower them with care and kindness, thanks
title: Emma

text: for their visit, solicitude for their shoes, anxious inquiries after
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse’s health, cheerful communications about her mother’s, and
title: Emma

text: sweet-cake from the beaufet—“Mrs. Cole had just been there, just called
title: Emma

text: in for ten minutes, and had been so good as to sit an hour with them,
title: Emma

text: and _she_ had taken a piece of cake and been so kind as to say she
title: Emma

text: liked it very much; and, therefore, she hoped Miss Woodhouse and Miss
title: Emma

text: Smith would do them the favour to eat a piece too.”
title: Emma

text: The mention of the Coles was sure to be followed by that of Mr. Elton.
title: Emma

text: There was intimacy between them, and Mr. Cole had heard from Mr. Elton
title: Emma

text: since his going away. Emma knew what was coming; they must have the
title: Emma

text: letter over again, and settle how long he had been gone, and how much
title: Emma

text: he was engaged in company, and what a favourite he was wherever he
title: Emma

text: went, and how full the Master of the Ceremonies’ ball had been; and she
title: Emma

text: went through it very well, with all the interest and all the
title: Emma

text: commendation that could be requisite, and always putting forward to
title: Emma

text: prevent Harriet’s being obliged to say a word.
title: Emma

text: This she had been prepared for when she entered the house; but meant,
title: Emma

text: having once talked him handsomely over, to be no farther incommoded by
title: Emma

text: any troublesome topic, and to wander at large amongst all the
title: Emma

text: Mistresses and Misses of Highbury, and their card-parties. She had not
title: Emma

text: been prepared to have Jane Fairfax succeed Mr. Elton; but he was
title: Emma

text: actually hurried off by Miss Bates, she jumped away from him at last
title: Emma

text: abruptly to the Coles, to usher in a letter from her niece.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes—Mr. Elton, I understand—certainly as to dancing—Mrs. Cole was
title: Emma

text: telling me that dancing at the rooms at Bath was—Mrs. Cole was so kind
title: Emma

text: as to sit some time with us, talking of Jane; for as soon as she came
title: Emma

text: in, she began inquiring after her, Jane is so very great a favourite
title: Emma

text: there. Whenever she is with us, Mrs. Cole does not know how to shew her
title: Emma

text: kindness enough; and I must say that Jane deserves it as much as any
title: Emma

text: body can. And so she began inquiring after her directly, saying, ‘I
title: Emma

text: know you cannot have heard from Jane lately, because it is not her time
title: Emma

text: for writing;’ and when I immediately said, ‘But indeed we have, we had
title: Emma

text: a letter this very morning,’ I do not know that I ever saw any body
title: Emma

text: more surprized. ‘Have you, upon your honour?’ said she; ‘well, that is
title: Emma

text: quite unexpected. Do let me hear what she says.’”
title: Emma

text: Emma’s politeness was at hand directly, to say, with smiling interest—
title: Emma

text: “Have you heard from Miss Fairfax so lately? I am extremely happy. I
title: Emma

text: hope she is well?”
title: Emma

text: “Thank you. You are so kind!” replied the happily deceived aunt, while
title: Emma

text: eagerly hunting for the letter.—“Oh! here it is. I was sure it could
title: Emma

text: not be far off; but I had put my huswife upon it, you see, without
title: Emma

text: being aware, and so it was quite hid, but I had it in my hand so very
title: Emma

text: lately that I was almost sure it must be on the table. I was reading it
title: Emma

text: to Mrs. Cole, and since she went away, I was reading it again to my
title: Emma

text: mother, for it is such a pleasure to her—a letter from Jane—that she
title: Emma

text: can never hear it often enough; so I knew it could not be far off, and
title: Emma

text: here it is, only just under my huswife—and since you are so kind as to
title: Emma

text: wish to hear what she says;—but, first of all, I really must, in
title: Emma

text: justice to Jane, apologise for her writing so short a letter—only two
title: Emma

text: pages you see—hardly two—and in general she fills the whole paper and
title: Emma

text: crosses half. My mother often wonders that I can make it out so well.
title: Emma

text: She often says, when the letter is first opened, ‘Well, Hetty, now I
title: Emma

text: think you will be put to it to make out all that checker-work’—don’t
title: Emma

text: you, ma’am?—And then I tell her, I am sure she would contrive to make
title: Emma

text: it out herself, if she had nobody to do it for her—every word of it—I
title: Emma

text: am sure she would pore over it till she had made out every word. And,
title: Emma

text: indeed, though my mother’s eyes are not so good as they were, she can
title: Emma

text: see amazingly well still, thank God! with the help of spectacles. It is
title: Emma

text: such a blessing! My mother’s are really very good indeed. Jane often
title: Emma

text: says, when she is here, ‘I am sure, grandmama, you must have had very
title: Emma

text: strong eyes to see as you do—and so much fine work as you have done
title: Emma

text: too!—I only wish my eyes may last me as well.’”
title: Emma

text: All this spoken extremely fast obliged Miss Bates to stop for breath;
title: Emma

text: and Emma said something very civil about the excellence of Miss
title: Emma

text: Fairfax’s handwriting.
title: Emma

text: “You are extremely kind,” replied Miss Bates, highly gratified; “you
title: Emma

text: who are such a judge, and write so beautifully yourself. I am sure
title: Emma

text: there is nobody’s praise that could give us so much pleasure as Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s. My mother does not hear; she is a little deaf you know.
title: Emma

text: Ma’am,” addressing her, “do you hear what Miss Woodhouse is so obliging
title: Emma

text: to say about Jane’s handwriting?”
title: Emma

text: And Emma had the advantage of hearing her own silly compliment repeated
title: Emma

text: twice over before the good old lady could comprehend it. She was
title: Emma

text: pondering, in the meanwhile, upon the possibility, without seeming very
title: Emma

text: rude, of making her escape from Jane Fairfax’s letter, and had almost
title: Emma

text: resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse, when Miss
title: Emma

text: Bates turned to her again and seized her attention.
title: Emma

text: “My mother’s deafness is very trifling you see—just nothing at all. By
title: Emma

text: only raising my voice, and saying any thing two or three times over,
title: Emma

text: she is sure to hear; but then she is used to my voice. But it is very
title: Emma

text: remarkable that she should always hear Jane better than she does me.
title: Emma

text: Jane speaks so distinct! However, she will not find her grandmama at
title: Emma

text: all deafer than she was two years ago; which is saying a great deal at
title: Emma

text: my mother’s time of life—and it really is full two years, you know,
title: Emma

text: since she was here. We never were so long without seeing her before,
title: Emma

text: and as I was telling Mrs. Cole, we shall hardly know how to make enough
title: Emma

text: of her now.”
title: Emma

text: “Are you expecting Miss Fairfax here soon?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh yes; next week.”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed!—that must be a very great pleasure.”
title: Emma

text: “Thank you. You are very kind. Yes, next week. Every body is so
title: Emma

text: surprized; and every body says the same obliging things. I am sure she
title: Emma

text: will be as happy to see her friends at Highbury, as they can be to see
title: Emma

text: her. Yes, Friday or Saturday; she cannot say which, because Colonel
title: Emma

text: Campbell will be wanting the carriage himself one of those days. So
title: Emma

text: very good of them to send her the whole way! But they always do, you
title: Emma

text: know. Oh yes, Friday or Saturday next. That is what she writes about.
title: Emma

text: That is the reason of her writing out of rule, as we call it; for, in
title: Emma

text: the common course, we should not have heard from her before next
title: Emma

text: Tuesday or Wednesday.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, so I imagined. I was afraid there could be little chance of my
title: Emma

text: hearing any thing of Miss Fairfax to-day.”
title: Emma

text: “So obliging of you! No, we should not have heard, if it had not been
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: mother is so delighted!—for she is to be three months with us at least.
title: Emma

text: Three months, she says so, positively, as I am going to have the
title: Emma

text: pleasure of reading to you. The case is, you see, that the Campbells
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: married, last October, she was never away from them so much as a week,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: things.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: me, as to that. I always make a point of reading Jane’s letters through
title: Emma

text: to myself first, before I read them aloud to my mother, you know, for
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER II
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax was an orphan, the only child of Mrs. Bates’s youngest
title: Emma

text: daughter.
title: Emma

text: The marriage of Lieut. Fairfax of the ——regiment of infantry, and Miss
title: Emma

text: Jane Bates, had had its day of fame and pleasure, hope and interest;
title: Emma

text: but nothing now remained of it, save the melancholy remembrance of him
title: Emma

text: dying in action abroad—of his widow sinking under consumption and grief
title: Emma

text: soon afterwards—and this girl.
title: Emma

text: By birth she belonged to Highbury: and when at three years old, on
title: Emma

text: losing her mother, she became the property, the charge, the
title: Emma

text: consolation, the foundling of her grandmother and aunt, there had
title: Emma

text: seemed every probability of her being permanently fixed there; of her
title: Emma

text: being taught only what very limited means could command, and growing up
title: Emma

text: with no advantages of connexion or improvement, to be engrafted on what
title: Emma

text: nature had given her in a pleasing person, good understanding, and
title: Emma

text: warm-hearted, well-meaning relations.
title: Emma

text: But the compassionate feelings of a friend of her father gave a change
title: Emma

text: to her destiny. This was Colonel Campbell, who had very highly regarded
title: Emma

text: Fairfax, as an excellent officer and most deserving young man; and
title: Emma

text: farther, had been indebted to him for such attentions, during a severe
title: Emma

text: camp-fever, as he believed had saved his life. These were claims which
title: Emma

text: he did not learn to overlook, though some years passed away from the
title: Emma

text: death of poor Fairfax, before his own return to England put any thing
title: Emma

text: in his power. When he did return, he sought out the child and took
title: Emma

text: notice of her. He was a married man, with only one living child, a
title: Emma

text: girl, about Jane’s age: and Jane became their guest, paying them long
title: Emma

text: visits and growing a favourite with all; and before she was nine years
title: Emma

text: old, his daughter’s great fondness for her, and his own wish of being a
title: Emma

text: real friend, united to produce an offer from Colonel Campbell of
title: Emma

text: undertaking the whole charge of her education. It was accepted; and
title: Emma

text: from that period Jane had belonged to Colonel Campbell’s family, and
title: Emma

text: had lived with them entirely, only visiting her grandmother from time
title: Emma

text: to time.
title: Emma

text: The plan was that she should be brought up for educating others; the
title: Emma

text: very few hundred pounds which she inherited from her father making
title: Emma

text: independence impossible. To provide for her otherwise was out of
title: Emma

text: Colonel Campbell’s power; for though his income, by pay and
title: Emma

text: appointments, was handsome, his fortune was moderate and must be all
title: Emma

text: his daughter’s; but, by giving her an education, he hoped to be
title: Emma

text: supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter.
title: Emma

text: Such was Jane Fairfax’s history. She had fallen into good hands, known
title: Emma

text: nothing but kindness from the Campbells, and been given an excellent
title: Emma

text: education. Living constantly with right-minded and well-informed
title: Emma

text: people, her heart and understanding had received every advantage of
title: Emma

text: discipline and culture; and Colonel Campbell’s residence being in
title: Emma

text: London, every lighter talent had been done full justice to, by the
title: Emma

text: attendance of first-rate masters. Her disposition and abilities were
title: Emma

text: equally worthy of all that friendship could do; and at eighteen or
title: Emma

text: nineteen she was, as far as such an early age can be qualified for the
title: Emma

text: care of children, fully competent to the office of instruction herself;
title: Emma

text: but she was too much beloved to be parted with. Neither father nor
title: Emma

text: mother could promote, and the daughter could not endure it. The evil
title: Emma

text: day was put off. It was easy to decide that she was still too young;
title: Emma

text: and Jane remained with them, sharing, as another daughter, in all the
title: Emma

text: rational pleasures of an elegant society, and a judicious mixture of
title: Emma

text: home and amusement, with only the drawback of the future, the sobering
title: Emma

text: suggestions of her own good understanding to remind her that all this
title: Emma

text: might soon be over.
title: Emma

text: The affection of the whole family, the warm attachment of Miss Campbell
title: Emma

text: in particular, was the more honourable to each party from the
title: Emma

text: circumstance of Jane’s decided superiority both in beauty and
title: Emma

text: acquirements. That nature had given it in feature could not be unseen
title: Emma

text: by the young woman, nor could her higher powers of mind be unfelt by
title: Emma

text: the parents. They continued together with unabated regard however, till
title: Emma

text: the marriage of Miss Campbell, who by that chance, that luck which so
title: Emma

text: often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs, giving attraction to
title: Emma

text: what is moderate rather than to what is superior, engaged the
title: Emma

text: affections of Mr. Dixon, a young man, rich and agreeable, almost as
title: Emma

text: soon as they were acquainted; and was eligibly and happily settled,
title: Emma

text: while Jane Fairfax had yet her bread to earn.
title: Emma

text: This event had very lately taken place; too lately for any thing to be
title: Emma

text: yet attempted by her less fortunate friend towards entering on her path
title: Emma

text: of duty; though she had now reached the age which her own judgment had
title: Emma

text: fixed on for beginning. She had long resolved that one-and-twenty
title: Emma

text: should be the period. With the fortitude of a devoted novitiate, she
title: Emma

text: had resolved at one-and-twenty to complete the sacrifice, and retire
title: Emma

text: from all the pleasures of life, of rational intercourse, equal society,
title: Emma

text: peace and hope, to penance and mortification for ever.
title: Emma

text: The good sense of Colonel and Mrs. Campbell could not oppose such a
title: Emma

text: resolution, though their feelings did. As long as they lived, no
title: Emma

text: exertions would be necessary, their home might be hers for ever; and
title: Emma

text: for their own comfort they would have retained her wholly; but this
title: Emma

text: would be selfishness:—what must be at last, had better be soon. Perhaps
title: Emma

text: they began to feel it might have been kinder and wiser to have resisted
title: Emma

text: the temptation of any delay, and spared her from a taste of such
title: Emma

text: enjoyments of ease and leisure as must now be relinquished. Still,
title: Emma

text: however, affection was glad to catch at any reasonable excuse for not
title: Emma

text: hurrying on the wretched moment. She had never been quite well since
title: Emma

text: the time of their daughter’s marriage; and till she should have
title: Emma

text: completely recovered her usual strength, they must forbid her engaging
title: Emma

text: in duties, which, so far from being compatible with a weakened frame
title: Emma

text: and varying spirits, seemed, under the most favourable circumstances,
title: Emma

text: to require something more than human perfection of body and mind to be
title: Emma

text: discharged with tolerable comfort.
title: Emma

text: With regard to her not accompanying them to Ireland, her account to her
title: Emma

text: aunt contained nothing but truth, though there might be some truths not
title: Emma

text: told. It was her own choice to give the time of their absence to
title: Emma

text: Highbury; to spend, perhaps, her last months of perfect liberty with
title: Emma

text: those kind relations to whom she was so very dear: and the Campbells,
title: Emma

text: whatever might be their motive or motives, whether single, or double,
title: Emma

text: or treble, gave the arrangement their ready sanction, and said, that
title: Emma

text: they depended more on a few months spent in her native air, for the
title: Emma

text: recovery of her health, than on any thing else. Certain it was that she
title: Emma

text: was to come; and that Highbury, instead of welcoming that perfect
title: Emma

text: novelty which had been so long promised it—Mr. Frank Churchill—must put
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: freshness of a two years’ absence.
title: Emma

text: Emma was sorry;—to have to pay civilities to a person she did not like
title: Emma

text: through three long months!—to be always doing more than she wished, and
title: Emma

text: less than she ought! Why she did not like Jane Fairfax might be a
title: Emma

text: difficult question to answer; Mr. Knightley had once told her it was
title: Emma

text: because she saw in her the really accomplished young woman, which she
title: Emma

text: wanted to be thought herself; and though the accusation had been
title: Emma

text: eagerly refuted at the time, there were moments of self-examination in
title: Emma

text: which her conscience could not quite acquit her. But “she could never
title: Emma

text: get acquainted with her: she did not know how it was, but there was
title: Emma

text: such coldness and reserve—such apparent indifference whether she
title: Emma

text: pleased or not—and then, her aunt was such an eternal talker!—and she
title: Emma

text: was made such a fuss with by every body!—and it had been always
title: Emma

text: imagined that they were to be so intimate—because their ages were the
title: Emma

text: same, every body had supposed they must be so fond of each other.”
title: Emma

text: These were her reasons—she had no better.
title: Emma

text: It was a dislike so little just—every imputed fault was so magnified by
title: Emma

text: fancy, that she never saw Jane Fairfax the first time after any
title: Emma

text: considerable absence, without feeling that she had injured her; and
title: Emma

text: now, when the due visit was paid, on her arrival, after a two years’
title: Emma

text: interval, she was particularly struck with the very appearance and
title: Emma

text: manners, which for those two whole years she had been depreciating.
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax was very elegant, remarkably elegant; and she had herself
title: Emma

text: the highest value for elegance. Her height was pretty, just such as
title: Emma

text: almost every body would think tall, and nobody could think very tall;
title: Emma

text: her figure particularly graceful; her size a most becoming medium,
title: Emma

text: between fat and thin, though a slight appearance of ill-health seemed
title: Emma

text: to point out the likeliest evil of the two. Emma could not but feel all
title: Emma

text: this; and then, her face—her features—there was more beauty in them
title: Emma

text: altogether than she had remembered; it was not regular, but it was very
title: Emma

text: pleasing beauty. Her eyes, a deep grey, with dark eye-lashes and
title: Emma

text: eyebrows, had never been denied their praise; but the skin, which she
title: Emma

text: had been used to cavil at, as wanting colour, had a clearness and
title: Emma

text: delicacy which really needed no fuller bloom. It was a style of beauty,
title: Emma

text: of which elegance was the reigning character, and as such, she must, in
title: Emma

text: honour, by all her principles, admire it:—elegance, which, whether of
title: Emma

text: person or of mind, she saw so little in Highbury. There, not to be
title: Emma

text: vulgar, was distinction, and merit.
title: Emma

text: In short, she sat, during the first visit, looking at Jane Fairfax with
title: Emma

text: twofold complacency; the sense of pleasure and the sense of rendering
title: Emma

text: justice, and was determining that she would dislike her no longer. When
title: Emma

text: she took in her history, indeed, her situation, as well as her beauty;
title: Emma

text: when she considered what all this elegance was destined to, what she
title: Emma

text: was going to sink from, how she was going to live, it seemed impossible
title: Emma

text: to feel any thing but compassion and respect; especially, if to every
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: pitiable or more honourable than the sacrifices she had resolved on.
title: Emma

text: Emma was very willing now to acquit her of having seduced Mr. Dixon’s
title: Emma

text: affections from his wife, or of any thing mischievous which her
title: Emma

text: imagination had suggested at first. If it were love, it might be
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: unconsciously sucking in the sad poison, while a sharer of his
title: Emma

text: conversation with her friend; and from the best, the purest of motives,
title: Emma

text: might now be denying herself this visit to Ireland, and resolving to
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: beginning her career of laborious duty.
title: Emma

text: Upon the whole, Emma left her with such softened, charitable feelings,
title: Emma

text: as made her look around in walking home, and lament that Highbury
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: and see, and Jane said, ‘Shall I go down instead? for I think you have
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: it, she sat down and wrote to me. A Miss Hawkins—”
title: Emma

text: “I was with Mr. Cole on business an hour and a half ago. He had just
title: Emma

text: read Elton’s letter as I was shewn in, and handed it to me directly.”
title: Emma

text: “Well! that is quite—I suppose there never was a piece of news more
title: Emma

text: generally interesting. My dear sir, you really are too bountiful. My
title: Emma

text: mother desires her very best compliments and regards, and a thousand
title: Emma

text: thanks, and says you really quite oppress her.”
title: Emma

text: “We consider our Hartfield pork,” replied Mr. Woodhouse—“indeed it
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: cannot have a greater pleasure than—”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! my dear sir, as my mother says, our friends are only too good to
title: Emma

text: us. If ever there were people who, without having great wealth
title: Emma

text: themselves, had every thing they could wish for, I am sure it is us. We
title: Emma

text: may well say that ‘our lot is cast in a goodly heritage.’ Well, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley, and so you actually saw the letter; well—”
title: Emma

text: “It was short—merely to announce—but cheerful, exulting, of course.”—
title: Emma

text: Here was a sly glance at Emma. “He had been so fortunate as to—I forget
title: Emma

text: the precise words—one has no business to remember them. The information
title: Emma

text: was, as you state, that he was going to be married to a Miss Hawkins.
title: Emma

text: By his style, I should imagine it just settled.”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton going to be married!” said Emma, as soon as she could speak.
title: Emma

text: “He will have every body’s wishes for his happiness.”
title: Emma

text: “He is very young to settle,” was Mr. Woodhouse’s observation. “He had
title: Emma

text: better not be in a hurry. He seemed to me very well off as he was. We
title: Emma

text: were always glad to see him at Hartfield.”
title: Emma

text: “A new neighbour for us all, Miss Woodhouse!” said Miss Bates,
title: Emma

text: joyfully; “my mother is so pleased!—she says she cannot bear to have
title: Emma

text: the poor old Vicarage without a mistress. This is great news, indeed.
title: Emma

text: Jane, you have never seen Mr. Elton!—no wonder that you have such a
title: Emma

text: curiosity to see him.”
title: Emma

text: Jane’s curiosity did not appear of that absorbing nature as wholly to
title: Emma

text: occupy her.
title: Emma

text: “No—I have never seen Mr. Elton,” she replied, starting on this appeal;
title: Emma

text: “is he—is he a tall man?”
title: Emma

text: “Who shall answer that question?” cried Emma. “My father would say
title: Emma

text: ‘yes,’ Mr. Knightley ‘no;’ and Miss Bates and I that he is just the
title: Emma

text: happy medium. When you have been here a little longer, Miss Fairfax,
title: Emma

text: you will understand that Mr. Elton is the standard of perfection in
title: Emma

text: Highbury, both in person and mind.”
title: Emma

text: “Very true, Miss Woodhouse, so she will. He is the very best young
title: Emma

text: man—But, my dear Jane, if you remember, I told you yesterday he was
title: Emma

text: precisely the height of Mr. Perry. Miss Hawkins,—I dare say, an
title: Emma

text: excellent young woman. His extreme attention to my mother—wanting her
title: Emma

text: to sit in the vicarage pew, that she might hear the better, for my
title: Emma

text: mother is a little deaf, you know—it is not much, but she does not hear
title: Emma

text: quite quick. Jane says that Colonel Campbell is a little deaf. He
title: Emma

text: fancied bathing might be good for it—the warm bath—but she says it did
title: Emma

text: him no lasting benefit. Colonel Campbell, you know, is quite our angel.
title: Emma

text: And Mr. Dixon seems a very charming young man, quite worthy of him. It
title: Emma

text: is such a happiness when good people get together—and they always do.
title: Emma

text: Now, here will be Mr. Elton and Miss Hawkins; and there are the Coles,
title: Emma

text: such very good people; and the Perrys—I suppose there never was a
title: Emma

text: happier or a better couple than Mr. and Mrs. Perry. I say, sir,”
title: Emma

text: turning to Mr. Woodhouse, “I think there are few places with such
title: Emma

text: society as Highbury. I always say, we are quite blessed in our
title: Emma

text: neighbours.—My dear sir, if there is one thing my mother loves better
title: Emma

text: than another, it is pork—a roast loin of pork—”
title: Emma

text: “As to who, or what Miss Hawkins is, or how long he has been acquainted
title: Emma

text: with her,” said Emma, “nothing I suppose can be known. One feels that
title: Emma

text: it cannot be a very long acquaintance. He has been gone only four
title: Emma

text: weeks.”
title: Emma

text: Nobody had any information to give; and, after a few more wonderings,
title: Emma

text: Emma said,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Yes, he has been gone just four weeks, as you observe, Miss
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Well, my dear Jane, I believe we must be running away. The weather
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma, alone with her father, had half her attention wanted by him while
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: of the subject. It was to herself an amusing and a very welcome piece
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: The shower was heavy, but short; and it had not been over five minutes,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: to tell. “She had set out from Mrs. Goddard’s half an hour ago—she had
title: Emma

text: been afraid it would rain—she had been afraid it would pour down every
title: Emma

text: moment—but she thought she might get to Hartfield first—she had hurried
title: Emma

text: on as fast as possible; but then, as she was passing by the house where
title: Emma

text: a young woman was making up a gown for her, she thought she would just
title: Emma

text: step in and see how it went on; and though she did not seem to stay
title: Emma

text: half a moment there, soon after she came out it began to rain, and she
title: Emma

text: did not know what to do; so she ran on directly, as fast as she could,
title: Emma

text: and took shelter at Ford’s.”—Ford’s was the principal woollen-draper,
title: Emma

text: linen-draper, and haberdasher’s shop united; the shop first in size and
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: any thing in the world, full ten minutes, perhaps—when, all of a
title: Emma

text: sudden, who should come in—to be sure it was so very odd!—but they
title: Emma

text: always dealt at Ford’s—who should come in, but Elizabeth Martin and her
title: Emma

text: brother!—Dear Miss Woodhouse! only think. I thought I should have
title: Emma

text: fainted. I did not know what to do. I was sitting near the
title: Emma

text: door—Elizabeth saw me directly; but he did not; he was busy with the
title: Emma

text: umbrella. I am sure she saw me, but she looked away directly, and took
title: Emma

text: no notice; and they both went to quite the farther end of the shop; and
title: Emma

text: I kept sitting near the door!—Oh! dear; I was so miserable! I am sure I
title: Emma

text: must have been as white as my gown. I could not go away you know,
title: Emma

text: because of the rain; but I did so wish myself anywhere in the world but
title: Emma

text: there.—Oh! dear, Miss Woodhouse—well, at last, I fancy, he looked round
title: Emma

text: and saw me; for instead of going on with her buyings, they began
title: Emma

text: whispering to one another. I am sure they were talking of me; and I
title: Emma

text: could not help thinking that he was persuading her to speak to me—(do
title: Emma

text: you think he was, Miss Woodhouse?)—for presently she came forward—came
title: Emma

text: quite up to me, and asked me how I did, and seemed ready to shake
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse, I was absolutely miserable! By that time, it was
title: Emma

text: beginning to hold up, and I was determined that nothing should stop me
title: Emma

text: from getting away—and then—only think!—I found he was coming up towards
title: Emma

text: me too—slowly you know, and as if he did not quite know what to do; and
title: Emma

text: so he came and spoke, and I answered—and I stood for a minute, feeling
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: was going to Hartfield, he thought I had much better go round by Mr.
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: rain. Oh! dear, I thought it would have been the death of me! So I
title: Emma

text: said, I was very much obliged to him: you know I could not do less; and
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: believe I did—but I hardly knew where I was, or any thing about it. Oh!
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse, I would rather done any thing than have it happen: and
title: Emma

text: yet, you know, there was a sort of satisfaction in seeing him behave so
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: talk to me and make me comfortable again.”

text: Very sincerely did Emma wish to do so; but it was not immediately in
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: comfortable herself. The young man’s conduct, and his sister’s, seemed
title: Emma

text: the result of real feeling, and she could not but pity them. As Harriet
title: Emma

text: described it, there had been an interesting mixture of wounded
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: them to be well-meaning, worthy people before; and what difference did
title: Emma

text: this make in the evils of the connexion? It was folly to be disturbed
title: Emma

text: by it. Of course, he must be sorry to lose her—they must be all sorry.
title: Emma

text: Ambition, as well as love, had probably been mortified. They might all
title: Emma

text: have hoped to rise by Harriet’s acquaintance: and besides, what was the
title: Emma

text: value of Harriet’s description?—So easily pleased—so little
title: Emma

text: discerning;—what signified her praise?
title: Emma

text: She exerted herself, and did try to make her comfortable, by
title: Emma

text: considering all that had passed as a mere trifle, and quite unworthy of
title: Emma

text: being dwelt on,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: it.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet said, “very true,” and she “would not think about it;” but
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma
