text: CHAPTER IV
title: Emma

text: Human nature is so well disposed towards those who are in interesting
title: Emma

text: situations, that a young person, who either marries or dies, is sure of
title: Emma

text: being kindly spoken of.
title: Emma

text: A week had not passed since Miss Hawkins’s name was first mentioned in
title: Emma

text: Highbury, before she was, by some means or other, discovered to have
title: Emma

text: every recommendation of person and mind; to be handsome, elegant,
title: Emma

text: highly accomplished, and perfectly amiable: and when Mr. Elton himself
title: Emma

text: arrived to triumph in his happy prospects, and circulate the fame of
title: Emma

text: her merits, there was very little more for him to do, than to tell her
title: Emma

text: Christian name, and say whose music she principally played.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Elton returned, a very happy man. He had gone away rejected and
title: Emma

text: mortified—disappointed in a very sanguine hope, after a series of what
title: Emma

text: appeared to him strong encouragement; and not only losing the right
title: Emma

text: lady, but finding himself debased to the level of a very wrong one. He
title: Emma

text: had gone away deeply offended—he came back engaged to another—and to
title: Emma

text: another as superior, of course, to the first, as under such
title: Emma

text: circumstances what is gained always is to what is lost. He came back
title: Emma

text: gay and self-satisfied, eager and busy, caring nothing for Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, and defying Miss Smith.
title: Emma

text: The charming Augusta Hawkins, in addition to all the usual advantages
title: Emma

text: of perfect beauty and merit, was in possession of an independent
title: Emma

text: fortune, of so many thousands as would always be called ten; a point of
title: Emma

text: some dignity, as well as some convenience: the story told well; he had
title: Emma

text: not thrown himself away—he had gained a woman of 10,000 _l_. or
title: Emma

text: thereabouts; and he had gained her with such delightful rapidity—the
title: Emma

text: first hour of introduction had been so very soon followed by
title: Emma

text: distinguishing notice; the history which he had to give Mrs. Cole of
title: Emma

text: the rise and progress of the affair was so glorious—the steps so quick,
title: Emma

text: from the accidental rencontre, to the dinner at Mr. Green’s, and the
title: Emma

text: party at Mrs. Brown’s—smiles and blushes rising in importance—with
title: Emma

text: consciousness and agitation richly scattered—the lady had been so
title: Emma

text: easily impressed—so sweetly disposed—had in short, to use a most
title: Emma

text: intelligible phrase, been so very ready to have him, that vanity and
title: Emma

text: prudence were equally contented.
title: Emma

text: He had caught both substance and shadow—both fortune and affection, and
title: Emma

text: was just the happy man he ought to be; talking only of himself and his
title: Emma

text: own concerns—expecting to be congratulated—ready to be laughed at—and,
title: Emma

text: with cordial, fearless smiles, now addressing all the young ladies of
title: Emma

text: the place, to whom, a few weeks ago, he would have been more cautiously
title: Emma

text: gallant.
title: Emma

text: The wedding was no distant event, as the parties had only themselves to
title: Emma

text: please, and nothing but the necessary preparations to wait for; and
title: Emma

text: when he set out for Bath again, there was a general expectation, which
title: Emma

text: a certain glance of Mrs. Cole’s did not seem to contradict, that when
title: Emma

text: he next entered Highbury he would bring his bride.
title: Emma

text: During his present short stay, Emma had barely seen him; but just
title: Emma

text: enough to feel that the first meeting was over, and to give her the
title: Emma

text: impression of his not being improved by the mixture of pique and
title: Emma

text: pretension, now spread over his air. She was, in fact, beginning very
title: Emma

text: much to wonder that she had ever thought him pleasing at all; and his
title: Emma

text: sight was so inseparably connected with some very disagreeable
title: Emma

text: feelings, that, except in a moral light, as a penance, a lesson, a
title: Emma

text: source of profitable humiliation to her own mind, she would have been
title: Emma

text: thankful to be assured of never seeing him again. She wished him very
title: Emma

text: well; but he gave her pain, and his welfare twenty miles off would
title: Emma

text: administer most satisfaction.
title: Emma

text: The pain of his continued residence in Highbury, however, must
title: Emma

text: certainly be lessened by his marriage. Many vain solicitudes would be
title: Emma

text: prevented—many awkwardnesses smoothed by it. A _Mrs._ _Elton_ would be
title: Emma

text: an excuse for any change of intercourse; former intimacy might sink
title: Emma

text: without remark. It would be almost beginning their life of civility
title: Emma

text: again.
title: Emma

text: Of the lady, individually, Emma thought very little. She was good
title: Emma

text: enough for Mr. Elton, no doubt; accomplished enough for
title: Emma

text: Highbury—handsome enough—to look plain, probably, by Harriet’s side. As
title: Emma

text: to connexion, there Emma was perfectly easy; persuaded, that after all
title: Emma

text: his own vaunted claims and disdain of Harriet, he had done nothing. On
title: Emma

text: that article, truth seemed attainable. _What_ she was, must be
title: Emma

text: uncertain; but _who_ she was, might be found out; and setting aside the
title: Emma

text: 10,000 l., it did not appear that she was at all Harriet’s superior.
title: Emma

text: She brought no name, no blood, no alliance. Miss Hawkins was the
title: Emma

text: youngest of the two daughters of a Bristol—merchant, of course, he must
title: Emma

text: be called; but, as the whole of the profits of his mercantile life
title: Emma

text: appeared so very moderate, it was not unfair to guess the dignity of
title: Emma

text: his line of trade had been very moderate also. Part of every winter she
title: Emma

text: had been used to spend in Bath; but Bristol was her home, the very
title: Emma

text: heart of Bristol; for though the father and mother had died some years
title: Emma

text: ago, an uncle remained—in the law line—nothing more distinctly
title: Emma

text: honourable was hazarded of him, than that he was in the law line; and
title: Emma

text: with him the daughter had lived. Emma guessed him to be the drudge of
title: Emma

text: some attorney, and too stupid to rise. And all the grandeur of the
title: Emma

text: connexion seemed dependent on the elder sister, who was _very_ _well_
title: Emma

text: _married_, to a gentleman in a _great_ _way_, near Bristol, who kept
title: Emma

text: two carriages! That was the wind-up of the history; that was the glory
title: Emma

text: of Miss Hawkins.
title: Emma

text: Could she but have given Harriet her feelings about it all! She had
title: Emma

text: talked her into love; but, alas! she was not so easily to be talked out
title: Emma

text: of it. The charm of an object to occupy the many vacancies of Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: mind was not to be talked away. He might be superseded by another; he
title: Emma

text: certainly would indeed; nothing could be clearer; even a Robert Martin
title: Emma

text: would have been sufficient; but nothing else, she feared, would cure
title: Emma

text: her. Harriet was one of those, who, having once begun, would be always
title: Emma

text: in love. And now, poor girl! she was considerably worse from this
title: Emma

text: reappearance of Mr. Elton. She was always having a glimpse of him
title: Emma

text: somewhere or other. Emma saw him only once; but two or three times
title: Emma

text: every day Harriet was sure _just_ to meet with him, or _just_ to miss
title: Emma

text: him, _just_ to hear his voice, or see his shoulder, _just_ to have
title: Emma

text: something occur to preserve him in her fancy, in all the favouring
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: hearing about him; for, excepting when at Hartfield, she was always
title: Emma

text: among those who saw no fault in Mr. Elton, and found nothing so
title: Emma

text: interesting as the discussion of his concerns; and every report,
title: Emma

text: therefore, every guess—all that had already occurred, all that might
title: Emma

text: occur in the arrangement of his affairs, comprehending income,
title: Emma

text: servants, and furniture, was continually in agitation around her. Her
title: Emma

text: regard was receiving strength by invariable praise of him, and her
title: Emma

text: regrets kept alive, and feelings irritated by ceaseless repetitions of
title: Emma

text: Miss Hawkins’s happiness, and continual observation of, how much he
title: Emma

text: seemed attached!—his air as he walked by the house—the very sitting of
title: Emma

text: his hat, being all in proof of how much he was in love!
title: Emma

text: Had it been allowable entertainment, had there been no pain to her
title: Emma

text: friend, or reproach to herself, in the waverings of Harriet’s mind,
title: Emma

text: Emma would have been amused by its variations. Sometimes Mr. Elton
title: Emma

text: predominated, sometimes the Martins; and each was occasionally useful
title: Emma

text: as a check to the other. Mr. Elton’s engagement had been the cure of
title: Emma

text: the agitation of meeting Mr. Martin. The unhappiness produced by the
title: Emma

text: knowledge of that engagement had been a little put aside by Elizabeth
title: Emma

text: Martin’s calling at Mrs. Goddard’s a few days afterwards. Harriet had
title: Emma

text: not been at home; but a note had been prepared and left for her,
title: Emma

text: written in the very style to touch; a small mixture of reproach, with a
title: Emma

text: great deal of kindness; and till Mr. Elton himself appeared, she had
title: Emma

text: been much occupied by it, continually pondering over what could be done
title: Emma

text: in return, and wishing to do more than she dared to confess. But Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton, in person, had driven away all such cares. While he staid, the
title: Emma

text: Martins were forgotten; and on the very morning of his setting off for
title: Emma

text: Bath again, Emma, to dissipate some of the distress it occasioned,
title: Emma

text: judged it best for her to return Elizabeth Martin’s visit.
title: Emma

text: How that visit was to be acknowledged—what would be necessary—and what
title: Emma

text: might be safest, had been a point of some doubtful consideration.
title: Emma

text: Absolute neglect of the mother and sisters, when invited to come, would
title: Emma

text: be ingratitude. It must not be: and yet the danger of a renewal of the
title: Emma

text: acquaintance—!
title: Emma

text: After much thinking, she could determine on nothing better, than
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s returning the visit; but in a way that, if they had
title: Emma

text: understanding, should convince them that it was to be only a formal
title: Emma

text: acquaintance. She meant to take her in the carriage, leave her at the
title: Emma

text: Abbey Mill, while she drove a little farther, and call for her again so
title: Emma

text: soon, as to allow no time for insidious applications or dangerous
title: Emma

text: recurrences to the past, and give the most decided proof of what degree
title: Emma

text: of intimacy was chosen for the future.
title: Emma

text: She could think of nothing better: and though there was something in it
title: Emma

text: which her own heart could not approve—something of ingratitude, merely
title: Emma

text: glossed over—it must be done, or what would become of Harriet?
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER V
title: Emma

text: Small heart had Harriet for visiting. Only half an hour before her
title: Emma

text: friend called for her at Mrs. Goddard’s, her evil stars had led her to
title: Emma

text: the very spot where, at that moment, a trunk, directed to _The Rev.
title: Emma

text: Philip Elton, White-Hart, Bath_, was to be seen under the operation of
title: Emma

text: being lifted into the butcher’s cart, which was to convey it to where
title: Emma

text: the coaches past; and every thing in this world, excepting that trunk
title: Emma

text: and the direction, was consequently a blank.
title: Emma

text: She went, however; and when they reached the farm, and she was to be
title: Emma

text: put down, at the end of the broad, neat gravel walk, which led between
title: Emma

text: espalier apple-trees to the front door, the sight of every thing which
title: Emma

text: had given her so much pleasure the autumn before, was beginning to
title: Emma

text: revive a little local agitation; and when they parted, Emma observed
title: Emma

text: her to be looking around with a sort of fearful curiosity, which
title: Emma

text: determined her not to allow the visit to exceed the proposed quarter of
title: Emma

text: an hour. She went on herself, to give that portion of time to an old
title: Emma

text: servant who was married, and settled in Donwell.
title: Emma

text: The quarter of an hour brought her punctually to the white gate again;
title: Emma

text: and Miss Smith receiving her summons, was with her without delay, and
title: Emma

text: unattended by any alarming young man. She came solitarily down the
title: Emma

text: gravel walk—a Miss Martin just appearing at the door, and parting with
title: Emma

text: her seemingly with ceremonious civility.
title: Emma

text: Harriet could not very soon give an intelligible account. She was
title: Emma

text: feeling too much; but at last Emma collected from her enough to
title: Emma

text: understand the sort of meeting, and the sort of pain it was creating.
title: Emma

text: She had seen only Mrs. Martin and the two girls. They had received her
title: Emma

text: doubtingly, if not coolly; and nothing beyond the merest commonplace
title: Emma

text: had been talked almost all the time—till just at last, when Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Martin’s saying, all of a sudden, that she thought Miss Smith was
title: Emma

text: grown, had brought on a more interesting subject, and a warmer manner.
title: Emma

text: In that very room she had been measured last September, with her two
title: Emma

text: friends. There were the pencilled marks and memorandums on the wainscot
title: Emma

text: by the window. _He_ had done it. They all seemed to remember the day,
title: Emma

text: the hour, the party, the occasion—to feel the same consciousness, the
title: Emma

text: same regrets—to be ready to return to the same good understanding; and
title: Emma

text: they were just growing again like themselves, (Harriet, as Emma must
title: Emma

text: suspect, as ready as the best of them to be cordial and happy,) when
title: Emma

text: the carriage reappeared, and all was over. The style of the visit, and
title: Emma

text: the shortness of it, were then felt to be decisive. Fourteen minutes to
title: Emma

text: be given to those with whom she had thankfully passed six weeks not six
title: Emma

text: months ago!—Emma could not but picture it all, and feel how justly they
title: Emma

text: might resent, how naturally Harriet must suffer. It was a bad business.
title: Emma

text: She would have given a great deal, or endured a great deal, to have had
title: Emma

text: the Martins in a higher rank of life. They were so deserving, that a
title: Emma

text: _little_ higher should have been enough: but as it was, how could she
title: Emma

text: have done otherwise?—Impossible!—She could not repent. They must be
title: Emma

text: separated; but there was a great deal of pain in the process—so much to
title: Emma

text: herself at this time, that she soon felt the necessity of a little
title: Emma

text: consolation, and resolved on going home by way of Randalls to procure
title: Emma

text: it. Her mind was quite sick of Mr. Elton and the Martins. The
title: Emma

text: refreshment of Randalls was absolutely necessary.
title: Emma

text: It was a good scheme; but on driving to the door they heard that
title: Emma

text: neither “master nor mistress was at home;” they had both been out some
title: Emma

text: time; the man believed they were gone to Hartfield.
title: Emma

text: “This is too bad,” cried Emma, as they turned away. “And now we shall
title: Emma

text: just miss them; too provoking!—I do not know when I have been so
title: Emma

text: disappointed.” And she leaned back in the corner, to indulge her
title: Emma

text: murmurs, or to reason them away; probably a little of both—such being
title: Emma

text: the commonest process of a not ill-disposed mind. Presently the
title: Emma

text: carriage stopt; she looked up; it was stopt by Mr. and Mrs. Weston, who
title: Emma

text: were standing to speak to her. There was instant pleasure in the sight
title: Emma

text: of them, and still greater pleasure was conveyed in sound—for Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston immediately accosted her with,
title: Emma

text: “How d’ye do?—how d’ye do?—We have been sitting with your father—glad
title: Emma

text: to see him so well. Frank comes to-morrow—I had a letter this
title: Emma

text: morning—we see him to-morrow by dinner-time to a certainty—he is at
title: Emma

text: Oxford to-day, and he comes for a whole fortnight; I knew it would be
title: Emma

text: so. If he had come at Christmas he could not have staid three days; I
title: Emma

text: was always glad he did not come at Christmas; now we are going to have
title: Emma

text: just the right weather for him, fine, dry, settled weather. We shall
title: Emma

text: enjoy him completely; every thing has turned out exactly as we could
title: Emma

text: wish.”
title: Emma

text: There was no resisting such news, no possibility of avoiding the
title: Emma

text: influence of such a happy face as Mr. Weston’s, confirmed as it all was
title: Emma

text: by the words and the countenance of his wife, fewer and quieter, but
title: Emma

text: not less to the purpose. To know that _she_ thought his coming certain
title: Emma

text: was enough to make Emma consider it so, and sincerely did she rejoice
title: Emma

text: in their joy. It was a most delightful reanimation of exhausted
title: Emma

text: spirits. The worn-out past was sunk in the freshness of what was
title: Emma

text: coming; and in the rapidity of half a moment’s thought, she hoped Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton would now be talked of no more.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston gave her the history of the engagements at Enscombe, which
title: Emma

text: allowed his son to answer for having an entire fortnight at his
title: Emma

text: command, as well as the route and the method of his journey; and she
title: Emma

text: listened, and smiled, and congratulated.
title: Emma

text: “I shall soon bring him over to Hartfield,” said he, at the conclusion.
title: Emma

text: Emma could imagine she saw a touch of the arm at this speech, from his
title: Emma

text: wife.
title: Emma

text: “We had better move on, Mr. Weston,” said she, “we are detaining the
title: Emma

text: girls.”
title: Emma

text: “Well, well, I am ready;”—and turning again to Emma, “but you must not
title: Emma

text: be expecting such a _very_ fine young man; you have only had _my_
title: Emma

text: account you know; I dare say he is really nothing
title: Emma

text: extraordinary:”—though his own sparkling eyes at the moment were
title: Emma

text: speaking a very different conviction.
title: Emma

text: Emma could look perfectly unconscious and innocent, and answer in a
title: Emma

text: manner that appropriated nothing.
title: Emma

text: “Think of me to-morrow, my dear Emma, about four o’clock,” was Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston’s parting injunction; spoken with some anxiety, and meant only
title: Emma

text: for her.
title: Emma

text: “Four o’clock!—depend upon it he will be here by three,” was Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston’s quick amendment; and so ended a most satisfactory meeting.
title: Emma

text: Emma’s spirits were mounted quite up to happiness; every thing wore a
title: Emma

text: different air; James and his horses seemed not half so sluggish as
title: Emma

text: before. When she looked at the hedges, she thought the elder at least
title: Emma

text: must soon be coming out; and when she turned round to Harriet, she saw
title: Emma

text: something like a look of spring, a tender smile even there.
title: Emma

text: “Will Mr. Frank Churchill pass through Bath as well as Oxford?”—was a
title: Emma

text: question, however, which did not augur much.
title: Emma

text: But neither geography nor tranquillity could come all at once, and Emma
title: Emma

text: was now in a humour to resolve that they should both come in time.
title: Emma

text: The morning of the interesting day arrived, and Mrs. Weston’s faithful
title: Emma

text: pupil did not forget either at ten, or eleven, or twelve o’clock, that
title: Emma

text: she was to think of her at four.
title: Emma

text: “My dear, dear anxious friend,”—said she, in mental soliloquy, while
title: Emma

text: walking downstairs from her own room, “always overcareful for every
title: Emma

text: body’s comfort but your own; I see you now in all your little fidgets,
title: Emma

text: going again and again into his room, to be sure that all is right.” The
title: Emma

text: clock struck twelve as she passed through the hall. “’Tis twelve; I
title: Emma

text: shall not forget to think of you four hours hence; and by this time
title: Emma

text: to-morrow, perhaps, or a little later, I may be thinking of the
title: Emma

text: possibility of their all calling here. I am sure they will bring him
title: Emma

text: soon.”
title: Emma

text: She opened the parlour door, and saw two gentlemen sitting with her
title: Emma

text: father—Mr. Weston and his son. They had been arrived only a few
title: Emma

text: minutes, and Mr. Weston had scarcely finished his explanation of
title: Emma

text: Frank’s being a day before his time, and her father was yet in the
title: Emma

text: midst of his very civil welcome and congratulations, when she appeared,
title: Emma

text: to have her share of surprize, introduction, and pleasure.
title: Emma

text: The Frank Churchill so long talked of, so high in interest, was
title: Emma

text: actually before her—he was presented to her, and she did not think too
title: Emma

text: much had been said in his praise; he was a _very_ good looking young
title: Emma

text: man; height, air, address, all were unexceptionable, and his
title: Emma

text: countenance had a great deal of the spirit and liveliness of his
title: Emma

text: father’s; he looked quick and sensible. She felt immediately that she
title: Emma

text: should like him; and there was a well-bred ease of manner, and a
title: Emma

text: readiness to talk, which convinced her that he came intending to be
title: Emma

text: acquainted with her, and that acquainted they soon must be.
title: Emma

text: He had reached Randalls the evening before. She was pleased with the
title: Emma

text: eagerness to arrive which had made him alter his plan, and travel
title: Emma

text: earlier, later, and quicker, that he might gain half a day.
title: Emma

text: “I told you yesterday,” cried Mr. Weston with exultation, “I told you
title: Emma

text: all that he would be here before the time named. I remembered what I
title: Emma

text: used to do myself. One cannot creep upon a journey; one cannot help
title: Emma

text: getting on faster than one has planned; and the pleasure of coming in
title: Emma

text: upon one’s friends before the look-out begins, is worth a great deal
title: Emma

text: more than any little exertion it needs.”
title: Emma

text: “It is a great pleasure where one can indulge in it,” said the young
title: Emma

text: man, “though there are not many houses that I should presume on so far;
title: Emma

text: but in coming _home_ I felt I might do any thing.”
title: Emma

text: The word _home_ made his father look on him with fresh complacency.
title: Emma

text: Emma was directly sure that he knew how to make himself agreeable; the
title: Emma

text: conviction was strengthened by what followed. He was very much pleased
title: Emma

text: with Randalls, thought it a most admirably arranged house, would hardly
title: Emma

text: allow it even to be very small, admired the situation, the walk to
title: Emma

text: Highbury, Highbury itself, Hartfield still more, and professed himself
title: Emma

text: to have always felt the sort of interest in the country which none but
title: Emma

text: one’s _own_ country gives, and the greatest curiosity to visit it. That
title: Emma

text: he should never have been able to indulge so amiable a feeling before,
title: Emma

text: passed suspiciously through Emma’s brain; but still, if it were a
title: Emma

text: falsehood, it was a pleasant one, and pleasantly handled. His manner
title: Emma

text: had no air of study or exaggeration. He did really look and speak as if
title: Emma

text: in a state of no common enjoyment.
title: Emma

text: Their subjects in general were such as belong to an opening
title: Emma

text: acquaintance. On his side were the inquiries,—“Was she a
title: Emma

text: horsewoman?—Pleasant rides?—Pleasant walks?—Had they a large
title: Emma

text: neighbourhood?—Highbury, perhaps, afforded society enough?—There were
title: Emma

text: several very pretty houses in and about it.—Balls—had they balls?—Was
title: Emma

text: it a musical society?”
title: Emma

text: But when satisfied on all these points, and their acquaintance
title: Emma

text: proportionably advanced, he contrived to find an opportunity, while
title: Emma

text: their two fathers were engaged with each other, of introducing his
title: Emma

text: mother-in-law, and speaking of her with so much handsome praise, so
title: Emma

text: much warm admiration, so much gratitude for the happiness she secured
title: Emma

text: to his father, and her very kind reception of himself, as was an
title: Emma

text: additional proof of his knowing how to please—and of his certainly
title: Emma

text: thinking it worth while to try to please her. He did not advance a word
title: Emma

text: of praise beyond what she knew to be thoroughly deserved by Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston; but, undoubtedly he could know very little of the matter. He
title: Emma

text: understood what would be welcome; he could be sure of little else. “His
title: Emma

text: father’s marriage,” he said, “had been the wisest measure, every friend
title: Emma

text: must rejoice in it; and the family from whom he had received such a
title: Emma

text: blessing must be ever considered as having conferred the highest
title: Emma

text: obligation on him.”
title: Emma

text: He got as near as he could to thanking her for Miss Taylor’s merits,
title: Emma

text: without seeming quite to forget that in the common course of things it
title: Emma

text: was to be rather supposed that Miss Taylor had formed Miss Woodhouse’s
title: Emma

text: character, than Miss Woodhouse Miss Taylor’s. And at last, as if
title: Emma

text: resolved to qualify his opinion completely for travelling round to its
title: Emma

text: object, he wound it all up with astonishment at the youth and beauty of
title: Emma

text: her person.
title: Emma

text: “Elegant, agreeable manners, I was prepared for,” said he; “but I
title: Emma

text: confess that, considering every thing, I had not expected more than a
title: Emma

text: very tolerably well-looking woman of a certain age; I did not know that
title: Emma

text: I was to find a pretty young woman in Mrs. Weston.”
title: Emma

text: “You cannot see too much perfection in Mrs. Weston for my feelings,”
title: Emma

text: said Emma; “were you to guess her to be _eighteen_, I should listen
title: Emma

text: with pleasure; but _she_ would be ready to quarrel with you for using
title: Emma

text: such words. Don’t let her imagine that you have spoken of her as a
title: Emma

text: pretty young woman.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope I should know better,” he replied; “no, depend upon it, (with a
title: Emma

text: gallant bow,) that in addressing Mrs. Weston I should understand whom I
title: Emma

text: might praise without any danger of being thought extravagant in my
title: Emma

text: terms.”
title: Emma

text: Emma wondered whether the same suspicion of what might be expected from
title: Emma

text: their knowing each other, which had taken strong possession of her
title: Emma

text: mind, had ever crossed his; and whether his compliments were to be
title: Emma

text: considered as marks of acquiescence, or proofs of defiance. She must
title: Emma

text: see more of him to understand his ways; at present she only felt they
title: Emma

text: were agreeable.
title: Emma

text: She had no doubt of what Mr. Weston was often thinking about. His quick
title: Emma

text: eye she detected again and again glancing towards them with a happy
title: Emma

text: expression; and even, when he might have determined not to look, she
title: Emma

text: was confident that he was often listening.
title: Emma

text: Her own father’s perfect exemption from any thought of the kind, the
title: Emma

text: entire deficiency in him of all such sort of penetration or suspicion,
title: Emma

text: was a most comfortable circumstance. Happily he was not farther from
title: Emma

text: approving matrimony than from foreseeing it.—Though always objecting to
title: Emma

text: every marriage that was arranged, he never suffered beforehand from the
title: Emma

text: apprehension of any; it seemed as if he could not think so ill of any
title: Emma

text: two persons’ understanding as to suppose they meant to marry till it
title: Emma

text: were proved against them. She blessed the favouring blindness. He could
title: Emma

text: now, without the drawback of a single unpleasant surmise, without a
title: Emma

text: glance forward at any possible treachery in his guest, give way to all
title: Emma

text: his natural kind-hearted civility in solicitous inquiries after Mr.
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: for Mrs. Weston at Ford’s, but he need not hurry any body else.” His
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: family of that name?”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure we do,” cried his father; “Mrs. Bates—we passed her house—I
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Call upon her, by all means.”
title: Emma

text: “There is no necessity for my calling this morning,” said the young
title: Emma

text: man; “another day would do as well; but there was that degree of
title: Emma

text: acquaintance at Weymouth which—”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! go to-day, go to-day. Do not defer it. What is right to be done
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: The son looked convinced.
title: Emma

text: “I have heard her speak of the acquaintance,” said Emma; “she is a very
title: Emma

text: elegant young woman.”
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Emma

text: The next morning brought Mr. Frank Churchill again. He came with Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston, to whom and to Highbury he seemed to take very cordially. He
title: Emma

text: had been sitting with her, it appeared, most companionably at home,
title: Emma

text: till her usual hour of exercise; and on being desired to chuse their
title: Emma

text: walk, immediately fixed on Highbury.—“He did not doubt there being very
title: Emma

text: pleasant walks in every direction, but if left to him, he should always
title: Emma

text: chuse the same. Highbury, that airy, cheerful, happy-looking Highbury,
title: Emma

text: would be his constant attraction.”—Highbury, with Mrs. Weston, stood
title: Emma

text: for Hartfield; and she trusted to its bearing the same construction
title: Emma

text: with him. They walked thither directly.
title: Emma

text: Emma had hardly expected them: for Mr. Weston, who had called in for
title: Emma

text: half a minute, in order to hear that his son was very handsome, knew
title: Emma

text: nothing of their plans; and it was an agreeable surprize to her,
title: Emma

text: therefore, to perceive them walking up to the house together, arm in
title: Emma

text: arm. She was wanting to see him again, and especially to see him in
title: Emma

text: company with Mrs. Weston, upon his behaviour to whom her opinion of him
title: Emma

text: was to depend. If he were deficient there, nothing should make amends
title: Emma

text: for it. But on seeing them together, she became perfectly satisfied. It
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: it was long enough, broad enough, handsome enough. It would hold the
title: Emma

text: very number for comfort. They ought to have balls there at least every
title: Emma

text: fortnight through the winter. Why had not Miss Woodhouse revived the
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: that none beyond the place and its immediate environs could be tempted
title: Emma

text: to attend, were mentioned; but he was not satisfied. He could not be
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “And how did you think Miss Fairfax looking?”
title: Emma

text: “Ill, very ill—that is, if a young lady can ever be allowed to look
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I have known her from a child, undoubtedly; we have been children and
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “It is a most repulsive quality, indeed,” said he. “Oftentimes very
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: agreeable companion, than I have yet been, to take the trouble of
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Fairfax and me is quite out of the question. I have no reason to think
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Emma

text: Emma’s very good opinion of Frank Churchill was a little shaken the
title: Emma

text: following day, by hearing that he was gone off to London, merely to
title: Emma

text: have his hair cut. A sudden freak seemed to have seized him at
title: Emma

text: breakfast, and he had sent for a chaise and set off, intending to
title: Emma

text: return to dinner, but with no more important view that appeared than
title: Emma

text: having his hair cut. There was certainly no harm in his travelling
title: Emma

text: sixteen miles twice over on such an errand; but there was an air of
title: Emma

text: foppery and nonsense in it which she could not approve. It did not
title: Emma

text: accord with the rationality of plan, the moderation in expense, or even
title: Emma

text: the unselfish warmth of heart, which she had believed herself to
title: Emma

text: discern in him yesterday. Vanity, extravagance, love of change,
title: Emma

text: restlessness of temper, which must be doing something, good or bad;
title: Emma

text: heedlessness as to the pleasure of his father and Mrs. Weston,
title: Emma

text: indifferent as to how his conduct might appear in general; he became
title: Emma

text: liable to all these charges. His father only called him a coxcomb, and
title: Emma

text: thought it a very good story; but that Mrs. Weston did not like it, was
title: Emma

text: clear enough, by her passing it over as quickly as possible, and making
title: Emma

text: no other comment than that “all young people would have their little
title: Emma

text: whims.”
title: Emma

text: With the exception of this little blot, Emma found that his visit
title: Emma

text: hitherto had given her friend only good ideas of him. Mrs. Weston was
title: Emma

text: very ready to say how attentive and pleasant a companion he made
title: Emma

text: himself—how much she saw to like in his disposition altogether. He
title: Emma

text: appeared to have a very open temper—certainly a very cheerful and
title: Emma

text: lively one; she could observe nothing wrong in his notions, a great
title: Emma

text: deal decidedly right; he spoke of his uncle with warm regard, was fond
title: Emma

text: of talking of him—said he would be the best man in the world if he were
title: Emma

text: left to himself; and though there was no being attached to the aunt, he
title: Emma

text: acknowledged her kindness with gratitude, and seemed to mean always to
title: Emma

text: speak of her with respect. This was all very promising; and, but for
title: Emma

text: such an unfortunate fancy for having his hair cut, there was nothing to
title: Emma

text: denote him unworthy of the distinguished honour which her imagination
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: indifference—(for still her resolution held of never marrying)—the
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: acquaintance.

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: This was the occurrence:—The Coles had been settled some years in
title: Emma

text: Highbury, and were very good sort of people—friendly, liberal, and
title: Emma

text: unpretending; but, on the other hand, they were of low origin, in
title: Emma

text: trade, and only moderately genteel. On their first coming into the
title: Emma

text: country, they had lived in proportion to their income, quietly, keeping
title: Emma

text: little company, and that little unexpensively; but the last year or two
title: Emma

text: had brought them a considerable increase of means—the house in town had
title: Emma

text: yielded greater profits, and fortune in general had smiled on them.
title: Emma

text: With their wealth, their views increased; their want of a larger house,
title: Emma

text: their inclination for more company. They added to their house, to their
title: Emma

text: number of servants, to their expenses of every sort; and by this time
title: Emma

text: were, in fortune and style of living, second only to the family at
title: Emma

text: Hartfield. Their love of society, and their new dining-room, prepared
title: Emma

text: every body for their keeping dinner-company; and a few parties, chiefly
title: Emma

text: among the single men, had already taken place. The regular and best
title: Emma

text: families Emma could hardly suppose they would presume to invite—neither
title: Emma

text: Donwell, nor Hartfield, nor Randalls. Nothing should tempt _her_ to go,
title: Emma

text: if they did; and she regretted that her father’s known habits would be
title: Emma

text: giving her refusal less meaning than she could wish. The Coles were
title: Emma

text: very respectable in their way, but they ought to be taught that it was
title: Emma

text: not for them to arrange the terms on which the superior families would
title: Emma

text: visit them. This lesson, she very much feared, they would receive only
title: Emma

text: from herself; she had little hope of Mr. Knightley, none of Mr. Weston.
title: Emma

text: that their advice for her going was most prompt and successful.
title: Emma

text: She owned that, considering every thing, she was not absolutely without
title: Emma

text: inclination for the party. The Coles expressed themselves so
title: Emma

text: properly—there was so much real attention in the manner of it—so much
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: earlier, but had been waiting the arrival of a folding-screen from
title: Emma

text: London, which they hoped might keep Mr. Woodhouse from any draught of
title: Emma

text: air, and therefore induce him the more readily to give them the honour
title: Emma

text: of his company.” Upon the whole, she was very persuadable; and it being
title: Emma

text: briefly settled among themselves how it might be done without
title: Emma

text: neglecting his comfort—how certainly Mrs. Goddard, if not Mrs. Bates,
title: Emma

text: might be depended on for bearing him company—Mr. Woodhouse was to be
title: Emma

text: talked into an acquiescence of his daughter’s going out to dinner on a
title: Emma

text: day now near at hand, and spending the whole evening away from him. As
title: Emma

text: for _his_ going, Emma did not wish him to think it possible, the hours
title: Emma

text: would be too late, and the party too numerous. He was soon pretty well
title: Emma

text: resigned.
title: Emma

text: “I am not fond of dinner-visiting,” said he—“I never was. No more is
title: Emma

text: Emma. Late hours do not agree with us. I am sorry Mr. and Mrs. Cole
title: Emma

text: should have done it. I think it would be much better if they would come
title: Emma

text: in one afternoon next summer, and take their tea with us—take us in
title: Emma

text: their afternoon walk; which they might do, as our hours are so
title: Emma

text: reasonable, and yet get home without being out in the damp of the
title: Emma

text: evening. The dews of a summer evening are what I would not expose any
title: Emma

text: body to. However, as they are so very desirous to have dear Emma dine
title: Emma

text: with them, and as you will both be there, and Mr. Knightley too, to
title: Emma

text: take care of her, I cannot wish to prevent it, provided the weather be
title: Emma

text: what it ought, neither damp, nor cold, nor windy.” Then turning to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston, with a look of gentle reproach—“Ah! Miss Taylor, if you had not
title: Emma

text: married, you would have staid at home with me.”
title: Emma

text: “Well, sir,” cried Mr. Weston, “as I took Miss Taylor away, it is
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Goddard in a moment, if you wish it.”
title: Emma

text: But the idea of any thing to be done in a _moment_, was increasing, not
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: allay it. Mr. Weston must be quiet, and every thing deliberately
title: Emma

text: arranged.
title: Emma

text: With this treatment, Mr. Woodhouse was soon composed enough for talking
title: Emma

text: as usual. “He should be happy to see Mrs. Goddard. He had a great
title: Emma

text: regard for Mrs. Goddard; and Emma should write a line, and invite her.
title: Emma

text: James could take the note. But first of all, there must be an answer
title: Emma

text: written to Mrs. Cole.”
title: Emma

text: “You will make my excuses, my dear, as civilly as possible. You will
title: Emma

text: say that I am quite an invalid, and go no where, and therefore must
title: Emma

text: decline their obliging invitation; beginning with my _compliments_, of
title: Emma

text: course. But you will do every thing right. I need not tell you what is
title: Emma

text: to be done. We must remember to let James know that the carriage will
title: Emma

text: be wanted on Tuesday. I shall have no fears for you with him. We have
title: Emma

text: never been there above once since the new approach was made; but still
title: Emma

text: I have no doubt that James will take you very safely. And when you get
title: Emma

text: there, you must tell him at what time you would have him come for you
title: Emma

text: again; and you had better name an early hour. You will not like staying
title: Emma

text: late. You will get very tired when tea is over.”
title: Emma

text: “But you would not wish me to come away before I am tired, papa?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no, my love; but you will soon be tired. There will be a great
title: Emma

text: many people talking at once. You will not like the noise.”
title: Emma

text: “But, my dear sir,” cried Mr. Weston, “if Emma comes away early, it
title: Emma

text: will be breaking up the party.”
title: Emma

text: “And no great harm if it does,” said Mr. Woodhouse. “The sooner every
title: Emma

text: party breaks up, the better.”
title: Emma

text: “But you do not consider how it may appear to the Coles. Emma’s going
title: Emma

text: away directly after tea might be giving offence. They are good-natured
title: Emma

text: people, and think little of their own claims; but still they must feel
title: Emma

text: that any body’s hurrying away is no great compliment; and Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s doing it would be more thought of than any other person’s
title: Emma

text: in the room. You would not wish to disappoint and mortify the Coles, I
title: Emma

text: am sure, sir; friendly, good sort of people as ever lived, and who have
title: Emma

text: been your neighbours these _ten_ years.”
title: Emma

text: “No, upon no account in the world, Mr. Weston; I am much obliged to you
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: pain. I know what worthy people they are. Perry tells me that Mr. Cole
title: Emma

text: never touches malt liquor. You would not think it to look at him, but
title: Emma

text: he is bilious—Mr. Cole is very bilious. No, I would not be the means of
title: Emma

text: giving them any pain. My dear Emma, we must consider this. I am sure,
title: Emma

text: rather than run the risk of hurting Mr. and Mrs. Cole, you would stay a
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: will be perfectly safe, you know, among your friends.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh yes, papa. I have no fears at all for myself; and I should have no
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: that would entirely destroy my comfort. You must promise me not to sit
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: He came back, had had his hair cut, and laughed at himself with a very
title: Emma

text: good grace, but without seeming really at all ashamed of what he had
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: confusion of face; no reason to wish the money unspent, to improve his
title: Emma

text: spirits. He was quite as undaunted and as lively as ever; and, after
title: Emma

text: seeing him, Emma thus moralised to herself:—
title: Emma

text: “I do not know whether it ought to be so, but certainly silly things do
title: Emma

text: cease to be silly if they are done by sensible people in an impudent
title: Emma

text: way. Wickedness is always wickedness, but folly is not always folly.—It
title: Emma

text: depends upon the character of those who handle it. Mr. Knightley, he is
title: Emma

text: _not_ a trifling, silly young man. If he were, he would have done this
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: vanities.—No, I am perfectly sure that he is not trifling or silly.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Yes I should, I am sure I should. There is always a look of
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: surprized. Such a very kind attention—and so thoughtful an
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Very likely,” said Emma—“nothing more likely. I know no man more
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: could betray.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Mr. Knightley and Jane Fairfax!” exclaimed Emma. “Dear Mrs. Weston,
title: Emma

text: how could you think of such a thing?—Mr. Knightley!—Mr. Knightley must
title: Emma

text: not marry!—You would not have little Henry cut out from Donwell?—Oh!
title: Emma

text: no, no, Henry must have Donwell. I cannot at all consent to Mr.
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: amazed that you should think of such a thing.”
title: Emma

text: “My dear Emma, I have told you what led me to think of it. I do not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: six years old, who knows nothing of the matter?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, I would. I could not bear to have Henry supplanted.—Mr. Knightley
title: Emma

text: marry!—No, I have never had such an idea, and I cannot adopt it now.
title: Emma

text: And Jane Fairfax, too, of all women!”
title: Emma

text: “Nay, she has always been a first favourite with him, as you very well
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I see no probability in it, unless you have any better foundation than
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Abbey!—Oh! no, no;—every feeling revolts. For his own sake, I would not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: his time or his heart.”

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER IX
title: Emma

text: Emma did not repent her condescension in going to the Coles. The visit
title: Emma

text: afforded her many pleasant recollections the next day; and all that she
title: Emma

text: might be supposed to have lost on the side of dignified seclusion, must
title: Emma

text: be amply repaid in the splendour of popularity. She must have delighted
title: Emma

text: the Coles—worthy people, who deserved to be made happy!—And left a name
title: Emma

text: behind her that would not soon die away.
title: Emma

text: Perfect happiness, even in memory, is not common; and there were two
title: Emma

text: points on which she was not quite easy. She doubted whether she had not
title: Emma

text: transgressed the duty of woman by woman, in betraying her suspicions of
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax’s feelings to Frank Churchill. It was hardly right; but it
title: Emma

text: had been so strong an idea, that it would escape her, and his
title: Emma

text: submission to all that she told, was a compliment to her penetration,
title: Emma

text: which made it difficult for her to be quite certain that she ought to
title: Emma

text: have held her tongue.
title: Emma

text: The other circumstance of regret related also to Jane Fairfax; and
title: Emma

text: there she had no doubt. She did unfeignedly and unequivocally regret
title: Emma

text: the inferiority of her own playing and singing. She did most heartily
title: Emma

text: grieve over the idleness of her childhood—and sat down and practised
title: Emma

text: vigorously an hour and a half.
title: Emma

text: She was then interrupted by Harriet’s coming in; and if Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: praise could have satisfied her, she might soon have been comforted.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! if I could but play as well as you and Miss Fairfax!”
title: Emma

text: “Don’t class us together, Harriet. My playing is no more like her’s,
title: Emma

text: than a lamp is like sunshine.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! dear—I think you play the best of the two. I think you play quite
title: Emma

text: as well as she does. I am sure I had much rather hear you. Every body
title: Emma

text: last night said how well you played.”
title: Emma

text: “Those who knew any thing about it, must have felt the difference. The
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: but Jane Fairfax’s is much beyond it.”
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: deal about your taste, and that he valued taste much more than
title: Emma

text: execution.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! but Jane Fairfax has them both, Harriet.”
title: Emma

text: “Are you sure? I saw she had execution, but I did not know she had any
title: Emma

text: taste. Nobody talked about it. And I hate Italian singing.—There is no
title: Emma

text: understanding a word of it. Besides, if she does play so very well, you
title: Emma

text: know, it is no more than she is obliged to do, because she will have to
title: Emma

text: teach. The Coxes were wondering last night whether she would get into
title: Emma

text: any great family. How did you think the Coxes looked?”
title: Emma

text: “Just as they always do—very vulgar.”
title: Emma

text: “They told me something,” said Harriet rather hesitatingly; “but it is
title: Emma

text: nothing of any consequence.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was obliged to ask what they had told her, though fearful of its
title: Emma

text: producing Mr. Elton.
title: Emma

text: “They told me—that Mr. Martin dined with them last Saturday.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh!”
title: Emma

text: “He came to their father upon some business, and he asked him to stay
title: Emma

text: to dinner.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh!”
title: Emma

text: “They talked a great deal about him, especially Anne Cox. I do not know
title: Emma

text: what she meant, but she asked me if I thought I should go and stay
title: Emma

text: there again next summer.”
title: Emma

text: “She meant to be impertinently curious, just as such an Anne Cox should
title: Emma

text: be.”
title: Emma

text: “She said he was very agreeable the day he dined there. He sat by her
title: Emma

text: at dinner. Miss Nash thinks either of the Coxes would be very glad to
title: Emma

text: marry him.”
title: Emma

text: “Very likely.—I think they are, without exception, the most vulgar
title: Emma

text: girls in Highbury.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet had business at Ford’s.—Emma thought it most prudent to go with
title: Emma

text: her. Another accidental meeting with the Martins was possible, and in
title: Emma

text: her present state, would be dangerous.
title: Emma

text: Harriet, tempted by every thing and swayed by half a word, was always
title: Emma

text: very long at a purchase; and while she was still hanging over muslins
title: Emma

text: and changing her mind, Emma went to the door for amusement.—Much could
title: Emma

text: not be hoped from the traffic of even the busiest part of Highbury;—Mr.
title: Emma

text: Perry walking hastily by, Mr. William Cox letting himself in at the
title: Emma

text: office-door, Mr. Cole’s carriage-horses returning from exercise, or a
title: Emma

text: stray letter-boy on an obstinate mule, were the liveliest objects she
title: Emma

text: could presume to expect; and when her eyes fell only on the butcher
title: Emma

text: with his tray, a tidy old woman travelling homewards from shop with her
title: Emma

text: full basket, two curs quarrelling over a dirty bone, and a string of
title: Emma

text: dawdling children round the baker’s little bow-window eyeing the
title: Emma

text: gingerbread, she knew she had no reason to complain, and was amused
title: Emma

text: enough; quite enough still to stand at the door. A mind lively and at
title: Emma

text: ease, can do with seeing nothing, and can see nothing that does not
title: Emma

text: answer.
title: Emma

text: She looked down the Randalls road. The scene enlarged; two persons
title: Emma

text: appeared; Mrs. Weston and her son-in-law; they were walking into
title: Emma

text: Highbury;—to Hartfield of course. They were stopping, however, in the
title: Emma

text: first place at Mrs. Bates’s; whose house was a little nearer Randalls
title: Emma

text: than Ford’s; and had all but knocked, when Emma caught their
title: Emma

text: eye.—Immediately they crossed the road and came forward to her; and the
title: Emma

text: agreeableness of yesterday’s engagement seemed to give fresh pleasure
title: Emma

text: to the present meeting. Mrs. Weston informed her that she was going to
title: Emma

text: call on the Bateses, in order to hear the new instrument.
title: Emma

text: “For my companion tells me,” said she, “that I absolutely promised Miss
title: Emma

text: Bates last night, that I would come this morning. I was not aware of it
title: Emma

text: myself. I did not know that I had fixed a day, but as he says I did, I
title: Emma

text: am going now.”
title: Emma

text: “And while Mrs. Weston pays her visit, I may be allowed, I hope,” said
title: Emma

text: Frank Churchill, “to join your party and wait for her at Hartfield—if
title: Emma

text: you are going home.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston was disappointed.
title: Emma

text: “I thought you meant to go with me. They would be very much pleased.”
title: Emma

text: “Me! I should be quite in the way. But, perhaps—I may be equally in the
title: Emma

text: way here. Miss Woodhouse looks as if she did not want me. My aunt
title: Emma

text: always sends me off when she is shopping. She says I fidget her to
title: Emma

text: death; and Miss Woodhouse looks as if she could almost say the same.
title: Emma

text: What am I to do?”
title: Emma

text: “I am here on no business of my own,” said Emma; “I am only waiting for
title: Emma

text: my friend. She will probably have soon done, and then we shall go home.
title: Emma

text: But you had better go with Mrs. Weston and hear the instrument.”
title: Emma

text: “Well—if you advise it.—But (with a smile) if Colonel Campbell should
title: Emma

text: have employed a careless friend, and if it should prove to have an
title: Emma

text: indifferent tone—what shall I say? I shall be no support to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston. She might do very well by herself. A disagreeable truth would
title: Emma

text: be palatable through her lips, but I am the wretchedest being in the
title: Emma

text: world at a civil falsehood.”
title: Emma

text: “I do not believe any such thing,” replied Emma.—“I am persuaded that
title: Emma

text: you can be as insincere as your neighbours, when it is necessary; but
title: Emma

text: there is no reason to suppose the instrument is indifferent. Quite
title: Emma

text: otherwise indeed, if I understood Miss Fairfax’s opinion last night.”
title: Emma

text: “Do come with me,” said Mrs. Weston, “if it be not very disagreeable to
title: Emma

text: you. It need not detain us long. We will go to Hartfield afterwards. We
title: Emma

text: will follow them to Hartfield. I really wish you to call with me. It
title: Emma

text: will be felt so great an attention! and I always thought you meant it.”
title: Emma

text: He could say no more; and with the hope of Hartfield to reward him,
title: Emma

text: returned with Mrs. Weston to Mrs. Bates’s door. Emma watched them in,
title: Emma

text: and then joined Harriet at the interesting counter,—trying, with all
title: Emma

text: the force of her own mind, to convince her that if she wanted plain
title: Emma

text: muslin it was of no use to look at figured; and that a blue ribbon, be
title: Emma

text: it ever so beautiful, would still never match her yellow pattern. At
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Should I send it to Mrs. Goddard’s, ma’am?” asked Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Ford.—“Yes—no—yes, to Mrs. Goddard’s. Only my pattern gown is at
title: Emma

text: Hartfield. No, you shall send it to Hartfield, if you please. But then,
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Goddard will want to see it.—And I could take the pattern gown
title: Emma

text: home any day. But I shall want the ribbon directly—so it had better go
title: Emma

text: to Hartfield—at least the ribbon. You could make it into two parcels,
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Ford, could not you?”
title: Emma

text: “It is not worth while, Harriet, to give Mrs. Ford the trouble of two
title: Emma

text: parcels.”
title: Emma

text: “No more it is.”
title: Emma

text: “No trouble in the world, ma’am,” said the obliging Mrs. Ford.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! but indeed I would much rather have it only in one. Then, if you
title: Emma

text: please, you shall send it all to Mrs. Goddard’s—I do not know—No, I
title: Emma

text: think, Miss Woodhouse, I may just as well have it sent to Hartfield,
title: Emma

text: and take it home with me at night. What do you advise?”
title: Emma

text: “That you do not give another half-second to the subject. To Hartfield,
title: Emma

text: if you please, Mrs. Ford.”
title: Emma

text: “Aye, that will be much best,” said Harriet, quite satisfied, “I should
title: Emma

text: not at all like to have it sent to Mrs. Goddard’s.”
title: Emma

text: Voices approached the shop—or rather one voice and two ladies: Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston and Miss Bates met them at the door.
title: Emma

text: “My dear Miss Woodhouse,” said the latter, “I am just run across to
title: Emma

text: entreat the favour of you to come and sit down with us a little while,
title: Emma

text: and give us your opinion of our new instrument; you and Miss Smith. How
title: Emma

text: do you do, Miss Smith?—Very well I thank you.—And I begged Mrs. Weston
title: Emma

text: to come with me, that I might be sure of succeeding.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope Mrs. Bates and Miss Fairfax are—”
title: Emma

text: “Very well, I am much obliged to you. My mother is delightfully well;
title: Emma

text: and Jane caught no cold last night. How is Mr. Woodhouse?—I am so glad
title: Emma

text: to hear such a good account. Mrs. Weston told me you were here.—Oh!
title: Emma

text: then, said I, I must run across, I am sure Miss Woodhouse will allow me
title: Emma

text: just to run across and entreat her to come in; my mother will be so
title: Emma

text: very happy to see her—and now we are such a nice party, she cannot
title: Emma

text: refuse.—‘Aye, pray do,’ said Mr. Frank Churchill, ‘Miss Woodhouse’s
title: Emma

text: opinion of the instrument will be worth having.’—But, said I, I shall
title: Emma

text: be more sure of succeeding if one of you will go with me.—‘Oh,’ said
title: Emma

text: he, ‘wait half a minute, till I have finished my job;’—For, would you
title: Emma

text: believe it, Miss Woodhouse, there he is, in the most obliging manner in
title: Emma

text: the world, fastening in the rivet of my mother’s spectacles.—The rivet
title: Emma

text: came out, you know, this morning.—So very obliging!—For my mother had
title: Emma

text: no use of her spectacles—could not put them on. And, by the bye, every
title: Emma

text: body ought to have two pair of spectacles; they should indeed. Jane
title: Emma

text: said so. I meant to take them over to John Saunders the first thing I
title: Emma

text: did, but something or other hindered me all the morning; first one
title: Emma

text: thing, then another, there is no saying what, you know. At one time
title: Emma

text: Patty came to say she thought the kitchen chimney wanted sweeping. Oh,
title: Emma

text: said I, Patty do not come with your bad news to me. Here is the rivet
title: Emma

text: of your mistress’s spectacles out. Then the baked apples came home,
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Wallis sent them by her boy; they are extremely civil and obliging
title: Emma

text: to us, the Wallises, always—I have heard some people say that Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Wallis can be uncivil and give a very rude answer, but we have never
title: Emma

text: known any thing but the greatest attention from them. And it cannot be
title: Emma

text: for the value of our custom now, for what is our consumption of bread,
title: Emma

text: you know? Only three of us.—besides dear Jane at present—and she really
title: Emma

text: eats nothing—makes such a shocking breakfast, you would be quite
title: Emma

text: frightened if you saw it. I dare not let my mother know how little she
title: Emma

text: eats—so I say one thing and then I say another, and it passes off. But
title: Emma

text: about the middle of the day she gets hungry, and there is nothing she
title: Emma

text: likes so well as these baked apples, and they are extremely wholesome,
title: Emma

text: for I took the opportunity the other day of asking Mr. Perry; I
title: Emma

text: happened to meet him in the street. Not that I had any doubt before—I
title: Emma

text: have so often heard Mr. Woodhouse recommend a baked apple. I believe it
title: Emma

text: is the only way that Mr. Woodhouse thinks the fruit thoroughly
title: Emma

text: wholesome. We have apple-dumplings, however, very often. Patty makes an
title: Emma

text: excellent apple-dumpling. Well, Mrs. Weston, you have prevailed, I
title: Emma

text: hope, and these ladies will oblige us.”
title: Emma

text: Emma would be “very happy to wait on Mrs. Bates, &c.,” and they did at
title: Emma

text: last move out of the shop, with no farther delay from Miss Bates than,
title: Emma

text: “How do you do, Mrs. Ford? I beg your pardon. I did not see you before.
title: Emma

text: I hear you have a charming collection of new ribbons from town. Jane
title: Emma

text: came back delighted yesterday. Thank ye, the gloves do very well—only a
title: Emma

text: little too large about the wrist; but Jane is taking them in.”
title: Emma

text: “What was I talking of?” said she, beginning again when they were all
title: Emma

text: in the street.
title: Emma

text: Emma wondered on what, of all the medley, she would fix.
title: Emma

text: “I declare I cannot recollect what I was talking of.—Oh! my mother’s
title: Emma

text: spectacles. So very obliging of Mr. Frank Churchill! ‘Oh!’ said he, ‘I
title: Emma

text: do think I can fasten the rivet; I like a job of this kind
title: Emma

text: excessively.’—Which you know shewed him to be so very.... Indeed I must
title: Emma

text: say that, much as I had heard of him before and much as I had expected,
title: Emma

text: he very far exceeds any thing.... I do congratulate you, Mrs. Weston,
title: Emma

text: most warmly. He seems every thing the fondest parent could.... ‘Oh!’
title: Emma

text: said he, ‘I can fasten the rivet. I like a job of that sort
title: Emma

text: excessively.’ I never shall forget his manner. And when I brought out
title: Emma

text: the baked apples from the closet, and hoped our friends would be so
title: Emma

text: very obliging as to take some, ‘Oh!’ said he directly, ‘there is
title: Emma

text: nothing in the way of fruit half so good, and these are the
title: Emma

text: finest-looking home-baked apples I ever saw in my life.’ That, you
title: Emma

text: know, was so very.... And I am sure, by his manner, it was no
title: Emma

text: compliment. Indeed they are very delightful apples, and Mrs. Wallis
title: Emma

text: does them full justice—only we do not have them baked more than twice,
title: Emma

text: and Mr. Woodhouse made us promise to have them done three times—but
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse will be so good as not to mention it. The apples
title: Emma

text: themselves are the very finest sort for baking, beyond a doubt; all
title: Emma

text: from Donwell—some of Mr. Knightley’s most liberal supply. He sends us a
title: Emma

text: sack every year; and certainly there never was such a keeping apple
title: Emma

text: anywhere as one of his trees—I believe there is two of them. My mother
title: Emma

text: says the orchard was always famous in her younger days. But I was
title: Emma

text: really quite shocked the other day—for Mr. Knightley called one
title: Emma

text: morning, and Jane was eating these apples, and we talked about them and
title: Emma

text: said how much she enjoyed them, and he asked whether we were not got to
title: Emma

text: the end of our stock. ‘I am sure you must be,’ said he, ‘and I will
title: Emma

text: send you another supply; for I have a great many more than I can ever
title: Emma

text: use. William Larkins let me keep a larger quantity than usual this
title: Emma

text: year. I will send you some more, before they get good for nothing.’ So
title: Emma

text: I begged he would not—for really as to ours being gone, I could not
title: Emma

text: absolutely say that we had a great many left—it was but half a dozen
title: Emma

text: indeed; but they should be all kept for Jane; and I could not at all
title: Emma

text: bear that he should be sending us more, so liberal as he had been
title: Emma

text: already; and Jane said the same. And when he was gone, she almost
title: Emma

text: quarrelled with me—No, I should not say quarrelled, for we never had a
title: Emma

text: quarrel in our lives; but she was quite distressed that I had owned the
title: Emma

text: apples were so nearly gone; she wished I had made him believe we had a
title: Emma

text: great many left. Oh, said I, my dear, I did say as much as I could.
title: Emma

text: However, the very same evening William Larkins came over with a large
title: Emma

text: basket of apples, the same sort of apples, a bushel at least, and I was
title: Emma

text: very much obliged, and went down and spoke to William Larkins and said
title: Emma

text: every thing, as you may suppose. William Larkins is such an old
title: Emma

text: acquaintance! I am always glad to see him. But, however, I found
title: Emma

text: afterwards from Patty, that William said it was all the apples of
title: Emma

text: _that_ sort his master had; he had brought them all—and now his master
title: Emma

text: had not one left to bake or boil. William did not seem to mind it
title: Emma

text: himself, he was so pleased to think his master had sold so many; for
title: Emma

text: William, you know, thinks more of his master’s profit than any thing;
title: Emma

text: but Mrs. Hodges, he said, was quite displeased at their being all sent
title: Emma

text: away. She could not bear that her master should not be able to have
title: Emma

text: another apple-tart this spring. He told Patty this, but bid her not
title: Emma

text: mind it, and be sure not to say any thing to us about it, for Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Hodges _would_ be cross sometimes, and as long as so many sacks were
title: Emma

text: sold, it did not signify who ate the remainder. And so Patty told me,
title: Emma

text: and I was excessively shocked indeed! I would not have Mr. Knightley
title: Emma

text: know any thing about it for the world! He would be so very.... I wanted
title: Emma

text: to keep it from Jane’s knowledge; but, unluckily, I had mentioned it
title: Emma

text: before I was aware.”
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates had just done as Patty opened the door; and her visitors
title: Emma

text: walked upstairs without having any regular narration to attend to,
title: Emma

text: pursued only by the sounds of her desultory good-will.
title: Emma

text: “Pray take care, Mrs. Weston, there is a step at the turning. Pray take
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, I am quite concerned, I am sure you hit your foot. Miss
title: Emma

text: Smith, the step at the turning.”

text: CHAPTER X
title: Emma

text: The appearance of the little sitting-room as they entered, was
title: Emma

text: tranquillity itself; Mrs. Bates, deprived of her usual employment,
title: Emma

text: slumbering on one side of the fire, Frank Churchill, at a table near
title: Emma

text: her, most deedily occupied about her spectacles, and Jane Fairfax,
title: Emma

text: standing with her back to them, intent on her pianoforte.
title: Emma

text: Busy as he was, however, the young man was yet able to shew a most
title: Emma

text: happy countenance on seeing Emma again.
title: Emma

text: “This is a pleasure,” said he, in rather a low voice, “coming at least
title: Emma

text: ten minutes earlier than I had calculated. You find me trying to be
title: Emma

text: useful; tell me if you think I shall succeed.”
title: Emma

text: “What!” said Mrs. Weston, “have not you finished it yet? you would not
title: Emma

text: earn a very good livelihood as a working silversmith at this rate.”
title: Emma

text: “I have not been working uninterruptedly,” he replied, “I have been
title: Emma

text: assisting Miss Fairfax in trying to make her instrument stand steadily,
title: Emma

text: it was not quite firm; an unevenness in the floor, I believe. You see
title: Emma

text: we have been wedging one leg with paper. This was very kind of you to
title: Emma

text: be persuaded to come. I was almost afraid you would be hurrying home.”
title: Emma

text: He contrived that she should be seated by him; and was sufficiently
title: Emma

text: employed in looking out the best baked apple for her, and trying to
title: Emma

text: make her help or advise him in his work, till Jane Fairfax was quite
title: Emma

text: ready to sit down to the pianoforte again. That she was not immediately
title: Emma

text: ready, Emma did suspect to arise from the state of her nerves; she had
title: Emma

text: not yet possessed the instrument long enough to touch it without
title: Emma

text: emotion; she must reason herself into the power of performance; and
title: Emma

text: Emma could not but pity such feelings, whatever their origin, and could
title: Emma

text: not but resolve never to expose them to her neighbour again.
title: Emma

text: At last Jane began, and though the first bars were feebly given, the
title: Emma

text: powers of the instrument were gradually done full justice to. Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston had been delighted before, and was delighted again; Emma joined
title: Emma

text: her in all her praise; and the pianoforte, with every proper
title: Emma

text: discrimination, was pronounced to be altogether of the highest promise.
title: Emma

text: “Whoever Colonel Campbell might employ,” said Frank Churchill, with a
title: Emma

text: smile at Emma, “the person has not chosen ill. I heard a good deal of
title: Emma

text: Colonel Campbell’s taste at Weymouth; and the softness of the upper
title: Emma

text: notes I am sure is exactly what he and _all_ _that_ _party_ would
title: Emma

text: particularly prize. I dare say, Miss Fairfax, that he either gave his
title: Emma

text: friend very minute directions, or wrote to Broadwood himself. Do not
title: Emma

text: you think so?”
title: Emma

text: Jane did not look round. She was not obliged to hear. Mrs. Weston had
title: Emma

text: been speaking to her at the same moment.
title: Emma

text: “It is not fair,” said Emma, in a whisper; “mine was a random guess. Do
title: Emma

text: not distress her.”
title: Emma

text: He shook his head with a smile, and looked as if he had very little
title: Emma

text: doubt and very little mercy. Soon afterwards he began again,
title: Emma

text: “How much your friends in Ireland must be enjoying your pleasure on
title: Emma

text: this occasion, Miss Fairfax. I dare say they often think of you, and
title: Emma

text: wonder which will be the day, the precise day of the instrument’s
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: He paused. She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering,
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: forced calmness, “I can imagine nothing with any confidence. It must be
title: Emma

text: all conjecture.”
title: Emma

text: “Conjecture—aye, sometimes one conjectures right, and sometimes one
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “If you are very kind,” said he, “it will be one of the waltzes we
title: Emma

text: danced last night;—let me live them over again. You did not enjoy them
title: Emma

text: as I did; you appeared tired the whole time. I believe you were glad we
title: Emma

text: danced no longer; but I would have given worlds—all the worlds one ever
title: Emma

text: has to give—for another half-hour.”
title: Emma

text: She played.
title: Emma

text: “What felicity it is to hear a tune again which _has_ made one
title: Emma

text: happy!—If I mistake not that was danced at Weymouth.”
title: Emma

text: She looked up at him for a moment, coloured deeply, and played
title: Emma

text: something else. He took some music from a chair near the pianoforte,
title: Emma

text: and turning to Emma, said,
title: Emma

text: “Here is something quite new to me. Do you know it?—Cramer.—And here
title: Emma

text: are a new set of Irish melodies. That, from such a quarter, one might
title: Emma

text: expect. This was all sent with the instrument. Very thoughtful of
title: Emma

text: Colonel Campbell, was not it?—He knew Miss Fairfax could have no music
title: Emma

text: here. I honour that part of the attention particularly; it shews it to
title: Emma

text: have been so thoroughly from the heart. Nothing hastily done; nothing
title: Emma

text: incomplete. True affection only could have prompted it.”
title: Emma

text: Emma wished he would be less pointed, yet could not help being amused;
title: Emma

text: and when on glancing her eye towards Jane Fairfax she caught the
title: Emma

text: remains of a smile, when she saw that with all the deep blush of
title: Emma

text: consciousness, there had been a smile of secret delight, she had less
title: Emma

text: scruple in the amusement, and much less compunction with respect to
title: Emma

text: her.—This amiable, upright, perfect Jane Fairfax was apparently
title: Emma

text: cherishing very reprehensible feelings.
title: Emma

text: He brought all the music to her, and they looked it over together.—Emma
title: Emma

text: took the opportunity of whispering,
title: Emma

text: “You speak too plain. She must understand you.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope she does. I would have her understand me. I am not in the least
title: Emma

text: ashamed of my meaning.”
title: Emma

text: “But really, I am half ashamed, and wish I had never taken up the
title: Emma

text: idea.”
title: Emma

text: “I am very glad you did, and that you communicated it to me. I have now
title: Emma

title: Emma
