text: Shortly afterwards Miss Bates, passing near the window, descried Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley on horse-back not far off.
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Knightley I declare!—I must speak to him if possible, just to
title: Emma

text: thank him. I will not open the window here; it would give you all cold;
title: Emma

text: but I can go into my mother’s room you know. I dare say he will come in
title: Emma

text: when he knows who is here. Quite delightful to have you all meet
title: Emma

text: so!—Our little room so honoured!”
title: Emma

text: She was in the adjoining chamber while she still spoke, and opening the
title: Emma

text: casement there, immediately called Mr. Knightley’s attention, and every
title: Emma

text: syllable of their conversation was as distinctly heard by the others,
title: Emma

text: as if it had passed within the same apartment.
title: Emma

text: “How d’ ye do?—how d’ye do?—Very well, I thank you. So obliged to you
title: Emma

text: for the carriage last night. We were just in time; my mother just ready
title: Emma

text: for us. Pray come in; do come in. You will find some friends here.”
title: Emma

text: So began Miss Bates; and Mr. Knightley seemed determined to be heard in
title: Emma

text: his turn, for most resolutely and commandingly did he say,
title: Emma

text: “How is your niece, Miss Bates?—I want to inquire after you all, but
title: Emma

text: particularly your niece. How is Miss Fairfax?—I hope she caught no cold
title: Emma

text: last night. How is she to-day? Tell me how Miss Fairfax is.”
title: Emma

text: And Miss Bates was obliged to give a direct answer before he would hear
title: Emma

text: her in any thing else. The listeners were amused; and Mrs. Weston gave
title: Emma

text: Emma a look of particular meaning. But Emma still shook her head in
title: Emma

text: steady scepticism.
title: Emma

text: “So obliged to you!—so very much obliged to you for the carriage,”
title: Emma

text: resumed Miss Bates.
title: Emma

text: He cut her short with,
title: Emma

text: “I am going to Kingston. Can I do any thing for you?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! dear, Kingston—are you?—Mrs. Cole was saying the other day she
title: Emma

text: wanted something from Kingston.”
title: Emma

text: “Mrs. Cole has servants to send. Can I do any thing for _you_?”
title: Emma

text: “No, I thank you. But do come in. Who do you think is here?—Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse and Miss Smith; so kind as to call to hear the new
title: Emma

text: pianoforte. Do put up your horse at the Crown, and come in.”
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said he, in a deliberating manner, “for five minutes, perhaps.”
title: Emma

text: “And here is Mrs. Weston and Mr. Frank Churchill too!—Quite delightful;
title: Emma

text: so many friends!”
title: Emma

text: “No, not now, I thank you. I could not stay two minutes. I must get on
title: Emma

text: to Kingston as fast as I can.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! do come in. They will be so very happy to see you.”
title: Emma

text: “No, no; your room is full enough. I will call another day, and hear
title: Emma

text: the pianoforte.”
title: Emma

text: “Well, I am so sorry!—Oh! Mr. Knightley, what a delightful party last
title: Emma

text: night; how extremely pleasant.—Did you ever see such dancing?—Was not
title: Emma

text: it delightful?—Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill; I never saw any
title: Emma

text: thing equal to it.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! very delightful indeed; I can say nothing less, for I suppose Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill are hearing every thing that passes.
title: Emma

text: And (raising his voice still more) I do not see why Miss Fairfax should
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: England. Now, if your friends have any gratitude, they will say
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: hear it.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! Mr. Knightley, one moment more; something of consequence—so
title: Emma

text: shocked!—Jane and I are both so shocked about the apples!”
title: Emma

text: “What is the matter now?”
title: Emma

text: “To think of your sending us all your store apples. You said you had a
title: Emma

text: great many, and now you have not one left. We really are so shocked!
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Hodges may well be angry. William Larkins mentioned it here. You
title: Emma

text: should not have done it, indeed you should not. Ah! he is off. He never
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: would have been a pity not to have mentioned.... Well, (returning to
title: Emma

text: the room,) I have not been able to succeed. Mr. Knightley cannot stop.
title: Emma

text: He is going to Kingston. He asked me if he could do any thing....”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said Jane, “we heard his kind offers, we heard every thing.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes, my dear, I dare say you might, because you know, the door was
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Kingston?’ said he; so I just mentioned.... Oh! Miss Woodhouse, must
title: Emma

text: you be going?—You seem but just come—so very obliging of you.”
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XI
title: Emma

text: It may be possible to do without dancing entirely. Instances have been
title: Emma

text: known of young people passing many, many months successively, without
title: Emma

text: being at any ball of any description, and no material injury accrue
title: Emma

text: either to body or mind;—but when a beginning is made—when the
title: Emma

text: felicities of rapid motion have once been, though slightly, felt—it
title: Emma

text: must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more.
title: Emma

text: Frank Churchill had danced once at Highbury, and longed to dance again;
title: Emma

text: and the last half-hour of an evening which Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded
title: Emma

text: to spend with his daughter at Randalls, was passed by the two young
title: Emma

text: people in schemes on the subject. Frank’s was the first idea; and his
title: Emma

text: the greatest zeal in pursuing it; for the lady was the best judge of
title: Emma

text: the difficulties, and the most solicitous for accommodation and
title: Emma

text: appearance. But still she had inclination enough for shewing people
title: Emma

text: again how delightfully Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: danced—for doing that in which she need not blush to compare herself
title: Emma

text: with Jane Fairfax—and even for simple dancing itself, without any of
title: Emma

text: the wicked aids of vanity—to assist him first in pacing out the room
title: Emma

text: they were in to see what it could be made to hold—and then in taking
title: Emma

text: the dimensions of the other parlour, in the hope of discovering, in
title: Emma

text: spite of all that Mr. Weston could say of their exactly equal size,
title: Emma

text: that it was a little the largest.
title: Emma

text: His first proposition and request, that the dance begun at Mr. Cole’s
title: Emma

text: should be finished there—that the same party should be collected, and
title: Emma

text: the same musician engaged, met with the readiest acquiescence. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment, and Mrs. Weston
title: Emma

text: most willingly undertook to play as long as they could wish to dance;
title: Emma

text: and the interesting employment had followed, of reckoning up exactly
title: Emma

text: who there would be, and portioning out the indispensable division of
title: Emma

text: space to every couple.
title: Emma

text: “You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss
title: Emma

text: Coxes five,” had been repeated many times over. “And there will be the
title: Emma

text: two Gilberts, young Cox, my father, and myself, besides Mr. Knightley.
title: Emma

text: Yes, that will be quite enough for pleasure. You and Miss Smith, and
title: Emma

text: Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss Coxes five; and for five
title: Emma

text: couple there will be plenty of room.”
title: Emma

text: But soon it came to be on one side,
title: Emma

text: “But will there be good room for five couple?—I really do not think
title: Emma

text: there will.”
title: Emma

text: On another,
title: Emma

text: “And after all, five couple are not enough to make it worth while to
title: Emma

text: stand up. Five couple are nothing, when one thinks seriously about it.
title: Emma

text: It will not do to _invite_ five couple. It can be allowable only as the
title: Emma

text: thought of the moment.”
title: Emma

text: Somebody said that _Miss_ Gilbert was expected at her brother’s, and
title: Emma

text: must be invited with the rest. Somebody else believed _Mrs_. Gilbert
title: Emma

text: would have danced the other evening, if she had been asked. A word was
title: Emma

text: put in for a second young Cox; and at last, Mr. Weston naming one
title: Emma

text: family of cousins who must be included, and another of very old
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: The doors of the two rooms were just opposite each other. “Might not
title: Emma

text: they use both rooms, and dance across the passage?” It seemed the best
title: Emma

text: scheme; and yet it was not so good but that many of them wanted a
title: Emma

text: better. Emma said it would be awkward; Mrs. Weston was in distress
title: Emma

text: about the supper; and Mr. Woodhouse opposed it earnestly, on the score
title: Emma

text: of health. It made him so very unhappy, indeed, that it could not be
title: Emma

text: persevered in.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no,” said he; “it would be the extreme of imprudence. I could not
title: Emma

text: bear it for Emma!—Emma is not strong. She would catch a dreadful cold.
title: Emma

text: So would poor little Harriet. So you would all. Mrs. Weston, you would
title: Emma

text: be quite laid up; do not let them talk of such a wild thing. Pray do
title: Emma

text: not let them talk of it. That young man (speaking lower) is very
title: Emma

text: thoughtless. Do not tell his father, but that young man is not quite
title: Emma

text: the thing. He has been opening the doors very often this evening, and
title: Emma

text: keeping them open very inconsiderately. He does not think of the
title: Emma

text: draught. I do not mean to set you against him, but indeed he is not
title: Emma

text: quite the thing!”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston was sorry for such a charge. She knew the importance of it,
title: Emma

text: and said every thing in her power to do it away. Every door was now
title: Emma

text: closed, the passage plan given up, and the first scheme of dancing only
title: Emma

text: in the room they were in resorted to again; and with such good-will on
title: Emma

text: Frank Churchill’s part, that the space which a quarter of an hour
title: Emma

text: before had been deemed barely sufficient for five couple, was now
title: Emma

text: endeavoured to be made out quite enough for ten.
title: Emma

text: “We were too magnificent,” said he. “We allowed unnecessary room. Ten
title: Emma

text: couple may stand here very well.”
title: Emma

text: Emma demurred. “It would be a crowd—a sad crowd; and what could be
title: Emma

text: worse than dancing without space to turn in?”
title: Emma

text: “Very true,” he gravely replied; “it was very bad.” But still he went
title: Emma

text: on measuring, and still he ended with,
title: Emma

text: “I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple.”
title: Emma

text: “No, no,” said she, “you are quite unreasonable. It would be dreadful
title: Emma

text: to be standing so close! Nothing can be farther from pleasure than to
title: Emma

text: be dancing in a crowd—and a crowd in a little room!”
title: Emma

text: “There is no denying it,” he replied. “I agree with you exactly. A
title: Emma

text: crowd in a little room—Miss Woodhouse, you have the art of giving
title: Emma

text: pictures in a few words. Exquisite, quite exquisite!—Still, however,
title: Emma

text: having proceeded so far, one is unwilling to give the matter up. It
title: Emma

text: would be a disappointment to my father—and altogether—I do not know
title: Emma

text: that—I am rather of opinion that ten couple might stand here very
title: Emma

text: well.”
title: Emma

text: Emma perceived that the nature of his gallantry was a little
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: the scheme. It soon appeared that he came to announce an improvement.
title: Emma

text: “Well, Miss Woodhouse,” he almost immediately began, “your inclination
title: Emma

text: for dancing has not been quite frightened away, I hope, by the terrors
title: Emma

text: of my father’s little rooms. I bring a new proposal on the subject:—a
title: Emma

text: thought of my father’s, which waits only your approbation to be acted
title: Emma

text: upon. May I hope for the honour of your hand for the two first dances
title: Emma

text: of this little projected ball, to be given, not at Randalls, but at the
title: Emma

text: Crown Inn?”
title: Emma

text: “The Crown!”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; if you and Mr. Woodhouse see no objection, and I trust you
title: Emma

text: cannot, my father hopes his friends will be so kind as to visit him
title: Emma

text: there. Better accommodations, he can promise them, and not a less
title: Emma

text: grateful welcome than at Randalls. It is his own idea. Mrs. Weston sees
title: Emma

text: no objection to it, provided you are satisfied. This is what we all
title: Emma

text: feel. Oh! you were perfectly right! Ten couple, in either of the
title: Emma

text: Randalls rooms, would have been insufferable!—Dreadful!—I felt how
title: Emma

text: right you were the whole time, but was too anxious for securing _any_
title: Emma

text: _thing_ to like to yield. Is not it a good exchange?—You consent—I hope
title: Emma

text: you consent?”
title: Emma

text: “It appears to me a plan that nobody can object to, if Mr. and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston do not. I think it admirable; and, as far as I can answer for
title: Emma

text: myself, shall be most happy—It seems the only improvement that could
title: Emma

text: be. Papa, do you not think it an excellent improvement?”
title: Emma

text: She was obliged to repeat and explain it, before it was fully
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: necessary to make it acceptable.
title: Emma

text: “No; he thought it very far from an improvement—a very bad plan—much
title: Emma

text: worse than the other. A room at an inn was always damp and dangerous;
title: Emma

text: never properly aired, or fit to be inhabited. If they must dance, they
title: Emma

text: had better dance at Randalls. He had never been in the room at the
title: Emma

text: Crown in his life—did not know the people who kept it by sight.—Oh!
title: Emma

text: no—a very bad plan. They would catch worse colds at the Crown than
title: Emma

text: anywhere.”
title: Emma

text: “I was going to observe, sir,” said Frank Churchill, “that one of the
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: any body’s catching cold—so much less danger at the Crown than at
title: Emma

text: Randalls! Mr. Perry might have reason to regret the alteration, but
title: Emma

text: nobody else could.”
title: Emma

text: “Sir,” said Mr. Woodhouse, rather warmly, “you are very much mistaken
title: Emma

text: if you suppose Mr. Perry to be that sort of character. Mr. Perry is
title: Emma

text: extremely concerned when any of us are ill. But I do not understand how
title: Emma

text: the room at the Crown can be safer for you than your father’s house.”
title: Emma

text: “From the very circumstance of its being larger, sir. We shall have no
title: Emma

text: occasion to open the windows at all—not once the whole evening; and it
title: Emma

text: is that dreadful habit of opening the windows, letting in cold air upon
title: Emma

text: heated bodies, which (as you well know, sir) does the mischief.”
title: Emma

text: “Open the windows!—but surely, Mr. Churchill, nobody would think of
title: Emma

text: opening the windows at Randalls. Nobody could be so imprudent! I never
title: Emma

text: heard of such a thing. Dancing with open windows!—I am sure, neither
title: Emma

text: your father nor Mrs. Weston (poor Miss Taylor that was) would suffer
title: Emma

text: it.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! sir—but a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind a
title: Emma

text: window-curtain, and throw up a sash, without its being suspected. I
title: Emma

text: have often known it done myself.”
title: Emma

text: “Have you indeed, sir?—Bless me! I never could have supposed it. But I
title: Emma

text: live out of the world, and am often astonished at what I hear. However,
title: Emma

text: this does make a difference; and, perhaps, when we come to talk it
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: can be done.”
title: Emma

text: “But, unfortunately, sir, my time is so limited—”
title: Emma

text: “Oh!” interrupted Emma, “there will be plenty of time for talking every
title: Emma

text: thing over. There is no hurry at all. If it can be contrived to be at
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: be so near their own stable.”
title: Emma

text: “So they will, my dear. That is a great thing. Not that James ever
title: Emma

text: complains; but it is right to spare our horses when we can. If I could
title: Emma

text: be sure of the rooms being thoroughly aired—but is Mrs. Stokes to be
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I can answer for every thing of that nature, sir, because it will be
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “There, papa!—Now you must be satisfied—Our own dear Mrs. Weston, who
title: Emma

text: is carefulness itself. Do not you remember what Mr. Perry said, so many
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: wrap Miss Emma up, you need not have any fears, sir.’ How often have I
title: Emma

text: heard you speak of it as such a compliment to her!”
title: Emma

text: “Aye, very true. Mr. Perry did say so. I shall never forget it. Poor
title: Emma

text: little Emma! You were very bad with the measles; that is, you would
title: Emma

text: have been very bad, but for Perry’s great attention. He came four times
title: Emma

text: a day for a week. He said, from the first, it was a very good
title: Emma

text: sort—which was our great comfort; but the measles are a dreadful
title: Emma

text: complaint. I hope whenever poor Isabella’s little ones have the
title: Emma

text: measles, she will send for Perry.”

text: “My father and Mrs. Weston are at the Crown at this moment,” said Frank
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma was most happy to be called to such a council; and her father,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “My dear, you are too particular,” said her husband. “What does all
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: One perplexity, however, arose, which the gentlemen did not disdain. It
title: Emma

text: regarded a supper-room. At the time of the ballroom’s being built,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Weston was afraid of draughts for the young people in that passage; and
title: Emma

text: neither Emma nor the gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: expediency, and looking into the doubtful room, observed,
title: Emma

text: “I do not think it _is_ so very small. We shall not be many, you know.”

title: Emma

text: through the passage, was calling out,
title: Emma

text: “You talk a great deal of the length of this passage, my dear. It is a
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: and a good wife, had examined the passage again, and found the evils of
title: Emma

text: it much less than she had supposed before—indeed very trifling; and
title: Emma

text: here ended the difficulties of decision. All the rest, in speculation
title: Emma

text: at least, was perfectly smooth. All the minor arrangements of table and
title: Emma

text: chair, lights and music, tea and supper, made themselves; or were left
title: Emma

text: as mere trifles to be settled at any time between Mrs. Weston and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Stokes.—Every body invited, was certainly to come; Frank had already
title: Emma

text: written to Enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond his fortnight,
title: Emma

text: which could not possibly be refused. And a delightful dance it was to
title: Emma

text: be.
title: Emma

text: Most cordially, when Miss Bates arrived, did she agree that it must. As
title: Emma

text: a counsellor she was not wanted; but as an approver, (a much safer
title: Emma

text: character,) she was truly welcome. Her approbation, at once general and
title: Emma

text: minute, warm and incessant, could not but please; and for another
title: Emma

text: half-hour they were all walking to and fro, between the different
title: Emma

text: rooms, some suggesting, some attending, and all in happy enjoyment of
title: Emma

text: the future. The party did not break up without Emma’s being positively
title: Emma

text: secured for the two first dances by the hero of the evening, nor
title: Emma

text: without her overhearing Mr. Weston whisper to his wife, “He has asked
title: Emma

text: her, my dear. That’s right. I knew he would!”
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XII
title: Emma

text: One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball completely
title: Emma

text: satisfactory to Emma—its being fixed for a day within the granted term
title: Emma

text: of Frank Churchill’s stay in Surry; for, in spite of Mr. Weston’s
title: Emma

text: confidence, she could not think it so very impossible that the
title: Emma

text: Churchills might not allow their nephew to remain a day beyond his
title: Emma

text: fortnight. But this was not judged feasible. The preparations must take
title: Emma

text: their time, nothing could be properly ready till the third week were
title: Emma

text: entered on, and for a few days they must be planning, proceeding and
title: Emma

text: hoping in uncertainty—at the risk—in her opinion, the great risk, of
title: Emma

text: its being all in vain.
title: Emma

text: Enscombe however was gracious, gracious in fact, if not in word. His
title: Emma

text: wish of staying longer evidently did not please; but it was not
title: Emma

text: opposed. All was safe and prosperous; and as the removal of one
title: Emma

text: solicitude generally makes way for another, Emma, being now certain of
title: Emma

text: her ball, began to adopt as the next vexation Mr. Knightley’s provoking
title: Emma

text: indifference about it. Either because he did not dance himself, or
title: Emma

text: because the plan had been formed without his being consulted, he seemed
title: Emma

text: resolved that it should not interest him, determined against its
title: Emma

text: exciting any present curiosity, or affording him any future amusement.
title: Emma

text: To her voluntary communications Emma could get no more approving reply,
title: Emma

text: than,
title: Emma

text: “Very well. If the Westons think it worth while to be at all this
title: Emma

text: trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment, I have nothing to say
title: Emma

text: against it, but that they shall not chuse pleasures for me.—Oh! yes, I
title: Emma

text: must be there; I could not refuse; and I will keep as much awake as I
title: Emma

text: can; but I would rather be at home, looking over William Larkins’s
title: Emma

text: week’s account; much rather, I confess.—Pleasure in seeing dancing!—not
title: Emma

text: I, indeed—I never look at it—I do not know who does.—Fine dancing, I
title: Emma

text: believe, like virtue, must be its own reward. Those who are standing by
title: Emma

text: are usually thinking of something very different.”
title: Emma

text: This Emma felt was aimed at her; and it made her quite angry. It was
title: Emma

text: not in compliment to Jane Fairfax however that he was so indifferent,
title: Emma

text: or so indignant; he was not guided by _her_ feelings in reprobating the
title: Emma

text: ball, for _she_ enjoyed the thought of it to an extraordinary degree.
title: Emma

text: It made her animated—open hearted—she voluntarily said;—
title: Emma

text: “Oh! Miss Woodhouse, I hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball.
title: Emma

text: What a disappointment it would be! I do look forward to it, I own, with
title: Emma

text: _very_ great pleasure.”
title: Emma

text: It was not to oblige Jane Fairfax therefore that he would have
title: Emma

text: preferred the society of William Larkins. No!—she was more and more
title: Emma

text: convinced that Mrs. Weston was quite mistaken in that surmise. There
title: Emma

text: was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment on his
title: Emma

text: side—but no love.
title: Emma

text: Alas! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with Mr. Knightley. Two
title: Emma

text: days of joyful security were immediately followed by the over-throw of
title: Emma

text: every thing. A letter arrived from Mr. Churchill to urge his nephew’s
title: Emma

text: instant return. Mrs. Churchill was unwell—far too unwell to do without
title: Emma

text: him; she had been in a very suffering state (so said her husband) when
title: Emma

text: writing to her nephew two days before, though from her usual
title: Emma

text: unwillingness to give pain, and constant habit of never thinking of
title: Emma

text: herself, she had not mentioned it; but now she was too ill to trifle,
title: Emma

text: and must entreat him to set off for Enscombe without delay.
title: Emma

text: The substance of this letter was forwarded to Emma, in a note from Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston, instantly. As to his going, it was inevitable. He must be gone
title: Emma

text: within a few hours, though without feeling any real alarm for his aunt,
title: Emma

text: to lessen his repugnance. He knew her illnesses; they never occurred
title: Emma

text: but for her own convenience.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston added, “that he could only allow himself time to hurry to
title: Emma

text: Highbury, after breakfast, and take leave of the few friends there whom
title: Emma

text: he could suppose to feel any interest in him; and that he might be
title: Emma

text: expected at Hartfield very soon.”
title: Emma

text: This wretched note was the finale of Emma’s breakfast. When once it had
title: Emma

text: been read, there was no doing any thing, but lament and exclaim. The
title: Emma

text: loss of the ball—the loss of the young man—and all that the young man
title: Emma

text: might be feeling!—It was too wretched!—Such a delightful evening as it
title: Emma

text: would have been!—Every body so happy! and she and her partner the
title: Emma

text: happiest!—“I said it would be so,” was the only consolation.
title: Emma

text: Her father’s feelings were quite distinct. He thought principally of
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Churchill’s illness, and wanted to know how she was treated; and
title: Emma

text: as for the ball, it was shocking to have dear Emma disappointed; but
title: Emma

text: they would all be safer at home.
title: Emma

text: Emma was ready for her visitor some time before he appeared; but if
title: Emma

text: this reflected at all upon his impatience, his sorrowful look and total
title: Emma

text: want of spirits when he did come might redeem him. He felt the going
title: Emma

text: away almost too much to speak of it. His dejection was most evident. He
title: Emma

text: sat really lost in thought for the first few minutes; and when rousing
title: Emma

text: himself, it was only to say,
title: Emma

text: “Of all horrid things, leave-taking is the worst.”
title: Emma

text: “But you will come again,” said Emma. “This will not be your only visit
title: Emma

text: to Randalls.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah!—(shaking his head)—the uncertainty of when I may be able to
title: Emma

text: return!—I shall try for it with a zeal!—It will be the object of all my
title: Emma

text: thoughts and cares!—and if my uncle and aunt go to town this spring—but
title: Emma

text: I am afraid—they did not stir last spring—I am afraid it is a custom
title: Emma

text: gone for ever.”
title: Emma

text: “Our poor ball must be quite given up.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! that ball!—why did we wait for any thing?—why not seize the
title: Emma

text: pleasure at once?—How often is happiness destroyed by preparation,
title: Emma

text: foolish preparation!—You told us it would be so.—Oh! Miss Woodhouse,
title: Emma

text: why are you always so right?”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed, I am very sorry to be right in this instance. I would much
title: Emma

text: rather have been merry than wise.”
title: Emma

text: “If I can come again, we are still to have our ball. My father depends
title: Emma

text: on it. Do not forget your engagement.”
title: Emma

text: Emma looked graciously.
title: Emma

text: “Such a fortnight as it has been!” he continued; “every day more
title: Emma

text: precious and more delightful than the day before!—every day making me
title: Emma

text: less fit to bear any other place. Happy those, who can remain at
title: Emma

text: Highbury!”
title: Emma

text: “As you do us such ample justice now,” said Emma, laughing, “I will
title: Emma

text: venture to ask, whether you did not come a little doubtfully at first?
title: Emma

text: Do not we rather surpass your expectations? I am sure we do. I am sure
title: Emma

text: you did not much expect to like us. You would not have been so long in
title: Emma

text: coming, if you had had a pleasant idea of Highbury.”
title: Emma

text: He laughed rather consciously; and though denying the sentiment, Emma
title: Emma

text: was convinced that it had been so.
title: Emma

text: “And you must be off this very morning?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; my father is to join me here: we shall walk back together, and I
title: Emma

text: must be off immediately. I am almost afraid that every moment will
title: Emma

text: bring him.”
title: Emma

text: “Not five minutes to spare even for your friends Miss Fairfax and Miss
title: Emma

text: Bates? How unlucky! Miss Bates’s powerful, argumentative mind might
title: Emma

text: have strengthened yours.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—I _have_ called there; passing the door, I thought it better. It
title: Emma

text: was a right thing to do. I went in for three minutes, and was detained
title: Emma

text: by Miss Bates’s being absent. She was out; and I felt it impossible not
title: Emma

text: to wait till she came in. She is a woman that one may, that one _must_
title: Emma

text: laugh at; but that one would not wish to slight. It was better to pay
title: Emma

text: my visit, then”—
title: Emma

text: He hesitated, got up, walked to a window.
title: Emma

text: “In short,” said he, “perhaps, Miss Woodhouse—I think you can hardly be
title: Emma

text: quite without suspicion”—
title: Emma

text: He looked at her, as if wanting to read her thoughts. She hardly knew
title: Emma

text: what to say. It seemed like the forerunner of something absolutely
title: Emma

text: serious, which she did not wish. Forcing herself to speak, therefore,
title: Emma

text: in the hope of putting it by, she calmly said,
title: Emma

text: “You are quite in the right; it was most natural to pay your visit,
title: Emma

text: then”—
title: Emma

text: He was silent. She believed he was looking at her; probably reflecting
title: Emma

text: on what she had said, and trying to understand the manner. She heard
title: Emma

text: him sigh. It was natural for him to feel that he had _cause_ to sigh.
title: Emma

text: He could not believe her to be encouraging him. A few awkward moments
title: Emma

text: passed, and he sat down again; and in a more determined manner said,
title: Emma

text: “It was something to feel that all the rest of my time might be given
title: Emma

text: to Hartfield. My regard for Hartfield is most warm”—
title: Emma

text: He stopt again, rose again, and seemed quite embarrassed.—He was more
title: Emma

text: in love with her than Emma had supposed; and who can say how it might
title: Emma

text: have ended, if his father had not made his appearance? Mr. Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: soon followed; and the necessity of exertion made him composed.
title: Emma

text: A very few minutes more, however, completed the present trial. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston, always alert when business was to be done, and as incapable of
title: Emma

text: procrastinating any evil that was inevitable, as of foreseeing any that
title: Emma

text: was doubtful, said, “It was time to go;” and the young man, though he
title: Emma

text: might and did sigh, could not but agree, to take leave.
title: Emma

text: “I shall hear about you all,” said he; “that is my chief consolation. I
title: Emma

text: shall hear of every thing that is going on among you. I have engaged
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston to correspond with me. She has been so kind as to promise
title: Emma

text: it. Oh! the blessing of a female correspondent, when one is really
title: Emma

text: interested in the absent!—she will tell me every thing. In her letters
title: Emma

text: I shall be at dear Highbury again.”
title: Emma

text: A very friendly shake of the hand, a very earnest “Good-bye,” closed
title: Emma

text: the speech, and the door had soon shut out Frank Churchill. Short had
title: Emma

text: been the notice—short their meeting; he was gone; and Emma felt so
title: Emma

text: sorry to part, and foresaw so great a loss to their little society from
title: Emma

text: his absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry, and feeling it
title: Emma

text: too much.
title: Emma

text: It was a sad change. They had been meeting almost every day since his
title: Emma

text: arrival. Certainly his being at Randalls had given great spirit to the
title: Emma

text: last two weeks—indescribable spirit; the idea, the expectation of
title: Emma

text: seeing him which every morning had brought, the assurance of his
title: Emma

text: attentions, his liveliness, his manners! It had been a very happy
title: Emma

text: fortnight, and forlorn must be the sinking from it into the common
title: Emma

text: course of Hartfield days. To complete every other recommendation, he
title: Emma

text: had _almost_ told her that he loved her. What strength, or what
title: Emma

text: constancy of affection he might be subject to, was another point; but
title: Emma

text: at present she could not doubt his having a decidedly warm admiration,
title: Emma

text: a conscious preference of herself; and this persuasion, joined to all
title: Emma

text: the rest, made her think that she _must_ be a little in love with him,
title: Emma

text: in spite of every previous determination against it.
title: Emma

text: “I certainly must,” said she. “This sensation of listlessness,
title: Emma

text: weariness, stupidity, this disinclination to sit down and employ
title: Emma

text: myself, this feeling of every thing’s being dull and insipid about the
title: Emma

text: house!— I must be in love; I should be the oddest creature in the world
title: Emma

text: if I were not—for a few weeks at least. Well! evil to some is always
title: Emma

text: good to others. I shall have many fellow-mourners for the ball, if not
title: Emma

text: for Frank Churchill; but Mr. Knightley will be happy. He may spend the
title: Emma

text: evening with his dear William Larkins now if he likes.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, however, shewed no triumphant happiness. He could not
title: Emma

text: say that he was sorry on his own account; his very cheerful look would
title: Emma

text: have contradicted him if he had; but he said, and very steadily, that
title: Emma

text: he was sorry for the disappointment of the others, and with
title: Emma

text: considerable kindness added,
title: Emma

text: “You, Emma, who have so few opportunities of dancing, you are really
title: Emma

text: out of luck; you are very much out of luck!”
title: Emma

text: It was some days before she saw Jane Fairfax, to judge of her honest
title: Emma

text: regret in this woeful change; but when they did meet, her composure was
title: Emma

text: odious. She had been particularly unwell, however, suffering from
title: Emma

text: headache to a degree, which made her aunt declare, that had the ball
title: Emma

text: taken place, she did not think Jane could have attended it; and it was
title: Emma

text: charity to impute some of her unbecoming indifference to the languor of
title: Emma

text: ill-health.

text: CHAPTER XIII
title: Emma

text: Emma continued to entertain no doubt of her being in love. Her ideas
title: Emma

text: only varied as to the how much. At first, she thought it was a good
title: Emma

text: deal; and afterwards, but little. She had great pleasure in hearing
title: Emma

text: Frank Churchill talked of; and, for his sake, greater pleasure than
title: Emma

text: ever in seeing Mr. and Mrs. Weston; she was very often thinking of him,
title: Emma

text: and quite impatient for a letter, that she might know how he was, how
title: Emma

text: were his spirits, how was his aunt, and what was the chance of his
title: Emma

text: coming to Randalls again this spring. But, on the other hand, she could
title: Emma

text: not admit herself to be unhappy, nor, after the first morning, to be
title: Emma

text: less disposed for employment than usual; she was still busy and
title: Emma

text: cheerful; and, pleasing as he was, she could yet imagine him to have
title: Emma

text: faults; and farther, though thinking of him so much, and, as she sat
title: Emma

text: drawing or working, forming a thousand amusing schemes for the progress
title: Emma

text: and close of their attachment, fancying interesting dialogues, and
title: Emma

text: inventing elegant letters; the conclusion of every imaginary
title: Emma

text: declaration on his side was that she _refused_ _him_. Their affection
title: Emma

text: was always to subside into friendship. Every thing tender and charming
title: Emma

text: was to mark their parting; but still they were to part. When she became
title: Emma

text: sensible of this, it struck her that she could not be very much in
title: Emma

text: love; for in spite of her previous and fixed determination never to
title: Emma

text: quit her father, never to marry, a strong attachment certainly must
title: Emma

text: produce more of a struggle than she could foresee in her own feelings.
title: Emma

text: “I do not find myself making any use of the word _sacrifice_,” said
title: Emma

text: she.—“In not one of all my clever replies, my delicate negatives, is
title: Emma

text: there any allusion to making a sacrifice. I do suspect that he is not
title: Emma

text: really necessary to my happiness. So much the better. I certainly will
title: Emma

text: not persuade myself to feel more than I do. I am quite enough in love.
title: Emma

text: I should be sorry to be more.”
title: Emma

text: Upon the whole, she was equally contented with her view of his
title: Emma

text: feelings.
title: Emma

text: “_He_ is undoubtedly very much in love—every thing denotes it—very much
title: Emma

text: in love indeed!—and when he comes again, if his affection continue, I
title: Emma

text: must be on my guard not to encourage it.—It would be most inexcusable
title: Emma

text: to do otherwise, as my own mind is quite made up. Not that I imagine he
title: Emma

text: can think I have been encouraging him hitherto. No, if he had believed
title: Emma

text: me at all to share his feelings, he would not have been so wretched.
title: Emma

text: Could he have thought himself encouraged, his looks and language at
title: Emma

text: parting would have been different.—Still, however, I must be on my
title: Emma

text: guard. This is in the supposition of his attachment continuing what it
title: Emma

text: now is; but I do not know that I expect it will; I do not look upon him
title: Emma

text: to be quite the sort of man—I do not altogether build upon his
title: Emma

text: steadiness or constancy.—His feelings are warm, but I can imagine them
title: Emma

text: rather changeable.—Every consideration of the subject, in short, makes
title: Emma

text: me thankful that my happiness is not more deeply involved.—I shall do
title: Emma

text: very well again after a little while—and then, it will be a good thing
title: Emma

text: over; for they say every body is in love once in their lives, and I
title: Emma

text: shall have been let off easily.”
title: Emma

text: When his letter to Mrs. Weston arrived, Emma had the perusal of it; and
title: Emma

text: she read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made her at
title: Emma

text: first shake her head over her own sensations, and think she had
title: Emma

text: undervalued their strength. It was a long, well-written letter, giving
title: Emma

text: the particulars of his journey and of his feelings, expressing all the
title: Emma

text: affection, gratitude, and respect which was natural and honourable, and
title: Emma

text: describing every thing exterior and local that could be supposed
title: Emma

text: attractive, with spirit and precision. No suspicious flourishes now of
title: Emma

text: apology or concern; it was the language of real feeling towards Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston; and the transition from Highbury to Enscombe, the contrast
title: Emma

text: between the places in some of the first blessings of social life was
title: Emma

text: just enough touched on to shew how keenly it was felt, and how much
title: Emma

text: more might have been said but for the restraints of propriety.—The
title: Emma

text: charm of her own name was not wanting. _Miss_ _Woodhouse_ appeared more
title: Emma

text: than once, and never without a something of pleasing connexion, either
title: Emma

text: a compliment to her taste, or a remembrance of what she had said; and
title: Emma

text: in the very last time of its meeting her eye, unadorned as it was by
title: Emma

text: any such broad wreath of gallantry, she yet could discern the effect of
title: Emma

text: her influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment perhaps of all
title: Emma

text: conveyed. Compressed into the very lowest vacant corner were these
title: Emma

text: words—“I had not a spare moment on Tuesday, as you know, for Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s beautiful little friend. Pray make my excuses and adieus to
title: Emma

text: her.” This, Emma could not doubt, was all for herself. Harriet was
title: Emma

text: remembered only from being _her_ friend. His information and prospects
title: Emma

text: as to Enscombe were neither worse nor better than had been anticipated;
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Churchill was recovering, and he dared not yet, even in his own
title: Emma

text: imagination, fix a time for coming to Randalls again.
title: Emma

text: Gratifying, however, and stimulative as was the letter in the material
title: Emma

text: part, its sentiments, she yet found, when it was folded up and returned
title: Emma

text: to Mrs. Weston, that it had not added any lasting warmth, that she
title: Emma

text: could still do without the writer, and that he must learn to do without
title: Emma

text: her. Her intentions were unchanged. Her resolution of refusal only grew
title: Emma

text: more interesting by the addition of a scheme for his subsequent
title: Emma

text: consolation and happiness. His recollection of Harriet, and the words
title: Emma

text: which clothed it, the “beautiful little friend,” suggested to her the
title: Emma

text: idea of Harriet’s succeeding her in his affections. Was it
title: Emma

text: impossible?—No.—Harriet undoubtedly was greatly his inferior in
title: Emma

text: understanding; but he had been very much struck with the loveliness of
title: Emma

text: her face and the warm simplicity of her manner; and all the
title: Emma

text: probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in her favour.—For
title: Emma

text: Harriet, it would be advantageous and delightful indeed.
title: Emma

text: “I must not dwell upon it,” said she.—“I must not think of it. I know
title: Emma

text: the danger of indulging such speculations. But stranger things have
title: Emma

text: happened; and when we cease to care for each other as we do now, it
title: Emma

text: will be the means of confirming us in that sort of true disinterested
title: Emma

text: friendship which I can already look forward to with pleasure.”
title: Emma

text: It was well to have a comfort in store on Harriet’s behalf, though it
title: Emma

text: might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom; for evil in that
title: Emma

text: quarter was at hand. As Frank Churchill’s arrival had succeeded Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s engagement in the conversation of Highbury, as the latest
title: Emma

text: interest had entirely borne down the first, so now upon Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill’s disappearance, Mr. Elton’s concerns were assuming the most
title: Emma

text: irresistible form.—His wedding-day was named. He would soon be among
title: Emma

text: them again; Mr. Elton and his bride. There was hardly time to talk over
title: Emma

text: the first letter from Enscombe before “Mr. Elton and his bride” was in
title: Emma

text: every body’s mouth, and Frank Churchill was forgotten. Emma grew sick
title: Emma

text: at the sound. She had had three weeks of happy exemption from Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton; and Harriet’s mind, she had been willing to hope, had been
title: Emma

text: lately gaining strength. With Mr. Weston’s ball in view at least, there
title: Emma

text: had been a great deal of insensibility to other things; but it was now
title: Emma

text: too evident that she had not attained such a state of composure as
title: Emma

text: could stand against the actual approach—new carriage, bell-ringing, and
title: Emma

text: all.
title: Emma

text: Poor Harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the
title: Emma

text: reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that Emma could
title: Emma

text: give. Emma felt that she could not do too much for her, that Harriet
title: Emma

text: had a right to all her ingenuity and all her patience; but it was heavy
title: Emma

text: work to be for ever convincing without producing any effect, for ever
title: Emma

text: agreed to, without being able to make their opinions the same. Harriet
title: Emma

text: listened submissively, and said “it was very true—it was just as Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse described—it was not worth while to think about them—and she
title: Emma

text: would not think about them any longer” but no change of subject could
title: Emma

text: avail, and the next half-hour saw her as anxious and restless about the
title: Emma

text: Eltons as before. At last Emma attacked her on another ground.
title: Emma

text: “Your allowing yourself to be so occupied and so unhappy about Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s marrying, Harriet, is the strongest reproach you can make _me_.
title: Emma

text: You could not give me a greater reproof for the mistake I fell into. It
title: Emma

text: was all my doing, I know. I have not forgotten it, I assure
title: Emma

text: you.—Deceived myself, I did very miserably deceive you—and it will be a
title: Emma

text: painful reflection to me for ever. Do not imagine me in danger of
title: Emma

text: forgetting it.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words of eager
title: Emma

text: exclamation. Emma continued,
title: Emma

text: “I have not said, exert yourself Harriet for my sake; think less, talk
title: Emma

text: less of Mr. Elton for my sake; because for your own sake rather, I
title: Emma

text: would wish it to be done, for the sake of what is more important than
title: Emma

text: my comfort, a habit of self-command in you, a consideration of what is
title: Emma

text: your duty, an attention to propriety, an endeavour to avoid the
title: Emma

text: suspicions of others, to save your health and credit, and restore your
title: Emma

text: tranquillity. These are the motives which I have been pressing on you.
title: Emma

text: They are very important—and sorry I am that you cannot feel them
title: Emma

text: sufficiently to act upon them. My being saved from pain is a very
title: Emma

text: secondary consideration. I want you to save yourself from greater pain.
title: Emma

text: Perhaps I may sometimes have felt that Harriet would not forget what
title: Emma

text: was due—or rather what would be kind by me.”
title: Emma

text: This appeal to her affections did more than all the rest. The idea of
title: Emma

text: wanting gratitude and consideration for Miss Woodhouse, whom she really
title: Emma

text: loved extremely, made her wretched for a while, and when the violence
title: Emma

text: of grief was comforted away, still remained powerful enough to prompt
title: Emma

text: to what was right and support her in it very tolerably.
title: Emma

text: “You, who have been the best friend I ever had in my life—Want
title: Emma

text: gratitude to you!—Nobody is equal to you!—I care for nobody as I do for
title: Emma

text: you!—Oh! Miss Woodhouse, how ungrateful I have been!”
title: Emma

text: Such expressions, assisted as they were by every thing that look and
title: Emma

text: manner could do, made Emma feel that she had never loved Harriet so
title: Emma

text: well, nor valued her affection so highly before.
title: Emma

text: “There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart,” said she afterwards
title: Emma

text: to herself. “There is nothing to be compared to it. Warmth and
title: Emma

text: tenderness of heart, with an affectionate, open manner, will beat all
title: Emma

text: the clearness of head in the world, for attraction, I am sure it will.
title: Emma

text: It is tenderness of heart which makes my dear father so generally
title: Emma

text: beloved—which gives Isabella all her popularity.—I have it not—but I
title: Emma

text: know how to prize and respect it.—Harriet is my superior in all the
title: Emma

text: charm and all the felicity it gives. Dear Harriet!—I would not change
title: Emma

text: you for the clearest-headed, longest-sighted, best-judging female
title: Emma

text: breathing. Oh! the coldness of a Jane Fairfax!—Harriet is worth a
title: Emma

text: hundred such—And for a wife—a sensible man’s wife—it is invaluable. I
title: Emma

text: mention no names; but happy the man who changes Emma for Harriet!”
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XIV
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton was first seen at church: but though devotion might be
title: Emma

text: interrupted, curiosity could not be satisfied by a bride in a pew, and
title: Emma

text: it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid, to
title: Emma

text: settle whether she were very pretty indeed, or only rather pretty, or
title: Emma

text: not pretty at all.
title: Emma

text: Emma had feelings, less of curiosity than of pride or propriety, to
title: Emma

text: make her resolve on not being the last to pay her respects; and she
title: Emma

text: made a point of Harriet’s going with her, that the worst of the
title: Emma

text: business might be gone through as soon as possible.
title: Emma

text: She could not enter the house again, could not be in the same room to
title: Emma

text: which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago, to
title: Emma

text: lace up her boot, without _recollecting_. A thousand vexatious thoughts
title: Emma

text: would recur. Compliments, charades, and horrible blunders; and it was
title: Emma

text: not to be supposed that poor Harriet should not be recollecting too;
title: Emma

text: but she behaved very well, and was only rather pale and silent. The
title: Emma

text: visit was of course short; and there was so much embarrassment and
title: Emma

text: occupation of mind to shorten it, that Emma would not allow herself
title: Emma

text: entirely to form an opinion of the lady, and on no account to give one,
title: Emma

text: beyond the nothing-meaning terms of being “elegantly dressed, and very
title: Emma

text: pleasing.”
title: Emma

text: She did not really like her. She would not be in a hurry to find fault,
title: Emma

text: but she suspected that there was no elegance;—ease, but not elegance.—
title: Emma

text: She was almost sure that for a young woman, a stranger, a bride, there
title: Emma

text: was too much ease. Her person was rather good; her face not unpretty;
title: Emma

text: but neither feature, nor air, nor voice, nor manner, were elegant. Emma
title: Emma

text: thought at least it would turn out so.
title: Emma

text: As for Mr. Elton, his manners did not appear—but no, she would not
title: Emma

text: permit a hasty or a witty word from herself about his manners. It was
title: Emma

text: an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits, and a
title: Emma

text: man had need be all grace to acquit himself well through it. The woman
title: Emma

text: was better off; she might have the assistance of fine clothes, and the
title: Emma

text: privilege of bashfulness, but the man had only his own good sense to
title: Emma

text: depend on; and when she considered how peculiarly unlucky poor Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton was in being in the same room at once with the woman he had just
title: Emma

text: married, the woman he had wanted to marry, and the woman whom he had
title: Emma

text: been expected to marry, she must allow him to have the right to look as
title: Emma

text: little wise, and to be as much affectedly, and as little really easy as
title: Emma

text: could be.
title: Emma

text: “Well, Miss Woodhouse,” said Harriet, when they had quitted the house,
title: Emma

text: and after waiting in vain for her friend to begin; “Well, Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, (with a gentle sigh,) what do you think of her?—Is not she
title: Emma

text: very charming?”
title: Emma

text: There was a little hesitation in Emma’s answer.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes—very—a very pleasing young woman.”
title: Emma

text: “I think her beautiful, quite beautiful.”
title: Emma

text: “Very nicely dressed, indeed; a remarkably elegant gown.”
title: Emma

text: “I am not at all surprized that he should have fallen in love.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no—there is nothing to surprize one at all.—A pretty fortune; and
title: Emma

text: she came in his way.”
title: Emma

text: “I dare say,” returned Harriet, sighing again, “I dare say she was very
title: Emma

text: much attached to him.”
title: Emma

text: “Perhaps she might; but it is not every man’s fate to marry the woman
title: Emma

text: who loves him best. Miss Hawkins perhaps wanted a home, and thought
title: Emma

text: this the best offer she was likely to have.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said Harriet earnestly, “and well she might, nobody could ever
title: Emma

text: have a better. Well, I wish them happy with all my heart. And now, Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, I do not think I shall mind seeing them again. He is just as
title: Emma

text: superior as ever;—but being married, you know, it is quite a different
title: Emma

text: thing. No, indeed, Miss Woodhouse, you need not be afraid; I can sit
title: Emma

text: and admire him now without any great misery. To know that he has not
title: Emma

text: thrown himself away, is such a comfort!—She does seem a charming young
title: Emma

text: woman, just what he deserves. Happy creature! He called her ‘Augusta.’
title: Emma

text: How delightful!”
title: Emma

text: When the visit was returned, Emma made up her mind. She could then see
title: Emma

text: more and judge better. From Harriet’s happening not to be at Hartfield,
title: Emma

text: and her father’s being present to engage Mr. Elton, she had a quarter
title: Emma

text: of an hour of the lady’s conversation to herself, and could composedly
title: Emma

text: attend to her; and the quarter of an hour quite convinced her that Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton was a vain woman, extremely well satisfied with herself, and
title: Emma

text: thinking much of her own importance; that she meant to shine and be
title: Emma

text: very superior, but with manners which had been formed in a bad school,
title: Emma

text: pert and familiar; that all her notions were drawn from one set of
title: Emma

text: people, and one style of living; that if not foolish she was ignorant,
title: Emma

text: and that her society would certainly do Mr. Elton no good.
title: Emma

text: Harriet would have been a better match. If not wise or refined herself,
title: Emma

text: she would have connected him with those who were; but Miss Hawkins, it
title: Emma

text: might be fairly supposed from her easy conceit, had been the best of
title: Emma

text: her own set. The rich brother-in-law near Bristol was the pride of the
title: Emma

text: alliance, and his place and his carriages were the pride of him.
title: Emma

text: The very first subject after being seated was Maple Grove, “My brother
title: Emma

text: Mr. Suckling’s seat;”—a comparison of Hartfield to Maple Grove. The
title: Emma

text: grounds of Hartfield were small, but neat and pretty; and the house was
title: Emma

text: modern and well-built. Mrs. Elton seemed most favourably impressed by
title: Emma

text: the size of the room, the entrance, and all that she could see or
title: Emma

text: imagine. “Very like Maple Grove indeed!—She was quite struck by the
title: Emma

text: likeness!—That room was the very shape and size of the morning-room at
title: Emma

text: Maple Grove; her sister’s favourite room.”—Mr. Elton was appealed
title: Emma

text: to.—“Was not it astonishingly like?—She could really almost fancy
title: Emma

text: herself at Maple Grove.”
title: Emma

text: “And the staircase—You know, as I came in, I observed how very like the
title: Emma

text: staircase was; placed exactly in the same part of the house. I really
title: Emma

text: could not help exclaiming! I assure you, Miss Woodhouse, it is very
title: Emma

text: delightful to me, to be reminded of a place I am so extremely partial
title: Emma

text: to as Maple Grove. I have spent so many happy months there! (with a
title: Emma

text: little sigh of sentiment). A charming place, undoubtedly. Every body
title: Emma

text: who sees it is struck by its beauty; but to me, it has been quite a
title: Emma

text: home. Whenever you are transplanted, like me, Miss Woodhouse, you will
title: Emma

text: understand how very delightful it is to meet with any thing at all like
title: Emma

text: what one has left behind. I always say this is quite one of the evils
title: Emma

text: of matrimony.”
title: Emma

text: Emma made as slight a reply as she could; but it was fully sufficient
title: Emma

text: for Mrs. Elton, who only wanted to be talking herself.
title: Emma

text: “So extremely like Maple Grove! And it is not merely the house—the
title: Emma

text: grounds, I assure you, as far as I could observe, are strikingly like.
title: Emma

text: The laurels at Maple Grove are in the same profusion as here, and stand
title: Emma

text: very much in the same way—just across the lawn; and I had a glimpse of
title: Emma

text: a fine large tree, with a bench round it, which put me so exactly in
title: Emma

text: mind! My brother and sister will be enchanted with this place. People
title: Emma

text: who have extensive grounds themselves are always pleased with any thing
title: Emma

text: in the same style.”
title: Emma

text: Emma doubted the truth of this sentiment. She had a great idea that
title: Emma

text: people who had extensive grounds themselves cared very little for the
title: Emma

text: extensive grounds of any body else; but it was not worth while to
title: Emma

text: attack an error so double-dyed, and therefore only said in reply,
title: Emma

text: “When you have seen more of this country, I am afraid you will think
title: Emma

text: you have overrated Hartfield. Surry is full of beauties.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes, I am quite aware of that. It is the garden of England, you
title: Emma

text: know. Surry is the garden of England.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; but we must not rest our claims on that distinction. Many
title: Emma

text: counties, I believe, are called the garden of England, as well as
title: Emma

text: Surry.”
title: Emma

text: “No, I fancy not,” replied Mrs. Elton, with a most satisfied smile. “I
title: Emma

text: never heard any county but Surry called so.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was silenced.
title: Emma

text: “My brother and sister have promised us a visit in the spring, or
title: Emma

text: summer at farthest,” continued Mrs. Elton; “and that will be our time
title: Emma

text: for exploring. While they are with us, we shall explore a great deal, I
title: Emma

text: dare say. They will have their barouche-landau, of course, which holds
title: Emma

text: four perfectly; and therefore, without saying any thing of _our_
title: Emma

text: carriage, we should be able to explore the different beauties extremely
title: Emma

text: well. They would hardly come in their chaise, I think, at that season
title: Emma

text: of the year. Indeed, when the time draws on, I shall decidedly
title: Emma

text: recommend their bringing the barouche-landau; it will be so very much
title: Emma

text: preferable. When people come into a beautiful country of this sort, you
title: Emma

text: know, Miss Woodhouse, one naturally wishes them to see as much as
title: Emma

text: possible; and Mr. Suckling is extremely fond of exploring. We explored
title: Emma

text: to King’s-Weston twice last summer, in that way, most delightfully,
title: Emma

text: just after their first having the barouche-landau. You have many
title: Emma

text: parties of that kind here, I suppose, Miss Woodhouse, every summer?”
title: Emma

text: “No; not immediately here. We are rather out of distance of the very
title: Emma

text: striking beauties which attract the sort of parties you speak of; and
title: Emma

text: we are a very quiet set of people, I believe; more disposed to stay at
title: Emma

text: home than engage in schemes of pleasure.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! there is nothing like staying at home for real comfort. Nobody can
title: Emma

text: be more devoted to home than I am. I was quite a proverb for it at
title: Emma

text: Maple Grove. Many a time has Selina said, when she has been going to
title: Emma

text: Bristol, ‘I really cannot get this girl to move from the house. I
title: Emma

text: absolutely must go in by myself, though I hate being stuck up in the
title: Emma

text: barouche-landau without a companion; but Augusta, I believe, with her
title: Emma

text: own good-will, would never stir beyond the park paling.’ Many a time
title: Emma

text: has she said so; and yet I am no advocate for entire seclusion. I
title: Emma

text: think, on the contrary, when people shut themselves up entirely from
title: Emma

text: society, it is a very bad thing; and that it is much more advisable to
title: Emma

text: mix in the world in a proper degree, without living in it either too
title: Emma

text: much or too little. I perfectly understand your situation, however,
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse—(looking towards Mr. Woodhouse), Your father’s state of
title: Emma

text: health must be a great drawback. Why does not he try Bath?—Indeed he
title: Emma

text: should. Let me recommend Bath to you. I assure you I have no doubt of
title: Emma

text: its doing Mr. Woodhouse good.”
title: Emma

text: “My father tried it more than once, formerly; but without receiving any
title: Emma

text: benefit; and Mr. Perry, whose name, I dare say, is not unknown to you,
title: Emma

text: does not conceive it would be at all more likely to be useful now.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! that’s a great pity; for I assure you, Miss Woodhouse, where the
title: Emma

text: waters do agree, it is quite wonderful the relief they give. In my Bath
title: Emma

text: life, I have seen such instances of it! And it is so cheerful a place,
title: Emma

text: that it could not fail of being of use to Mr. Woodhouse’s spirits,
title: Emma

text: which, I understand, are sometimes much depressed. And as to its
title: Emma

text: recommendations to _you_, I fancy I need not take much pains to dwell
title: Emma

text: on them. The advantages of Bath to the young are pretty generally
title: Emma

text: understood. It would be a charming introduction for you, who have lived
title: Emma

text: so secluded a life; and I could immediately secure you some of the best
title: Emma

text: society in the place. A line from me would bring you a little host of
title: Emma

text: acquaintance; and my particular friend, Mrs. Partridge, the lady I have
title: Emma

text: always resided with when in Bath, would be most happy to shew you any
title: Emma

text: attentions, and would be the very person for you to go into public
title: Emma

text: with.”
title: Emma

text: It was as much as Emma could bear, without being impolite. The idea of
title: Emma

text: her being indebted to Mrs. Elton for what was called an
title: Emma

text: _introduction_—of her going into public under the auspices of a friend
title: Emma

text: of Mrs. Elton’s—probably some vulgar, dashing widow, who, with the help
title: Emma

text: of a boarder, just made a shift to live!—The dignity of Miss Woodhouse,
title: Emma

text: of Hartfield, was sunk indeed!
title: Emma

text: She restrained herself, however, from any of the reproofs she could
title: Emma

text: have given, and only thanked Mrs. Elton coolly; “but their going to
title: Emma

text: Bath was quite out of the question; and she was not perfectly convinced
title: Emma

text: that the place might suit her better than her father.” And then, to
title: Emma

text: prevent farther outrage and indignation, changed the subject directly.
title: Emma

text: “I do not ask whether you are musical, Mrs. Elton. Upon these
title: Emma

text: occasions, a lady’s character generally precedes her; and Highbury has
title: Emma

text: long known that you are a superior performer.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! no, indeed; I must protest against any such idea. A superior
title: Emma

text: performer!—very far from it, I assure you. Consider from how partial a
title: Emma

text: quarter your information came. I am doatingly fond of
title: Emma

text: music—passionately fond;—and my friends say I am not entirely devoid of
title: Emma

text: taste; but as to any thing else, upon my honour my performance is
title: Emma

text: _mediocre_ to the last degree. You, Miss Woodhouse, I well know, play
title: Emma

text: delightfully. I assure you it has been the greatest satisfaction,
title: Emma

text: comfort, and delight to me, to hear what a musical society I am got
title: Emma

text: into. I absolutely cannot do without music. It is a necessary of life
title: Emma

text: to me; and having always been used to a very musical society, both at
title: Emma

text: Maple Grove and in Bath, it would have been a most serious sacrifice. I
title: Emma

text: honestly said as much to Mr. E. when he was speaking of my future home,
title: Emma

text: and expressing his fears lest the retirement of it should be
title: Emma

text: disagreeable; and the inferiority of the house too—knowing what I had
title: Emma

text: been accustomed to—of course he was not wholly without apprehension.
title: Emma

text: When he was speaking of it in that way, I honestly said that _the_
title: Emma

text: _world_ I could give up—parties, balls, plays—for I had no fear of
title: Emma

text: retirement. Blessed with so many resources within myself, the world was
title: Emma

text: not necessary to _me_. I could do very well without it. To those who
title: Emma

text: had no resources it was a different thing; but my resources made me
title: Emma

text: quite independent. And as to smaller-sized rooms than I had been used
title: Emma

text: to, I really could not give it a thought. I hoped I was perfectly equal
title: Emma

text: to any sacrifice of that description. Certainly I had been accustomed
title: Emma

text: to every luxury at Maple Grove; but I did assure him that two carriages
title: Emma

text: were not necessary to my happiness, nor were spacious apartments.
title: Emma

text: ‘But,’ said I, ‘to be quite honest, I do not think I can live without
title: Emma

text: something of a musical society. I condition for nothing else; but
title: Emma

text: without music, life would be a blank to me.’”
title: Emma

text: “We cannot suppose,” said Emma, smiling, “that Mr. Elton would hesitate
title: Emma

text: to assure you of there being a _very_ musical society in Highbury; and
title: Emma

text: I hope you will not find he has outstepped the truth more than may be
title: Emma

text: pardoned, in consideration of the motive.”
title: Emma

text: “No, indeed, I have no doubts at all on that head. I am delighted to
title: Emma

text: find myself in such a circle. I hope we shall have many sweet little
title: Emma

text: concerts together. I think, Miss Woodhouse, you and I must establish a
title: Emma

text: musical club, and have regular weekly meetings at your house, or ours.
title: Emma

text: Will not it be a good plan? If _we_ exert ourselves, I think we shall
title: Emma

text: not be long in want of allies. Something of that nature would be
title: Emma

text: particularly desirable for _me_, as an inducement to keep me in
title: Emma

text: practice; for married women, you know—there is a sad story against
title: Emma

text: them, in general. They are but too apt to give up music.”
title: Emma

text: “But you, who are so extremely fond of it—there can be no danger,
title: Emma

text: surely?”
title: Emma

text: “I should hope not; but really when I look around among my
title: Emma

text: acquaintance, I tremble. Selina has entirely given up music—never
title: Emma

text: touches the instrument—though she played sweetly. And the same may be
title: Emma

text: said of Mrs. Jeffereys—Clara Partridge, that was—and of the two
title: Emma

text: Milmans, now Mrs. Bird and Mrs. James Cooper; and of more than I can
title: Emma

text: enumerate. Upon my word it is enough to put one in a fright. I used to
title: Emma

text: be quite angry with Selina; but really I begin now to comprehend that a
title: Emma

text: married woman has many things to call her attention. I believe I was
title: Emma

text: half an hour this morning shut up with my housekeeper.”
title: Emma

text: “But every thing of that kind,” said Emma, “will soon be in so regular
title: Emma

text: a train—”
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said Mrs. Elton, laughing, “we shall see.”
title: Emma

text: Emma, finding her so determined upon neglecting her music, had nothing
title: Emma

text: more to say; and, after a moment’s pause, Mrs. Elton chose another
title: Emma

text: subject.
title: Emma

text: “We have been calling at Randalls,” said she, “and found them both at
title: Emma

text: home; and very pleasant people they seem to be. I like them extremely.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston seems an excellent creature—quite a first-rate favourite
title: Emma

text: with me already, I assure you. And _she_ appears so truly good—there is
title: Emma

text: something so motherly and kind-hearted about her, that it wins upon one
title: Emma

text: directly. She was your governess, I think?”
title: Emma

text: Emma was almost too much astonished to answer; but Mrs. Elton hardly
title: Emma

text: waited for the affirmative before she went on.
title: Emma

text: “Having understood as much, I was rather astonished to find her so very
title: Emma

text: lady-like! But she is really quite the gentlewoman.”
title: Emma

text: “Mrs. Weston’s manners,” said Emma, “were always particularly good.
title: Emma

text: Their propriety, simplicity, and elegance, would make them the safest
title: Emma

text: model for any young woman.”
title: Emma

text: “And who do you think came in while we were there?”
title: Emma

text: Emma was quite at a loss. The tone implied some old acquaintance—and
title: Emma

text: how could she possibly guess?
title: Emma

text: “Knightley!” continued Mrs. Elton; “Knightley himself!—Was not it
title: Emma

text: lucky?—for, not being within when he called the other day, I had never
title: Emma

text: seen him before; and of course, as so particular a friend of Mr. E.’s,
title: Emma

text: I had a great curiosity. ‘My friend Knightley’ had been so often
title: Emma

text: mentioned, that I was really impatient to see him; and I must do my
title: Emma

text: caro sposo the justice to say that he need not be ashamed of his
title: Emma

text: friend. Knightley is quite the gentleman. I like him very much.
title: Emma

text: Decidedly, I think, a very gentleman-like man.”
title: Emma

text: Happily, it was now time to be gone. They were off; and Emma could
title: Emma

text: breathe.
title: Emma

text: “Insufferable woman!” was her immediate exclamation. “Worse than I had
title: Emma

text: supposed. Absolutely insufferable! Knightley!—I could not have believed
title: Emma

text: it. Knightley!—never seen him in her life before, and call him
title: Emma

text: Knightley!—and discover that he is a gentleman! A little upstart,
title: Emma

text: vulgar being, with her Mr. E., and her _caro_ _sposo_, and her
title: Emma

text: resources, and all her airs of pert pretension and underbred finery.
title: Emma

text: Actually to discover that Mr. Knightley is a gentleman! I doubt whether
title: Emma

text: he will return the compliment, and discover her to be a lady. I could
title: Emma

text: not have believed it! And to propose that she and I should unite to
title: Emma

text: form a musical club! One would fancy we were bosom friends! And Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston!—Astonished that the person who had brought me up should be a
title: Emma

text: gentlewoman! Worse and worse. I never met with her equal. Much beyond
title: Emma

text: my hopes. Harriet is disgraced by any comparison. Oh! what would Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill say to her, if he were here? How angry and how diverted he
title: Emma

text: would be! Ah! there I am—thinking of him directly. Always the first
title: Emma

text: person to be thought of! How I catch myself out! Frank Churchill comes
title: Emma

text: as regularly into my mind!”—
title: Emma

text: All this ran so glibly through her thoughts, that by the time her
title: Emma

text: father had arranged himself, after the bustle of the Eltons’ departure,
title: Emma

text: and was ready to speak, she was very tolerably capable of attending.
title: Emma

text: “Well, my dear,” he deliberately began, “considering we never saw her
title: Emma

text: before, she seems a very pretty sort of young lady; and I dare say she
title: Emma

text: was very much pleased with you. She speaks a little too quick. A little
title: Emma

text: quickness of voice there is which rather hurts the ear. But I believe I
title: Emma

text: am nice; I do not like strange voices; and nobody speaks like you and
title: Emma

text: poor Miss Taylor. However, she seems a very obliging, pretty-behaved
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I dare say your apologies were accepted, sir. Mr. Elton knows you.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes: but a young lady—a bride—I ought to have paid my respects to her

title: Emma

text: “But, my dear papa, you are no friend to matrimony; and therefore why
title: Emma

text: should you be so anxious to pay your respects to a _bride_? It ought to
title: Emma

text: be no recommendation to _you_. It is encouraging people to marry if you
title: Emma

text: make so much of them.”
title: Emma

text: “No, my dear, I never encouraged any body to marry, but I would always
title: Emma

text: wish to pay every proper attention to a lady—and a bride, especially,
title: Emma

text: is never to be neglected. More is avowedly due to _her_. A bride, you
title: Emma

text: know, my dear, is always the first in company, let the others be who
title: Emma

text: they may.”
title: Emma

text: “Well, papa, if this is not encouragement to marry, I do not know what
title: Emma

text: is. And I should never have expected you to be lending your sanction to
title: Emma

text: such vanity-baits for poor young ladies.”
title: Emma

text: “My dear, you do not understand me. This is a matter of mere common
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XV
title: Emma

text: Emma was not required, by any subsequent discovery, to retract her ill
title: Emma

text: opinion of Mrs. Elton. Her observation had been pretty correct. Such as
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton appeared to her on this second interview, such she appeared
title: Emma

text: whenever they met again,—self-important, presuming, familiar, ignorant,
title: Emma

text: and ill-bred. She had a little beauty and a little accomplishment, but
title: Emma

text: so little judgment that she thought herself coming with superior
title: Emma

text: knowledge of the world, to enliven and improve a country neighbourhood;
title: Emma

text: and conceived Miss Hawkins to have held such a place in society as Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s consequence only could surpass.
title: Emma

text: There was no reason to suppose Mr. Elton thought at all differently
title: Emma

text: from his wife. He seemed not merely happy with her, but proud. He had
title: Emma

text: the air of congratulating himself on having brought such a woman to
title: Emma

text: Highbury, as not even Miss Woodhouse could equal; and the greater part
title: Emma

text: of her new acquaintance, disposed to commend, or not in the habit of
title: Emma
