title: Emma

text: granted that the bride must be as clever and as agreeable as she
title: Emma

text: professed herself, were very well satisfied; so that Mrs. Elton’s
title: Emma

text: praise passed from one mouth to another as it ought to do, unimpeded by
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse, who readily continued her first contribution and talked
title: Emma

text: with a good grace of her being “very pleasant and very elegantly
title: Emma

text: dressed.”
title: Emma

text: In one respect Mrs. Elton grew even worse than she had appeared at
title: Emma

text: first. Her feelings altered towards Emma.—Offended, probably, by the
title: Emma

text: little encouragement which her proposals of intimacy met with, she drew
title: Emma

text: back in her turn and gradually became much more cold and distant; and
title: Emma

text: though the effect was agreeable, the ill-will which produced it was
title: Emma

text: necessarily increasing Emma’s dislike. Her manners, too—and Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s, were unpleasant towards Harriet. They were sneering and
title: Emma

text: negligent. Emma hoped it must rapidly work Harriet’s cure; but the
title: Emma

text: sensations which could prompt such behaviour sunk them both very
title: Emma

text: much.—It was not to be doubted that poor Harriet’s attachment had been
title: Emma

text: an offering to conjugal unreserve, and her own share in the story,
title: Emma

text: under a colouring the least favourable to her and the most soothing to
title: Emma

text: him, had in all likelihood been given also. She was, of course, the
title: Emma

text: object of their joint dislike.—When they had nothing else to say, it
title: Emma

text: must be always easy to begin abusing Miss Woodhouse; and the enmity
title: Emma

text: which they dared not shew in open disrespect to her, found a broader
title: Emma

text: vent in contemptuous treatment of Harriet.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton took a great fancy to Jane Fairfax; and from the first. Not
title: Emma

text: merely when a state of warfare with one young lady might be supposed to
title: Emma

text: recommend the other, but from the very first; and she was not satisfied
title: Emma

text: with expressing a natural and reasonable admiration—but without
title: Emma

text: solicitation, or plea, or privilege, she must be wanting to assist and
title: Emma

text: befriend her.—Before Emma had forfeited her confidence, and about the
title: Emma

text: third time of their meeting, she heard all Mrs. Elton’s knight-errantry
title: Emma

text: on the subject.—
title: Emma

text: “Jane Fairfax is absolutely charming, Miss Woodhouse.—I quite rave
title: Emma

text: about Jane Fairfax.—A sweet, interesting creature. So mild and
title: Emma

text: ladylike—and with such talents!—I assure you I think she has very
title: Emma

text: extraordinary talents. I do not scruple to say that she plays extremely
title: Emma

text: well. I know enough of music to speak decidedly on that point. Oh! she
title: Emma

text: is absolutely charming! You will laugh at my warmth—but, upon my word,
title: Emma

text: I talk of nothing but Jane Fairfax.—And her situation is so calculated
title: Emma

text: to affect one!—Miss Woodhouse, we must exert ourselves and endeavour to
title: Emma

text: do something for her. We must bring her forward. Such talent as hers
title: Emma

text: must not be suffered to remain unknown.—I dare say you have heard those
title: Emma

text: charming lines of the poet,
title: Emma

text: ‘Full many a flower is born to blush unseen,
title: Emma

text: ‘And waste its fragrance on the desert air.’
title: Emma

text: We must not allow them to be verified in sweet Jane Fairfax.”
title: Emma

text: “I cannot think there is any danger of it,” was Emma’s calm answer—“and
title: Emma

text: when you are better acquainted with Miss Fairfax’s situation and
title: Emma

text: understand what her home has been, with Colonel and Mrs. Campbell, I
title: Emma

text: have no idea that you will suppose her talents can be unknown.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! but dear Miss Woodhouse, she is now in such retirement, such
title: Emma

text: obscurity, so thrown away.—Whatever advantages she may have enjoyed
title: Emma

text: with the Campbells are so palpably at an end! And I think she feels it.
title: Emma

text: I am sure she does. She is very timid and silent. One can see that she
title: Emma

text: feels the want of encouragement. I like her the better for it. I must
title: Emma

text: confess it is a recommendation to me. I am a great advocate for
title: Emma

text: timidity—and I am sure one does not often meet with it.—But in those
title: Emma

text: who are at all inferior, it is extremely prepossessing. Oh! I assure
title: Emma

text: you, Jane Fairfax is a very delightful character, and interests me more
title: Emma

text: than I can express.”
title: Emma

text: “You appear to feel a great deal—but I am not aware how you or any of
title: Emma

text: Miss Fairfax’s acquaintance here, any of those who have known her
title: Emma

text: longer than yourself, can shew her any other attention than”—
title: Emma

text: “My dear Miss Woodhouse, a vast deal may be done by those who dare to
title: Emma

text: act. You and I need not be afraid. If _we_ set the example, many will
title: Emma

text: follow it as far as they can; though all have not our situations. _We_
title: Emma

text: have carriages to fetch and convey her home, and _we_ live in a style
title: Emma

text: which could not make the addition of Jane Fairfax, at any time, the
title: Emma

text: least inconvenient.—I should be extremely displeased if Wright were to
title: Emma

text: send us up such a dinner, as could make me regret having asked _more_
title: Emma

text: than Jane Fairfax to partake of it. I have no idea of that sort of
title: Emma

text: thing. It is not likely that I _should_, considering what I have been
title: Emma

text: used to. My greatest danger, perhaps, in housekeeping, may be quite the
title: Emma

text: other way, in doing too much, and being too careless of expense. Maple
title: Emma

text: Grove will probably be my model more than it ought to be—for we do not
title: Emma

text: at all affect to equal my brother, Mr. Suckling, in income.—However, my
title: Emma

text: resolution is taken as to noticing Jane Fairfax.—I shall certainly have
title: Emma

text: her very often at my house, shall introduce her wherever I can, shall
title: Emma

text: have musical parties to draw out her talents, and shall be constantly
title: Emma

text: on the watch for an eligible situation. My acquaintance is so very
title: Emma

text: extensive, that I have little doubt of hearing of something to suit her
title: Emma

text: shortly.—I shall introduce her, of course, very particularly to my
title: Emma

text: brother and sister when they come to us. I am sure they will like her
title: Emma

text: extremely; and when she gets a little acquainted with them, her fears
title: Emma

text: will completely wear off, for there really is nothing in the manners of
title: Emma

text: either but what is highly conciliating.—I shall have her very often
title: Emma

text: indeed while they are with me, and I dare say we shall sometimes find a
title: Emma

text: seat for her in the barouche-landau in some of our exploring parties.”
title: Emma

text: “Poor Jane Fairfax!”—thought Emma.—“You have not deserved this. You may
title: Emma

text: have done wrong with regard to Mr. Dixon, but this is a punishment
title: Emma

text: beyond what you can have merited!—The kindness and protection of Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton!—‘Jane Fairfax and Jane Fairfax.’ Heavens! Let me not suppose
title: Emma

text: that she dares go about, Emma Woodhouse-ing me!—But upon my honour,
title: Emma

text: there seems no limits to the licentiousness of that woman’s tongue!”
title: Emma

text: Emma had not to listen to such paradings again—to any so exclusively
title: Emma

text: addressed to herself—so disgustingly decorated with a “dear Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse.” The change on Mrs. Elton’s side soon afterwards appeared,
title: Emma

text: and she was left in peace—neither forced to be the very particular
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: way, in knowing what was felt, what was meditated, what was done.
title: Emma

text: She looked on with some amusement.—Miss Bates’s gratitude for Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s attentions to Jane was in the first style of guileless
title: Emma

text: simplicity and warmth. She was quite one of her worthies—the most
title: Emma

text: amiable, affable, delightful woman—just as accomplished and
title: Emma

text: condescending as Mrs. Elton meant to be considered. Emma’s only
title: Emma

text: surprize was that Jane Fairfax should accept those attentions and
title: Emma

text: tolerate Mrs. Elton as she seemed to do. She heard of her walking with
title: Emma

text: the Eltons, sitting with the Eltons, spending a day with the Eltons!
title: Emma

text: This was astonishing!—She could not have believed it possible that the
title: Emma

text: taste or the pride of Miss Fairfax could endure such society and
title: Emma

text: friendship as the Vicarage had to offer.
title: Emma

text: “She is a riddle, quite a riddle!” said she.—“To chuse to remain here
title: Emma

text: month after month, under privations of every sort! And now to chuse the
title: Emma

text: mortification of Mrs. Elton’s notice and the penury of her
title: Emma

text: conversation, rather than return to the superior companions who have
title: Emma

text: always loved her with such real, generous affection.”
title: Emma

text: Jane had come to Highbury professedly for three months; the Campbells
title: Emma

text: were gone to Ireland for three months; but now the Campbells had
title: Emma

text: promised their daughter to stay at least till Midsummer, and fresh
title: Emma

text: invitations had arrived for her to join them there. According to Miss
title: Emma

text: Bates—it all came from her—Mrs. Dixon had written most pressingly.
title: Emma

text: Would Jane but go, means were to be found, servants sent, friends
title: Emma

text: contrived—no travelling difficulty allowed to exist; but still she had
title: Emma

text: declined it!
title: Emma

text: “She must have some motive, more powerful than appears, for refusing
title: Emma

text: this invitation,” was Emma’s conclusion. “She must be under some sort
title: Emma

text: of penance, inflicted either by the Campbells or herself. There is
title: Emma

text: great fear, great caution, great resolution somewhere.—She is _not_ to
title: Emma

text: be with the _Dixons_. The decree is issued by somebody. But why must
title: Emma

text: she consent to be with the Eltons?—Here is quite a separate puzzle.”
title: Emma

text: Upon her speaking her wonder aloud on that part of the subject, before
title: Emma

text: the few who knew her opinion of Mrs. Elton, Mrs. Weston ventured this
title: Emma

text: apology for Jane.
title: Emma

text: “We cannot suppose that she has any great enjoyment at the Vicarage, my
title: Emma

text: dear Emma—but it is better than being always at home. Her aunt is a
title: Emma

text: good creature, but, as a constant companion, must be very tiresome. We
title: Emma

text: must consider what Miss Fairfax quits, before we condemn her taste for
title: Emma

text: what she goes to.”
title: Emma

text: “You are right, Mrs. Weston,” said Mr. Knightley warmly, “Miss Fairfax
title: Emma

text: is as capable as any of us of forming a just opinion of Mrs. Elton.
title: Emma

text: Could she have chosen with whom to associate, she would not have chosen
title: Emma

text: her. But (with a reproachful smile at Emma) she receives attentions
title: Emma

text: from Mrs. Elton, which nobody else pays her.”
title: Emma

text: Emma felt that Mrs. Weston was giving her a momentary glance; and she
title: Emma

text: was herself struck by his warmth. With a faint blush, she presently
title: Emma

text: replied,
title: Emma

text: “Such attentions as Mrs. Elton’s, I should have imagined, would rather
title: Emma

text: disgust than gratify Miss Fairfax. Mrs. Elton’s invitations I should
title: Emma

text: have imagined any thing but inviting.”
title: Emma

text: “I should not wonder,” said Mrs. Weston, “if Miss Fairfax were to have
title: Emma

text: been drawn on beyond her own inclination, by her aunt’s eagerness in
title: Emma

text: accepting Mrs. Elton’s civilities for her. Poor Miss Bates may very
title: Emma

text: likely have committed her niece and hurried her into a greater
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: minutes silence, he said,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “I know how highly you think of Jane Fairfax,” said Emma. Little Henry
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “And yet,” said Emma, beginning hastily and with an arch look, but soon
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: other.”

text: Mr. Knightley was hard at work upon the lower buttons of his thick
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma returned her friend’s pressure with interest; and was pleased
title: Emma

text: enough to exclaim,
title: Emma

text: “You are not vain, Mr. Knightley. I will say that for you.”
title: Emma

text: He seemed hardly to hear her; he was thoughtful—and in a manner which
title: Emma

text: shewed him not pleased, soon afterwards said,
title: Emma

text: “So you have been settling that I should marry Jane Fairfax?”
title: Emma

text: “No indeed I have not. You have scolded me too much for match-making,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley was thoughtful again. The result of his reverie was, “No,
title: Emma

text: Emma, I do not think the extent of my admiration for her will ever take
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma could not but rejoice to hear that she had a fault. “Well,” said
title: Emma

text: she, “and you soon silenced Mr. Cole, I suppose?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, very soon. He gave me a quiet hint; I told him he was mistaken;
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “In that respect how unlike dear Mrs. Elton, who wants to be wiser and
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Miss Fairfax’s mind over Mrs. Elton. I have no faith in Mrs. Elton’s
title: Emma

text: acknowledging herself the inferior in thought, word, or deed; or in her
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Jane Fairfax has feeling,” said Mr. Knightley—“I do not accuse her of
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVI
title: Emma

text: Every body in and about Highbury who had ever visited Mr. Elton, was
title: Emma

text: disposed to pay him attention on his marriage. Dinner-parties and
title: Emma

text: evening-parties were made for him and his lady; and invitations flowed
title: Emma

text: in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending they were
title: Emma

text: never to have a disengaged day.
title: Emma

text: “I see how it is,” said she. “I see what a life I am to lead among you.
title: Emma

text: Upon my word we shall be absolutely dissipated. We really seem quite
title: Emma

text: the fashion. If this is living in the country, it is nothing very
title: Emma

text: formidable. From Monday next to Saturday, I assure you we have not a
title: Emma

text: disengaged day!—A woman with fewer resources than I have, need not have
title: Emma

text: been at a loss.”
title: Emma

text: No invitation came amiss to her. Her Bath habits made evening-parties
title: Emma

text: perfectly natural to her, and Maple Grove had given her a taste for
title: Emma

text: dinners. She was a little shocked at the want of two drawing rooms, at
title: Emma

text: the poor attempt at rout-cakes, and there being no ice in the Highbury
title: Emma

text: card-parties. Mrs. Bates, Mrs. Perry, Mrs. Goddard and others, were a
title: Emma

text: good deal behind-hand in knowledge of the world, but she would soon
title: Emma

text: shew them how every thing ought to be arranged. In the course of the
title: Emma

text: spring she must return their civilities by one very superior party—in
title: Emma

text: which her card-tables should be set out with their separate candles and
title: Emma

text: unbroken packs in the true style—and more waiters engaged for the
title: Emma

text: evening than their own establishment could furnish, to carry round the
title: Emma

text: refreshments at exactly the proper hour, and in the proper order.
title: Emma

text: Emma, in the meanwhile, could not be satisfied without a dinner at
title: Emma

text: Hartfield for the Eltons. They must not do less than others, or she
title: Emma

text: should be exposed to odious suspicions, and imagined capable of pitiful
title: Emma

text: resentment. A dinner there must be. After Emma had talked about it for
title: Emma

text: ten minutes, Mr. Woodhouse felt no unwillingness, and only made the
title: Emma

text: usual stipulation of not sitting at the bottom of the table himself,
title: Emma

text: with the usual regular difficulty of deciding who should do it for him.
title: Emma

text: The persons to be invited, required little thought. Besides the Eltons,
title: Emma

text: it must be the Westons and Mr. Knightley; so far it was all of
title: Emma

text: course—and it was hardly less inevitable that poor little Harriet must
title: Emma

text: be asked to make the eighth:—but this invitation was not given with
title: Emma

text: equal satisfaction, and on many accounts Emma was particularly pleased
title: Emma

text: by Harriet’s begging to be allowed to decline it. “She would rather not
title: Emma

text: be in his company more than she could help. She was not yet quite able
title: Emma

text: to see him and his charming happy wife together, without feeling
title: Emma

text: uncomfortable. If Miss Woodhouse would not be displeased, she would
title: Emma

text: rather stay at home.” It was precisely what Emma would have wished, had
title: Emma

text: she deemed it possible enough for wishing. She was delighted with the
title: Emma

text: fortitude of her little friend—for fortitude she knew it was in her to
title: Emma

text: give up being in company and stay at home; and she could now invite the
title: Emma

text: very person whom she really wanted to make the eighth, Jane Fairfax.—
title: Emma

text: Since her last conversation with Mrs. Weston and Mr. Knightley, she was
title: Emma

text: more conscience-stricken about Jane Fairfax than she had often
title: Emma

text: been.—Mr. Knightley’s words dwelt with her. He had said that Jane
title: Emma

text: Fairfax received attentions from Mrs. Elton which nobody else paid her.
title: Emma

text: “This is very true,” said she, “at least as far as relates to me, which
title: Emma

text: was all that was meant—and it is very shameful.—Of the same age—and
title: Emma

text: always knowing her—I ought to have been more her friend.—She will never
title: Emma

text: like me now. I have neglected her too long. But I will shew her greater
title: Emma

text: attention than I have done.”
title: Emma

text: Every invitation was successful. They were all disengaged and all
title: Emma

text: happy.—The preparatory interest of this dinner, however, was not yet
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: weeks in the spring, and their papa now proposed bringing them, and
title: Emma

text: staying one whole day at Hartfield—which one day would be the very day
title: Emma

text: of this party.—His professional engagements did not allow of his being
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: turned directly.”
title: Emma

text: “I went only to the post-office,” said she, “and reached home before
title: Emma

text: the rain was much. It is my daily errand. I always fetch the letters
title: Emma

text: when I am here. It saves trouble, and is a something to get me out. A
title: Emma

text: walk before breakfast does me good.”
title: Emma

text: “Not a walk in the rain, I should imagine.”
title: Emma

text: “No, but it did not absolutely rain when I set out.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. John Knightley smiled, and replied,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Henry and John had seen more drops than they could count long before.
title: Emma

text: The post-office has a great charm at one period of our lives. When you
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: going through the rain for.”
title: Emma

text: There was a little blush, and then this answer,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: Emma

text: When the ladies returned to the drawing-room after dinner, Emma found
title: Emma

text: it hardly possible to prevent their making two distinct parties;—with
title: Emma

text: so much perseverance in judging and behaving ill did Mrs. Elton engross
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax and slight herself. She and Mrs. Weston were obliged to be
title: Emma

text: almost always either talking together or silent together. Mrs. Elton
title: Emma

text: left them no choice. If Jane repressed her for a little time, she soon
title: Emma

text: began again; and though much that passed between them was in a
title: Emma

text: half-whisper, especially on Mrs. Elton’s side, there was no avoiding a
title: Emma

text: knowledge of their principal subjects: The post-office—catching
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: suit her, and professions of Mrs. Elton’s meditated activity.
title: Emma

text: “Here is April come!” said she, “I get quite anxious about you. June
title: Emma

text: will soon be here.”
title: Emma

text: “But I have never fixed on June or any other month—merely looked
title: Emma

text: forward to the summer in general.”
title: Emma

text: “But have you really heard of nothing?”
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Oh! my dear, we cannot begin too early; you are not aware of the
title: Emma

text: difficulty of procuring exactly the desirable thing.”
title: Emma

text: “I not aware!” said Jane, shaking her head; “dear Mrs. Elton, who can
title: Emma

text: have thought of it as I have done?”
title: Emma

text: “But you have not seen so much of the world as I have. You do not know
title: Emma

text: how many candidates there always are for the _first_ situations. I saw
title: Emma

text: a vast deal of that in the neighbourhood round Maple Grove. A cousin of
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: body was anxious to be in her family, for she moves in the first
title: Emma

text: circle. Wax-candles in the schoolroom! You may imagine how desirable!
title: Emma

text: Of all houses in the kingdom Mrs. Bragge’s is the one I would most wish
title: Emma

text: to see you in.”
title: Emma

text: “Colonel and Mrs. Campbell are to be in town again by midsummer,” said
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: it;—afterwards I may probably be glad to dispose of myself. But I would
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Trouble! aye, I know your scruples. You are afraid of giving me
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: us. Your inexperience really amuses me! A situation such as you
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Excuse me, ma’am, but this is by no means my intention; I make no

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: into the world!—Could he by a touch of his finger have instantly taken
title: Emma

text: back his wife, there would have been a motive; but his coming would
title: Emma

text: probably prolong rather than break up the party. John Knightley looked
title: Emma

text: at him with amazement, then shrugged his shoulders, and said, “I could
title: Emma

text: not have believed it even of _him_.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston meanwhile, perfectly unsuspicious of the indignation he was
title: Emma

text: exciting, happy and cheerful as usual, and with all the right of being
title: Emma

text: principal talker, which a day spent anywhere from home confers, was
title: Emma

text: making himself agreeable among the rest; and having satisfied the
title: Emma

text: inquiries of his wife as to his dinner, convincing her that none of all
title: Emma

text: her careful directions to the servants had been forgotten, and spread
title: Emma

text: abroad what public news he had heard, was proceeding to a family
title: Emma

text: communication, which, though principally addressed to Mrs. Weston, he
title: Emma

text: had not the smallest doubt of being highly interesting to every body in
title: Emma

text: the room. He gave her a letter, it was from Frank, and to herself; he
title: Emma

text: had met with it in his way, and had taken the liberty of opening it.
title: Emma

text: “Read it, read it,” said he, “it will give you pleasure; only a few
title: Emma

text: lines—will not take you long; read it to Emma.”
title: Emma

text: The two ladies looked over it together; and he sat smiling and talking
title: Emma

text: to them the whole time, in a voice a little subdued, but very audible
title: Emma

text: to every body.
title: Emma

text: “Well, he is coming, you see; good news, I think. Well, what do you say
title: Emma

text: to it?—I always told you he would be here again soon, did not I?—Anne,
title: Emma

text: my dear, did not I always tell you so, and you would not believe me?—In
title: Emma

text: town next week, you see—at the latest, I dare say; for _she_ is as
title: Emma

text: impatient as the black gentleman when any thing is to be done; most
title: Emma

text: likely they will be there to-morrow or Saturday. As to her illness, all
title: Emma

text: nothing of course. But it is an excellent thing to have Frank among us
title: Emma

text: again, so near as town. They will stay a good while when they do come,
title: Emma

text: and he will be half his time with us. This is precisely what I wanted.
title: Emma

text: Well, pretty good news, is not it? Have you finished it? Has Emma read
title: Emma

text: it all? Put it up, put it up; we will have a good talk about it some
title: Emma

text: other time, but it will not do now. I shall only just mention the
title: Emma

text: circumstance to the others in a common way.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston was most comfortably pleased on the occasion. Her looks and
title: Emma

text: words had nothing to restrain them. She was happy, she knew she was
title: Emma

text: happy, and knew she ought to be happy. Her congratulations were warm
title: Emma

text: and open; but Emma could not speak so fluently. _She_ was a little
title: Emma

text: occupied in weighing her own feelings, and trying to understand the
title: Emma

text: degree of her agitation, which she rather thought was considerable.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston, however, too eager to be very observant, too communicative
title: Emma

text: to want others to talk, was very well satisfied with what she did say,
title: Emma

text: and soon moved away to make the rest of his friends happy by a partial
title: Emma

text: communication of what the whole room must have overheard already.
title: Emma

text: It was well that he took every body’s joy for granted, or he might not
title: Emma

text: have thought either Mr. Woodhouse or Mr. Knightley particularly
title: Emma

text: delighted. They were the first entitled, after Mrs. Weston and Emma, to
title: Emma

text: be made happy;—from them he would have proceeded to Miss Fairfax, but
title: Emma

text: she was so deep in conversation with John Knightley, that it would have
title: Emma

text: been too positive an interruption; and finding himself close to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton, and her attention disengaged, he necessarily began on the
title: Emma

text: subject with her.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XVIII
title: Emma

text: “I hope I shall soon have the pleasure of introducing my son to you,”
title: Emma

text: said Mr. Weston.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton, very willing to suppose a particular compliment intended
title: Emma

text: her by such a hope, smiled most graciously.
title: Emma

text: “You have heard of a certain Frank Churchill, I presume,” he
title: Emma

text: continued—“and know him to be my son, though he does not bear my name.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes, and I shall be very happy in his acquaintance. I am sure Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton will lose no time in calling on him; and we shall both have great
title: Emma

text: pleasure in seeing him at the Vicarage.”
title: Emma

text: “You are very obliging.—Frank will be extremely happy, I am sure.— He
title: Emma

text: is to be in town next week, if not sooner. We have notice of it in a
title: Emma

text: letter to-day. I met the letters in my way this morning, and seeing my
title: Emma

text: son’s hand, presumed to open it—though it was not directed to me—it was
title: Emma

text: to Mrs. Weston. She is his principal correspondent, I assure you. I
title: Emma

text: hardly ever get a letter.”
title: Emma

text: “And so you absolutely opened what was directed to her! Oh! Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston—(laughing affectedly) I must protest against that.—A most
title: Emma

text: dangerous precedent indeed!—I beg you will not let your neighbours
title: Emma

text: follow your example.—Upon my word, if this is what I am to expect, we
title: Emma

text: married women must begin to exert ourselves!—Oh! Mr. Weston, I could
title: Emma

text: not have believed it of you!”
title: Emma

text: “Aye, we men are sad fellows. You must take care of yourself, Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton.—This letter tells us—it is a short letter—written in a hurry,
title: Emma

text: merely to give us notice—it tells us that they are all coming up to
title: Emma

text: town directly, on Mrs. Churchill’s account—she has not been well the
title: Emma

text: whole winter, and thinks Enscombe too cold for her—so they are all to
title: Emma

text: move southward without loss of time.”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed!—from Yorkshire, I think. Enscombe is in Yorkshire?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, they are about one hundred and ninety miles from London, a
title: Emma

text: considerable journey.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, upon my word, very considerable. Sixty-five miles farther than
title: Emma

text: from Maple Grove to London. But what is distance, Mr. Weston, to people
title: Emma

text: of large fortune?—You would be amazed to hear how my brother, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Suckling, sometimes flies about. You will hardly believe me—but twice
title: Emma

text: in one week he and Mr. Bragge went to London and back again with four
title: Emma

text: horses.”
title: Emma

text: “The evil of the distance from Enscombe,” said Mr. Weston, “is, that
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Churchill, _as_ _we_ _understand_, has not been able to leave the
title: Emma

text: sofa for a week together. In Frank’s last letter she complained, he
title: Emma

text: said, of being too weak to get into her conservatory without having
title: Emma

text: both his arm and his uncle’s! This, you know, speaks a great degree of
title: Emma

text: weakness—but now she is so impatient to be in town, that she means to
title: Emma

text: sleep only two nights on the road.—So Frank writes word. Certainly,
title: Emma

text: delicate ladies have very extraordinary constitutions, Mrs. Elton. You
title: Emma

text: must grant me that.”
title: Emma

text: “No, indeed, I shall grant you nothing. I always take the part of my
title: Emma

text: own sex. I do indeed. I give you notice—You will find me a formidable
title: Emma

text: antagonist on that point. I always stand up for women—and I assure you,
title: Emma

text: if you knew how Selina feels with respect to sleeping at an inn, you
title: Emma

text: would not wonder at Mrs. Churchill’s making incredible exertions to
title: Emma

text: avoid it. Selina says it is quite horror to her—and I believe I have
title: Emma

text: caught a little of her nicety. She always travels with her own sheets;
title: Emma

text: an excellent precaution. Does Mrs. Churchill do the same?”
title: Emma

text: “Depend upon it, Mrs. Churchill does every thing that any other fine
title: Emma

text: lady ever did. Mrs. Churchill will not be second to any lady in the
title: Emma

text: land for”—
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton eagerly interposed with,
title: Emma

text: “Oh! Mr. Weston, do not mistake me. Selina is no fine lady, I assure
title: Emma

text: you. Do not run away with such an idea.”
title: Emma

text: “Is not she? Then she is no rule for Mrs. Churchill, who is as thorough
title: Emma

text: a fine lady as any body ever beheld.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton began to think she had been wrong in disclaiming so warmly.
title: Emma

text: It was by no means her object to have it believed that her sister was
title: Emma

text: _not_ a fine lady; perhaps there was want of spirit in the pretence of
title: Emma

text: it;—and she was considering in what way she had best retract, when Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston went on.
title: Emma

text: “Mrs. Churchill is not much in my good graces, as you may suspect—but
title: Emma

text: this is quite between ourselves. She is very fond of Frank, and
title: Emma

text: therefore I would not speak ill of her. Besides, she is out of health
title: Emma

text: now; but _that_ indeed, by her own account, she has always been. I
title: Emma

text: would not say so to every body, Mrs. Elton, but I have not much faith
title: Emma

text: in Mrs. Churchill’s illness.”
title: Emma

text: “If she is really ill, why not go to Bath, Mr. Weston?—To Bath, or to
title: Emma

text: Clifton?” “She has taken it into her head that Enscombe is too cold for
title: Emma

text: her. The fact is, I suppose, that she is tired of Enscombe. She has now
title: Emma

text: been a longer time stationary there, than she ever was before, and she
title: Emma

text: begins to want change. It is a retired place. A fine place, but very
title: Emma

text: retired.”
title: Emma

text: “Aye—like Maple Grove, I dare say. Nothing can stand more retired from
title: Emma

text: the road than Maple Grove. Such an immense plantation all round it! You
title: Emma

text: seem shut out from every thing—in the most complete retirement.—And
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Churchill probably has not health or spirits like Selina to enjoy
title: Emma

text: that sort of seclusion. Or, perhaps she may not have resources enough
title: Emma

text: in herself to be qualified for a country life. I always say a woman
title: Emma

text: cannot have too many resources—and I feel very thankful that I have so
title: Emma

text: many myself as to be quite independent of society.”
title: Emma

text: “Frank was here in February for a fortnight.”
title: Emma

text: “So I remember to have heard. He will find an _addition_ to the society
title: Emma

text: of Highbury when he comes again; that is, if I may presume to call
title: Emma

text: myself an addition. But perhaps he may never have heard of there being
title: Emma

text: such a creature in the world.”
title: Emma

text: This was too loud a call for a compliment to be passed by, and Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston, with a very good grace, immediately exclaimed,
title: Emma

text: “My dear madam! Nobody but yourself could imagine such a thing
title: Emma

text: possible. Not heard of you!—I believe Mrs. Weston’s letters lately have
title: Emma

text: been full of very little else than Mrs. Elton.”
title: Emma

text: He had done his duty and could return to his son.
title: Emma

text: “When Frank left us,” continued he, “it was quite uncertain when we
title: Emma

text: might see him again, which makes this day’s news doubly welcome. It has
title: Emma

text: been completely unexpected. That is, _I_ always had a strong persuasion
title: Emma

text: he would be here again soon, I was sure something favourable would turn
title: Emma

text: up—but nobody believed me. He and Mrs. Weston were both dreadfully
title: Emma

text: desponding. ‘How could he contrive to come? And how could it be
title: Emma

text: supposed that his uncle and aunt would spare him again?’ and so forth—I
title: Emma

text: always felt that something would happen in our favour; and so it has,
title: Emma

text: you see. I have observed, Mrs. Elton, in the course of my life, that if
title: Emma

text: things are going untowardly one month, they are sure to mend the next.”
title: Emma

text: “Very true, Mr. Weston, perfectly true. It is just what I used to say
title: Emma

text: to a certain gentleman in company in the days of courtship, when,
title: Emma

text: because things did not go quite right, did not proceed with all the
title: Emma

text: rapidity which suited his feelings, he was apt to be in despair, and
title: Emma

text: exclaim that he was sure at this rate it would be _May_ before Hymen’s
title: Emma

text: saffron robe would be put on for us. Oh! the pains I have been at to
title: Emma

text: dispel those gloomy ideas and give him cheerfuller views! The
title: Emma

text: carriage—we had disappointments about the carriage;—one morning, I
title: Emma

text: remember, he came to me quite in despair.”
title: Emma

text: She was stopped by a slight fit of coughing, and Mr. Weston instantly
title: Emma

text: seized the opportunity of going on.
title: Emma

text: “You were mentioning May. May is the very month which Mrs. Churchill is
title: Emma

text: ordered, or has ordered herself, to spend in some warmer place than
title: Emma

text: Enscombe—in short, to spend in London; so that we have the agreeable
title: Emma

text: prospect of frequent visits from Frank the whole spring—precisely the
title: Emma

text: season of the year which one should have chosen for it: days almost at
title: Emma

text: the longest; weather genial and pleasant, always inviting one out, and
title: Emma

text: never too hot for exercise. When he was here before, we made the best
title: Emma

text: of it; but there was a good deal of wet, damp, cheerless weather; there
title: Emma

text: always is in February, you know, and we could not do half that we
title: Emma

text: intended. Now will be the time. This will be complete enjoyment; and I
title: Emma

text: do not know, Mrs. Elton, whether the uncertainty of our meetings, the
title: Emma

text: sort of constant expectation there will be of his coming in to-day or
title: Emma

text: to-morrow, and at any hour, may not be more friendly to happiness than
title: Emma

text: having him actually in the house. I think it is so. I think it is the
title: Emma

text: state of mind which gives most spirit and delight. I hope you will be
title: Emma

text: pleased with my son; but you must not expect a prodigy. He is generally
title: Emma

text: thought a fine young man, but do not expect a prodigy. Mrs. Weston’s
title: Emma

text: partiality for him is very great, and, as you may suppose, most
title: Emma

text: gratifying to me. She thinks nobody equal to him.”
title: Emma

text: “And I assure you, Mr. Weston, I have very little doubt that my opinion
title: Emma

text: will be decidedly in his favour. I have heard so much in praise of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Frank Churchill.—At the same time it is fair to observe, that I am one
title: Emma

text: of those who always judge for themselves, and are by no means
title: Emma

text: implicitly guided by others. I give you notice that as I find your son,
title: Emma

text: so I shall judge of him.—I am no flatterer.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston was musing.
title: Emma

text: “I hope,” said he presently, “I have not been severe upon poor Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Churchill. If she is ill I should be sorry to do her injustice; but
title: Emma

text: there are some traits in her character which make it difficult for me
title: Emma

text: to speak of her with the forbearance I could wish. You cannot be
title: Emma

text: ignorant, Mrs. Elton, of my connexion with the family, nor of the
title: Emma

text: treatment I have met with; and, between ourselves, the whole blame of
title: Emma

text: it is to be laid to her. She was the instigator. Frank’s mother would
title: Emma

text: never have been slighted as she was but for her. Mr. Churchill has
title: Emma

text: pride; but his pride is nothing to his wife’s: his is a quiet,
title: Emma

text: indolent, gentlemanlike sort of pride that would harm nobody, and only
title: Emma

text: make himself a little helpless and tiresome; but her pride is arrogance
title: Emma

text: and insolence! And what inclines one less to bear, she has no fair
title: Emma

text: pretence of family or blood. She was nobody when he married her, barely
title: Emma

text: the daughter of a gentleman; but ever since her being turned into a
title: Emma

text: Churchill she has out-Churchill’d them all in high and mighty claims:
title: Emma

text: but in herself, I assure you, she is an upstart.”
title: Emma

text: “Only think! well, that must be infinitely provoking! I have quite a
title: Emma

text: horror of upstarts. Maple Grove has given me a thorough disgust to
title: Emma

text: people of that sort; for there is a family in that neighbourhood who
title: Emma

text: are such an annoyance to my brother and sister from the airs they give
title: Emma

text: themselves! Your description of Mrs. Churchill made me think of them
title: Emma

text: directly. People of the name of Tupman, very lately settled there, and
title: Emma

text: encumbered with many low connexions, but giving themselves immense
title: Emma

text: airs, and expecting to be on a footing with the old established
title: Emma

text: families. A year and a half is the very utmost that they can have lived
title: Emma

text: at West Hall; and how they got their fortune nobody knows. They came
title: Emma

text: from Birmingham, which is not a place to promise much, you know, Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston. One has not great hopes from Birmingham. I always say there is
title: Emma

text: something direful in the sound: but nothing more is positively known of
title: Emma

text: the Tupmans, though a good many things I assure you are suspected; and
title: Emma

text: yet by their manners they evidently think themselves equal even to my
title: Emma

text: brother, Mr. Suckling, who happens to be one of their nearest
title: Emma

text: neighbours. It is infinitely too bad. Mr. Suckling, who has been eleven
title: Emma

text: years a resident at Maple Grove, and whose father had it before him—I
title: Emma

text: believe, at least—I am almost sure that old Mr. Suckling had completed
title: Emma

text: the purchase before his death.”
title: Emma

text: They were interrupted. Tea was carrying round, and Mr. Weston, having
title: Emma

text: said all that he wanted, soon took the opportunity of walking away.
title: Emma

text: After tea, Mr. and Mrs. Weston, and Mr. Elton sat down with Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse to cards. The remaining five were left to their own powers,
title: Emma

text: and Emma doubted their getting on very well; for Mr. Knightley seemed
title: Emma

text: little disposed for conversation; Mrs. Elton was wanting notice, which
title: Emma

text: nobody had inclination to pay, and she was herself in a worry of
title: Emma

text: spirits which would have made her prefer being silent.
title: Emma

text: Mr. John Knightley proved more talkative than his brother. He was to
title: Emma

text: leave them early the next day; and he soon began with—
title: Emma

text: “Well, Emma, I do not believe I have any thing more to say about the
title: Emma

text: boys; but you have your sister’s letter, and every thing is down at
title: Emma

text: full length there we may be sure. My charge would be much more concise
title: Emma

text: than her’s, and probably not much in the same spirit; all that I have
title: Emma

text: to recommend being comprised in, do not spoil them, and do not physic
title: Emma

text: them.”
title: Emma

text: “I rather hope to satisfy you both,” said Emma, “for I shall do all in
title: Emma

text: my power to make them happy, which will be enough for Isabella; and
title: Emma

text: happiness must preclude false indulgence and physic.”
title: Emma

text: “And if you find them troublesome, you must send them home again.”
title: Emma

text: “That is very likely. You think so, do not you?”
title: Emma

text: “I hope I am aware that they may be too noisy for your father—or even
title: Emma

text: may be some encumbrance to you, if your visiting engagements continue
title: Emma

text: to increase as much as they have done lately.”
title: Emma

text: “Increase!”
title: Emma

text: “Certainly; you must be sensible that the last half-year has made a
title: Emma

text: great difference in your way of life.”
title: Emma

text: “Difference! No indeed I am not.”
title: Emma

text: “There can be no doubt of your being much more engaged with company
title: Emma

text: than you used to be. Witness this very time. Here am I come down for
title: Emma

text: only one day, and you are engaged with a dinner-party!—When did it
title: Emma

text: happen before, or any thing like it? Your neighbourhood is increasing,
title: Emma

text: and you mix more with it. A little while ago, every letter to Isabella
title: Emma

text: brought an account of fresh gaieties; dinners at Mr. Cole’s, or balls
title: Emma

text: at the Crown. The difference which Randalls, Randalls alone makes in
title: Emma

text: your goings-on, is very great.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said his brother quickly, “it is Randalls that does it all.”
title: Emma

text: “Very well—and as Randalls, I suppose, is not likely to have less
title: Emma

text: influence than heretofore, it strikes me as a possible thing, Emma,
title: Emma

text: that Henry and John may be sometimes in the way. And if they are, I
title: Emma

text: only beg you to send them home.”
title: Emma

text: “No,” cried Mr. Knightley, “that need not be the consequence. Let them
title: Emma

text: be sent to Donwell. I shall certainly be at leisure.”
title: Emma

text: “Upon my word,” exclaimed Emma, “you amuse me! I should like to know
title: Emma

text: how many of all my numerous engagements take place without your being
title: Emma

text: of the party; and why I am to be supposed in danger of wanting leisure
title: Emma

text: to attend to the little boys. These amazing engagements of mine—what
title: Emma

text: have they been? Dining once with the Coles—and having a ball talked of,
title: Emma

text: which never took place. I can understand you—(nodding at Mr. John
title: Emma

text: Knightley)—your good fortune in meeting with so many of your friends at
title: Emma

text: once here, delights you too much to pass unnoticed. But you, (turning
title: Emma

text: to Mr. Knightley,) who know how very, very seldom I am ever two hours
title: Emma

text: from Hartfield, why you should foresee such a series of dissipation for
title: Emma

text: me, I cannot imagine. And as to my dear little boys, I must say, that
title: Emma

text: if Aunt Emma has not time for them, I do not think they would fare much
title: Emma

text: better with Uncle Knightley, who is absent from home about five hours
title: Emma

text: where she is absent one—and who, when he is at home, is either reading
title: Emma

text: to himself or settling his accounts.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley seemed to be trying not to smile; and succeeded without
title: Emma

text: difficulty, upon Mrs. Elton’s beginning to talk to him.
title: Emma

text: VOLUME III
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER I
title: Emma

text: A very little quiet reflection was enough to satisfy Emma as to the
title: Emma

text: nature of her agitation on hearing this news of Frank Churchill. She
title: Emma

text: was soon convinced that it was not for herself she was feeling at all
title: Emma

text: apprehensive or embarrassed; it was for him. Her own attachment had
title: Emma

text: really subsided into a mere nothing; it was not worth thinking of;—but
title: Emma

text: if he, who had undoubtedly been always so much the most in love of the
title: Emma

text: two, were to be returning with the same warmth of sentiment which he
title: Emma

text: had taken away, it would be very distressing. If a separation of two
title: Emma

text: months should not have cooled him, there were dangers and evils before
title: Emma

text: her:—caution for him and for herself would be necessary. She did not
title: Emma

text: mean to have her own affections entangled again, and it would be
title: Emma

text: incumbent on her to avoid any encouragement of his.
title: Emma

text: She wished she might be able to keep him from an absolute declaration.
title: Emma

text: That would be so very painful a conclusion of their present
title: Emma

text: acquaintance! and yet, she could not help rather anticipating something
title: Emma

text: decisive. She felt as if the spring would not pass without bringing a
title: Emma

text: crisis, an event, a something to alter her present composed and
title: Emma

text: tranquil state.
title: Emma

text: It was not very long, though rather longer than Mr. Weston had
title: Emma

text: foreseen, before she had the power of forming some opinion of Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill’s feelings. The Enscombe family were not in town quite so
title: Emma

text: soon as had been imagined, but he was at Highbury very soon afterwards.
title: Emma

text: He rode down for a couple of hours; he could not yet do more; but as he
title: Emma

text: came from Randalls immediately to Hartfield, she could then exercise
title: Emma

text: all her quick observation, and speedily determine how he was
title: Emma

text: influenced, and how she must act. They met with the utmost
title: Emma

text: friendliness. There could be no doubt of his great pleasure in seeing
title: Emma

text: her. But she had an almost instant doubt of his caring for her as he
title: Emma

text: had done, of his feeling the same tenderness in the same degree. She
title: Emma

text: watched him well. It was a clear thing he was less in love than he had
title: Emma

text: been. Absence, with the conviction probably of her indifference, had
title: Emma

text: produced this very natural and very desirable effect.
title: Emma

text: He was in high spirits; as ready to talk and laugh as ever, and seemed
title: Emma

text: delighted to speak of his former visit, and recur to old stories: and
title: Emma

text: he was not without agitation. It was not in his calmness that she read
title: Emma

text: his comparative indifference. He was not calm; his spirits were
title: Emma

text: evidently fluttered; there was restlessness about him. Lively as he
title: Emma

text: was, it seemed a liveliness that did not satisfy himself; but what
title: Emma

text: decided her belief on the subject, was his staying only a quarter of an
title: Emma

text: hour, and hurrying away to make other calls in Highbury. “He had seen a
title: Emma

text: group of old acquaintance in the street as he passed—he had not
title: Emma

text: stopped, he would not stop for more than a word—but he had the vanity
title: Emma

text: to think they would be disappointed if he did not call, and much as he
title: Emma

text: wished to stay longer at Hartfield, he must hurry off.” She had no
title: Emma

text: doubt as to his being less in love—but neither his agitated spirits,
title: Emma

text: nor his hurrying away, seemed like a perfect cure; and she was rather
title: Emma

text: inclined to think it implied a dread of her returning power, and a

text: This was the only visit from Frank Churchill in the course of ten days.
title: Emma

text: He was often hoping, intending to come—but was always prevented. His
title: Emma

text: aunt could not bear to have him leave her. Such was his own account at
title: Emma

text: Randall’s. If he were quite sincere, if he really tried to come, it was
title: Emma

text: to be inferred that Mrs. Churchill’s removal to London had been of no
title: Emma

text: service to the wilful or nervous part of her disorder. That she was
title: Emma

text: really ill was very certain; he had declared himself convinced of it,
title: Emma

text: at Randalls. Though much might be fancy, he could not doubt, when he
title: Emma

text: looked back, that she was in a weaker state of health than she had been
title: Emma

text: half a year ago. He did not believe it to proceed from any thing that
title: Emma

text: care and medicine might not remove, or at least that she might not have
title: Emma

text: many years of existence before her; but he could not be prevailed on,
title: Emma

text: by all his father’s doubts, to say that her complaints were merely
title: Emma

text: imaginary, or that she was as strong as ever.
title: Emma

text: It soon appeared that London was not the place for her. She could not
title: Emma

text: endure its noise. Her nerves were under continual irritation and
title: Emma

text: suffering; and by the ten days’ end, her nephew’s letter to Randalls
title: Emma

text: communicated a change of plan. They were going to remove immediately to
title: Emma

text: Richmond. Mrs. Churchill had been recommended to the medical skill of
title: Emma

text: an eminent person there, and had otherwise a fancy for the place. A
title: Emma

text: ready-furnished house in a favourite spot was engaged, and much benefit
title: Emma

text: expected from the change.
title: Emma

text: Emma heard that Frank wrote in the highest spirits of this arrangement,
title: Emma

text: and seemed most fully to appreciate the blessing of having two months
title: Emma

text: before him of such near neighbourhood to many dear friends—for the
title: Emma

text: house was taken for May and June. She was told that now he wrote with
title: Emma

text: the greatest confidence of being often with them, almost as often as he
title: Emma

text: could even wish.
title: Emma

text: Emma saw how Mr. Weston understood these joyous prospects. He was
title: Emma

text: considering her as the source of all the happiness they offered. She
title: Emma

text: hoped it was not so. Two months must bring it to the proof.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston’s own happiness was indisputable. He was quite delighted. It
title: Emma

text: was the very circumstance he could have wished for. Now, it would be
title: Emma

text: really having Frank in their neighbourhood. What were nine miles to a
title: Emma

text: young man?—An hour’s ride. He would be always coming over. The
title: Emma

text: difference in that respect of Richmond and London was enough to make
title: Emma

text: the whole difference of seeing him always and seeing him never. Sixteen
title: Emma

text: miles—nay, eighteen—it must be full eighteen to Manchester-street—was a
title: Emma

text: serious obstacle. Were he ever able to get away, the day would be spent
title: Emma

text: in coming and returning. There was no comfort in having him in London;
title: Emma

text: he might as well be at Enscombe; but Richmond was the very distance for
title: Emma

text: easy intercourse. Better than nearer!
title: Emma

text: One good thing was immediately brought to a certainty by this
title: Emma

text: removal,—the ball at the Crown. It had not been forgotten before, but
title: Emma

text: it had been soon acknowledged vain to attempt to fix a day. Now,
title: Emma

text: however, it was absolutely to be; every preparation was resumed, and
title: Emma

text: very soon after the Churchills had removed to Richmond, a few lines
title: Emma

text: from Frank, to say that his aunt felt already much better for the
title: Emma

text: change, and that he had no doubt of being able to join them for
title: Emma

text: twenty-four hours at any given time, induced them to name as early a
title: Emma

text: day as possible.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston’s ball was to be a real thing. A very few to-morrows stood
title: Emma

text: between the young people of Highbury and happiness.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Woodhouse was resigned. The time of year lightened the evil to him.
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: No misfortune occurred, again to prevent the ball. The day approached,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: before dinner, and every thing was safe.

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: entreaties for her arriving there as soon as possible after themselves,
title: Emma

text: for the purpose of taking her opinion as to the propriety and comfort
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: It cannot be long, I think, before she comes.”
title: Emma

text: A carriage was heard. He was on the move immediately; but coming back,
title: Emma

text: said,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: passed.

title: Emma

text: thought you were to bring them.”
title: Emma

text: The mistake had been slight. The carriage was sent for them now. Emma
title: Emma

text: longed to know what Frank’s first opinion of Mrs. Elton might be; how
title: Emma

text: he was affected by the studied elegance of her dress, and her smiles of
title: Emma

text: graciousness. He was immediately qualifying himself to form an opinion,
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: In a few minutes the carriage returned.—Somebody talked of rain.—“I
title: Emma

text: will see that there are umbrellas, sir,” said Frank to his father:
title: Emma

text: “Miss Bates must not be forgotten:” and away he went. Mr. Weston was
title: Emma

text: following; but Mrs. Elton detained him, to gratify him by her opinion
title: Emma

text: of his son; and so briskly did she begin, that the young man himself,
title: Emma

text: though by no means moving slowly, could hardly be out of hearing.
title: Emma

text: “A very fine young man indeed, Mr. Weston. You know I candidly told you
title: Emma

text: I should form my own opinion; and I am happy to say that I am extremely
title: Emma

text: pleased with him.—You may believe me. I never compliment. I think him a
title: Emma

text: very handsome young man, and his manners are precisely what I like and
title: Emma

text: approve—so truly the gentleman, without the least conceit or puppyism.
title: Emma

text: You must know I have a vast dislike to puppies—quite a horror of them.
title: Emma

text: They were never tolerated at Maple Grove. Neither Mr. Suckling nor me
title: Emma

text: had ever any patience with them; and we used sometimes to say very
title: Emma

text: cutting things! Selina, who is mild almost to a fault, bore with them
title: Emma

text: much better.”
title: Emma

text: While she talked of his son, Mr. Weston’s attention was chained; but
title: Emma

text: when she got to Maple Grove, he could recollect that there were ladies
title: Emma

text: just arriving to be attended to, and with happy smiles must hurry away.
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: were so kind as to offer, but another time it will be quite
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: missed me.—I set off without saying a word, just as I told you.
title: Emma

text: Grandmama was quite well, had a charming evening with Mr. Woodhouse, a
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: and baked apples and wine before she came away: amazing luck in some of
title: Emma

text: her throws: and she inquired a great deal about you, how you were
title: Emma

text: amused, and who were your partners. ‘Oh!’ said I, ‘I shall not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: My dear sir, you are too obliging.—Is there nobody you would not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: of the evening!—Well, here we are at the passage. Two steps, Jane, take
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Jane,—There was a little disappointment.—The baked apples and biscuits,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: how shall we ever recollect half the dishes for grandmama? Soup too!
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Emma had no opportunity of speaking to Mr. Knightley till after supper;
title: Emma

text: but, when they were all in the ballroom again, her eyes invited him
title: Emma

text: irresistibly to come to her and be thanked. He was warm in his
title: Emma

text: reprobation of Mr. Elton’s conduct; it had been unpardonable rudeness;
title: Emma

text: and Mrs. Elton’s looks also received the due share of censure.
title: Emma

text: “They aimed at wounding more than Harriet,” said he. “Emma, why is it
title: Emma

text: that they are your enemies?”
title: Emma

text: He looked with smiling penetration; and, on receiving no answer, added,
title: Emma

text: “_She_ ought not to be angry with you, I suspect, whatever he may
title: Emma

text: be.—To that surmise, you say nothing, of course; but confess, Emma,
title: Emma

text: that you did want him to marry Harriet.”
title: Emma

text: “I did,” replied Emma, “and they cannot forgive me.”
title: Emma

text: He shook his head; but there was a smile of indulgence with it, and he
title: Emma

text: only said,
title: Emma

text: “I shall not scold you. I leave you to your own reflections.”
title: Emma

text: “Can you trust me with such flatterers?—Does my vain spirit ever tell
title: Emma

text: me I am wrong?”
title: Emma

text: “Not your vain spirit, but your serious spirit.—If one leads you wrong,
title: Emma

text: I am sure the other tells you of it.”
title: Emma

text: “I do own myself to have been completely mistaken in Mr. Elton. There
title: Emma

text: is a littleness about him which you discovered, and which I did not:
title: Emma

text: and I was fully convinced of his being in love with Harriet. It was
title: Emma

text: through a series of strange blunders!”
title: Emma

text: “And, in return for your acknowledging so much, I will do you the
title: Emma

text: justice to say, that you would have chosen for him better than he has
title: Emma

text: chosen for himself.—Harriet Smith has some first-rate qualities, which
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton is totally without. An unpretending, single-minded, artless
title: Emma

text: girl—infinitely to be preferred by any man of sense and taste to such a
title: Emma

text: woman as Mrs. Elton. I found Harriet more conversable than I expected.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was extremely gratified.—They were interrupted by the bustle of
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Come Miss Woodhouse, Miss Otway, Miss Fairfax, what are you all
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Every body is asleep!”

text: “I am ready,” said Emma, “whenever I am wanted.”

text: “Whom are you going to dance with?” asked Mr. Knightley.

title: Emma
