text: CHAPTER III
title: Emma

text: This little explanation with Mr. Knightley gave Emma considerable
title: Emma

text: pleasure. It was one of the agreeable recollections of the ball, which
title: Emma

text: she walked about the lawn the next morning to enjoy.—She was extremely
title: Emma

text: glad that they had come to so good an understanding respecting the
title: Emma

text: Eltons, and that their opinions of both husband and wife were so much
title: Emma

text: alike; and his praise of Harriet, his concession in her favour, was
title: Emma

text: peculiarly gratifying. The impertinence of the Eltons, which for a few
title: Emma

text: minutes had threatened to ruin the rest of her evening, had been the
title: Emma

text: occasion of some of its highest satisfactions; and she looked forward
title: Emma

text: to another happy result—the cure of Harriet’s infatuation.—From
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s manner of speaking of the circumstance before they quitted
title: Emma

text: the ballroom, she had strong hopes. It seemed as if her eyes were
title: Emma

text: suddenly opened, and she were enabled to see that Mr. Elton was not the
title: Emma

text: superior creature she had believed him. The fever was over, and Emma
title: Emma

text: could harbour little fear of the pulse being quickened again by
title: Emma

text: injurious courtesy. She depended on the evil feelings of the Eltons for
title: Emma

text: supplying all the discipline of pointed neglect that could be farther
title: Emma

text: requisite.—Harriet rational, Frank Churchill not too much in love, and
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley not wanting to quarrel with her, how very happy a summer
title: Emma

text: must be before her!
title: Emma

text: She was not to see Frank Churchill this morning. He had told her that
title: Emma

text: he could not allow himself the pleasure of stopping at Hartfield, as he
title: Emma

text: was to be at home by the middle of the day. She did not regret it.
title: Emma

text: Having arranged all these matters, looked them through, and put them
title: Emma

text: all to rights, she was just turning to the house with spirits freshened
title: Emma

text: up for the demands of the two little boys, as well as of their
title: Emma

text: grandpapa, when the great iron sweep-gate opened, and two persons
title: Emma

text: entered whom she had never less expected to see together—Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill, with Harriet leaning on his arm—actually Harriet!—A moment
title: Emma

text: sufficed to convince her that something extraordinary had happened.
title: Emma

text: Harriet looked white and frightened, and he was trying to cheer
title: Emma

text: her.—The iron gates and the front-door were not twenty yards
title: Emma

text: asunder;—they were all three soon in the hall, and Harriet immediately
title: Emma

text: sinking into a chair fainted away.
title: Emma

text: A young lady who faints, must be recovered; questions must be answered,
title: Emma

text: and surprizes be explained. Such events are very interesting, but the
title: Emma

text: suspense of them cannot last long. A few minutes made Emma acquainted
title: Emma

text: with the whole.
title: Emma

text: Miss Smith, and Miss Bickerton, another parlour boarder at Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Goddard’s, who had been also at the ball, had walked out together, and
title: Emma

text: taken a road, the Richmond road, which, though apparently public enough
title: Emma

text: for safety, had led them into alarm.—About half a mile beyond Highbury,
title: Emma

text: making a sudden turn, and deeply shaded by elms on each side, it became
title: Emma

text: for a considerable stretch very retired; and when the young ladies had
title: Emma

text: advanced some way into it, they had suddenly perceived at a small
title: Emma

text: distance before them, on a broader patch of greensward by the side, a
title: Emma

text: party of gipsies. A child on the watch, came towards them to beg; and
title: Emma

text: Miss Bickerton, excessively frightened, gave a great scream, and
title: Emma

text: calling on Harriet to follow her, ran up a steep bank, cleared a slight
title: Emma

text: hedge at the top, and made the best of her way by a short cut back to
title: Emma

text: Highbury. But poor Harriet could not follow. She had suffered very much
title: Emma

text: from cramp after dancing, and her first attempt to mount the bank
title: Emma

text: brought on such a return of it as made her absolutely powerless—and in
title: Emma

text: this state, and exceedingly terrified, she had been obliged to remain.
title: Emma

text: How the trampers might have behaved, had the young ladies been more
title: Emma

text: courageous, must be doubtful; but such an invitation for attack could
title: Emma

text: not be resisted; and Harriet was soon assailed by half a dozen
title: Emma

text: children, headed by a stout woman and a great boy, all clamorous, and
title: Emma

text: impertinent in look, though not absolutely in word.—More and more
title: Emma

text: frightened, she immediately promised them money, and taking out her
title: Emma

text: purse, gave them a shilling, and begged them not to want more, or to
title: Emma

text: use her ill.—She was then able to walk, though but slowly, and was
title: Emma

text: moving away—but her terror and her purse were too tempting, and she was
title: Emma

text: followed, or rather surrounded, by the whole gang, demanding more.
title: Emma

text: In this state Frank Churchill had found her, she trembling and
title: Emma

text: conditioning, they loud and insolent. By a most fortunate chance his
title: Emma

text: leaving Highbury had been delayed so as to bring him to her assistance
title: Emma

text: at this critical moment. The pleasantness of the morning had induced
title: Emma

text: him to walk forward, and leave his horses to meet him by another road,
title: Emma

text: a mile or two beyond Highbury—and happening to have borrowed a pair of
title: Emma

text: scissors the night before of Miss Bates, and to have forgotten to
title: Emma

text: restore them, he had been obliged to stop at her door, and go in for a
title: Emma

text: few minutes: he was therefore later than he had intended; and being on
title: Emma

text: foot, was unseen by the whole party till almost close to them. The
title: Emma

text: terror which the woman and boy had been creating in Harriet was then
title: Emma

text: their own portion. He had left them completely frightened; and Harriet
title: Emma

text: eagerly clinging to him, and hardly able to speak, had just strength
title: Emma

text: enough to reach Hartfield, before her spirits were quite overcome. It
title: Emma

text: was his idea to bring her to Hartfield: he had thought of no other
title: Emma

text: place.
title: Emma

text: This was the amount of the whole story,—of his communication and of
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s as soon as she had recovered her senses and speech.—He dared
title: Emma

text: not stay longer than to see her well; these several delays left him not
title: Emma

text: another minute to lose; and Emma engaging to give assurance of her
title: Emma

text: safety to Mrs. Goddard, and notice of there being such a set of people
title: Emma

text: in the neighbourhood to Mr. Knightley, he set off, with all the
title: Emma

text: grateful blessings that she could utter for her friend and herself.
title: Emma

text: Such an adventure as this,—a fine young man and a lovely young woman
title: Emma

text: thrown together in such a way, could hardly fail of suggesting certain
title: Emma

text: ideas to the coldest heart and the steadiest brain. So Emma thought, at
title: Emma

text: least. Could a linguist, could a grammarian, could even a mathematician
title: Emma

text: have seen what she did, have witnessed their appearance together, and
title: Emma

text: heard their history of it, without feeling that circumstances had been
title: Emma

text: at work to make them peculiarly interesting to each other?—How much
title: Emma

text: more must an imaginist, like herself, be on fire with speculation and
title: Emma

text: foresight!—especially with such a groundwork of anticipation as her
title: Emma

text: mind had already made.
title: Emma

text: It was a very extraordinary thing! Nothing of the sort had ever
title: Emma

text: occurred before to any young ladies in the place, within her memory; no
title: Emma

text: rencontre, no alarm of the kind;—and now it had happened to the very
title: Emma

text: person, and at the very hour, when the other very person was chancing
title: Emma

text: to pass by to rescue her!—It certainly was very extraordinary!—And
title: Emma

text: knowing, as she did, the favourable state of mind of each at this
title: Emma

text: period, it struck her the more. He was wishing to get the better of his
title: Emma

text: attachment to herself, she just recovering from her mania for Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton. It seemed as if every thing united to promise the most
title: Emma

text: interesting consequences. It was not possible that the occurrence
title: Emma

text: should not be strongly recommending each to the other.
title: Emma

text: In the few minutes’ conversation which she had yet had with him, while
title: Emma

text: Harriet had been partially insensible, he had spoken of her terror, her
title: Emma

text: naïveté, her fervour as she seized and clung to his arm, with a
title: Emma

text: sensibility amused and delighted; and just at last, after Harriet’s own
title: Emma

text: account had been given, he had expressed his indignation at the
title: Emma

text: abominable folly of Miss Bickerton in the warmest terms. Every thing
title: Emma

text: was to take its natural course, however, neither impelled nor assisted.
title: Emma

text: She would not stir a step, nor drop a hint. No, she had had enough of
title: Emma

text: interference. There could be no harm in a scheme, a mere passive
title: Emma

text: scheme. It was no more than a wish. Beyond it she would on no account
title: Emma

text: proceed.
title: Emma

text: Emma’s first resolution was to keep her father from the knowledge of
title: Emma

text: what had passed,—aware of the anxiety and alarm it would occasion: but
title: Emma

text: she soon felt that concealment must be impossible. Within half an hour
title: Emma

text: it was known all over Highbury. It was the very event to engage those
title: Emma

text: who talk most, the young and the low; and all the youth and servants in
title: Emma

text: the place were soon in the happiness of frightful news. The last
title: Emma

text: night’s ball seemed lost in the gipsies. Poor Mr. Woodhouse trembled as
title: Emma

text: he sat, and, as Emma had foreseen, would scarcely be satisfied without
title: Emma

text: their promising never to go beyond the shrubbery again. It was some
title: Emma

text: comfort to him that many inquiries after himself and Miss Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: (for his neighbours knew that he loved to be inquired after), as well
title: Emma

text: as Miss Smith, were coming in during the rest of the day; and he had
title: Emma

text: the pleasure of returning for answer, that they were all very
title: Emma

text: indifferent—which, though not exactly true, for she was perfectly well,
title: Emma

text: and Harriet not much otherwise, Emma would not interfere with. She had
title: Emma

text: an unhappy state of health in general for the child of such a man, for
title: Emma

text: she hardly knew what indisposition was; and if he did not invent
title: Emma

text: illnesses for her, she could make no figure in a message.
title: Emma

text: The gipsies did not wait for the operations of justice; they took
title: Emma

text: themselves off in a hurry. The young ladies of Highbury might have
title: Emma

text: walked again in safety before their panic began, and the whole history
title: Emma

text: dwindled soon into a matter of little importance but to Emma and her
title: Emma

text: nephews:—in her imagination it maintained its ground, and Henry and
title: Emma

text: John were still asking every day for the story of Harriet and the
title: Emma

text: gipsies, and still tenaciously setting her right if she varied in the
title: Emma

text: slightest particular from the original recital.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Emma

text: A very few days had passed after this adventure, when Harriet came one
title: Emma

text: morning to Emma with a small parcel in her hand, and after sitting down
title: Emma

text: and hesitating, thus began:
title: Emma

text: “Miss Woodhouse—if you are at leisure—I have something that I should
title: Emma

text: like to tell you—a sort of confession to make—and then, you know, it
title: Emma

text: will be over.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was a good deal surprized; but begged her to speak. There was a
title: Emma

text: seriousness in Harriet’s manner which prepared her, quite as much as
title: Emma

text: her words, for something more than ordinary.
title: Emma

text: “It is my duty, and I am sure it is my wish,” she continued, “to have
title: Emma

text: no reserves with you on this subject. As I am happily quite an altered
title: Emma

text: creature in _one_ _respect_, it is very fit that you should have the
title: Emma

text: satisfaction of knowing it. I do not want to say more than is
title: Emma

text: necessary—I am too much ashamed of having given way as I have done, and
title: Emma

text: I dare say you understand me.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” said Emma, “I hope I do.”
title: Emma

text: “How I could so long a time be fancying myself!...” cried Harriet,
title: Emma

text: warmly. “It seems like madness! I can see nothing at all extraordinary
title: Emma

text: in him now.—I do not care whether I meet him or not—except that of the
title: Emma

text: two I had rather not see him—and indeed I would go any distance round
title: Emma

text: to avoid him—but I do not envy his wife in the least; I neither admire
title: Emma

text: her nor envy her, as I have done: she is very charming, I dare say, and
title: Emma

text: all that, but I think her very ill-tempered and disagreeable—I shall
title: Emma

text: never forget her look the other night!—However, I assure you, Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, I wish her no evil.—No, let them be ever so happy together,
title: Emma

text: it will not give me another moment’s pang: and to convince you that I
title: Emma

text: have been speaking truth, I am now going to destroy—what I ought to
title: Emma

text: have destroyed long ago—what I ought never to have kept—I know that
title: Emma

text: very well (blushing as she spoke).—However, now I will destroy it
title: Emma

text: all—and it is my particular wish to do it in your presence, that you
title: Emma

text: may see how rational I am grown. Cannot you guess what this parcel
title: Emma

text: holds?” said she, with a conscious look.
title: Emma

text: “Not the least in the world.—Did he ever give you any thing?”
title: Emma

text: “No—I cannot call them gifts; but they are things that I have valued
title: Emma

text: very much.”
title: Emma

text: She held the parcel towards her, and Emma read the words _Most_
title: Emma

text: _precious_ _treasures_ on the top. Her curiosity was greatly excited.
title: Emma

text: Harriet unfolded the parcel, and she looked on with impatience. Within
title: Emma

text: abundance of silver paper was a pretty little Tunbridge-ware box, which
title: Emma

text: Harriet opened: it was well lined with the softest cotton; but,
title: Emma

text: excepting the cotton, Emma saw only a small piece of court-plaister.
title: Emma

text: “Now,” said Harriet, “you _must_ recollect.”
title: Emma

text: “No, indeed I do not.”
title: Emma

text: “Dear me! I should not have thought it possible you could forget what
title: Emma

text: passed in this very room about court-plaister, one of the very last
title: Emma

text: times we ever met in it!—It was but a very few days before I had my
title: Emma

text: sore throat—just before Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley came—I think the
title: Emma

text: very evening.—Do not you remember his cutting his finger with your new
title: Emma

text: penknife, and your recommending court-plaister?—But, as you had none
title: Emma

text: about you, and knew I had, you desired me to supply him; and so I took
title: Emma

text: mine out and cut him a piece; but it was a great deal too large, and he
title: Emma

text: cut it smaller, and kept playing some time with what was left, before
title: Emma

text: he gave it back to me. And so then, in my nonsense, I could not help
title: Emma

text: making a treasure of it—so I put it by never to be used, and looked at
title: Emma

text: it now and then as a great treat.”
title: Emma

text: “My dearest Harriet!” cried Emma, putting her hand before her face, and
title: Emma

text: jumping up, “you make me more ashamed of myself than I can bear.
title: Emma

text: Remember it? Aye, I remember it all now; all, except your saving this
title: Emma

text: relic—I knew nothing of that till this moment—but the cutting the
title: Emma

text: finger, and my recommending court-plaister, and saying I had none about
title: Emma

text: me!—Oh! my sins, my sins!—And I had plenty all the while in my
title: Emma

text: pocket!—One of my senseless tricks!—I deserve to be under a continual
title: Emma

text: blush all the rest of my life.—Well—(sitting down again)—go on—what
title: Emma

text: else?”
title: Emma

text: “And had you really some at hand yourself? I am sure I never suspected
title: Emma

text: it, you did it so naturally.”
title: Emma

text: “And so you actually put this piece of court-plaister by for his sake!”
title: Emma

text: said Emma, recovering from her state of shame and feeling divided
title: Emma

text: between wonder and amusement. And secretly she added to herself, “Lord
title: Emma

text: bless me! when should I ever have thought of putting by in cotton a
title: Emma

text: piece of court-plaister that Frank Churchill had been pulling about! I
title: Emma

text: never was equal to this.”
title: Emma

text: “Here,” resumed Harriet, turning to her box again, “here is something
title: Emma

text: still more valuable, I mean that _has_ _been_ more valuable, because
title: Emma

text: this is what did really once belong to him, which the court-plaister
title: Emma

text: never did.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was quite eager to see this superior treasure. It was the end of
title: Emma

text: an old pencil,—the part without any lead.
title: Emma

text: “This was really his,” said Harriet.—“Do not you remember one
title: Emma

text: morning?—no, I dare say you do not. But one morning—I forget exactly
title: Emma

text: the day—but perhaps it was the Tuesday or Wednesday before _that_
title: Emma

text: _evening_, he wanted to make a memorandum in his pocket-book; it was
title: Emma

text: about spruce-beer. Mr. Knightley had been telling him something about
title: Emma

text: brewing spruce-beer, and he wanted to put it down; but when he took out
title: Emma

text: his pencil, there was so little lead that he soon cut it all away, and
title: Emma

text: it would not do, so you lent him another, and this was left upon the
title: Emma

text: table as good for nothing. But I kept my eye on it; and, as soon as I
title: Emma

text: dared, caught it up, and never parted with it again from that moment.”

text: “I do remember it,” cried Emma; “I perfectly remember it.—Talking about

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “And when,” thought Emma, “will there be a beginning of Mr. Churchill?”
title: Emma

text: She had soon afterwards reason to believe that the beginning was
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: fortnight after the alarm, they came to a sufficient explanation, and
title: Emma

text: quite undesignedly. Emma was not thinking of it at the moment, which
title: Emma

text: made the information she received more valuable. She merely said, in
title: Emma

text: the course of some trivial chat, “Well, Harriet, whenever you marry I
title: Emma

text: would advise you to do so and so”—and thought no more of it, till after
title: Emma

text: a minute’s silence she heard Harriet say in a very serious tone, “I
title: Emma

text: shall never marry.”
title: Emma

text: Emma then looked up, and immediately saw how it was; and after a
title: Emma

text: moment’s debate, as to whether it should pass unnoticed or not,
title: Emma

text: replied,
title: Emma

text: “Never marry!—This is a new resolution.”
title: Emma

text: “It is one that I shall never change, however.”
title: Emma

text: After another short hesitation, “I hope it does not proceed from—I hope
title: Emma

text: it is not in compliment to Mr. Elton?”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Elton indeed!” cried Harriet indignantly.—“Oh! no”—and Emma could
title: Emma

text: just catch the words, “so superior to Mr. Elton!”
title: Emma

text: She then took a longer time for consideration. Should she proceed no
title: Emma

text: farther?—should she let it pass, and seem to suspect nothing?—Perhaps
title: Emma

text: Harriet might think her cold or angry if she did; or perhaps if she
title: Emma

text: were totally silent, it might only drive Harriet into asking her to
title: Emma

text: hear too much; and against any thing like such an unreserve as had
title: Emma

text: been, such an open and frequent discussion of hopes and chances, she
title: Emma

text: was perfectly resolved.—She believed it would be wiser for her to say
title: Emma

text: and know at once, all that she meant to say and know. Plain dealing was
title: Emma

text: always best. She had previously determined how far she would proceed,
title: Emma

text: on any application of the sort; and it would be safer for both, to have
title: Emma

text: the judicious law of her own brain laid down with speed.—She was
title: Emma

text: decided, and thus spoke—
title: Emma

text: “Harriet, I will not affect to be in doubt of your meaning. Your
title: Emma

text: resolution, or rather your expectation of never marrying, results from
title: Emma

text: an idea that the person whom you might prefer, would be too greatly
title: Emma

text: your superior in situation to think of you. Is not it so?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! Miss Woodhouse, believe me I have not the presumption to suppose—
title: Emma

text: Indeed I am not so mad.—But it is a pleasure to me to admire him at a
title: Emma

text: distance—and to think of his infinite superiority to all the rest of
title: Emma

text: the world, with the gratitude, wonder, and veneration, which are so
title: Emma

text: proper, in me especially.”
title: Emma

text: “I am not at all surprized at you, Harriet. The service he rendered you
title: Emma

text: was enough to warm your heart.”
title: Emma

text: “Service! oh! it was such an inexpressible obligation!—The very
title: Emma

text: recollection of it, and all that I felt at the time—when I saw him
title: Emma

text: coming—his noble look—and my wretchedness before. Such a change! In one
title: Emma

text: moment such a change! From perfect misery to perfect happiness!”
title: Emma

text: “It is very natural. It is natural, and it is honourable.—Yes,
title: Emma

text: honourable, I think, to chuse so well and so gratefully.—But that it
title: Emma

text: will be a fortunate preference is more than I can promise. I do not
title: Emma

text: advise you to give way to it, Harriet. I do not by any means engage for
title: Emma

text: its being returned. Consider what you are about. Perhaps it will be
title: Emma

text: wisest in you to check your feelings while you can: at any rate do not
title: Emma

text: let them carry you far, unless you are persuaded of his liking you. Be
title: Emma

text: observant of him. Let his behaviour be the guide of your sensations. I
title: Emma

text: give you this caution now, because I shall never speak to you again on
title: Emma

text: the subject. I am determined against all interference. Henceforward I
title: Emma

text: know nothing of the matter. Let no name ever pass our lips. We were
title: Emma

text: very wrong before; we will be cautious now.—He is your superior, no
title: Emma

text: doubt, and there do seem objections and obstacles of a very serious
title: Emma

text: nature; but yet, Harriet, more wonderful things have taken place, there
title: Emma

text: have been matches of greater disparity. But take care of yourself. I
title: Emma

text: would not have you too sanguine; though, however it may end, be assured
title: Emma

text: your raising your thoughts to _him_, is a mark of good taste which I
title: Emma

text: shall always know how to value.”

text: Harriet kissed her hand in silent and submissive gratitude. Emma was
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: friend. Its tendency would be to raise and refine her mind—and it must
title: Emma

text: be saving her from the danger of degradation.

text: CHAPTER V
title: Emma

text: In this state of schemes, and hopes, and connivance, June opened upon
title: Emma

text: Hartfield. To Highbury in general it brought no material change. The
title: Emma

text: Eltons were still talking of a visit from the Sucklings, and of the use
title: Emma

text: to be made of their barouche-landau; and Jane Fairfax was still at her
title: Emma

text: grandmother’s; and as the return of the Campbells from Ireland was
title: Emma

text: again delayed, and August, instead of Midsummer, fixed for it, she was
title: Emma

text: likely to remain there full two months longer, provided at least she
title: Emma

text: were able to defeat Mrs. Elton’s activity in her service, and save
title: Emma

text: herself from being hurried into a delightful situation against her
title: Emma

text: will.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley, who, for some reason best known to himself, had
title: Emma

text: certainly taken an early dislike to Frank Churchill, was only growing
title: Emma

text: to dislike him more. He began to suspect him of some double dealing in
title: Emma

text: his pursuit of Emma. That Emma was his object appeared indisputable.
title: Emma

text: Every thing declared it; his own attentions, his father’s hints, his
title: Emma

text: mother-in-law’s guarded silence; it was all in unison; words, conduct,
title: Emma

text: discretion, and indiscretion, told the same story. But while so many
title: Emma

text: were devoting him to Emma, and Emma herself making him over to Harriet,
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley began to suspect him of some inclination to trifle with
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax. He could not understand it; but there were symptoms of
title: Emma

text: intelligence between them—he thought so at least—symptoms of admiration
title: Emma

text: on his side, which, having once observed, he could not persuade himself
title: Emma

text: to think entirely void of meaning, however he might wish to escape any
title: Emma

text: of Emma’s errors of imagination. _She_ was not present when the
title: Emma

text: suspicion first arose. He was dining with the Randalls family, and
title: Emma

text: Jane, at the Eltons’; and he had seen a look, more than a single look,
title: Emma

text: at Miss Fairfax, which, from the admirer of Miss Woodhouse, seemed
title: Emma

text: somewhat out of place. When he was again in their company, he could not
title: Emma

text: help remembering what he had seen; nor could he avoid observations
title: Emma

text: which, unless it were like Cowper and his fire at twilight,
title: Emma

text: “Myself creating what I saw,”
title: Emma

text: brought him yet stronger suspicion of there being a something of
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: He had walked up one day after dinner, as he very often did, to spend
title: Emma

text: his evening at Hartfield. Emma and Harriet were going to walk; he
title: Emma

text: joined them; and, on returning, they fell in with a larger party, who,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: reaching Hartfield gates, Emma, who knew it was exactly the sort of
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: and drink tea with him. The Randalls party agreed to it immediately;
title: Emma

text: and after a pretty long speech from Miss Bates, which few persons
title: Emma

text: listened to, she also found it possible to accept dear Miss Woodhouse’s
title: Emma

text: As they were turning into the grounds, Mr. Perry passed by on
title: Emma

text: horseback. The gentlemen spoke of his horse.
title: Emma

text: “By the bye,” said Frank Churchill to Mrs. Weston presently, “what
title: Emma

text: became of Mr. Perry’s plan of setting up his carriage?”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston looked surprized, and said, “I did not know that he ever
title: Emma

text: had any such plan.”
title: Emma

text: “Nay, I had it from you. You wrote me word of it three months ago.”
title: Emma

text: “Me! impossible!”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed you did. I remember it perfectly. You mentioned it as what was
title: Emma

text: certainly to be very soon. Mrs. Perry had told somebody, and was
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: thought his being out in bad weather did him a great deal of harm. You
title: Emma

text: must remember it now?”
title: Emma

text: “Upon my word I never heard of it till this moment.”
title: Emma

text: “Never! really, never!—Bless me! how could it be?—Then I must have
title: Emma

text: dreamt it—but I was completely persuaded—Miss Smith, you walk as if you
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: can afford it. You had it from himself, had you?”
title: Emma

text: “No, sir,” replied his son, laughing, “I seem to have had it from
title: Emma

text: nobody.—Very odd!—I really was persuaded of Mrs. Weston’s having
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: it before, of course it must have been a dream. I am a great dreamer. I
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Perry.”
title: Emma

text: “It is odd though,” observed his father, “that you should have had such
title: Emma

text: a regular connected dream about people whom it was not very likely you
title: Emma

text: should be thinking of at Enscombe. Perry’s setting up his carriage! and
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: absent. Emma, you are a great dreamer, I think?”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: circumstance which highly entertained her: but his gaiety did not meet
title: Emma

text: hers. He found he could not be useful, and his feelings were too much
title: Emma

text: irritated for talking. That he might not be irritated into an absolute
title: Emma

text: fever, by the fire which Mr. Woodhouse’s tender habits required almost
title: Emma

text: every evening throughout the year, he soon afterwards took a hasty
title: Emma

text: leave, and walked home to the coolness and solitude of Donwell Abbey.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Emma

text: After being long fed with hopes of a speedy visit from Mr. and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Suckling, the Highbury world were obliged to endure the mortification
title: Emma

text: of hearing that they could not possibly come till the autumn. No such
title: Emma

text: importation of novelties could enrich their intellectual stores at
title: Emma

text: present. In the daily interchange of news, they must be again
title: Emma

text: restricted to the other topics with which for a while the Sucklings’
title: Emma

text: coming had been united, such as the last accounts of Mrs. Churchill,
title: Emma

text: whose health seemed every day to supply a different report, and the
title: Emma

text: situation of Mrs. Weston, whose happiness it was to be hoped might
title: Emma

text: eventually be as much increased by the arrival of a child, as that of
title: Emma

text: all her neighbours was by the approach of it.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton was very much disappointed. It was the delay of a great deal
title: Emma

text: of pleasure and parade. Her introductions and recommendations must all
title: Emma

text: wait, and every projected party be still only talked of. So she thought
title: Emma

text: at first;—but a little consideration convinced her that every thing
title: Emma

text: need not be put off. Why should not they explore to Box Hill though the
title: Emma

text: Sucklings did not come? They could go there again with them in the
title: Emma

text: autumn. It was settled that they should go to Box Hill. That there was
title: Emma

text: to be such a party had been long generally known: it had even given the
title: Emma

text: idea of another. Emma had never been to Box Hill; she wished to see
title: Emma

text: what every body found so well worth seeing, and she and Mr. Weston had
title: Emma

text: agreed to chuse some fine morning and drive thither. Two or three more
title: Emma

text: of the chosen only were to be admitted to join them, and it was to be
title: Emma

text: done in a quiet, unpretending, elegant way, infinitely superior to the
title: Emma

text: bustle and preparation, the regular eating and drinking, and picnic
title: Emma

text: parade of the Eltons and the Sucklings.
title: Emma

text: This was so very well understood between them, that Emma could not but
title: Emma

text: feel some surprise, and a little displeasure, on hearing from Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston that he had been proposing to Mrs. Elton, as her brother and
title: Emma

text: sister had failed her, that the two parties should unite, and go
title: Emma

text: together; and that as Mrs. Elton had very readily acceded to it, so it
title: Emma

text: was to be, if she had no objection. Now, as her objection was nothing
title: Emma

text: but her very great dislike of Mrs. Elton, of which Mr. Weston must
title: Emma

text: already be perfectly aware, it was not worth bringing forward again:—it
title: Emma

text: could not be done without a reproof to him, which would be giving pain
title: Emma

text: to his wife; and she found herself therefore obliged to consent to an
title: Emma

text: arrangement which she would have done a great deal to avoid; an
title: Emma

text: arrangement which would probably expose her even to the degradation of
title: Emma

text: being said to be of Mrs. Elton’s party! Every feeling was offended; and
title: Emma

text: the forbearance of her outward submission left a heavy arrear due of
title: Emma

text: secret severity in her reflections on the unmanageable goodwill of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston’s temper.
title: Emma

text: “I am glad you approve of what I have done,” said he very comfortably.
title: Emma

text: “But I thought you would. Such schemes as these are nothing without
title: Emma

text: numbers. One cannot have too large a party. A large party secures its
title: Emma

text: own amusement. And she is a good-natured woman after all. One could not
title: Emma

text: leave her out.”
title: Emma

text: Emma denied none of it aloud, and agreed to none of it in private.
title: Emma

text: It was now the middle of June, and the weather fine; and Mrs. Elton was
title: Emma

text: growing impatient to name the day, and settle with Mr. Weston as to
title: Emma

text: pigeon-pies and cold lamb, when a lame carriage-horse threw every thing
title: Emma

text: into sad uncertainty. It might be weeks, it might be only a few days,
title: Emma

text: before the horse were useable; but no preparations could be ventured
title: Emma

text: on, and it was all melancholy stagnation. Mrs. Elton’s resources were
title: Emma

text: inadequate to such an attack.
title: Emma

text: “Is not this most vexatious, Knightley?” she cried.—“And such weather
title: Emma

text: for exploring!—These delays and disappointments are quite odious. What
title: Emma

text: are we to do?—The year will wear away at this rate, and nothing done.
title: Emma

text: Before this time last year I assure you we had had a delightful
title: Emma

text: exploring party from Maple Grove to Kings Weston.”
title: Emma

text: “You had better explore to Donwell,” replied Mr. Knightley. “That may
title: Emma

text: be done without horses. Come, and eat my strawberries. They are
title: Emma

text: ripening fast.”
title: Emma

text: If Mr. Knightley did not begin seriously, he was obliged to proceed so,
title: Emma

text: for his proposal was caught at with delight; and the “Oh! I should like
title: Emma

text: it of all things,” was not plainer in words than manner. Donwell was
title: Emma

text: famous for its strawberry-beds, which seemed a plea for the invitation:
title: Emma

text: but no plea was necessary; cabbage-beds would have been enough to tempt
title: Emma

text: the lady, who only wanted to be going somewhere. She promised him again
title: Emma

text: and again to come—much oftener than he doubted—and was extremely
title: Emma

text: gratified by such a proof of intimacy, such a distinguishing compliment
title: Emma

text: as she chose to consider it.
title: Emma

text: “You may depend upon me,” said she. “I certainly will come. Name your
title: Emma

text: day, and I will come. You will allow me to bring Jane Fairfax?”
title: Emma

text: “I cannot name a day,” said he, “till I have spoken to some others whom
title: Emma

text: I would wish to meet you.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! leave all that to me. Only give me a carte-blanche.—I am Lady
title: Emma

text: Patroness, you know. It is my party. I will bring friends with me.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope you will bring Elton,” said he: “but I will not trouble you to
title: Emma

text: give any other invitations.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! now you are looking very sly. But consider—you need not be afraid
title: Emma

text: of delegating power to _me_. I am no young lady on her preferment.
title: Emma

text: Married women, you know, may be safely authorised. It is my party.
title: Emma

text: Leave it all to me. I will invite your guests.”
title: Emma

text: “No,”—he calmly replied,—“there is but one married woman in the world
title: Emma

text: whom I can ever allow to invite what guests she pleases to Donwell, and
title: Emma

text: that one is—”
title: Emma

text: “—Mrs. Weston, I suppose,” interrupted Mrs. Elton, rather mortified.
title: Emma

text: “No—Mrs. Knightley;—and till she is in being, I will manage such
title: Emma

text: matters myself.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! you are an odd creature!” she cried, satisfied to have no one
title: Emma

text: preferred to herself.—“You are a humourist, and may say what you like.
title: Emma

text: Quite a humourist. Well, I shall bring Jane with me—Jane and her
title: Emma

text: aunt.—The rest I leave to you. I have no objections at all to meeting
title: Emma

text: the Hartfield family. Don’t scruple. I know you are attached to them.”
title: Emma

text: “You certainly will meet them if I can prevail; and I shall call on
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates in my way home.”
title: Emma

text: “That’s quite unnecessary; I see Jane every day:—but as you like. It is
title: Emma

text: to be a morning scheme, you know, Knightley; quite a simple thing. I
title: Emma

text: shall wear a large bonnet, and bring one of my little baskets hanging
title: Emma

text: on my arm. Here,—probably this basket with pink ribbon. Nothing can be
title: Emma

text: more simple, you see. And Jane will have such another. There is to be
title: Emma

text: no form or parade—a sort of gipsy party. We are to walk about your
title: Emma

text: gardens, and gather the strawberries ourselves, and sit under
title: Emma

text: trees;—and whatever else you may like to provide, it is to be all out
title: Emma

text: of doors—a table spread in the shade, you know. Every thing as natural
title: Emma

text: and simple as possible. Is not that your idea?”
title: Emma

text: “Not quite. My idea of the simple and the natural will be to have the
title: Emma

text: table spread in the dining-room. The nature and the simplicity of
title: Emma

text: gentlemen and ladies, with their servants and furniture, I think is
title: Emma

text: best observed by meals within doors. When you are tired of eating
title: Emma

text: strawberries in the garden, there shall be cold meat in the house.”
title: Emma

text: “Well—as you please; only don’t have a great set out. And, by the bye,
title: Emma

text: can I or my housekeeper be of any use to you with our opinion?—Pray be
title: Emma

text: sincere, Knightley. If you wish me to talk to Mrs. Hodges, or to
title: Emma

text: inspect anything—”
title: Emma

text: “I have not the least wish for it, I thank you.”
title: Emma

text: “Well—but if any difficulties should arise, my housekeeper is extremely
title: Emma

text: clever.”
title: Emma

text: “I will answer for it, that mine thinks herself full as clever, and
title: Emma

text: would spurn any body’s assistance.”
title: Emma

text: “I wish we had a donkey. The thing would be for us all to come on
title: Emma

text: donkeys, Jane, Miss Bates, and me—and my caro sposo walking by. I
title: Emma

text: really must talk to him about purchasing a donkey. In a country life I
title: Emma

text: conceive it to be a sort of necessary; for, let a woman have ever so
title: Emma

text: many resources, it is not possible for her to be always shut up at
title: Emma

text: home;—and very long walks, you know—in summer there is dust, and in
title: Emma

text: winter there is dirt.”
title: Emma

text: “You will not find either, between Donwell and Highbury. Donwell Lane
title: Emma

text: is never dusty, and now it is perfectly dry. Come on a donkey, however,
title: Emma

text: if you prefer it. You can borrow Mrs. Cole’s. I would wish every thing
title: Emma

text: to be as much to your taste as possible.”
title: Emma

text: “That I am sure you would. Indeed I do you justice, my good friend.
title: Emma

text: Under that peculiar sort of dry, blunt manner, I know you have the
title: Emma

text: warmest heart. As I tell Mr. E., you are a thorough humourist.—Yes,
title: Emma

text: believe me, Knightley, I am fully sensible of your attention to me in
title: Emma

text: the whole of this scheme. You have hit upon the very thing to please
title: Emma

text: me.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley had another reason for avoiding a table in the shade. He
title: Emma

text: wished to persuade Mr. Woodhouse, as well as Emma, to join the party;
title: Emma

text: and he knew that to have any of them sitting down out of doors to eat
title: Emma

text: would inevitably make him ill. Mr. Woodhouse must not, under the
title: Emma

text: specious pretence of a morning drive, and an hour or two spent at
title: Emma

text: Donwell, be tempted away to his misery.
title: Emma

text: He was invited on good faith. No lurking horrors were to upbraid him
title: Emma

text: for his easy credulity. He did consent. He had not been at Donwell for
title: Emma

text: two years. “Some very fine morning, he, and Emma, and Harriet, could go
title: Emma

text: very well; and he could sit still with Mrs. Weston, while the dear
title: Emma

text: girls walked about the gardens. He did not suppose they could be damp
title: Emma

text: now, in the middle of the day. He should like to see the old house
title: Emma

text: again exceedingly, and should be very happy to meet Mr. and Mrs. Elton,
title: Emma

text: and any other of his neighbours.—He could not see any objection at all
title: Emma

text: to his, and Emma’s, and Harriet’s going there some very fine morning.
title: Emma

text: He thought it very well done of Mr. Knightley to invite them—very kind
title: Emma

text: and sensible—much cleverer than dining out.—He was not fond of dining
title: Emma

text: out.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley was fortunate in every body’s most ready concurrence. The
title: Emma

text: invitation was everywhere so well received, that it seemed as if, like
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Elton, they were all taking the scheme as a particular compliment
title: Emma

text: to themselves.—Emma and Harriet professed very high expectations of
title: Emma

text: pleasure from it; and Mr. Weston, unasked, promised to get Frank over
title: Emma

text: to join them, if possible; a proof of approbation and gratitude which
title: Emma

text: could have been dispensed with.—Mr. Knightley was then obliged to say
title: Emma

text: that he should be glad to see him; and Mr. Weston engaged to lose no
title: Emma

text: time in writing, and spare no arguments to induce him to come.
title: Emma

text: In the meanwhile the lame horse recovered so fast, that the party to
title: Emma

text: Box Hill was again under happy consideration; and at last Donwell was
title: Emma

text: settled for one day, and Box Hill for the next,—the weather appearing
title: Emma

text: exactly right.
title: Emma

text: Under a bright mid-day sun, at almost Midsummer, Mr. Woodhouse was
title: Emma

text: safely conveyed in his carriage, with one window down, to partake of
title: Emma

text: this al-fresco party; and in one of the most comfortable rooms in the
title: Emma

text: Abbey, especially prepared for him by a fire all the morning, he was
title: Emma

text: happily placed, quite at his ease, ready to talk with pleasure of what
title: Emma

text: had been achieved, and advise every body to come and sit down, and not
title: Emma

text: to heat themselves.—Mrs. Weston, who seemed to have walked there on
title: Emma

text: purpose to be tired, and sit all the time with him, remained, when all
title: Emma

text: the others were invited or persuaded out, his patient listener and
title: Emma

text: sympathiser.
title: Emma

text: It was so long since Emma had been at the Abbey, that as soon as she
title: Emma

text: was satisfied of her father’s comfort, she was glad to leave him, and
title: Emma

text: look around her; eager to refresh and correct her memory with more
title: Emma

text: particular observation, more exact understanding of a house and grounds
title: Emma

text: which must ever be so interesting to her and all her family.
title: Emma

text: She felt all the honest pride and complacency which her alliance with
title: Emma

text: the present and future proprietor could fairly warrant, as she viewed
title: Emma

text: the respectable size and style of the building, its suitable, becoming,
title: Emma

text: characteristic situation, low and sheltered—its ample gardens
title: Emma

text: stretching down to meadows washed by a stream, of which the Abbey, with
title: Emma

text: all the old neglect of prospect, had scarcely a sight—and its abundance
title: Emma

text: of timber in rows and avenues, which neither fashion nor extravagance
title: Emma

text: had rooted up.—The house was larger than Hartfield, and totally unlike
title: Emma

text: it, covering a good deal of ground, rambling and irregular, with many
title: Emma

text: comfortable, and one or two handsome rooms.—It was just what it ought
title: Emma

text: to be, and it looked what it was—and Emma felt an increasing respect
title: Emma

text: for it, as the residence of a family of such true gentility, untainted
title: Emma

text: in blood and understanding.—Some faults of temper John Knightley had;
title: Emma

text: but Isabella had connected herself unexceptionably. She had given them
title: Emma

text: neither men, nor names, nor places, that could raise a blush. These
title: Emma

text: were pleasant feelings, and she walked about and indulged them till it
title: Emma

text: was necessary to do as the others did, and collect round the
title: Emma

text: strawberry-beds.—The whole party were assembled, excepting Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill, who was expected every moment from Richmond; and Mrs. Elton,
title: Emma

text: in all her apparatus of happiness, her large bonnet and her basket, was
title: Emma

text: very ready to lead the way in gathering, accepting, or
title: Emma

text: talking—strawberries, and only strawberries, could now be thought or
title: Emma

text: spoken of.—“The best fruit in England—every body’s favourite—always
title: Emma

text: wholesome.—These the finest beds and finest sorts.—Delightful to gather
title: Emma

text: for one’s self—the only way of really enjoying them.—Morning decidedly
title: Emma

text: the best time—never tired—every sort good—hautboy infinitely
title: Emma

text: superior—no comparison—the others hardly eatable—hautboys very
title: Emma

text: scarce—Chili preferred—white wood finest flavour of all—price of
title: Emma

text: strawberries in London—abundance about Bristol—Maple
title: Emma

text: Grove—cultivation—beds when to be renewed—gardeners thinking exactly
title: Emma

text: different—no general rule—gardeners never to be put out of their
title: Emma

text: way—delicious fruit—only too rich to be eaten much of—inferior to
title: Emma

text: cherries—currants more refreshing—only objection to gathering
title: Emma

text: strawberries the stooping—glaring sun—tired to death—could bear it no
title: Emma

text: longer—must go and sit in the shade.”
title: Emma

text: Such, for half an hour, was the conversation—interrupted only once by
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston, who came out, in her solicitude after her son-in-law, to
title: Emma

text: inquire if he were come—and she was a little uneasy.—She had some fears
title: Emma

text: of his horse.
title: Emma

text: Seats tolerably in the shade were found; and now Emma was obliged to
title: Emma

text: overhear what Mrs. Elton and Jane Fairfax were talking of.—A situation,
title: Emma

text: a most desirable situation, was in question. Mrs. Elton had received
title: Emma

text: notice of it that morning, and was in raptures. It was not with Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Suckling, it was not with Mrs. Bragge, but in felicity and splendour it
title: Emma

text: fell short only of them: it was with a cousin of Mrs. Bragge, an
title: Emma

text: acquaintance of Mrs. Suckling, a lady known at Maple Grove. Delightful,
title: Emma

text: charming, superior, first circles, spheres, lines, ranks, every
title: Emma

text: thing—and Mrs. Elton was wild to have the offer closed with
title: Emma

text: immediately.—On her side, all was warmth, energy, and triumph—and she
title: Emma

text: positively refused to take her friend’s negative, though Miss Fairfax
title: Emma

text: continued to assure her that she would not at present engage in any
title: Emma

text: thing, repeating the same motives which she had been heard to urge
title: Emma

text: before.—Still Mrs. Elton insisted on being authorised to write an
title: Emma

text: acquiescence by the morrow’s post.—How Jane could bear it at all, was
title: Emma

text: astonishing to Emma.—She did look vexed, she did speak pointedly—and at
title: Emma

text: last, with a decision of action unusual to her, proposed a
title: Emma

text: removal.—“Should not they walk? Would not Mr. Knightley shew them the
title: Emma

text: gardens—all the gardens?—She wished to see the whole extent.”—The
title: Emma

text: pertinacity of her friend seemed more than she could bear.
title: Emma

text: It was hot; and after walking some time over the gardens in a
title: Emma

text: scattered, dispersed way, scarcely any three together, they insensibly
title: Emma

text: followed one another to the delicious shade of a broad short avenue of
title: Emma

text: limes, which stretching beyond the garden at an equal distance from the
title: Emma

text: river, seemed the finish of the pleasure grounds.—It led to nothing;
title: Emma

text: nothing but a view at the end over a low stone wall with high pillars,
title: Emma

text: which seemed intended, in their erection, to give the appearance of an
title: Emma

text: approach to the house, which never had been there. Disputable, however,
title: Emma

text: as might be the taste of such a termination, it was in itself a
title: Emma

text: charming walk, and the view which closed it extremely pretty.—The
title: Emma

text: considerable slope, at nearly the foot of which the Abbey stood,
title: Emma

text: gradually acquired a steeper form beyond its grounds; and at half a
title: Emma

text: mile distant was a bank of considerable abruptness and grandeur, well
title: Emma

text: clothed with wood;—and at the bottom of this bank, favourably placed
title: Emma

text: and sheltered, rose the Abbey Mill Farm, with meadows in front, and the
title: Emma

text: river making a close and handsome curve around it.
title: Emma

text: It was a sweet view—sweet to the eye and the mind. English verdure,
title: Emma

text: English culture, English comfort, seen under a sun bright, without
title: Emma

text: being oppressive.
title: Emma

text: In this walk Emma and Mr. Weston found all the others assembled; and
title: Emma

text: towards this view she immediately perceived Mr. Knightley and Harriet
title: Emma

text: distinct from the rest, quietly leading the way. Mr. Knightley and
title: Emma

text: Harriet!—It was an odd tête-à-tête; but she was glad to see it.—There
title: Emma

text: had been a time when he would have scorned her as a companion, and
title: Emma

text: turned from her with little ceremony. Now they seemed in pleasant
title: Emma

text: conversation. There had been a time also when Emma would have been
title: Emma

text: sorry to see Harriet in a spot so favourable for the Abbey Mill Farm;
title: Emma

text: but now she feared it not. It might be safely viewed with all its
title: Emma

text: appendages of prosperity and beauty, its rich pastures, spreading
title: Emma

text: flocks, orchard in blossom, and light column of smoke ascending.—She
title: Emma

text: joined them at the wall, and found them more engaged in talking than in
title: Emma

text: looking around. He was giving Harriet information as to modes of
title: Emma

text: agriculture, etc. and Emma received a smile which seemed to say, “These
title: Emma

text: are my own concerns. I have a right to talk on such subjects, without
title: Emma

text: being suspected of introducing Robert Martin.”—She did not suspect him.
title: Emma

text: It was too old a story.—Robert Martin had probably ceased to think of
title: Emma

text: Harriet.—They took a few turns together along the walk.—The shade was
title: Emma

text: most refreshing, and Emma found it the pleasantest part of the day.
title: Emma

text: The next remove was to the house; they must all go in and eat;—and they
title: Emma

text: were all seated and busy, and still Frank Churchill did not come. Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston looked, and looked in vain. His father would not own himself
title: Emma

text: uneasy, and laughed at her fears; but she could not be cured of wishing
title: Emma

text: that he would part with his black mare. He had expressed himself as to
title: Emma

text: coming, with more than common certainty. “His aunt was so much better,
title: Emma

text: that he had not a doubt of getting over to them.”—Mrs. Churchill’s
title: Emma

text: state, however, as many were ready to remind her, was liable to such
title: Emma

text: sudden variation as might disappoint her nephew in the most reasonable
title: Emma

text: dependence—and Mrs. Weston was at last persuaded to believe, or to say,
title: Emma

text: that it must be by some attack of Mrs. Churchill that he was prevented
title: Emma

text: coming.—Emma looked at Harriet while the point was under consideration;
title: Emma

text: she behaved very well, and betrayed no emotion.
title: Emma

text: The cold repast was over, and the party were to go out once more to see
title: Emma

text: what had not yet been seen, the old Abbey fish-ponds; perhaps get as
title: Emma

text: far as the clover, which was to be begun cutting on the morrow, or, at
title: Emma

text: any rate, have the pleasure of being hot, and growing cool again.—Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, who had already taken his little round in the highest part
title: Emma

text: of the gardens, where no damps from the river were imagined even by
title: Emma

text: him, stirred no more; and his daughter resolved to remain with him,
title: Emma

text: that Mrs. Weston might be persuaded away by her husband to the exercise
title: Emma

text: and variety which her spirits seemed to need.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley had done all in his power for Mr. Woodhouse’s
title: Emma

text: entertainment. Books of engravings, drawers of medals, cameos, corals,
title: Emma

text: shells, and every other family collection within his cabinets, had been
title: Emma

text: prepared for his old friend, to while away the morning; and the
title: Emma

text: kindness had perfectly answered. Mr. Woodhouse had been exceedingly
title: Emma

text: well amused. Mrs. Weston had been shewing them all to him, and now he
title: Emma

text: would shew them all to Emma;—fortunate in having no other resemblance
title: Emma

text: to a child, than in a total want of taste for what he saw, for he was
title: Emma

text: slow, constant, and methodical.—Before this second looking over was
title: Emma

text: begun, however, Emma walked into the hall for the sake of a few
title: Emma

text: moments’ free observation of the entrance and ground-plot of the
title: Emma

text: house—and was hardly there, when Jane Fairfax appeared, coming quickly
title: Emma

text: in from the garden, and with a look of escape.—Little expecting to meet
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse so soon, there was a start at first; but Miss Woodhouse
title: Emma

text: was the very person she was in quest of.
title: Emma

text: “Will you be so kind,” said she, “when I am missed, as to say that I am
title: Emma

text: gone home?—I am going this moment.—My aunt is not aware how late it is,
title: Emma

text: nor how long we have been absent—but I am sure we shall be wanted, and
title: Emma

text: I am determined to go directly.—I have said nothing about it to any
title: Emma

text: body. It would only be giving trouble and distress. Some are gone to
title: Emma

text: the ponds, and some to the lime walk. Till they all come in I shall not
title: Emma

text: be missed; and when they do, will you have the goodness to say that I
title: Emma

text: am gone?”
title: Emma

text: “Certainly, if you wish it;—but you are not going to walk to Highbury
title: Emma

text: alone?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—what should hurt me?—I walk fast. I shall be at home in twenty
title: Emma

text: minutes.”
title: Emma

text: “But it is too far, indeed it is, to be walking quite alone. Let my
title: Emma

text: father’s servant go with you.—Let me order the carriage. It can be
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Emma

text: They had a very fine day for Box Hill; and all the other outward
title: Emma

text: circumstances of arrangement, accommodation, and punctuality, were in
title: Emma

text: favour of a pleasant party. Mr. Weston directed the whole, officiating
title: Emma

text: safely between Hartfield and the Vicarage, and every body was in good
title: Emma

text: time. Emma and Harriet went together; Miss Bates and her niece, with
title: Emma

text: the Eltons; the gentlemen on horseback. Mrs. Weston remained with Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse. Nothing was wanting but to be happy when they got there.
title: Emma

text: Seven miles were travelled in expectation of enjoyment, and every body
title: Emma

text: had a burst of admiration on first arriving; but in the general amount
title: Emma

text: of the day there was deficiency. There was a languor, a want of
title: Emma

text: spirits, a want of union, which could not be got over. They separated
title: Emma

text: too much into parties. The Eltons walked together; Mr. Knightley took
title: Emma

text: charge of Miss Bates and Jane; and Emma and Harriet belonged to Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill. And Mr. Weston tried, in vain, to make them harmonise
title: Emma

text: better. It seemed at first an accidental division, but it never
title: Emma

text: materially varied. Mr. and Mrs. Elton, indeed, shewed no unwillingness
title: Emma

text: to mix, and be as agreeable as they could; but during the two whole
title: Emma

text: hours that were spent on the hill, there seemed a principle of
title: Emma

text: separation, between the other parties, too strong for any fine
title: Emma

text: prospects, or any cold collation, or any cheerful Mr. Weston, to
title: Emma

text: remove.
title: Emma

text: At first it was downright dulness to Emma. She had never seen Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill so silent and stupid. He said nothing worth hearing—looked
title: Emma

text: without seeing—admired without intelligence—listened without knowing
title: Emma

text: what she said. While he was so dull, it was no wonder that Harriet
title: Emma

text: should be dull likewise; and they were both insufferable.
title: Emma

text: When they all sat down it was better; to her taste a great deal better,
title: Emma

text: for Frank Churchill grew talkative and gay, making her his first
title: Emma

text: object. Every distinguishing attention that could be paid, was paid to
title: Emma

text: her. To amuse her, and be agreeable in her eyes, seemed all that he
title: Emma

text: cared for—and Emma, glad to be enlivened, not sorry to be flattered,
title: Emma

text: was gay and easy too, and gave him all the friendly encouragement, the
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma
