text: privilege rather endured than allowed, perhaps, but I must still use
title: Emma

text: it. I cannot see you acting wrong, without a remonstrance. How could
title: Emma

text: you be so unfeeling to Miss Bates? How could you be so insolent in your
title: Emma

text: wit to a woman of her character, age, and situation?—Emma, I had not
title: Emma

text: thought it possible.”
title: Emma

text: Emma recollected, blushed, was sorry, but tried to laugh it off.
title: Emma

text: “Nay, how could I help saying what I did?—Nobody could have helped it.
title: Emma

text: It was not so very bad. I dare say she did not understand me.”
title: Emma

text: “I assure you she did. She felt your full meaning. She has talked of it
title: Emma

text: since. I wish you could have heard how she talked of it—with what
title: Emma

text: candour and generosity. I wish you could have heard her honouring your
title: Emma

text: forbearance, in being able to pay her such attentions, as she was for
title: Emma

text: ever receiving from yourself and your father, when her society must be
title: Emma

text: so irksome.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh!” cried Emma, “I know there is not a better creature in the world:
title: Emma

text: but you must allow, that what is good and what is ridiculous are most
title: Emma

text: unfortunately blended in her.”
title: Emma

text: “They are blended,” said he, “I acknowledge; and, were she prosperous,
title: Emma

text: I could allow much for the occasional prevalence of the ridiculous over
title: Emma

text: the good. Were she a woman of fortune, I would leave every harmless
title: Emma

text: absurdity to take its chance, I would not quarrel with you for any
title: Emma

text: liberties of manner. Were she your equal in situation—but, Emma,
title: Emma

text: consider how far this is from being the case. She is poor; she has sunk
title: Emma

text: from the comforts she was born to; and, if she live to old age, must
title: Emma

text: probably sink more. Her situation should secure your compassion. It was
title: Emma

text: badly done, indeed! You, whom she had known from an infant, whom she
title: Emma

text: had seen grow up from a period when her notice was an honour, to have
title: Emma

text: you now, in thoughtless spirits, and the pride of the moment, laugh at
title: Emma

text: her, humble her—and before her niece, too—and before others, many of
title: Emma

text: whom (certainly _some_,) would be entirely guided by _your_ treatment
title: Emma

text: of her.—This is not pleasant to you, Emma—and it is very far from
title: Emma

text: pleasant to me; but I must, I will,—I will tell you truths while I can;
title: Emma

text: satisfied with proving myself your friend by very faithful counsel, and
title: Emma

text: trusting that you will some time or other do me greater justice than
title: Emma

text: you can do now.”
title: Emma

text: While they talked, they were advancing towards the carriage; it was
title: Emma

text: ready; and, before she could speak again, he had handed her in. He had
title: Emma

text: misinterpreted the feelings which had kept her face averted, and her
title: Emma

text: tongue motionless. They were combined only of anger against herself,
title: Emma

text: mortification, and deep concern. She had not been able to speak; and,
title: Emma

text: on entering the carriage, sunk back for a moment overcome—then
title: Emma

text: reproaching herself for having taken no leave, making no
title: Emma

text: acknowledgment, parting in apparent sullenness, she looked out with
title: Emma

text: voice and hand eager to shew a difference; but it was just too late. He
title: Emma

text: had turned away, and the horses were in motion. She continued to look
title: Emma

text: back, but in vain; and soon, with what appeared unusual speed, they
title: Emma

text: were half way down the hill, and every thing left far behind. She was
title: Emma

text: vexed beyond what could have been expressed—almost beyond what she
title: Emma

text: could conceal. Never had she felt so agitated, mortified, grieved, at
title: Emma

text: any circumstance in her life. She was most forcibly struck. The truth
title: Emma

text: of this representation there was no denying. She felt it at her heart.
title: Emma

text: How could she have been so brutal, so cruel to Miss Bates! How could
title: Emma

text: she have exposed herself to such ill opinion in any one she valued! And
title: Emma

text: how suffer him to leave her without saying one word of gratitude, of
title: Emma

text: concurrence, of common kindness!
title: Emma

text: Time did not compose her. As she reflected more, she seemed but to feel
title: Emma

text: it more. She never had been so depressed. Happily it was not necessary
title: Emma

text: to speak. There was only Harriet, who seemed not in spirits herself,
title: Emma

text: fagged, and very willing to be silent; and Emma felt the tears running
title: Emma

text: down her cheeks almost all the way home, without being at any trouble
title: Emma

text: to check them, extraordinary as they were.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Emma

text: The wretchedness of a scheme to Box Hill was in Emma’s thoughts all the
title: Emma

text: evening. How it might be considered by the rest of the party, she could
title: Emma

text: not tell. They, in their different homes, and their different ways,
title: Emma

text: might be looking back on it with pleasure; but in her view it was a
title: Emma

text: morning more completely misspent, more totally bare of rational
title: Emma

text: satisfaction at the time, and more to be abhorred in recollection, than
title: Emma

text: any she had ever passed. A whole evening of back-gammon with her
title: Emma

text: father, was felicity to it. _There_, indeed, lay real pleasure, for
title: Emma

text: there she was giving up the sweetest hours of the twenty-four to his
title: Emma

text: comfort; and feeling that, unmerited as might be the degree of his fond
title: Emma

text: affection and confiding esteem, she could not, in her general conduct,
title: Emma

text: be open to any severe reproach. As a daughter, she hoped she was not
title: Emma

text: without a heart. She hoped no one could have said to her, “How could
title: Emma

text: you be so unfeeling to your father?—I must, I will tell you truths
title: Emma

text: while I can.” Miss Bates should never again—no, never! If attention, in
title: Emma

text: future, could do away the past, she might hope to be forgiven. She had
title: Emma

text: been often remiss, her conscience told her so; remiss, perhaps, more in
title: Emma

text: thought than fact; scornful, ungracious. But it should be so no more.
title: Emma

text: In the warmth of true contrition, she would call upon her the very next
title: Emma

text: morning, and it should be the beginning, on her side, of a regular,
title: Emma

text: equal, kindly intercourse.
title: Emma

text: She was just as determined when the morrow came, and went early, that
title: Emma

text: nothing might prevent her. It was not unlikely, she thought, that she
title: Emma

text: might see Mr. Knightley in her way; or, perhaps, he might come in while
title: Emma

text: she were paying her visit. She had no objection. She would not be
title: Emma

text: ashamed of the appearance of the penitence, so justly and truly hers.
title: Emma

text: Her eyes were towards Donwell as she walked, but she saw him not.
title: Emma

text: “The ladies were all at home.” She had never rejoiced at the sound
title: Emma

text: before, nor ever before entered the passage, nor walked up the stairs,
title: Emma

text: with any wish of giving pleasure, but in conferring obligation, or of
title: Emma

text: deriving it, except in subsequent ridicule.
title: Emma

text: There was a bustle on her approach; a good deal of moving and talking.
title: Emma

text: She heard Miss Bates’s voice, something was to be done in a hurry; the
title: Emma

text: maid looked frightened and awkward; hoped she would be pleased to wait
title: Emma

text: a moment, and then ushered her in too soon. The aunt and niece seemed
title: Emma

text: both escaping into the adjoining room. Jane she had a distinct glimpse
title: Emma

text: of, looking extremely ill; and, before the door had shut them out, she
title: Emma

text: heard Miss Bates saying, “Well, my dear, I shall _say_ you are laid
title: Emma

text: down upon the bed, and I am sure you are ill enough.”
title: Emma

text: Poor old Mrs. Bates, civil and humble as usual, looked as if she did
title: Emma

text: not quite understand what was going on.
title: Emma

text: “I am afraid Jane is not very well,” said she, “but I do not know; they
title: Emma

text: _tell_ me she is well. I dare say my daughter will be here presently,
title: Emma

text: Miss Woodhouse. I hope you find a chair. I wish Hetty had not gone. I
title: Emma

text: am very little able—Have you a chair, ma’am? Do you sit where you like?
title: Emma

text: I am sure she will be here presently.”
title: Emma

text: Emma seriously hoped she would. She had a moment’s fear of Miss Bates
title: Emma

text: keeping away from her. But Miss Bates soon came—“Very happy and
title: Emma

text: obliged”—but Emma’s conscience told her that there was not the same
title: Emma

text: cheerful volubility as before—less ease of look and manner. A very
title: Emma

text: friendly inquiry after Miss Fairfax, she hoped, might lead the way to a
title: Emma

text: return of old feelings. The touch seemed immediate.
title: Emma

text: “Ah! Miss Woodhouse, how kind you are!—I suppose you have heard—and are
title: Emma

text: come to give us joy. This does not seem much like joy, indeed, in
title: Emma

text: me—(twinkling away a tear or two)—but it will be very trying for us to
title: Emma

text: part with her, after having had her so long, and she has a dreadful
title: Emma

text: headache just now, writing all the morning:—such long letters, you
title: Emma

text: know, to be written to Colonel Campbell, and Mrs. Dixon. ‘My dear,’
title: Emma

text: said I, ‘you will blind yourself’—for tears were in her eyes
title: Emma

text: perpetually. One cannot wonder, one cannot wonder. It is a great
title: Emma

text: change; and though she is amazingly fortunate—such a situation, I
title: Emma

text: suppose, as no young woman before ever met with on first going out—do
title: Emma

text: not think us ungrateful, Miss Woodhouse, for such surprising good
title: Emma

text: fortune—(again dispersing her tears)—but, poor dear soul! if you were
title: Emma

text: to see what a headache she has. When one is in great pain, you know one
title: Emma

text: cannot feel any blessing quite as it may deserve. She is as low as
title: Emma

text: possible. To look at her, nobody would think how delighted and happy
title: Emma

text: she is to have secured such a situation. You will excuse her not coming
title: Emma

text: to you—she is not able—she is gone into her own room—I want her to lie
title: Emma

text: down upon the bed. ‘My dear,’ said I, ‘I shall say you are laid down
title: Emma

text: upon the bed:’ but, however, she is not; she is walking about the room.
title: Emma

text: But, now that she has written her letters, she says she shall soon be
title: Emma

text: well. She will be extremely sorry to miss seeing you, Miss Woodhouse,
title: Emma

text: but your kindness will excuse her. You were kept waiting at the door—I
title: Emma

text: was quite ashamed—but somehow there was a little bustle—for it so
title: Emma

text: happened that we had not heard the knock, and till you were on the
title: Emma

text: stairs, we did not know any body was coming. ‘It is only Mrs. Cole,’
title: Emma

text: said I, ‘depend upon it. Nobody else would come so early.’ ‘Well,’ said
title: Emma

text: she, ‘it must be borne some time or other, and it may as well be now.’
title: Emma

text: But then Patty came in, and said it was you. ‘Oh!’ said I, ‘it is Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse: I am sure you will like to see her.’—‘I can see nobody,’
title: Emma

text: said she; and up she got, and would go away; and that was what made us
title: Emma

text: keep you waiting—and extremely sorry and ashamed we were. ‘If you must
title: Emma

text: go, my dear,’ said I, ‘you must, and I will say you are laid down upon
title: Emma

text: the bed.’”
title: Emma

text: Emma was most sincerely interested. Her heart had been long growing
title: Emma

text: kinder towards Jane; and this picture of her present sufferings acted
title: Emma

text: as a cure of every former ungenerous suspicion, and left her nothing
title: Emma

text: but pity; and the remembrance of the less just and less gentle
title: Emma

text: sensations of the past, obliged her to admit that Jane might very
title: Emma

text: naturally resolve on seeing Mrs. Cole or any other steady friend, when
title: Emma

text: she might not bear to see herself. She spoke as she felt, with earnest
title: Emma

text: regret and solicitude—sincerely wishing that the circumstances which
title: Emma

text: she collected from Miss Bates to be now actually determined on, might
title: Emma

text: be as much for Miss Fairfax’s advantage and comfort as possible. “It
title: Emma

text: must be a severe trial to them all. She had understood it was to be
title: Emma

text: delayed till Colonel Campbell’s return.”
title: Emma

text: “So very kind!” replied Miss Bates. “But you are always kind.”
title: Emma

text: There was no bearing such an “always;” and to break through her
title: Emma

text: dreadful gratitude, Emma made the direct inquiry of—
title: Emma

text: “Where—may I ask?—is Miss Fairfax going?”
title: Emma

text: “To a Mrs. Smallridge—charming woman—most superior—to have the charge
title: Emma

text: of her three little girls—delightful children. Impossible that any
title: Emma

text: situation could be more replete with comfort; if we except, perhaps,
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Suckling’s own family, and Mrs. Bragge’s; but Mrs. Smallridge is
title: Emma

text: intimate with both, and in the very same neighbourhood:—lives only four
title: Emma

text: miles from Maple Grove. Jane will be only four miles from Maple Grove.”
title: Emma

text: “Mrs. Elton, I suppose, has been the person to whom Miss Fairfax owes—”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, our good Mrs. Elton. The most indefatigable, true friend. She
title: Emma

text: would not take a denial. She would not let Jane say, ‘No;’ for when
title: Emma

text: Jane first heard of it, (it was the day before yesterday, the very
title: Emma

text: morning we were at Donwell,) when Jane first heard of it, she was quite
title: Emma

text: decided against accepting the offer, and for the reasons you mention;
title: Emma

text: exactly as you say, she had made up her mind to close with nothing till
title: Emma

text: Colonel Campbell’s return, and nothing should induce her to enter into
title: Emma

text: any engagement at present—and so she told Mrs. Elton over and over
title: Emma

text: again—and I am sure I had no more idea that she would change her
title: Emma

text: mind!—but that good Mrs. Elton, whose judgment never fails her, saw
title: Emma

text: farther than I did. It is not every body that would have stood out in
title: Emma

text: such a kind way as she did, and refuse to take Jane’s answer; but she
title: Emma

text: positively declared she would _not_ write any such denial yesterday, as
title: Emma

text: Jane wished her; she would wait—and, sure enough, yesterday evening it
title: Emma

text: was all settled that Jane should go. Quite a surprize to me! I had not
title: Emma

text: the least idea!—Jane took Mrs. Elton aside, and told her at once, that
title: Emma

text: upon thinking over the advantages of Mrs. Smallridge’s situation, she
title: Emma

text: had come to the resolution of accepting it.—I did not know a word of it
title: Emma

text: till it was all settled.”
title: Emma

text: “You spent the evening with Mrs. Elton?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, all of us; Mrs. Elton would have us come. It was settled so, upon
title: Emma

text: the hill, while we were walking about with Mr. Knightley. ‘You _must_
title: Emma

text: _all_ spend your evening with us,’ said she—‘I positively must have you
title: Emma

text: _all_ come.’”
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Knightley was there too, was he?”
title: Emma

text: “No, not Mr. Knightley; he declined it from the first; and though I
title: Emma

text: thought he would come, because Mrs. Elton declared she would not let
title: Emma

text: him off, he did not;—but my mother, and Jane, and I, were all there,
title: Emma

text: and a very agreeable evening we had. Such kind friends, you know, Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, one must always find agreeable, though every body seemed
title: Emma

text: rather fagged after the morning’s party. Even pleasure, you know, is
title: Emma

text: fatiguing—and I cannot say that any of them seemed very much to have
title: Emma

text: enjoyed it. However, _I_ shall always think it a very pleasant party,
title: Emma

text: and feel extremely obliged to the kind friends who included me in it.”
title: Emma

text: “Miss Fairfax, I suppose, though you were not aware of it, had been
title: Emma

text: making up her mind the whole day?”
title: Emma

text: “I dare say she had.”
title: Emma

text: “Whenever the time may come, it must be unwelcome to her and all her
title: Emma

text: friends—but I hope her engagement will have every alleviation that is
title: Emma

text: possible—I mean, as to the character and manners of the family.”
title: Emma

text: “Thank you, dear Miss Woodhouse. Yes, indeed, there is every thing in
title: Emma

text: the world that can make her happy in it. Except the Sucklings and
title: Emma

text: Bragges, there is not such another nursery establishment, so liberal
title: Emma

text: and elegant, in all Mrs. Elton’s acquaintance. Mrs. Smallridge, a most
title: Emma

text: delightful woman!—A style of living almost equal to Maple Grove—and as
title: Emma

text: to the children, except the little Sucklings and little Bragges, there
title: Emma

text: are not such elegant sweet children anywhere. Jane will be treated with
title: Emma

text: such regard and kindness!—It will be nothing but pleasure, a life of
title: Emma

text: pleasure.—And her salary!—I really cannot venture to name her salary to
title: Emma

text: you, Miss Woodhouse. Even you, used as you are to great sums, would
title: Emma

text: hardly believe that so much could be given to a young person like
title: Emma

text: Jane.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah! madam,” cried Emma, “if other children are at all like what I
title: Emma

text: remember to have been myself, I should think five times the amount of
title: Emma

text: what I have ever yet heard named as a salary on such occasions, dearly
title: Emma

text: earned.”
title: Emma

text: “You are so noble in your ideas!”
title: Emma

text: “And when is Miss Fairfax to leave you?”
title: Emma

text: “Very soon, very soon, indeed; that’s the worst of it. Within a
title: Emma

text: fortnight. Mrs. Smallridge is in a great hurry. My poor mother does not
title: Emma

text: know how to bear it. So then, I try to put it out of her thoughts, and
title: Emma

text: say, Come ma’am, do not let us think about it any more.”
title: Emma

text: “Her friends must all be sorry to lose her; and will not Colonel and
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Campbell be sorry to find that she has engaged herself before
title: Emma

text: their return?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes; Jane says she is sure they will; but yet, this is such a
title: Emma

text: situation as she cannot feel herself justified in declining. I was so
title: Emma

text: astonished when she first told me what she had been saying to Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Elton, and when Mrs. Elton at the same moment came congratulating me
title: Emma

text: upon it! It was before tea—stay—no, it could not be before tea, because
title: Emma

text: we were just going to cards—and yet it was before tea, because I
title: Emma

text: remember thinking—Oh! no, now I recollect, now I have it; something
title: Emma

text: happened before tea, but not that. Mr. Elton was called out of the room
title: Emma

text: before tea, old John Abdy’s son wanted to speak with him. Poor old
title: Emma

text: John, I have a great regard for him; he was clerk to my poor father
title: Emma

text: twenty-seven years; and now, poor old man, he is bed-ridden, and very
title: Emma

text: poorly with the rheumatic gout in his joints—I must go and see him
title: Emma

text: to-day; and so will Jane, I am sure, if she gets out at all. And poor
title: Emma

text: John’s son came to talk to Mr. Elton about relief from the parish; he
title: Emma

text: is very well to do himself, you know, being head man at the Crown,
title: Emma

text: ostler, and every thing of that sort, but still he cannot keep his
title: Emma

text: father without some help; and so, when Mr. Elton came back, he told us
title: Emma

text: what John ostler had been telling him, and then it came out about the
title: Emma

text: chaise having been sent to Randalls to take Mr. Frank Churchill to
title: Emma

text: Richmond. That was what happened before tea. It was after tea that Jane
title: Emma

text: spoke to Mrs. Elton.”
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates would hardly give Emma time to say how perfectly new this
title: Emma

text: circumstance was to her; but as without supposing it possible that she
title: Emma

text: could be ignorant of any of the particulars of Mr. Frank Churchill’s
title: Emma

text: going, she proceeded to give them all, it was of no consequence.
title: Emma

text: What Mr. Elton had learned from the ostler on the subject, being the
title: Emma

text: accumulation of the ostler’s own knowledge, and the knowledge of the
title: Emma

text: servants at Randalls, was, that a messenger had come over from Richmond
title: Emma

text: soon after the return of the party from Box Hill—which messenger,
title: Emma

text: however, had been no more than was expected; and that Mr. Churchill had
title: Emma

text: sent his nephew a few lines, containing, upon the whole, a tolerable
title: Emma

text: account of Mrs. Churchill, and only wishing him not to delay coming
title: Emma

text: back beyond the next morning early; but that Mr. Frank Churchill having
title: Emma

text: resolved to go home directly, without waiting at all, and his horse
title: Emma

text: seeming to have got a cold, Tom had been sent off immediately for the
title: Emma

text: Crown chaise, and the ostler had stood out and seen it pass by, the boy
title: Emma

text: going a good pace, and driving very steady.
title: Emma

text: There was nothing in all this either to astonish or interest, and it
title: Emma

text: caught Emma’s attention only as it united with the subject which
title: Emma

text: already engaged her mind. The contrast between Mrs. Churchill’s
title: Emma

text: importance in the world, and Jane Fairfax’s, struck her; one was every
title: Emma

text: thing, the other nothing—and she sat musing on the difference of
title: Emma

text: woman’s destiny, and quite unconscious on what her eyes were fixed,
title: Emma

text: till roused by Miss Bates’s saying,
title: Emma

text: “Aye, I see what you are thinking of, the pianoforte. What is to become
title: Emma

text: of that?—Very true. Poor dear Jane was talking of it just now.—‘You
title: Emma

text: must go,’ said she. ‘You and I must part. You will have no business
title: Emma

text: here.—Let it stay, however,’ said she; ‘give it houseroom till Colonel
title: Emma

text: Campbell comes back. I shall talk about it to him; he will settle for
title: Emma

text: me; he will help me out of all my difficulties.’—And to this day, I do
title: Emma

text: believe, she knows not whether it was his present or his daughter’s.”
title: Emma

text: Now Emma was obliged to think of the pianoforte; and the remembrance of
title: Emma

text: all her former fanciful and unfair conjectures was so little pleasing,
title: Emma

text: that she soon allowed herself to believe her visit had been long
title: Emma

text: enough; and, with a repetition of every thing that she could venture to
title: Emma

text: say of the good wishes which she really felt, took leave.

text: CHAPTER IX
title: Emma

text: Emma’s pensive meditations, as she walked home, were not interrupted;
title: Emma

text: but on entering the parlour, she found those who must rouse her. Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley and Harriet had arrived during her absence, and were sitting
title: Emma

text: with her father.—Mr. Knightley immediately got up, and in a manner
title: Emma

text: decidedly graver than usual, said,
title: Emma

text: “I would not go away without seeing you, but I have no time to spare,
title: Emma

text: and therefore must now be gone directly. I am going to London, to spend
title: Emma

text: a few days with John and Isabella. Have you any thing to send or say,
title: Emma

text: besides the ‘love,’ which nobody carries?”
title: Emma

text: “Nothing at all. But is not this a sudden scheme?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes—rather—I have been thinking of it some little time.”
title: Emma

text: Emma was sure he had not forgiven her; he looked unlike himself. Time,
title: Emma

text: however, she thought, would tell him that they ought to be friends
title: Emma

text: again. While he stood, as if meaning to go, but not going—her father
title: Emma

text: began his inquiries.
title: Emma

text: “Well, my dear, and did you get there safely?—And how did you find my
title: Emma

text: worthy old friend and her daughter?—I dare say they must have been very
title: Emma

text: much obliged to you for coming. Dear Emma has been to call on Mrs. and
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates, Mr. Knightley, as I told you before. She is always so
title: Emma

text: attentive to them!”
title: Emma

text: Emma’s colour was heightened by this unjust praise; and with a smile,
title: Emma

text: and shake of the head, which spoke much, she looked at Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley.—It seemed as if there were an instantaneous impression in
title: Emma

text: her favour, as if his eyes received the truth from hers, and all that
title: Emma

text: had passed of good in her feelings were at once caught and honoured.—
title: Emma

text: He looked at her with a glow of regard. She was warmly gratified—and in
title: Emma

text: another moment still more so, by a little movement of more than common
title: Emma

text: friendliness on his part.—He took her hand;—whether she had not herself
title: Emma

text: made the first motion, she could not say—she might, perhaps, have
title: Emma

text: rather offered it—but he took her hand, pressed it, and certainly was
title: Emma

text: on the point of carrying it to his lips—when, from some fancy or other,
title: Emma

text: he suddenly let it go.—Why he should feel such a scruple, why he should
title: Emma

text: change his mind when it was all but done, she could not perceive.—He
title: Emma

text: would have judged better, she thought, if he had not stopped.—The
title: Emma

text: intention, however, was indubitable; and whether it was that his
title: Emma

text: manners had in general so little gallantry, or however else it
title: Emma

text: happened, but she thought nothing became him more.—It was with him, of
title: Emma

text: so simple, yet so dignified a nature.—She could not but recall the
title: Emma

text: attempt with great satisfaction. It spoke such perfect amity.—He left
title: Emma

text: them immediately afterwards—gone in a moment. He always moved with the
title: Emma

text: alertness of a mind which could neither be undecided nor dilatory, but
title: Emma

text: now he seemed more sudden than usual in his disappearance.

text: Emma could not regret her having gone to Miss Bates, but she wished she
title: Emma

text: had left her ten minutes earlier;—it would have been a great pleasure
title: Emma

text: to talk over Jane Fairfax’s situation with Mr. Knightley.—Neither would
title: Emma

text: she regret that he should be going to Brunswick Square, for she knew
title: Emma

text: how much his visit would be enjoyed—but it might have happened at a
title: Emma

text: better time—and to have had longer notice of it, would have been
title: Emma

text: pleasanter.—They parted thorough friends, however; she could not be
title: Emma

text: deceived as to the meaning of his countenance, and his unfinished
title: Emma

text: gallantry;—it was all done to assure her that she had fully recovered
title: Emma

text: his good opinion.—He had been sitting with them half an hour, she
title: Emma

text: found. It was a pity that she had not come back earlier!
title: Emma

text: In the hope of diverting her father’s thoughts from the
title: Emma

text: disagreeableness of Mr. Knightley’s going to London; and going so
title: Emma

text: suddenly; and going on horseback, which she knew would be all very bad;
title: Emma

text: Emma communicated her news of Jane Fairfax, and her dependence on the
title: Emma

text: effect was justified; it supplied a very useful check,—interested,
title: Emma

text: without disturbing him. He had long made up his mind to Jane Fairfax’s
title: Emma

text: going out as governess, and could talk of it cheerfully, but Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley’s going to London had been an unexpected blow.
title: Emma

text: “I am very glad, indeed, my dear, to hear she is to be so comfortably
title: Emma

text: settled. Mrs. Elton is very good-natured and agreeable, and I dare say
title: Emma

text: her acquaintance are just what they ought to be. I hope it is a dry
title: Emma

text: situation, and that her health will be taken good care of. It ought to
title: Emma

text: be a first object, as I am sure poor Miss Taylor’s always was with me.
title: Emma

text: You know, my dear, she is going to be to this new lady what Miss Taylor
title: Emma

text: was to us. And I hope she will be better off in one respect, and not be
title: Emma

text: induced to go away after it has been her home so long.”
title: Emma

text: The following day brought news from Richmond to throw every thing else
title: Emma

text: into the background. An express arrived at Randalls to announce the
title: Emma

text: death of Mrs. Churchill! Though her nephew had had no particular reason
title: Emma

text: to hasten back on her account, she had not lived above six-and-thirty
title: Emma

text: hours after his return. A sudden seizure of a different nature from any
title: Emma

text: thing foreboded by her general state, had carried her off after a short
title: Emma

text: struggle. The great Mrs. Churchill was no more.
title: Emma

text: It was felt as such things must be felt. Every body had a degree of
title: Emma

text: gravity and sorrow; tenderness towards the departed, solicitude for the
title: Emma

text: surviving friends; and, in a reasonable time, curiosity to know where
title: Emma

text: she would be buried. Goldsmith tells us, that when lovely woman stoops
title: Emma

text: to folly, she has nothing to do but to die; and when she stoops to be
title: Emma

text: disagreeable, it is equally to be recommended as a clearer of ill-fame.
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Churchill, after being disliked at least twenty-five years, was
title: Emma

text: now spoken of with compassionate allowances. In one point she was fully
title: Emma

text: justified. She had never been admitted before to be seriously ill. The
title: Emma

text: event acquitted her of all the fancifulness, and all the selfishness of
title: Emma

text: imaginary complaints.
title: Emma

text: “Poor Mrs. Churchill! no doubt she had been suffering a great deal:
title: Emma

text: more than any body had ever supposed—and continual pain would try the
title: Emma

text: temper. It was a sad event—a great shock—with all her faults, what
title: Emma

text: would Mr. Churchill do without her? Mr. Churchill’s loss would be
title: Emma

text: dreadful indeed. Mr. Churchill would never get over it.”—Even Mr.
title: Emma

text: Weston shook his head, and looked solemn, and said, “Ah! poor woman,
title: Emma

text: who would have thought it!” and resolved, that his mourning should be
title: Emma

text: as handsome as possible; and his wife sat sighing and moralising over
title: Emma

text: her broad hems with a commiseration and good sense, true and steady.
title: Emma

text: How it would affect Frank was among the earliest thoughts of both. It
title: Emma

text: was also a very early speculation with Emma. The character of Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Churchill, the grief of her husband—her mind glanced over them both
title: Emma

text: with awe and compassion—and then rested with lightened feelings on how
title: Emma

text: Frank might be affected by the event, how benefited, how freed. She saw
title: Emma

text: in a moment all the possible good. Now, an attachment to Harriet Smith
title: Emma

text: would have nothing to encounter. Mr. Churchill, independent of his
title: Emma

text: wife, was feared by nobody; an easy, guidable man, to be persuaded into
title: Emma

text: any thing by his nephew. All that remained to be wished was, that the
title: Emma

text: nephew should form the attachment, as, with all her goodwill in the
title: Emma

text: cause, Emma could feel no certainty of its being already formed.
title: Emma

text: Harriet behaved extremely well on the occasion, with great
title: Emma

text: self-command. What ever she might feel of brighter hope, she betrayed
title: Emma

text: nothing. Emma was gratified, to observe such a proof in her of
title: Emma

text: strengthened character, and refrained from any allusion that might
title: Emma

text: endanger its maintenance. They spoke, therefore, of Mrs. Churchill’s
title: Emma

text: death with mutual forbearance.
title: Emma

text: Short letters from Frank were received at Randalls, communicating all
title: Emma

text: that was immediately important of their state and plans. Mr. Churchill
title: Emma

text: was better than could be expected; and their first removal, on the
title: Emma

text: departure of the funeral for Yorkshire, was to be to the house of a
title: Emma

text: very old friend in Windsor, to whom Mr. Churchill had been promising a
title: Emma

text: visit the last ten years. At present, there was nothing to be done for
title: Emma

text: Harriet; good wishes for the future were all that could yet be possible
title: Emma

text: on Emma’s side.
title: Emma

text: It was a more pressing concern to shew attention to Jane Fairfax, whose
title: Emma

text: prospects were closing, while Harriet’s opened, and whose engagements
title: Emma

text: now allowed of no delay in any one at Highbury, who wished to shew her
title: Emma

text: kindness—and with Emma it was grown into a first wish. She had scarcely
title: Emma

text: a stronger regret than for her past coldness; and the person, whom she
title: Emma

text: had been so many months neglecting, was now the very one on whom she
title: Emma

text: would have lavished every distinction of regard or sympathy. She wanted
title: Emma

text: to be of use to her; wanted to shew a value for her society, and
title: Emma

text: testify respect and consideration. She resolved to prevail on her to
title: Emma

text: spend a day at Hartfield. A note was written to urge it. The invitation
title: Emma

text: was refused, and by a verbal message. “Miss Fairfax was not well enough
title: Emma

text: to write;” and when Mr. Perry called at Hartfield, the same morning, it
title: Emma

text: appeared that she was so much indisposed as to have been visited,
title: Emma

text: though against her own consent, by himself, and that she was suffering
title: Emma

text: under severe headaches, and a nervous fever to a degree, which made him
title: Emma

text: doubt the possibility of her going to Mrs. Smallridge’s at the time
title: Emma

text: proposed. Her health seemed for the moment completely deranged—appetite
title: Emma

text: quite gone—and though there were no absolutely alarming symptoms,
title: Emma

text: nothing touching the pulmonary complaint, which was the standing
title: Emma

text: apprehension of the family, Mr. Perry was uneasy about her. He thought
title: Emma

text: she had undertaken more than she was equal to, and that she felt it so
title: Emma

text: herself, though she would not own it. Her spirits seemed overcome. Her
title: Emma

text: present home, he could not but observe, was unfavourable to a nervous
title: Emma

text: disorder:—confined always to one room;—he could have wished it
title: Emma

text: otherwise—and her good aunt, though his very old friend, he must
title: Emma

text: acknowledge to be not the best companion for an invalid of that
title: Emma

text: description. Her care and attention could not be questioned; they were,
title: Emma

text: in fact, only too great. He very much feared that Miss Fairfax derived
title: Emma

text: more evil than good from them. Emma listened with the warmest concern;
title: Emma

text: grieved for her more and more, and looked around eager to discover some
title: Emma

text: way of being useful. To take her—be it only an hour or two—from her
title: Emma

text: aunt, to give her change of air and scene, and quiet rational
title: Emma

text: conversation, even for an hour or two, might do her good; and the
title: Emma

text: following morning she wrote again to say, in the most feeling language
title: Emma

text: she could command, that she would call for her in the carriage at any
title: Emma

text: hour that Jane would name—mentioning that she had Mr. Perry’s decided
title: Emma

text: opinion, in favour of such exercise for his patient. The answer was
title: Emma

text: only in this short note:
title: Emma

text: “Miss Fairfax’s compliments and thanks, but is quite unequal to any
title: Emma

text: exercise.”
title: Emma

text: Emma felt that her own note had deserved something better; but it was
title: Emma

text: impossible to quarrel with words, whose tremulous inequality shewed
title: Emma

text: indisposition so plainly, and she thought only of how she might best
title: Emma

text: counteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted. In spite of the
title: Emma

text: answer, therefore, she ordered the carriage, and drove to Mrs. Bates’s,
title: Emma

text: in the hope that Jane would be induced to join her—but it would not
title: Emma

text: do;—Miss Bates came to the carriage door, all gratitude, and agreeing
title: Emma

text: with her most earnestly in thinking an airing might be of the greatest
title: Emma

text: service—and every thing that message could do was tried—but all in
title: Emma

text: vain. Miss Bates was obliged to return without success; Jane was quite
title: Emma

text: unpersuadable; the mere proposal of going out seemed to make her
title: Emma

text: worse.—Emma wished she could have seen her, and tried her own powers;
title: Emma

text: but, almost before she could hint the wish, Miss Bates made it appear
title: Emma

text: that she had promised her niece on no account to let Miss Woodhouse in.
title: Emma

text: “Indeed, the truth was, that poor dear Jane could not bear to see any
title: Emma

text: body—any body at all—Mrs. Elton, indeed, could not be denied—and Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Cole had made such a point—and Mrs. Perry had said so much—but, except
title: Emma

text: them, Jane would really see nobody.”
title: Emma

text: Emma did not want to be classed with the Mrs. Eltons, the Mrs. Perrys,
title: Emma

text: and the Mrs. Coles, who would force themselves anywhere; neither could
title: Emma

text: she feel any right of preference herself—she submitted, therefore, and
title: Emma

text: only questioned Miss Bates farther as to her niece’s appetite and diet,
title: Emma

text: which she longed to be able to assist. On that subject poor Miss Bates
title: Emma

text: was very unhappy, and very communicative; Jane would hardly eat any
title: Emma

text: thing:—Mr. Perry recommended nourishing food; but every thing they
title: Emma

text: could command (and never had any body such good neighbours) was
title: Emma

text: distasteful.
title: Emma

text: Emma, on reaching home, called the housekeeper directly, to an
title: Emma

text: examination of her stores; and some arrowroot of very superior quality
title: Emma

text: was speedily despatched to Miss Bates with a most friendly note. In
title: Emma

text: half an hour the arrowroot was returned, with a thousand thanks from
title: Emma

text: Miss Bates, but “dear Jane would not be satisfied without its being
title: Emma

text: sent back; it was a thing she could not take—and, moreover, she
title: Emma

text: insisted on her saying, that she was not at all in want of any thing.”
title: Emma

text: When Emma afterwards heard that Jane Fairfax had been seen wandering
title: Emma

text: about the meadows, at some distance from Highbury, on the afternoon of
title: Emma

text: the very day on which she had, under the plea of being unequal to any
title: Emma

text: exercise, so peremptorily refused to go out with her in the carriage,
title: Emma

text: she could have no doubt—putting every thing together—that Jane was
title: Emma

text: resolved to receive no kindness from _her_. She was sorry, very sorry.
title: Emma

text: Her heart was grieved for a state which seemed but the more pitiable
title: Emma

text: from this sort of irritation of spirits, inconsistency of action, and
title: Emma

text: inequality of powers; and it mortified her that she was given so little
title: Emma

text: credit for proper feeling, or esteemed so little worthy as a friend:
title: Emma

text: but she had the consolation of knowing that her intentions were good,
title: Emma

text: and of being able to say to herself, that could Mr. Knightley have been
title: Emma

text: privy to all her attempts of assisting Jane Fairfax, could he even have
title: Emma

text: seen into her heart, he would not, on this occasion, have found any
title: Emma

text: thing to reprove.

text: CHAPTER X
title: Emma

text: One morning, about ten days after Mrs. Churchill’s decease, Emma was
title: Emma

text: called downstairs to Mr. Weston, who “could not stay five minutes, and
title: Emma

text: wanted particularly to speak with her.”—He met her at the parlour-door,
title: Emma

text: and hardly asking her how she did, in the natural key of his voice,
title: Emma

text: sunk it immediately, to say, unheard by her father,
title: Emma

text: “Can you come to Randalls at any time this morning?—Do, if it be
title: Emma

text: possible. Mrs. Weston wants to see you. She must see you.”
title: Emma

text: “Is she unwell?”
title: Emma

text: “No, no, not at all—only a little agitated. She would have ordered the
title: Emma

text: carriage, and come to you, but she must see you _alone_, and that you
title: Emma

text: know—(nodding towards her father)—Humph!—Can you come?”
title: Emma

text: “Certainly. This moment, if you please. It is impossible to refuse what
title: Emma

text: you ask in such a way. But what can be the matter?—Is she really not
title: Emma

text: ill?”
title: Emma

text: “Depend upon me—but ask no more questions. You will know it all in
title: Emma

text: time. The most unaccountable business! But hush, hush!”
title: Emma

text: To guess what all this meant, was impossible even for Emma. Something
title: Emma

text: really important seemed announced by his looks; but, as her friend was
title: Emma

text: well, she endeavoured not to be uneasy, and settling it with her
title: Emma

text: father, that she would take her walk now, she and Mr. Weston were soon
title: Emma

text: out of the house together and on their way at a quick pace for
title: Emma

text: Randalls.
title: Emma

text: “Now,”—said Emma, when they were fairly beyond the sweep gates,—“now
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston, do let me know what has happened.”
title: Emma

text: “No, no,”—he gravely replied.—“Don’t ask me. I promised my wife to
title: Emma

text: leave it all to her. She will break it to you better than I can. Do not
title: Emma

text: be impatient, Emma; it will all come out too soon.”
title: Emma

text: “Break it to me,” cried Emma, standing still with terror.—“Good
title: Emma

text: God!—Mr. Weston, tell me at once.—Something has happened in Brunswick
title: Emma

text: Square. I know it has. Tell me, I charge you tell me this moment what
title: Emma

text: it is.”
title: Emma

text: “No, indeed you are mistaken.”—
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Weston do not trifle with me.—Consider how many of my dearest
title: Emma

text: friends are now in Brunswick Square. Which of them is it?—I charge you
title: Emma

text: by all that is sacred, not to attempt concealment.”
title: Emma

text: “Upon my word, Emma.”—
title: Emma

text: “Your word!—why not your honour!—why not say upon your honour, that it
title: Emma

text: has nothing to do with any of them? Good Heavens!—What can be to be
title: Emma

text: _broke_ to me, that does not relate to one of that family?”
title: Emma

text: “Upon my honour,” said he very seriously, “it does not. It is not in
title: Emma

text: the smallest degree connected with any human being of the name of
title: Emma

text: Knightley.”
title: Emma

text: Emma’s courage returned, and she walked on.
title: Emma

text: “I was wrong,” he continued, “in talking of its being _broke_ to you. I
title: Emma

text: should not have used the expression. In fact, it does not concern
title: Emma

text: you—it concerns only myself,—that is, we hope.—Humph!—In short, my dear
title: Emma

text: Emma, there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it. I don’t say that
title: Emma

text: it is not a disagreeable business—but things might be much worse.—If we
title: Emma

text: walk fast, we shall soon be at Randalls.”
title: Emma

text: Emma found that she must wait; and now it required little effort. She
title: Emma

text: asked no more questions therefore, merely employed her own fancy, and
title: Emma

text: that soon pointed out to her the probability of its being some money
title: Emma

text: concern—something just come to light, of a disagreeable nature in the
title: Emma

text: circumstances of the family,—something which the late event at Richmond
title: Emma

text: had brought forward. Her fancy was very active. Half a dozen natural
title: Emma

text: children, perhaps—and poor Frank cut off!—This, though very
title: Emma

text: undesirable, would be no matter of agony to her. It inspired little
title: Emma

text: more than an animating curiosity.
title: Emma

text: “Who is that gentleman on horseback?” said she, as they
title: Emma

text: proceeded—speaking more to assist Mr. Weston in keeping his secret,
title: Emma

text: than with any other view.
title: Emma

text: “I do not know.—One of the Otways.—Not Frank;—it is not Frank, I assure
title: Emma

text: you. You will not see him. He is half way to Windsor by this time.”
title: Emma

text: “Has your son been with you, then?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! yes—did not you know?—Well, well, never mind.”
title: Emma

text: For a moment he was silent; and then added, in a tone much more guarded
title: Emma

text: and demure,
title: Emma

text: “Yes, Frank came over this morning, just to ask us how we did.”
title: Emma

text: They hurried on, and were speedily at Randalls.—“Well, my dear,” said
title: Emma

text: he, as they entered the room—“I have brought her, and now I hope you
title: Emma

text: will soon be better. I shall leave you together. There is no use in
title: Emma

text: delay. I shall not be far off, if you want me.”—And Emma distinctly
title: Emma

text: heard him add, in a lower tone, before he quitted the room,—“I have
title: Emma

text: been as good as my word. She has not the least idea.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston was looking so ill, and had an air of so much perturbation,
title: Emma

text: that Emma’s uneasiness increased; and the moment they were alone, she
title: Emma

text: eagerly said,
title: Emma

text: “What is it my dear friend? Something of a very unpleasant nature, I
title: Emma

text: find, has occurred;—do let me know directly what it is. I have been
title: Emma

text: walking all this way in complete suspense. We both abhor suspense. Do
title: Emma

text: not let mine continue longer. It will do you good to speak of your
title: Emma

text: distress, whatever it may be.”
title: Emma

text: “Have you indeed no idea?” said Mrs. Weston in a trembling voice.
title: Emma

text: “Cannot you, my dear Emma—cannot you form a guess as to what you are to
title: Emma

text: hear?”
title: Emma

text: “So far as that it relates to Mr. Frank Churchill, I do guess.”
title: Emma

text: “You are right. It does relate to him, and I will tell you directly;”
title: Emma

text: (resuming her work, and seeming resolved against looking up.) “He has
title: Emma

text: been here this very morning, on a most extraordinary errand. It is
title: Emma

text: impossible to express our surprize. He came to speak to his father on a
title: Emma

text: subject,—to announce an attachment—”
title: Emma

text: She stopped to breathe. Emma thought first of herself, and then of
title: Emma

text: Harriet.
title: Emma

text: “More than an attachment, indeed,” resumed Mrs. Weston; “an
title: Emma

text: engagement—a positive engagement.—What will you say, Emma—what will any
title: Emma

text: body say, when it is known that Frank Churchill and Miss Fairfax are
title: Emma

text: engaged;—nay, that they have been long engaged!”
title: Emma

text: Emma even jumped with surprize;—and, horror-struck, exclaimed,
title: Emma

text: “Jane Fairfax!—Good God! You are not serious? You do not mean it?”
title: Emma

text: “You may well be amazed,” returned Mrs. Weston, still averting her
title: Emma

text: eyes, and talking on with eagerness, that Emma might have time to
title: Emma

text: recover— “You may well be amazed. But it is even so. There has been a
title: Emma

text: solemn engagement between them ever since October—formed at Weymouth,
title: Emma

text: and kept a secret from every body. Not a creature knowing it but
title: Emma

text: themselves—neither the Campbells, nor her family, nor his.—It is so
title: Emma

text: wonderful, that though perfectly convinced of the fact, it is yet
title: Emma

text: almost incredible to myself. I can hardly believe it.—I thought I knew
title: Emma

text: him.”
title: Emma

text: Emma scarcely heard what was said.—Her mind was divided between two
title: Emma

text: ideas—her own former conversations with him about Miss Fairfax; and
title: Emma

text: poor Harriet;—and for some time she could only exclaim, and require
title: Emma

text: confirmation, repeated confirmation.
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said she at last, trying to recover herself; “this is a
title: Emma

text: circumstance which I must think of at least half a day, before I can at
title: Emma

text: all comprehend it. What!—engaged to her all the winter—before either of
title: Emma

text: them came to Highbury?”
title: Emma

text: “Engaged since October,—secretly engaged.—It has hurt me, Emma, very
title: Emma

text: much. It has hurt his father equally. _Some_ _part_ of his conduct we
title: Emma

text: cannot excuse.”
title: Emma

text: Emma pondered a moment, and then replied, “I will not pretend _not_ to
title: Emma

text: understand you; and to give you all the relief in my power, be assured
title: Emma

text: that no such effect has followed his attentions to me, as you are
title: Emma

text: apprehensive of.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston looked up, afraid to believe; but Emma’s countenance was as
title: Emma

text: steady as her words.
title: Emma

text: “That you may have less difficulty in believing this boast, of my
title: Emma

text: present perfect indifference,” she continued, “I will farther tell you,
title: Emma

text: that there was a period in the early part of our acquaintance, when I
title: Emma

text: did like him, when I was very much disposed to be attached to him—nay,
title: Emma

text: was attached—and how it came to cease, is perhaps the wonder.
title: Emma

text: Fortunately, however, it did cease. I have really for some time past,
title: Emma

text: for at least these three months, cared nothing about him. You may
title: Emma

text: believe me, Mrs. Weston. This is the simple truth.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston kissed her with tears of joy; and when she could find
title: Emma

text: utterance, assured her, that this protestation had done her more good
title: Emma

text: than any thing else in the world could do.
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Weston will be almost as much relieved as myself,” said she. “On
title: Emma

text: this point we have been wretched. It was our darling wish that you
title: Emma

text: might be attached to each other—and we were persuaded that it was so.—
title: Emma

text: Imagine what we have been feeling on your account.”
title: Emma

text: “I have escaped; and that I should escape, may be a matter of grateful
title: Emma

text: wonder to you and myself. But this does not acquit _him_, Mrs. Weston;
title: Emma

text: and I must say, that I think him greatly to blame. What right had he to
title: Emma

text: come among us with affection and faith engaged, and with manners so
title: Emma

text: _very_ disengaged? What right had he to endeavour to please, as he
title: Emma

text: certainly did—to distinguish any one young woman with persevering
title: Emma

text: attention, as he certainly did—while he really belonged to another?—How
title: Emma

text: could he tell what mischief he might be doing?—How could he tell that
title: Emma

text: he might not be making me in love with him?—very wrong, very wrong
title: Emma

text: indeed.”
title: Emma

text: “From something that he said, my dear Emma, I rather imagine—”
title: Emma

text: “And how could _she_ bear such behaviour! Composure with a witness! to
title: Emma

text: look on, while repeated attentions were offering to another woman,
title: Emma

text: before her face, and not resent it.—That is a degree of placidity,
title: Emma

text: which I can neither comprehend nor respect.”
title: Emma

text: “There were misunderstandings between them, Emma; he said so expressly.
title: Emma

text: He had not time to enter into much explanation. He was here only a
title: Emma

text: quarter of an hour, and in a state of agitation which did not allow the
title: Emma

text: full use even of the time he could stay—but that there had been
title: Emma

text: misunderstandings he decidedly said. The present crisis, indeed, seemed
title: Emma

text: to be brought on by them; and those misunderstandings might very
title: Emma

text: possibly arise from the impropriety of his conduct.”
title: Emma

text: “Impropriety! Oh! Mrs. Weston—it is too calm a censure. Much, much
title: Emma

text: beyond impropriety!—It has sunk him, I cannot say how it has sunk him
title: Emma

text: in my opinion. So unlike what a man should be!—None of that upright
title: Emma

text: integrity, that strict adherence to truth and principle, that disdain
title: Emma

text: of trick and littleness, which a man should display in every
title: Emma

text: transaction of his life.”
title: Emma

text: “Nay, dear Emma, now I must take his part; for though he has been wrong
title: Emma

text: in this instance, I have known him long enough to answer for his having
title: Emma

text: many, very many, good qualities; and—”
title: Emma

text: “Good God!” cried Emma, not attending to her.—“Mrs. Smallridge, too!
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “He knew nothing about it, Emma. On this article I can fully acquit
title: Emma

text: him. It was a private resolution of hers, not communicated to him—or at
title: Emma

text: least not communicated in a way to carry conviction.—Till yesterday, I
title: Emma

text: know he said he was in the dark as to her plans. They burst on him, I
title: Emma

text: do not know how, but by some letter or message—and it was the discovery
title: Emma

text: of what she was doing, of this very project of hers, which determined
title: Emma

text: him to come forward at once, own it all to his uncle, throw himself on
title: Emma

text: his kindness, and, in short, put an end to the miserable state of
title: Emma

text: concealment that had been carrying on so long.”
title: Emma

text: Emma began to listen better.
title: Emma

text: “I am to hear from him soon,” continued Mrs. Weston. “He told me at
title: Emma

text: parting, that he should soon write; and he spoke in a manner which
title: Emma

text: seemed to promise me many particulars that could not be given now. Let
title: Emma

text: us wait, therefore, for this letter. It may bring many extenuations. It
title: Emma

text: may make many things intelligible and excusable which now are not to be
title: Emma

text: understood. Don’t let us be severe, don’t let us be in a hurry to
title: Emma

text: condemn him. Let us have patience. I must love him; and now that I am
title: Emma

text: satisfied on one point, the one material point, I am sincerely anxious
title: Emma

text: for its all turning out well, and ready to hope that it may. They must
title: Emma

text: both have suffered a great deal under such a system of secresy and
title: Emma

text: concealment.”
title: Emma

text: “_His_ sufferings,” replied Emma dryly, “do not appear to have done him
title: Emma

text: much harm. Well, and how did Mr. Churchill take it?”
title: Emma

text: “Most favourably for his nephew—gave his consent with scarcely a
title: Emma

text: difficulty. Conceive what the events of a week have done in that
title: Emma

text: family! While poor Mrs. Churchill lived, I suppose there could not have
title: Emma

text: been a hope, a chance, a possibility;—but scarcely are her remains at
title: Emma

text: rest in the family vault, than her husband is persuaded to act exactly
title: Emma

text: opposite to what she would have required. What a blessing it is, when
title: Emma

text: undue influence does not survive the grave!—He gave his consent with
title: Emma

text: very little persuasion.”
title: Emma

text: “Ah!” thought Emma, “he would have done as much for Harriet.”
title: Emma

text: “This was settled last night, and Frank was off with the light this
title: Emma

text: morning. He stopped at Highbury, at the Bates’s, I fancy, some time—and
title: Emma

text: then came on hither; but was in such a hurry to get back to his uncle,
title: Emma

text: to whom he is just now more necessary than ever, that, as I tell you,
title: Emma

text: he could stay with us but a quarter of an hour.—He was very much
title: Emma

text: agitated—very much, indeed—to a degree that made him appear quite a
title: Emma

text: different creature from any thing I had ever seen him before.—In
title: Emma

text: addition to all the rest, there had been the shock of finding her so
title: Emma

text: very unwell, which he had had no previous suspicion of—and there was
title: Emma

text: every appearance of his having been feeling a great deal.”
title: Emma

text: “And do you really believe the affair to have been carrying on with
title: Emma

text: such perfect secresy?—The Campbells, the Dixons, did none of them know
title: Emma

text: of the engagement?”
title: Emma

text: Emma could not speak the name of Dixon without a little blush.
title: Emma

text: “None; not one. He positively said that it had been known to no being
title: Emma

text: in the world but their two selves.”
title: Emma

text: “Well,” said Emma, “I suppose we shall gradually grow reconciled to the
title: Emma

text: idea, and I wish them very happy. But I shall always think it a very
title: Emma

text: abominable sort of proceeding. What has it been but a system of
title: Emma

text: hypocrisy and deceit,—espionage, and treachery?—To come among us with
title: Emma

text: professions of openness and simplicity; and such a league in secret to
title: Emma

text: judge us all!—Here have we been, the whole winter and spring,
title: Emma

text: completely duped, fancying ourselves all on an equal footing of truth
title: Emma

text: and honour, with two people in the midst of us who may have been
title: Emma

text: carrying round, comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and
title: Emma

text: words that were never meant for both to hear.—They must take the
title: Emma

text: consequence, if they have heard each other spoken of in a way not
title: Emma

text: perfectly agreeable!”
title: Emma

text: “I am quite easy on that head,” replied Mrs. Weston. “I am very sure
title: Emma

text: that I never said any thing of either to the other, which both might
title: Emma

text: not have heard.”
title: Emma

text: “You are in luck.—Your only blunder was confined to my ear, when you
title: Emma

text: imagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady.”
title: Emma

text: “True. But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss
title: Emma

text: Fairfax, I never could, under any blunder, have spoken ill of her; and
title: Emma

text: as to speaking ill of him, there I must have been safe.”
title: Emma

text: At this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the
title: Emma

text: window, evidently on the watch. His wife gave him a look which invited
title: Emma

text: him in; and, while he was coming round, added, “Now, dearest Emma, let
title: Emma

text: me intreat you to say and look every thing that may set his heart at
title: Emma

text: ease, and incline him to be satisfied with the match. Let us make the
title: Emma

text: best of it—and, indeed, almost every thing may be fairly said in her
title: Emma

text: favour. It is not a connexion to gratify; but if Mr. Churchill does not
title: Emma

text: feel that, why should we? and it may be a very fortunate circumstance
title: Emma

text: for him, for Frank, I mean, that he should have attached himself to a
title: Emma

text: girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as I have always
title: Emma

text: given her credit for—and still am disposed to give her credit for, in
title: Emma

text: spite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right. And
title: Emma

text: how much may be said in her situation for even that error!”
title: Emma

text: “Much, indeed!” cried Emma feelingly. “If a woman can ever be excused
title: Emma

text: for thinking only of herself, it is in a situation like Jane
title: Emma

text: Fairfax’s.—Of such, one may almost say, that ‘the world is not their’s,
title: Emma

text: nor the world’s law.’”
title: Emma

text: She met Mr. Weston on his entrance, with a smiling countenance,
title: Emma

text: exclaiming,
title: Emma

text: “A very pretty trick you have been playing me, upon my word! This was a
title: Emma

text: device, I suppose, to sport with my curiosity, and exercise my talent
title: Emma

text: of guessing. But you really frightened me. I thought you had lost half
title: Emma

text: your property, at least. And here, instead of its being a matter of
title: Emma

text: condolence, it turns out to be one of congratulation.—I congratulate
title: Emma

text: you, Mr. Weston, with all my heart, on the prospect of having one of
title: Emma

text: the most lovely and accomplished young women in England for your
title: Emma

text: daughter.”
title: Emma

text: A glance or two between him and his wife, convinced him that all was as
title: Emma

text: right as this speech proclaimed; and its happy effect on his spirits
title: Emma

text: was immediate. His air and voice recovered their usual briskness: he
title: Emma

text: shook her heartily and gratefully by the hand, and entered on the
title: Emma

text: subject in a manner to prove, that he now only wanted time and
title: Emma

text: persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing. His companions
title: Emma

text: suggested only what could palliate imprudence, or smooth objections;
title: Emma

text: and by the time they had talked it all over together, and he had talked
title: Emma

text: it all over again with Emma, in their walk back to Hartfield, he was
title: Emma

text: become perfectly reconciled, and not far from thinking it the very best
title: Emma

text: thing that Frank could possibly have done.

text: CHAPTER XI
title: Emma

text: “Harriet, poor Harriet!”—Those were the words; in them lay the
title: Emma

text: tormenting ideas which Emma could not get rid of, and which constituted
title: Emma

text: the real misery of the business to her. Frank Churchill had behaved
title: Emma

text: very ill by herself—very ill in many ways,—but it was not so much _his_
title: Emma

text: behaviour as her _own_, which made her so angry with him. It was the
title: Emma

text: scrape which he had drawn her into on Harriet’s account, that gave the
title: Emma

text: deepest hue to his offence.—Poor Harriet! to be a second time the dupe
title: Emma

text: of her misconceptions and flattery. Mr. Knightley had spoken
title: Emma

text: prophetically, when he once said, “Emma, you have been no friend to
title: Emma

text: Harriet Smith.”—She was afraid she had done her nothing but
title: Emma

text: disservice.—It was true that she had not to charge herself, in this
title: Emma

text: instance as in the former, with being the sole and original author of
title: Emma

text: the mischief; with having suggested such feelings as might otherwise
title: Emma

text: never have entered Harriet’s imagination; for Harriet had acknowledged
title: Emma

text: her admiration and preference of Frank Churchill before she had ever
title: Emma

text: given her a hint on the subject; but she felt completely guilty of
title: Emma

text: having encouraged what she might have repressed. She might have
title: Emma

text: prevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments. Her influence
title: Emma

text: would have been enough. And now she was very conscious that she ought
title: Emma

text: to have prevented them.—She felt that she had been risking her friend’s
title: Emma

text: happiness on most insufficient grounds. Common sense would have
title: Emma

text: directed her to tell Harriet, that she must not allow herself to think
title: Emma

text: of him, and that there were five hundred chances to one against his
title: Emma

text: ever caring for her.—“But, with common sense,” she added, “I am afraid
title: Emma

text: I have had little to do.”
title: Emma

text: She was extremely angry with herself. If she could not have been angry
title: Emma

text: with Frank Churchill too, it would have been dreadful.—As for Jane
title: Emma

text: Fairfax, she might at least relieve her feelings from any present
title: Emma

text: solicitude on her account. Harriet would be anxiety enough; she need no
title: Emma

text: longer be unhappy about Jane, whose troubles and whose ill-health
title: Emma

text: having, of course, the same origin, must be equally under cure.—Her
title: Emma

text: days of insignificance and evil were over.—She would soon be well, and
title: Emma

text: happy, and prosperous.—Emma could now imagine why her own attentions
title: Emma

text: had been slighted. This discovery laid many smaller matters open. No
title: Emma

text: doubt it had been from jealousy.—In Jane’s eyes she had been a rival;
title: Emma

text: and well might any thing she could offer of assistance or regard be
title: Emma

text: repulsed. An airing in the Hartfield carriage would have been the rack,
title: Emma

text: and arrowroot from the Hartfield storeroom must have been poison. She
title: Emma

text: understood it all; and as far as her mind could disengage itself from
title: Emma

text: the injustice and selfishness of angry feelings, she acknowledged that
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond her
title: Emma

text: desert. But poor Harriet was such an engrossing charge! There was
title: Emma

text: little sympathy to be spared for any body else. Emma was sadly fearful
title: Emma

text: that this second disappointment would be more severe than the first.
title: Emma

text: Considering the very superior claims of the object, it ought; and
title: Emma

text: judging by its apparently stronger effect on Harriet’s mind, producing
title: Emma

text: reserve and self-command, it would.—She must communicate the painful
title: Emma

text: truth, however, and as soon as possible. An injunction of secresy had
title: Emma

text: been among Mr. Weston’s parting words. “For the present, the whole
title: Emma

text: affair was to be completely a secret. Mr. Churchill had made a point of
title: Emma

text: it, as a token of respect to the wife he had so very recently lost; and
title: Emma

text: every body admitted it to be no more than due decorum.”—Emma had
title: Emma

text: promised; but still Harriet must be excepted. It was her superior duty.
title: Emma

text: In spite of her vexation, she could not help feeling it almost
title: Emma

text: ridiculous, that she should have the very same distressing and delicate
title: Emma

text: office to perform by Harriet, which Mrs. Weston had just gone through
title: Emma

text: by herself. The intelligence, which had been so anxiously announced to
title: Emma

text: her, she was now to be anxiously announcing to another. Her heart beat
title: Emma

text: quick on hearing Harriet’s footstep and voice; so, she supposed, had
title: Emma

text: poor Mrs. Weston felt when _she_ was approaching Randalls. Could the
title: Emma

text: event of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!—But of that,
title: Emma

text: unfortunately, there could be no chance.
title: Emma

text: “Well, Miss Woodhouse!” cried Harriet, coming eagerly into the room—“is
title: Emma

text: not this the oddest news that ever was?”
title: Emma

text: “What news do you mean?” replied Emma, unable to guess, by look or
title: Emma

text: voice, whether Harriet could indeed have received any hint.
title: Emma

text: “About Jane Fairfax. Did you ever hear any thing so strange? Oh!—you
title: Emma

text: need not be afraid of owning it to me, for Mr. Weston has told me
title: Emma

text: himself. I met him just now. He told me it was to be a great secret;
title: Emma

text: and, therefore, I should not think of mentioning it to any body but
title: Emma

text: you, but he said you knew it.”
title: Emma

text: “What did Mr. Weston tell you?”—said Emma, still perplexed.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! he told me all about it; that Jane Fairfax and Mr. Frank Churchill
title: Emma

text: are to be married, and that they have been privately engaged to one
title: Emma

text: another this long while. How very odd!”
title: Emma

text: It was, indeed, so odd; Harriet’s behaviour was so extremely odd, that
title: Emma

text: Emma did not know how to understand it. Her character appeared
title: Emma

text: absolutely changed. She seemed to propose shewing no agitation, or
title: Emma

text: disappointment, or peculiar concern in the discovery. Emma looked at
title: Emma

text: her, quite unable to speak.
title: Emma

text: “Had you any idea,” cried Harriet, “of his being in love with her?—You,
title: Emma

text: perhaps, might.—You (blushing as she spoke) who can see into every
title: Emma

text: body’s heart; but nobody else—”
title: Emma

text: “Upon my word,” said Emma, “I begin to doubt my having any such talent.
title: Emma

text: Can you seriously ask me, Harriet, whether I imagined him attached to
title: Emma

text: another woman at the very time that I was—tacitly, if not
title: Emma

text: openly—encouraging you to give way to your own feelings?—I never had
title: Emma

text: the slightest suspicion, till within the last hour, of Mr. Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill’s having the least regard for Jane Fairfax. You may be very
title: Emma

text: sure that if I had, I should have cautioned you accordingly.”
title: Emma

text: “Me!” cried Harriet, colouring, and astonished. “Why should you caution
title: Emma

text: me?—You do not think I care about Mr. Frank Churchill.”
title: Emma

text: “I am delighted to hear you speak so stoutly on the subject,” replied
title: Emma

text: Emma, smiling; “but you do not mean to deny that there was a time—and
title: Emma

text: not very distant either—when you gave me reason to understand that you
title: Emma

text: did care about him?”
title: Emma

text: “Him!—never, never. Dear Miss Woodhouse, how could you so mistake me?”
title: Emma

text: turning away distressed.
title: Emma

text: “Harriet!” cried Emma, after a moment’s pause—“What do you mean?—Good
title: Emma

text: Heaven! what do you mean?—Mistake you!—Am I to suppose then?—”
title: Emma

text: She could not speak another word.—Her voice was lost; and she sat down,
title: Emma

text: waiting in great terror till Harriet should answer.
title: Emma

text: Harriet, who was standing at some distance, and with face turned from
title: Emma

text: her, did not immediately say any thing; and when she did speak, it was
title: Emma

text: in a voice nearly as agitated as Emma’s.
title: Emma

text: “I should not have thought it possible,” she began, “that you could
title: Emma

text: have misunderstood me! I know we agreed never to name him—but
title: Emma

text: considering how infinitely superior he is to every body else, I should
title: Emma

text: not have thought it possible that I could be supposed to mean any other
title: Emma

text: person. Mr. Frank Churchill, indeed! I do not know who would ever look
title: Emma

text: at him in the company of the other. I hope I have a better taste than
title: Emma

text: to think of Mr. Frank Churchill, who is like nobody by his side. And
title: Emma

text: that you should have been so mistaken, is amazing!—I am sure, but for
title: Emma

text: believing that you entirely approved and meant to encourage me in my
title: Emma

text: attachment, I should have considered it at first too great a
title: Emma

text: presumption almost, to dare to think of him. At first, if you had not
title: Emma

text: told me that more wonderful things had happened; that there had been
title: Emma

text: matches of greater disparity (those were your very words);—I should not
title: Emma

text: have dared to give way to—I should not have thought it possible—But if
title: Emma

text: _you_, who had been always acquainted with him—”
title: Emma

text: “Harriet!” cried Emma, collecting herself resolutely—“Let us understand
title: Emma

text: each other now, without the possibility of farther mistake. Are you
title: Emma

text: speaking of—Mr. Knightley?”
title: Emma

text: “To be sure I am. I never could have an idea of any body else—and so I
title: Emma

text: thought you knew. When we talked about him, it was as clear as
title: Emma

text: possible.”
title: Emma

text: “Not quite,” returned Emma, with forced calmness, “for all that you
title: Emma

text: then said, appeared to me to relate to a different person. I could
title: Emma

text: almost assert that you had _named_ Mr. Frank Churchill. I am sure the
title: Emma

text: service Mr. Frank Churchill had rendered you, in protecting you from
title: Emma

text: the gipsies, was spoken of.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! Miss Woodhouse, how you do forget!”
title: Emma

text: “My dear Harriet, I perfectly remember the substance of what I said on
title: Emma

text: the occasion. I told you that I did not wonder at your attachment; that
title: Emma

text: considering the service he had rendered you, it was extremely
title: Emma

text: natural:—and you agreed to it, expressing yourself very warmly as to
title: Emma

text: your sense of that service, and mentioning even what your sensations
title: Emma

text: had been in seeing him come forward to your rescue.—The impression of
title: Emma

text: it is strong on my memory.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh, dear,” cried Harriet, “now I recollect what you mean; but I was
title: Emma

text: thinking of something very different at the time. It was not the
title: Emma

text: gipsies—it was not Mr. Frank Churchill that I meant. No! (with some
title: Emma

text: elevation) I was thinking of a much more precious circumstance—of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley’s coming and asking me to dance, when Mr. Elton would not
title: Emma

text: stand up with me; and when there was no other partner in the room. That
title: Emma

text: was the kind action; that was the noble benevolence and generosity;
title: Emma

text: that was the service which made me begin to feel how superior he was to
title: Emma

text: every other being upon earth.”
title: Emma

text: “Good God!” cried Emma, “this has been a most unfortunate—most
title: Emma

text: deplorable mistake!—What is to be done?”
title: Emma

text: “You would not have encouraged me, then, if you had understood me? At
title: Emma

text: least, however, I cannot be worse off than I should have been, if the
title: Emma

text: other had been the person; and now—it _is_ possible—”
title: Emma

text: She paused a few moments. Emma could not speak.
title: Emma

text: “I do not wonder, Miss Woodhouse,” she resumed, “that you should feel a
title: Emma

text: great difference between the two, as to me or as to any body. You must
title: Emma

text: think one five hundred million times more above me than the other. But
title: Emma

text: I hope, Miss Woodhouse, that supposing—that if—strange as it may
title: Emma

text: appear—. But you know they were your own words, that _more_ wonderful
title: Emma

text: things had happened, matches of _greater_ disparity had taken place
title: Emma

text: than between Mr. Frank Churchill and me; and, therefore, it seems as if
title: Emma

text: such a thing even as this, may have occurred before—and if I should be
title: Emma

text: so fortunate, beyond expression, as to—if Mr. Knightley should
title: Emma
