title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, you will not set yourself against it, and try to put
title: Emma

text: difficulties in the way. But you are too good for that, I am sure.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet was standing at one of the windows. Emma turned round to look
title: Emma

text: at her in consternation, and hastily said,
title: Emma

text: “Have you any idea of Mr. Knightley’s returning your affection?”
title: Emma

text: “Yes,” replied Harriet modestly, but not fearfully—“I must say that I
title: Emma

text: have.”
title: Emma

text: Emma’s eyes were instantly withdrawn; and she sat silently meditating,
title: Emma

text: in a fixed attitude, for a few minutes. A few minutes were sufficient
title: Emma

text: for making her acquainted with her own heart. A mind like hers, once
title: Emma

text: opening to suspicion, made rapid progress. She touched—she admitted—she
title: Emma

text: acknowledged the whole truth. Why was it so much worse that Harriet
title: Emma

text: should be in love with Mr. Knightley, than with Frank Churchill? Why
title: Emma

text: was the evil so dreadfully increased by Harriet’s having some hope of a
title: Emma

text: return? It darted through her, with the speed of an arrow, that Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley must marry no one but herself!
title: Emma

text: Her own conduct, as well as her own heart, was before her in the same
title: Emma

text: few minutes. She saw it all with a clearness which had never blessed
title: Emma

text: her before. How improperly had she been acting by Harriet! How
title: Emma

text: inconsiderate, how indelicate, how irrational, how unfeeling had been
title: Emma

text: her conduct! What blindness, what madness, had led her on! It struck
title: Emma

text: her with dreadful force, and she was ready to give it every bad name in
title: Emma

text: the world. Some portion of respect for herself, however, in spite of
title: Emma

text: all these demerits—some concern for her own appearance, and a strong
title: Emma

text: sense of justice by Harriet—(there would be no need of _compassion_ to
title: Emma

text: the girl who believed herself loved by Mr. Knightley—but justice
title: Emma

text: required that she should not be made unhappy by any coldness now,) gave
title: Emma

text: Emma the resolution to sit and endure farther with calmness, with even
title: Emma

text: apparent kindness.—For her own advantage indeed, it was fit that the
title: Emma

text: utmost extent of Harriet’s hopes should be enquired into; and Harriet
title: Emma

text: had done nothing to forfeit the regard and interest which had been so
title: Emma

text: voluntarily formed and maintained—or to deserve to be slighted by the
title: Emma

text: person, whose counsels had never led her right.—Rousing from
title: Emma

text: reflection, therefore, and subduing her emotion, she turned to Harriet
title: Emma

text: again, and, in a more inviting accent, renewed the conversation; for as
title: Emma

text: to the subject which had first introduced it, the wonderful story of
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax, that was quite sunk and lost.—Neither of them thought but
title: Emma

text: of Mr. Knightley and themselves.
title: Emma

text: Harriet, who had been standing in no unhappy reverie, was yet very glad
title: Emma

text: to be called from it, by the now encouraging manner of such a judge,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: better concealed than Harriet’s, but they were not less. Her voice was
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: inward suffering, but with great outward patience, to Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: detail.—Methodical, or well arranged, or very well delivered, it could
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: Harriet.
title: Emma

text: Harriet had been conscious of a difference in his behaviour ever since
title: Emma

text: those two decisive dances.—Emma knew that he had, on that occasion,
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: compliment implied, a preference inferred, had been unnoticed, because
title: Emma

text: unsuspected, by Emma. Circumstances that might swell to half an hour’s
title: Emma

text: relation, and contained multiplied proofs to her who had seen them, had
title: Emma

text: passed undiscerned by her who now heard them; but the two latest
title: Emma

text: occurrences to be mentioned, the two of strongest promise to Harriet,
title: Emma

text: were not without some degree of witness from Emma herself.—The first,
title: Emma

text: was his walking with her apart from the others, in the lime-walk at
title: Emma

text: Donwell, where they had been walking some time before Emma came, and he
title: Emma

text: had taken pains (as she was convinced) to draw her from the rest to
title: Emma

text: himself—and at first, he had talked to her in a more particular way
title: Emma

text: than he had ever done before, in a very particular way indeed!—(Harriet
title: Emma

text: could not recall it without a blush.) He seemed to be almost asking
title: Emma

text: her, whether her affections were engaged.—But as soon as she (Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse) appeared likely to join them, he changed the subject, and
title: Emma

text: began talking about farming:—The second, was his having sat talking
title: Emma

text: with her nearly half an hour before Emma came back from her visit, the
title: Emma

text: very last morning of his being at Hartfield—though, when he first came
title: Emma

text: in, he had said that he could not stay five minutes—and his having told
title: Emma

text: her, during their conversation, that though he must go to London, it
title: Emma

text: was very much against his inclination that he left home at all, which
title: Emma

text: was much more (as Emma felt) than he had acknowledged to _her_. The
title: Emma

text: superior degree of confidence towards Harriet, which this one article
title: Emma

text: marked, gave her severe pain.
title: Emma

text: On the subject of the first of the two circumstances, she did, after a
title: Emma

text: little reflection, venture the following question. “Might he not?—Is
title: Emma

text: not it possible, that when enquiring, as you thought, into the state of
title: Emma

text: your affections, he might be alluding to Mr. Martin—he might have Mr.
title: Emma

text: Martin’s interest in view? But Harriet rejected the suspicion with
title: Emma

text: spirit.
title: Emma

text: “Mr. Martin! No indeed!—There was not a hint of Mr. Martin. I hope I
title: Emma

text: know better now, than to care for Mr. Martin, or to be suspected of
title: Emma

text: it.”
title: Emma

text: When Harriet had closed her evidence, she appealed to her dear Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, to say whether she had not good ground for hope.
title: Emma

text: “I never should have presumed to think of it at first,” said she, “but
title: Emma

text: for you. You told me to observe him carefully, and let his behaviour be
title: Emma

text: the rule of mine—and so I have. But now I seem to feel that I may
title: Emma

text: deserve him; and that if he does chuse me, it will not be any thing so
title: Emma

text: very wonderful.”
title: Emma

text: The bitter feelings occasioned by this speech, the many bitter
title: Emma

text: feelings, made the utmost exertion necessary on Emma’s side, to enable
title: Emma

text: her to say on reply,
title: Emma

text: “Harriet, I will only venture to declare, that Mr. Knightley is the
title: Emma

text: last man in the world, who would intentionally give any woman the idea
title: Emma

text: of his feeling for her more than he really does.”
title: Emma

text: Harriet seemed ready to worship her friend for a sentence so
title: Emma

text: satisfactory; and Emma was only saved from raptures and fondness, which
title: Emma

text: at that moment would have been dreadful penance, by the sound of her
title: Emma

text: father’s footsteps. He was coming through the hall. Harriet was too
title: Emma

text: much agitated to encounter him. “She could not compose herself— Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse would be alarmed—she had better go;”—with most ready
title: Emma

text: encouragement from her friend, therefore, she passed off through
title: Emma

text: another door—and the moment she was gone, this was the spontaneous
title: Emma

text: burst of Emma’s feelings: “Oh God! that I had never seen her!”
title: Emma

text: The rest of the day, the following night, were hardly enough for her
title: Emma

text: thoughts.—She was bewildered amidst the confusion of all that had
title: Emma

text: rushed on her within the last few hours. Every moment had brought a
title: Emma

text: fresh surprize; and every surprize must be matter of humiliation to
title: Emma

text: her.—How to understand it all! How to understand the deceptions she had
title: Emma

text: been thus practising on herself, and living under!—The blunders, the
title: Emma

text: blindness of her own head and heart!—she sat still, she walked about,
title: Emma

text: she tried her own room, she tried the shrubbery—in every place, every
title: Emma

text: posture, she perceived that she had acted most weakly; that she had
title: Emma

text: been imposed on by others in a most mortifying degree; that she had
title: Emma

text: been imposing on herself in a degree yet more mortifying; that she was
title: Emma

text: wretched, and should probably find this day but the beginning of
title: Emma

text: wretchedness.
title: Emma

text: To understand, thoroughly understand her own heart, was the first
title: Emma

text: endeavour. To that point went every leisure moment which her father’s
title: Emma

text: claims on her allowed, and every moment of involuntary absence of mind.
title: Emma

text: How long had Mr. Knightley been so dear to her, as every feeling
title: Emma

text: declared him now to be? When had his influence, such influence begun?—
title: Emma

text: When had he succeeded to that place in her affection, which Frank
title: Emma

text: Churchill had once, for a short period, occupied?—She looked back; she
title: Emma

text: compared the two—compared them, as they had always stood in her
title: Emma

text: estimation, from the time of the latter’s becoming known to her—and as
title: Emma

text: they must at any time have been compared by her, had it—oh! had it, by
title: Emma

text: any blessed felicity, occurred to her, to institute the comparison.—She
title: Emma

text: saw that there never had been a time when she did not consider Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley as infinitely the superior, or when his regard for her had
title: Emma

text: not been infinitely the most dear. She saw, that in persuading herself,
title: Emma

text: in fancying, in acting to the contrary, she had been entirely under a
title: Emma

text: delusion, totally ignorant of her own heart—and, in short, that she had
title: Emma

text: never really cared for Frank Churchill at all!
title: Emma

text: This was the conclusion of the first series of reflection. This was the
title: Emma

text: knowledge of herself, on the first question of inquiry, which she
title: Emma

text: reached; and without being long in reaching it.—She was most
title: Emma

text: sorrowfully indignant; ashamed of every sensation but the one revealed
title: Emma

text: to her—her affection for Mr. Knightley.—Every other part of her mind
title: Emma

text: was disgusting.
title: Emma

text: With insufferable vanity had she believed herself in the secret of
title: Emma

text: every body’s feelings; with unpardonable arrogance proposed to arrange
title: Emma

text: every body’s destiny. She was proved to have been universally mistaken;
title: Emma

text: and she had not quite done nothing—for she had done mischief. She had
title: Emma

text: brought evil on Harriet, on herself, and she too much feared, on Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley.—Were this most unequal of all connexions to take place, on
title: Emma

text: her must rest all the reproach of having given it a beginning; for his
title: Emma

text: attachment, she must believe to be produced only by a consciousness of
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s;—and even were this not the case, he would never have known
title: Emma

text: Harriet at all but for her folly.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!—It was a union to distance every
title: Emma

text: wonder of the kind.—The attachment of Frank Churchill and Jane Fairfax
title: Emma

text: became commonplace, threadbare, stale in the comparison, exciting no
title: Emma

text: surprize, presenting no disparity, affording nothing to be said or
title: Emma

text: thought.—Mr. Knightley and Harriet Smith!—Such an elevation on her
title: Emma

text: side! Such a debasement on his! It was horrible to Emma to think how it
title: Emma

text: must sink him in the general opinion, to foresee the smiles, the
title: Emma

text: sneers, the merriment it would prompt at his expense; the mortification
title: Emma

text: and disdain of his brother, the thousand inconveniences to
title: Emma

text: himself.—Could it be?—No; it was impossible. And yet it was far, very
title: Emma

text: far, from impossible.—Was it a new circumstance for a man of first-rate
title: Emma

text: abilities to be captivated by very inferior powers? Was it new for one,
title: Emma

text: perhaps too busy to seek, to be the prize of a girl who would seek
title: Emma

text: him?—Was it new for any thing in this world to be unequal,
title: Emma

text: inconsistent, incongruous—or for chance and circumstance (as second
title: Emma

text: causes) to direct the human fate?
title: Emma

text: Oh! had she never brought Harriet forward! Had she left her where she
title: Emma

text: ought, and where he had told her she ought!—Had she not, with a folly
title: Emma

text: which no tongue could express, prevented her marrying the
title: Emma

text: unexceptionable young man who would have made her happy and respectable
title: Emma

text: in the line of life to which she ought to belong—all would have been
title: Emma

text: safe; none of this dreadful sequel would have been.
title: Emma

text: How Harriet could ever have had the presumption to raise her thoughts
title: Emma

text: to Mr. Knightley!—How she could dare to fancy herself the chosen of
title: Emma

text: such a man till actually assured of it!—But Harriet was less humble,
title: Emma

text: had fewer scruples than formerly.—Her inferiority, whether of mind or
title: Emma

text: situation, seemed little felt.—She had seemed more sensible of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Elton’s being to stoop in marrying her, than she now seemed of Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley’s.—Alas! was not that her own doing too? Who had been at
title: Emma

text: pains to give Harriet notions of self-consequence but herself?—Who but
title: Emma

text: herself had taught her, that she was to elevate herself if possible,
title: Emma

text: and that her claims were great to a high worldly establishment?—If
title: Emma

text: Harriet, from being humble, were grown vain, it was her doing too.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XII
title: Emma

text: Till now that she was threatened with its loss, Emma had never known
title: Emma

text: how much of her happiness depended on being _first_ with Mr. Knightley,
title: Emma

text: first in interest and affection.—Satisfied that it was so, and feeling
title: Emma

text: it her due, she had enjoyed it without reflection; and only in the
title: Emma

text: dread of being supplanted, found how inexpressibly important it had
title: Emma

text: been.—Long, very long, she felt she had been first; for, having no
title: Emma

text: female connexions of his own, there had been only Isabella whose claims
title: Emma

text: could be compared with hers, and she had always known exactly how far
title: Emma

text: he loved and esteemed Isabella. She had herself been first with him for
title: Emma

text: many years past. She had not deserved it; she had often been negligent
title: Emma

text: or perverse, slighting his advice, or even wilfully opposing him,
title: Emma

text: insensible of half his merits, and quarrelling with him because he
title: Emma

text: would not acknowledge her false and insolent estimate of her own—but
title: Emma

text: still, from family attachment and habit, and thorough excellence of
title: Emma

text: mind, he had loved her, and watched over her from a girl, with an
title: Emma

text: endeavour to improve her, and an anxiety for her doing right, which no
title: Emma

text: other creature had at all shared. In spite of all her faults, she knew
title: Emma

text: she was dear to him; might she not say, very dear?—When the suggestions
title: Emma

text: of hope, however, which must follow here, presented themselves, she
title: Emma

text: could not presume to indulge them. Harriet Smith might think herself
title: Emma

text: not unworthy of being peculiarly, exclusively, passionately loved by
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley. _She_ could not. She could not flatter herself with any
title: Emma

text: idea of blindness in his attachment to _her_. She had received a very
title: Emma

text: recent proof of its impartiality.—How shocked had he been by her
title: Emma

text: behaviour to Miss Bates! How directly, how strongly had he expressed
title: Emma

text: himself to her on the subject!—Not too strongly for the offence—but
title: Emma

text: far, far too strongly to issue from any feeling softer than upright
title: Emma

text: justice and clear-sighted goodwill.—She had no hope, nothing to deserve
title: Emma

text: the name of hope, that he could have that sort of affection for herself
title: Emma

text: which was now in question; but there was a hope (at times a slight one,
title: Emma

text: at times much stronger,) that Harriet might have deceived herself, and
title: Emma

text: be overrating his regard for _her_.—Wish it she must, for his sake—be
title: Emma

text: the consequence nothing to herself, but his remaining single all his
title: Emma

text: life. Could she be secure of that, indeed, of his never marrying at
title: Emma

text: all, she believed she should be perfectly satisfied.—Let him but
title: Emma

text: continue the same Mr. Knightley to her and her father, the same Mr.
title: Emma

text: Knightley to all the world; let Donwell and Hartfield lose none of
title: Emma

text: their precious intercourse of friendship and confidence, and her peace
title: Emma

text: would be fully secured.—Marriage, in fact, would not do for her. It
title: Emma

text: would be incompatible with what she owed to her father, and with what
title: Emma

text: she felt for him. Nothing should separate her from her father. She
title: Emma

text: would not marry, even if she were asked by Mr. Knightley.
title: Emma

text: It must be her ardent wish that Harriet might be disappointed; and she
title: Emma

text: hoped, that when able to see them together again, she might at least be
title: Emma

text: able to ascertain what the chances for it were.—She should see them
title: Emma

text: henceforward with the closest observance; and wretchedly as she had
title: Emma

text: hitherto misunderstood even those she was watching, she did not know
title: Emma

text: how to admit that she could be blinded here.—He was expected back every
title: Emma

text: day. The power of observation would be soon given—frightfully soon it
title: Emma

text: appeared when her thoughts were in one course. In the meanwhile, she
title: Emma

text: resolved against seeing Harriet.—It would do neither of them good, it
title: Emma

text: would do the subject no good, to be talking of it farther.—She was
title: Emma

text: resolved not to be convinced, as long as she could doubt, and yet had
title: Emma

text: no authority for opposing Harriet’s confidence. To talk would be only
title: Emma

text: to irritate.—She wrote to her, therefore, kindly, but decisively, to
title: Emma

text: beg that she would not, at present, come to Hartfield; acknowledging it
title: Emma

text: to be her conviction, that all farther confidential discussion of _one_
title: Emma

text: topic had better be avoided; and hoping, that if a few days were
title: Emma

text: allowed to pass before they met again, except in the company of
title: Emma

text: others—she objected only to a tête-à-tête—they might be able to act as
title: Emma

text: if they had forgotten the conversation of yesterday.—Harriet submitted,
title: Emma

text: and approved, and was grateful.
title: Emma

text: This point was just arranged, when a visitor arrived to tear Emma’s
title: Emma

text: thoughts a little from the one subject which had engrossed them,
title: Emma

text: sleeping or waking, the last twenty-four hours—Mrs. Weston, who had
title: Emma

text: been calling on her daughter-in-law elect, and took Hartfield in her
title: Emma

text: way home, almost as much in duty to Emma as in pleasure to herself, to
title: Emma

text: relate all the particulars of so interesting an interview.
title: Emma

text: Mr. Weston had accompanied her to Mrs. Bates’s, and gone through his
title: Emma

text: share of this essential attention most handsomely; but she having then
title: Emma

text: induced Miss Fairfax to join her in an airing, was now returned with
title: Emma

text: much more to say, and much more to say with satisfaction, than a
title: Emma

text: quarter of an hour spent in Mrs. Bates’s parlour, with all the
title: Emma

text: encumbrance of awkward feelings, could have afforded.
title: Emma

text: A little curiosity Emma had; and she made the most of it while her
title: Emma

text: friend related. Mrs. Weston had set off to pay the visit in a good deal
title: Emma

text: of agitation herself; and in the first place had wished not to go at
title: Emma

text: all at present, to be allowed merely to write to Miss Fairfax instead,
title: Emma

text: and to defer this ceremonious call till a little time had passed, and
title: Emma

text: Mr. Churchill could be reconciled to the engagement’s becoming known;
title: Emma

text: as, considering every thing, she thought such a visit could not be paid
title: Emma

text: without leading to reports:—but Mr. Weston had thought differently; he
title: Emma

text: was extremely anxious to shew his approbation to Miss Fairfax and her
title: Emma

text: family, and did not conceive that any suspicion could be excited by it;
title: Emma

text: or if it were, that it would be of any consequence; for “such things,”
title: Emma

text: he observed, “always got about.” Emma smiled, and felt that Mr. Weston
title: Emma

text: had very good reason for saying so. They had gone, in short—and very
title: Emma

text: great had been the evident distress and confusion of the lady. She had
title: Emma

text: hardly been able to speak a word, and every look and action had shewn
title: Emma

text: how deeply she was suffering from consciousness. The quiet, heart-felt
title: Emma

text: satisfaction of the old lady, and the rapturous delight of her
title: Emma

text: daughter—who proved even too joyous to talk as usual, had been a
title: Emma

text: gratifying, yet almost an affecting, scene. They were both so truly
title: Emma

text: respectable in their happiness, so disinterested in every sensation;
title: Emma

text: thought so much of Jane; so much of every body, and so little of
title: Emma

text: themselves, that every kindly feeling was at work for them. Miss
title: Emma

text: Fairfax’s recent illness had offered a fair plea for Mrs. Weston to
title: Emma

text: invite her to an airing; she had drawn back and declined at first, but,
title: Emma

text: on being pressed had yielded; and, in the course of their drive, Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston had, by gentle encouragement, overcome so much of her
title: Emma

text: embarrassment, as to bring her to converse on the important subject.
title: Emma

text: Apologies for her seemingly ungracious silence in their first
title: Emma

text: reception, and the warmest expressions of the gratitude she was always
title: Emma

text: feeling towards herself and Mr. Weston, must necessarily open the
title: Emma

text: cause; but when these effusions were put by, they had talked a good
title: Emma

text: deal of the present and of the future state of the engagement. Mrs.
title: Emma

text: Weston was convinced that such conversation must be the greatest relief
title: Emma

text: to her companion, pent up within her own mind as every thing had so
title: Emma

text: long been, and was very much pleased with all that she had said on the
title: Emma

text: subject.
title: Emma

text: “On the misery of what she had suffered, during the concealment of so
title: Emma

text: many months,” continued Mrs. Weston, “she was energetic. This was one
title: Emma

text: of her expressions. ‘I will not say, that since I entered into the
title: Emma

text: engagement I have not had some happy moments; but I can say, that I
title: Emma

text: have never known the blessing of one tranquil hour:’—and the quivering
title: Emma

text: lip, Emma, which uttered it, was an attestation that I felt at my
title: Emma

text: heart.”
title: Emma

text: “Poor girl!” said Emma. “She thinks herself wrong, then, for having
title: Emma

text: consented to a private engagement?”
title: Emma

text: “Wrong! No one, I believe, can blame her more than she is disposed to
title: Emma

text: blame herself. ‘The consequence,’ said she, ‘has been a state of
title: Emma

text: perpetual suffering to me; and so it ought. But after all the
title: Emma

text: punishment that misconduct can bring, it is still not less misconduct.
title: Emma

text: Pain is no expiation. I never can be blameless. I have been acting
title: Emma

text: contrary to all my sense of right; and the fortunate turn that every
title: Emma

text: thing has taken, and the kindness I am now receiving, is what my
title: Emma

text: conscience tells me ought not to be.’ ‘Do not imagine, madam,’ she
title: Emma

text: continued, ‘that I was taught wrong. Do not let any reflection fall on
title: Emma

text: the principles or the care of the friends who brought me up. The error
title: Emma

text: has been all my own; and I do assure you that, with all the excuse that
title: Emma

text: present circumstances may appear to give, I shall yet dread making the
title: Emma

text: story known to Colonel Campbell.’”
title: Emma

text: “Poor girl!” said Emma again. “She loves him then excessively, I
title: Emma

text: suppose. It must have been from attachment only, that she could be led
title: Emma

text: to form the engagement. Her affection must have overpowered her
title: Emma

text: judgment.”
title: Emma

text: “Yes, I have no doubt of her being extremely attached to him.”
title: Emma

text: “I am afraid,” returned Emma, sighing, “that I must often have
title: Emma

text: contributed to make her unhappy.”
title: Emma

text: “On your side, my love, it was very innocently done. But she probably
title: Emma

text: had something of that in her thoughts, when alluding to the
title: Emma

text: misunderstandings which he had given us hints of before. One natural
title: Emma

text: consequence of the evil she had involved herself in,” she said, “was
title: Emma

text: that of making her _unreasonable_. The consciousness of having done
title: Emma

text: amiss, had exposed her to a thousand inquietudes, and made her captious
title: Emma

text: and irritable to a degree that must have been—that had been—hard for
title: Emma

text: him to bear. ‘I did not make the allowances,’ said she, ‘which I ought
title: Emma

text: to have done, for his temper and spirits—his delightful spirits, and
title: Emma

text: that gaiety, that playfulness of disposition, which, under any other
title: Emma

text: circumstances, would, I am sure, have been as constantly bewitching to
title: Emma

text: me, as they were at first.’ She then began to speak of you, and of the
title: Emma

text: great kindness you had shewn her during her illness; and with a blush
title: Emma

text: which shewed me how it was all connected, desired me, whenever I had an
title: Emma

text: opportunity, to thank you—I could not thank you too much—for every wish
title: Emma

text: and every endeavour to do her good. She was sensible that you had never
title: Emma

text: received any proper acknowledgment from herself.”
title: Emma

text: “If I did not know her to be happy now,” said Emma, seriously, “which,
title: Emma

text: in spite of every little drawback from her scrupulous conscience, she
title: Emma

text: must be, I could not bear these thanks;—for, oh! Mrs. Weston, if there
title: Emma

text: were an account drawn up of the evil and the good I have done Miss
title: Emma

text: Fairfax!—Well (checking herself, and trying to be more lively), this is
title: Emma

text: all to be forgotten. You are very kind to bring me these interesting
title: Emma

text: particulars. They shew her to the greatest advantage. I am sure she is
title: Emma

text: very good—I hope she will be very happy. It is fit that the fortune
title: Emma

text: should be on his side, for I think the merit will be all on hers.”
title: Emma

text: Such a conclusion could not pass unanswered by Mrs. Weston. She thought
title: Emma

text: well of Frank in almost every respect; and, what was more, she loved
title: Emma

text: him very much, and her defence was, therefore, earnest. She talked with
title: Emma

text: a great deal of reason, and at least equal affection—but she had too
title: Emma

text: much to urge for Emma’s attention; it was soon gone to Brunswick Square
title: Emma

text: or to Donwell; she forgot to attempt to listen; and when Mrs. Weston
title: Emma

text: ended with, “We have not yet had the letter we are so anxious for, you
title: Emma

text: know, but I hope it will soon come,” she was obliged to pause before
title: Emma

text: she answered, and at last obliged to answer at random, before she could
title: Emma

text: at all recollect what letter it was which they were so anxious for.
title: Emma

text: “Are you well, my Emma?” was Mrs. Weston’s parting question.
title: Emma

text: “Oh! perfectly. I am always well, you know. Be sure to give me
title: Emma

text: intelligence of the letter as soon as possible.”
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston’s communications furnished Emma with more food for
title: Emma

text: unpleasant reflection, by increasing her esteem and compassion, and her
title: Emma

text: sense of past injustice towards Miss Fairfax. She bitterly regretted
title: Emma

text: not having sought a closer acquaintance with her, and blushed for the
title: Emma

text: envious feelings which had certainly been, in some measure, the cause.
title: Emma

text: Had she followed Mr. Knightley’s known wishes, in paying that attention
title: Emma

text: to Miss Fairfax, which was every way her due; had she tried to know her
title: Emma

text: better; had she done her part towards intimacy; had she endeavoured to
title: Emma

text: find a friend there instead of in Harriet Smith; she must, in all
title: Emma

text: probability, have been spared from every pain which pressed on her
title: Emma

text: now.—Birth, abilities, and education, had been equally marking one as
title: Emma

text: an associate for her, to be received with gratitude; and the other—what
title: Emma

text: was she?—Supposing even that they had never become intimate friends;
title: Emma

text: that she had never been admitted into Miss Fairfax’s confidence on this
title: Emma

text: important matter—which was most probable—still, in knowing her as she
title: Emma

text: ought, and as she might, she must have been preserved from the
title: Emma

text: abominable suspicions of an improper attachment to Mr. Dixon, which she
title: Emma

text: had not only so foolishly fashioned and harboured herself, but had so
title: Emma

text: unpardonably imparted; an idea which she greatly feared had been made a
title: Emma

text: subject of material distress to the delicacy of Jane’s feelings, by the
title: Emma

text: levity or carelessness of Frank Churchill’s. Of all the sources of evil
title: Emma

text: surrounding the former, since her coming to Highbury, she was persuaded
title: Emma

text: that she must herself have been the worst. She must have been a
title: Emma

text: perpetual enemy. They never could have been all three together, without
title: Emma

text: her having stabbed Jane Fairfax’s peace in a thousand instances; and on
title: Emma

text: Box Hill, perhaps, it had been the agony of a mind that would bear no
title: Emma

text: more.
title: Emma

text: The evening of this day was very long, and melancholy, at Hartfield.
title: Emma

text: The weather added what it could of gloom. A cold stormy rain set in,
title: Emma

text: and nothing of July appeared but in the trees and shrubs, which the

text: The weather continued much the same all the following morning; and the
title: Emma

text: same loneliness, and the same melancholy, seemed to reign at
title: Emma

text: Hartfield—but in the afternoon it cleared; the wind changed into a
title: Emma

text: softer quarter; the clouds were carried off; the sun appeared; it was
title: Emma

text: summer again. With all the eagerness which such a transition gives,
title: Emma

text: Emma resolved to be out of doors as soon as possible. Never had the
title: Emma

text: exquisite sight, smell, sensation of nature, tranquil, warm, and
title: Emma

text: brilliant after a storm, been more attractive to her. She longed for
title: Emma

text: the serenity they might gradually introduce; and on Mr. Perry’s coming
title: Emma

text: in soon after dinner, with a disengaged hour to give her father, she
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: London. She had been thinking of him the moment before, as
title: Emma

text: unquestionably sixteen miles distant.—There was time only for the
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: had been collected!—and how often had her eyes fallen on the same
title: Emma

text: shrubs in the lawn, and observed the same beautiful effect of the
title: Emma

text: western sun!—But never in such a state of spirits, never in any thing
title: Emma

text: like it; and it was with difficulty that she could summon enough of her
title: Emma

text: usual self to be the attentive lady of the house, or even the attentive
title: Emma

text: daughter.
title: Emma

text: Poor Mr. Woodhouse little suspected what was plotting against him in
title: Emma

text: the breast of that man whom he was so cordially welcoming, and so
title: Emma

text: anxiously hoping might not have taken cold from his ride.—Could he have
title: Emma

text: seen the heart, he would have cared very little for the lungs; but
title: Emma

text: without the most distant imagination of the impending evil, without the
title: Emma

text: slightest perception of any thing extraordinary in the looks or ways of
title: Emma

text: either, he repeated to them very comfortably all the articles of news
title: Emma

text: he had received from Mr. Perry, and talked on with much
title: Emma

text: self-contentment, totally unsuspicious of what they could have told him
title: Emma

text: in return.
title: Emma

text: As long as Mr. Knightley remained with them, Emma’s fever continued;
title: Emma

text: but when he was gone, she began to be a little tranquillised and
title: Emma

text: subdued—and in the course of the sleepless night, which was the tax for
title: Emma

text: such an evening, she found one or two such very serious points to
title: Emma

text: consider, as made her feel, that even her happiness must have some
title: Emma

text: alloy. Her father—and Harriet. She could not be alone without feeling
title: Emma

text: the full weight of their separate claims; and how to guard the comfort
title: Emma

text: of both to the utmost, was the question. With respect to her father, it
title: Emma

text: was a question soon answered. She hardly knew yet what Mr. Knightley
title: Emma

text: would ask; but a very short parley with her own heart produced the most
title: Emma

text: solemn resolution of never quitting her father.—She even wept over the
title: Emma

text: idea of it, as a sin of thought. While he lived, it must be only an
title: Emma

text: engagement; but she flattered herself, that if divested of the danger
title: Emma

text: of drawing her away, it might become an increase of comfort to him.—How
title: Emma

text: to do her best by Harriet, was of more difficult decision;—how to spare
title: Emma

text: her from any unnecessary pain; how to make her any possible atonement;
title: Emma

text: how to appear least her enemy?—On these subjects, her perplexity and
title: Emma

text: distress were very great—and her mind had to pass again and again
title: Emma

text: through every bitter reproach and sorrowful regret that had ever
title: Emma

text: surrounded it.—She could only resolve at last, that she would still
title: Emma

text: avoid a meeting with her, and communicate all that need be told by
title: Emma

text: letter; that it would be inexpressibly desirable to have her removed
title: Emma

text: just now for a time from Highbury, and—indulging in one scheme
title: Emma

text: more—nearly resolve, that it might be practicable to get an invitation
title: Emma

text: for her to Brunswick Square.—Isabella had been pleased with Harriet;
title: Emma

text: and a few weeks spent in London must give her some amusement.—She did
title: Emma

text: not think it in Harriet’s nature to escape being benefited by novelty
title: Emma

text: and variety, by the streets, the shops, and the children.—At any rate,
title: Emma

text: it would be a proof of attention and kindness in herself, from whom
title: Emma

text: every thing was due; a separation for the present; an averting of the
title: Emma

text: evil day, when they must all be together again.
title: Emma

text: She rose early, and wrote her letter to Harriet; an employment which
title: Emma

text: left her so very serious, so nearly sad, that Mr. Knightley, in walking
title: Emma

text: up to Hartfield to breakfast, did not arrive at all too soon; and half
title: Emma

text: an hour stolen afterwards to go over the same ground again with him,
title: Emma

text: literally and figuratively, was quite necessary to reinstate her in a
title: Emma

text: proper share of the happiness of the evening before.
title: Emma

text: He had not left her long, by no means long enough for her to have the
title: Emma

text: slightest inclination for thinking of any body else, when a letter was
title: Emma

text: brought her from Randalls—a very thick letter;—she guessed what it must
title: Emma

text: contain, and deprecated the necessity of reading it.—She was now in
title: Emma

text: perfect charity with Frank Churchill; she wanted no explanations, she
title: Emma

text: wanted only to have her thoughts to herself—and as for understanding
title: Emma

text: any thing he wrote, she was sure she was incapable of it.—It must be
title: Emma

text: waded through, however. She opened the packet; it was too surely so;—a
title: Emma

text: note from Mrs. Weston to herself, ushered in the letter from Frank to
title: Emma

text: Mrs. Weston.
title: Emma

text: “I have the greatest pleasure, my dear Emma, in forwarding to you the
title: Emma

text: enclosed. I know what thorough justice you will do it, and have
title: Emma

text: scarcely a doubt of its happy effect.—I think we shall never materially
title: Emma

text: disagree about the writer again; but I will not delay you by a long
title: Emma

text: preface.—We are quite well.—This letter has been the cure of all the
title: Emma

text: little nervousness I have been feeling lately.—I did not quite like
title: Emma

text: your looks on Tuesday, but it was an ungenial morning; and though you
title: Emma

text: will never own being affected by weather, I think every body feels a
title: Emma

text: north-east wind.—I felt for your dear father very much in the storm of
title: Emma

text: Tuesday afternoon and yesterday morning, but had the comfort of hearing
title: Emma

text: last night, by Mr. Perry, that it had not made him ill.
title: Emma

text: “Yours ever,
title: Emma

text: [_To Mrs. Weston_.]
title: Emma

text: Windsor—July.
title: Emma

text: MY DEAR MADAM,
title: Emma

text: “If I made myself intelligible yesterday, this letter will be expected;
title: Emma

text: but expected or not, I know it will be read with candour and
title: Emma

text: indulgence.—You are all goodness, and I believe there will be need of
title: Emma

text: even all your goodness to allow for some parts of my past conduct.—But
title: Emma

text: I have been forgiven by one who had still more to resent. My courage
title: Emma

text: rises while I write. It is very difficult for the prosperous to be
title: Emma

text: humble. I have already met with such success in two applications for
title: Emma

text: pardon, that I may be in danger of thinking myself too sure of yours,
title: Emma

text: and of those among your friends who have had any ground of offence.—You
title: Emma

text: must all endeavour to comprehend the exact nature of my situation when
title: Emma

text: I first arrived at Randalls; you must consider me as having a secret
title: Emma

text: which was to be kept at all hazards. This was the fact. My right to
title: Emma

text: place myself in a situation requiring such concealment, is another
title: Emma

text: question. I shall not discuss it here. For my temptation to _think_ it
title: Emma

text: a right, I refer every caviller to a brick house, sashed windows below,
title: Emma

text: and casements above, in Highbury. I dared not address her openly; my
title: Emma

text: difficulties in the then state of Enscombe must be too well known to
title: Emma

text: require definition; and I was fortunate enough to prevail, before we
title: Emma

text: parted at Weymouth, and to induce the most upright female mind in the
title: Emma

text: creation to stoop in charity to a secret engagement.—Had she refused, I
title: Emma

text: should have gone mad.—But you will be ready to say, what was your hope
title: Emma

text: in doing this?—What did you look forward to?—To any thing, every
title: Emma

text: thing—to time, chance, circumstance, slow effects, sudden bursts,
title: Emma

text: perseverance and weariness, health and sickness. Every possibility of
title: Emma

text: good was before me, and the first of blessings secured, in obtaining
title: Emma

text: her promises of faith and correspondence. If you need farther
title: Emma

text: explanation, I have the honour, my dear madam, of being your husband’s
title: Emma

text: son, and the advantage of inheriting a disposition to hope for good,
title: Emma

text: which no inheritance of houses or lands can ever equal the value
title: Emma

text: of.—See me, then, under these circumstances, arriving on my first visit
title: Emma

text: to Randalls;—and here I am conscious of wrong, for that visit might
title: Emma

text: have been sooner paid. You will look back and see that I did not come
title: Emma

text: till Miss Fairfax was in Highbury; and as _you_ were the person
title: Emma

text: slighted, you will forgive me instantly; but I must work on my father’s
title: Emma

text: compassion, by reminding him, that so long as I absented myself from
title: Emma

text: his house, so long I lost the blessing of knowing you. My behaviour,
title: Emma

text: during the very happy fortnight which I spent with you, did not, I
title: Emma

text: hope, lay me open to reprehension, excepting on one point. And now I
title: Emma

text: come to the principal, the only important part of my conduct while
title: Emma

text: belonging to you, which excites my own anxiety, or requires very
title: Emma

text: solicitous explanation. With the greatest respect, and the warmest
title: Emma

text: friendship, do I mention Miss Woodhouse; my father perhaps will think I
title: Emma

text: ought to add, with the deepest humiliation.—A few words which dropped
title: Emma

text: from him yesterday spoke his opinion, and some censure I acknowledge
title: Emma

text: myself liable to.—My behaviour to Miss Woodhouse indicated, I believe,
title: Emma

text: more than it ought.—In order to assist a concealment so essential to
title: Emma

text: me, I was led on to make more than an allowable use of the sort of
title: Emma

text: intimacy into which we were immediately thrown.—I cannot deny that Miss
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse was my ostensible object—but I am sure you will believe the
title: Emma

text: declaration, that had I not been convinced of her indifference, I would
title: Emma

text: not have been induced by any selfish views to go on.—Amiable and
title: Emma

text: delightful as Miss Woodhouse is, she never gave me the idea of a young
title: Emma

text: woman likely to be attached; and that she was perfectly free from any
title: Emma

text: tendency to being attached to me, was as much my conviction as my
title: Emma

text: wish.—She received my attentions with an easy, friendly, goodhumoured
title: Emma

text: playfulness, which exactly suited me. We seemed to understand each
title: Emma

text: other. From our relative situation, those attentions were her due, and
title: Emma

text: were felt to be so.—Whether Miss Woodhouse began really to understand
title: Emma

text: me before the expiration of that fortnight, I cannot say;—when I called
title: Emma

text: to take leave of her, I remember that I was within a moment of
title: Emma

text: confessing the truth, and I then fancied she was not without suspicion;
title: Emma

text: but I have no doubt of her having since detected me, at least in some
title: Emma

text: degree.—She may not have surmised the whole, but her quickness must
title: Emma

text: have penetrated a part. I cannot doubt it. You will find, whenever the
title: Emma

text: subject becomes freed from its present restraints, that it did not take
title: Emma

text: her wholly by surprize. She frequently gave me hints of it. I remember
title: Emma

text: her telling me at the ball, that I owed Mrs. Elton gratitude for her
title: Emma

text: attentions to Miss Fairfax.—I hope this history of my conduct towards
title: Emma

text: her will be admitted by you and my father as great extenuation of what
title: Emma

text: you saw amiss. While you considered me as having sinned against Emma
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse, I could deserve nothing from either. Acquit me here, and
title: Emma

text: procure for me, when it is allowable, the acquittal and good wishes of
title: Emma

text: that said Emma Woodhouse, whom I regard with so much brotherly
title: Emma

text: affection, as to long to have her as deeply and as happily in love as
title: Emma

text: myself.—Whatever strange things I said or did during that fortnight,
title: Emma

text: you have now a key to. My heart was in Highbury, and my business was to
title: Emma

text: get my body thither as often as might be, and with the least suspicion.
title: Emma

text: If you remember any queernesses, set them all to the right account.—Of
title: Emma

text: the pianoforte so much talked of, I feel it only necessary to say, that
title: Emma

text: its being ordered was absolutely unknown to Miss F—, who would never
title: Emma

text: have allowed me to send it, had any choice been given her.—The delicacy
title: Emma

text: of her mind throughout the whole engagement, my dear madam, is much
title: Emma

text: beyond my power of doing justice to. You will soon, I earnestly hope,
title: Emma

text: know her thoroughly yourself.—No description can describe her. She must
title: Emma

text: tell you herself what she is—yet not by word, for never was there a
title: Emma

text: human creature who would so designedly suppress her own merit.—Since I
title: Emma

text: began this letter, which will be longer than I foresaw, I have heard
title: Emma

text: from her.—She gives a good account of her own health; but as she never
title: Emma

text: complains, I dare not depend. I want to have your opinion of her looks.
title: Emma

text: I know you will soon call on her; she is living in dread of the visit.
title: Emma

text: Perhaps it is paid already. Let me hear from you without delay; I am
title: Emma

text: impatient for a thousand particulars. Remember how few minutes I was at
title: Emma

text: Randalls, and in how bewildered, how mad a state: and I am not much
title: Emma

text: better yet; still insane either from happiness or misery. When I think
title: Emma

text: of the kindness and favour I have met with, of her excellence and
title: Emma

text: patience, and my uncle’s generosity, I am mad with joy: but when I
title: Emma

text: recollect all the uneasiness I occasioned her, and how little I deserve
title: Emma

text: to be forgiven, I am mad with anger. If I could but see her again!—But
title: Emma

text: I must not propose it yet. My uncle has been too good for me to
title: Emma

text: encroach.—I must still add to this long letter. You have not heard all
title: Emma

text: that you ought to hear. I could not give any connected detail
title: Emma

text: yesterday; but the suddenness, and, in one light, the unseasonableness
title: Emma

text: with which the affair burst out, needs explanation; for though the
title: Emma

text: event of the 26th ult., as you will conclude, immediately opened to me
title: Emma

text: the happiest prospects, I should not have presumed on such early
title: Emma

text: measures, but from the very particular circumstances, which left me not
title: Emma

text: an hour to lose. I should myself have shrunk from any thing so hasty,
title: Emma

text: and she would have felt every scruple of mine with multiplied strength
title: Emma

text: and refinement.—But I had no choice. The hasty engagement she had
title: Emma

text: entered into with that woman—Here, my dear madam, I was obliged to
title: Emma

text: leave off abruptly, to recollect and compose myself.—I have been
title: Emma

text: walking over the country, and am now, I hope, rational enough to make
title: Emma

text: the rest of my letter what it ought to be.—It is, in fact, a most
title: Emma

text: mortifying retrospect for me. I behaved shamefully. And here I can
title: Emma

text: admit, that my manners to Miss W., in being unpleasant to Miss F., were
title: Emma

text: highly blameable. _She_ disapproved them, which ought to have been
title: Emma

text: enough.—My plea of concealing the truth she did not think
title: Emma

text: sufficient.—She was displeased; I thought unreasonably so: I thought
title: Emma

text: her, on a thousand occasions, unnecessarily scrupulous and cautious: I
title: Emma

text: thought her even cold. But she was always right. If I had followed her
title: Emma

text: judgment, and subdued my spirits to the level of what she deemed
title: Emma

text: proper, I should have escaped the greatest unhappiness I have ever
title: Emma

text: known.—We quarrelled.— Do you remember the morning spent at
title: Emma

text: Donwell?—_There_ every little dissatisfaction that had occurred before
title: Emma

text: came to a crisis. I was late; I met her walking home by herself, and
title: Emma

text: wanted to walk with her, but she would not suffer it. She absolutely
title: Emma

text: refused to allow me, which I then thought most unreasonable. Now,
title: Emma

text: however, I see nothing in it but a very natural and consistent degree
title: Emma

text: of discretion. While I, to blind the world to our engagement, was
title: Emma

text: behaving one hour with objectionable particularity to another woman,
title: Emma

text: was she to be consenting the next to a proposal which might have made
title: Emma

text: every previous caution useless?—Had we been met walking together
title: Emma

text: between Donwell and Highbury, the truth must have been suspected.—I was
title: Emma

text: mad enough, however, to resent.—I doubted her affection. I doubted it
title: Emma

text: more the next day on Box Hill; when, provoked by such conduct on my
title: Emma

text: side, such shameful, insolent neglect of her, and such apparent
title: Emma

text: devotion to Miss W., as it would have been impossible for any woman of
title: Emma

text: sense to endure, she spoke her resentment in a form of words perfectly
title: Emma

text: intelligible to me.—In short, my dear madam, it was a quarrel blameless
title: Emma

text: on her side, abominable on mine; and I returned the same evening to
title: Emma

text: Richmond, though I might have staid with you till the next morning,
title: Emma

text: merely because I would be as angry with her as possible. Even then, I
title: Emma

text: was not such a fool as not to mean to be reconciled in time; but I was
title: Emma

text: the injured person, injured by her coldness, and I went away determined
title: Emma

text: that she should make the first advances.—I shall always congratulate
title: Emma

text: myself that you were not of the Box Hill party. Had you witnessed my
title: Emma

text: behaviour there, I can hardly suppose you would ever have thought well
title: Emma

text: of me again. Its effect upon her appears in the immediate resolution it
title: Emma

text: produced: as soon as she found I was really gone from Randalls, she
title: Emma

text: closed with the offer of that officious Mrs. Elton; the whole system of
title: Emma

text: whose treatment of her, by the bye, has ever filled me with indignation
title: Emma

text: and hatred. I must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has
title: Emma

text: been so richly extended towards myself; but, otherwise, I should loudly
title: Emma

text: protest against the share of it which that woman has known.—‘Jane,’
title: Emma

text: indeed!—You will observe that I have not yet indulged myself in calling
title: Emma

text: her by that name, even to you. Think, then, what I must have endured in
title: Emma

text: hearing it bandied between the Eltons with all the vulgarity of
title: Emma

text: needless repetition, and all the insolence of imaginary superiority.
title: Emma

text: Have patience with me, I shall soon have done.—She closed with this
title: Emma

text: offer, resolving to break with me entirely, and wrote the next day to
title: Emma

text: tell me that we never were to meet again.—_She_ _felt_ _the_
title: Emma

text: _engagement_ _to_ _be_ _a_ _source_ _of_ _repentance_ _and_ _misery_
title: Emma

text: _to_ _each_: _she_ _dissolved_ _it_.—This letter reached me on the very
title: Emma

text: morning of my poor aunt’s death. I answered it within an hour; but from
title: Emma

text: the confusion of my mind, and the multiplicity of business falling on
title: Emma

text: me at once, my answer, instead of being sent with all the many other
title: Emma

text: letters of that day, was locked up in my writing-desk; and I, trusting
title: Emma

text: that I had written enough, though but a few lines, to satisfy her,
title: Emma

text: remained without any uneasiness.—I was rather disappointed that I did
title: Emma

text: not hear from her again speedily; but I made excuses for her, and was
title: Emma

text: too busy, and—may I add?—too cheerful in my views to be captious.—We
title: Emma

text: removed to Windsor; and two days afterwards I received a parcel from
title: Emma

text: her, my own letters all returned!—and a few lines at the same time by
title: Emma

text: the post, stating her extreme surprize at not having had the smallest
title: Emma

text: reply to her last; and adding, that as silence on such a point could
title: Emma

text: not be misconstrued, and as it must be equally desirable to both to
title: Emma

text: have every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible, she
title: Emma

text: now sent me, by a safe conveyance, all my letters, and requested, that
title: Emma

text: if I could not directly command hers, so as to send them to Highbury
title: Emma

text: within a week, I would forward them after that period to her at—: in
title: Emma

text: short, the full direction to Mr. Smallridge’s, near Bristol, stared me
title: Emma

text: in the face. I knew the name, the place, I knew all about it, and
title: Emma

text: instantly saw what she had been doing. It was perfectly accordant with
title: Emma

text: that resolution of character which I knew her to possess; and the
title: Emma

text: secrecy she had maintained, as to any such design in her former letter,
title: Emma

text: was equally descriptive of its anxious delicacy. For the world would
title: Emma

text: not she have seemed to threaten me.—Imagine the shock; imagine how,
title: Emma

text: till I had actually detected my own blunder, I raved at the blunders of
title: Emma

text: the post.—What was to be done?—One thing only.—I must speak to my
title: Emma

text: uncle. Without his sanction I could not hope to be listened to again.—I
title: Emma

text: spoke; circumstances were in my favour; the late event had softened
title: Emma

text: away his pride, and he was, earlier than I could have anticipated,
title: Emma

text: wholly reconciled and complying; and could say at last, poor man! with
title: Emma

text: a deep sigh, that he wished I might find as much happiness in the
title: Emma

text: marriage state as he had done.—I felt that it would be of a different
title: Emma

text: sort.—Are you disposed to pity me for what I must have suffered in
title: Emma

text: opening the cause to him, for my suspense while all was at stake?—No;
title: Emma

text: do not pity me till I reached Highbury, and saw how ill I had made her.
title: Emma

text: Do not pity me till I saw her wan, sick looks.—I reached Highbury at
title: Emma

text: the time of day when, from my knowledge of their late breakfast hour, I
title: Emma

text: was certain of a good chance of finding her alone.—I was not
title: Emma

text: disappointed; and at last I was not disappointed either in the object
title: Emma

text: of my journey. A great deal of very reasonable, very just displeasure I
title: Emma

text: had to persuade away. But it is done; we are reconciled, dearer, much
title: Emma

text: dearer, than ever, and no moment’s uneasiness can ever occur between us
title: Emma

text: again. Now, my dear madam, I will release you; but I could not conclude
title: Emma

text: before. A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness you have
title: Emma

text: ever shewn me, and ten thousand for the attentions your heart will
title: Emma

text: dictate towards her.—If you think me in a way to be happier than I
title: Emma

text: deserve, I am quite of your opinion.—Miss W. calls me the child of good
title: Emma

text: fortune. I hope she is right.—In one respect, my good fortune is
title: Emma

text: undoubted, that of being able to subscribe myself,
title: Emma

text: Your obliged and affectionate Son,
title: Emma

text: F. C. WESTON CHURCHILL.
title: Emma

text: CHAPTER XV
title: Emma

text: This letter must make its way to Emma’s feelings. She was obliged, in
title: Emma

text: spite of her previous determination to the contrary, to do it all the
title: Emma

text: justice that Mrs. Weston foretold. As soon as she came to her own name,
title: Emma

text: it was irresistible; every line relating to herself was interesting,
title: Emma

text: and almost every line agreeable; and when this charm ceased, the
title: Emma

text: subject could still maintain itself, by the natural return of her
title: Emma

text: former regard for the writer, and the very strong attraction which any
title: Emma

text: picture of love must have for her at that moment. She never stopt till
title: Emma

text: she had gone through the whole; and though it was impossible not to
title: Emma

text: feel that he had been wrong, yet he had been less wrong than she had
title: Emma

text: supposed—and he had suffered, and was very sorry—and he was so grateful
title: Emma

text: to Mrs. Weston, and so much in love with Miss Fairfax, and she was so
title: Emma

text: happy herself, that there was no being severe; and could he have
title: Emma

text: entered the room, she must have shaken hands with him as heartily as
title: Emma

text: ever.
title: Emma

text: She thought so well of the letter, that when Mr. Knightley came again,
title: Emma

text: she desired him to read it. She was sure of Mrs. Weston’s wishing it to
title: Emma

text: be communicated; especially to one, who, like Mr. Knightley, had seen
title: Emma

text: so much to blame in his conduct.
title: Emma

text: “I shall be very glad to look it over,” said he; “but it seems long. I
title: Emma

text: will take it home with me at night.”
title: Emma

text: But that would not do. Mr. Weston was to call in the evening, and she
title: Emma

text: must return it by him.
title: Emma

text: “I would rather be talking to you,” he replied; “but as it seems a
title: Emma

text: matter of justice, it shall be done.”
title: Emma

text: He began—stopping, however, almost directly to say, “Had I been offered
title: Emma

text: the sight of one of this gentleman’s letters to his mother-in-law a few
title: Emma

text: months ago, Emma, it would not have been taken with such indifference.”
title: Emma

text: He proceeded a little farther, reading to himself; and then, with a
title: Emma

text: smile, observed, “Humph! a fine complimentary opening: But it is his
title: Emma

text: way. One man’s style must not be the rule of another’s. We will not be
title: Emma

text: severe.”
title: Emma

text: “It will be natural for me,” he added shortly afterwards, “to speak my
title: Emma

text: opinion aloud as I read. By doing it, I shall feel that I am near you.
title: Emma

text: It will not be so great a loss of time: but if you dislike it—”
title: Emma

text: “Not at all. I should wish it.”
title: Emma

text: Mr. Knightley returned to his reading with greater alacrity.
title: Emma

text: “He trifles here,” said he, “as to the temptation. He knows he is
title: Emma

text: wrong, and has nothing rational to urge.—Bad.—He ought not to have
title: Emma

text: formed the engagement.—‘His father’s disposition:’—he is unjust,
title: Emma

text: however, to his father. Mr. Weston’s sanguine temper was a blessing on
title: Emma

text: all his upright and honourable exertions; but Mr. Weston earned every
title: Emma

text: present comfort before he endeavoured to gain it.—Very true; he did not
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: “Do you?—I have no doubt. Nature gave you understanding:—Miss Taylor
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: thirteen.”

text: point. He told her the news. Was not she like a daughter, his eldest
title: Emma

text: daughter?—he must tell her; and Miss Bates being present, it passed, of
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: afterwards. It was no more than the principals were prepared for; they
title: Emma

text: had calculated from the time of its being known at Randalls, how soon
title: Emma

text: it would be over Highbury; and were thinking of themselves, as the
title: Emma

text: evening wonder in many a family circle, with great sagacity.
title: Emma

text: In general, it was a very well approved match. Some might think him,
title: Emma

text: and others might think her, the most in luck. One set might recommend
title: Emma

text: their all removing to Donwell, and leaving Hartfield for the John
title: Emma

text: Knightleys; and another might predict disagreements among their
title: Emma

text: servants; but yet, upon the whole, there was no serious objection
title: Emma

text: raised, except in one habitation, the Vicarage.—There, the surprize was
title: Emma

text: not softened by any satisfaction. Mr. Elton cared little about it,
title: Emma

text: compared with his wife; he only hoped “the young lady’s pride would now
title: Emma

text: be contented;” and supposed “she had always meant to catch Knightley if
title: Emma

text: she could;” and, on the point of living at Hartfield, could daringly
title: Emma

text: exclaim, “Rather he than I!”—But Mrs. Elton was very much discomposed
title: Emma

text: indeed.—“Poor Knightley! poor fellow!—sad business for him.”—She was
title: Emma

text: extremely concerned; for, though very eccentric, he had a thousand good
title: Emma

text: qualities.—How could he be so taken in?—Did not think him at all in
title: Emma

text: love—not in the least.—Poor Knightley!—There would be an end of all
title: Emma

text: pleasant intercourse with him.—How happy he had been to come and dine
title: Emma

text: with them whenever they asked him! But that would be all over now.—Poor
title: Emma

text: fellow!—No more exploring parties to Donwell made for _her_. Oh! no;
title: Emma

text: there would be a Mrs. Knightley to throw cold water on every
title: Emma

text: thing.—Extremely disagreeable! But she was not at all sorry that she
title: Emma

text: had abused the housekeeper the other day.—Shocking plan, living
title: Emma

text: together. It would never do. She knew a family near Maple Grove who had
title: Emma

text: tried it, and been obliged to separate before the end of the first
title: Emma

text: quarter.

text: CHAPTER XVIII
title: Emma

text: Time passed on. A few more to-morrows, and the party from London would
title: Emma

text: be arriving. It was an alarming change; and Emma was thinking of it one
title: Emma

text: morning, as what must bring a great deal to agitate and grieve her,
title: Emma

text: when Mr. Knightley came in, and distressing thoughts were put by. After
title: Emma

text: the first chat of pleasure he was silent; and then, in a graver tone,
title: Emma

text: began with,
title: Emma

text: “I have something to tell you, Emma; some news.”
title: Emma

text: “Good or bad?” said she, quickly, looking up in his face.
title: Emma

text: “I do not know which it ought to be called.”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! good I am sure.—I see it in your countenance. You are trying not
title: Emma

text: to smile.”
title: Emma

text: “I am afraid,” said he, composing his features, “I am very much afraid,
title: Emma

text: my dear Emma, that you will not smile when you hear it.”
title: Emma

text: “Indeed! but why so?—I can hardly imagine that any thing which pleases
title: Emma

text: or amuses you, should not please and amuse me too.”
title: Emma

text: “There is one subject,” he replied, “I hope but one, on which we do not
title: Emma

text: think alike.” He paused a moment, again smiling, with his eyes fixed on
title: Emma

text: her face. “Does nothing occur to you?—Do not you recollect?—Harriet
title: Emma

text: Smith.”
title: Emma

text: Her cheeks flushed at the name, and she felt afraid of something,
title: Emma

text: though she knew not what.
title: Emma

text: “Have you heard from her yourself this morning?” cried he. “You have, I
title: Emma

text: believe, and know the whole.”
title: Emma

text: “No, I have not; I know nothing; pray tell me.”
title: Emma

text: “You are prepared for the worst, I see—and very bad it is. Harriet
title: Emma

text: Smith marries Robert Martin.”
title: Emma

text: Emma gave a start, which did not seem like being prepared—and her eyes,
title: Emma

text: in eager gaze, said, “No, this is impossible!” but her lips were
title: Emma

text: closed.
title: Emma

text: “It is so, indeed,” continued Mr. Knightley; “I have it from Robert
title: Emma

text: Martin himself. He left me not half an hour ago.”
title: Emma

text: She was still looking at him with the most speaking amazement.
title: Emma

text: “You like it, my Emma, as little as I feared.—I wish our opinions were
title: Emma

text: the same. But in time they will. Time, you may be sure, will make one
title: Emma

text: or the other of us think differently; and, in the meanwhile, we need
title: Emma

text: not talk much on the subject.”
title: Emma

text: “You mistake me, you quite mistake me,” she replied, exerting herself.
title: Emma

text: “It is not that such a circumstance would now make me unhappy, but I
title: Emma

text: cannot believe it. It seems an impossibility!—You cannot mean to say,
title: Emma

text: that Harriet Smith has accepted Robert Martin. You cannot mean that he
title: Emma

text: has even proposed to her again—yet. You only mean, that he intends it.”
title: Emma

text: “I mean that he has done it,” answered Mr. Knightley, with smiling but
title: Emma

text: determined decision, “and been accepted.”
title: Emma

text: “Good God!” she cried.—“Well!”—Then having recourse to her workbasket,
title: Emma

text: in excuse for leaning down her face, and concealing all the exquisite
title: Emma

text: feelings of delight and entertainment which she knew she must be
title: Emma

text: expressing, she added, “Well, now tell me every thing; make this
title: Emma

text: intelligible to me. How, where, when?—Let me know it all. I never was
title: Emma

text: more surprized—but it does not make me unhappy, I assure you.—How—how
title: Emma

text: has it been possible?”
title: Emma

text: “It is a very simple story. He went to town on business three days ago,
title: Emma

text: and I got him to take charge of some papers which I was wanting to send
title: Emma

text: to John.—He delivered these papers to John, at his chambers, and was
title: Emma

text: asked by him to join their party the same evening to Astley’s. They
title: Emma

text: were going to take the two eldest boys to Astley’s. The party was to be
title: Emma

text: our brother and sister, Henry, John—and Miss Smith. My friend Robert
title: Emma

text: could not resist. They called for him in their way; were all extremely
title: Emma

text: amused; and my brother asked him to dine with them the next day—which
title: Emma

text: he did—and in the course of that visit (as I understand) he found an
title: Emma

text: opportunity of speaking to Harriet; and certainly did not speak in
title: Emma

text: vain.—She made him, by her acceptance, as happy even as he is
title: Emma

text: deserving. He came down by yesterday’s coach, and was with me this
title: Emma

text: morning immediately after breakfast, to report his proceedings, first
title: Emma

text: on my affairs, and then on his own. This is all that I can relate of
title: Emma

text: the how, where, and when. Your friend Harriet will make a much longer
title: Emma

text: history when you see her.—She will give you all the minute particulars,
title: Emma

text: which only woman’s language can make interesting.—In our communications
title: Emma

text: we deal only in the great.—However, I must say, that Robert Martin’s
title: Emma

text: heart seemed for _him_, and to _me_, very overflowing; and that he did
title: Emma

text: mention, without its being much to the purpose, that on quitting their
title: Emma

text: box at Astley’s, my brother took charge of Mrs. John Knightley and
title: Emma

text: little John, and he followed with Miss Smith and Henry; and that at one
title: Emma

text: time they were in such a crowd, as to make Miss Smith rather uneasy.”
title: Emma

text: He stopped.—Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply. To speak, she
title: Emma

text: was sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree of happiness.
title: Emma

text: She must wait a moment, or he would think her mad. Her silence
title: Emma

text: disturbed him; and after observing her a little while, he added,
title: Emma

text: “Emma, my love, you said that this circumstance would not now make you
title: Emma

text: unhappy; but I am afraid it gives you more pain than you expected. His
title: Emma

text: situation is an evil—but you must consider it as what satisfies your
title: Emma

text: friend; and I will answer for your thinking better and better of him as
title: Emma

text: you know him more. His good sense and good principles would delight
title: Emma

text: you.—As far as the man is concerned, you could not wish your friend in
title: Emma

text: better hands. His rank in society I would alter if I could, which is
title: Emma

text: saying a great deal I assure you, Emma.—You laugh at me about William
title: Emma

text: Larkins; but I could quite as ill spare Robert Martin.”
title: Emma

text: He wanted her to look up and smile; and having now brought herself not
title: Emma

text: to smile too broadly—she did—cheerfully answering,
title: Emma

text: “You need not be at any pains to reconcile me to the match. I think
title: Emma

text: Harriet is doing extremely well. _Her_ connexions may be worse than
title: Emma

text: _his_. In respectability of character, there can be no doubt that they
title: Emma

text: are. I have been silent from surprize merely, excessive surprize. You
title: Emma

text: cannot imagine how suddenly it has come on me! how peculiarly
title: Emma

text: unprepared I was!—for I had reason to believe her very lately more
title: Emma

text: determined against him, much more, than she was before.”
title: Emma

text: “You ought to know your friend best,” replied Mr. Knightley; “but I
title: Emma

text: should say she was a good-tempered, soft-hearted girl, not likely to be
title: Emma

text: very, very determined against any young man who told her he loved her.”
title: Emma

text: Emma could not help laughing as she answered, “Upon my word, I believe
title: Emma

text: you know her quite as well as I do.—But, Mr. Knightley, are you
title: Emma

text: perfectly sure that she has absolutely and downright _accepted_ him. I
title: Emma

text: could suppose she might in time—but can she already?—Did not you
title: Emma

text: misunderstand him?—You were both talking of other things; of business,
title: Emma

text: shows of cattle, or new drills—and might not you, in the confusion of
title: Emma

text: so many subjects, mistake him?—It was not Harriet’s hand that he was
title: Emma

text: certain of—it was the dimensions of some famous ox.”
title: Emma

text: The contrast between the countenance and air of Mr. Knightley and
title: Emma

text: Robert Martin was, at this moment, so strong to Emma’s feelings, and so
title: Emma

text: strong was the recollection of all that had so recently passed on
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s side, so fresh the sound of those words, spoken with such
title: Emma

text: emphasis, “No, I hope I know better than to think of Robert Martin,”
title: Emma

text: that she was really expecting the intelligence to prove, in some
title: Emma

text: measure, premature. It could not be otherwise.
title: Emma

text: “Do you dare say this?” cried Mr. Knightley. “Do you dare to suppose me
title: Emma

text: so great a blockhead, as not to know what a man is talking of?—What do
title: Emma

text: you deserve?”
title: Emma

text: “Oh! I always deserve the best treatment, because I never put up with
title: Emma

text: any other; and, therefore, you must give me a plain, direct answer. Are
title: Emma

text: you quite sure that you understand the terms on which Mr. Martin and
title: Emma

text: Harriet now are?”
title: Emma

text: “I am quite sure,” he replied, speaking very distinctly, “that he told
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: doubtful, in the words he used; and I think I can give you a proof that
title: Emma

text: it must be so. He asked my opinion as to what he was now to do. He knew
title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: done, than to go to Mrs. Goddard? I assured him that I could not. Then,
title: Emma

text: he said, he would endeavour to see her in the course of this day.”
title: Emma

text: “I am perfectly satisfied,” replied Emma, with the brightest smiles,
title: Emma

text: “and most sincerely wish them happy.”
title: Emma

text: “You are materially changed since we talked on this subject before.”
title: Emma

text: “I hope so—for at that time I was a fool.”
title: Emma

text: “And I am changed also; for I am now very willing to grant you all
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s good qualities. I have taken some pains for your sake, and
title: Emma

text: for Robert Martin’s sake, (whom I have always had reason to believe as
title: Emma

text: much in love with her as ever,) to get acquainted with her. I have
title: Emma

text: often talked to her a good deal. You must have seen that I did.
title: Emma

text: Sometimes, indeed, I have thought you were half suspecting me of
title: Emma

text: pleading poor Martin’s cause, which was never the case; but, from all
title: Emma

text: my observations, I am convinced of her being an artless, amiable girl,
title: Emma

text: with very good notions, very seriously good principles, and placing her
title: Emma

text: happiness in the affections and utility of domestic life.—Much of this,
title: Emma

text: I have no doubt, she may thank you for.”
title: Emma

text: “Me!” cried Emma, shaking her head.—“Ah! poor Harriet!”

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: she could be fit for nothing rational.

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

text: imagined. The sole grievance and alloy thus removed in the prospect of
title: Emma

text: Harriet’s welfare, she was really in danger of becoming too happy for
title: Emma

text: security.—What had she to wish for? Nothing, but to grow more worthy of
title: Emma

text: him, whose intentions and judgment had been ever so superior to her
title: Emma

text: own. Nothing, but that the lessons of her past folly might teach her
title: Emma

text: humility and circumspection in future.
title: Emma

text: Serious she was, very serious in her thankfulness, and in her
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: very midst of them. She must laugh at such a close! Such an end of the
title: Emma

text: doleful disappointment of five weeks back! Such a heart—such a Harriet!
title: Emma

text: Now there would be pleasure in her returning—Every thing would be a
title: Emma

text: pleasure. It would be a great pleasure to know Robert Martin.
title: Emma

text: High in the rank of her most serious and heartfelt felicities, was the
title: Emma

title: Emma

text: soon be over. The disguise, equivocation, mystery, so hateful to her to
title: Emma

text: practise, might soon be over. She could now look forward to giving him
title: Emma

text: that full and perfect confidence which her disposition was most ready
title: Emma

text: to welcome as a duty.

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma

title: Emma
