text: CHAPTER XIX
title: Emma

text: If Emma had still, at intervals, an anxious feeling for Harriet, a
title: Emma

text: momentary doubt of its being possible for her to be really cured of her
title: Emma

text: attachment to Mr. Knightley, and really able to accept another man from
title: Emma

text: unbiased inclination, it was not long that she had to suffer from the
title: Emma

text: recurrence of any such uncertainty. A very few days brought the party
title: Emma

text: from London, and she had no sooner an opportunity of being one hour
title: Emma

text: alone with Harriet, than she became perfectly satisfied—unaccountable
title: Emma

text: as it was!—that Robert Martin had thoroughly supplanted Mr. Knightley,
title: Emma

text: and was now forming all her views of happiness.
title: Emma

text: Harriet was a little distressed—did look a little foolish at first: but
title: Emma

text: having once owned that she had been presumptuous and silly, and
title: Emma

text: self-deceived, before, her pain and confusion seemed to die away with
title: Emma

text: the words, and leave her without a care for the past, and with the
title: Emma

text: fullest exultation in the present and future; for, as to her friend’s
title: Emma

text: approbation, Emma had instantly removed every fear of that nature, by
title: Emma

text: meeting her with the most unqualified congratulations.—Harriet was most
title: Emma

text: happy to give every particular of the evening at Astley’s, and the
title: Emma

text: dinner the next day; she could dwell on it all with the utmost delight.
title: Emma

text: But what did such particulars explain?—The fact was, as Emma could now
title: Emma

text: acknowledge, that Harriet had always liked Robert Martin; and that his
title: Emma

text: continuing to love her had been irresistible.—Beyond this, it must ever
title: Emma

text: be unintelligible to Emma.
title: Emma

text: The event, however, was most joyful; and every day was giving her fresh
title: Emma

text: reason for thinking so.—Harriet’s parentage became known. She proved to
title: Emma

text: be the daughter of a tradesman, rich enough to afford her the
title: Emma

text: comfortable maintenance which had ever been hers, and decent enough to
title: Emma

text: have always wished for concealment.—Such was the blood of gentility
title: Emma

text: which Emma had formerly been so ready to vouch for!—It was likely to be
title: Emma

text: as untainted, perhaps, as the blood of many a gentleman: but what a
title: Emma

text: connexion had she been preparing for Mr. Knightley—or for the
title: Emma

text: Churchills—or even for Mr. Elton!—The stain of illegitimacy, unbleached
title: Emma

text: by nobility or wealth, would have been a stain indeed.
title: Emma

text: No objection was raised on the father’s side; the young man was treated
title: Emma

text: liberally; it was all as it should be: and as Emma became acquainted
title: Emma

text: with Robert Martin, who was now introduced at Hartfield, she fully
title: Emma

text: acknowledged in him all the appearance of sense and worth which could
title: Emma

text: bid fairest for her little friend. She had no doubt of Harriet’s
title: Emma

text: happiness with any good-tempered man; but with him, and in the home he
title: Emma

text: offered, there would be the hope of more, of security, stability, and
title: Emma

text: improvement. She would be placed in the midst of those who loved her,
title: Emma

text: and who had better sense than herself; retired enough for safety, and
title: Emma

text: occupied enough for cheerfulness. She would be never led into
title: Emma

text: temptation, nor left for it to find her out. She would be respectable
title: Emma

text: and happy; and Emma admitted her to be the luckiest creature in the
title: Emma

text: world, to have created so steady and persevering an affection in such a
title: Emma

text: man;—or, if not quite the luckiest, to yield only to herself.
title: Emma

text: Harriet, necessarily drawn away by her engagements with the Martins,
title: Emma

text: was less and less at Hartfield; which was not to be regretted.—The
title: Emma

text: intimacy between her and Emma must sink; their friendship must change
title: Emma

text: into a calmer sort of goodwill; and, fortunately, what ought to be, and
title: Emma

text: must be, seemed already beginning, and in the most gradual, natural
title: Emma

text: manner.
title: Emma

text: Before the end of September, Emma attended Harriet to church, and saw
title: Emma

text: her hand bestowed on Robert Martin with so complete a satisfaction, as
title: Emma

text: no remembrances, even connected with Mr. Elton as he stood before them,
title: Emma

text: could impair.—Perhaps, indeed, at that time she scarcely saw Mr. Elton,
title: Emma

text: but as the clergyman whose blessing at the altar might next fall on
title: Emma

text: herself.—Robert Martin and Harriet Smith, the latest couple engaged of
title: Emma

text: the three, were the first to be married.
title: Emma

text: Jane Fairfax had already quitted Highbury, and was restored to the
title: Emma

text: comforts of her beloved home with the Campbells.—The Mr. Churchills
title: Emma

text: were also in town; and they were only waiting for November.
title: Emma

text: The intermediate month was the one fixed on, as far as they dared, by
title: Emma

text: Emma and Mr. Knightley.—They had determined that their marriage ought
title: Emma

text: to be concluded while John and Isabella were still at Hartfield, to
title: Emma

text: allow them the fortnight’s absence in a tour to the seaside, which was
title: Emma

text: the plan.—John and Isabella, and every other friend, were agreed in
title: Emma

text: approving it. But Mr. Woodhouse—how was Mr. Woodhouse to be induced to
title: Emma

text: consent?—he, who had never yet alluded to their marriage but as a
title: Emma

text: distant event.
title: Emma

text: When first sounded on the subject, he was so miserable, that they were
title: Emma

text: almost hopeless.—A second allusion, indeed, gave less pain.—He began to
title: Emma

text: think it was to be, and that he could not prevent it—a very promising
title: Emma

text: step of the mind on its way to resignation. Still, however, he was not
title: Emma

text: happy. Nay, he appeared so much otherwise, that his daughter’s courage
title: Emma

text: failed. She could not bear to see him suffering, to know him fancying
title: Emma

text: himself neglected; and though her understanding almost acquiesced in
title: Emma

text: the assurance of both the Mr. Knightleys, that when once the event were
title: Emma

text: over, his distress would be soon over too, she hesitated—she could not
title: Emma

text: proceed.
title: Emma

text: In this state of suspense they were befriended, not by any sudden
title: Emma

text: illumination of Mr. Woodhouse’s mind, or any wonderful change of his
title: Emma

text: nervous system, but by the operation of the same system in another
title: Emma

text: way.—Mrs. Weston’s poultry-house was robbed one night of all her
title: Emma

text: turkeys—evidently by the ingenuity of man. Other poultry-yards in the
title: Emma

text: neighbourhood also suffered.—Pilfering was _housebreaking_ to Mr.
title: Emma

text: Woodhouse’s fears.—He was very uneasy; and but for the sense of his
title: Emma

text: son-in-law’s protection, would have been under wretched alarm every
title: Emma

text: night of his life. The strength, resolution, and presence of mind of
title: Emma

text: the Mr. Knightleys, commanded his fullest dependence. While either of
title: Emma

text: them protected him and his, Hartfield was safe.—But Mr. John Knightley
title: Emma

text: must be in London again by the end of the first week in November.
title: Emma

text: The result of this distress was, that, with a much more voluntary,
title: Emma

text: cheerful consent than his daughter had ever presumed to hope for at the
title: Emma

text: moment, she was able to fix her wedding-day—and Mr. Elton was called
title: Emma

text: on, within a month from the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Martin, to
title: Emma

text: join the hands of Mr. Knightley and Miss Woodhouse.
title: Emma

text: The wedding was very much like other weddings, where the parties have
title: Emma

text: no taste for finery or parade; and Mrs. Elton, from the particulars
title: Emma

text: detailed by her husband, thought it all extremely shabby, and very
title: Emma

text: inferior to her own.—“Very little white satin, very few lace veils; a
title: Emma

text: most pitiful business!—Selina would stare when she heard of it.”—But,
title: Emma

text: in spite of these deficiencies, the wishes, the hopes, the confidence,
title: Emma

text: the predictions of the small band of true friends who witnessed the
title: Emma

text: ceremony, were fully answered in the perfect happiness of the union.
title: Emma

title: Pride and prejudice

title: Pride and prejudice

title: Pride and prejudice

title: Pride and prejudice

title: Metamorphosis

text: I
title: Metamorphosis

text: One morning, when Gregor Samsa woke from troubled dreams, he found
title: Metamorphosis

text: himself transformed in his bed into a horrible vermin. He lay on his
title: Metamorphosis

text: armour-like back, and if he lifted his head a little he could see his
title: Metamorphosis

text: brown belly, slightly domed and divided by arches into stiff sections.
title: Metamorphosis

text: The bedding was hardly able to cover it and seemed ready to slide off
title: Metamorphosis

text: any moment. His many legs, pitifully thin compared with the size of the
title: Metamorphosis

text: rest of him, waved about helplessly as he looked.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “What’s happened to me?” he thought. It wasn’t a dream. His room, a
title: Metamorphosis

text: proper human room although a little too small, lay peacefully between
title: Metamorphosis

text: its four familiar walls. A collection of textile samples lay spread out
title: Metamorphosis

text: on the table—Samsa was a travelling salesman—and above it there hung a
title: Metamorphosis

text: picture that he had recently cut out of an illustrated magazine and
title: Metamorphosis

text: housed in a nice, gilded frame. It showed a lady fitted out with a fur
title: Metamorphosis

text: hat and fur boa who sat upright, raising a heavy fur muff that covered
title: Metamorphosis

text: the whole of her lower arm towards the viewer.
title: Metamorphosis

text: Gregor then turned to look out the window at the dull weather. Drops of
title: Metamorphosis

text: rain could be heard hitting the pane, which made him feel quite sad.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “How about if I sleep a little bit longer and forget all this
title: Metamorphosis

text: nonsense”, he thought, but that was something he was unable to do
title: Metamorphosis

text: because he was used to sleeping on his right, and in his present state
title: Metamorphosis

text: couldn’t get into that position. However hard he threw himself onto his
title: Metamorphosis

text: right, he always rolled back to where he was. He must have tried it a
title: Metamorphosis

text: hundred times, shut his eyes so that he wouldn’t have to look at the
title: Metamorphosis

text: floundering legs, and only stopped when he began to feel a mild, dull
title: Metamorphosis

text: pain there that he had never felt before.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “Oh, God”, he thought, “what a strenuous career it is that I’ve chosen!
title: Metamorphosis

text: Travelling day in and day out. Doing business like this takes much more
title: Metamorphosis

text: effort than doing your own business at home, and on top of that there’s
title: Metamorphosis

text: the curse of travelling, worries about making train connections, bad
title: Metamorphosis

text: and irregular food, contact with different people all the time so that
title: Metamorphosis

text: you can never get to know anyone or become friendly with them. It can
title: Metamorphosis

text: all go to Hell!” He felt a slight itch up on his belly; pushed himself
title: Metamorphosis

text: slowly up on his back towards the headboard so that he could lift his
title: Metamorphosis

text: head better; found where the itch was, and saw that it was covered with
title: Metamorphosis

text: lots of little white spots which he didn’t know what to make of; and
title: Metamorphosis

text: when he tried to feel the place with one of his legs he drew it quickly
title: Metamorphosis

text: back because as soon as he touched it he was overcome by a cold
title: Metamorphosis

text: shudder.
title: Metamorphosis

text: He slid back into his former position. “Getting up early all the time”,
title: Metamorphosis

text: he thought, “it makes you stupid. You’ve got to get enough sleep. Other
title: Metamorphosis

text: travelling salesmen live a life of luxury. For instance, whenever I go
title: Metamorphosis

text: back to the guest house during the morning to copy out the contract,
title: Metamorphosis

text: these gentlemen are always still sitting there eating their breakfasts.
title: Metamorphosis

text: I ought to just try that with my boss; I’d get kicked out on the spot.
title: Metamorphosis

text: But who knows, maybe that would be the best thing for me. If I didn’t
title: Metamorphosis

text: have my parents to think about I’d have given in my notice a long time
title: Metamorphosis

text: ago, I’d have gone up to the boss and told him just what I think, tell
title: Metamorphosis

text: him everything I would, let him know just what I feel. He’d fall right
title: Metamorphosis

text: off his desk! And it’s a funny sort of business to be sitting up there
title: Metamorphosis

text: at your desk, talking down at your subordinates from up there,
title: Metamorphosis

text: especially when you have to go right up close because the boss is hard
title: Metamorphosis

text: of hearing. Well, there’s still some hope; once I’ve got the money
title: Metamorphosis

text: together to pay off my parents’ debt to him—another five or six years I
title: Metamorphosis

text: suppose—that’s definitely what I’ll do. That’s when I’ll make the big
title: Metamorphosis

text: change. First of all though, I’ve got to get up, my train leaves at
title: Metamorphosis

text: five.”
title: Metamorphosis

text: And he looked over at the alarm clock, ticking on the chest of drawers.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “God in Heaven!” he thought. It was half past six and the hands were
title: Metamorphosis

text: quietly moving forwards, it was even later than half past, more like
title: Metamorphosis

text: quarter to seven. Had the alarm clock not rung? He could see from the
title: Metamorphosis

text: bed that it had been set for four o’clock as it should have been; it
title: Metamorphosis

text: certainly must have rung. Yes, but was it possible to quietly sleep
title: Metamorphosis

text: through that furniture-rattling noise? True, he had not slept
title: Metamorphosis

text: peacefully, but probably all the more deeply because of that. What
title: Metamorphosis

text: should he do now? The next train went at seven; if he were to catch
title: Metamorphosis

text: that he would have to rush like mad and the collection of samples was
title: Metamorphosis

text: still not packed, and he did not at all feel particularly fresh and
title: Metamorphosis

text: lively. And even if he did catch the train he would not avoid his
title: Metamorphosis

text: boss’s anger as the office assistant would have been there to see the
title: Metamorphosis

text: five o’clock train go, he would have put in his report about Gregor’s
title: Metamorphosis

text: not being there a long time ago. The office assistant was the boss’s
title: Metamorphosis

text: man, spineless, and with no understanding. What about if he reported
title: Metamorphosis

text: sick? But that would be extremely strained and suspicious as in five
title: Metamorphosis

text: years of service Gregor had never once yet been ill. His boss would
title: Metamorphosis

text: certainly come round with the doctor from the medical insurance
title: Metamorphosis

text: company, accuse his parents of having a lazy son, and accept the
title: Metamorphosis

text: doctor’s recommendation not to make any claim as the doctor believed
title: Metamorphosis

text: that no-one was ever ill but that many were workshy. And what’s more,
title: Metamorphosis

text: would he have been entirely wrong in this case? Gregor did in fact,
title: Metamorphosis

text: apart from excessive sleepiness after sleeping for so long, feel
title: Metamorphosis

text: completely well and even felt much hungrier than usual.
title: Metamorphosis

text: He was still hurriedly thinking all this through, unable to decide to
title: Metamorphosis

text: get out of the bed, when the clock struck quarter to seven. There was a
title: Metamorphosis

text: cautious knock at the door near his head. “Gregor”, somebody called—it
title: Metamorphosis

text: was his mother—“it’s quarter to seven. Didn’t you want to go
title: Metamorphosis

text: somewhere?” That gentle voice! Gregor was shocked when he heard his own
title: Metamorphosis

text: voice answering, it could hardly be recognised as the voice he had had
title: Metamorphosis

text: before. As if from deep inside him, there was a painful and
title: Metamorphosis

text: uncontrollable squeaking mixed in with it, the words could be made out
title: Metamorphosis

text: at first but then there was a sort of echo which made them unclear,
title: Metamorphosis

text: leaving the hearer unsure whether he had heard properly or not. Gregor
title: Metamorphosis

text: had wanted to give a full answer and explain everything, but in the
title: Metamorphosis

text: circumstances contented himself with saying: “Yes, mother, yes,
title: Metamorphosis

text: thank-you, I’m getting up now.” The change in Gregor’s voice probably
title: Metamorphosis

text: could not be noticed outside through the wooden door, as his mother was
title: Metamorphosis

text: satisfied with this explanation and shuffled away. But this short
title: Metamorphosis

text: conversation made the other members of the family aware that Gregor,
title: Metamorphosis

text: against their expectations was still at home, and soon his father came
title: Metamorphosis

text: knocking at one of the side doors, gently, but with his fist. “Gregor,
title: Metamorphosis

text: Gregor”, he called, “what’s wrong?” And after a short while he called
title: Metamorphosis

text: again with a warning deepness in his voice: “Gregor! Gregor!” At the
title: Metamorphosis

text: other side door his sister came plaintively: “Gregor? Aren’t you well?
title: Metamorphosis

text: Do you need anything?” Gregor answered to both sides: “I’m ready, now”,
title: Metamorphosis

text: making an effort to remove all the strangeness from his voice by
title: Metamorphosis

text: enunciating very carefully and putting long pauses between each,
title: Metamorphosis

text: individual word. His father went back to his breakfast, but his sister
title: Metamorphosis

text: whispered: “Gregor, open the door, I beg of you.” Gregor, however, had
title: Metamorphosis

text: no thought of opening the door, and instead congratulated himself for
title: Metamorphosis

text: his cautious habit, acquired from his travelling, of locking all doors
title: Metamorphosis

text: at night even when he was at home.
title: Metamorphosis

text: The first thing he wanted to do was to get up in peace without being
title: Metamorphosis

text: disturbed, to get dressed, and most of all to have his breakfast. Only
title: Metamorphosis

text: then would he consider what to do next, as he was well aware that he
title: Metamorphosis

text: would not bring his thoughts to any sensible conclusions by lying in
title: Metamorphosis

text: bed. He remembered that he had often felt a slight pain in bed, perhaps
title: Metamorphosis

text: caused by lying awkwardly, but that had always turned out to be pure
title: Metamorphosis

text: imagination and he wondered how his imaginings would slowly resolve
title: Metamorphosis

text: themselves today. He did not have the slightest doubt that the change
title: Metamorphosis

text: in his voice was nothing more than the first sign of a serious cold,
title: Metamorphosis

text: which was an occupational hazard for travelling salesmen.
title: Metamorphosis

text: It was a simple matter to throw off the covers; he only had to blow
title: Metamorphosis

text: himself up a little and they fell off by themselves. But it became
title: Metamorphosis

text: difficult after that, especially as he was so exceptionally broad. He
title: Metamorphosis

text: would have used his arms and his hands to push himself up; but instead
title: Metamorphosis

text: of them he only had all those little legs continuously moving in
title: Metamorphosis

text: different directions, and which he was moreover unable to control. If
title: Metamorphosis

text: he wanted to bend one of them, then that was the first one that would
title: Metamorphosis

text: stretch itself out; and if he finally managed to do what he wanted with
title: Metamorphosis

text: that leg, all the others seemed to be set free and would move about
title: Metamorphosis

text: painfully. “This is something that can’t be done in bed”, Gregor said
title: Metamorphosis

text: to himself, “so don’t keep trying to do it”.
title: Metamorphosis

text: The first thing he wanted to do was get the lower part of his body out
title: Metamorphosis

text: of the bed, but he had never seen this lower part, and could not
title: Metamorphosis

text: imagine what it looked like; it turned out to be too hard to move; it
title: Metamorphosis

text: went so slowly; and finally, almost in a frenzy, when he carelessly
title: Metamorphosis

text: shoved himself forwards with all the force he could gather, he chose
title: Metamorphosis

text: the wrong direction, hit hard against the lower bedpost, and learned
title: Metamorphosis

text: from the burning pain he felt that the lower part of his body might
title: Metamorphosis

text: well, at present, be the most sensitive.
title: Metamorphosis

text: So then he tried to get the top part of his body out of the bed first,
title: Metamorphosis

text: carefully turning his head to the side. This he managed quite easily,
title: Metamorphosis

text: and despite its breadth and its weight, the bulk of his body eventually
title: Metamorphosis

text: followed slowly in the direction of the head. But when he had at last
title: Metamorphosis

text: got his head out of the bed and into the fresh air it occurred to him
title: Metamorphosis

text: that if he let himself fall it would be a miracle if his head were not
title: Metamorphosis

text: injured, so he became afraid to carry on pushing himself forward the
title: Metamorphosis

text: same way. And he could not knock himself out now at any price; better
title: Metamorphosis

text: to stay in bed than lose consciousness.
title: Metamorphosis

text: It took just as much effort to get back to where he had been earlier,
title: Metamorphosis

text: but when he lay there sighing, and was once more watching his legs as
title: Metamorphosis

text: they struggled against each other even harder than before, if that was
title: Metamorphosis

text: possible, he could think of no way of bringing peace and order to this
title: Metamorphosis

text: chaos. He told himself once more that it was not possible for him to
title: Metamorphosis

text: stay in bed and that the most sensible thing to do would be to get free
title: Metamorphosis

text: of it in whatever way he could at whatever sacrifice. At the same time,
title: Metamorphosis

text: though, he did not forget to remind himself that calm consideration was
title: Metamorphosis

text: much better than rushing to desperate conclusions. At times like this
title: Metamorphosis

text: he would direct his eyes to the window and look out as clearly as he
title: Metamorphosis

text: could, but unfortunately, even the other side of the narrow street was
title: Metamorphosis

text: enveloped in morning fog and the view had little confidence or cheer to
title: Metamorphosis

text: offer him. “Seven o’clock, already”, he said to himself when the clock
title: Metamorphosis

text: struck again, “seven o’clock, and there’s still a fog like this.” And
title: Metamorphosis

text: he lay there quietly a while longer, breathing lightly as if he perhaps
title: Metamorphosis

text: expected the total stillness to bring things back to their real and
title: Metamorphosis

text: natural state.
title: Metamorphosis

text: But then he said to himself: “Before it strikes quarter past seven I’ll
title: Metamorphosis

text: definitely have to have got properly out of bed. And by then somebody
title: Metamorphosis

text: will have come round from work to ask what’s happened to me as well, as
title: Metamorphosis

text: they open up at work before seven o’clock.” And so he set himself to
title: Metamorphosis

text: the task of swinging the entire length of his body out of the bed all
title: Metamorphosis

text: at the same time. If he succeeded in falling out of bed in this way and
title: Metamorphosis

text: kept his head raised as he did so he could probably avoid injuring it.
title: Metamorphosis

text: His back seemed to be quite hard, and probably nothing would happen to
title: Metamorphosis

text: it falling onto the carpet. His main concern was for the loud noise he
title: Metamorphosis

text: was bound to make, and which even through all the doors would probably
title: Metamorphosis

text: raise concern if not alarm. But it was something that had to be risked.
title: Metamorphosis

text: When Gregor was already sticking half way out of the bed—the new method
title: Metamorphosis

text: was more of a game than an effort, all he had to do was rock back and
title: Metamorphosis

text: forth—it occurred to him how simple everything would be if somebody
title: Metamorphosis

text: came to help him. Two strong people—he had his father and the maid in
title: Metamorphosis

text: mind—would have been more than enough; they would only have to push
title: Metamorphosis

text: their arms under the dome of his back, peel him away from the bed, bend
title: Metamorphosis

text: down with the load and then be patient and careful as he swang over
title: Metamorphosis

text: onto the floor, where, hopefully, the little legs would find a use.
title: Metamorphosis

text: Should he really call for help though, even apart from the fact that
title: Metamorphosis

text: all the doors were locked? Despite all the difficulty he was in, he
title: Metamorphosis

text: could not suppress a smile at this thought.
title: Metamorphosis

text: After a while he had already moved so far across that it would have
title: Metamorphosis

text: been hard for him to keep his balance if he rocked too hard. The time
title: Metamorphosis

text: was now ten past seven and he would have to make a final decision very
title: Metamorphosis

text: soon. Then there was a ring at the door of the flat. “That’ll be
title: Metamorphosis

text: someone from work”, he said to himself, and froze very still, although
title: Metamorphosis

text: his little legs only became all the more lively as they danced around.
title: Metamorphosis

text: For a moment everything remained quiet. “They’re not opening the door”,
title: Metamorphosis

text: Gregor said to himself, caught in some nonsensical hope. But then of
title: Metamorphosis

text: course, the maid’s firm steps went to the door as ever and opened it.
title: Metamorphosis

text: Gregor only needed to hear the visitor’s first words of greeting and he
title: Metamorphosis

text: knew who it was—the chief clerk himself. Why did Gregor have to be the
title: Metamorphosis

text: only one condemned to work for a company where they immediately became
title: Metamorphosis

text: highly suspicious at the slightest shortcoming? Were all employees,
title: Metamorphosis

text: every one of them, louts, was there not one of them who was faithful
title: Metamorphosis

text: and devoted who would go so mad with pangs of conscience that he
title: Metamorphosis

text: couldn’t get out of bed if he didn’t spend at least a couple of hours
title: Metamorphosis

text: in the morning on company business? Was it really not enough to let one
title: Metamorphosis

text: of the trainees make enquiries—assuming enquiries were even
title: Metamorphosis

text: necessary—did the chief clerk have to come himself, and did they have
title: Metamorphosis

text: to show the whole, innocent family that this was so suspicious that
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: proper decision, he swang himself with all his force out of the bed.
title: Metamorphosis

text: There was a loud thump, but it wasn’t really a loud noise. His fall was
title: Metamorphosis

text: softened a little by the carpet, and Gregor’s back was also more
title: Metamorphosis

text: elastic than he had thought, which made the sound muffled and not too
title: Metamorphosis

text: noticeable. He had not held his head carefully enough, though, and hit
title: Metamorphosis

text: it as he fell; annoyed and in pain, he turned it and rubbed it against
title: Metamorphosis

text: the carpet.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “Something’s fallen down in there”, said the chief clerk in the room on
title: Metamorphosis

text: the left. Gregor tried to imagine whether something of the sort that
title: Metamorphosis

text: had happened to him today could ever happen to the chief clerk too; you
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: could now be heard in the adjoining room. From the room on his right,
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: clerk is here.” “Yes, I know”, said Gregor to himself; but without
title: Metamorphosis

text: daring to raise his voice loud enough for his sister to hear him.
title: Metamorphosis

text: “Gregor”, said his father now from the room to his left, “the chief
title: Metamorphosis

text: clerk has come round and wants to know why you didn’t leave on the
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: good enough to forgive the untidiness of your room.” Then the chief
title: Metamorphosis

text: clerk called “Good morning, Mr. Samsa”. “He isn’t well”, said his
title: Metamorphosis

text: mother to the chief clerk, while his father continued to speak through
title: Metamorphosis

text: the door. “He isn’t well, please believe me. Why else would Gregor have
title: Metamorphosis

text: missed a train! The lad only ever thinks about the business. It nearly
title: Metamorphosis

text: makes me cross the way he never goes out in the evenings; he’s been in
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: the kitchen and just reads the paper or studies train timetables. His
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: amazed how nice it is; it’s hanging up in his room; you’ll see it as
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: wouldn’t have been able to get Gregor to open the door by ourselves;
title: Metamorphosis

text: he’s so stubborn; and I’m sure he isn’t well, he said this morning that
title: Metamorphosis

text: he is, but he isn’t.” “I’ll be there in a moment”, said Gregor slowly
title: Metamorphosis

text: and thoughtfully, but without moving so that he would not miss any word
title: Metamorphosis

text: of the conversation. “Well I can’t think of any other way of explaining
title: Metamorphosis

text: it, Mrs. Samsa”, said the chief clerk, “I hope it’s nothing serious.
title: Metamorphosis

text: But on the other hand, I must say that if we people in commerce ever
title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

text: we simply have to overcome it because of business considerations.” “Can
title: Metamorphosis

text: the chief clerk come in to see you now then?”, asked his father
title: Metamorphosis

text: impatiently, knocking at the door again. “No”, said Gregor. In the room
title: Metamorphosis

text: on his right there followed a painful silence; in the room on his left
title: Metamorphosis

text: his sister began to cry.

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis
