text: <h2 id="Chapter_One">Chapter One
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Arrest—Conversation with Mrs. Grubach—Then Miss Bürstner
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Someone must have been telling lies about Josef K., he knew he had done
title: The Trial

text: nothing wrong but, one morning, he was arrested. Every day at eight in
title: The Trial

text: the morning he was brought his breakfast by Mrs. Grubach's cook—Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach was his landlady—but today she didn't come. That had never
title: The Trial

text: happened before. K. waited a little while, looked from his pillow at the
title: The Trial

text: old woman who lived opposite and who was watching him with an
title: The Trial

text: inquisitiveness quite unusual for her, and finally, both hungry and
title: The Trial

text: disconcerted, rang the bell. There was immediately a knock at the door
title: The Trial

text: and a man entered. He had never seen the man in this house before. He
title: The Trial

text: was slim but firmly built, his clothes were black and close-fitting,
title: The Trial

text: with many folds and pockets, buckles and buttons and a belt, all of
title: The Trial

text: which gave the impression of being very practical but without making it
title: The Trial

text: very clear what they were actually for. "Who are you?" asked K., sitting
title: The Trial

text: half upright in his bed. The man, however, ignored the question as if
title: The Trial

text: his arrival simply had to be accepted, and merely replied, "You rang?"
title: The Trial

text: "Anna should have brought me my breakfast," said K. He tried to work
title: The Trial

text: out who the man actually was, first in silence, just through
title: The Trial

text: observation and by thinking about it, but the man didn't stay still to
title: The Trial

text: be looked at for very long. Instead he went over to the door, opened it
title: The Trial

text: slightly, and said to someone who was clearly standing immediately
title: The Trial

text: behind it, "He
title: The Trial

text: wants Anna to bring him his breakfast." There was a little laughter in
title: The Trial

text: the neighbouring room, it was not clear from the sound of it whether
title: The Trial

text: there were several people laughing. The strange man could not have
title: The Trial

text: learned anything from it that he hadn't known already, but now he said
title: The Trial

text: to K., as if making his report "It is not possible." "It would be the
title: The Trial

text: first time that's happened," said K., as he jumped out of bed and
title: The Trial

text: quickly pulled on his trousers. "I want to see who that is in the next
title: The Trial

text: room, and why it is that Mrs. Grubach has let me be disturbed in this
title: The Trial

text: way." It immediately occurred to him that he needn't have said this out
title: The Trial

text: loud, and that he must to some extent have acknowledged their authority
title: The Trial

text: by doing so, but that didn't seem important to him at the time. That, at
title: The Trial

text: least, is how the stranger took it, as he said, "Don't you think you'd
title: The Trial

text: better stay where you are?" "I want neither to stay here nor to be
title: The Trial

text: spoken to by you until you've introduced yourself." "I meant it for your
title: The Trial

text: own good," said the stranger and opened the door, this time without
title: The Trial

text: being asked. The next room, which K. entered more slowly than he had
title: The Trial

text: intended, looked at first glance exactly the same as it had the previous
title: The Trial

text: evening. It was Mrs. Grubach's living room, over-filled with furniture,
title: The Trial

text: tablecloths, porcelain and photographs. Perhaps there was a little more
title: The Trial

text: space in there than usual today, but if so it was not immediately
title: The Trial

text: obvious, especially as the main difference was the presence of a man
title: The Trial

text: sitting by the open window with a book from which he now looked up.
title: The Trial

text: "You should have stayed in your room! Didn't Franz tell you?" "And what
title: The Trial

text: is it you want, then?" said K., looking back and forth between this new
title: The Trial

text: acquaintance and the one named Franz, who had remained in the doorway.
title: The Trial

text: Through the open window he noticed the old woman again, who had come
title: The Trial

text: close to the window opposite so that she could continue to see
title: The Trial

text: everything. She was showing an inquisitiveness that really made it seem
title: The Trial

text: like she was going senile. "I want to see Mrs. Grubach ...," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: making a movement as if tearing himself away from the two men—even
title: The Trial

text: though they were standing well away from him—and wanted to go. "No,"
title: The Trial

text: said the man at the window, who threw his book down on a coffee table
title: The Trial

text: and stood up. "You can't go away when you're under arrest." "That's how
title: The Trial

text: it seems," said K. "And why am I under arrest?" he then asked. "That's
title: The Trial

text: something we're not allowed to tell you. Go into your room and wait
title: The Trial

text: there. Proceedings are underway and you'll learn about everything all in
title: The Trial

text: good time. It's not really part of my job to be friendly towards you
title: The Trial

text: like this, but I hope no-one, apart from Franz, will hear about it, and
title: The Trial

text: he's been more friendly towards you than he should have been, under the
title: The Trial

text: rules, himself. If you carry on having as much good luck as you have
title: The Trial

text: been with your arresting officers then you can reckon on things going
title: The Trial

text: well with you." K. wanted to sit down, but then he saw that, apart from
title: The Trial

text: the chair by the window, there was nowhere anywhere in the room where he
title: The Trial

text: could sit. "You'll get the chance to see for yourself how true all this
title: The Trial

text: is," said Franz and both men then walked up to K. They were
title: The Trial

text: significantly bigger than him, especially the second man, who frequently
title: The Trial

text: slapped him on the shoulder. The two of them felt K.'s nightshirt, and
title: The Trial

text: said he would now have to wear one that was of much lower quality, but
title: The Trial

text: that they would keep the nightshirt along with his other underclothes
title: The Trial

text: and return them to him if his case turned out well. "It's better for you
title: The Trial

text: if you give us the things than if you leave them in the storeroom," they
title: The Trial

text: said. "Things have a tendency to go missing in the storeroom, and after
title: The Trial

text: a certain amount of time they sell things off, whether the case involved
title: The Trial

text: has come to an end or not. And cases like this can last a long time,
title: The Trial

text: especially the ones that have been coming up lately. They'd give you the
title: The Trial

text: money they got for them, but it wouldn't be very much as it's not what
title: The Trial

text: they're offered for them when they sell them that counts, it's how much
title: The Trial

text: they get slipped on the side, and things like that lose their value
title: The Trial

text: anyway when they get passed on from hand to hand, year after year." K.
title: The Trial

text: paid hardly any attention to what they were saying, he did not place
title: The Trial

text: much value on what he may have still possessed or on who decided what
title: The Trial

text: happened to them. It was much more important to him to get a clear
title: The Trial

text: understanding of his position, but he could not think clearly while
title: The Trial

text: these people were here, the second policeman's belly—and they could
title: The Trial

text: only be policemen—looked friendly enough, sticking out towards him, but
title: The Trial

text: when K. looked up and saw his dry, bony face it did not seem to fit
title: The Trial

text: with the body. His strong nose twisted to one side as if ignoring K. and
title: The Trial

text: sharing an understanding with the other policeman. What sort of people
title: The Trial

text: were these? What were they talking about? What office did they belong
title: The Trial

text: to? K. was living in a free country, after all, everywhere was at peace,
title: The Trial

text: all laws were decent and were upheld, who was it who dared accost him in
title: The Trial

text: his own home. He was always inclined to take life as lightly as he
title: The Trial

text: could, to cross bridges when he came to them, pay no heed for the
title: The Trial

text: future, even when everything seemed under threat. But here that did not
title: The Trial

text: seem the right thing to do. He could have taken it all as a joke, a big
title: The Trial

text: joke set up by his colleagues at the bank for some unknown reason, or
title: The Trial

text: also perhaps because today was his thirtieth birthday, it was all
title: The Trial

text: possible of course, maybe all he had to do was laugh in the policemen's
title: The Trial

text: face in some way and they would laugh with him, maybe they were
title: The Trial

text: tradesmen from the corner of the street, they looked like they might
title: The Trial

text: be—but he was nonetheless determined, ever since he first caught sight
title: The Trial

text: of the one called Franz, not to lose any slight advantage he might have
title: The Trial

text: had over these people. There was a very slight risk that people would
title: The Trial

text: later say he couldn't understand a joke, but—although he wasn't
title: The Trial

text: normally in the habit of learning from experience—he might also have
title: The Trial

text: had a few unimportant occasions in mind when, unlike his more cautious
title: The Trial

text: friends, he had acted with no thought at all for what might follow and
title: The Trial

text: had been made to suffer for it. He didn't want that to happen again, not
title: The Trial

text: this time at least; if they were play-acting he would act along with
title: The Trial

text: them.
title: The Trial

text: He still had time. "Allow me," he said, and hurried between the two
title: The Trial

text: policemen through into his room. "He seems sensible enough," he heard
title: The Trial

text: them say behind him. Once in his room, he quickly pulled open the drawer
title: The Trial

text: of his writing desk, everything in it was very tidy but in his
title: The Trial

text: agitation he was unable to find the identification documents he was
title: The Trial

text: looking for straight away. He finally found his bicycle permit and was
title: The Trial

text: about to go back to the policemen with it when it seemed to him too
title: The Trial

text: petty, so he carried on searching until he found his birth certificate.
title: The Trial

text: Just as he got back in the adjoining room the door on the other side
title: The Trial

text: opened and Mrs. Grubach was about to enter. He only saw her for an
title: The Trial

text: instant, for as soon as she recognised K. she was clearly embarrassed,
title: The Trial

text: asked for forgiveness and disappeared, closing the door behind her very
title: The Trial

text: carefully. "Do come in," K. could have said just then. But now he stood
title: The Trial

text: in the middle of the room with his papers in his hand and still looking
title: The Trial

text: at the door which did not open again. He stayed like that until he was
title: The Trial

text: startled out of it by the shout of the policeman who sat at the little
title: The Trial

text: table at the open window and, as K. now saw, was eating his breakfast.
title: The Trial

text: "Why didn't she come in?" he asked. "She's not allowed to," said the
title: The Trial

text: big policeman. "You're under arrest, aren't you?" "But how can I be
title: The Trial

text: under arrest? And how come it's like this?" "Now you're starting again,"
title: The Trial

text: said the policeman, dipping a piece of buttered bread in the honeypot.
title: The Trial

text: "We don't answer questions like that." "You will have to answer them,"
title: The Trial

text: said K. "Here are my identification papers, now show me yours and I
title: The Trial

text: certainly want to see the arrest warrant." "Oh, my God!" said the
title: The Trial

text: policeman. "In a position like yours, and you think you can start giving
title: The Trial

text: orders, do you. It won't do you any good to get us on the wrong side,
title: The Trial

text: even if you think it will—we're probably more on your side that anyone
title: The Trial

text: else you know!" "That's true, you know, you'd better believe it," said
title: The Trial

text: Franz, holding a cup of coffee in his hand which he did not lift to his
title: The Trial

text: mouth but looked at K. in a way that was probably meant to be full of
title: The Trial

text: meaning but could not actually be understood. K. found himself, without
title: The Trial

text: intending it, in a mute dialogue with Franz, but then slapped his hand
title: The Trial

text: down on his papers and said, "Here are my identity documents." "And what
title: The Trial

text: do you want us to do about it?" replied the big policeman, loudly. "The
title: The Trial

text: way you're carrying on, it's worse than a child. What is it you want? Do
title: The Trial

text: you want to get this great, bloody trial of yours over with quickly by
title: The Trial

text: talking about ID and arrest warrants with us? We're just coppers, that's
title: The Trial

text: all we are. Junior officers like us hardly know one end of an ID card
title: The Trial

text: from another, all we've got to do with you is keep an eye on you for
title: The Trial

text: ten hours a day and get paid for it. That's all we are. Mind you, what
title: The Trial

text: we can do is make sure that the high officials we work for find out
title: The Trial

text: just what sort of person it is they're going to arrest, and why he
title: The Trial

text: should be arrested, before they issue the warrant. There's no mistake
title: The Trial

text: there. Our authorities as far as I know, and I only know the lowest
title: The Trial

text: grades, don't go out looking for guilt among the public; it's the guilt
title: The Trial

text: that draws them out, like it says in the law, and they have to send us
title: The Trial

text: police officers out. That's the law. Where d'you think there'd be any
title: The Trial

text: mistake there?" "I don't know this law," said K. "So much the worse for
title: The Trial

text: you, then," said the policeman. "It's probably exists only in your
title: The Trial

text: heads," said K., he wanted, in some way, to insinuate his way into the
title: The Trial

text: thoughts of the policemen, to re-shape those thoughts to his benefit or
title: The Trial

text: to make himself at home there. But the policeman just said dismissively,
title: The Trial

text: "You'll find out when it affects you." Franz joined in, and said, "Look
title: The Trial

text: at this, Willem, he admits he doesn't know the law and at the same time
title: The Trial

text: insists he's innocent." "You're quite right, but we can't get him to
title: The Trial

text: understand a thing," said the other. K. stopped talking with them; do I,
title: The Trial

text: he thought to himself, do I really have to carry on getting tangled up
title: The Trial

text: with the chattering of base functionaries like this?—and they admit
title: The Trial

text: themselves that they are of the lowest position. They're talking about
title: The Trial

text: things of which they don't have the slightest understanding, anyway.
title: The Trial

text: It's only because of their stupidity that they're able to be so sure of
title: The Trial

text: themselves. I just need few words with someone of the same social
title: The Trial

text: standing as myself and everything will be incomparably clearer, much
title: The Trial

text: clearer than a long conversation with these two can make it. He walked
title: The Trial

text: up and down the free space in the room a couple of times, across the
title: The Trial

text: street he could see the old woman who, now, had pulled an old man, much
title: The Trial

text: older than herself, up to the window and had her arms around him. K. had
title: The Trial

text: to put an end to this display, "Take me to your superior," he said. "As
title: The Trial

text: soon as he wants to see you. Not before," said the policeman, the one
title: The Trial

text: called Willem. "And now my advice to you," he added, "is to go into your
title: The Trial

text: room, stay calm, and wait and see what's to be done with you. If you
title: The Trial

text: take our advice, you won't tire yourself out thinking about things to no
title: The Trial

text: purpose, you need to pull yourself together as there's a lot that's
title: The Trial

text: going to required of you. You've not behaved towards us the way we
title: The Trial

text: deserve after being so good to you, you forget that we, whatever we are,
title: The Trial

text: we're still free men and you're not, and that's quite an advantage. But
title: The Trial

text: in spite of all that we're still willing, if you've got the money, to go
title: The Trial

text: and get you some breakfast from the café over the road."
title: The Trial

text: Without giving any answer to this offer, K. stood still for some time.
title: The Trial

text: Perhaps, if he opened the door of the next room or even the front door,
title: The Trial

text: the two of them would not dare to stand in his way, perhaps that would
title: The Trial

text: be the simplest way to settle the whole thing, by bringing it to a head.
title: The Trial

text: But maybe they would grab him, and if he were thrown down on the ground
title: The Trial

text: he would lose all the advantage he, in a certain respect, had over them.
title: The Trial

text: So he decided on the more certain solution, the way things would go in
title: The Trial

text: the natural course of events, and went back in his room without another
title: The Trial

text: word either from him or from the policemen.
title: The Trial

text: He threw himself down on his bed, and from the dressing table he took
title: The Trial

text: the nice apple that he had put there the previous evening for his
title: The Trial

text: breakfast. Now it was all the breakfast he had and anyway, as he
title: The Trial

text: confirmed as soon as he took his first, big bite of it, it was far
title: The Trial

text: better than a breakfast he could have had through the good will of the
title: The Trial

text: policemen from the dirty café. He felt well and confident, he had failed
title: The Trial

text: to go into work at the bank this morning but that could easily be
title: The Trial

text: excused because of the relatively high position he held there. Should he
title: The Trial

text: really send in his explanation? He wondered about it. If nobody believed
title: The Trial

text: him, and in this case that would be understandable, he could bring Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach in as a witness, or even the old pair from across the street,
title: The Trial

text: who probably even now were on their way over to the window opposite. It
title: The Trial

text: puzzled K., at least it puzzled him looking at it from the policemen's
title: The Trial

text: point of view, that they had made him go into the room and left him
title: The Trial

text: alone there, where he had ten different ways of killing himself. At the
title: The Trial

text: same time, though, he asked himself, this time looking at it from his
title: The Trial

text: own point of view, what reason he could have to do so. Because those two
title: The Trial

text: were sitting there in the next room and had taken his breakfast,
title: The Trial

text: perhaps. It would have been so pointless to kill himself that, even if
title: The Trial

text: he had wanted to, the pointlessness would have made him unable. Maybe,
title: The Trial

text: if the policemen had not been so obviously limited in their mental
title: The Trial

text: abilities, it could have been supposed that they had come to the same
title: The Trial

text: conclusion and saw no danger in leaving him alone because of it. They
title: The Trial

text: could watch now, if they wanted, and see how he went over to the
title: The Trial

text: cupboard in the wall where he kept a bottle of good schnapps, how he
title: The Trial

text: first emptied a glass of it in place of his breakfast and how he then
title: The Trial

text: took a second glassful in order to give himself courage, the last one
title: The Trial

text: just as a precaution for the unlikely chance it would be needed.
title: The Trial

text: Then he was so startled by a shout to him from the other room that he
title: The Trial

text: struck his teeth against the glass. "The supervisor wants to see you!" a
title: The Trial

text: voice said. It was only the shout that startled him, this curt, abrupt,
title: The Trial

text: military shout, that he would not have expected from the policeman
title: The Trial

text: called Franz. In itself, he found the order very welcome. "At last!" he
title: The Trial

text: called back, locked the cupboard and, without delay, hurried into the
title: The Trial

text: next room. The two policemen were standing there and chased him back
title: The Trial

text: into his bedroom as if that were a matter of course. "What d'you think
title: The Trial

text: you're doing?" they cried. "Think you're going to see the supervisor
title: The Trial

text: dressed in just your shirt, do you? He'd see to it you got a right
title: The Trial

text: thumping, and us and all!" "Let go of me for God's sake!" called K., who
title: The Trial

text: had already been pushed back as far as his wardrobe, "if you accost me
title: The Trial

text: when I'm still in bed you can't expect to find me in my evening dress."
title: The Trial

text: "That won't help you," said the policemen, who always became very quiet,
title: The Trial

text: almost sad, when K. began to shout, and in that way confused him or, to
title: The Trial

text: some extent, brought him to his senses. "Ridiculous formalities!" he
title: The Trial

text: grumbled, as he lifted his coat from the chair and kept it in both his
title: The Trial

text: hands for a little while, as if holding it out for the policemen's
title: The Trial

text: inspection. They shook their heads. "It's got to be a black coat,"
title: The Trial

text: they said. At that, K. threw the coat to the floor and said—without
title: The Trial

text: knowing even himself what he meant by it—"Well it's not going to be the
title: The Trial

text: main trial, after all." The policemen laughed, but continued to insist,
title: The Trial

text: "It's got to be a black coat." "Well that's alright by me if it makes
title: The Trial

text: things go any faster," said K. He opened the wardrobe himself, spent a
title: The Trial

text: long time searching through all the clothes, and chose his best black
title: The Trial

text: suit which had a short jacket that had greatly surprised those who knew
title: The Trial

text: him, then he also pulled out a fresh shirt and began, carefully, to get
title: The Trial

text: dressed. He secretly told himself that he had succeeded in speeding
title: The Trial

text: things up by letting the policemen forget to make him have a bath. He
title: The Trial

text: watched them to see if they might remember after all, but of course it
title: The Trial

text: never occurred to them, although Willem did not forget to send Franz up
title: The Trial

text: to the supervisor with the message saying that K. was getting dressed.
title: The Trial

text: Once he was properly dressed, K. had to pass by Willem as he went
title: The Trial

text: through the next room into the one beyond, the door of which was already
title: The Trial

text: wide open. K. knew very well that this room had recently been let to a
title: The Trial

text: typist called 'Miss Bürstner'. She was in the habit of going out to work
title: The Trial

text: very early and coming back home very late, and K. had never exchanged
title: The Trial

text: more than a few words of greeting with her. Now, her bedside table had
title: The Trial

text: been pulled into the middle of the room to be used as a desk for these
title: The Trial

text: proceedings, and the supervisor sat behind it. He had his legs crossed,
title: The Trial

text: and had thrown one arm over the backrest of the chair.
title: The Trial

text: In one corner of the room there were three young people looking at the
title: The Trial

text: photographs belonging to Miss Bürstner that had been put into a piece of
title: The Trial

text: fabric on the wall. Hung up on the handle of the open window was a white
title: The Trial

text: blouse. At the window across the street, there was the old pair again,
title: The Trial

text: although now their number had increased, as behind them, and far taller
title: The Trial

text: than they were, stood a man with an open shirt that showed his chest and
title: The Trial

text: a reddish goatee beard which he squeezed and twisted with his fingers.
title: The Trial

text: "Josef K.?" asked the supervisor, perhaps merely to attract K.'s
title: The Trial

text: attention as he looked round the room. K. nodded. "I daresay you were

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: looking round at everyone there and even wishing he could get the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: other hand this really can't be all that important. That follows from
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the table. "You're making a big mistake," he said. "These gentlemen and
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: that's all it is, chit-chat. I can't give you an answer to your
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: you don't make such a bad impression, but with all this fuss you're
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: everything you've said so far has been things we could have taken from
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: you have said has not exactly been in your favour."
title: The Trial

text: K. stared at the supervisor. Was this man, probably younger than he was,
title: The Trial

text: lecturing him like a schoolmaster. Was he being punished for his honesty
title: The Trial

text: with a telling off. And was he to learn nothing about the reasons for
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: began to walk up and down. No-one stopped him doing this and he pushed
title: The Trial

text: his sleeves back, felt his chest, straightened his hair, went over to
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: finally came again to a halt in front of the supervisor's desk. "State
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: him?" "Certainly," said the supervisor, "but I don't know what the point
title: The Trial

text: of that will be, I suppose you must have some private matter you want to
title: The Trial

text: discuss with him." "What the point is?" shouted K., more disconcerted
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: while you're carrying out something as pointless as it could be. It's
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: of the house on the other side of the street where the large man with
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: that he had not noticed the supervisor and the policemen leaving—the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: three bank staff had stopped him noticing the supervisor. This showed

text: that K. was not very attentive, and he resolved to watch himself more
title: The Trial

text: carefully in this respect. Nonetheless, he gave it no thought as he
title: The Trial

text: twisted himself round and leant over onto the rear shelf of the car to
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: turned back round straight away and leant comfortably into the corner of
title: The Trial

text: the taxi without even having made the effort to see anyone. Although it
title: The Trial

text: did not seem like it, now was just the time when he needed some
title: The Trial

text: encouragement, but the gentlemen seemed tired just then, Rabensteiner
title: The Trial

text: looked out of the car to the right, Kullich to the left and only Kaminer
title: The Trial

text: was there with his grin at K.'s service. It would have been inhumane to
title: The Trial

text: make fun of that.
title: The Trial

text: That spring, whenever possible, K. usually spent his evenings after
title: The Trial

text: work—he usually stayed in the office until nine o'clock—with a short
title: The Trial

text: walk, either by himself or in the company of some of the bank officials,
title: The Trial

text: and then he would go into a pub where he would sit at the regulars'
title: The Trial

text: table with mostly older men until eleven. There were, however, also
title: The Trial

text: exceptions to this habit, times, for instance, when K. was invited by
title: The Trial

text: the bank's manager (whom he greatly respected for his industry and
title: The Trial

text: trustworthiness) to go with him for a ride in his car or to eat dinner
title: The Trial

text: with him at his large house. K. would also go, once a week, to see a
title: The Trial

text: girl called Elsa who worked as a waitress in a wine bar through the
title: The Trial

text: night until late in the morning. During the daytime she only received
title: The Trial

text: visitors while still in bed.
title: The Trial

text: That evening, though,—the day had passed quickly with a lot of hard
title: The Trial

text: work and many respectful and friendly birthday greetings—K. wanted to
title: The Trial

text: go straight home. Each time he had any small break from the day's work
title: The Trial

text: he considered, without knowing exactly what he had in mind, that Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach's flat seemed to have been put into great disarray by the events
title: The Trial

text: of that morning, and that it was up to him to put it back into order.
title: The Trial

text: Once order had been restored, every trace of those events would have
title: The Trial

text: been erased and everything would take its previous course once more. In
title: The Trial

text: particular, there was nothing to fear from the three bank officials,
title: The Trial

text: they had immersed themselves back into their paperwork and there was no
title: The Trial

text: alteration to be seen in them. K. had called each of them, separately or
title: The Trial

text: all together, into his office that day for no other reason than to
title: The Trial

text: observe them; he was always satisfied and had always been able to let
title: The Trial

text: them go again.
title: The Trial

text: At half past nine that evening, when he arrived back in front of the
title: The Trial

text: building where he lived, he met a young lad in the doorway who was
title: The Trial

text: standing there, his legs apart and smoking a pipe. "Who are you?"
title: The Trial

text: immediately asked K., bringing his face close to the lad's, as it was
title: The Trial

text: hard to see in the half light of the landing. "I'm the landlord's son,
title: The Trial

text: sir," answered the lad, taking the pipe from his mouth and stepping to
title: The Trial

text: one side. "The landlord's son?" asked K., and impatiently knocked on the
title: The Trial

text: ground with his stick. "Did you want anything, sir? Would you like me
title: The Trial

text: to fetch my father?" "No, no," said K., there was something forgiving
title: The Trial

text: in his voice, as if the boy had harmed him in some way and he was
title: The Trial

text: excusing him. "It's alright," he said then, and went on, but before
title: The Trial

text: going up the stairs he turned round once more.
title: The Trial

text: He could have gone directly to his room, but as he wanted to speak with
title: The Trial

text: Mrs. Grubach he went straight to her door and knocked. She was sat at
title: The Trial

text: the table with a knitted stocking and a pile of old stockings in front
title: The Trial

text: of her. K. apologised, a little embarrassed at coming so late, but Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach was very friendly and did not want to hear any apology, she was
title: The Trial

text: always ready to speak to him, he knew very well that he was her best and
title: The Trial

text: her favourite tenant. K. looked round the room, it looked exactly as it
title: The Trial

text: usually did, the breakfast dishes, which had been on the table by the
title: The Trial

text: window that morning, had already been cleared away. "A woman's hands
title: The Trial

text: will do many things when no-one's looking," he thought, he might himself
title: The Trial

text: have smashed all the dishes on the spot but certainly would not have
title: The Trial

text: been able to carry it all out. He looked at Mrs. Grubach with some
title: The Trial

text: gratitude. "Why are you working so late?" he asked. They were now both
title: The Trial

text: sitting at the table, and K. now and then sank his hands into the pile
title: The Trial

text: of stockings. "There's a lot of work to do," she said, "during the day I
title: The Trial

text: belong to the tenants; if I'm to sort out my own things there are only
title: The Trial

text: the evenings left to me." "I fear I may have caused you some exceptional
title: The Trial

text: work today." "How do you mean, Mr. K.?" she asked, becoming more
title: The Trial

text: interested and leaving her work in her lap. "I mean the men who were
title: The Trial

text: here this morning." "Oh, I see," she said, and went peacefully back to
title: The Trial

text: what she was doing, "that was no trouble, not especially." K. looked on
title: The Trial

text: in silence as she took up the knitted stocking once more. She seems
title: The Trial

text: surprised at my mentioning it, he thought, she seems to think it's
title: The Trial

text: improper for me to mention it. All the more important for me to do so.
title: The Trial

text: An old woman is the only person I can speak about it with. "But it must
title: The Trial

text: have caused some work for you," he said then, "but it won't happen
title: The Trial

text: again." "No, it can't happen again," she agreed, and smiled at K. in a
title: The Trial

text: way that was almost pained. "Do you mean that seriously?" asked K.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," she said, more gently, "but the important thing is you mustn't
title: The Trial

text: take it too hard. There are so many awful things happening in the world!
title: The Trial

text: As you're being so honest with me, Mr. K., I can admit to you that I
title: The Trial

text: listened to a little of what was going on from behind the door, and that
title: The Trial

text: those two policemen told me one or two things as well. It's all to do
title: The Trial

text: with your happiness, and that's something that's quite close to my
title: The Trial

text: heart, perhaps more than it should be as I am, after all, only your
title: The Trial

text: landlady. Anyway, so I heard one or two things but I can't really say
title: The Trial

text: that it's about anything very serious. No. You have been arrested, but
title: The Trial

text: it's not in the same way as when they arrest a thief. If you're arrested
title: The Trial

text: in the same way as a thief, then it's bad, but an arrest like this....
title: The Trial

text: It seems to me that it's something very complicated—forgive me if I'm
title: The Trial

text: saying something stupid—something very complicated that I don't
title: The Trial

text: understand, but something that you don't really need to understand
title: The Trial

text: anyway."
title: The Trial

text: "There's nothing stupid about what you've said, Mrs. Grubach, or at
title: The Trial

text: least I partly agree with you, only, the way I judge the whole thing is
title: The Trial

text: harsher than yours, and think it's not only not something complicated
title: The Trial

text: but simply a fuss about nothing. I was just caught unawares, that's what
title: The Trial

text: happened. If I had got up as soon as I was awake without letting myself
title: The Trial

text: get confused because Anna wasn't there, if I'd got up and paid no regard
title: The Trial

text: to anyone who might have been in my way and come straight to you, if I'd

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: waiting to happen would have been stifled. People are so often
title: The Trial

text: unprepared. In the bank, for example, I am well prepared, nothing of
title: The Trial

text: this sort could possibly happen to me there, I have my own assistant
title: The Trial

text: there, there are telephones for internal and external calls in front of
title: The Trial

text: me on the desk, I continually receive visits from people,
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: about it any more, only I wanted to hear what you, as a sensible woman,
title: The Trial

text: thought about it all, and I'm very glad to hear that we're in agreement.
title: The Trial

text: But now you must give me your hand, an agreement of this sort needs to
title: The Trial

text: be confirmed with a handshake."
title: The Trial

text: Will she shake hands with me? The supervisor didn't shake hands, he
title: The Trial

text: thought, and looked at the woman differently from before, examining her.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: not intend and certainly was not appropriate. "Don't take it so hard,
title: The Trial

text: Mr. K.," she said, with tears in her voice and also, of course,
title: The Trial

text: forgetting the handshake. "I didn't know I was taking it hard," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: feeling suddenly tired and seeing that if this woman did agree with him
title: The Trial

text: it was of very little value.
title: The Trial

text: Before going out the door he asked, "Is Miss Bürstner home?" "No," said
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: to see her? Should I give her a message?" "I, er, I just wanted to have
title: The Trial

text: a few words with her." "I'm afraid I don't know when she's coming in;
title: The Trial

text: she usually gets back late when she's been to the theatre." "It really
title: The Trial

text: doesn't matter," said K. his head hanging as he turned to the door to
title: The Trial

text: leave, "I just wanted to give her my apology for taking over her room
title: The Trial

text: today." "There's no need for that, Mr. K., you're too conscientious, the
title: The Trial

text: young lady doesn't know anything about it, she hasn't been home since
title: The Trial

text: early this morning and everything's been tidied up again, you can see
title: The Trial

text: for yourself." And she opened the door to Miss Bürstner's room. "Thank
title: The Trial

text: you, I'll take your word for it," said K., but went nonetheless over to
title: The Trial

text: the open door. The moon shone quietly into the unlit room. As far as
title: The Trial

text: could be seen, everything was indeed in its place, not even the blouse
title: The Trial

text: was hanging on the window handle. The pillows on the bed looked
title: The Trial

text: remarkably plump as they lay half in the moonlight. "Miss Bürstner often
title: The Trial

text: comes home late," said K., looking at Mrs. Grubach as if that were her
title: The Trial

text: responsibility. "That's how young people are!" said Mrs. Grubach to
title: The Trial

text: excuse herself. "Of course, of course," said K., "but it can be taken
title: The Trial

text: too far." "Yes, it can be," said Mrs. Grubach, "you're so right, Mr. K.
title: The Trial

text: Perhaps it is in this case. I certainly wouldn't want to say anything
title: The Trial

text: nasty about Miss Bürstner, she is a good, sweet girl, friendly, tidy,
title: The Trial

text: punctual, works hard, I appreciate all that very much, but one thing is
title: The Trial

text: true, she ought to have more pride, be a bit less forthcoming. Twice
title: The Trial

text: this month already, in the street over the way, I've seen her with a
title: The Trial

text: different gentleman. I really don't like saying this, you're the only
title: The Trial

text: one I've said this to, Mr. K., I swear to God, but I'm going to have no
title: The Trial

text: choice but to have a few words with Miss Bürstner about it myself. And
title: The Trial

text: it's not the only thing about her that I'm worried about." "Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach, you are on quite the wrong track," said K., so angry that he
title: The Trial

text: was hardly able to hide it, "and you have moreover misunderstood what I
title: The Trial

text: was saying about Miss Bürstner, that is not what I meant. In fact I warn
title: The Trial

text: you quite directly not to say anything to her, you are quite mistaken, I
title: The Trial

text: know Miss Bürstner very well and there is no truth at all in what you
title: The Trial

text: say. And what's more, perhaps I'm going to far, I don't want to get in
title: The Trial

text: your way, say to her whatever you see fit. Good night." "Mr. K.," said
title: The Trial

text: Mrs. Grubach as if asking him for something and hurrying to his door
title: The Trial

text: which he had already opened, "I don't want to speak to Miss Bürstner at
title: The Trial

text: all, not yet, of course I'll continue to keep an eye on her but you're
title: The Trial

text: the only one I've told what I know. And it is, after all something that
title: The Trial

text: everyone who lets rooms has to do if she's to keep the house decent,
title: The Trial

text: that's all I'm trying to do." "Decent!" called out K. through the crack
title: The Trial

text: in the door, "if you want to keep the house decent you'll first have to
title: The Trial

text: give me notice." Then he slammed the door shut, there was a gentle
title: The Trial

text: knocking to which he paid no more attention.
title: The Trial

text: He did not feel at all like going to bed, so he decided to stay up, and
title: The Trial

text: this would also give him the chance to find out when Miss Bürstner would
title: The Trial

text: arrive home. Perhaps it would also still be possible, even if a little
title: The Trial

text: inappropriate, to have a few words with her. As he lay there by the
title: The Trial

text: window, pressing his hands to his tired eyes, he even thought for a
title: The Trial

text: moment that he might punish Mrs. Grubach by persuading Miss Bürstner to
title: The Trial

text: give in her notice at the same time as he would. But he immediately
title: The Trial

text: realised that that would be shockingly excessive, and there would even
title: The Trial

text: be the suspicion that he was moving house because of the incidents of
title: The Trial

text: that morning. Nothing would have been more nonsensical and, above all,
title: The Trial

text: more pointless and contemptible.
title: The Trial

text: When he had become tired of looking out onto the empty street he
title: The Trial

text: slightly opened the door to the living room so that he could see anyone
title: The Trial

text: who entered the flat from where he was and lay down on the couch. He lay
title: The Trial

text: there, quietly smoking a cigar, until about eleven o'clock. He wasn't
title: The Trial

text: able to hold out longer than that, and went a little way into the
title: The Trial

text: hallway as if in that way he could make Miss Bürstner arrive sooner. He
title: The Trial

text: had no particular desire for her, he could not even remember what she
title: The Trial

text: looked like, but now he wanted to speak to her and it irritated him that
title: The Trial

text: her late arrival home meant this day would be full of unease and
title: The Trial

text: disorder right to its very end. It was also her fault that he had not
title: The Trial

text: had any dinner that evening and that he had been unable to visit Elsa
title: The Trial

text: as he had intended. He could still make up for both of those things,
title: The Trial

text: though, if he went to the wine bar where Elsa worked. He wanted to do so
title: The Trial

text: even later, after the discussion with Miss Bürstner.
title: The Trial

text: It was already gone half past eleven when someone could be heard in the
title: The Trial

text: stairway. K., who had been lost in his thoughts in the hallway, walking
title: The Trial

text: up and down loudly as if it were his own room, fled behind his door.
title: The Trial

text: Miss Bürstner had arrived. Shivering, she pulled a silk shawl over her
title: The Trial

text: slender shoulders as she locked the door. The next moment she would
title: The Trial

text: certainly go into her room, where K. ought not to intrude in the middle
title: The Trial

text: of the night; that meant he would have to speak to her now, but,
title: The Trial

text: unfortunately, he had not put the electric light on in his room so that
title: The Trial

text: when he stepped out of the dark it would give the impression of being an
title: The Trial

text: attack and would certainly, at the very least, have been quite alarming.
title: The Trial

text: There was no time to lose, and in his helplessness he whispered through
title: The Trial

text: the crack of the door, "Miss Bürstner." It sounded like he was pleading
title: The Trial

text: with her, not calling to her. "Is there someone there?" asked Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner, looking round with her eyes wide open. "It's me," said K. and
title: The Trial

text: came out. "Oh, Mr. K.!" said Miss Bürstner with a smile. "Good Evening,"
title: The Trial

text: and offered him her hand. "I wanted to have a word with you, if you
title: The Trial

text: would allow me?" "Now?" asked Miss Bürstner, "does it have to be now? It
title: The Trial

text: is a little odd, isn't it?" "I've been waiting for you since nine
title: The Trial

text: o'clock." "Well, I was at the theatre, I didn't know anything about you
title: The Trial

text: waiting for me." "The reason I need to speak to you only came up
title: The Trial

text: today." "I see, well I don't see why not, I suppose, apart from being
title: The Trial

text: so tired I could drop. Come into my room for a few minutes then. We
title: The Trial

text: certainly can't talk out here, we'd wake everyone up and I think that
title: The Trial

text: would be more unpleasant for us than for them. Wait here till I've put
title: The Trial

text: the light on in my room, and then turn the light down out here." K. did
title: The Trial

text: as he was told, and then even waited until Miss Bürstner came out of her
title: The Trial

text: room and quietly invited him, once more, to come in. "Sit down," she
title: The Trial

text: said, indicating the ottoman, while she herself remained standing by
title: The Trial

text: the bedpost despite the tiredness she had spoken of; she did not even
title: The Trial

text: take off her hat, which was small but decorated with an abundance of
title: The Trial

text: flowers. "What is it you wanted, then? I'm really quite curious." She
title: The Trial

text: gently crossed her legs. "I expect you'll say," K. began, "that the
title: The Trial

text: matter really isn't all that urgent and we don't need to talk about it
title: The Trial

text: right now, but...." "I never listen to introductions," said Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner. "That makes my job so much easier," said K. "This morning, to
title: The Trial

text: some extent through my fault, your room was made a little untidy, this
title: The Trial

text: happened because of people I did not know and against my will but, as I
title: The Trial

text: said, because of my fault; I wanted to apologise for it." "My room?"
title: The Trial

text: asked Miss Bürstner, and instead of looking round the room scrutinised
title: The Trial

text: K. "It is true," said K., and now, for the first time, they looked each
title: The Trial

text: other in the eyes, "there's no point in saying exactly how this came
title: The Trial

text: about." "But that's the interesting thing about it," said Miss Bürstner.
title: The Trial

text: "No," said K. "Well then," said Miss Bürstner, "I don't want to force my
title: The Trial

text: way into any secrets, if you insist that it's of no interest I won't
title: The Trial

text: insist. I'm quite happy to forgive you for it, as you ask, especially as
title: The Trial

text: I can't see anything at all that's been left untidy." With her hand laid
title: The Trial

text: flat on her lower hip, she made a tour around the room. At the mat where
title: The Trial

text: the photographs were she stopped. "Look at this!" she cried. "My
title: The Trial

text: photographs really have been put in the wrong places. Oh, that's
title: The Trial

text: horrible. Someone really has been in my room without permission." K.
title: The Trial

text: nodded, and quietly cursed Kaminer who worked at his bank and who was
title: The Trial

text: always active doing things that had neither use nor purpose. "It is
title: The Trial

text: odd," said Miss Bürstner, "that I'm forced to forbid you to do something
title: The Trial

text: that you ought to have forbidden yourself to do, namely to come into my
title: The Trial

text: room when I'm not here." "But I did explain to you," said K., and went
title: The Trial

text: over to join her by the photographs, "that it wasn't me who interfered
title: The Trial

text: with your photographs; but as you don't believe me I'll have to admit
title: The Trial

text: that the investigating committee brought along three bank employees with
title: The Trial

text: them, one of them must have touched your photographs and as soon as I
title: The Trial

text: get the chance I'll ask to have him dismissed from the bank. Yes, there
title: The Trial

text: was an investigating committee here," added K., as the young lady was
title: The Trial

text: looking at him enquiringly. "Because of you?" she asked. "Yes," answered
title: The Trial

text: K. "No!" the lady cried with a laugh. "Yes, they were," said K., "you
title: The Trial

text: believe that I'm innocent then, do you?" "Well now, innocent ..." said
title: The Trial

text: the lady, "I don't want to start making any pronouncements that might
title: The Trial

text: have serious consequences, I don't really know you after all, it means
title: The Trial

text: they're dealing with a serious criminal if they send an investigating
title: The Trial

text: committee straight out to get him. But you're not in custody now—at
title: The Trial

text: least I take it you've not escaped from prison considering that you seem
title: The Trial

text: quite calm—so you can't have committed any crime of that sort." "Yes,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., "but it might be that the investigating committee could see
title: The Trial

text: that I'm innocent, or not so guilty as had been supposed." "Yes, that's
title: The Trial

text: certainly a possibility," said Miss Bürstner, who seemed very
title: The Trial

text: interested. "Listen," said K., "you don't have much experience in legal
title: The Trial

text: matters." "No, that's true, I don't," said Miss Bürstner, "and I've
title: The Trial

text: often regretted it, as I'd like to know everything and I'm very
title: The Trial

text: interested in legal matters. There's something peculiarly attractive
title: The Trial

text: about the law, isn't there. But I'll certainly be perfecting my
title: The Trial

text: knowledge in this area, as next month I start work in a legal office."
title: The Trial

text: "That's very good," said K., "that means you'll be able to give me some
title: The Trial

text: help with my trial." "That could well be," said Miss Bürstner, "why not?
title: The Trial

text: I like to make use of what I know." "I mean it quite seriously," said
title: The Trial

text: K., "or at least, half seriously, as you do. This affair is too petty to
title: The Trial

text: call in a lawyer, but I could make good use of someone who could give me
title: The Trial

text: advice." "Yes, but if I'm to give you advice I'll have to know what it's
title: The Trial

text: all about," said Miss Bürstner. "That's exactly the problem," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: "I don't know that myself." "So you have been making fun of me, then,"
title: The Trial

text: said Miss Bürstner exceedingly disappointed, "you really ought not to
title: The Trial

text: try something like that on at this time of night." And she stepped away
title: The Trial

text: from the photographs where they had stood so long together. "Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner, no," said K., "I'm not making fun of you. Please believe me!
title: The Trial

text: I've already told you everything I know. More than I know, in fact, as
title: The Trial

text: it actually wasn't even an investigating committee, that's just what I
title: The Trial

text: called them because I don't know what else to call them. There was no
title: The Trial

text: cross questioning at all, I was merely arrested, but by a committee."
title: The Trial

text: Miss Bürstner sat on the ottoman and laughed again. "What was it like
title: The Trial

text: then?" she asked. "It was terrible," said K., although his mind was no
title: The Trial

text: longer on the subject, he had become totally absorbed by Miss Bürstner's
title: The Trial

text: gaze who was supporting her chin on one hand—the elbow rested on the
title: The Trial

text: cushion of the ottoman—and slowly stroking her hip with the other.
title: The Trial

text: "That's too vague," said Miss Bürstner. "What's too vague?" asked K.
title: The Trial

text: Then he remembered himself and asked, "Would you like me to show you
title: The Trial

text: what it was like?" He wanted to move in some way but did not want to
title: The Trial

text: leave. "I'm already tired," said Miss Bürstner. "You arrived back so
title: The Trial

text: late," said K. "Now you've started telling me off. Well I suppose I
title: The Trial

text: deserve it as I shouldn't have let you in here in the first place, and
title: The Trial

text: it turns out there wasn't even any point." "Oh, there was a point,
title: The Trial

text: you'll see now how important a point it was," said K. "May I move this
title: The Trial

text: table away from your bedside and put it here?" "What do you think you're
title: The Trial

text: doing?" said Miss Bürstner. "Of course you can't!" "In that case I
title: The Trial

text: can't show you," said K., quite upset, as if Miss Bürstner had committed
title: The Trial

text: some incomprehensible offence against him. "Alright then, if you need it
title: The Trial

text: to show what you mean, just take the bedside table then," said Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner, and after a short pause added in a weak voice, "I'm so tired
title: The Trial

text: I'm allowing more than I ought to." K. put the little table in the
title: The Trial

text: middle of the room and sat down behind it. "You have to get a proper
title: The Trial

text: idea of where the people were situated, it is very interesting. I'm the
title: The Trial

text: supervisor, sitting over there on the chest are two policemen, standing
title: The Trial

text: next to the photographs there are three young people. Hanging on the
title: The Trial

text: handle of the window is a white blouse—I just mention that by the way.
title: The Trial

text: And now it begins. Ah yes, I'm forgetting myself, the most important
title: The Trial

text: person of all, so I'm standing here in front of the table. The
title: The Trial

text: supervisor is sitting extremely comfortably with his legs crossed and
title: The Trial

text: his arm hanging over the backrest here like some layabout. And now it
title: The Trial

text: really does begin. The supervisor calls out as if he had to wake me up,
title: The Trial

text: in fact he shouts at me, I'm afraid, if I'm to make it clear to you,
title: The Trial

text: I'll have to shout as well, and it's nothing more than my name that he
title: The Trial

text: shouts out." Miss Bürstner, laughing as she listened to him, laid her
title: The Trial

text: forefinger on her mouth so that K. would not shout, but it was too late.
title: The Trial

text: K. was too engrossed in his role and slowly called out, "Josef K.!" It
title: The Trial

text: was not as loud as he had threatened, but nonetheless, once he had
title: The Trial

text: suddenly called it out, the cry seemed gradually to spread itself all
title: The Trial

text: round the room.
title: The Trial

text: There was a series of loud, curt and regular knocks at the door of the
title: The Trial

text: adjoining room. Miss Bürstner went pale and laid her hand on her heart.
title: The Trial

text: K. was especially startled, as for a moment he had been quite unable to
title: The Trial

text: think of anything other than the events of that morning and the girl for
title: The Trial

text: whom he was performing them. He had hardly pulled himself together when
title: The Trial

text: he jumped over to Miss Bürstner and took her hand. "Don't be afraid," he
title: The Trial

text: whispered, "I'll put everything right. But who can it be? It's only the
title: The Trial

text: living room next door, nobody sleeps in there." "Yes they do," whispered
title: The Trial

text: Miss Bürstner into K.'s ear, "a nephew of Mrs. Grubach's, a captain in
title: The Trial

text: the army, has been sleeping there since yesterday. There's no other room
title: The Trial

text: free. I'd forgotten about it too. Why did you have to shout like that?
title: The Trial

text: You've made me quite upset." "There is no reason for it," said K., and,
title: The Trial

text: now as she sank back onto the cushion, kissed her forehead. "Go away, go
title: The Trial

text: away," she said, hurriedly sitting back up, "get out of here, go, what
title: The Trial

text: is it you want, he's listening at the door, he can hear everything.
title: The Trial

text: You're causing me so much trouble!" "I won't go," said K., "until you've
title: The Trial

text: calmed down a bit. Come over into the other corner of the room, he
title: The Trial

text: won't be able to hear us there." She let him lead her there. "Don't
title: The Trial

text: forget," he said, "although this might be unpleasant for you you're not
title: The Trial

text: in any real danger. You know how much esteem Mrs. Grubach has for me,
title: The Trial

text: she's the one who will make all the decisions in this, especially as the
title: The Trial

text: captain is her nephew, but she believes everything I say without
title: The Trial

text: question. What's more, she has borrowed a large sum of money from me and
title: The Trial

text: that makes her dependent on me. I will confirm whatever you say to
title: The Trial

text: explain our being here together, however inappropriate it might be, and
title: The Trial

text: I guarantee to make sure that Mrs. Grubach will not only say she
title: The Trial

text: believes the explanation in public but will believe it truly and
title: The Trial

text: sincerely. You will have no need to consider me in any way. If you wish
title: The Trial

text: to let it be known that I have attacked you then Mrs. Grubach will be
title: The Trial

text: informed of such and she will believe it without even losing her trust
title: The Trial

text: in me, that's how much respect she has for me." Miss Bürstner looked at
title: The Trial

text: the floor in front of her, quiet and a little sunk in on herself. "Why
title: The Trial

text: would Mrs. Grubach not believe that I've attacked you?" added K. He
title: The Trial

text: looked at her hair in front of him, parted, bunched down, reddish and
title: The Trial

text: firmly held in place. He thought she would look up at him, but without
title: The Trial

text: changing her manner she said, "Forgive me, but it was the suddenness of
title: The Trial

text: the knocking that startled me so much, not so much what the consequences
title: The Trial

text: of the captain being here might be. It was all so quiet after you'd
title: The Trial

text: shouted, and then there was the knocking, that's what made me so
title: The Trial

text: shocked, and I was sitting right by the door, the knocking was right
title: The Trial

text: next to me. Thank you for your suggestions, but I won't accept them. I
title: The Trial

text: can bear the responsibility for anything that happens in my room myself,
title: The Trial

text: and I can do so with anyone. I'm surprised you don't realise just how
title: The Trial

text: insulting your suggestions are and what they imply about me, although I
title: The Trial

text: certainly acknowledge your good intentions. But now, please go, leave me
title: The Trial

text: alone, I need you to go now even more than I did earlier. The couple of
title: The Trial

text: minutes you asked for have grown into half an hour, more than half an
title: The Trial

text: hour now." K. took hold of her hand, and then of her wrist, "You're not
title: The Trial

text: cross with me, though?" he said. She pulled her hand away and answered,
title: The Trial

text: "No, no, I'm never cross with anyone." He grasped her wrist once more,
title: The Trial

text: she tolerated it now and, in that way, led him to the door. He had
title: The Trial

text: fully intended to leave. But when he reached the door he came to a halt
title: The Trial

text: as if he hadn't expected to find a door there, Miss Bürstner made use of
title: The Trial

text: that moment to get herself free, open the door, slip out into the
title: The Trial

text: hallway and gently say to K. from there, "Now, come along, please.
title: The Trial

text: Look," she pointed to the captain's door, from under which there was a
title: The Trial

text: light shining, "he's put a light on and he's laughing at us." "Alright,
title: The Trial

text: I'm coming," said K., moved forward, took hold of her, kissed her on
title: The Trial

text: the mouth and then over her whole face like a thirsty animal lapping
title: The Trial

text: with its tongue when it eventually finds water. He finally kissed her on
title: The Trial

text: her neck and her throat and left his lips pressed there for a long time.
title: The Trial

text: He did not look up until there was a noise from the captain's room.
title: The Trial

text: "I'll go now," he said, he wanted to address Miss Bürstner by her
title: The Trial

text: Christian name, but did not know it. She gave him a tired nod, offered
title: The Trial

text: him her hand to kiss as she turned away as if she did not know what she
title: The Trial

text: was doing, and went back into her room with her head bowed. A short
title: The Trial

text: while later, K. was lying in his bed. He very soon went to sleep, but
title: The Trial

text: before he did he thought a little while about his behaviour, he was
title: The Trial

text: satisfied with it but felt some surprise that he was not more satisfied;
title: The Trial

text: he was seriously worried about Miss Bürstner because of the captain.
