text: <h2 id="Chapter_Two">Chapter Two
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: First Cross-examination
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: K. was informed by telephone that there would be a small hearing
title: The Trial

text: concerning his case the following Sunday. He was made aware that these
title: The Trial

text: cross examinations would follow one another regularly, perhaps not every
title: The Trial

text: week but quite frequently. On the one hand it was in everyone's interest
title: The Trial

text: to bring proceedings quickly to their conclusion, but on the other hand
title: The Trial

text: every aspect of the examinations had to be carried out thoroughly
title: The Trial

text: without lasting too long because of the associated stress. For these
title: The Trial

text: reasons, it had been decided to hold a series of brief examinations
title: The Trial

text: following on one after another. Sunday had been chosen as the day for
title: The Trial

text: the hearings so that K. would not be disturbed in his professional work.
title: The Trial

text: It was assumed that he would be in agreement with this, but if he wished
title: The Trial

text: for another date then, as far as possible, he would be accommodated.
title: The Trial

text: Cross-examinations could even be held in the night, for instance, but K.
title: The Trial

text: would probably not be fresh enough at that time. Anyway, as long as K.
title: The Trial

text: made no objection, the hearing would be left on Sundays. It was a matter
title: The Trial

text: of course that he would have to appear without fail, there was probably
title: The Trial

text: no need to point this out to him. He would be given the number of the
title: The Trial

text: building where he was to present himself, which was in a street in a
title: The Trial

text: suburb well away from the city centre which K. had never been to before.
title: The Trial

text: Once he had received this notice, K. hung up the receiver without giving
title: The Trial

text: an answer; he had decided immediately to go there that Sunday, it was
title: The Trial

text: certainly necessary, proceedings had begun and he had to face up to it,
title: The Trial

text: and this first examination would probably also be the last. He was still
title: The Trial

text: standing in thought by the telephone when he heard the voice of the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director behind him—he wanted to use the telephone but K. stood
title: The Trial

text: in his way. "Bad news?" asked the deputy director casually, not in order
title: The Trial

text: to find anything out but just to get K. away from the device. "No, no,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., he stepped to one side but did not go away entirely. The deputy
title: The Trial

text: director picked up the receiver and, as he waited for his connection,
title: The Trial

text: turned away from it and said to K., "One question, Mr. K.: Would you
title: The Trial

text: like to give me the pleasure of joining me on my sailing boat on Sunday
title: The Trial

text: morning? There's quite a few people coming, you're bound to know some
title: The Trial

text: of them. One of them is Hasterer, the state attorney. Would you like to
title: The Trial

text: come along? Do come along!" K. tried to pay attention to what the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director was saying. It was of no small importance for him, as
title: The Trial

text: this invitation from the deputy director, with whom he had never got on
title: The Trial

text: very well, meant that he was trying to improve his relations with him.
title: The Trial

text: It showed how important K. had become in the bank and how its second
title: The Trial

text: most important official seemed to value his friendship, or at least his
title: The Trial

text: impartiality. He was only speaking at the side of the telephone receiver
title: The Trial

text: while he waited for his connection, but in giving this invitation the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director was humbling himself. But K. would have to humiliate him
title: The Trial

text: a second time as a result, he said, "Thank you very much, but I'm afraid
title: The Trial

text: I will have no time on Sunday, I have a previous obligation." "Pity,"
title: The Trial

text: said the deputy director, and turned to the telephone conversation that
title: The Trial

text: had just been connected. It was not a short conversation, but K.
title: The Trial

text: remained standing confused by the instrument all the time it was going
title: The Trial

text: on. It was only when the deputy director hung up that he was shocked
title: The Trial

text: into awareness and said, in order to partially excuse his standing there
title: The Trial

text: for no reason, "I've just received a telephone call, there's somewhere I
title: The Trial

text: need to go, but they forgot to tell me what time." "Ask them then," said
title: The Trial

text: the deputy director. "It's not that important," said K., although in
title: The Trial

text: that way his earlier excuse, already weak enough, was made even weaker.
title: The Trial

text: As he went, the deputy director continued to speak about other things.
title: The Trial

text: K. forced himself to answer, but his thoughts were mainly about that
title: The Trial

text: Sunday, how it would be best to get there for nine o'clock in the
title: The Trial

text: morning as that was the time that courts always start work on weekdays.
title: The Trial

text: The weather was dull on Sunday. K. was very tired, as he had stayed out
title: The Trial

text: drinking until late in the night celebrating with some of the regulars,
title: The Trial

text: and he had almost overslept. He dressed hurriedly, without the time to
title: The Trial

text: think and assemble the various plans he had worked out during the week.
title: The Trial

text: With no breakfast, he rushed to the suburb he had been told about. Oddly
title: The Trial

text: enough, although he had little time to look around him, he came across
title: The Trial

text: the three bank officials involved in his case, Rabensteiner, Kullich and
title: The Trial

text: Kaminer. The first two were travelling in a tram that went across K.'s
title: The Trial

text: route, but Kaminer sat on the terrace of a café and leant curiously
title: The Trial

text: over the wall as K. came over. All of them seemed to be looking at him,
title: The Trial

text: surprised at seeing their superior running; it was a kind of pride that
title: The Trial

text: made K. want to go on foot, this was his affair and the idea of any help
title: The Trial

text: from strangers, however slight, was repulsive to him, he also wanted to
title: The Trial

text: avoid asking for anyone's help because that would initiate them into the
title: The Trial

text: affair even if only slightly. And after all, he had no wish at all to
title: The Trial

text: humiliate himself before the committee by being too punctual. Anyway,
title: The Trial

text: now he was running so that he would get there by nine o'clock if at all
title: The Trial

text: possible, even though he had no appointment for this time.
title: The Trial

text: He had thought that he would recognise the building from a distance by
title: The Trial

text: some kind of sign, without knowing exactly what the sign would look
title: The Trial

text: like, or from some particular kind of activity outside the entrance. K.
title: The Trial

text: had been told that the building was in Juliusstrasse, but when he stood
title: The Trial

text: at the street's entrance it consisted on each side of almost nothing but
title: The Trial

text: monotonous, grey constructions, tall blocks of flats occupied by poor
title: The Trial

text: people. Now, on a Sunday morning, most of the windows were occupied, men
title: The Trial

text: in their shirtsleeves leant out smoking, or carefully and gently held
title: The Trial

text: small children on the sills. Other windows were piled up with bedding,
title: The Trial

text: above which the dishevelled head of a woman would briefly appear. People
title: The Trial

text: called out to each other across the street, one of the calls provoked a
title: The Trial

text: loud laugh about K. himself. It was a long street, and spaced evenly
title: The Trial

text: along it were small shops below street level, selling various kinds of
title: The Trial

text: foodstuffs, which you reached by going down a few steps. Women went in
title: The Trial

text: and out of them or stood chatting on the steps. A fruitmonger, taking
title: The Trial

text: his goods up to the windows, was just as inattentive as K. and nearly
title: The Trial

text: knocked him down with his cart. Just then, a gramophone, which in better
title: The Trial

text: parts of town would have been seen as worn out, began to play some
title: The Trial

text: murderous tune.
title: The Trial

text: K. went further into the street, slowly, as if he had plenty of time
title: The Trial

text: now, or as if the examining magistrate were looking at him from one of
title: The Trial

text: the windows and therefore knew that K. had found his way there. It was
title: The Trial

text: shortly after nine. The building was quite far down the street, it
title: The Trial

text: covered so much area it was almost extraordinary, and the gateway in
title: The Trial

text: particular was tall and long. It was clearly intended for delivery
title: The Trial

text: wagons belonging to the various warehouses all round the yard which were
title: The Trial

text: now locked up and carried the names of companies some of which K. knew
title: The Trial

text: from his work at the bank. In contrast with his usual habits, he
title: The Trial

text: remained standing a while at the entrance to the yard taking in all
title: The Trial

text: these external details. Near him, there was a bare-footed man sitting on
title: The Trial

text: a crate and reading a newspaper. There were two lads swinging on a hand
title: The Trial

text: cart. In front of a pump stood a weak, young girl in a bedjacket who, as
title: The Trial

text: the water flowed into her can, looked at K. There was a piece of rope
title: The Trial

text: stretched between two windows in a corner of the yard, with some washing
title: The Trial

text: hanging on it to dry. A man stood below it calling out instructions to
title: The Trial

text: direct the work being done.
title: The Trial

text: K. went over to the stairway to get to the room where the hearing was to
title: The Trial

text: take place, but then stood still again as besides these steps he could
title: The Trial

text: see three other stairway entrances, and there also seemed to be a small
title: The Trial

text: passageway at the end of the yard leading into a second yard. It
title: The Trial

text: irritated him that he had not been given more precise directions to the
title: The Trial

text: room, it meant they were either being especially neglectful with him or
title: The Trial

text: especially indifferent, and he decided to make that clear to them very
title: The Trial

text: loudly and very unambiguously. In the end he decided to climb up the
title: The Trial

text: stairs, his thoughts playing on something that he remembered the
title: The Trial

text: policeman, Willem, saying to him; that the court is attracted by the
title: The Trial

text: guilt, from which it followed that the courtroom must be on the stairway
title: The Trial

text: that K. selected by chance.
title: The Trial

text: As he went up he disturbed a large group of children playing on the
title: The Trial

text: stairs who looked at him as he stepped through their rows. "Next time I
title: The Trial

text: come here," he said to himself, "I must either bring sweets with me to
title: The Trial

text: make them like me or a stick to hit them with." Just before he reached
title: The Trial

text: the first landing he even had to wait a little while until a ball had
title: The Trial

text: finished its movement, two small lads with sly faces like grown-up
title: The Trial

text: scoundrels held him by his trouser-legs until it had; if he were to
title: The Trial

text: shake them off he would have to hurt them, and he was afraid of what
title: The Trial

text: noise they would make by shouting.
title: The Trial

text: On the first floor, his search began for real. He still felt unable to
title: The Trial

text: ask for the investigating committee, and so he invented a joiner called
title: The Trial

text: Lanz—that name occurred to him because the captain, Mrs. Grubach's
title: The Trial

text: nephew, was called Lanz—so that he could ask at every flat whether Lanz
title: The Trial

text: the joiner lived there and thus obtain a chance to look into the rooms.
title: The Trial

text: It turned out, though, that that was mostly possible without further
title: The Trial

text: ado, as almost all the doors were left open and the children ran in and
title: The Trial

text: out. Most of them were small, one-windowed rooms where they also did the
title: The Trial

text: cooking. Many women held babies in one arm and worked at the stove with
title: The Trial

text: the other. Half grown girls, who seemed to be dressed in just their
title: The Trial

text: pinafores worked hardest running to and fro. In every room, the beds
title: The Trial

text: were still in use by people who were ill, or still asleep, or people
title: The Trial

text: stretched out on them in their clothes. K. knocked at the flats where
title: The Trial

text: the doors were closed and asked whether Lanz the joiner lived there. It
title: The Trial

text: was usually a woman who opened the door, heard the enquiry and turned to
title: The Trial

text: somebody in the room who would raise himself from the bed. "The
title: The Trial

text: gentleman's asking if a joiner called Lanz, lives here." "A joiner,
title: The Trial

text: called Lanz?" he would ask from the bed." "That's right," K. would say,
title: The Trial

text: although it was clear that the investigating committee was not to be
title: The Trial

text: found there, and so his task was at an end. There were many who thought
title: The Trial

text: it must be very important for K. to find Lanz the joiner and thought
title: The Trial

text: long about it, naming a joiner who was not called Lanz or giving a name
title: The Trial

text: that had some vague similarity with Lanz, or they asked neighbours or
title: The Trial

text: accompanied K. to a door a long way away where they thought someone of
title: The Trial

text: that sort might live in the back part of the building or where someone
title: The Trial

text: would be who could advise K. better than they could themselves. K.
title: The Trial

text: eventually had to give up asking if he did not want to be led all round
title: The Trial

text: from floor to floor in this way. He regretted his initial plan, which
title: The Trial

text: had at first seemed so practical to him. As he reached the fifth floor,
title: The Trial

text: he decided to give up the search, took his leave of a friendly, young
title: The Trial

text: worker who wanted to lead him on still further and went down the stairs.
title: The Trial

text: But then the thought of how much time he was wasting made him cross, he
title: The Trial

text: went back again and knocked at the first door on the fifth floor. The
title: The Trial

text: first thing he saw in the small room was a large clock on the wall which
title: The Trial

text: already showed ten o'clock. "Is there a joiner called Lanz who lives
title: The Trial

text: here?" he asked. "Pardon?" said a young woman with black, shining eyes
title: The Trial

text: who was, at that moment, washing children's underclothes in a bucket.
title: The Trial

text: She pointed her wet hand towards the open door of the adjoining room.
title: The Trial

text: K. thought he had stepped into a meeting. A medium sized, two windowed
title: The Trial

text: room was filled with the most diverse crowd of people—nobody paid any
title: The Trial

text: attention to the person who had just entered. Close under its ceiling it
title: The Trial

text: was surrounded by a gallery which was also fully occupied and where the
title: The Trial

text: people could only stand bent down with their heads and their backs
title: The Trial

text: touching the ceiling. K., who found the air too stuffy, stepped out
title: The Trial

text: again and said to the young woman, who had probably misunderstood what
title: The Trial

text: he had said, "I asked for a joiner, someone by the name of Lanz." "Yes,"
title: The Trial

text: said the woman, "please go on in." K. would probably not have followed
title: The Trial

text: her if the woman had not gone up to him, taken hold of the door handle
title: The Trial

text: and said, "I'll have to close the door after you, no-one else will be
title: The Trial

text: allowed in." "Very sensible," said K., "but it's too full already." But
title: The Trial

text: then he went back in anyway. He passed through between two men who were
title: The Trial

text: talking beside the door—one of them held both hands far out in front of
title: The Trial

text: himself making the movements of counting out money, the other looked him
title: The Trial

text: closely in the eyes—and someone took him by the hand. It was a small,
title: The Trial

text: red-faced youth. "Come in, come in," he said. K. let himself be led by
title: The Trial

text: him, and it turned out that there was—surprisingly in a densely packed
title: The Trial

text: crowd of people moving to and fro—a narrow passage which may have been
title: The Trial

text: the division between two factions; this idea was reinforced by the fact
title: The Trial

text: that in the first few rows to the left and the right of him there was
title: The Trial

text: hardly any face looking in his direction, he saw nothing but the backs
title: The Trial

text: of people directing their speech and their movements only towards
title: The Trial

text: members of their own side. Most of them were dressed in black, in old,
title: The Trial

text: long, formal frock coats that hung down loosely around them. These
title: The Trial

text: clothes were the only thing that puzzled K., as he would otherwise have
title: The Trial

text: taken the whole assembly for a local political meeting.
title: The Trial

text: At the other end of the hall where K. had been led there was a little
title: The Trial

text: table set at an angle on a very low podium which was as overcrowded as
title: The Trial

text: everywhere else, and behind the table, near the edge of the podium, sat
title: The Trial

text: a small, fat, wheezing man who was talking with someone behind him. This
title: The Trial

text: second man was standing with his legs crossed and his elbows on the
title: The Trial

text: backrest of the chair, provoking much laughter. From time to time he
title: The Trial

text: threw his arm in the air as if doing a caricature of someone. The youth
title: The Trial

text: who was leading K. had some difficulty in reporting to the man. He had
title: The Trial

text: already tried twice to tell him something, standing on tiptoe, but
title: The Trial

text: without getting the man's attention as he sat there above him. It was
title: The Trial

text: only when one of the people up on the podium drew his attention to the
title: The Trial

text: youth that the man turned to him and leant down to hear what it was he
title: The Trial

text: quietly said. Then he pulled out his watch and quickly looked over at K.
title: The Trial

text: "You should have been here one hour and five minutes ago," he said. K.
title: The Trial

text: was going to give him a reply but had no time to do so, as hardly had
title: The Trial

text: the man spoken than a general muttering arose all over the right hand
title: The Trial

text: side of the hall. "You should have been here one hour and five minutes
title: The Trial

text: ago," the man now repeated, raising his voice this time, and quickly
title: The Trial

text: looked round the hall beneath him. The muttering also became immediately
title: The Trial

text: louder and, as the man said nothing more, died away only gradually. Now
title: The Trial

text: the hall was much quieter than when K. had entered. Only the people up
title: The Trial

text: in the gallery had not stopped passing remarks. As far as could be
title: The Trial

text: distinguished, up in the half-darkness, dust and haze, they seemed to be
title: The Trial

text: less well dressed than those below. Many of them had brought pillows
title: The Trial

text: that they had put between their heads and the ceiling so that they would
title: The Trial

text: not hurt themselves pressed against it.
title: The Trial

text: K. had decided he would do more watching than talking, so he did not
title: The Trial

text: defend himself for supposedly having come late, and simply said, "Well
title: The Trial

text: maybe I have arrived late, I'm here now." There followed loud applause,
title: The Trial

text: once more from the right hand side of the hall. Easy people to get on
title: The Trial

text: your side, thought K., and was bothered only by the quiet from the left
title: The Trial

text: hand side which was directly behind him and from which there was
title: The Trial

text: applause from only a few individuals. He wondered what he could say to
title: The Trial

text: get all of them to support him together or, if that were not possible,
title: The Trial

text: to at least get the support of the others for a while.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," said the man, "but I'm now no longer under any obligation to hear
title: The Trial

text: your case"—there was once more a muttering, but this time it was
title: The Trial

text: misleading as the man waved the people's objections aside with his hand
title: The Trial

text: and continued—"I will, however, as an exception, continue with it
title: The Trial

text: today. But you should never arrive late like this again. And now, step
title: The Trial

text: forward!" Someone jumped down from the podium so that there would be a
title: The Trial

text: place free for K., and K. stepped up onto it. He stood pressed closely
title: The Trial

text: against the table, the press of the crowd behind him was so great that
title: The Trial

text: he had to press back against it if he did not want to push the judge's
title: The Trial

text: desk down off the podium and perhaps the judge along with it.
title: The Trial

text: The judge, however, paid no attention to that but sat very comfortably
title: The Trial

text: on his chair and, after saying a few words to close his discussion with
title: The Trial

text: the man behind him, reached for a little note book, the only item on his
title: The Trial

text: desk. It was like an old school exercise book and had become quite
title: The Trial

text: misshapen from much thumbing. "Now then," said the judge, thumbing
title: The Trial

text: through the book. He turned to K. with the tone of someone who knows his
title: The Trial

text: facts and said, "you are a house painter?" "No," said K., "I am the
title: The Trial

text: chief clerk in a large bank." This reply was followed by laughter among
title: The Trial

text: the right hand faction down in the hall, it was so hearty that K.
title: The Trial

text: couldn't stop himself joining in with it. The people supported
title: The Trial

text: themselves with their hands on their knees and shook as if suffering a
title: The Trial

text: serious attack of coughing. Even some of those in the gallery were
title: The Trial

text: laughing. The judge had become quite cross but seemed to have no power
title: The Trial

text: over those below him in the hall, he tried to reduce what harm had been
title: The Trial

text: done in the gallery and jumped up threatening them, his eyebrows, until
title: The Trial

text: then hardly remarkable, pushed themselves up and became big, black and
title: The Trial

text: bushy over his eyes.
title: The Trial

text: The left hand side of the hall was still quiet, though, the people stood
title: The Trial

text: there in rows with their faces looking towards the podium listening to
title: The Trial

text: what was being said there, they observed the noise from the other side
title: The Trial

text: of the hall with the same quietness and even allowed some individuals
title: The Trial

text: from their own ranks, here and there, to go forward into the other
title: The Trial

text: faction. The people in the left faction were not only fewer in number
title: The Trial

text: than the right but probably were no more important than them, although
title: The Trial

text: their behaviour was calmer and that made it seem like they were. When K.
title: The Trial

text: now began to speak he was convinced he was doing it in the same way as
title: The Trial

text: them.
title: The Trial

text: "Your question, My Lord, as to whether I am a house painter—in fact
title: The Trial

text: even more than that, you did not ask at all but merely imposed it on
title: The Trial

text: me—is symptomatic of the whole way these proceedings against me are
title: The Trial

text: being carried out. Perhaps you will object that there are no proceedings
title: The Trial

text: against me. You will be quite right, as there are proceedings only if I
title: The Trial

text: acknowledge that there are. But, for the moment, I do acknowledge it,
title: The Trial

text: out of pity for yourselves to a large extent. It's impossible not to
title: The Trial

text: observe all this business without feeling pity. I don't say things are
title: The Trial

text: being done without due care but I would like to make it clear that it is
title: The Trial

text: I who make the acknowledgement."
title: The Trial

text: K. stopped speaking and looked down into the hall. He had spoken
title: The Trial

text: sharply, more sharply than he had intended, but he had been quite right.
title: The Trial

text: It should have been rewarded with some applause here and there but
title: The Trial

text: everything was quiet, they were all clearly waiting for what would
title: The Trial

text: follow, perhaps the quietness was laying the ground for an outbreak of
title: The Trial

text: activity that would bring this whole affair to an end. It was somewhat
title: The Trial

text: disturbing that just then the door at the end of the hall opened, the
title: The Trial

text: young washerwoman, who seemed to have finished her work, came in and,
title: The Trial

text: despite all her caution, attracted the attention of some of the people
title: The Trial

text: there. It was only the judge who gave K. any direct pleasure, as he
title: The Trial

text: seemed to have been immediately struck by K.'s words. Until then, he had
title: The Trial

text: listened to him standing, as K.'s speech had taken him by surprise while
title: The Trial

text: he was directing his attention to the gallery. Now, in the pause, he sat
title: The Trial

text: down very slowly, as if he did not want anyone to notice. He took out
title: The Trial

text: the notebook again, probably so that he could give the impression of
title: The Trial

text: being calmer.
title: The Trial

text: "That won't help you, sir," continued K., "even your little book will
title: The Trial

text: only confirm what I say." K. was satisfied to hear nothing but his own
title: The Trial

text: quiet words in this room full of strangers, and he even dared casually
title: The Trial

text: to pick up the examining judge's notebook and, touching it only with the
title: The Trial

text: tips of his fingers as if it were something revolting, lifted it in the
title: The Trial

text: air, holding it just by one of the middle pages so that the others on
title: The Trial

text: each side of it, closely written, blotted and yellowing, flapped down.
title: The Trial

text: "Those are the official notes of the examining judge," he said, and let
title: The Trial

text: the notebook fall down onto the desk. "You can read in your book as much
title: The Trial

text: as you like, sir, I really don't have anything in this charge book to be
title: The Trial

text: afraid of, even though I don't have access to it as I wouldn't want it
title: The Trial

text: in my hand, I can only touch it with two fingers." The judge grabbed the
title: The Trial

text: notebook from where it had fallen on the desk—which could only have
title: The Trial

text: been a sign of his deep humiliation, or at least that is how it must
title: The Trial

text: have been perceived—tried to tidy it up a little, and held it once more
title: The Trial

text: in front of himself in order to read from it.
title: The Trial

text: The people in the front row looked up at him, showing such tension on
title: The Trial

text: their faces that he looked back down at them for some time. Every one of
title: The Trial

text: them was an old man, some of them with white beards. Could they perhaps
title: The Trial

text: be the crucial group who could turn the whole assembly one way or the
title: The Trial

text: other. They had sunk into a state of motionlessness while K. gave his
title: The Trial

text: oration, and it had not been possible to raise them from this passivity
title: The Trial

text: even when the judge was being humiliated. "What has happened to me,"
title: The Trial

text: continued K., with less of the vigour he had had earlier, he continually
title: The Trial

text: scanned the faces in the first row, and this gave his address a somewhat
title: The Trial

text: nervous and distracted character, "what has happened to me is not just
title: The Trial

text: an isolated case. If it were it would not be of much importance as it's
title: The Trial

text: not of much importance to me, but it is a symptom of proceedings which
title: The Trial

text: are carried out against many. It's on behalf of them that I stand here
title: The Trial

text: now, not for myself alone."
title: The Trial

text: Without having intended it, he had raised his voice. Somewhere in the
title: The Trial

text: hall, someone raised his hands and applauded him shouting, "Bravo! Why
title: The Trial

text: not then? Bravo! Again I say, Bravo!" Some of the men in the first row
title: The Trial

text: groped around in their beards, none of them looked round to see who was
title: The Trial

text: shouting. Not even K. thought him of any importance but it did raise his
title: The Trial

text: spirits; he no longer thought it at all necessary that all of those in
title: The Trial

text: the hall should applaud him, it was enough if the majority of them began
title: The Trial

text: to think about the matter and if only one of them, now and then, was
title: The Trial

text: persuaded.
title: The Trial

text: "I'm not trying to be a successful orator," said K. after this thought,
title: The Trial

text: "that's probably more than I'm capable of anyway. I'm sure the examining
title: The Trial

text: judge can speak far better than I can, it is part of his job after all.
title: The Trial

text: All that I want is a public discussion of a public wrong. Listen: ten
title: The Trial

text: days ago I was placed under arrest, the arrest itself is something I
title: The Trial

text: laugh about but that's beside the point. They came for me in the morning
title: The Trial

text: when I was still in bed. Maybe the order had been given to arrest some
title: The Trial

text: house painter—that seems possible after what the judge has
title: The Trial

text: said—someone who is as innocent as I am, but it was me they chose.
title: The Trial

text: There were two police thugs occupying the next room. They could not have
title: The Trial

text: taken better precautions if I had been a dangerous robber. And these
title: The Trial

text: policemen were unprincipled riff-raff, they talked at me till I was sick
title: The Trial

text: of it, they wanted bribes, they wanted to trick me into giving them my
title: The Trial

text: clothes, they wanted money, supposedly so that they could bring me my
title: The Trial

text: breakfast after they had blatantly eaten my own breakfast in front of my
title: The Trial

text: eyes. And even that was not enough. I was led in front of the supervisor
title: The Trial

text: in another room. This was the room of a lady who I have a lot of respect
title: The Trial

text: for, and I was forced to look on while the supervisor and the policemen
title: The Trial

text: made quite a mess of this room because of me, although not through any
title: The Trial

text: fault of mine. It was not easy to stay calm, but I managed to do so and
title: The Trial

text: was completely calm when I asked the supervisor why it was that I was
title: The Trial

text: under arrest. If he were here he would have to confirm what I say. I can
title: The Trial

text: see him now, sitting on the chair belonging to that lady I mentioned—a
title: The Trial

text: picture of dull-witted arrogance. What do you think he answered? What
title: The Trial

text: he told me, gentlemen, was basically nothing at all; perhaps he really
title: The Trial

text: did know nothing, he had placed me under arrest and was satisfied. In
title: The Trial

text: fact he had done more than that and brought three junior employees from
title: The Trial

text: the bank where I work into the lady's room; they had made themselves
title: The Trial

text: busy interfering with some photographs that belonged to the lady and
title: The Trial

text: causing a mess. There was, of course, another reason for bringing these
title: The Trial

text: employees; they, just like my landlady and her maid, were expected to
title: The Trial

text: spread the news of my arrest and damage my public reputation and in
title: The Trial

text: particular to remove me from my position at the bank. Well they didn't
title: The Trial

text: succeed in any of that, not in the slightest, even my landlady, who is
title: The Trial

text: quite a simple person—and I will give you here her name in full
title: The Trial

text: respect, her name is Mrs. Grubach—even Mrs. Grubach was understanding
title: The Trial

text: enough to see that an arrest like this has no more significance than an
title: The Trial

text: attack carried out on the street by some youths who are not kept under
title: The Trial

text: proper control. I repeat, this whole affair has caused me nothing but
title: The Trial

text: unpleasantness and temporary irritation, but could it not also have had
title: The Trial

text: some far worse consequences?"
title: The Trial

text: K. broke off here and looked at the judge, who said nothing. As he did
title: The Trial

text: so he thought he saw the judge use a movement of his eyes to give a sign
title: The Trial

text: to someone in the crowd. K. smiled and said, "And now the judge, right
title: The Trial

text: next to me, is giving a secret sign to someone among you. There seems to
title: The Trial

text: be someone among you who is taking directions from above. I don't know
title: The Trial

text: whether the sign is meant to produce booing or applause, but I'll resist
title: The Trial

text: trying to guess what its meaning is too soon. It really doesn't matter
title: The Trial

text: to me, and I give his lordship the judge my full and public permission
title: The Trial

text: to stop giving secret signs to his paid subordinate down there and give
title: The Trial

text: his orders in words instead; let him just say 'Boo now!,' and then the
title: The Trial

text: next time 'Clap now!'"
title: The Trial

text: Whether it was embarrassment or impatience, the judge rocked backwards
title: The Trial

text: and forwards on his seat. The man behind him, whom he had been talking
title: The Trial

text: with earlier, leant forward again, either to give him a few general
title: The Trial

text: words of encouragement or some specific piece of advice. Below them in
title: The Trial

text: the hall the people talked to each other quietly but animatedly. The two
title: The Trial

text: factions had earlier seemed to hold views strongly opposed to each other
title: The Trial

text: but now they began to intermingle, a few individuals pointed up at K.,
title: The Trial

text: others pointed at the judge. The air in the room was fuggy and extremely
title: The Trial

text: oppressive, those who were standing furthest away could hardly even be
title: The Trial

text: seen through it. It must have been especially troublesome for those
title: The Trial

text: visitors who were in the gallery, as they were forced to quietly ask
title: The Trial

text: the participants in the assembly what exactly was happening, albeit
title: The Trial

text: with timid glances at the judge. The replies they received were just as
title: The Trial

text: quiet, and given behind the protection of a raised hand.
title: The Trial

text: "I have nearly finished what I have to say," said K., and as there was
title: The Trial

text: no bell available he struck the desk with his fist in a way that
title: The Trial

text: startled the judge and his advisor and made them look up from each
title: The Trial

text: other. "None of this concerns me, and I am therefore able to make a calm
title: The Trial

text: assessment of it, and, assuming that this so-called court is of any real
title: The Trial

text: importance, it will be very much to your advantage to listen to what I
title: The Trial

text: have to say. If you want to discuss what I say, please don't bother to
title: The Trial

text: write it down until later on, I don't have any time to waste and I'll
title: The Trial

text: soon be leaving."
title: The Trial

text: There was immediate silence, which showed how well K. was in control of
title: The Trial

text: the crowd. There were no shouts among them as there had been at the
title: The Trial

text: start, no-one even applauded, but if they weren't already persuaded they
title: The Trial

text: seemed very close to it.
title: The Trial

text: K. was pleased at the tension among all the people there as they
title: The Trial

text: listened to him, a rustling rose from the silence which was more
title: The Trial

text: invigorating than the most ecstatic applause could have been. "There is
title: The Trial

text: no doubt," he said quietly, "that there is some enormous organisation
title: The Trial

text: determining what is said by this court. In my case this includes my
title: The Trial

text: arrest and the examination taking place here today, an organisation that
title: The Trial

text: employs policemen who can be bribed, oafish supervisors and judges of
title: The Trial

text: whom nothing better can be said than that they are not as arrogant as
title: The Trial

text: some others. This organisation even maintains a high-level judiciary
title: The Trial

text: along with its train of countless servants, scribes, policemen and all
title: The Trial

text: the other assistance that it needs, perhaps even executioners and
title: The Trial

text: torturers—I'm not afraid of using those words. And what, gentlemen, is
title: The Trial

text: the purpose of this enormous organisation. Its purpose is to arrest
title: The Trial

text: innocent people and wage pointless prosecutions against them which, as
title: The Trial

text: in my case, lead to no result. How are we to avoid those in office
title: The Trial

text: becoming deeply corrupt when everything is devoid of meaning? That is
title: The Trial

text: impossible, not even the highest judge would be able to achieve that for
title: The Trial

text: himself. That is why policemen try to steal the clothes off the back of
title: The Trial

text: those they arrest, that is why supervisors break into the homes of
title: The Trial

text: people they do not know, that is why innocent people are humiliated in
title: The Trial

text: front of crowds rather than being given a proper trial. The policemen
title: The Trial

text: only talked about the warehouses where they put the property of those
title: The Trial

text: they arrest, I would like to see these warehouses where the hard won
title: The Trial

text: possessions of people under arrest is left to decay, if, that is, it's
title: The Trial

text: not stolen by the thieving hands of the warehouse workers."
title: The Trial

text: K. was interrupted by a screeching from the far end of the hall, he
title: The Trial

text: shaded his eyes to see that far, as the dull light of day made the smoke
title: The Trial

text: whitish and hard to see through. It was the washerwoman whom K. had
title: The Trial

text: recognised as a likely source of disturbance as soon as she had entered.
title: The Trial

text: It was hard to see now whether it was her fault or not. K. could only
title: The Trial

text: see that a man had pulled her into a corner by the door and was pressing
title: The Trial

text: himself against her. But it was not her who was screaming, but the man,
title: The Trial

text: he had opened his mouth wide and looked up at the ceiling. A small
title: The Trial

text: circle had formed around the two of them, the visitors near him in the
title: The Trial

text: gallery seemed delighted that the serious tone K. had introduced into
title: The Trial

text: the gathering had been disturbed in this way. K.'s first thought was to
title: The Trial

text: run over there, and he also thought that everyone would want to bring
title: The Trial

text: things back into order there or at least to make the pair leave the
title: The Trial

text: room, but the first row of people in front of him stayed were they were,
title: The Trial

text: no-one moved and no-one let K. through. On the contrary, they stood in
title: The Trial

text: his way, old men held out their arms in front of him and a hand from
title: The Trial

text: somewhere—he did not have the time to turn round—took hold of his
title: The Trial

text: collar. K., by this time, had forgotten about the pair, it seemed to him
title: The Trial

text: that his freedom was being limited as if his arrest was being taken
title: The Trial

text: seriously, and, without any thought for what he was doing, he jumped
title: The Trial

text: down from the podium. Now he stood face to face with the crowd. Had he
title: The Trial

text: judged the people properly? Had he put too much faith in the effect of
title: The Trial

text: his speech? Had they been putting up a pretence all the time he had
title: The Trial

text: been speaking, and now that he came to the end and to what must follow,
title: The Trial

text: were they tired of pretending? What faces they were, all around him!
title: The Trial

text: Dark, little eyes flickered here and there, cheeks drooped down like on
title: The Trial

text: drunken men, their long beards were thin and stiff, if they took hold of
title: The Trial

text: them it was more like they were making their hands into claws, not as if
title: The Trial

text: they were taking hold of their own beards. But underneath those
title: The Trial

text: beards—and this was the real discovery made by K.—there were badges of
title: The Trial

text: various sizes and colours shining on the collars of their coats. As far
title: The Trial

text: as he could see, every one of them was wearing one of these badges. All
title: The Trial

text: of them belonged to the same group, even though they seemed to be
title: The Trial

text: divided to the right and the left of him, and when he suddenly turned
title: The Trial

text: round he saw the same badge on the collar of the examining judge who
title: The Trial

text: calmly looked down at him with his hands in his lap. "So," called out
title: The Trial

text: K., throwing his arms in the air as if this sudden realisation needed
title: The Trial

text: more room, "all of you are working for this organisation, I see now that
title: The Trial

text: you are all the very bunch of cheats and liars I've just been speaking
title: The Trial

text: about, you've all pressed yourselves in here in order to listen in and
title: The Trial

text: snoop on me, you gave the impression of having formed into factions, one
title: The Trial

text: of you even applauded me to test me out, and you wanted to learn how to
title: The Trial

text: trap an innocent man! Well, I hope you haven't come here for nothing, I
title: The Trial

text: hope you've either had some fun from someone who expected you to defend
title: The Trial

text: his innocence or else—let go of me or I'll hit you," shouted K. to a
title: The Trial

text: quivery old man who had pressed himself especially close to him—"or
title: The Trial

text: else that you've actually learned something. And so I wish you good luck
title: The Trial

text: in your trade." He briskly took his hat from where it lay on the edge of
title: The Trial

text: the table and, surrounded by a silence caused perhaps by the
title: The Trial

text: completeness of their surprise, pushed his way to the exit. However, the
title: The Trial

text: examining judge seems to have moved even more quickly than K., as he was
title: The Trial

text: waiting for him at the doorway. "One moment," he said. K. stood where he
title: The Trial

text: was, but looked at the door with his hand already on its handle rather
title: The Trial

text: than at the judge. "I merely wanted to draw your attention," said the
title: The Trial

text: judge, "to something you seem not yet to be aware of: today, you have
title: The Trial

text: robbed yourself of the advantages that a hearing of this sort always
title: The Trial

text: gives to someone who is under arrest." K. laughed towards the door. "You
title: The Trial

text: bunch of louts," he called, "you can keep all your hearings as a present
title: The Trial

text: from me," then opened the door and hurried down the steps. Behind him,
title: The Trial

text: the noise of the assembly rose as it became lively once more and
title: The Trial

text: probably began to discuss these events as if making a scientific study
title: The Trial

text: of them.

text: In the empty Courtroom—The Student—The Offices
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Every day over the following week, K. expected another summons to
title: The Trial

text: arrive, he could not believe that his rejection of any more hearings had
title: The Trial

text: been taken literally, and when the expected summons really had not come
title: The Trial

text: by Saturday evening he took it to mean that he was expected, without
title: The Trial

text: being told, to appear at the same place at the same time. So on Sunday,
title: The Trial

text: he set out once more in the same direction, going without hesitation up
title: The Trial

text: the steps and through the corridors; some of the people remembered him
title: The Trial

text: and greeted him from their doorways, but he no longer needed to ask
title: The Trial

text: anyone the way and soon arrived at the right door. It was opened as soon
title: The Trial

text: as he knocked and, paying no attention to the woman he had seen last
title: The Trial

text: time who was standing at the doorway, he was about to go straight into
title: The Trial

text: the adjoining room when she said to him "There's no session today."
title: The Trial

text: "What do you mean; no session?" he asked, unable to believe it. But the
title: The Trial

text: woman persuaded him by opening the door to the next room. It was indeed
title: The Trial

text: empty, and looked even more dismal empty than it had the previous
title: The Trial

text: Sunday. On the podium stood the table exactly as it had been before with
title: The Trial

text: a few books laying on it. "Can I have a look at those books?" asked K.,
title: The Trial

text: not because he was especially curious but so that he would not have come
title: The Trial

text: for nothing. "No," said the woman as she re-closed the door, "that's not
title: The Trial

text: allowed. Those books belong to the examining judge." "I see," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: and nodded, "those books must be law books, and that's how this court
title: The Trial

text: does things, not only to try people who are innocent but even to try
title: The Trial

text: them without letting them know what's going on." "I expect you're
title: The Trial

text: right," said the woman, who had not understood exactly what he meant.
title: The Trial

text: "I'd better go away again, then," said K. "Should I give a message to
title: The Trial

text: the examining judge?" asked the woman. "Do you know him, then?" asked K.
title: The Trial

text: "Of course I know him," said the woman, "my husband is the court usher."
title: The Trial

text: It was only now that K. noticed that the room, which before had held
title: The Trial

text: nothing but a wash-tub, had been fitted out as a living room. The woman
title: The Trial

text: saw how surprised he was and said, "Yes, we're allowed to live here as
title: The Trial

text: we like, only we have to clear the room out when the court's in session.
title: The Trial

text: There's lots of disadvantages to my husband's job." "It's not so much
title: The Trial

text: the room that surprises me," said K., looking at her crossly, "it's your
title: The Trial

text: being married that shocks me." "Are you thinking about what happened
title: The Trial

text: last time the court was in session, when I disturbed what you were
title: The Trial

text: saying?" asked the woman. "Of course," said K., "it's in the past now
title: The Trial

text: and I've nearly forgotten about it, but at the time it made me furious.
title: The Trial

text: And now you tell me yourself that you are a married woman." "It wasn't
title: The Trial

text: any disadvantage for you to have your speech interrupted. The way they
title: The Trial

text: talked about you after you'd gone was really bad." "That could well be,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., turning away, "but it does not excuse you." "There's no-one I
title: The Trial

text: know who'd hold it against me," said the woman. "Him, who put his arms
title: The Trial

text: around me, he's been chasing after me for a long time. I might not be
title: The Trial

text: very attractive for most people, but I am for him. I've got no
title: The Trial

text: protection from him, even my husband has had to get used to it; if he
title: The Trial

text: wants to keep his job he's got to put up with it as that man's a student
title: The Trial

text: and he'll almost certainly be very powerful later on. He's always after
title: The Trial

text: me, he'd only just left when you arrived." "That fits in with everything
title: The Trial

text: else," said K., "I'm not surprised." "Do you want to make things a bit
title: The Trial

text: better here?" the woman asked slowly, watching him as if she were saying
title: The Trial

text: something that could be as dangerous for K. as for herself. "That's what
title: The Trial

text: I thought when I heard you speak, I really liked what you said. Mind
title: The Trial

text: you, I only heard part of it, I missed the beginning of it and at the
title: The Trial

text: end I was lying on the floor with the student—it's so horrible here,"
title: The Trial

text: she said after a pause, and took hold of K.'s hand. "Do you believe you
title: The Trial

text: really will be able to make things better?" K. smiled and twisted his
title: The Trial

text: hand round a little in her soft hands. "It's really not my job to make
title: The Trial

text: things better here, as you put it," he said, "and if you said that to
title: The Trial

text: the examining judge he would laugh at you or punish you for it. I really
title: The Trial

text: would not have become involved in this matter if I could have helped it,
title: The Trial

text: and I would have lost no sleep worrying about how this court needs to be
title: The Trial

text: made better. But because I'm told that I have been arrested—and I am
title: The Trial

text: under arrest—it forces me to take some action, and to do so for my own
title: The Trial

text: sake. However, if I can be of some service to you in the process I will,
title: The Trial

text: of course, be glad to do so. And I will be glad to do so not only for
title: The Trial

text: the sake of charity but also because you can be of some help to me."
title: The Trial

text: "How could I help you, then?" said the woman. "You could, for example,
title: The Trial

text: show me the books on the table there." "Yes, certainly," the woman
title: The Trial

text: cried, and pulled K. along behind her as she rushed to them. The books
title: The Trial

text: were old and well worn, the cover of one of them had nearly broken
title: The Trial

text: through in its middle, and it was held together with a few threads.
title: The Trial

text: "Everything is so dirty here," said K., shaking his head, and before he
title: The Trial

text: could pick the books up the woman wiped some of the dust off with her
title: The Trial

text: apron. K. took hold of the book that lay on top and threw it open, an
title: The Trial

text: indecent picture appeared. A man and a woman sat naked on a sofa, the
title: The Trial

text: base intent of whoever drew it was easy to see but he had been so
title: The Trial

text: grossly lacking in skill that all that anyone could really make out were
title: The Trial

text: the man and the woman who dominated the picture with their bodies,
title: The Trial

text: sitting in overly upright postures that created a false perspective and
title: The Trial

text: made it difficult for them to approach each other. K. didn't thumb
title: The Trial

text: through that book any more, but just threw open the next one at its
title: The Trial

text: title page, it was a novel with the title, What Grete Suffered from her
title: The Trial

text: Husband, Hans. "So this is the sort of law book they study here," said
title: The Trial

text: K., "this is the sort of person sitting in judgement over me." "I can
title: The Trial

text: help you," said the woman, "would you like me to?" "Could you really do
title: The Trial

text: that without placing yourself in danger? You did say earlier on that
title: The Trial

text: your husband is wholly dependent on his superiors." "I still want to
title: The Trial

text: help you," said the woman, "come over here, we've got to talk about it.
title: The Trial

text: Don't say any more about what danger I'm in, I only fear danger where I
title: The Trial

text: want to fear it. Come over here." She pointed to the podium and invited
title: The Trial

text: him to sit down on the step with her. "You've got lovely dark eyes," she
title: The Trial

text: said after they had sat down, looking up into K.'s face, "people say
title: The Trial

text: I've got nice eyes too, but yours are much nicer. It was the first thing
title: The Trial

text: I noticed when you first came here. That's even why I came in here, into
title: The Trial

text: the assembly room, afterwards, I'd never normally do that, I'm not
title: The Trial

text: really even allowed to." So that's what all this is about, thought K.,
title: The Trial

text: she's offering herself to me, she's as degenerate as everything else
title: The Trial

text: around here, she's had enough of the court officials, which is
title: The Trial

text: understandable I suppose, and so she approaches any stranger and makes
title: The Trial

text: compliments about his eyes. With that, K. stood up in silence as if he
title: The Trial

text: had spoken his thoughts out loud and thus explained his action to the
title: The Trial

text: woman. "I don't think you can be of any assistance to me," he said, "to
title: The Trial

text: be of any real assistance you would need to be in contact with high
title: The Trial

text: officials. But I'm sure you only know the lower employees, and there are
title: The Trial

text: crowds of them milling about here. I'm sure you're very familiar with
title: The Trial

text: them and could achieve a great deal through them, I've no doubt of that,
title: The Trial

text: but the most that could be done through them would have no bearing at
title: The Trial

text: all on the final outcome of the trial. You, on the other hand, would
title: The Trial

text: lose some of your friends as a result, and I have no wish of that. Carry
title: The Trial

text: on with these people in the same way as you have been, as it does seem
title: The Trial

text: to me to be something you cannot do without. I have no regrets in saying
title: The Trial

text: this as, in return for your compliment to me, I also find you rather
title: The Trial

text: attractive, especially when you look at me as sadly as you are now,
title: The Trial

text: although you really have no reason to do so. You belong to the people I
title: The Trial

text: have to combat, and you're very comfortable among them, you're even in
title: The Trial

text: love with the student, or if you don't love him you do at least prefer
title: The Trial

text: him to your husband. It's easy to see that from what you've been
title: The Trial

text: saying." "No!" she shouted, remained sitting where she was and grasped
title: The Trial

text: K.'s hand, which he failed to pull away fast enough. "You can't go away
title: The Trial

text: now, you can't go away when you've misjudged me like that! Are you
title: The Trial

text: really capable of going away now? Am I really so worthless that you
title: The Trial

text: won't even do me the favour of staying a little bit longer?" "You
title: The Trial

text: misunderstand me," said K., sitting back down, "if it's really important
title: The Trial

text: to you for me to stay here then I'll be glad to do so, I have plenty of
title: The Trial

text: time, I came here thinking there would be a trial taking place. All I
title: The Trial

text: meant with what I said just now was to ask you not to do anything on my
title: The Trial

text: behalf in the proceedings against me. But even that is nothing for you
title: The Trial

text: to worry about when you consider that there's nothing hanging on the
title: The Trial

text: outcome of this trial, and that, whatever the verdict, I will just laugh
title: The Trial

text: at it. And that's even presupposing it ever even reaches any conclusion,
title: The Trial

text: which I very much doubt. I think it's much more likely that the court
title: The Trial

text: officials will be too lazy, too forgetful, or even too fearful ever to
title: The Trial

text: continue with these proceedings and that they will soon be abandoned if
title: The Trial

text: they haven't been abandoned already. It's even possible that they will
title: The Trial

text: pretend to be carrying on with the trial in the hope of receiving a
title: The Trial

text: large bribe, although I can tell you now that that will be quite in vain
title: The Trial

text: as I pay bribes to no-one. Perhaps one favour you could do me would be
title: The Trial

text: to tell the examining judge, or anyone else who likes to spread
title: The Trial

text: important news, that I will never be induced to pay any sort of bribe
title: The Trial

text: through any stratagem of theirs—and I'm sure they have many stratagems
title: The Trial

text: at their disposal. There is no prospect of that, you can tell them that
title: The Trial

text: quite openly. And what's more, I expect they have already noticed
title: The Trial

text: themselves, or even if they haven't, this affair is really not so
title: The Trial

text: important to me as they think. Those gentlemen would only save some work
title: The Trial

text: for themselves, or at least some unpleasantness for me, which, however,
title: The Trial

text: I am glad to endure if I know that each piece of unpleasantness for me
title: The Trial

text: is a blow against them. And I will make quite sure it is a blow against
title: The Trial

text: them. Do you actually know the judge?" "Course I do," said the woman,
title: The Trial

text: "he was the first one I thought of when I offered to help you. I didn't
title: The Trial

text: know he's only a minor official, but if you say so it must be true. Mind
title: The Trial

text: you, I still think the report he gives to his superiors must have some
title: The Trial

text: influence. And he writes so many reports. You say these officials are
title: The Trial

text: lazy, but they're certainly not all lazy, especially this examining
title: The Trial

text: judge, he writes ever such a lot. Last Sunday, for instance, that
title: The Trial

text: session went on till the evening. Everyone had gone, but the examining
title: The Trial

text: judge, he stayed in the hall, I had to bring him a lamp in, all I had
title: The Trial

text: was a little kitchen lamp but he was very satisfied with it and started
title: The Trial

text: to write straight away. Meantime my husband arrived, he always has the
title: The Trial

text: day off on Sundays, we got the furniture back in and got our room sorted
title: The Trial

text: out and then a few of the neighbours came, we sat and talked for a bit
title: The Trial

text: by a candle, in short, we forgot all about the examining judge and went
title: The Trial

text: to bed. All of a sudden in the night, it must have been quite late in
title: The Trial

text: the night, I wakes up, next to the bed, there's the examining judge
title: The Trial

text: shading the lamp with his hand so that there's no light from it falls on
title: The Trial

text: my husband, he didn't need to be as careful as that, the way my husband
title: The Trial

text: sleeps the light wouldn't have woken him up anyway. I was quite shocked
title: The Trial

text: and nearly screamed, but the judge was very friendly, warned me I should
title: The Trial

text: be careful, he whispered to me he's been writing all this time, and now
title: The Trial

text: he's brought me the lamp back, and he'll never forget how I looked when
title: The Trial

text: he found me there asleep. What I mean, with all this, I just wanted to
title: The Trial

text: tell you how the examining judge really does write lots of reports,
title: The Trial

text: especially about you as questioning you was definitely one of the main

text: things on the agenda that Sunday. If he writes reports as long as that
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: when he's first begun to notice me, that I can have a lot of influence
title: The Trial

text: on him. And I've got other proof I mean a lot to him, too. Yesterday, he
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: paid for. Nice stockings, they are, look,"—she stretched out her leg,
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: She suddenly interrupted herself and lay her hand on K.'s as if she
title: The Trial

text: wanted to calm him down, and whispered, "Be quiet, Berthold is watching
title: The Trial

text: us." K. slowly looked up. In the doorway to the courtroom stood a young
title: The Trial

text: man, he was short, his legs were not quite straight, and he continually
title: The Trial

text: moved his finger round in a short, thin, red beard with which he hoped
title: The Trial

text: to make himself look dignified. K. looked at him with some curiosity, he
title: The Trial

text: was the first student he had ever met of the unfamiliar discipline of
title: The Trial

text: jurisprudence, face to face at least, a man who would even most likely
title: The Trial

text: attain high office one day. The student, in contrast, seemed to take no
title: The Trial

text: notice of K. at all, he merely withdrew his finger from his beard long
title: The Trial

text: enough to beckon to the woman and went over to the window, the woman
title: The Trial

text: leant over to K. and whispered, "Don't be cross with me, please don't,
title: The Trial

text: and please don't think ill of me either, I've got to go to him now, to
title: The Trial

text: this horrible man, just look at his bent legs. But I'll come straight
title: The Trial

text: back and then I'll go with you if you'll take me, I'll go wherever you
title: The Trial

text: want, you can do whatever you like with me, I'll be happy if I can be
title: The Trial

text: away from here for as long as possible, it'd be best if I could get away
title: The Trial

text: from here for good." She stroked K.'s hand once more, jumped up and ran
title: The Trial

text: over to the window. Before he realised it, K. grasped for her hand but
title: The Trial

text: failed to catch it. He really was attracted to the woman, and even after
title: The Trial

text: thinking hard about it could find no good reason why he should not give
title: The Trial

text: in to her allure. It briefly crossed his mind that the woman meant to
title: The Trial

text: entrap him on behalf of the court, but that was an objection he had no
title: The Trial

text: difficulty in fending off. In what way could she entrap him? Was he not
title: The Trial

text: still free, so free that he could crush the entire court whenever he
title: The Trial

text: wanted, at least where it concerned him? Could he not have that much
title: The Trial

text: confidence in himself? And her offer of help sounded sincere, and maybe
title: The Trial

text: it wasn't quite worthless. And maybe there was no better revenge against
title: The Trial

text: the examining judge and his cronies than to take this woman from him and
title: The Trial

text: have her for himself. Maybe then, after much hard work writing dishonest
title: The Trial

text: reports about K., the judge would go to the woman's bed late one night
title: The Trial

text: and find it empty. And it would be empty because she belonged to K.,
title: The Trial

text: because this woman at the window, this lush, supple, warm body in its
title: The Trial

text: sombre clothes of rough, heavy material belonged to him, totally to him
title: The Trial

text: and to him alone. Once he had settled his thoughts towards the woman in
title: The Trial

text: this way, he began to find the quiet conversation at the window was
title: The Trial

text: taking too long, he rapped on the podium with his knuckles, and then
title: The Trial

text: even with his fist. The student briefly looked away from the woman to
title: The Trial

text: glance at K. over his shoulder but did allow himself to be disturbed, in
title: The Trial

text: fact he even pressed himself close to the woman and put his arms around
title: The Trial

text: her. She dropped her head down low as if listening to him carefully, as
title: The Trial

text: she did so he kissed her right on the neck, hardly even interrupting
title: The Trial

text: what he was saying. K. saw this as confirmation of the tyranny the
title: The Trial

text: student held over the woman and which she had already complained about,
title: The Trial

text: he stood up and walked up and down the room. Glancing sideways at the
title: The Trial

text: student, he wondered what would be the quickest possible way to get rid
title: The Trial

text: of him, and so it was not unwelcome to him when the student, clearly
title: The Trial

text: disturbed by K.'s to-ing and fro-ing which K. had now developed into a
title: The Trial

text: stamping up and down, said to him, "You don't have to stay here, you
title: The Trial

text: know, if you're getting impatient. You could have gone earlier, no-one
title: The Trial

text: would have missed you. In fact you should have gone, you should have
title: The Trial

text: left as quickly as possible as soon as I got here." This comment could
title: The Trial

text: have caused all possible rage to break out between them, but K. also
title: The Trial

text: bore in mind that this was a prospective court official speaking to a
title: The Trial

text: disfavoured defendant, and he might well have been taking pride in
title: The Trial

text: speaking in this way. K. remained standing quite close to him and said
title: The Trial

text: with a smile, "You're quite right, I am impatient, but the easiest way
title: The Trial

text: to settle this impatience would be if you left us. On the other hand,
title: The Trial

text: if you've come here to study—you are a student, I hear—I'll be quite
title: The Trial

text: happy to leave the room to you and go away with the woman. I'm sure
title: The Trial

text: you'll still have a lot of study to do before you're made into a judge.
title: The Trial

text: It's true that I'm still not all that familiar with your branch of
title: The Trial

text: jurisprudence but I take it it involves a lot more than speaking
title: The Trial

text: roughly—and I see you have no shame in doing that extremely well." "He
title: The Trial

text: shouldn't have been allowed to move about so freely," said the student,
title: The Trial

text: as if he wanted to give the woman an explanation for K.'s insults, "that
title: The Trial

text: was a mistake. I've told the examining judge so. He should at least have
title: The Trial

text: been detained in his room between hearings. Sometimes it's impossible to
title: The Trial

text: understand what the judge thinks he's doing." "You're wasting your
title: The Trial

text: breath," said K., then he reached his hand out towards the woman and
title: The Trial

text: said, "come with me." "So that's it," said the student, "oh no, you're
title: The Trial

text: not going to get her," and with a strength you would not have expected
title: The Trial

text: from him, he glanced tenderly at her, lifted her up on one arm and, his
title: The Trial

text: back bent under the weight, ran with her to the door. In this way he
title: The Trial

text: showed, unmistakably, that he was to some extent afraid of K., but he
title: The Trial

text: nonetheless dared to provoke him still further by stroking and squeezing
title: The Trial

text: the woman's arm with his free hand. K. ran the few steps up to him, but
title: The Trial

text: when he had reached him and was about to take hold of him and, if
title: The Trial

text: necessary, throttle him, the woman said, "It's no good, it's the
title: The Trial
