title: The Trial

text: bastard ..." and here she ran her hand over the student's face, "this
title: The Trial

text: little bastard won't let me." "And you don't want to be set free!"
title: The Trial

text: shouted K., laying his hand on the student's shoulder, who then snapped
title: The Trial

text: at it with his teeth. "No!" shouted the woman, pushing K. away with both
title: The Trial

text: hands, "no, no don't do that, what d'you think you're doing? That'd be
title: The Trial

text: the end of me. Let go of him, please just let go of him. He's only
title: The Trial

text: carrying out the judge's orders, he's carrying me to him." "Let him take
title: The Trial

text: you then, and I want to see nothing more of you," said K., enraged by
title: The Trial

text: his disappointment and giving the student a thump in the back so that he
title: The Trial

text: briefly stumbled and then, glad that he had not fallen, immediately
title: The Trial

text: jumped up all the higher with his burden. K. followed them slowly. He
title: The Trial

text: realised that this was the first unambiguous setback he had suffered
title: The Trial

text: from these people. It was of course nothing to worry about, he accepted
title: The Trial

text: the setback only because he was looking for a fight. If he stayed at
title: The Trial

text: home and carried on with his normal life he would be a thousand times
title: The Trial

text: superior to these people and could get any of them out of his way just
title: The Trial

text: with a kick. And he imagined the most laughable scene possible as an
title: The Trial

text: example of this, if this contemptible student, this inflated child, this
title: The Trial

text: knock-kneed redbeard, if he were kneeling at Elsa's bed wringing his
title: The Trial

text: hands and begging for forgiveness. K. so enjoyed imagining this scene
title: The Trial

text: that he decided to take the student along to Elsa with him if ever he
title: The Trial

text: should get the opportunity.
title: The Trial

text: K. was curious to see where the woman would be taken and he hurried over
title: The Trial

text: to the door, the student was not likely to carry her through the streets
title: The Trial

text: on his arm. It turned out that the journey was far shorter. Directly
title: The Trial

text: opposite the flat there was a narrow flight of wooden steps which
title: The Trial

text: probably led up to the attic, they turned as they went so that it was
title: The Trial

text: not possible to see where they ended. The student carried the woman up
title: The Trial

text: these steps, and after the exertions of running with her he was soon
title: The Trial

text: groaning and moving very slowly. The woman waved down at K. and by
title: The Trial

text: raising and lowering her shoulders she tried to show that she was an
title: The Trial

text: innocent party in this abduction, although the gesture did not show a
title: The Trial

text: lot of regret. K. watched her without expression like a stranger, he
title: The Trial

text: wanted to show neither that he was disappointed nor that he would easily
title: The Trial

text: get over his disappointment.
title: The Trial

text: The two of them had disappeared, but K. remained standing in the
title: The Trial

text: doorway. He had to accept that the woman had not only cheated him but
title: The Trial

text: that she had also lied to him when she said she was being taken to the
title: The Trial

text: examining judge. The examining judge certainly wouldn't be sitting and
title: The Trial

text: waiting in the attic. The wooden stairs would explain nothing to him
title: The Trial

text: however long he stared at them. Then K. noticed a small piece of paper
title: The Trial

text: next to them, went across to it and read, in a childish and unpractised
title: The Trial

text: hand, "Entrance to the Court Offices". Were the court offices here, in
title: The Trial

text: the attic of this tenement, then? If that was how they were
title: The Trial

text: accommodated it did not attract much respect, and it was some comfort
title: The Trial

text: for the accused to realise how little money this court had at its
title: The Trial

text: disposal if it had to locate its offices in a place where the tenants of
title: The Trial

text: the building, who were themselves among the poorest of people, would
title: The Trial

text: throw their unneeded junk. On the other hand, it was possible that the
title: The Trial

text: officials had enough money but that they squandered it on themselves
title: The Trial

text: rather than use it for the court's purposes. Going by K.'s experience of
title: The Trial

text: them so far, that even seemed probable, except that if the court were
title: The Trial

text: allowed to decay in that way it would not just humiliate the accused but
title: The Trial

text: also give him more encouragement than if the court were simply in a
title: The Trial

text: state of poverty. K. also now understood that the court was ashamed to
title: The Trial

text: summon those it accused to the attic of this building for the initial
title: The Trial

text: hearing, and why it preferred to impose upon them in their own homes.
title: The Trial

text: What a position it was that K. found himself in, compared with the judge
title: The Trial

text: sitting up in the attic! K., at the bank, had a big office with an
title: The Trial

text: ante-room, and had an enormous window through which he could look down
title: The Trial

text: at the activity in the square. It was true, though, that he had no
title: The Trial

text: secondary income from bribes and fraud, and he couldn't tell a servant
title: The Trial

text: to bring him a woman up to the office on his arm. K., however, was quite
title: The Trial

text: willing to do without such things, in this life at least. K. was still
title: The Trial

text: looking at the notice when a man came up the stairs, looked through the
title: The Trial

text: open door into the living room where it was also possible to see the
title: The Trial

text: courtroom, and finally asked K. whether he had just seen a woman there.
title: The Trial

text: "You're the court usher, aren't you?" asked K. "That's right," said the
title: The Trial

text: man, "oh, yes, you're defendant K., I recognise you now as well. Nice to
title: The Trial

text: see you here." And he offered K. his hand, which was far from what K.
title: The Trial

text: had expected. And when K. said nothing, he added, "There's no court
title: The Trial

text: session planned for today, though." "I know that," said K. as he looked
title: The Trial

text: at the usher's civilian coat which, beside its ordinary buttons,
title: The Trial

text: displayed two gilded ones as the only sign of his office and seemed to
title: The Trial

text: have been taken from an old army officer's coat. "I was speaking with
title: The Trial

text: your wife a little while ago. She is no longer here. The student has
title: The Trial

text: carried her off to the examining judge." "Listen to this," said the
title: The Trial

text: usher, "they're always carrying her away from me. It's Sunday today, and
title: The Trial

text: it's not part of my job to do any work today, but they send me off with
title: The Trial

text: some message which isn't even necessary just to get me away from here.
title: The Trial

text: What they do is they send me off not too far away so that I can still
title: The Trial

text: hope to get back on time if I really hurry. So off I go running as fast
title: The Trial

text: as I can, shout the message through the crack in the door of the office
title: The Trial

text: I've been sent to, so out of breath they'll hardly be able to understand
title: The Trial

text: it, run back here again, but the student's been even faster than I
title: The Trial

text: have—well he's got less far to go, he's only got to run down the steps.
title: The Trial

text: If I wasn't so dependent on them I'd have squashed the student against
title: The Trial

text: the wall here a long time ago. Right here, next to the sign. I'm always
title: The Trial

text: dreaming of doing that. Just here, just above the floor, that's where
title: The Trial

text: he's crushed onto the wall, his arms stretched out, his fingers spread
title: The Trial

text: apart, his crooked legs twisted round into a circle and blood squirted
title: The Trial

text: out all around him. It's only ever been a dream so far, though." "Is
title: The Trial

text: there nothing else you do?" asked K. with a smile. "Nothing that I know
title: The Trial

text: of," said the usher. "And it's going to get even worse now, up till now
title: The Trial

text: he's only been carrying her off for himself, now he's started carrying
title: The Trial

text: her off for the judge and all, just like I'd always said he would."
title: The Trial

text: "Does your wife, then, not share some of the responsibility?" asked K.
title: The Trial

text: He had to force himself as he asked this question, as he, too, felt so
title: The Trial

text: jealous now. "Course she does," said the usher, "it's more her fault
title: The Trial

text: than theirs. It was her who attached herself to him. All he did, he just
title: The Trial

text: chases after any woman. There's five flats in this block alone where
title: The Trial

text: he's been thrown out after working his way in there. And my wife is the
title: The Trial

text: best looking woman in the whole building, but it's me who's not even
title: The Trial

text: allowed to defend himself." "If that's how things are, then there's
title: The Trial

text: nothing that can be done," said K. "Well why not?" asked the usher.
title: The Trial

text: "He's a coward that student, if he wants to lay a finger on my wife all
title: The Trial

text: you'd have to do is give him such a good hiding he'd never dare do it
title: The Trial

text: again. But I'm not allowed to do that, and nobody else is going to do me
title: The Trial

text: the favour as they're all afraid of his power. The only one who could do
title: The Trial

text: it is a man like you." "What, how could I do it?" asked K. in
title: The Trial

text: astonishment. "Well you're facing a charge, aren't you," said the usher.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes, but that's all the more reason for me to be afraid. Even if he has
title: The Trial

text: no influence on the outcome of the trial he probably has some on the
title: The Trial

text: initial examination." "Yes, exactly," said the usher, as if K.'s view
title: The Trial

text: had been just as correct as his own. "Only we don't usually get any
title: The Trial

text: trials heard here with no hope at all." "I am not of the same opinion,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., "although that ought not to prevent me from dealing with the
title: The Trial

text: student if the opportunity arises." "I would be very grateful to you,"
title: The Trial

text: said the usher of the court, somewhat formally, not really seeming to
title: The Trial

text: believe that his highest wish could be fulfilled. "Perhaps," continued
title: The Trial

text: K., "perhaps there are some other officials of yours here, perhaps all
title: The Trial

text: of them, who would deserve the same." "Oh yes, yes," said the usher, as
title: The Trial

text: if this was a matter of course. Then he looked at K. trustingly which,
title: The Trial

text: despite all his friendliness, he had not done until then, and added,
title: The Trial

text: "they're always rebelling." But the conversation seemed to have become a
title: The Trial

text: little uncomfortable for him, as he broke it off by saying, "now I have
title: The Trial

text: to report to the office. Would you like to come with me?" "There's
title: The Trial

text: nothing for me to do there," said K. "You'd be able to have a look at
title: The Trial

text: it. No-one will take any notice of you." "Is it worth seeing then?"
title: The Trial

text: asked K. hesitatingly, although he felt very keen to go with him.
title: The Trial

text: "Well," said the usher, "I thought you'd be interested in it." "Alright
title: The Trial

text: then," said K. finally, "I'll come with you." And, quicker than the
title: The Trial

text: usher himself, he ran up the steps.
title: The Trial

text: At the entrance he nearly fell over, as behind the door there was
title: The Trial

text: another step. "They don't show much concern for the public," he said.
title: The Trial

text: "They don't show any concern at all," said the usher, "just look at the
title: The Trial

text: waiting room here." It consisted of a long corridor from which roughly
title: The Trial

text: made doors led out to the separate departments of the attic. There was
title: The Trial

text: no direct source of light but it was not entirely dark as many of the
title: The Trial

text: departments, instead of solid walls, had just wooden bars reaching up to
title: The Trial

text: the ceiling to separate them from the corridor. The light made its way
title: The Trial

text: in through them, and it was also possible to see individual officials
title: The Trial

text: through them as they sat writing at their desks or stood up at the
title: The Trial

text: wooden frameworks and watched the people on the corridor through the
title: The Trial

text: gaps. There were only a few people in the corridor, probably because it
title: The Trial

text: was Sunday. They were not very impressive. They sat, equally spaced, on
title: The Trial

text: two rows of long wooden benches which had been placed along both sides
title: The Trial

text: of the corridor. All of them were carelessly dressed although the
title: The Trial

text: expressions on their faces, their bearing, the style of their beards and
title: The Trial

text: many details which were hard to identify showed that they belonged to
title: The Trial

text: the upper classes. There were no coat hooks for them to use, and so they
title: The Trial

text: had placed their hats under the bench, each probably having followed the
title: The Trial

text: example of the others. When those who were sitting nearest the door saw
title: The Trial

text: K. and the usher of the court they stood up to greet them, and when the
title: The Trial

text: others saw that, they also thought they had to greet them, so that as
title: The Trial

text: the two of them went by all the people there stood up. None of them
title: The Trial

text: stood properly upright, their backs were bowed, their knees bent, they
title: The Trial

text: stood like beggars on the street. K. waited for the usher, who was
title: The Trial

text: following just behind him. "They must all be very dispirited," he said.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," said the usher, "they are the accused, everyone you see here has
title: The Trial

text: been accused." "Really!" said K. "They're colleagues of mine then." And
title: The Trial

text: he turned to the nearest one, a tall, thin man with hair that was nearly
title: The Trial

text: grey. "What is it you are waiting for here?" asked K., politely, but the
title: The Trial

text: man was startled at being spoken to unexpectedly, which was all the more
title: The Trial

text: pitiful to see because the man clearly had some experience of the world
title: The Trial

text: and elsewhere would certainly have been able to show his superiority and
title: The Trial

text: would not have easily given up the advantage he had acquired. Here,
title: The Trial

text: though, he did not know what answer to give to such a simple question
title: The Trial

text: and looked round at the others as if they were under some obligation to
title: The Trial

text: help him, and as if no-one could expect any answer from him without this
title: The Trial

text: help. Then the usher of the court stepped forward to him and, in order
title: The Trial

text: to calm him down and raise his spirits, said, "The gentleman here's only
title: The Trial

text: asking what it is you're waiting for. You can give him an answer." The
title: The Trial

text: voice of the usher was probably familiar to him, and had a better effect
title: The Trial

text: than K.'s. "I'm ... I'm waiting...." he began, and then came to a halt.
title: The Trial

text: He had clearly chosen this beginning so that he could give a precise
title: The Trial

text: answer to the question, but now he didn't know how to continue. Some of
title: The Trial

text: the others waiting had come closer and stood round the group, the usher
title: The Trial

text: of the court said to them, "Get out the way, keep the gangway free."
title: The Trial

text: They moved back slightly, but not as far as where they had been sitting
title: The Trial

text: before. In the meantime, the man whom K. had first approached had pulled
title: The Trial

text: himself together and even answered him with a smile. "A month ago I made
title: The Trial

text: some applications for evidence to be heard in my case, and I'm waiting
title: The Trial

text: for it to be settled." "You certainly seem to be going to a lot of
title: The Trial

text: effort," said K. "Yes," said the man, "it is my affair after all." "Not
title: The Trial

text: everyone thinks the same way as you do," said K. "I've been indicted as
title: The Trial

text: well but I swear on my soul that I've neither submitted evidence nor
title: The Trial

text: done anything else of the sort. Do you really think that's necessary?"
title: The Trial

text: "I don't really know, exactly," said the man, once more totally unsure
title: The Trial

text: of himself; he clearly thought K. was joking with him and therefore
title: The Trial

text: probably thought it best to repeat his earlier answer in order to avoid
title: The Trial

text: making any new mistakes. With K. looking at him impatiently, he just
title: The Trial

text: said, "as far as I'm concerned, I've applied to have this evidence
title: The Trial

text: heard." "Perhaps you don't believe I've been indicted?" asked K. "Oh,
title: The Trial

text: please, I certainly do," said the man, stepping slightly to one side,
title: The Trial

text: but there was more anxiety in his answer than belief. "You don't believe
title: The Trial

text: me then?" asked K., and took hold of his arm, unconsciously prompted by
title: The Trial

text: the man's humble demeanour, and as if he wanted to force him to believe
title: The Trial

text: him. But he did not want to hurt the man and had only taken hold of him
title: The Trial

text: very lightly. Nonetheless, the man cried out as if K. had grasped him
title: The Trial

text: not with two fingers but with red hot tongs. Shouting in this ridiculous
title: The Trial

text: way finally made K. tired of him, if he didn't believe he was indicted
title: The Trial

text: then so much the better; maybe he even thought K. was a judge. And
title: The Trial

text: before leaving, he held him a lot harder, shoved him back onto the bench
title: The Trial

text: and walked on. "These defendants are so sensitive, most of them," said
title: The Trial

text: the usher of the court. Almost all of those who had been waiting had now
title: The Trial

text: assembled around the man who, by now, had stopped shouting and they
title: The Trial

text: seemed to be asking him lots of precise questions about the incident. K.
title: The Trial

text: was approached by a security guard, identifiable mainly by his sword, of
title: The Trial

text: which the scabbard seemed to be made of aluminium. This greatly
title: The Trial

text: surprised K., and he reached out for it with his hand. The guard had
title: The Trial

text: come because of the shouting and asked what had been happening. The
title: The Trial

text: usher of the court said a few words to try and calm him down but the
title: The Trial

text: guard explained that he had to look into it himself, saluted, and
title: The Trial

text: hurried on, walking with very short steps, probably because of gout.
title: The Trial

text: K. didn't concern himself long with the guard or these people,
title: The Trial

text: especially as he saw a turning off the corridor, about half way along
title: The Trial

text: it on the right hand side, where there was no door to stop him going
title: The Trial

text: that way. He asked the usher whether that was the right way to go, the
title: The Trial

text: usher nodded, and that is the way that K. went. The usher remained
title: The Trial

text: always one or two steps behind K., which he found irritating as in a
title: The Trial

text: place like this it could give the impression that he was being driven
title: The Trial

text: along by someone who had arrested him, so he frequently waited for the
title: The Trial

text: usher to catch up, but the usher always remained behind him. In order to
title: The Trial

text: put an end to his discomfort, K. finally said, "Now that I've seen what
title: The Trial

text: it looks like here, I'd like to go." "You haven't seen everything yet,"
title: The Trial

text: said the usher ingenuously. "I don't want to see everything," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: who was also feeling very tired, "I want to go, what is the way to the
title: The Trial

text: exit?" "You haven't got lost, have you?" asked the usher in amazement,
title: The Trial

text: "you go down this way to the corner, then right down the corridor
title: The Trial

text: straight ahead as far as the door." "Come with me," said K., "show me
title: The Trial

text: the way, I'll miss it, there are so many different ways here." "It's the
title: The Trial

text: only way there is," said the usher, who had now started to sound quite
title: The Trial

text: reproachful, "I can't go back with you again, I've got to hand in my
title: The Trial

text: report, and I've already lost a lot of time because of you as it is."
title: The Trial

text: "Come with me!" K. repeated, now somewhat sharper as if he had finally
title: The Trial

text: caught the usher out in a lie. "Don't shout like that," whispered the
title: The Trial

text: usher, "there's offices all round us here. If you don't want to go back
title: The Trial

text: by yourself come on a bit further with me or else wait here till I've
title: The Trial

text: sorted out my report, then I'll be glad to go back with you again." "No,
title: The Trial

text: no," said K., "I will not wait and you must come with me now." K. had
title: The Trial

text: still not looked round at anything at all in the room where he found
title: The Trial

text: himself, and it was only when one of the many wooden doors all around
title: The Trial

text: him opened that he noticed it. A young woman, probably summoned by the
title: The Trial

text: loudness of K.'s voice, entered and asked, "What is it the gentleman
title: The Trial

text: wants?" In the darkness behind her there was also a man approaching. K.
title: The Trial

text: looked at the usher. He had, after all, said that no-one would take any
title: The Trial

text: notice of K., and now there were two people coming, it only needed a few
title: The Trial

text: and everyone in the office would become aware of him and asking for
title: The Trial

text: explanations as to why he was there. The only understandable and
title: The Trial

text: acceptable thing to say was that he was accused of something and wanted
title: The Trial

text: to know the date of his next hearing, but this was an explanation he did
title: The Trial

text: not want to give, especially as it was not true—he had only come out of
title: The Trial

text: curiosity. Or else, an explanation even less usable, he could say that
title: The Trial

text: he wanted to ascertain that the court was as revolting on the inside as
title: The Trial

text: it was on the outside. And it did seem that he had been quite right in
title: The Trial

text: this supposition, he had no wish to intrude any deeper, he was disturbed
title: The Trial

text: enough by what he had seen already, he was not in the right frame of
title: The Trial

text: mind just then to face a high official such as might appear from behind
title: The Trial

text: any door, and he wanted to go, either with the usher of the court or, if
title: The Trial

text: needs be, alone.
title: The Trial

text: But he must have seemed very odd standing there in silence, and the
title: The Trial

text: young woman and the usher were indeed looking at him as if they thought
title: The Trial

text: he would go through some major metamorphosis any second which they
title: The Trial

text: didn't want to miss seeing. And in the doorway stood the man whom K. had
title: The Trial

text: noticed in the background earlier, he held firmly on to the beam above
title: The Trial

text: the low door swinging a little on the tips of his feet as if becoming
title: The Trial

text: impatient as he watched. But the young woman was the first to recognise
title: The Trial

text: that K.'s behaviour was caused by his feeling slightly unwell, she
title: The Trial

text: brought a chair and asked, "Would you not like to sit down?" K. sat down
title: The Trial

text: immediately and, in order to keep his place better, put his elbows on
title: The Trial

text: the armrests. "You're a little bit dizzy, aren't you?" she asked him.
title: The Trial

text: Her face was now close in front of him, it bore the severe expression
title: The Trial

text: that many young women have just when they're in the bloom of their
title: The Trial

text: youth. "It's nothing for you to worry about," she said, "that's nothing
title: The Trial

text: unusual here, almost everyone gets an attack like that the first time
title: The Trial

text: they come here. This is your first time is it. Yes, it's nothing unusual
title: The Trial

text: then. The sun burns down on the roof and the hot wood makes the air so
title: The Trial

text: thick and heavy. It makes this place rather unsuitable for offices,
title: The Trial

text: whatever other advantages it might offer. But the air is almost
title: The Trial

text: impossible to breathe on days when there's a lot of business, and that's
title: The Trial

text: almost every day. And when you think that there's a lot of washing put
title: The Trial

text: out to dry here as well—and we can't stop the tenants doing that—it's
title: The Trial

text: not surprising you started to feel unwell. But you get used to the air
title: The Trial

text: alright in the end. When you're here for the second or third time you'll
title: The Trial

text: hardly notice how oppressive the air is. Are you feeling any better
title: The Trial

text: now?" K. made no answer, he felt too embarrassed at being put at the
title: The Trial

text: mercy of these people by his sudden weakness, and learning the reason
title: The Trial

text: for feeling ill made him feel not better but a little worse. The girl
title: The Trial

text: noticed it straight away, and to make the air fresher for K., she took a
title: The Trial

text: window pole that was leaning against the wall and pushed open a small
title: The Trial

text: hatch directly above K.'s head that led to the outside. But so much soot
title: The Trial

text: fell in that the girl had to immediately close the hatch again and clean
title: The Trial

text: the soot off K.'s hands with her handkerchief, as K. was too tired to do
title: The Trial

text: that for himself. He would have liked just to sit quietly where he was
title: The Trial

text: until he had enough strength to leave, and the less fuss people made
title: The Trial

text: about him the sooner that would be. But then the girl said, "You can't
title: The Trial

text: stay here, we're in people's way here...." K. looked at her as if to ask
title: The Trial

text: whose way they were impeding. "If you like, I can take you to the sick
title: The Trial

text: room," and turning to the man in the doorway said, "please help me." The
title: The Trial

text: man immediately came over to them, but K. did not want to go to the sick
title: The Trial

text: room, that was just what he wanted to avoid, being led further from
title: The Trial

text: place to place, the further he went the more difficult it must become.
title: The Trial

text: So he said, "I am able to walk now," and stood up, shaking after
title: The Trial

text: becoming used to sitting so comfortably. But then he was unable to stay
title: The Trial

text: upright. "I can't manage it," he said shaking his head, and sat down
title: The Trial

text: again with a sigh. He remembered the usher who, despite everything,
title: The Trial

text: would have been able to lead him out of there but who seemed to have
title: The Trial

text: gone long before. K. looked out between the man and the young woman who
title: The Trial

text: were standing in front of him but was unable to find the usher. "I
title: The Trial

text: think," said the man, who was elegantly dressed and whose appearance was
title: The Trial

text: made especially impressive with a grey waistcoat that had two long,
title: The Trial

text: sharply tailored points, "the gentleman is feeling unwell because of the
title: The Trial

text: atmosphere here, so the best thing, and what he would most prefer, would
title: The Trial

text: be not to take him to the sick room but get him out of the offices
title: The Trial

text: altogether." "That's right," exclaimed K., with such joy that he nearly
title: The Trial

text: interrupted what the man was saying, "I'm sure that'll make me feel
title: The Trial

text: better straight away, I'm really not that weak, all I need is a little
title: The Trial

text: support under my arms, I won't cause you much trouble, it's not such a
title: The Trial

text: long way anyway, lead me to the door and then I'll sit on the stairs for
title: The Trial

text: a while and soon recover, as I don't suffer from attacks like this at
title: The Trial

text: all, I'm surprised at it myself. I also work in an office and I'm quite
title: The Trial

text: used to office air, but here it seems to be too strong, you've said so
title: The Trial

text: yourselves. So please, be so kind as to help me on my way a little, I'm
title: The Trial

text: feeling dizzy, you see, and it'll make me ill if I stand up by myself."
title: The Trial

text: And with that he raised his shoulders to make it easier for the two of
title: The Trial

text: them to take him by the arms.
title: The Trial

text: The man, however, didn't follow this suggestion but just stood there
title: The Trial

text: with his hands in his trouser pockets and laughed out loud. "There, you
title: The Trial

text: see," he said to the girl, "I was quite right. The gentleman is only
title: The Trial

text: unwell here, and not in general." The young woman smiled too, but
title: The Trial

text: lightly tapped the man's arm with the tips of her fingers as if he had
title: The Trial

text: allowed himself too much fun with K. "So what do you think, then?" said
title: The Trial

text: the man, still laughing, "I really do want to lead the gentleman out of
title: The Trial

text: here." "That's alright, then," said the girl, briefly inclining her
title: The Trial

text: charming head. "Don't worry too much about him laughing," said the girl
title: The Trial

text: to K., who had become unhappy once more and stared quietly in front of
title: The Trial

text: himself as if needing no further explanation. "This gentleman—may I
title: The Trial

text: introduce you?"—(the man gave his permission with a wave of the
title: The Trial

text: hand)—"so, this gentleman's job is to give out information. He gives
title: The Trial

text: all the information they need to people who are waiting, as our court
title: The Trial

text: and its offices are not very well known among the public he gets asked
title: The Trial

text: for quite a lot. He has an answer for every question, you can try him
title: The Trial

text: out if you feel like it. But that's not his only distinction, his other
title: The Trial

text: distinction is his elegance of dress. We, that's to say all of us who
title: The Trial

text: work in the offices here, we decided that the information-giver would
title: The Trial

text: have to be elegantly dressed as he continually has to deal with the
title: The Trial

text: litigants and he's the first one they meet, so he needs to give a
title: The Trial

text: dignified first impression. The rest of us I'm afraid, as you can see
title: The Trial

text: just by looking at me, dress very badly and old-fashioned; and there's
title: The Trial

text: not much point in spending much on clothes anyway, as we hardly ever
title: The Trial

text: leave the offices, we even sleep here. But, as I said, we decided that
title: The Trial

text: the information-giver would have to have nice clothes. As the management
title: The Trial

text: here is rather peculiar in this respect, and they would get them for us,
title: The Trial

text: we had a collection—some of the litigants contributed too—and bought
title: The Trial

text: him these lovely clothes and some others besides. So everything would be
title: The Trial

text: ready for him to give a good impression, except that he spoils it again
title: The Trial

text: by laughing and frightening people." "That's how it is," said the man,
title: The Trial

text: mocking her, "but I don't understand why it is that you're explaining
title: The Trial

text: all our intimate facts to the gentleman, or rather why it is that you're
title: The Trial

text: pressing them on him, as I'm sure he's not all interested. Just look at
title: The Trial

text: him sitting there, it's clear he's occupied with his own affairs." K.
title: The Trial

text: just did not feel like contradicting him. The girl's intention may have
title: The Trial

text: been good, perhaps she was under instructions to distract him or to give
title: The Trial

text: him the chance to collect himself, but the attempt had not worked. "I
title: The Trial

text: had to explain to him why you were laughing," said the girl. "I suppose
title: The Trial

text: it was insulting." "I think he would forgive even worse insults if I
title: The Trial

text: finally took him outside." K. said nothing, did not even look up, he
title: The Trial

text: tolerated the two of them negotiating over him like an object, that was
title: The Trial

text: even what suited him best. But suddenly he felt the information-giver's
title: The Trial

text: hand on one arm and the young woman's hand on the other. "Up you get
title: The Trial

text: then, weakling," said the information-giver. "Thank you both very much,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., pleasantly surprised, as he slowly rose and personally guided
title: The Trial

text: these unfamiliar hands to the places where he most needed support. As
title: The Trial

text: they approached the corridor, the girl said quietly into K.'s ear, "I
title: The Trial

text: must seem to think it's very important to show the information-giver in
title: The Trial

text: a good light, but you shouldn't doubt what I say, I just want to say the
title: The Trial

text: truth. He isn't hard-hearted. It's not really his job to help litigants
title: The Trial

text: outside if they're unwell but he's doing it anyway, as you can see. I
title: The Trial

text: don't suppose any of us is hard-hearted, perhaps we'd all like to be
title: The Trial

text: helpful, but working for the court offices it's easy for us to give the
title: The Trial

text: impression we are hard-hearted and don't want to help anyone. It makes
title: The Trial

text: me quite sad." "Would you not like to sit down here a while?" asked the
title: The Trial

text: information-giver, there were already in the corridor and just in front
title: The Trial

text: of the defendant whom K. had spoken to earlier. K. felt almost ashamed
title: The Trial

text: to be seen by him, earlier he had stood so upright in front of him and
title: The Trial

text: now he had to be supported by two others, his hat was held up by the
title: The Trial

text: information-giver balanced on outstretched fingers, his hair was
title: The Trial

text: dishevelled and hung down onto the sweat on his forehead. But the
title: The Trial

text: defendant seemed to notice nothing of what was going on and just stood
title: The Trial

text: there humbly, as if wanting to apologise to the information-giver for
title: The Trial

text: being there. The information-giver looked past him. "I know," he said,
title: The Trial

text: "that my case can't be settled today, not yet, but I've come in anyway,
title: The Trial

text: I thought, I thought I could wait here anyway, it's Sunday today, I've
title: The Trial

text: got plenty of time, and I'm not disturbing anyone here." "There's no
title: The Trial

text: need to be so apologetic," said the information-giver, "it's very
title: The Trial

text: commendable for you to be so attentive. You are taking up space here
title: The Trial

text: when you don't need to but as long as you don't get in my way I will do
title: The Trial

text: nothing to stop you following the progress of your case as closely as
title: The Trial

text: you like. When one has seen so many people who shamefully neglect their
title: The Trial

text: cases one learns to show patience with people like you. Do sit down."
title: The Trial

text: "He's very good with the litigants," whispered the girl. K. nodded, but
title: The Trial

text: started to move off again when the information-giver repeated, "Would
title: The Trial

text: you not like to sit down here a while?" "No," said K., "I don't want to
title: The Trial

text: rest." He had said that as decisively as he could, but in fact it would
title: The Trial

text: have done him a lot of good to sit down. It was as if he were suffering
title: The Trial

text: sea-sickness. He felt as if he were on a ship in a rough sea, as if the
title: The Trial

text: water were hitting against the wooden walls, a thundering from the
title: The Trial

text: depths of the corridor as if the torrent were crashing over it, as if
title: The Trial

text: the corridor were swaying and the waiting litigants on each side of it
title: The Trial

text: rising and sinking. It made the calmness of the girl and the man leading
title: The Trial

text: him all the more incomprehensible. He was at their mercy, if they let go
title: The Trial

text: of him he would fall like a board. Their little eyes glanced here and
title: The Trial

text: there, K. could feel the evenness of their steps but could not do the
title: The Trial

text: same, as from step to step he was virtually being carried. He finally
title: The Trial

text: noticed they were speaking to him but he did not understand them, all he
title: The Trial

text: heard was a noise that filled all the space and through which there
title: The Trial

text: seemed to be an unchanging higher note sounding, like a siren. "Louder,"
title: The Trial

text: he whispered with his head sunk low, ashamed at having to ask them to
title: The Trial

text: speak louder when he knew they had spoken loudly enough, even if it had
title: The Trial

text: been, for him, incomprehensible. At last, a draught of cool air blew in
title: The Trial

text: his face as if a gap had been torn out in the wall in front of him, and
title: The Trial

text: next to him he heard someone say, "First he says he wants to go, and
title: The Trial

text: then you can tell him a hundred times that this is the way out and he
title: The Trial

text: doesn't move." K. became aware that he was standing in front of the way
title: The Trial

text: out, and that the young woman had opened the door. It seemed to him that
title: The Trial

text: all his strength returned to him at once, and to get a foretaste of
title: The Trial

text: freedom he stepped straight on to one of the stairs and took his leave
title: The Trial

text: there of his companions, who bowed to him. "Thank you very much," he
title: The Trial

text: repeated, shook their hands once more and did not let go until he
title: The Trial

text: thought he saw that they found it hard to bear the comparatively fresh
title: The Trial

text: air from the stairway after being so long used to the air in the
title: The Trial

text: offices. They were hardly able to reply, and the young woman might even
title: The Trial

text: have fallen over if K. had not shut the door extremely fast. K. then
title: The Trial

text: stood still for a while, combed his hair with the help of a pocket
title: The Trial

text: mirror, picked up his hat from the next stair—the information-giver
title: The Trial

text: must have thrown it down there—and then he ran down the steps so fresh
title: The Trial

text: and in such long leaps that the contrast with his previous state nearly
title: The Trial

text: frightened him. His normally sturdy state of health had never prepared
title: The Trial

text: him for surprises such as this. Did his body want to revolt and cause
title: The Trial

text: him a new trial as he was bearing the old one with such little effort?
title: The Trial

text: He did not quite reject the idea that he should see a doctor the next
title: The Trial

text: time he had the chance, but whatever he did—and this was something on
title: The Trial

text: which he could advise himself—he wanted to spend all Sunday mornings in
title: The Trial

text: future better than he had spent this one.

title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Miss Bürstner's Friend
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: For some time after this, K. found it impossible to exchange even just a
title: The Trial

text: few words with Miss Bürstner. He tried to reach her in many and various
title: The Trial

text: ways but she always found a way to avoid it. He would come straight home
title: The Trial

text: from the office, remain in her room without the light on, and sit on the
title: The Trial

text: sofa with nothing more to distract him than keeping watch on the empty
title: The Trial

text: hallway. If the maid went by and closed the door of the apparently empty
title: The Trial

text: room he would get up after a while and open it again. He got up an hour
title: The Trial

text: earlier than usual in the morning so that he might perhaps find Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner alone as she went to the office. But none of these efforts
title: The Trial

text: brought any success. Then he wrote her a letter, both to the office and
title: The Trial

text: the flat, attempting once more to justify his behaviour, offered to make
title: The Trial

text: whatever amends he could, promised never to cross whatever boundary she
title: The Trial

text: might set him and begged merely to have the chance to speak to her some
title: The Trial

text: time, especially as he was unable to do anything with Mrs. Grubach
title: The Trial

text: either until he had spoken with Miss Bürstner, he finally informed her
title: The Trial

text: that the following Sunday he would stay in his room all day waiting for
title: The Trial

text: a sign from her that there was some hope of his request being fulfilled,
title: The Trial

text: or at least that she would explain to him why she could not fulfil it
title: The Trial

text: even though he had promised to observe whatever stipulations she might
title: The Trial

text: make. The letters were not returned, but there was no answer either.
title: The Trial

text: However, on the following Sunday there was a sign that seemed clear
title: The Trial

text: enough. It was still early when K. noticed, through the keyhole, that
title: The Trial

text: there was an unusual level of activity in the hallway which soon abated.
title: The Trial

text: A French teacher, although she was German and called Montag, a pale and
title: The Trial

text: febrile girl with a slight limp who had previously occupied a room of
title: The Trial

text: her own, was moving into Miss Bürstner's room. She could be seen
title: The Trial

text: shuffling through the hallway for several hours, there was always
title: The Trial

text: another piece of clothing or a blanket or a book that she had forgotten
title: The Trial

text: and had to be fetched specially and brought into the new home.
title: The Trial

text: When Mrs. Grubach brought K. his breakfast—ever since the time when she
title: The Trial

text: had made K. so cross she didn't trust the maid to do the slightest
title: The Trial

text: job—he had no choice but to speak to her, for the first time in five
title: The Trial

text: days. "Why is there so much noise in the hallway today?" he asked as she
title: The Trial

text: poured his coffee out, "Can't something be done about it? Does this
title: The Trial

text: clearing out have to be done on a Sunday?" K. did not look up at Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach, but he saw nonetheless that she seemed to feel some relief as
title: The Trial

text: she breathed in. Even sharp questions like this from Mr. K. she
title: The Trial

text: perceived as forgiveness, or as the beginning of forgiveness. "We're not
title: The Trial

text: clearing anything out, Mr. K.," she said, "it's just that Miss Montag is
title: The Trial

text: moving in with Miss Bürstner and is moving her things across." She said
title: The Trial

text: nothing more, but just waited to see how K. would take it and whether he
title: The Trial

text: would allow her to carry on speaking. But K. kept her in uncertainty,
title: The Trial

text: took the spoon and pensively stirred his coffee while he remained
title: The Trial

text: silent. Then he looked up at her and said, "What about the suspicions
title: The Trial

text: you had earlier about Miss Bürstner, have you given them up?" "Mr. K.,"
title: The Trial

text: called Mrs. Grubach, who had been waiting for this very question, as she
title: The Trial

text: put her hands together and held them out towards him. "I just made a
title: The Trial

text: chance remark and you took it so badly. I didn't have the slightest
title: The Trial

text: intention of offending anyone, not you or anyone else. You've known me
title: The Trial

text: for long enough, Mr. K., I'm sure you're convinced of that. You don't
title: The Trial

text: know how I've been suffering for the past few days! That I should tell
title: The Trial

text: lies about my tenants! And you, Mr. K., you believed it! And said I
title: The Trial

text: should give you notice! Give you notice!" At this last outcry, Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach was already choking back her tears, she raised her apron to her
title: The Trial

text: face and blubbered out loud.
title: The Trial

text: "Oh, don't cry Mrs. Grubach," said K., looking out the window, he was
title: The Trial

text: thinking only of Miss Bürstner and how she was accepting an unknown girl
title: The Trial

text: into her room. "Now don't cry," he said again as he turned his look back
title: The Trial

text: into the room where Mrs. Grubach was still crying. "I meant no harm
title: The Trial

text: either when I said that. It was simply a misunderstanding between us.
title: The Trial

text: That can happen even between old friends sometimes." Mrs. Grubach pulled
title: The Trial

text: her apron down to below her eyes to see whether K. really was attempting
title: The Trial

text: a reconciliation. "Well, yes, that's how it is," said K., and as Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach's behaviour indicated that the captain had said nothing he dared
title: The Trial

text: to add, "Do you really think, then, that I'd want to make an enemy of
title: The Trial

text: you for the sake of a girl we hardly know?" "Yes, you're quite right,
title: The Trial

text: Mr. K.," said Mrs. Grubach, and then, to her misfortune, as soon as she
title: The Trial

text: felt just a little freer to speak, she added something rather inept. "I
title: The Trial

text: kept asking myself why it was that Mr. K. took such an interest in Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner. Why does he quarrel with me over her when he knows that any
title: The Trial

text: cross word from him and I can't sleep that night? And I didn't say
title: The Trial

text: anything about Miss Bürstner that I hadn't seen with my own eyes." K.
title: The Trial

text: said nothing in reply, he should have chased her from the room as soon
title: The Trial

text: as she had opened her mouth, and he didn't want to do that. He contented
title: The Trial

text: himself with merely drinking his coffee and letting Mrs. Grubach feel
title: The Trial

text: that she was superfluous. Outside, the dragging steps of Miss Montag
title: The Trial

text: could still be heard as she went from one side of the hallway to the
title: The Trial

text: other. "Do you hear that?" asked K. pointing his hand at the door.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," said Mrs. Grubach with a sigh, "I wanted to give her some help
title: The Trial

text: and I wanted the maid to help her too but she's stubborn, she wants to
title: The Trial

text: move everything in herself. I wonder at Miss Bürstner. I often feel it's
title: The Trial

text: a burden for me to have Miss Montag as a tenant but Miss Bürstner
title: The Trial

text: accepts her into her room with herself." "There's nothing there for you
title: The Trial

text: to worry about," said K., crushing the remains of a sugar lump in his
title: The Trial

text: cup. "Does she cause you any trouble?" "No," said Mrs. Grubach, "in
title: The Trial

text: itself it's very good to have her there, it makes another room free for
title: The Trial

text: me and I can let my nephew, the captain, occupy it. I began to worry he
title: The Trial

text: might be disturbing you when I had to let him live in the living room
title: The Trial

text: next to you over the last few days. He's not very considerate." "What an
title: The Trial

text: idea!" said K. standing up, "there's no question of that. You seem to
title: The Trial

text: think that because I can't stand this to-ing and fro-ing of Miss Montag
title: The Trial

text: that I'm over-sensitive—and there she goes back again." Mrs. Grubach
title: The Trial

text: appeared quite powerless. "Should I tell her to leave moving the rest of
title: The Trial

text: her things over till later, then, Mr. K.? If that's what you want I'll
title: The Trial

text: do it immediately." "But she has to move in with Miss Bürstner!" said K.
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," said Mrs. Grubach, without quite understanding what K. meant. "So
title: The Trial

text: she has to take her things over there." Mrs. Grubach just nodded. K. was
title: The Trial

text: irritated all the more by this dumb helplessness which, seen from the
title: The Trial

text: outside, could have seemed like a kind of defiance on her part. He began
title: The Trial

text: to walk up and down the room between the window and the door, thus
title: The Trial

text: depriving Mrs. Grubach of the chance to leave, which she otherwise
title: The Trial

text: probably would have done.
title: The Trial

text: Just as K. once more reached the door, someone knocked at it. It was the
title: The Trial

text: maid, to say that Miss Montag would like to have a few words with Mr.
title: The Trial

text: K., and therefore requested that he come to the dining room where she
title: The Trial

text: was waiting for him. K. heard the maid out thoughtfully, and then looked
title: The Trial

text: back at the shocked Mrs. Grubach in a way that was almost contemptuous.
title: The Trial

text: His look seemed to be saying that K. had been expecting this invitation
title: The Trial

text: for Miss Montag for a long time, and that it was confirmation of the
title: The Trial

text: suffering he had been made to endure that Sunday morning from Mrs.
title: The Trial

text: Grubach's tenants. He sent the maid back with the reply that he was on
title: The Trial

text: his way, then he went to the wardrobe to change his coat, and in answer
title: The Trial

text: to Mrs. Grubach's gentle whining about the nuisance Miss Montag was
title: The Trial

text: causing merely asked her to clear away the breakfast things. "But you've
title: The Trial

text: hardly touched it," said Mrs. Grubach. "Oh just take it away!" shouted
title: The Trial

text: K. It seemed to him that Miss Montag was mixed up in everything and made
title: The Trial

text: it repulsive to him.
title: The Trial

text: As he went through the hallway he looked at the closed door of Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner's room. But it wasn't there that he was invited, but the dining
title: The Trial

text: room, to which he yanked the door open without knocking.
title: The Trial

text: The room was long but narrow with one window. There was only enough
title: The Trial

text: space available to put two cupboards at an angle in the corner by the
title: The Trial

text: door, and the rest of the room was entirely taken up with the long
title: The Trial

text: dining table which started by the door and reached all the way to the
title: The Trial

text: great window, which was thus made almost inaccessible. The table was
title: The Trial

text: already laid for a large number of people, as on Sundays almost all the
title: The Trial

text: tenants ate their dinner here at midday.
title: The Trial

text: When K. entered, Miss Montag came towards him from the window along one
title: The Trial

text: side of the table. They greeted each other in silence. Then Miss Montag,
title: The Trial

text: her head unusually erect as always, said, "I'm not sure whether you know
title: The Trial

text: me." K. looked at her with a frown. "Of course I do," he said, "you've
title: The Trial

text: been living here with Mrs. Grubach for quite some time now." "But I get
title: The Trial

text: the impression you don't pay much attention to what's going on in the
title: The Trial

text: lodging house," said Miss Montag. "No," said K. "Would you not like to
title: The Trial

text: sit down?" said Miss Montag. In silence, the two of them drew chairs out
title: The Trial

text: from the farthest end of the table and sat down facing each other. But
title: The Trial

text: Miss Montag stood straight up again as she had left her handbag on the
title: The Trial

text: window sill and went to fetch it; she shuffled down the whole length of
title: The Trial

text: the room. When she came back, the handbag lightly swinging, she said,
title: The Trial

text: "I'd like just to have a few words with you on behalf of my friend. She
title: The Trial

text: would have come herself, but she's feeling a little unwell today.
title: The Trial

text: Perhaps you'll be kind enough to forgive her and listen to me instead.
title: The Trial

text: There's anyway nothing that she could have said that I won't. On the
title: The Trial

text: contrary, in fact, I think I can say even more than her because I'm
title: The Trial

text: relatively impartial. Would you not agree?" "What is there to say,
title: The Trial

text: then?" answered K., who was tired of Miss Montag continuously watching
title: The Trial

text: his lips. In that way she took control of what he wanted to say before
title: The Trial

text: he said it. "Miss Bürstner clearly refuses to grant me the personal
title: The Trial

text: meeting that I asked her for." "That's how it is," said Miss Montag, "or
title: The Trial

text: rather, that's not at all how it is, the way you put it is remarkably
title: The Trial

text: severe. Generally speaking, meetings are neither granted nor the
title: The Trial

text: opposite. But it can be that meetings are considered unnecessary, and
title: The Trial

text: that's how it is here. Now, after your comment, I can speak openly. You
title: The Trial

text: asked my friend, verbally or in writing, for the chance to speak with
title: The Trial

text: her. Now my friend is aware of your reasons for asking for this
title: The Trial

text: meeting—or at least I suppose she is—and so, for reasons I know
title: The Trial

text: nothing about, she is quite sure that it would be of no benefit to
title: The Trial

text: anyone if this meeting actually took place. Moreover, it was only
title: The Trial

text: yesterday, and only very briefly, that she made it clear to me that such
title: The Trial

text: a meeting could be of no benefit for yourself either, she feels that it
title: The Trial

text: can only have been a matter of chance that such an idea came to you, and
title: The Trial

text: that even without any explanations from her, you will very soon come to
title: The Trial

text: realise yourself, if you have not done so already, the futility of your
title: The Trial

text: idea. My answer to that is that although it may be quite right, I
title: The Trial

text: consider it advantageous, if the matter is to be made perfectly clear,
title: The Trial

text: to give you an explicit answer. I offered my services in taking on the
title: The Trial

text: task, and after some hesitation my friend conceded. I hope, however,
title: The Trial

text: also to have acted in your interests, as even the slightest uncertainty
title: The Trial

text: in the least significant of matters will always remain a cause of
title: The Trial

text: suffering and if, as in this case, it can be removed without substantial
title: The Trial

text: effort, then it is better if that is done without delay." "I thank you,"
title: The Trial

text: said K. as soon as Miss Montag had finished. He stood slowly up, looked
title: The Trial

text: at her, then across the table, then out the window—the house opposite
title: The Trial

text: stood there in the sun—and went to the door. Miss Montag followed him a
title: The Trial

text: few paces, as if she did not quite trust him. At the door, however, both
title: The Trial

text: of them had to step back as it opened and Captain Lanz entered. This was
title: The Trial

text: the first time that K. had seen him close up. He was a large man of
title: The Trial

text: about forty with a tanned, fleshy face. He bowed slightly, intending it
title: The Trial

text: also for K., and then went over to Miss Montag and deferentially kissed
title: The Trial

text: her hand. He was very elegant in the way he moved. The courtesy he
title: The Trial

text: showed towards Miss Montag made a striking contrast with the way she had
title: The Trial

text: been treated by K. Nonetheless, Miss Montag did not seem to be cross
title: The Trial

text: with K. as it even seemed to him that she wanted to introduce the
title: The Trial

text: captain. K. however, did not want to be introduced, he would not have
title: The Trial

text: been able to show any sort of friendliness either to Miss Montag or to
title: The Trial

text: the captain, the kiss on the hand had, for K., bound them into a group
title: The Trial

text: which would keep him at a distance from Miss Bürstner whilst at the same
title: The Trial

text: time seeming to be totally harmless and unselfish. K. thought, however,
title: The Trial

text: that he saw more than that, he thought he also saw that Miss Montag had
title: The Trial

text: chosen a means of doing it that was good, but two-edged. She exaggerated
title: The Trial

text: the importance of the relationship between K. and Miss Bürstner, and
title: The Trial

text: above all she exaggerated the importance of asking to speak with her and
title: The Trial

text: she tried at the same time to make out that K. was exaggerating
title: The Trial

text: everything. She would be disappointed, K. did not want to exaggerate
title: The Trial

text: anything, he was aware that Miss Bürstner was a little typist who would
title: The Trial

text: not offer him much resistance for long. In doing so he deliberately took
title: The Trial

text: no account of what Mrs. Grubach had told him about Miss Bürstner. All
title: The Trial

text: these things were going through his mind as he left the room with hardly
title: The Trial

text: a polite word. He wanted to go straight to his room, but a little laugh
title: The Trial

text: from Miss Montag that he heard from the dining room behind him brought
title: The Trial

text: him to the idea that he might prepare a surprise for the two of them,
title: The Trial

text: the captain and Miss Montag. He looked round and listened to find out if
title: The Trial

text: there might be any disturbance from any of the surrounding rooms,
title: The Trial

text: everywhere was quiet, the only thing to be heard was the conversation
title: The Trial

text: from the dining room and Mrs. Grubach's voice from the passage leading
title: The Trial

text: to the kitchen. This seemed an opportune time, K. went to Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner's room and knocked gently. There was no sound so he knocked
title: The Trial

text: again but there was still no answer in reply. Was she asleep? Or was
title: The Trial

text: she really unwell? Or was she just pretending as she realised it could
title: The Trial

text: only be K. knocking so gently? K. assumed she was pretending and
title: The Trial

text: knocked harder, eventually, when the knocking brought no result, he
title: The Trial

text: carefully opened the door with the sense of doing something that was not
title: The Trial

text: only improper but also pointless. In the room there was no-one. What's
title: The Trial

text: more, it looked hardly at all like the room K. had known before. Against
title: The Trial

text: the wall there were now two beds behind one another, there were clothes
title: The Trial

text: piled up on three chairs near the door, a wardrobe stood open. Miss
title: The Trial

text: Bürstner must have gone out while Miss Montag was speaking to him in the
title: The Trial

text: dining room. K. was not greatly bothered by this, he had hardly expected
title: The Trial

text: to be able to find Miss Bürstner so easily and had made this attempt for
title: The Trial

text: little more reason than to spite Miss Montag. But that made it all the
title: The Trial

text: more embarrassing for him when, as he was closing the door again, he saw
title: The Trial

text: Miss Montag and the captain talking in the open doorway of the dining
title: The Trial

text: room. They had probably been standing there ever since K. had opened the
title: The Trial

text: door, they avoided seeming to observe K. but chatted lightly and
title: The Trial

text: followed his movements with glances, the absent minded glances to the
title: The Trial

text: side such as you make during a conversation. But these glances were
title: The Trial

text: heavy for K., and he rushed alongside the wall back into his own room.
