The Trial

text: The whip-man
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: One evening, a few days later, K. was walking along one of the corridors
title: The Trial

text: that separated his office from the main stairway—he was nearly the last
title: The Trial

text: one to leave for home that evening, there remained only a couple of
title: The Trial

text: workers in the light of a single bulb in the dispatch department—when
title: The Trial

text: he heard a sigh from behind a door which he had himself never opened but
title: The Trial

text: which he had always thought just led into a junk room. He stood in
title: The Trial

text: amazement and listened again to establish whether he might not be
title: The Trial

text: mistaken. For a while there was silence, but then came some more sighs.
title: The Trial

text: His first thought was to fetch one of the servitors, it might well have
title: The Trial

text: been worth having a witness present, but then he was taken by an
title: The Trial

text: uncontrollable curiosity that make him simply yank the door open. It
title: The Trial

text: was, as he had thought, a junk room. Old, unusable forms, empty stone
title: The Trial

text: ink-bottles lay scattered behind the entrance. But in the cupboard-like
title: The Trial

text: room itself stood three men, crouching under the low ceiling. A candle
title: The Trial

text: fixed on a shelf gave them light. "What are you doing here?" asked K.
title: The Trial

text: quietly, but crossly and without thinking. One of the men was clearly in
title: The Trial

text: charge, and attracted attention by being dressed in a kind of dark
title: The Trial

text: leather costume which left his neck and chest and his arms exposed. He
title: The Trial

text: did not answer. But the other two called out, "Mr. K.! We're to be
title: The Trial

text: beaten because you made a complaint about us to the examining judge."
title: The Trial

text: And now, K. finally realised that it was actually the two policemen,
title: The Trial

text: Franz and Willem, and that the third man held a cane in his hand with
title: The Trial

text: which to beat them. "Well," said K., staring at them, "I didn't make any
title: The Trial

text: complaint, I only said what took place in my home. And your behaviour
title: The Trial

text: was not entirely unobjectionable, after all." "Mr. K.," said Willem,
title: The Trial

text: while Franz clearly tried to shelter behind him as protection from the
title: The Trial

text: third man, "if you knew how badly we get paid you wouldn't think so
title: The Trial

text: badly of us. I've got a family to feed, and Franz here wanted to get
title: The Trial

text: married, you just have to get more money where you can, you can't do it
title: The Trial

text: just by working hard, not however hard you try. I was sorely tempted by
title: The Trial

text: your fine clothes, policemen aren't allowed to do that sort of thing,
title: The Trial

text: course they aren't, and it wasn't right of us, but it's tradition that
title: The Trial

text: the clothes go to the officers, that's how it's always been, believe me;
title: The Trial

text: and it's understandable too, isn't it, what can things like that mean
title: The Trial

text: for anyone unlucky enough to be arrested. But if he starts talking about
title: The Trial

text: it openly then the punishment has to follow." "I didn't know about any
title: The Trial

text: of this that you've been telling me, and I made no sort of request that
title: The Trial

text: you be punished, I was simply acting on principle." "Franz," said
title: The Trial

text: Willem, turning to the other policeman, "didn't I tell you that the
title: The Trial

text: gentleman didn't say he wanted us to be punished. Now you can hear for
title: The Trial

text: yourself, he didn't even know we'd have to be punished." "Don't you let
title: The Trial

text: them persuade you, talking like that," said the third man to K., "this
title: The Trial

text: punishment is both just and unavoidable." "Don't listen to him," said
title: The Trial

text: Willem, interrupting himself only to quickly bring his hand to his mouth
title: The Trial

text: when it had received a stroke of the cane, "we're only being punished
title: The Trial

text: because you made a complaint against us. Nothing would have happened to
title: The Trial

text: us otherwise, not even if they'd found out what we'd done. Can you call
title: The Trial

text: that justice? Both of us, me especially, we'd proved our worth as good
title: The Trial

text: police officers over a long period—you've got to admit yourself that as
title: The Trial

text: far as official work was concerned we did the job well—things looked
title: The Trial

text: good for us, we had prospects, it's quite certain that we would've been
title: The Trial

text: made whip-men too, like this one, only he had the luck not to have
title: The Trial

text: anyone make a complaint about him, as you really don't get many
title: The Trial

text: complaints like that. Only that's all finished now, Mr. K., our careers
title: The Trial

text: are at an end, we're going to have to do work now that's far inferior to
title: The Trial

text: police work and besides all this we're going to get this terrible,
title: The Trial

text: painful beating." "Can the cane really cause so much pain, then?" asked
title: The Trial

text: K., testing the cane that the whip-man swang in front of him. "We're
title: The Trial

text: going to have to strip off totally naked," said Willem. "Oh, I see,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., looking straight at the whip-man, his skin was burned brown
title: The Trial

text: like a sailor's, and his face showed health and vigour. "Is there then
title: The Trial

text: no possibility of sparing these two their beating?" he asked him. "No,"
title: The Trial

text: said the whip-man, shaking his head with a laugh. "Get undressed!" he
title: The Trial

text: ordered the policemen. And to K. he said, "You shouldn't believe
title: The Trial

text: everything they tell you, it's the fear of being beaten, it's already
title: The Trial

text: made them a bit weak in the head. This one here, for instance," he
title: The Trial

text: pointed at Willem, "all that he told you about his career prospects,
title: The Trial

text: it's just ridiculous. Look at him, look how fat he is—the first strokes
title: The Trial

text: of the cane will just get lost in all that fat. Do you know what it is
title: The Trial

text: that's made him so fat. He's in the habit of, everyone that gets
title: The Trial

text: arrested by him, he eats their breakfast. Didn't he eat up your
title: The Trial

text: breakfast? Yeah, I thought as much. But a man with a belly like that
title: The Trial

text: can't be made into a whip-man and never will be, that is quite out of
title: The Trial

text: the question." "There are whip-men like that," Willem insisted, who had
title: The Trial

text: just released the belt of this trousers. "No," said the whip-man,
title: The Trial

text: striking him such a blow with the cane on his neck that it made him
title: The Trial

text: wince, "you shouldn't be listening to this, just get undressed." "I
title: The Trial

text: would make it well worth your while if you would let them go," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: and without looking at the whip-man again—as such matters are best
title: The Trial

text: carried on with both pairs of eyes turned down—he pulled out his
title: The Trial

text: wallet. "And then you'd try and put in a complaint against me, too,"
title: The Trial

text: said the whip-man, "and get me flogged. No, no!" "Now, do be
title: The Trial

text: reasonable," said K., "if I had wanted to get these two punished I would
title: The Trial

text: not now be trying to buy their freedom, would I? I could simply close
title: The Trial

text: the door here behind me, go home and see or hear nothing more of it. But
title: The Trial

text: that's not what I'm doing, it really is of much more importance to me to
title: The Trial

text: let them go free; if I had realised they would be punished, or even that
title: The Trial

text: they might be punished, I would never have named them in the first place
title: The Trial

text: as they are not the ones I hold responsible. It's the organisation
title: The Trial

text: that's to blame, the high officials are the ones to blame." "That's how
title: The Trial

text: it is!" shouted the policemen, who then immediately received another
title: The Trial

text: blow on their backs, which were by now exposed. "If you had a senior
title: The Trial

text: judge here beneath your stick," said K., pressing down the cane as he
title: The Trial

text: spoke to stop it being raised once more, "I really would do nothing to
title: The Trial

text: stop you, on the contrary, I would even pay you money to give you all
title: The Trial

text: the more strength." "Yeah, that's all very plausible, what you're saying
title: The Trial

text: there," said the whip-man, "only I'm not the sort of person you can
title: The Trial

text: bribe. It's my job to flog people, so I flog them." Franz, the
title: The Trial

text: policeman, had been fairly quiet so far, probably in expectation of a
title: The Trial

text: good result from K.'s intervention, but now he stepped forward to the
title: The Trial

text: door wearing just his trousers, knelt down hanging on to K.'s arm and
title: The Trial

text: whispered, "Even if you can't get mercy shown for both of us, at least
title: The Trial

text: try and get me set free. Willem is older than me, he's less sensitive
title: The Trial

text: than me in every way, he even got a light beating a couple of years
title: The Trial

text: ago, but my record's still clean, I only did things the way I did
title: The Trial

text: because Willem led me on to it, he's been my teacher both for good and
title: The Trial

text: bad. Down in front of the bank my poor bride is waiting for me at the
title: The Trial

text: entrance, I'm so ashamed of myself, it's pitiful." His face was flowing
title: The Trial

text: over with tears, and he wiped it dry on K.'s coat. "I'm not going to
title: The Trial

text: wait any longer," said the whip-man, taking hold of the cane in both
title: The Trial

text: hands and laying in to Franz while Willem cowered back in a corner and
title: The Trial

text: looked on secretly, not even daring to turn his head. Then, the sudden
title: The Trial

text: scream that shot out from Franz was long and irrevocable, it seemed to
title: The Trial

text: come not from a human being but from an instrument that was being
title: The Trial

text: tortured, the whole corridor rang with it, it must have been heard by
title: The Trial

text: everyone in the building. "Don't shout like that!", called out K.,
title: The Trial

text: unable to prevent himself, and, as he looked anxiously in the direction
title: The Trial

text: from which the servitor would come, he gave Franz a shove, not hard, but
title: The Trial

text: hard enough for him to fall down unconscious, clawing at the ground with
title: The Trial

text: his hands by reflex; he still did not avoid being hit; the rod still
title: The Trial

text: found him on the floor; the tip of the rod swang regularly up and down
title: The Trial

text: while he rolled to and fro under its blows. And now one of the servitors
title: The Trial

text: appeared in the distance, with another a few steps behind him. K. had
title: The Trial

text: quickly thrown the door shut, gone over to one of the windows
title: The Trial

text: overlooking the yard and opened it. The screams had completely stopped.
title: The Trial

text: So that the servitor wouldn't come in, he called out, "It's only me!"
title: The Trial

text: "Good evening, chief clerk," somebody called back. "Is there anything
title: The Trial

text: wrong?" "No, no," answered K., "it's only a dog yelping in the yard."
title: The Trial

text: There was no sound from the servitors so he added, "You can go back to
title: The Trial

text: what you were doing." He did not want to become involved with a
title: The Trial

text: conversation with them, and so he leant out of the window. A little
title: The Trial

text: while later, when he looked out in the corridor, they had already gone.
title: The Trial

text: Now, K. remained at the window, he did not dare go back into the junk
title: The Trial

text: room, and he did not want to go home either. The yard he looked down
title: The Trial

text: into was small and rectangular, all around it were offices, all the
title: The Trial

text: windows were now dark and only those at the very top caught a reflection
title: The Trial

text: of the moon. K. tried hard to see into the darkness of one corner of the
title: The Trial

text: yard, where a few handcarts had been left behind one another. He felt
title: The Trial

text: anguish at not having been able to prevent the flogging, but that was
title: The Trial

text: not his fault, if Franz had not screamed like that—clearly it must have
title: The Trial

text: caused a great deal of pain but it's important to maintain control of
title: The Trial

text: oneself at important moments—if Franz had not screamed then it was at
title: The Trial

text: least highly probable that K. would have been able to dissuade the
title: The Trial

text: whip-man. If all the junior officers were contemptible why would the
title: The Trial

text: whip-man, whose position was the most inhumane of all, be any exception,
title: The Trial

text: and K. had noticed very clearly how his eyes had lit up when he saw the
title: The Trial

text: banknotes, he had obviously only seemed serious about the flogging to
title: The Trial

text: raise the level of the bribe a little. And K. had not been ungenerous,
title: The Trial

text: he really had wanted to get the policemen freed; if he really had now
title: The Trial

text: begun to do something against the degeneracy of the court then it was a
title: The Trial

text: matter of course that he would have to do something here as well. But of
title: The Trial

text: course, it became impossible for him to do anything as soon as Franz
title: The Trial

text: started screaming. K. could not possibly have let the junior bank staff,
title: The Trial

text: and perhaps even all sorts of other people, come along and catch him by
title: The Trial

text: surprise as he haggled with those people in the junk room. Nobody could
title: The Trial

text: really expect that sort of sacrifice of him. If that had been his
title: The Trial

text: intention then it would almost have been easier, K. would have taken
title: The Trial

text: his own clothes off and offered himself to the whip-man in the
title: The Trial

text: policemen's place. The whip-man would certainly not have accepted this
title: The Trial

text: substitution anyway, as in that way he would have seriously violated his
title: The Trial

text: duty without gaining any benefit. He would most likely have violated his
title: The Trial

text: duty twice over, as court employees were probably under orders not to
title: The Trial

text: cause any harm to K. while he was facing charges, although there may
title: The Trial

text: have been special conditions in force here. However things stood, K. was
title: The Trial

text: able to do no more than throw the door shut, even though that would
title: The Trial

text: still do nothing to remove all the dangers he faced. It was regrettable
title: The Trial

text: that he had given Franz a shove, and it could only be excused by the
title: The Trial

text: heat of the moment.
title: The Trial

text: In the distance, he heard the steps of the servitors; he did not want
title: The Trial

text: them to be too aware of his presence, so he closed the window and
title: The Trial

text: walked towards the main staircase. At the door of the junk room he
title: The Trial

text: stopped and listened for a little while. All was silent. The two
title: The Trial

text: policemen were entirely at the whip-man's mercy; he could have beaten
title: The Trial

text: them to death. K. reached his hand out for the door handle but drew it
title: The Trial

text: suddenly back. He was no longer in any position to help anyone, and the
title: The Trial

text: servitors would soon be back; he did, though, promise himself that he
title: The Trial

text: would raise the matter again with somebody and see that, as far as it
title: The Trial

text: was in his power, those who really were guilty, the high officials whom
title: The Trial

text: nobody had so far dared point out to him, received their due punishment.
title: The Trial

text: As he went down the main stairway at the front of the bank, he looked
title: The Trial

text: carefully round at everyone who was passing, but there was no girl to be
title: The Trial

text: seen who might have been waiting for somebody, not even within some
title: The Trial

text: distance from the bank. Franz's claim that his bride was waiting for him
title: The Trial

text: was thus shown to be a lie, albeit one that was forgivable and intended
title: The Trial

text: only to elicit more sympathy.
title: The Trial

text: The policemen were still on K.'s mind all through the following day; he
title: The Trial

text: was unable to concentrate on his work and had to stay in his office a
title: The Trial

text: little longer than the previous day so that he could finish it. On the
title: The Trial

text: way home, as he passed by the junk room again, he opened its door as if
title: The Trial

text: that had been his habit. Instead of the darkness he expected, he saw
title: The Trial

text: everything unchanged from the previous evening, and did not know how he
title: The Trial

text: should respond. Everything was exactly the same as he had seen it when
title: The Trial

text: he had opened the door the previous evening. The forms and bottles of
title: The Trial

text: ink just inside the doorway, the whip-man with his cane, the two
title: The Trial

text: policemen, still undressed, the candle on the shelf, and the two
title: The Trial

text: policemen began to wail and call out "Mr. K.!" K. slammed the door
title: The Trial

text: immediately shut, and even thumped on it with his fists as if that
title: The Trial

text: would shut it all the firmer. Almost in tears, he ran to the servitors
title: The Trial

text: working quietly at the copying machine. "Go and get that junk room
title: The Trial

text: cleared out!" he shouted, and, in amazement, they stopped what they were
title: The Trial

text: doing. "It should have been done long ago, we're sinking in dirt!" They
title: The Trial

text: would be able to do the job the next day, K. nodded, it was too late in
title: The Trial

text: the evening to make them do it there and then as he had originally
title: The Trial

text: intended. He sat down briefly in order to keep them near him for a
title: The Trial

text: little longer, looked through a few of the copies to give the impression
title: The Trial

text: that he was checking them and then, as he saw that they would not dare
title: The Trial

text: to leave at the same time as himself, went home tired and with his mind
title: The Trial

text: numb.
title: The Trial

text: <hr class="chap x-ebookmaker-drop" />
title: The Trial

text: <div class="chapter">
title: The Trial

text: <h2 id="Chapter_Six">Chapter Six
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: K.'s uncle—Leni
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: One afternoon—K. was very busy at the time, getting the post
title: The Trial

text: ready—K.'s Uncle Karl, a small country land owner, came into the room,
title: The Trial

text: pushing his way between two of the staff who were bringing in some
title: The Trial

text: papers. K. had long expected his uncle to appear, but the sight of him
title: The Trial

text: now shocked K. far less than the prospect of it had done a long time
title: The Trial

text: before. His uncle was bound to come, K. had been sure of that for about
title: The Trial

text: a month. He already thought at the time he could see how his uncle
title: The Trial

text: would arrive, slightly bowed, his battered panama hat in his left hand,
title: The Trial

text: his right hand already stretched out over the desk long before he was
title: The Trial

text: close enough as he rushed carelessly towards K. knocking over everything
title: The Trial

text: that was in his way. K.'s uncle was always in a hurry, as he suffered
title: The Trial

text: from the unfortunate belief that he had a number of things to do while
title: The Trial

text: he was in the big city and had to settle all of them in one day—his
title: The Trial

text: visits were only ever for one day—and at the same time thought he could
title: The Trial

text: not forgo any conversation or piece of business or pleasure that might
title: The Trial

text: arise by chance. Uncle Karl was K.'s former guardian, and so K. was
title: The Trial

text: duty-bound to help him in all of this as well as to offer him a bed for
title: The Trial

text: the night. "I'm haunted by a ghost from the country," he would say.
title: The Trial

text: As soon as they had greeted each other—K. had invited him to sit in
title: The Trial

text: the armchair but Uncle Karl had no time for that—he said he wanted to
title: The Trial

text: speak briefly with K. in private. "It is necessary," he said with a
title: The Trial

text: tired gulp, "it is necessary for my peace of mind." K. immediately sent
title: The Trial

text: the junior staff from the room and told them to let no-one in. "What's
title: The Trial

text: this that I've been hearing, Josef?" cried K.'s uncle when they were
title: The Trial

text: alone, as he sat on the table shoving various papers under himself
title: The Trial

text: without looking at them to make himself more comfortable. K. said
title: The Trial

text: nothing, he knew what was coming, but, suddenly relieved from the
title: The Trial

text: effort of the work he had been doing, he gave way to a pleasant
title: The Trial

text: lassitude and looked out the window at the other side of the street.
title: The Trial

text: From where he sat, he could see just a small, triangular section of it,
title: The Trial

text: part of the empty walls of houses between two shop windows. "You're
title: The Trial

text: staring out the window!" called out his uncle, raising his arms, "For
title: The Trial

text: God's sake, Josef, give me an answer! Is it true, can it really be
title: The Trial

text: true?" "Uncle Karl," said K., wrenching himself back from his
title: The Trial

text: daydreaming, "I really don't know what it is you want of me." "Josef,"
title: The Trial

text: said his uncle in a warning tone, "as far as I know, you've always told
title: The Trial

text: the truth. Am I to take what you've just said as a bad sign?" "I think I
title: The Trial

text: know what it is you want," said K. obediently, "I expect you've heard
title: The Trial

text: about my trial." "That's right," answered his uncle with a slow nod,
title: The Trial

text: "I've heard about your trial." "Who did you hear it from, then?" asked
title: The Trial

text: K. "Erna wrote to me," said his uncle, "she doesn't have much contact
title: The Trial

text: with you, it's true, you don't pay very much attention to her, I'm
title: The Trial

text: afraid to say, but she learned about it nonetheless. I got her letter
title: The Trial

text: today and, of course, I came straight here. And for no other reason, but
title: The Trial

text: it seems to me that this is reason enough. I can read you out the part
title: The Trial

text: of the letter that concerns you." He drew the letter out from his
title: The Trial

text: wallet. "Here it is. She writes; 'I have not seen Josef for a long time,
title: The Trial

text: I was in the bank last week but Josef was so busy that they would not
title: The Trial

text: let me through; I waited there for nearly an hour but then I had to go
title: The Trial

text: home as I had my piano lesson. I would have liked to have spoken to him,
title: The Trial

text: maybe there will be a chance another time. He sent me a big box of
title: The Trial

text: chocolates for my name-day, that was very nice and attentive of him. I
title: The Trial

text: forgot to tell you about it when I wrote, and I only remember now that
title: The Trial

text: you ask me about it. Chocolate, as I am sure you are aware, disappears
title: The Trial

text: straight away in this lodging house, almost as soon as you know somebody
title: The Trial

text: has given you chocolate it is gone. But there is something else I wanted
title: The Trial

text: to tell you about Josef. Like I said, they would not let me through to
title: The Trial

text: see him at the bank because he was negotiating with some gentleman just
title: The Trial

text: then. After I had been waiting quietly for quite a long time I asked one
title: The Trial

text: of the staff whether his meeting would last much longer. He said it
title: The Trial

text: might well do, as it was probably about the legal proceedings, he said,
title: The Trial

text: that were being conducted against him. I asked what sort of legal
title: The Trial

text: proceedings it was that were being conducted against the chief clerk,
title: The Trial

text: and whether he was not making some mistake, but he said he was not
title: The Trial

text: making any mistake, there were legal proceedings underway and even that
title: The Trial

text: they were about something quite serious, but he did not know any more
title: The Trial

text: about it. He would have liked to have been of some help to the chief
title: The Trial

text: clerk himself, as the chief clerk was a gentleman, good and honest, but
title: The Trial

text: he did not know what it was he could do and merely hoped there would be
title: The Trial

text: some influential gentlemen who would take his side. I'm sure that is
title: The Trial

text: what will happen and that everything will turn out for the best in the
title: The Trial

text: end, but in the mean time things do not look at all good, and you can
title: The Trial

text: see that from the mood of the chief clerk himself. Of course, I did not
title: The Trial

text: place too much importance on this conversation, and even did my best to
title: The Trial

text: put the bank clerk's mind at rest, he was quite a simple man. I told him
title: The Trial

text: he was not to speak to anyone else about this, and I think it is all
title: The Trial

text: just a rumour, but I still think it might be good if you, Dear Father,
title: The Trial

text: if you looked into the matter the next time you visit. It will be easy
title: The Trial

text: for you to find out more detail and, if it is really necessary, to do
title: The Trial

text: something about it through the great and influential people you know.
title: The Trial

text: But if it is not necessary, and that is what seems most likely, then at
title: The Trial

text: least your daughter will soon have the chance to embrace you and I look
title: The Trial

text: forward to it.'—She's a good child," said K.'s uncle when he had
title: The Trial

text: finished reading, and wiped a few tears from his eyes. K. nodded. With
title: The Trial

text: all the different disruptions he had had recently he had completely
title: The Trial

text: forgotten about Erna, even her birthday, and the story of the chocolates
title: The Trial

text: had clearly just been invented so that he wouldn't get in trouble with
title: The Trial

text: his aunt and uncle. It was very touching, and even the theatre tickets,
title: The Trial

text: which he would regularly send her from then on, would not be enough to
title: The Trial

text: repay her, but he really did not feel, now, that it was right for him to
title: The Trial

text: visit her in her lodgings and hold conversations with a little, eighteen
title: The Trial

text: year old schoolgirl. "And what do you have to say about that?" asked his
title: The Trial

text: uncle, who had forgotten all his rush and excitement as he read the
title: The Trial

text: letter, and seemed to be about to read it again. "Yes, Uncle," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: "it is true." "True!" called out his uncle. "What is true? How can this
title: The Trial

text: be true? What sort of trial is it? Not a criminal trial, I hope?" "It's
title: The Trial

text: a criminal trial," answered K. "And you sit quietly here while you've
title: The Trial

text: got a criminal trial round your neck?" shouted his uncle, getting ever
title: The Trial

text: louder. "The more calm I am, the better it will be for the outcome,"
title: The Trial

text: said K. in a tired voice, "don't worry." "How can I help worrying?!"
title: The Trial

text: shouted his uncle, "Josef, my dear Josef, think about yourself, about
title: The Trial

text: your family, think about our good name! Up till now, you've always been
title: The Trial

text: our pride, don't now become our disgrace. I don't like the way you're
title: The Trial

text: behaving," he said, looking at K. with his head at an angle, "that's not
title: The Trial

text: how an innocent man behaves when he's accused of something, not if he's
title: The Trial

text: still got any strength in him. Just tell me what it's all about so that
title: The Trial

text: I can help you. It's something to do with the bank, I take it?" "No,"
title: The Trial

text: said K. as he stood up, "and you're speaking too loud, Uncle, I expect
title: The Trial

text: one of the staff is listening at the door and I find that rather
title: The Trial

text: unpleasant. It's best if we go somewhere else, then I can answer all
title: The Trial

text: your questions, as far as I can. And I know very well that I have to
title: The Trial

text: account to the family for what I do." "You certainly do!" his uncle
title: The Trial

text: shouted, "Quite right, you do. Now just get a move on, Josef, hurry up
title: The Trial

text: now!" "I still have a few documents I need to prepare," said K., and,
title: The Trial

text: using the intercom, he summoned his deputy who entered a few moments
title: The Trial

text: later. K.'s uncle, still angry and excited, gestured with his hand to
title: The Trial

text: show that K. had summoned him, even though there was no need whatever to
title: The Trial

text: do so. K. stood in front of the desk and explained to the young man, who
title: The Trial

text: listened calm and attentive, what would need to be done that day in his
title: The Trial

text: absence, speaking in a calm voice and making use of various documents.
title: The Trial

text: The presence of K.'s uncle while this was going on was quite disturbing;
title: The Trial

text: he did not listen to what was being said, but at first he stood there
title: The Trial

text: with eyes wide open and nervously biting his lips. Then he began to walk
title: The Trial

text: up and down the room, stopped now and then at the window, or stood in
title: The Trial

text: front of a picture always making various exclamations such as, "That is
title: The Trial

text: totally incomprehensible to me!" or "Now just tell me, what are you
title: The Trial

text: supposed to make of that?" The young man pretended to notice nothing of
title: The Trial

text: this and listened to K.'s instructions through to the end, he made a few
title: The Trial

text: notes, bowed to both K. and his uncle and then left the room. K.'s uncle
title: The Trial

text: had turned his back to him and was looking out the window, bunching up
title: The Trial

text: the curtains with his outstretched hands. The door had hardly closed
title: The Trial

text: when he called out, "At last! Now that he's stopped jumping about we can
title: The Trial

text: go too!" Once they were in the front hall of the bank, where several
title: The Trial

text: members of staff were standing about and where, just then, the deputy
title: The Trial

text: director was walking across, there was unfortunately no way of stopping
title: The Trial

text: K.'s uncle from continually asking questions about the trial. "Now
title: The Trial

text: then, Josef," he began, lightly acknowledging the bows from those around
title: The Trial

text: them as they passed, "tell me everything about this trial; what sort of
title: The Trial

text: trial is it?" K. made a few comments which conveyed little information,
title: The Trial

text: even laughed a little, and it was only when they reached the front steps
title: The Trial

text: that he explained to his uncle that he had not wanted to talk openly in
title: The Trial

text: front of those people. "Quite right," said his uncle, "but now start
title: The Trial

text: talking." With his head to one side, and smoking his cigar in short,
title: The Trial

text: impatient draughts, he listened. "First of all, Uncle," said K., "it's
title: The Trial

text: not a trial like you'd have in a normal courtroom." "So much the worse,"
title: The Trial

text: said his uncle. "How's that?" asked K., looking at him. "What I mean is,
title: The Trial

text: that's for the worse," he repeated. They were standing on the front
title: The Trial

text: steps of the bank; as the doorkeeper seemed to be listening to what they
title: The Trial

text: were saying K. drew his uncle down further, where they were absorbed
title: The Trial

text: into the bustle of the street. His uncle took K.'s arm and stopped
title: The Trial

text: asking questions with such urgency about the trial, they walked on for a
title: The Trial

text: while in silence. "But how did all this come about?" he eventually
title: The Trial

text: asked, stopping abruptly enough to startle the people walking behind,
title: The Trial

text: who had to avoid walking into him. "Things like this don't come all of a
title: The Trial

text: sudden, they start developing a long time beforehand, there must have
title: The Trial

text: been warning signs of it, why didn't you write to me? You know I'd do
title: The Trial

text: anything for you, to some extent I am still your guardian, and until
title: The Trial

text: today that's something I was proud of. I'll still help you, of course I
title: The Trial

text: will, only now, now that the trial is already underway, it makes it
title: The Trial

text: very difficult. But whatever; the best thing now is for you to take a
title: The Trial

text: short holiday staying with us in the country. You've lost weight, I can
title: The Trial

text: see that now. The country life will give you strength, that will be
title: The Trial

text: good, there's bound to be a lot of hard work ahead of you. But besides
title: The Trial

text: that it'll be a way of getting you away from the court, to some extent.
title: The Trial

text: Here they've got every means of showing the powers at their disposal
title: The Trial

text: and they're automatically bound to use them against you; in the country
title: The Trial

text: they'll either have to delegate authority to different bodies or just
title: The Trial

text: have to try and bother you by letter, telegram or telephone. And that's
title: The Trial

text: bound to weaken the effect, it won't release you from them but it'll
title: The Trial

text: give you room to breathe." "You could forbid me to leave," said K., who
title: The Trial

text: had been drawn slightly into his uncle's way of thinking by what he had
title: The Trial

text: been saying. "I didn't think you would do it," said his uncle
title: The Trial

text: thoughtfully, "you won't suffer too much loss of power by moving away."
title: The Trial

text: K. grasped his uncle under the arm to prevent him stopping still and
title: The Trial

text: said, "I thought you'd think all this is less important than I do, and
title: The Trial

text: now you're taking it so hard." "Josef," called his uncle trying to
title: The Trial

text: disentangle himself from him so that he could stop walking, but K. did
title: The Trial

text: not let go, "you've completely changed, you used to be so astute, are
title: The Trial

text: you losing it now? Do you want to lose the trial? Do you realise what
title: The Trial

text: that would mean? That would mean you would be simply destroyed. And
title: The Trial

text: that everyone you know would be pulled down with you or at the very
title: The Trial

text: least humiliated, disgraced right down to the ground. Josef, pull
title: The Trial

text: yourself together. The way you're so indifferent about it, it's driving
title: The Trial

text: me mad. Looking at you I can almost believe that old saying: 'Having a
title: The Trial

text: trial like that means losing a trial like that'." "My dear Uncle," said
title: The Trial

text: K., "it won't do any good to get excited, it's no good for you to do it
title: The Trial

text: and it'd be no good for me to do it. The case won't be won by getting
title: The Trial

text: excited, and please admit that my practical experience counts for
title: The Trial

text: something, just as I have always and still do respect your experience,
title: The Trial

text: even when it surprises me. You say that the family will also be
title: The Trial

text: affected by this trial; I really can't see how, but that's beside the
title: The Trial

text: point and I'm quite willing to follow your instructions in all of this.
title: The Trial

text: Only, I don't see any advantage in staying in the country, not even for
title: The Trial

text: you, as that would indicate flight and a sense of guilt. And besides,
title: The Trial

text: although I am more subject to persecution if I stay in the city I can
title: The Trial

text: also press the matter forward better here." "You're right," said his
title: The Trial

text: uncle in a tone that seemed to indicate they were finally coming closer
title: The Trial

text: to each other, "I just made the suggestion because, as I saw it, if you
title: The Trial

text: stay in the city the case will be put in danger by your indifference to
title: The Trial

text: it, and I thought it was better if I did the work for you. But will you
title: The Trial

text: push things forward yourself with all your strength, if so, that will
title: The Trial

text: naturally be far better." "We're agreed then," said K. "And do you have
title: The Trial

text: any suggestions for what I should do next?" "Well, naturally I'll have
title: The Trial

text: to think about it," said his uncle, "you must bear in mind that I've
title: The Trial

text: been living in the country for twenty years now, almost without a
title: The Trial

text: break, you lose your ability to deal with matters like this. But I do
title: The Trial

text: have some important connections with several people who, I expect, know
title: The Trial

text: their way around these things better than I do, and to contact them is a
title: The Trial

text: matter of course. Out there in the country I've been getting out of
title: The Trial

text: condition, I'm sure you're already aware of that. It's only at times
title: The Trial

text: like this that you notice it yourself. And this affair of yours came
title: The Trial

text: largely unexpected, although, oddly enough, I had expected something of
title: The Trial

text: the sort after I'd read Erna's letter, and today when I saw your face I
title: The Trial

text: knew it with almost total certainty. But all that is by the by, the
title: The Trial

text: important thing now is, we have no time to lose." Even while he was
title: The Trial

text: still speaking, K.'s uncle had stood on tiptoe to summon a taxi and now
title: The Trial

text: he pulled K. into the car behind himself as he called out an address to
title: The Trial

text: the driver. "We're going now to see Dr. Huld, the lawyer," he said, "we
title: The Trial

text: were at school together. I'm sure you know the name, don't you? No? Well
title: The Trial

text: that is odd. He's got a very good reputation as a defence barrister and
title: The Trial

text: for working with the poor. But I esteem him especially as someone you
title: The Trial

text: can trust." "It's alright with me, whatever you do," said K., although
title: The Trial

text: he was made uneasy by the rushed and urgent way his uncle was dealing
title: The Trial

text: with the matter. It was not very encouraging, as the accused, to be
title: The Trial

text: taken to a lawyer for poor people. "I didn't know," he said, "that you
title: The Trial

text: could take on a lawyer in matters like this." "Well of course you can,"
title: The Trial

text: said his uncle, "that goes without saying. Why wouldn't you take on a
title: The Trial

text: lawyer? And now, so that I'm properly instructed in this matter, tell me
title: The Trial

text: what's been happening so far." K. instantly began telling his uncle
title: The Trial

text: about what had been happening, holding nothing back—being completely
title: The Trial

text: open with him was the only way that K. could protest at his uncle's
title: The Trial

text: belief that the trial was a great disgrace. He mentioned Miss Bürstner's
title: The Trial

text: name just once and in passing, but that did nothing to diminish his
title: The Trial

text: openness about the trial as Miss Bürstner had no connection with it. As
title: The Trial

text: he spoke, he looked out the window and saw how, just then, they were
title: The Trial

text: getting closer to the suburb where the court offices were. He drew this
title: The Trial

text: to his uncle's attention, but he did not find the coincidence especially
title: The Trial

text: remarkable. The taxi stopped in front of a dark building. K.'s uncle
title: The Trial

text: knocked at the very first door at ground level; while they waited he
title: The Trial

text: smiled, showing his big teeth, and whispered, "Eight o'clock; not the
title: The Trial

text: usual sort of time to be visiting a lawyer, but Huld won't mind it from
title: The Trial

text: me." Two large, black eyes appeared in the spy-hatch in the door, they
title: The Trial

text: stared at the two visitors for a while and then disappeared; the door,
title: The Trial

text: however, did not open. K. and his uncle confirmed to each other the fact
title: The Trial

text: that they had seen the two eyes. "A new maid, afraid of strangers," said
title: The Trial

text: K.'s uncle, and knocked again. The eyes appeared once more. This time
title: The Trial

text: they seemed almost sad, but the open gas flame that burned with a hiss
title: The Trial

text: close above their heads gave off little light and that may have merely
title: The Trial

text: created an illusion. "Open the door," called K.'s uncle, raising his
title: The Trial

text: fist against it, "we are friends of Dr. Huld, the lawyer!" "Dr. Huld is
title: The Trial

text: ill," whispered someone behind them. In a doorway at the far end of a
title: The Trial

text: narrow passage stood a man in his dressing gown, giving them this
title: The Trial

text: information in an extremely quiet voice. K.'s uncle, who had already
title: The Trial

text: been made very angry by the long wait, turned abruptly round and
title: The Trial

text: retorted, "Ill. You say he's ill?" and strode towards the gentleman in a
title: The Trial

text: way that seemed almost threatening, as if he were the illness himself.
title: The Trial

text: "They've opened the door for you, now," said the gentleman, pointing at
title: The Trial

text: the door of the lawyer. He pulled his dressing gown together and
title: The Trial

text: disappeared. The door had indeed been opened, a young girl—K.
title: The Trial

text: recognised the dark, slightly bulging eyes—stood in the hallway in a
title: The Trial

text: long white apron, holding a candle in her hand. "Next time, open up
title: The Trial

text: sooner!" said K.'s uncle instead of a greeting, while the girl made a
title: The Trial

text: slight curtsey. "Come along, Josef," he then said to K. who was slowly
title: The Trial
