text: defects'?" asked K. "Yeah," said Leni, "as I do have a bodily defect,
title: The Trial

text: just a little one. Look." She spread the middle and ring fingers of her
title: The Trial

text: right hand apart from each other. Between those fingers the flap of skin
title: The Trial

text: connecting them reached up almost as far as the top joint of the little
title: The Trial

text: finger. In the darkness, K. did not see at first what it was she wanted
title: The Trial

text: to show him, so she led his hand to it so that he could feel. "What a
title: The Trial

text: freak of nature," said K., and when he had taken a look at the whole
title: The Trial

text: hand he added, "What a pretty claw!" Leni looked on with a kind of pride
title: The Trial

text: as K. repeatedly opened and closed her two fingers in amazement, until,
title: The Trial

text: finally, he briefly kissed them and let go. "Oh!" she immediately
title: The Trial

text: exclaimed, "you kissed me!" Hurriedly, and with her mouth open, she
title: The Trial

text: clambered up K.'s lap with her knees. He was almost aghast as he looked
title: The Trial

text: up at her, now that she was so close to him there was a bitter,
title: The Trial

text: irritating smell from her, like pepper, she grasped his head, leant out
title: The Trial

text: over him, and bit and kissed his neck, even biting into his hair. "I've
title: The Trial

text: taken her place!" she exclaimed from time to time. "Just look, now
title: The Trial

text: you've taken me instead of her!" Just then, her knee slipped out and,
title: The Trial

text: with a little cry, she nearly fell down onto the carpet, K. tried to
title: The Trial

text: hold her by putting his arms around her and was pulled down with her.
title: The Trial

text: "Now you're mine," she said. Her last words to him as he left were,
title: The Trial

text: "Here's the key to the door, come whenever you want," and she planted an
title: The Trial

text: undirected kiss on his back. When he stepped out the front door there
title: The Trial

text: was a light rain falling, he was about to go to the middle of the street
title: The Trial

text: to see if he could still glimpse Leni at the window when K.'s uncle
title: The Trial

text: leapt out of a car that K., thinking of other things, had not seen
title: The Trial

text: waiting outside the building. He took hold of K. by both arms and shoved
title: The Trial

text: him against the door as if he wanted to nail him to it. "Young man," he
title: The Trial

text: shouted, "how could you do a thing like that?! Things were going well
title: The Trial

text: with this business of yours, now you've caused it terrible damage. You
title: The Trial

text: slip off with some dirty, little thing who, moreover, is obviously the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer's beloved, and stay away for hours. You don't even try to find an
title: The Trial

text: excuse, don't try to hide anything, no, you're quite open about it, you
title: The Trial

text: run off with her and stay there. And meanwhile we're sitting there, your
title: The Trial

text: uncle who's going to such effort for you, the lawyer who needs to be won
title: The Trial

text: over to your side, and above all the office director, a very important
title: The Trial

text: gentleman who is in direct command of your affair in its present stage.
title: The Trial

text: We wanted to discuss how best to help you, I had to handle the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: very carefully, he had to handle the office director carefully, and you
title: The Trial

text: had most reason of all to at least give me some support. Instead of
title: The Trial

text: which you stay away. Eventually we couldn't keep up the pretence any
title: The Trial

text: longer, but these are polite and highly capable men, they didn't say
title: The Trial

text: anything about it so as to spare my feelings but in the end not even
title: The Trial

text: they could continue to force themselves and, as they couldn't speak
title: The Trial

text: about the matter in hand, they became silent. We sat there for several
title: The Trial

text: minutes, listening to see whether you wouldn't finally come back. All in
title: The Trial

text: vain. In the end the office director stood up, as he had stayed far
title: The Trial

text: longer than he had originally intended, made his farewell, looked at me
title: The Trial

text: in sympathy without being able to help, he waited at the door for a long
title: The Trial

text: time although it's more than I can understand why he was being so good,
title: The Trial

text: and then he went. I, of course, was glad he'd gone, I'd been holding my
title: The Trial

text: breath all this time. All this had even more effect on the lawyer lying
title: The Trial

text: there ill, when I took my leave of him, the good man, he was quite
title: The Trial

text: unable to speak. You have probably contributed to his total collapse
title: The Trial

text: and so brought the very man who you are dependent on closer to his
title: The Trial

text: death. And me, your own uncle, you leave me here in the rain—just feel
title: The Trial

text: this, I'm wet right through—waiting here for hours, sick with worry."
title: The Trial

text: <hr class="chap x-ebookmaker-drop" />
title: The Trial

text: <div class="chapter">
title: The Trial

text: <h2 id="Chapter_Seven">Chapter Seven
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Lawyer—Manufacturer—Painter
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: One winter morning—snow was falling in the dull light outside—K. was
title: The Trial

text: sitting in his office, already extremely tired despite the early hour.
title: The Trial

text: He had told the servitor he was engaged in a major piece of work and
title: The Trial

text: none of the junior staff should be allowed in to see him, so he would
title: The Trial

text: not be disturbed by them at least. But instead of working he turned
title: The Trial

text: round in his chair, slowly moved various items around his desk, but
title: The Trial

text: then, without being aware of it, he lay his arm stretched out on the
title: The Trial

text: desk top and sat there immobile with his head sunk down on his chest.
title: The Trial

text: He was no longer able to get the thought of the trial out of his head.
title: The Trial

text: He had often wondered whether it might not be a good idea to work out a
title: The Trial

text: written defence and hand it in to the court. It would contain a short
title: The Trial

text: description of his life and explain why he had acted the way he had at
title: The Trial

text: each event that was in any way important, whether he now considered he
title: The Trial

text: had acted well or ill, and his reasons for each. There was no doubt of
title: The Trial

text: the advantages a written defence of this sort would have over relying
title: The Trial

text: on the lawyer, who was anyway not without his shortcomings. K. had no
title: The Trial

text: idea what actions the lawyer was taking; it was certainly not a lot, it
title: The Trial

text: was more than a month since the lawyer had summoned him, and none of
title: The Trial

text: the previous discussions had given K. the impression that this man would
title: The Trial

text: be able to do much for him. Most importantly, he had asked him hardly
title: The Trial

text: any questions. And there were so many questions here to be asked.
title: The Trial

text: Asking questions was the most important thing. K. had the feeling that
title: The Trial

text: he would be able to ask all the questions needed here himself. The
title: The Trial

text: lawyer, in contrast, did not ask questions but did all the talking
title: The Trial

text: himself or sat silently facing him, leant forward slightly over the
title: The Trial

text: desk, probably because he was hard of hearing, pulled on a strand of
title: The Trial

text: hair in the middle of his beard and looked down at the carpet, perhaps
title: The Trial

text: at the very spot where K. had lain with Leni. Now and then he would give
title: The Trial

text: K. some vague warning of the sort you give to children. His speeches
title: The Trial

text: were as pointless as they were boring, and K. decided that when the
title: The Trial

text: final bill came he would pay not a penny for them. Once the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: thought he had humiliated K. sufficiently, he usually started something
title: The Trial

text: that would raise his spirits again. He had already, he would then say,
title: The Trial

text: won many such cases, partly or in whole, cases which may not really have
title: The Trial

text: been as difficult as this one but which, on the face of it, had even
title: The Trial

text: less hope of success. He had a list of these cases here in the
title: The Trial

text: drawer—here he would tap on one or other of the drawers in his
title: The Trial

text: desk—but could, unfortunately, not show them to K. as they dealt with
title: The Trial

text: official secrets. Nonetheless, the great experience he had acquired
title: The Trial

text: through all these cases would, of course, be of benefit to K. He had, of
title: The Trial

text: course, begun work straight away and was nearly ready to submit the
title: The Trial

text: first documents. They would be very important because the first
title: The Trial

text: impression made by the defence will often determine the whole course of
title: The Trial

text: the proceedings. Unfortunately, though, he would still have to make it
title: The Trial

text: clear to K. that the first documents submitted are sometimes not even
title: The Trial

text: read by the court. They simply put them with the other documents and
title: The Trial

text: point out that, for the time being, questioning and observing the
title: The Trial

text: accused are much more important than anything written. If the applicant
title: The Trial

text: becomes insistent, then they add that before they come to any decision,
title: The Trial

text: as soon as all the material has been brought together, with due regard,
title: The Trial

text: of course, to all the documents, then these first documents to have been
title: The Trial

text: submitted will also be checked over. But unfortunately, even this is not
title: The Trial

text: usually true, the first documents submitted are usually mislaid or lost
title: The Trial

text: completely, and even if they do keep them right to the end they are
title: The Trial

text: hardly read, although the lawyer only knew about this from rumour. This
title: The Trial

text: is all very regrettable, but not entirely without its justifications.
title: The Trial

text: But K. should not forget that the trial would not be public, if the
title: The Trial

text: court deems it necessary it can be made public but there is no law that
title: The Trial

text: says it has to be. As a result, the accused and his defence don't have
title: The Trial

text: access even to the court records, and especially not to the indictment,
title: The Trial

text: and that means we generally don't know—or at least not precisely—what
title: The Trial

text: the first documents need to be about, which means that if they do
title: The Trial

text: contain anything of relevance to the case it's only by a lucky
title: The Trial

text: coincidence. If anything about the individual charges and the reasons
title: The Trial

text: for them comes out clearly or can be guessed at while the accused is
title: The Trial

text: being questioned, then it's possible to work out and submit documents
title: The Trial

text: that really direct the issue and present proof, but not before.
title: The Trial

text: Conditions like this, of course, place the defence in a very
title: The Trial

text: unfavourable and difficult position. But that is what they intend. In
title: The Trial

text: fact, defence is not really allowed under the law, it's only tolerated,
title: The Trial

text: and there is even some dispute about whether the relevant parts of the
title: The Trial

text: law imply even that. So strictly speaking, there is no such thing as a
title: The Trial

text: counsel acknowledged by the court, and anyone who comes before this
title: The Trial

text: court as counsel is basically no more than a barrack room lawyer. The
title: The Trial

text: effect of all this, of course, is to remove the dignity of the whole
title: The Trial

text: procedure, the next time K. is in the court offices he might like to
title: The Trial

text: have a look in at the lawyers' room, just so that he's seen it. He might
title: The Trial

text: well be quite shocked by the people he sees assembled there. The room
title: The Trial

text: they've been allocated, with its narrow space and low ceiling, will be
title: The Trial

text: enough to show what contempt the court has for these people. The only
title: The Trial

text: light in the room comes through a little window that is so high up that,
title: The Trial

text: if you want to look out of it, you first have to get one of your
title: The Trial

text: colleagues to support you on his back, and even then the smoke from the
title: The Trial

text: chimney just in front of it will go up your nose and make your face
title: The Trial

text: black. In the floor of this room—to give yet another example of the
title: The Trial

text: conditions there—there is a hole that's been there for more than a
title: The Trial

text: year, it's not so big that a man could fall through, but it is big
title: The Trial

text: enough for your foot to disappear through it. The lawyers' room is on
title: The Trial

text: the second floor of the attic; if your foot does go through it will hang
title: The Trial

text: down into the first floor of the attic underneath it, and right in the
title: The Trial

text: corridor where the litigants are waiting. It's no exaggeration when
title: The Trial

text: lawyers say that conditions like that are a disgrace. Complaints to the
title: The Trial

text: management don't have the slightest effect, but the lawyers are strictly
title: The Trial

text: forbidden to alter anything in the room at their own expense. But even
title: The Trial

text: treating the lawyers in this way has its reasons. They want, as far as
title: The Trial

text: possible, to prevent any kind of defence, everything should be made the
title: The Trial

text: responsibility of the accused. Not a bad point of view, basically, but
title: The Trial

text: nothing could be more mistaken than to think from that that lawyers are
title: The Trial

text: not necessary for the accused in this court. On the contrary, there is
title: The Trial

text: no court where they are less needed than here. This is because
title: The Trial

text: proceedings are generally kept secret not only from the public but also
title: The Trial

text: from the accused. Only as far as that is possible, of course, but it is
title: The Trial

text: possible to a very large extent. And the accused doesn't get to see the
title: The Trial

text: court records either, and it's very difficult to infer what's in the
title: The Trial

text: court records from what's been said during questioning based on them,
title: The Trial

text: especially for the accused who is in a difficult situation and is faced
title: The Trial

text: with every possible worry to distract him. This is when the defence
title: The Trial

text: begins. Counsel for the defence are not normally allowed to be present
title: The Trial

text: while the accused is being questioned, so afterwards, and if possible
title: The Trial

text: still at the door of the interview room, he has to learn what he can
title: The Trial

text: about it from him and extract whatever he can that might be of use, even
title: The Trial

text: though what the accused has to report is often very confused. But that
title: The Trial

text: is not the most important thing, as there's really not a lot that can be
title: The Trial

text: learned in this way, although in this, as with anything else, a
title: The Trial

text: competent man will learn more than another. Nonetheless, the most
title: The Trial

text: important thing is the lawyer's personal connections, that's where the
title: The Trial

text: real value of taking counsel lies. Now K. will most likely have already
title: The Trial

text: learned from his own experience that, among its very lowest orders, the
title: The Trial

text: court organisation does have its imperfections, the court is strictly
title: The Trial

text: closed to the public, but staff who forget their duty or who take bribes
title: The Trial

text: do, to some extent, show where the gaps are. This is where most lawyers
title: The Trial

text: will push their way in, this is where bribes are paid and information
title: The Trial

text: extracted, there have even, in earlier times at least, been incidents
title: The Trial

text: where documents have been stolen. There's no denying that some
title: The Trial

text: surprisingly favourable results have been attained for the accused in
title: The Trial

text: this way, for a limited time, and these petty advocates then strut to
title: The Trial

text: and fro on the basis of them and attract new clients, but for the
title: The Trial

text: further course of the proceedings it signifies either nothing or nothing
title: The Trial

text: good. The only things of real value are honest personal contacts,
title: The Trial

text: contacts with higher officials, albeit higher officials of the lower
title: The Trial

text: grades, you understand. That is the only way the progress of the trial
title: The Trial

text: can be influenced, hardly noticeable at first, it's true, but from then
title: The Trial

text: on it becomes more and more visible. There are, of course, not many
title: The Trial

text: lawyers who can do this, and K. has made a very good choice in this
title: The Trial

text: matter. There were probably no more than one or two who had as many
title: The Trial

text: contacts as Dr. Huld, but they don't bother with the company of the
title: The Trial

text: lawyers' room and have nothing to do with it. This means they have all
title: The Trial

text: the less contact with the court officials. It is not at all necessary
title: The Trial

text: for Dr. Huld to go to the court, wait in the ante-rooms for the
title: The Trial

text: examining judges to turn up, if they turn up, and try to achieve
title: The Trial

text: something which, according to the judges' mood is usually more apparent
title: The Trial

text: than real and most often not even that. No, K. has seen for himself that
title: The Trial

text: the court officials, including some who are quite high up, come forward
title: The Trial

text: without being asked, are glad to give information which is fully open or
title: The Trial

text: at least easy to understand, they discuss the next stages in the
title: The Trial

text: proceedings, in fact in some cases they can be won over and are quite
title: The Trial

text: willing to adopt the other person's point of view. However, when this
title: The Trial

text: happens, you should never trust them too far, as however firmly they may
title: The Trial

text: have declared this new point of view in favour of the defendant they
title: The Trial

text: might well go straight back to their offices and write a report for the
title: The Trial

text: court that says just the opposite, and might well be even harder on the
title: The Trial

text: defendant than the original view, the one they insist they've been fully
title: The Trial

text: dissuaded from. And, of course, there's no way of defending yourself
title: The Trial

text: from this, something said in private is indeed in private and cannot
title: The Trial

text: then be used in public, it's not something that makes it easy for the
title: The Trial

text: defence to keep those gentlemen's favour. On the other hand, it's also
title: The Trial

text: true that the gentlemen don't become involved with the defence—which
title: The Trial

text: will of course be done with great expertise—just for philanthropic
title: The Trial

text: reasons or in order to be friendly, in some respects it would be truer
title: The Trial

text: to say that they, too, have it allocated to them. This is where the
title: The Trial

text: disadvantages of a court structure that, right from the start,
title: The Trial

text: stipulates that all proceedings take place in private, come into force.
title: The Trial

text: In normal, mediocre trials its officials have contact with the public,
title: The Trial

text: and they're very well equipped for it, but here they don't; normal
title: The Trial

text: trials run their course all by themselves, almost, and just need a nudge
title: The Trial

text: here and there; but when they're faced with cases that are especially
title: The Trial

text: difficult they're as lost as they often are with ones that are very
title: The Trial

text: simple; they're forced to spend all their time, day and night, with
title: The Trial

text: their laws, and so they don't have the right feel for human
title: The Trial

text: relationships, and that's a serious shortcoming in cases like this.
title: The Trial

text: That's when they come for advice to the lawyer, with a servant behind
title: The Trial

text: them carrying the documents which normally are kept so secret. You could
title: The Trial

text: have seen many gentlemen at this window, gentlemen of whom you would
title: The Trial

text: least expect it, staring out this window in despair on the street below
title: The Trial

text: while the lawyer is at his desk studying the documents so that he can
title: The Trial

text: give them good advice. And at times like that it's also possible to see
title: The Trial

text: how exceptionally seriously these gentlemen take their professions and
title: The Trial

text: how they are thrown into great confusion by difficulties which it's just
title: The Trial

text: not in their natures to overcome. But they're not in an easy position,
title: The Trial

text: to regard their positions as easy would be to do them an injustice. The
title: The Trial

text: different ranks and hierarchies of the court are endless, and even
title: The Trial

text: someone who knows his way around them cannot always tell what's going to
title: The Trial

text: happen. But even for the junior officials, the proceedings in the
title: The Trial

text: courtrooms are usually kept secret, so they are hardly able to see how
title: The Trial

text: the cases they work with proceed, court affairs appear in their range of
title: The Trial

text: vision often without their knowing where they come from and they move on
title: The Trial

text: further without their learning where they go. So civil servants like
title: The Trial

text: this are not able to learn the things you can learn from studying the
title: The Trial

text: successive stages that individual trials go through, the final verdict
title: The Trial

text: or the reasons for it. They're only allowed to deal with that part of
title: The Trial

text: the trial which the law allocates them, and they usually know less about
title: The Trial

text: the results of their work after it's left them than the defence does,
title: The Trial

text: even though the defence will usually stay in contact with the accused
title: The Trial

text: until the trial is nearly at its end, so that the court officials can
title: The Trial

text: learn many useful things from the defence. Bearing all this in mind,
title: The Trial

text: does it still surprise K. that the officials are irritated and often
title: The Trial

text: express themselves about the litigants in unflattering ways—which is an
title: The Trial

text: experience shared by everyone. All the officials are irritated, even
title: The Trial

text: when they appear calm. This causes many difficulties for the junior
title: The Trial

text: advocates, of course. There is a story, for instance, that has very much
title: The Trial

text: the ring of truth about it. It goes like this: One of the older
title: The Trial

text: officials, a good and peaceful man, was dealing with a difficult matter
title: The Trial

text: for the court which had become very confused, especially thanks to the
title: The Trial

text: contributions from the lawyers. He had been studying it for a day and a
title: The Trial

text: night without a break—as these officials are indeed hard working,
title: The Trial

text: no-one works as hard as they do. When it was nearly morning, and he had
title: The Trial

text: been working for twenty-four hours with probably very little result, he
title: The Trial

text: went to the front entrance, waited there in ambush, and every time a
title: The Trial

text: lawyer tried to enter the building he would throw him down the steps.
title: The Trial

text: The lawyers gathered together down in front of the steps and discussed
title: The Trial

text: with each other what they should do; on the one hand they had actually
title: The Trial

text: no right to be allowed into the building so that there was hardly
title: The Trial

text: anything that they could legally do to the official and, as I've already
title: The Trial

text: mentioned, they would have to be careful not to set all the officials
title: The Trial

text: against them. On the other hand, any day not spent in court is a day
title: The Trial

text: lost for them and it was a matter of some importance to force their way
title: The Trial

text: inside. In the end, they agreed that they would try to tire the old man
title: The Trial

text: out. One lawyer after another was sent out to run up the steps and let
title: The Trial

text: himself be thrown down again, offering what resistance he could as long
title: The Trial

text: as it was passive resistance, and his colleagues would catch him at the
title: The Trial

text: bottom of the steps. That went on for about an hour until the old
title: The Trial

text: gentleman, who was already exhausted from working all night, was very
title: The Trial

text: tired and went back to his office. Those who were at the bottom of the
title: The Trial

text: steps could not believe it at first, so they sent somebody out to go and
title: The Trial

text: look behind the door to see if there really was no-one there, and only
title: The Trial

text: then did they all gather together and probably didn't even dare to
title: The Trial

text: complain, as it's far from being the lawyers' job to introduce any
title: The Trial

text: improvements in the court system, or even to want to. Even the most
title: The Trial

text: junior lawyer can understand the relationship there to some extent, but
title: The Trial

text: one significant point is that almost every defendant, even very simple
title: The Trial

text: people, begins to think of suggestions for improving the court as soon
title: The Trial

text: as his proceedings have begun, many of them often even spend time and
title: The Trial

text: energy on the matter that could be spent far better elsewhere. The only
title: The Trial

text: right thing to do is to learn how to deal with the situation as it is.
title: The Trial

text: Even if it were possible to improve any detail of it—which is anyway no
title: The Trial

text: more than superstitious nonsense—the best that they could achieve,
title: The Trial

text: although doing themselves incalculable harm in the process, is that they
title: The Trial

text: will have attracted the special attention of the officials for any case
title: The Trial

text: that comes up in the future, and the officials are always ready to seek
title: The Trial

text: revenge. Never attract attention to yourself! Stay calm, however much it
title: The Trial

text: goes against your character! Try to gain some insight into the size of
title: The Trial

text: the court organism and how, to some extent, it remains in a state of
title: The Trial

text: suspension, and that even if you alter something in one place you'll
title: The Trial

text: draw the ground out from under your feet and might fall, whereas if an
title: The Trial

text: enormous organism like the court is disrupted in any one place it finds
title: The Trial

text: it easy to provide a substitute for itself somewhere else. Everything is
title: The Trial

text: connected with everything else and will continue without any change or
title: The Trial

text: else, which is quite probable, even more closed, more attentive, more
title: The Trial

text: strict, more malevolent. So it's best to leave the work to the lawyers
title: The Trial

text: and not to keep disturbing them. It doesn't do much good to make
title: The Trial

text: accusations, especially if you can't make it clear what they're based on
title: The Trial

text: and their full significance, but it must be said that K. caused a great
title: The Trial

text: deal of harm to his own case by his behaviour towards the office
title: The Trial

text: director, he was a very influential man but now he might as well be
title: The Trial

text: struck off the list of those who might do anything for K. If the trial
title: The Trial

text: is mentioned, even just in passing, it's quite obvious that he's
title: The Trial

text: ignoring it. These officials are in many ways just like children. Often,
title: The Trial

text: something quite harmless—although K.'s behaviour could unfortunately
title: The Trial

text: not be called harmless—will leave them feeling so offended that they
title: The Trial

text: will even stop talking with good friends of theirs, they turn away when
title: The Trial

text: they see them and do everything they can to oppose them. But then, with
title: The Trial

text: no particular reason, surprisingly enough, some little joke that was
title: The Trial

text: only ever attempted because everything seemed so hopeless will make them
title: The Trial

text: laugh and they'll be reconciled. It's both difficult and hard at the
title: The Trial

text: same time to deal with them, and there's hardly any reason for it. It's
title: The Trial

text: sometimes quite astonishing that a single, average life is enough to
title: The Trial

text: encompass so much that it's at all possible ever to have any success in
title: The Trial

text: one's work here. On the other hand, there are also dark moments, such as
title: The Trial

text: everyone has, when you think you've achieved nothing at all, when it
title: The Trial

text: seems that the only trials to come to a good end are those that were
title: The Trial

text: determined to have a good end from the start and would do so without any
title: The Trial

text: help, while all the others are lost despite all the running to and fro,
title: The Trial

text: all the effort, all the little, apparent successes that gave such joy.
title: The Trial

text: Then you no longer feel very sure of anything and, if asked about a
title: The Trial

text: trial that was doing well by its own nature but which was turned for the
title: The Trial

text: worse because you assisted in it, would not even dare deny that. And
title: The Trial

text: even that is a kind of self-confidence, but then it's the only one
title: The Trial

text: that's left. Lawyers are especially vulnerable to fits of depression of
title: The Trial

text: that sort—and they are no more than fits of depression of course—when
title: The Trial

text: a case is suddenly taken out of their hands after they've been
title: The Trial

text: conducting it satisfactorily for some time. That's probably the worst
title: The Trial

text: that can happen to a lawyer. It's not that the accused takes the case
title: The Trial

text: away from him, that hardly ever happens, once a defendant has taken on
title: The Trial

text: a certain lawyer he has to stay with him whatever happens. How could he
title: The Trial

text: ever carry on by himself after he's taken on help from a lawyer? No,
title: The Trial

text: that just doesn't happen, but what does sometimes happen is that the
title: The Trial

text: trial takes on a course where the lawyer may not go along with it.
title: The Trial

text: Client and trial are both simply taken away from the lawyer; and then
title: The Trial

text: even contact with the court officials won't help, however good they are,
title: The Trial

text: as they don't know anything themselves. The trial will have entered a
title: The Trial

text: stage where no more help can be given, where it's being processed in
title: The Trial

text: courts to which no-one has any access, where the defendant cannot even
title: The Trial

text: be contacted by his lawyer. You come home one day and find all the
title: The Trial

text: documents you've submitted, which you've worked hard to create and which
title: The Trial

text: you had the best hopes for, lying on the desk, they've been sent back as
title: The Trial

text: they can't be carried through to the next stage in the trial, they're
title: The Trial

text: just worthless scraps of paper. It doesn't mean that the case has been
title: The Trial

text: lost, not at all, or at least there is no decisive reason for supposing
title: The Trial

text: so, it's just that you don't know anything more about the case and won't
title: The Trial

text: be told anything of what's happening. Well, cases like that are the
title: The Trial

text: exceptions, I'm glad to say, and even if K.'s trial is one of them, it's
title: The Trial

text: still, for the time being, a long way off. But there was still plenty of
title: The Trial

text: opportunity for lawyers to get to work, and K. could be sure they would
title: The Trial

text: be made use of. As he had said, the time for submitting documents was
title: The Trial

text: still in the future and there was no rush to prepare them, it was much
title: The Trial

text: more important to start the initial discussions with the appropriate
title: The Trial

text: officials, and they had already taken place. With varying degrees of
title: The Trial

text: success, it must be said. It was much better not to give away any
title: The Trial

text: details before their time, as in that way K. could only be influenced
title: The Trial

text: unfavourably and his hopes might be raised or he might be made too
title: The Trial

text: anxious, better just to say that some individuals have spoken very
title: The Trial

text: favourably and shown themselves very willing to help, although others
title: The Trial

text: have spoken less favourably, but even they have not in any way refused
title: The Trial

text: to help. So all in all, the results are very encouraging, only you
title: The Trial

text: should certainly not draw any particular conclusions as all preliminary
title: The Trial

text: proceedings begin in the same way and it was only the way they developed
title: The Trial

text: further that would show what the value of these preliminary proceedings
title: The Trial

text: has been. Anyway, nothing has been lost yet, and if we can succeed in
title: The Trial

text: getting the office director, despite everything, on our side—and
title: The Trial

text: several actions have been undertaken to this end—then everything is a
title: The Trial

text: clean wound, as a surgeon would say, and we can wait for the results
title: The Trial

text: with some comfort.
title: The Trial

text: When he started talking on in this way the lawyer was quite tireless.
title: The Trial

text: He went through it all again every time K. went to see him. There was
title: The Trial

text: always some progress, but he could never be told what sort of progress
title: The Trial

text: it was. The first set of documents to be submitted were being worked on
title: The Trial

text: but still not ready, which usually turned out to be a great advantage
title: The Trial

text: the next time K. went to see him as the earlier occasion would have
title: The Trial

text: been a very bad time to put them in, which they could not then have
title: The Trial

text: known. If K., stupefied from all this talking, ever pointed out that
title: The Trial

text: even considering all these difficulties progress was very slow, the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer would object that progress was not slow at all, but that they
title: The Trial

text: might have progressed far further if K. had come to him at the right
title: The Trial

text: time. But he had come to him late and that lateness would bring still
title: The Trial

text: further difficulties, and not only where time was concerned. The only
title: The Trial

text: welcome interruption during these visits was always when Leni contrived
title: The Trial

text: to bring the lawyer his tea while K. was there. Then she would stand
title: The Trial

text: behind K.—pretending to watch the lawyer as he bent greedily over his
title: The Trial

text: cup, poured the tea in and drank—and secretly let K. hold her hand.
title: The Trial

text: There was always complete silence. The lawyer drank. K. squeezed Leni's
title: The Trial

text: hand and Leni would sometimes dare to gently stroke K.'s hair. "Still
title: The Trial

text: here, are you?" the lawyer would ask when he was ready. "I wanted to
title: The Trial

text: take the dishes away," said Leni, they would give each other's hands a
title: The Trial

text: final squeeze, the lawyer would wipe his mouth and then start talking at
title: The Trial

text: K. again with renewed energy.
title: The Trial

text: Was the lawyer trying to comfort K. or to confuse him? K. could not
title: The Trial

text: tell, but it seemed clear to him that his defence was not in good
title: The Trial

text: hands. Maybe everything the lawyer said was quite right, even though he
title: The Trial

text: obviously wanted to make himself as conspicuous as possible and
title: The Trial

text: probably had never even taken on a case as important as he said K.'s
title: The Trial

text: was. But it was still suspicious how he continually mentioned his
title: The Trial

text: personal contacts with the civil servants. Were they to be exploited
title: The Trial

text: solely for K.'s benefit. The lawyer never forgot to mention that they
title: The Trial

text: were dealing only with junior officials, which meant officials who were
title: The Trial

text: dependent on others, and the direction taken in each trial could be
title: The Trial

text: important for their own furtherment. Could it be that they were making
title: The Trial

text: use of the lawyer to turn trials in a certain direction, which would,
title: The Trial

text: of course, always be at the cost of the defendant. It certainly did not
title: The Trial

text: mean that they would do that in every trial, that was not likely at all,
title: The Trial

text: and there were probably also trials where they gave the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: advantages and all the room he needed to turn it in the direction he
title: The Trial

text: wanted, as it would also be to their advantage to keep his reputation
title: The Trial

text: intact. If that really was their relationship, how would they direct
title: The Trial

text: K.'s trial which, as the lawyer had explained, was especially difficult
title: The Trial

text: and therefore important enough to attract great attention from the very
title: The Trial

text: first time it came to court? There could not be much doubt about what
title: The Trial

text: they would do. The first signs of it could already be seen in the fact
title: The Trial

text: that the first documents still had not been submitted even though the
title: The Trial

text: trial had already lasted several months, and that, according to the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer, everything was still in its initial stages, which was very
title: The Trial

text: effective, of course, in making the defendant passive and keeping him
title: The Trial

text: helpless. Then he could be suddenly surprised with the verdict, or at
title: The Trial

text: least with a notification that the hearing had not decided in his favour
title: The Trial

text: and the matter would be passed on to a higher office.
title: The Trial

text: It was essential that K. take a hand in it himself. On winter's
title: The Trial

text: mornings such as this, when he was very tired and everything dragged
title: The Trial

text: itself lethargically through his head, this belief of his seemed
title: The Trial

text: irrefutable. He no longer felt the contempt for the trial that he had
title: The Trial

text: had earlier. If he had been alone in the world it would have been easy
title: The Trial

text: for him to ignore it, although it was also certain that, in that case,
title: The Trial

text: the trial would never have arisen in the first place. But now, his uncle
title: The Trial

text: had already dragged him to see the lawyer, he had to take account of his
title: The Trial

text: family; his job was no longer totally separate from the progress of the
title: The Trial

text: trial, he himself had carelessly—with a certain, inexplicable
title: The Trial

text: complacency—mentioned it to acquaintances and others had learned about
title: The Trial

text: it in ways he did not know, his relationship with Miss Bürstner seemed
title: The Trial

text: to be in trouble because of it. In short, he no longer had any choice
title: The Trial

text: whether he would accept the trial or turn it down, he was in the middle
title: The Trial

text: of it and had to defend himself. If he was tired, then that was bad.
title: The Trial

text: But there was no reason to worry too much before he needed to. He had
title: The Trial

text: been capable of working himself up to his high position in the bank in
title: The Trial

text: a relatively short time and to retain it with respect from everyone,
title: The Trial

text: now he simply had to apply some of the talents that had made that
title: The Trial

text: possible for him to the trial, and there was no doubt that it had to
title: The Trial

text: turn out well. The most important thing, if something was to be
title: The Trial

text: achieved, was to reject in advance any idea that he might be in any way
title: The Trial

text: guilty. There was no guilt. The trial was nothing but a big piece of
title: The Trial

text: business, just like he had already concluded to the benefit of the bank
title: The Trial

text: many times, a piece of business that concealed many lurking dangers
title: The Trial

text: waiting in ambush for him, as they usually did, and these dangers would
title: The Trial

text: need to be defended against. If that was to be achieved then he must not
title: The Trial

text: entertain any idea of guilt, whatever he did, he would need to look
title: The Trial

text: after his own interests as closely as he could. Seen in this way, there
title: The Trial

text: was no choice but to take his representation away from the lawyer very
title: The Trial

text: soon, at best that very evening. The lawyer had told him, as he talked
title: The Trial

text: to him, that that was something unheard of and would probably do him a
title: The Trial

text: great deal of harm, but K. could not tolerate any impediment to his
title: The Trial

text: efforts where his trial was concerned, and these impediments were
title: The Trial

text: probably caused by the lawyer himself. But once he had shaken off the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer the documents would need to be submitted straight away and, if
title: The Trial

text: possible, he would need to see to it that they were being dealt with
title: The Trial

text: every day. It would of course not be enough, if that was to be done, for
title: The Trial

text: K. to sit in the corridor with his hat under the bench like the others.
title: The Trial

text: Day after day, he himself, or one of the women or somebody else on his
title: The Trial

text: behalf, would have to run after the officials and force them to sit at
title: The Trial

text: their desks and study K.'s documents instead of looking out on the
title: The Trial

text: corridor through the grating. There could be no let-up in these efforts,
title: The Trial

text: everything would need to be organised and supervised, it was about time
title: The Trial

text: that the court came up against a defendant who knew how to defend and
title: The Trial

text: make use of his rights.
title: The Trial

text: But when K. had the confidence to try and do all this the difficulty of
title: The Trial

text: composing the documents was too much for him. Earlier, just a week or
title: The Trial

text: so before, he could only have felt shame at the thought of being made
title: The Trial

text: to write out such documents himself; it had never entered his head that
title: The Trial

text: the task could also be difficult. He remembered one morning when,
title: The Trial

text: already piled up with work, he suddenly shoved everything to one side
title: The Trial

text: and took a pad of paper on which he sketched out some of his thoughts on
title: The Trial

text: how documents of this sort should proceed. Perhaps he would offer them
title: The Trial

text: to that slow-witted lawyer, but just then the door of the manager's
title: The Trial

text: office opened and the deputy director entered the room with a loud
title: The Trial

text: laugh. K. was very embarrassed, although the deputy director, of
title: The Trial

text: course, was not laughing at K.'s documents, which he knew nothing about,
title: The Trial

text: but at a joke he had just heard about the stock-exchange, a joke which
title: The Trial

text: needed an illustration if it was to be understood, and now the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director leant over K.'s desk, took his pencil from his hand,
title: The Trial

text: and drew the illustration on the writing pad that K. had intended for
title: The Trial

text: his ideas about his case.
title: The Trial

text: K. now had no more thoughts of shame, the documents had to be prepared
title: The Trial

text: and submitted. If, as was very likely, he could find no time to do it
title: The Trial

text: in the office he would have to do it at home at night. If the nights
title: The Trial

text: weren't enough he would have to take a holiday. Above all, he could not
title: The Trial

text: stop half way, that was nonsense not only in business but always and
title: The Trial

text: everywhere. Needless to say, the documents would mean an almost endless
title: The Trial

text: amount of work. It was easy to come to the belief, not only for those
title: The Trial

text: of an anxious disposition, that it was impossible ever to finish it.
title: The Trial

text: This was not because of laziness or deceit, which were the only things
title: The Trial

text: that might have hindered the lawyer in preparing it, but because he did
title: The Trial

text: not know what the charge was or even what consequences it might bring,
title: The Trial

text: so that he had to remember every tiny action and event from the whole
title: The Trial

text: of his life, looking at them from all sides and checking and
title: The Trial

text: reconsidering them. It was also a very disheartening job. It would have
title: The Trial

text: been more suitable as a way of passing the long days after he had
title: The Trial

text: retired and become senile. But now, just when K. needed to apply all his
title: The Trial

text: thoughts to his work, when he was still rising and already posed a
title: The Trial

text: threat to the deputy director, when every hour passed so quickly and he
title: The Trial

text: wanted to enjoy the brief evenings and nights as a young man, this was
title: The Trial

text: the time he had to start working out these documents. Once more, he
title: The Trial

text: began to feel resentment. Almost involuntarily, only to put an end to
title: The Trial

text: it, his finger felt for the button of the electric bell in the
title: The Trial

text: ante-room. As he pressed it he glanced up to the clock. It was eleven
title: The Trial

text: o'clock, two hours, he had spent a great deal of his costly time just
title: The Trial

text: dreaming and his wits were, of course, even more dulled than they had
title: The Trial

text: been before. But the time had, nonetheless, not been wasted, he had come
title: The Trial

text: to some decisions that could be of value. As well as various pieces of
title: The Trial

text: mail, the servitors brought two visiting cards from gentlemen who had
title: The Trial

text: already been waiting for K. for some time. They were actually very
title: The Trial

text: important clients of the bank who should not really have been kept
title: The Trial

text: waiting under any circumstances. Why had they come at such an awkward
title: The Trial

text: time, and why, the gentlemen on the other side of the closed door seemed
title: The Trial

text: to be asking, was the industrious K. using up the best business time for
title: The Trial

text: his private affairs? Tired from what had gone before, and tired in
title: The Trial

text: anticipation of what was to follow, K. stood up to receive the first of
title: The Trial

text: them.
title: The Trial

text: He was a short, jolly man, a manufacturer who K. knew well. He
title: The Trial

text: apologised for disturbing K. at some important work, and K., for his
title: The Trial

text: part, apologised for having kept the manufacturer waiting for so long.
title: The Trial

text: But even this apology was spoken in such a mechanical way and with such
title: The Trial

text: false intonation that the manufacturer would certainly have noticed if
title: The Trial

text: he had not been fully preoccupied with his business affairs. Instead,
title: The Trial

text: he hurriedly pulled calculations and tables out from all his pockets,
title: The Trial

text: spread them out in front of K., explained several items, corrected a
title: The Trial

text: little mistake in the arithmetic that he noticed as he quickly glanced
title: The Trial

text: over it all, and reminded K. of a similar piece of business he'd
title: The Trial

text: concluded with him about a year before, mentioning in passing that this
title: The Trial

text: time there was another bank spending great effort to get his business,
title: The Trial

text: and finally stopped speaking in order to learn K.'s opinion on the
title: The Trial

text: matter. And K. had indeed, at first, been closely following what the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer was saying, he too was aware of how important the deal
title: The Trial

text: was, but unfortunately it did not last, he soon stopped listening,
title: The Trial

text: nodded at each of the manufacturer's louder exclamations for a short
title: The Trial

text: while, but eventually he stopped doing even that and did no more than
title: The Trial

text: stare at the bald head bent over the papers, asking himself when the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer would finally realise that everything he was saying was
title: The Trial

text: useless. When he did stop talking, K. really thought at first that this
title: The Trial

text: was so that he would have the chance to confess that he was incapable of
title: The Trial

text: listening. Instead, seeing the anticipation on the manufacturer's face,
title: The Trial

text: obviously ready to counter any objections made, he was sorry to realise
title: The Trial

text: that the business discussion had to be continued. So he bent his head as
title: The Trial

text: if he'd been given an order and began slowly to move his pencil over the
title: The Trial

text: papers, now and then he would stop and stare at one of the figures. The
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer thought there must be some objection, perhaps his figures
title: The Trial

text: weren't really sound, perhaps they weren't the decisive issue, whatever
title: The Trial

text: he thought, the manufacturer covered the papers with his hand and began
title: The Trial

text: once again, moving very close to K., to explain what the deal was all
title: The Trial

text: about. "It is difficult," said K., pursing his lips. The only thing
title: The Trial

text: that could offer him any guidance were the papers, and the manufacturer
title: The Trial

text: had covered them from his view, so he just sank back against the arm of
title: The Trial

text: the chair. Even when the door of the manager's office opened and
title: The Trial

text: revealed not very clearly, as if through a veil, the deputy director, he
title: The Trial

text: did no more than look up weakly. K. thought no more about the matter, he
title: The Trial

text: merely watched the immediate effect of the deputy director's appearance
title: The Trial

text: and, for him, the effect was very pleasing; the manufacturer
title: The Trial

text: immediately jumped up from his seat and hurried over to meet the deputy
title: The Trial

text: director, although K. would have liked to make him ten times livelier as
title: The Trial

text: he feared the deputy director might disappear again. He need not have
title: The Trial

text: worried, the two gentlemen met each other, shook each other's hand and
title: The Trial

text: went together over to K.'s desk. The manufacturer said he was sorry to
title: The Trial

text: find the chief clerk so little inclined to do business, pointing to K.
title: The Trial

text: who, under the view of the deputy director, had bent back down over the
title: The Trial

text: papers. As the two men leant over the desk and the manufacturer made
title: The Trial

text: some effort to gain and keep the deputy director's attention, K. felt as
title: The Trial

text: if they were much bigger than they really were and that their
title: The Trial

text: negotiations were about him. Carefully and slowly turning his eyes
title: The Trial

text: upwards, he tried to learn what was taking place above him, took one of
title: The Trial

text: the papers from his desk without looking to see what it was, lay it on
title: The Trial

text: the flat of his hand and raised it slowly up as he rose up to the level
title: The Trial

text: of the two men himself. He had no particular plan in mind as he did
title: The Trial

text: this, but merely felt this was how he would act if only he had finished
title: The Trial

text: preparing that great document that was to remove his burden entirely.
title: The Trial

text: The deputy director had been paying all his attention to the
title: The Trial

text: conversation and did no more than glance at the paper, he did not read
title: The Trial

text: what was written on it at all as what was important for the chief clerk
title: The Trial

text: was not important for him, he took it from K.'s hand saying, "Thank you,
title: The Trial

text: I'm already familiar with everything," and laid it calmly back on the
title: The Trial

text: desk. K. gave him a bitter, sideways look. But the deputy director did
title: The Trial

text: not notice this at all, or if he did notice it it only raised his
title: The Trial

text: spirits, he frequently laughed out loud, one time he clearly embarrassed
title: The Trial

text: the manufacturer when he raised an objection in a witty way but drew him
title: The Trial

text: immediately back out of his embarrassment by commenting adversely on
title: The Trial

text: himself, and finally invited him into his office where they could bring
title: The Trial

text: the matter to its conclusion. "It's a very important matter," said the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer. "I understand that completely. And I'm sure the chief
title: The Trial

text: clerk ..."—even as he said this he was actually speaking only to the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer—"will be very glad to have us take it off his hands. This
title: The Trial

text: is something that needs calm consideration. But he seems to be
title: The Trial

text: over-burdened today, there are even some people in the room outside
title: The Trial

text: who've been waiting there for hours for him." K. still had enough
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: friendly, albeit stiff, smile only at the manufacturer, he made no other
title: The Trial

text: retaliation, bent down slightly and supported himself with both hands on
title: The Trial

text: his desk like a clerk, and watched as the two gentlemen, still talking,
title: The Trial

text: took the papers from his desk and disappeared into the manager's office.
title: The Trial

text: In the doorway, the manufacturer turned and said he wouldn't make his
title: The Trial

text: farewell with K. just yet, he would of course let the chief clerk know
title: The Trial

text: about the success of his discussions but he also had a little something
title: The Trial

text: to tell him about.
title: The Trial

text: At last, K. was by himself. It did not enter his head to show anyone
title: The Trial

text: else into his office and only became vaguely aware of how nice it was
title: The Trial

text: that the people outside thought he was still negotiating with the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer and, for this reason, he could not let anyone in to see
title: The Trial

text: him, not even the servitor. He went over to the window, sat down on the
title: The Trial

text: ledge beside it, held firmly on to the handle and looked down onto the
title: The Trial

text: square outside. The snow was still falling, the weather still had not
title: The Trial

text: brightened up at all.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: actually was that made him so anxious, only occasionally did he glance,
title: The Trial

text: slightly startled, over his shoulder at the door to the outer room
title: The Trial

text: where, mistakenly, he thought he'd heard some noise. No-one came, and
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: face with cold water and, his head somewhat clearer, went back to his
title: The Trial

text: place by the window. The decision to take his defence into his own
title: The Trial

text: hands now seemed more of a burden than he had originally assumed. All
title: The Trial

text: the while he had left his defence up to the lawyer his trial had had
title: The Trial

text: little basic affect on him, he had observed it from afar as something
title: The Trial

text: that was scarcely able to reach him directly, when it suited him he
title: The Trial

text: looked to see how things stood but he was also able to draw his head
title: The Trial

text: back again whenever he wanted. Now, in contrast, if he was to conduct
title: The Trial

text: his defence himself, he would have to devote himself entirely to the
title: The Trial

text: court—for the time being, at least—success would mean, later on, his
title: The Trial

text: complete and conclusive liberation, but if he was to achieve this he
title: The Trial

text: would have to place himself, to start with, in far greater danger than
title: The Trial

text: he had been in so far. If he ever felt tempted to doubt this, then his
title: The Trial

text: experience with the deputy director and the manufacturer that day would
title: The Trial

text: be quite enough to convince him of it. How could he have sat there
title: The Trial

text: totally convinced of the need to do his own defence? How would it be
title: The Trial

text: later? What would his life be like in the days ahead? Would he find the
title: The Trial

text: way through it all to a happy conclusion? Did a carefully worked out
title: The Trial

text: defence—and any other sort would have made no sense—did a carefully
title: The Trial

text: worked out defence not also mean he would need to shut himself off from
title: The Trial

text: everything else as much as he could? Would he survive that? And how was
title: The Trial

text: he to succeed in conducting all this at the bank? It involved much more
title: The Trial

text: than just submitting some documents that he could probably prepare in a
title: The Trial

text: few days' leave, although it would have been great temerity to ask for
title: The Trial

text: time off from the bank just at that time, it was a whole trial and there
title: The Trial

text: was no way of seeing how long it might last. This was an enormous
title: The Trial

text: difficulty that had suddenly been thrown into K.'s life!
title: The Trial

text: And was he supposed to be doing the bank's work at a time like this? He
title: The Trial

text: looked down at his desk. Was he supposed to let people in to see him
title: The Trial
