title: The Trial

text: trundled on, while the court officials upstairs in the attic room sat
title: The Trial

text: looking at the papers for this trial, should he be worrying about the
title: The Trial

text: business of the bank? Did this not seem like a kind of torture,
title: The Trial

text: acknowledged by the court, connected with the trial and which followed
title: The Trial

text: him around? And is it likely that anyone in the bank, when judging his
title: The Trial

text: work, would take any account of his peculiar situation? No-one and
title: The Trial

text: never. There were those who knew about his trial, although it was not
title: The Trial

text: quite clear who knew about it or how much. But he hoped rumours had not
title: The Trial

text: reached as far as the deputy director, otherwise he would obviously
title: The Trial

text: soon find a way of making use of it to harm K., he would show neither
title: The Trial

text: comradeship nor humaneness. And what about the director? It was true
title: The Trial

text: that he was well disposed towards K., and as soon as he heard about the
title: The Trial

text: trial he would probably try to do everything he could to make it easier
title: The Trial

text: for him, but he would certainly not devote himself to it. K. at one
title: The Trial

text: time had provided the counter-balance to what the deputy director said
title: The Trial

text: but the director was now coming more and more under his influence, and
title: The Trial

text: the deputy director would also exploit the weakened condition of the
title: The Trial

text: director to strengthen his own power. So what could K. hope for? Maybe
title: The Trial

text: considerations of this sort weakened his power of resistance, but it
title: The Trial

text: was still necessary not to deceive oneself and to see everything as
title: The Trial

text: clearly as it could be seen at that moment.
title: The Trial

text: For no particular reason, just to avoiding returning to his desk for a
title: The Trial

text: while, he opened the window. It was difficult to open and he had to
title: The Trial

text: turn the handle with both his hands. Then, through the whole height and
title: The Trial

text: breadth of the window, the mixture of fog and smoke was drawn into the
title: The Trial

text: room, filling it with a slight smell of burning. A few flakes of snow
title: The Trial

text: were blown in with it. "It's a horrible autumn," said the manufacturer,
title: The Trial

text: who had come into the room unnoticed after seeing the deputy director
title: The Trial

text: and now stood behind K. K. nodded and looked uneasily at the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer's briefcase, from which he would now probably take the
title: The Trial

text: papers and inform K. of the result of his negotiations with the deputy
title: The Trial

text: director. However, the manufacturer saw where K. was looking, knocked
title: The Trial

text: on his briefcase and without opening it said, "You'll be wanting to
title: The Trial

text: hear how things turned out. I've already got the contract in my pocket,
title: The Trial

text: almost. He's a charming man, your deputy director—he's got his
title: The Trial

text: dangers, though." He laughed as he shook K.'s hand and wanted to make
title: The Trial

text: him laugh with him. But to K., it once more seemed suspicious that the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer did not want to show him the papers and saw nothing about
title: The Trial

text: his comments to laugh at. "Chief clerk," said the manufacturer, "I
title: The Trial

text: expect the weather's been affecting your mood, has it? You're looking
title: The Trial

text: so worried today." "Yes," said K., raising his hand and holding the
title: The Trial

text: temple of his head, "headaches, worries in the family." "Quite right,"
title: The Trial

text: said the manufacturer, who was always in a hurry and could never listen
title: The Trial

text: to anyone for very long, "everyone has his cross to bear." K. had
title: The Trial

text: unconsciously made a step towards the door as if wanting to show the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer out, but the manufacturer said, "Chief clerk, there's
title: The Trial

text: something else I'd like to mention to you. I'm very sorry if it's
title: The Trial

text: something that'll be a burden to you today of all days but I've been to
title: The Trial

text: see you twice already, lately, and each time I forgot all about it. If I
title: The Trial

text: delay it any longer it might well lose its point altogether. That would
title: The Trial

text: be a pity, as I think what I've got to say does have some value." Before
title: The Trial

text: K. had had the time to answer, the manufacturer came up close to him,
title: The Trial

text: tapped his knuckle lightly on his chest and said quietly, "You've got a
title: The Trial

text: trial going on, haven't you?" K. stepped back and immediately exclaimed,
title: The Trial

text: "That's what the deputy director's been telling you!" "No, no," said
title: The Trial

text: the manufacturer, "how would the deputy director know about it?" "And
title: The Trial

text: what about you?" asked K., already more in control of himself. "I hear
title: The Trial

text: things about the court here and there," said the manufacturer, "and that
title: The Trial

text: even applies to what it is that I wanted to tell you about." "There are
title: The Trial

text: so many people who have connections with the court!" said K. with
title: The Trial

text: lowered head, and he led the manufacturer over to his desk. They sat
title: The Trial

text: down where they had been before, and the manufacturer said, "I'm afraid
title: The Trial

text: it's not very much that I've got to tell you about. Only, in matters
title: The Trial

text: like this, it's best not to overlook the tiniest details. Besides, I
title: The Trial

text: really want to help you in some way, however modest my help might be.
title: The Trial

text: We've been good business partners up till now, haven't we? Well then."
title: The Trial

text: K. wanted to apologise for his behaviour in the conversation earlier
title: The Trial

text: that day, but the manufacturer would tolerate no interruption, shoved
title: The Trial

text: his briefcase up high in his armpit to show that he was in a hurry, and
title: The Trial

text: carried on. "I know about your case through a certain Titorelli. He's a
title: The Trial

text: painter, Titorelli's just his artistic name, I don't even know what his
title: The Trial

text: real name is. He's been coming to me in my office for years from time to
title: The Trial

text: time, and brings little pictures with him which I buy more or less just
title: The Trial

text: for the sake of charity as he's hardly more than a beggar. And they're
title: The Trial

text: nice pictures, too, moorland landscapes and that sort of thing. We'd
title: The Trial

text: both got used to doing business in this way and it always went smoothly.
title: The Trial

text: Only, one time these visits became a bit too frequent, I began to tell
title: The Trial

text: him off for it, we started talking and I became interested how it was
title: The Trial

text: that he could earn a living just by painting, and then I learned to my
title: The Trial

text: amazement that his main source of income was painting portraits. 'I work
title: The Trial

text: for the court,' he said, 'what court?' said I. And that's when he told
title: The Trial

text: me about the court. I'm sure you can imagine how amazed I was at being
title: The Trial

text: told all this. Ever since then I learn something new about the court
title: The Trial

text: every time he comes to visit, and so little by little I get to
title: The Trial

text: understand something of how it works. Anyway, Titorelli talks a lot and
title: The Trial

text: I often have to push him away, not only because he's bound to be lying
title: The Trial

text: but also, most of all, because a businessman like me who's already close
title: The Trial

text: to breaking point under the weight of his own business worries can't pay
title: The Trial

text: too much attention to other people's. But all that's just by the by.
title: The Trial

text: Perhaps—this is what I've been thinking—perhaps Titorelli might be
title: The Trial

text: able to help you in some small way, he knows lots of judges and even if
title: The Trial

text: he can't have much influence himself he can give you some advice about
title: The Trial

text: how to get some influential people on your side. And even if this
title: The Trial

text: advice doesn't turn out to make all the difference I still think it'll
title: The Trial

text: be very important once you've got it. You're nearly a lawyer yourself.
title: The Trial

text: That's what I always say, Mr. K. the chief clerk is nearly a lawyer. Oh
title: The Trial

text: I'm sure this trial of yours will turn out all right. So do you want to
title: The Trial

text: go and see Titorelli, then. If I ask him to he'll certainly do
title: The Trial

text: everything he possibly can. I really do think you ought to go. It
title: The Trial

text: needn't be today, of course, just some time, when you get the chance.
title: The Trial

text: And anyway—I want to tell you this too—you don't actually have to go
title: The Trial

text: and see Titorelli, this advice from me doesn't place you under any
title: The Trial

text: obligation at all. No, if you think you can get by without Titorelli
title: The Trial

text: it'll certainly be better to leave him completely out of it. Maybe
title: The Trial

text: you've already got a clear idea of what you're doing and Titorelli could
title: The Trial

text: upset your plans. No, if that's the case then of course you shouldn't go
title: The Trial

text: there under any circumstances! And it certainly won't be easy to take
title: The Trial

text: advice from a lad like that. Still, it's up to you. Here's the letter of
title: The Trial

text: recommendation and here's the address."
title: The Trial

text: Disappointed, K. took the letter and put it in his pocket. Even at
title: The Trial

text: best, the advantage he might derive from this recommendation was
title: The Trial

text: incomparably smaller than the damage that lay in the fact of the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer knowing about his trial, and that the painter was spreading
title: The Trial

text: the news about. It was all he could manage to give the manufacturer, who
title: The Trial

text: was already on his way to the door, a few words of thanks. "I'll go
title: The Trial

text: there," he said as he took his leave of the manufacturer at the door,
title: The Trial

text: "or, as I'm very busy at present, I'll write to him, perhaps he would
title: The Trial

text: like to come to me in my office some time." "I was sure you'd find the
title: The Trial

text: best solution," said the manufacturer. "Although I had thought you'd
title: The Trial

text: prefer to avoid inviting people like this Titorelli to the bank and
title: The Trial

text: talking about the trial here. And it's not always a good idea to send
title: The Trial

text: letters to people like Titorelli, you don't know what might happen to
title: The Trial

text: them. But you're bound to have thought everything through and you know
title: The Trial

text: what you can and can't do." K. nodded and accompanied the manufacturer
title: The Trial

text: on through the ante-room. But despite seeming calm on the outside he was
title: The Trial

text: actually very shocked; he had told the manufacturer he would write to
title: The Trial

text: Titorelli only to show him in some way that he valued his
title: The Trial

text: recommendations and would consider the opportunity to speak with
title: The Trial

text: Titorelli without delay, but if he had thought Titorelli could offer any
title: The Trial

text: worthwhile assistance he would not have delayed. But it was only the
title: The Trial

text: manufacturer's comment that made K. realise what dangers that could lead
title: The Trial

text: to. Was he really able to rely on his own understanding so little? If it
title: The Trial

text: was possible that he might invite a questionable character into the bank
title: The Trial

text: with a clear letter, and ask advice from him about his trial, separated
title: The Trial

text: from the deputy director by no more than a door, was it not possible or
title: The Trial

text: even very likely that there were also other dangers he had failed to see
title: The Trial

text: or that he was even running towards? There was not always someone
title: The Trial

text: beside him to warn him. And just now, just when he would have to act
title: The Trial

text: with all the strength he could muster, now a number of doubts of a sort
title: The Trial

text: he had never before known had presented themselves and affected his own
title: The Trial

text: vigilance! The difficulties he had been feeling in carrying out his
title: The Trial

text: office work; were they now going to affect the trial too? Now, at least,
title: The Trial

text: he found himself quite unable to understand how he could have intended
title: The Trial

text: to write to Titorelli and invite him into the bank.
title: The Trial

text: He shook his head at the thought of it once more as the servitor came
title: The Trial

text: up beside him and drew his attention to the three gentlemen who were
title: The Trial

text: waiting on a bench in the ante-room. They had already been waiting to
title: The Trial

text: see K. for a long time. Now that the servitor was speaking with K. they
title: The Trial

text: had stood up and each of them wanted to make use of the opportunity to
title: The Trial

text: see K. before the others. It had been negligent of the bank to let them
title: The Trial

text: waste their time here in the waiting room, but none of them wanted to
title: The Trial

text: draw attention to this. "Mr. K., ..." one of them was saying, but K.
title: The Trial

text: had told the servitor to fetch his winter coat and said to the three of
title: The Trial

text: them, as the servitor helped him to put it on, "Please forgive me,
title: The Trial

text: gentlemen, I'm afraid I have no time to see you at present. Please do
title: The Trial

text: forgive me but I have some urgent business to settle and have to leave
title: The Trial

text: straight away. You've already seen yourselves how long I've been
title: The Trial

text: delayed. Would you be so kind as to come back tomorrow or some time? Or
title: The Trial

text: perhaps we could settle your affairs by telephone. Or perhaps you would
title: The Trial

text: like to tell me now, briefly, what it's about and I can then give you a
title: The Trial

text: full answer in writing. Whatever, the best thing will be for you to
title: The Trial

text: come here again." The gentlemen now saw that their wait had been
title: The Trial

text: totally pointless, and these suggestions of K.'s left them so astounded
title: The Trial

text: that they looked at each other without a word. "That's agreed then, is
title: The Trial

text: it?" asked K., who had turned toward the servitor bringing him his hat.
title: The Trial

text: Through the open door of K.'s office they could see that the snowfall
title: The Trial

text: outside had become much heavier. So K. turned the collar of his coat up
title: The Trial

text: and buttoned it up high under his chin. Just then the deputy director
title: The Trial

text: came out of the adjoining room, smiled as he saw K. negotiating with
title: The Trial

text: the gentlemen in his winter coat, and asked, "Are you about to go out?"
title: The Trial

text: "Yes," said K., standing more upright, "I have to go out on some
title: The Trial

text: business." But the deputy director had already turned towards the
title: The Trial

text: gentlemen. "And what about these gentlemen?" he asked. "I think they've
title: The Trial

text: already been waiting quite a long time." "We've already come to an
title: The Trial

text: understanding," said K. But now the gentlemen could be held back no
title: The Trial

text: longer, they surrounded K. and explained that they would not have been
title: The Trial

text: waiting for hours if it had not been about something important that had
title: The Trial

text: to be discussed now, at length and in private. The deputy director
title: The Trial

text: listened to them for a short while, he also looked at K. as he held his
title: The Trial

text: hat in his hand cleaning the dust off it here and there, and then he
title: The Trial

text: said, "Gentlemen, there is a very simple way to solve this. If you
title: The Trial

text: would prefer it, I'll be very glad to take over these negotiations
title: The Trial

text: instead of the chief clerk. Your business does, of course, need to be
title: The Trial

text: discussed without delay. We are businessmen like yourselves and know the
title: The Trial

text: value of a businessman's time. Would you like to come this way?" And he
title: The Trial

text: opened the door leading to the ante-room of his own office.
title: The Trial

text: The deputy director seemed very good at appropriating everything that
title: The Trial

text: K. was now forced to give up! But was K. not giving up more than he
title: The Trial

text: absolutely had to? By running off to some unknown painter, with, as he
title: The Trial

text: had to admit, very little hope of any vague benefit, his renown was
title: The Trial

text: suffering damage that could not be repaired. It would probably be much
title: The Trial

text: better to take off his winter coat again and, at the very least, try to
title: The Trial

text: win back the two gentlemen who were certainly still waiting in the next
title: The Trial

text: room. If K. had not then glimpsed the deputy director in his office,
title: The Trial

text: looking for something from his bookshelves as if they were his own, he
title: The Trial

text: would probably even have made the attempt. As K., somewhat agitated,
title: The Trial

text: approached the door the deputy director called out, "Oh, you've still
title: The Trial

text: not left!" He turned his face toward him—its many deep folds seemed to
title: The Trial

text: show strength rather than age—and immediately began once more to
title: The Trial

text: search. "I'm looking for a copy of a contract," he said, "which this
title: The Trial

text: gentleman insists you must have. Could you help me look for it, do you
title: The Trial

text: think?" K. made a step forward, but the deputy director said, "thank
title: The Trial

text: you, I've already found it," and with a big package of papers, which
title: The Trial

text: certainly must have included many more documents than just the copy of
title: The Trial

text: the contract, he turned and went back into his own office.
title: The Trial

text: "I can't deal with him right now," K. said to himself, "but once my
title: The Trial

text: personal difficulties have been settled, then he'll certainly be the
title: The Trial

text: first to get the effect of it, and he certainly won't like it."
title: The Trial

text: Slightly calmed by these thoughts, K. gave the servitor, who had already
title: The Trial

text: long been holding the door to the corridor open for him, the task of
title: The Trial

text: telling the director, when he was able, that K. was going out of the
title: The Trial

text: bank on a business matter. As he left the bank he felt almost happy at
title: The Trial

text: the thought of being able to devote more of himself to his own business
title: The Trial

text: for a while.
title: The Trial

text: He went straight to the painter, who lived in an outlying part of town
title: The Trial

text: which was very near to the court offices, although this area was even
title: The Trial

text: poorer, the houses were darker, the streets were full of dirt that
title: The Trial

text: slowly blew about over the half-melted snow. In the great gateway to
title: The Trial

text: the building where the painter lived only one of the two doors was open,
title: The Trial

text: a hole had been broken open in the wall by the other door, and as K.
title: The Trial

text: approached it a repulsive, yellow, steaming liquid shot out causing
title: The Trial

text: some rats to scurry away into the nearby canal. Down by the staircase
title: The Trial

text: there was a small child lying on its belly crying, but it could hardly
title: The Trial

text: be heard because of the noise from a metal-workshop on the other side
title: The Trial

text: of the entrance hall, drowning out any other sound. The door to the
title: The Trial

text: workshop was open, three workers stood in a circle around some piece of
title: The Trial

text: work that they were beating with hammers. A large tin plate hung on the
title: The Trial

text: wall, casting a pale light that pushed its way in between two of the
title: The Trial

text: workers, lighting up their faces and their work-aprons. K. did no more
title: The Trial

text: than glance at any of these things, he wanted to get things over with
title: The Trial

text: here as soon as possible, to exchange just a few words to find out how
title: The Trial

text: things stood with the painter and go straight back to the bank. Even if
title: The Trial

text: he had just some tiny success here it would still have a good effect on
title: The Trial

text: his work at the bank for that day. On the third floor he had to slow
title: The Trial

text: down his pace, he was quite out of breath—the steps, just like the
title: The Trial

text: height of each floor, were much higher than they needed to be and he'd
title: The Trial

text: been told that the painter lived right up in the attic. The air was
title: The Trial

text: also quite oppressive, there was no proper stairwell and the narrow
title: The Trial

text: steps were closed in by walls on both sides with no more than a small,
title: The Trial

text: high window here and there. Just as K. paused for a while some young
title: The Trial

text: girls ran out of one of the flats and rushed higher up the stairs,
title: The Trial

text: laughing. K. followed them slowly, caught up with one of the girls who
title: The Trial

text: had stumbled and been left behind by the others, and asked her as they
title: The Trial

text: went up side by side, "Is there a painter, Titorelli, who lives here?"
title: The Trial

text: The girl, hardly thirteen years old and somewhat hunchbacked, jabbed
title: The Trial

text: him with her elbow and looked at him sideways. Her youth and her bodily
title: The Trial

text: defects had done nothing to stop her being already quite depraved. She
title: The Trial

text: did not smile once, but looked at K. earnestly, with sharp, acquisitive
title: The Trial

text: eyes. K. pretended not to notice her behaviour and asked, "Do you know
title: The Trial

text: Titorelli, the painter?" She nodded and asked in reply, "What d'you
title: The Trial

text: want to see him for?" K. thought it would be to his advantage quickly to
title: The Trial

text: find out something more about Titorelli. "I want to have him paint my
title: The Trial

text: portrait," he said. "Paint your portrait?" she asked, opening her mouth
title: The Trial

text: too wide and lightly hitting K. with her hand as if he had said
title: The Trial

text: something extraordinarily surprising or clumsy, with both hands she
title: The Trial

text: lifted her skirt, which was already very short, and, as fast as she
title: The Trial

text: could, she ran off after the other girls whose indistinct shouts lost
title: The Trial

text: themselves in the heights. At the next turn of the stairs, however, K.
title: The Trial

text: encountered all the girls once more. The hunchbacked girl had clearly
title: The Trial

text: told them about K.'s intentions and they were waiting for him. They
title: The Trial

text: stood on both sides of the stairs, pressing themselves against the wall
title: The Trial

text: so that K. could get through between them, and smoothed their aprons
title: The Trial

text: down with their hands. All their faces, even in this guard of honour,
title: The Trial

text: showed a mixture of childishness and depravity. Up at the head of the
title: The Trial

text: line of girls, who now, laughing, began to close in around K., was the
title: The Trial

text: hunchback who had taken on the role of leader. It was thanks to her
title: The Trial

text: that K. found the right direction without delay—he would have continued
title: The Trial

text: up the stairs straight in front of him, but she showed him that to
title: The Trial

text: reach Titorelli he would need to turn off to one side. The steps that
title: The Trial

text: led up to the painter were especially narrow, very long without any
title: The Trial

text: turning, the whole length could be seen in one glance and, at the top,
title: The Trial

text: at Titorelli's closed door, it came to its end. This door was much
title: The Trial

text: better illuminated than the rest of the stairway by the light from a
title: The Trial

text: small skylight set obliquely above it, it had been put together from
title: The Trial

text: unpainted planks of wood and the name 'Titorelli' was painted on it in
title: The Trial

text: broad, red brushstrokes. K. was no more than half way up the steps,
title: The Trial

text: accompanied by his retinue of girls, when, clearly the result of the
title: The Trial

text: noise of all those footsteps, the door opened slightly and in the crack
title: The Trial

text: a man who seemed to be dressed in just his nightshirt appeared. "Oh!" he
title: The Trial

text: cried, when he saw the approaching crowd, and vanished. The hunchbacked
title: The Trial

text: girl clapped her hands in glee and the other girls crowded in behind K.
title: The Trial

text: to push him faster forward.
title: The Trial

text: They still had not arrived at the top, however, when the painter up
title: The Trial

text: above them suddenly pulled the door wide open and, with a deep bow,
title: The Trial

text: invited K. to enter. The girls, on the other hand, he tried to keep
title: The Trial

text: away, he did not want to let any of them in however much they begged
title: The Trial

text: him and however much they tried to get in—if they could not get in with
title: The Trial

text: his permission they would try to force their way in against his will.
title: The Trial

text: The only one to succeed was the hunchback when she slipped through under
title: The Trial

text: his outstretched arm, but the painter chased after her, grabbed her by
title: The Trial

text: the skirt, span her once round and set her down again by the door with
title: The Trial

text: the other girls who, unlike the first, had not dared to cross the
title: The Trial

text: doorstep while the painter had left his post. K. did not know what he
title: The Trial

text: was to make of all this, as they all seemed to be having fun. One behind
title: The Trial

text: the other, the girls by the door stretched their necks up high and
title: The Trial

text: called out various words to the painter which were meant in jest but
title: The Trial

text: which K. did not understand, and even the painter laughed as the
title: The Trial

text: hunchback whirled round in his hand. Then he shut the door, bowed once
title: The Trial

text: more to K., offered him his hand and introduced himself, saying,
title: The Trial

text: "Titorelli, painter." K. pointed to the door, behind which the girls
title: The Trial

text: were whispering, and said, "You seem to be very popular in this
title: The Trial

text: building." "Ach, those brats!" said the painter, trying in vain to
title: The Trial

text: fasten his nightshirt at the neck. He was also bare-footed and, apart
title: The Trial

text: from that, was wearing nothing more than a loose pair of yellowish linen
title: The Trial

text: trousers held up with a belt whose free end whipped to and fro. "Those
title: The Trial

text: kids are a real burden for me," he continued. The top button of his
title: The Trial

text: nightshirt came off and he gave up trying to fasten it, fetched a chair
title: The Trial

text: for K. and made him sit down on it. "I painted one of them once—she's
title: The Trial

text: not here today—and ever since then they've been following me about. If
title: The Trial

text: I'm here they only come in when I allow it, but as soon as I've gone out
title: The Trial

text: there's always at least one of them in here. They had a key made to my
title: The Trial

text: door and lend it round to each other. It's hard to imagine what a pain
title: The Trial

text: that is. Suppose I come back home with a lady I'm going to paint, I open
title: The Trial

text: the door with my own key and find the hunchback there or something, by
title: The Trial

text: the table painting her lips red with my paintbrush, and meanwhile her
title: The Trial

text: little sisters will be keeping guard for her, moving about and causing
title: The Trial

text: chaos in every corner of the room. Or else, like happened yesterday, I
title: The Trial

text: might come back home late in the evening—please forgive my appearance
title: The Trial

text: and the room being in a mess, it is to do with them—so, I might come

text: anything the painter told him, even if he thought it unlikely or
title: The Trial

text: contradicted what he had been told by others. He did not now have the
title: The Trial

text: time to examine the truth of everything the painter said or even to
title: The Trial

text: disprove it, he would have achieved as much as he could if the painter
title: The Trial

text: would help him in any way even if his help would not be decisive. As a
title: The Trial

text: result, he said, "So let's pay no more attention to absolute acquittal,
title: The Trial

text: but you mentioned two other possibilities." "Apparent acquittal and
title: The Trial

text: deferment. They're the only possibilities," said the painter. "But
title: The Trial

text: before we talk about them, would you not like to take your coat off? You
title: The Trial

text: must be hot." "Yes," said K., who until then had paid attention to
title: The Trial

text: nothing but the painter's explanations, but now that he had had the heat
title: The Trial

text: pointed out to him his brow began to sweat heavily. "It's almost
title: The Trial

text: unbearable." The painter nodded as if he understood K.'s discomfort very
title: The Trial

text: well. "Could we not open the window?" asked K. "No," said the painter.
title: The Trial

text: "It's only a fixed pane of glass, it can't be opened." K. now realised
title: The Trial

text: that all this time he had been hoping the painter would suddenly go over
title: The Trial

text: to the window and pull it open. He had prepared himself even for the fog
title: The Trial

text: that he would breathe in through his open mouth. The thought that here
title: The Trial

text: he was entirely cut off from the air made him feel dizzy. He tapped
title: The Trial

text: lightly on the bedspread beside him and, with a weak voice, said, "That
title: The Trial

text: is very inconvenient and unhealthy." "Oh no," said the painter in
title: The Trial

text: defence of his window, "as it can't be opened this room retains the heat
title: The Trial

text: better than if the window were double glazed, even though it's only a
title: The Trial

text: single pane. There's not much need to air the room as there's so much
title: The Trial

text: ventilation through the gaps in the wood, but when I do want to I can
title: The Trial

text: open one of my doors, or even both of them." K. was slightly consoled
title: The Trial

text: by this explanation and looked around to see where the second door was.
title: The Trial

text: The painter saw him do so and said, "It's behind you, I had to hide it
title: The Trial

text: behind the bed." Only then was K. able to see the little door in the
title: The Trial

text: wall. "It's really much too small for a studio here," said the painter,
title: The Trial

text: as if he wanted to anticipate an objection K. would make. "I had to
title: The Trial

text: arrange things as well as I could. That's obviously a very bad place for
title: The Trial

text: the bed, in front of the door. For instance when the judge I'm painting
title: The Trial

text: at present comes he always comes through the door by the bed, and I've
title: The Trial

text: even given him a key to this door so that he can wait for me here in the
title: The Trial

text: studio when I'm not home. Although nowadays he usually comes early in
title: The Trial

text: the morning when I'm still asleep. And of course, it always wakes me up
title: The Trial

text: when I hear the door opened beside the bed, however fast asleep I am. If
title: The Trial

text: you could hear the way I curse him as he climbs over my bed in the
title: The Trial

text: morning you'd lose all respect for judges. I suppose I could take the
title: The Trial

text: key away from him but that'd only make things worse. It only takes a
title: The Trial

text: tiny effort to break any of the doors here off their hinges." All the
title: The Trial

text: time the painter was speaking, K. was considering whether he should take
title: The Trial

text: off his coat, but he finally realised that, if he didn't do so, he would
title: The Trial

text: be quite unable to stay here any longer, so he took off his frock coat
title: The Trial

text: and lay it on his knee so that he could put it back on again as soon as
title: The Trial

text: the conversation was over. He had hardly done this when one of the girls
title: The Trial

text: called out, "Now he's taken his coat off!" and they could all be heard
title: The Trial

text: pressing around the gaps in the planks to see the spectacle for
title: The Trial

text: themselves. "The girls think I'm going to paint your portrait," said the
title: The Trial

text: painter, "and that's why you're taking your coat off." "I see," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: only slightly amused by this, as he felt little better than he had
title: The Trial

text: before even though he now sat in his shirtsleeves. With some irritation
title: The Trial

text: he asked, "What did you say the two other possibilities were?" He had
title: The Trial

text: already forgotten the terms used. "Apparent acquittal and deferment,"
title: The Trial

text: said the painter. "It's up to you which one you choose. You can get
title: The Trial

text: either of them if I help you, but it'll take some effort of course, the
title: The Trial

text: difference between them is that apparent acquittal needs concentrated
title: The Trial

text: effort for a while and that deferment takes much less effort but it has
title: The Trial

text: to be sustained. Now then, apparent acquittal. If that's what you want
title: The Trial

text: I'll write down an assertion of your innocence on a piece of paper. The
title: The Trial

text: text for an assertion of this sort was passed down to me from my father
title: The Trial

text: and it's quite unassailable. I take this assertion round to the judges I
title: The Trial

text: know. So I'll start off with the one I'm currently painting, and put
title: The Trial

text: the assertion to him when he comes for his sitting this evening. I'll
title: The Trial

text: lay the assertion in front of him, explain that you're innocent and give
title: The Trial

text: him my personal guarantee of it. And that's not just a superficial
title: The Trial

text: guarantee, it's a real one and it's binding." The painter's eyes seemed
title: The Trial

text: to show some reproach of K. for wanting to impose that sort of
title: The Trial

text: responsibility on him. "That would be very kind of you," said K. "And
title: The Trial

text: would the judge then believe you and nonetheless not pass an absolute
title: The Trial

text: acquittal?" "It's like I just said," answered the painter. "And anyway,
title: The Trial

text: it's not entirely sure that all the judges would believe me, many of
title: The Trial

text: them, for instance, might want me to bring you to see them personally.
title: The Trial

text: So then you'd have to come along too. But at least then, if that
title: The Trial

text: happens, the matter is half way won, especially as I'd teach you in
title: The Trial

text: advance exactly how you'd need to act with the judge concerned, of
title: The Trial

text: course. What also happens, though, is that there are some judges who'll
title: The Trial

text: turn me down in advance, and that's worse. I'll certainly make several
title: The Trial

text: attempts, but still, we'll have to forget about them, but at least we
title: The Trial

text: can afford to do that as no one judge can pass the decisive verdict.
title: The Trial

text: Then when I've got enough judges' signatures on this document I take it
title: The Trial

text: to the judge who's concerned with your case. I might even have his
title: The Trial

text: signature already, in which case things develop a bit quicker than they
title: The Trial

text: would do otherwise. But there aren't usually many hold ups from then
title: The Trial

text: on, and that's the time that the defendant can feel most confident.
title: The Trial

text: It's odd, but true, that people feel more confidence in this time than
title: The Trial

text: they do after they've been acquitted. There's no particular exertion
title: The Trial

text: needed now. When he has the document asserting the defendant's
title: The Trial

text: innocence, guaranteed by a number of other judges, the judge can acquit
title: The Trial

text: you without any worries, and although there are still several
title: The Trial

text: formalities to be gone through there's no doubt that that's what he'll
title: The Trial

text: do as a favour to me and several other acquaintances. You, however, walk
title: The Trial

text: out the court and you're free." "So, then I'll be free," said K.,
title: The Trial

text: hesitantly. "That's right," said the painter, "but only apparently free
title: The Trial

text: or, to put it a better way, temporarily free, as the most junior judges,
title: The Trial

text: the ones I know, they don't have the right to give the final acquittal.
title: The Trial

text: Only the highest judge can do that, in the court that's quite out of
title: The Trial

text: reach for you, for me and for all of us. We don't know how things look
title: The Trial

text: there and, incidentally, we don't want to know. The right to acquit
title: The Trial

text: people is a major privilege and our judges don't have it, but they do
title: The Trial

text: have the right to free people from the indictment. That's to say, if
title: The Trial

text: they're freed in this way then for the time being the charge is
title: The Trial

text: withdrawn but it's still hanging over their heads and it only takes an
title: The Trial

text: order from higher up to bring it back into force. And as I'm in such
title: The Trial

text: good contact with the court I can also tell you how the difference
title: The Trial

text: between absolute and apparent acquittal is described, just in a
title: The Trial

text: superficial way, in the directives to the court offices. If there's an
title: The Trial

text: absolute acquittal all proceedings should stop, everything disappears
title: The Trial

text: from the process, not just the indictment but the trial and even the
title: The Trial

text: acquittal disappears, everything just disappears. With an apparent
title: The Trial

text: acquittal it's different. When that happens, nothing has changed except
title: The Trial

text: that the case for your innocence, for your acquittal and the grounds for
title: The Trial

text: the acquittal have been made stronger. Apart from that, proceedings go
title: The Trial

text: on as before, the court offices continue their business and the case
title: The Trial

text: gets passed to higher courts, gets passed back down to the lower courts
title: The Trial

text: and so on, backwards and forwards, sometimes faster, sometimes slower,
title: The Trial

text: to and fro. It's impossible to know exactly what's happening while this
title: The Trial

text: is going on. Seen from outside it can sometimes seem that everything has
title: The Trial

text: been long since forgotten, the documents have been lost and the
title: The Trial

text: acquittal is complete. No-one familiar with the court would believe it.
title: The Trial

text: No documents ever get lost, the court forgets nothing. One day—no-one
title: The Trial

text: expects it—some judge or other picks up the documents and looks more
title: The Trial

text: closely at them, he notices that this particular case is still active,
title: The Trial

text: and orders the defendant's immediate arrest. I've been talking here as
title: The Trial

text: if there's a long delay between apparent acquittal and re-arrest, that
title: The Trial

text: is quite possible and I do know of cases like that, but it's just as
title: The Trial

text: likely that the defendant goes home after he's been acquitted and finds
title: The Trial

text: somebody there waiting to re-arrest him. Then, of course, his life as a
title: The Trial

text: free man is at an end." "And does the trial start over again?" asked K.,
title: The Trial

text: finding it hard to believe. "The trial will always start over again,"
title: The Trial

text: said the painter, "but there is, once again as before, the possibility
title: The Trial

text: of getting an apparent acquittal. Once again, the accused has to muster
title: The Trial

text: all his strength and mustn't give up." The painter said that last phrase
title: The Trial

text: possibly as a result of the impression that K., whose shoulders had
title: The Trial

text: dropped somewhat, gave on him. "But to get a second acquittal," asked
title: The Trial

text: K., as if in anticipation of further revelations by the painter, "is
title: The Trial

text: that not harder to get than the first time?" "As far as that's
title: The Trial

text: concerned," answered the painter, "there's nothing you can say for
title: The Trial

text: certain. You mean, do you, that the second arrest would have an adverse
title: The Trial

text: influence on the judge and the verdict he passes on the defendant.
title: The Trial

text: That's not how it happens. When the acquittal is passed the judges are
title: The Trial

text: already aware that re-arrest is likely. So when it happens it has hardly
title: The Trial

text: any effect. But there are countless other reasons why the judges' mood
title: The Trial

text: and their legal acumen in the case can be altered, and efforts to obtain
title: The Trial

text: the second acquittal must therefore be suited to the new conditions, and
title: The Trial

text: generally just as vigorous as the first." "But this second acquittal
title: The Trial

text: will once again not be final," said K., shaking his head. "Of course
title: The Trial

text: not," said the painter, "the second acquittal is followed by the third
title: The Trial

text: arrest, the third acquittal by the fourth arrest and so on. That's what
title: The Trial

text: is meant by the term apparent acquittal." K. was silent. "You clearly
title: The Trial

text: don't think an apparent acquittal offers much advantage," said the
title: The Trial

text: painter, "perhaps deferment would suit you better. Would you like me to
title: The Trial

text: explain what deferment is about?" K. nodded. The painter had leant back
title: The Trial

text: and spread himself out in his chair, his nightshirt was wide open, he
title: The Trial

text: had pushed his hand inside and was stroking his breast and his sides.
title: The Trial

text: "Deferment," said the painter, looking vaguely in front of himself for a
title: The Trial

text: while as if trying to find a perfectly appropriate explanation,
title: The Trial

text: "deferment consists of keeping proceedings permanently in their earliest
title: The Trial

text: stages. To do that, the accused and those helping him need to keep in
title: The Trial

text: continuous personal contact with the court, especially those helping
title: The Trial

text: him. I repeat, this doesn't require so much effort as getting an
title: The Trial

text: apparent acquittal, but it probably requires a lot more attention. You
title: The Trial

text: must never let the trial out of your sight, you have to go and see the
title: The Trial

text: appropriate judge at regular intervals as well as when something in
title: The Trial

text: particular comes up and, whatever you do, you have to try and remain
title: The Trial

text: friendly with him; if you don't know the judge personally you have to
title: The Trial

text: influence him through the judges you do know, and you have to do it
title: The Trial

text: without giving up on the direct discussions. As long as you don't fail
title: The Trial

text: to do any of these things you can be reasonably sure the trial won't get
title: The Trial

text: past its first stages. The trial doesn't stop, but the defendant is
title: The Trial

text: almost as certain of avoiding conviction as if he'd been acquitted.
title: The Trial

text: Compared with an apparent acquittal, deferment has the advantage that
title: The Trial

text: the defendant's future is less uncertain, he's safe from the shock of
title: The Trial

text: being suddenly re-arrested and doesn't need to fear the exertions and
title: The Trial

text: stress involved in getting an apparent acquittal just when everything
title: The Trial

text: else in his life would make it most difficult. Deferment does have
title: The Trial

text: certain disadvantages of its own though, too, and they shouldn't be
title: The Trial

text: under-estimated. I don't mean by this that the defendant is never free,
title: The Trial

text: he's never free in the proper sense of the word with an apparent
title: The Trial

text: acquittal either. There's another disadvantage. Proceedings can't be
title: The Trial

text: prevented from moving forward unless there are some at least ostensible
title: The Trial

text: reasons given. So something needs to seem to be happening when looked at
title: The Trial

text: from the outside. This means that from time to time various injunctions
title: The Trial

text: have to be obeyed, the accused has to be questioned, investigations have
title: The Trial

text: to take place and so on. The trial's been artificially constrained
title: The Trial

text: inside a tiny circle, and it has to be continuously spun round within
title: The Trial

text: it. And that, of course, brings with it certain unpleasantnesses for the
title: The Trial

text: accused, although you shouldn't imagine they're all that bad. All of
title: The Trial

text: this is just for show, the interrogations, for instance, they're only
title: The Trial

text: very short, if you ever don't have the time or don't feel like going to
title: The Trial

text: them you can offer an excuse, with some judges you can even arrange the
title: The Trial

text: injunctions together a long time in advance, in essence all it means is
title: The Trial

text: that, as the accused, you have to report to the judge from time to
title: The Trial

text: time." Even while the painter was speaking those last words K. had laid
title: The Trial

text: his coat over his arm and had stood up. Immediately, from outside the
title: The Trial

text: door, there was a cry of "He's standing up now!" "Are you leaving
title: The Trial

text: already?" asked the painter, who had also stood up. "It must be the air
title: The Trial

text: that's driving you out. I'm very sorry about that. There's still a lot I
title: The Trial

text: need to tell you. I had to put everything very briefly but I hope at
title: The Trial

text: least it was all clear." "Oh yes," said K., whose head was aching from
title: The Trial

text: the effort of listening. Despite this affirmation the painter summed it
title: The Trial

text: all up once more, as if he wanted to give K. something to console him on
title: The Trial

text: his way home. "Both have in common that they prevent the defendant being
title: The Trial

text: convicted," he said. "But they also prevent his being properly
title: The Trial

text: acquitted," said K. quietly, as if ashamed to acknowledge it. "You've
title: The Trial

text: got it, in essence," said the painter quickly. K. placed his hand on his
title: The Trial

text: winter overcoat but could not bring himself to put it on. Most of all he
title: The Trial

text: would have liked to pack everything together and run out to the fresh
title: The Trial

text: air. Not even the girls could induce him to put his coat on, even though
title: The Trial

text: they were already loudly telling each other that he was doing so. The
title: The Trial

text: painter still had to interpret K.'s mood in some way, so he said, "I
title: The Trial

text: expect you've deliberately avoided deciding between my suggestions yet.
title: The Trial

text: That's good. I would even have advised against making a decision
title: The Trial

text: straight away. There's no more than a hair's breadth of difference
title: The Trial

text: between the advantages and disadvantages. Everything has to be carefully
title: The Trial

text: weighed up. But the most important thing is you shouldn't lose too much
title: The Trial

text: time." "I'll come back here again soon," said K., who had suddenly
title: The Trial

text: decided to put his frock coat on, threw his overcoat over his shoulder
title: The Trial

text: and hurried over to the door behind which the girls now began to scream.
title: The Trial

text: K. thought he could even see the screaming girls through the door.
title: The Trial

text: "Well, you'll have to keep your word," said the painter, who had not
title: The Trial

text: followed him, "otherwise I'll come to the bank to ask about it myself."
title: The Trial

text: "Will you open this door for me," said K. pulling at the handle which,
title: The Trial

text: as he noticed from the resistance, was being held tightly by the girls
title: The Trial

text: on the other side. "Do you want to be bothered by the girls?" asked the
title: The Trial

text: painter. "It's better if you use the other way out," he said, pointing
title: The Trial

text: to the door behind the bed. K. agreed to this and jumped back to the
title: The Trial

text: bed. But instead of opening that door the painter crawled under the bed
title: The Trial

text: and from underneath it asked K., "Just a moment more, would you not like
title: The Trial

text: to see a picture I could sell to you?" K. did not want to be impolite,
title: The Trial

text: the painter really had taken his side and promised to help him more in
title: The Trial

text: the future, and because of K.'s forgetfulness there had been no mention
title: The Trial

text: of any payment for the painter's help, so K. could not turn him down now
title: The Trial

text: and allowed him to show him the picture, even though he was quivering
title: The Trial

text: with impatience to get out of the studio. From under the bed, the
title: The Trial

text: painter withdrew a pile of unframed paintings. They were so covered in
title: The Trial

text: dust that when the painter tried to blow it off the one on top the dust
title: The Trial

text: swirled around in front of K.'s eyes, robbing him of breath for some
title: The Trial

text: time. "Moorland landscape," said the painter passing the picture to K.
title: The Trial

text: It showed two sickly trees, well separated from each other in dark
title: The Trial

text: grass. In the background there was a multi-coloured sunset. "That's
title: The Trial

text: nice," said K. "I'll buy it." K. expressed himself in this curt way
title: The Trial

text: without any thought, so he was glad when the painter did not take this
title: The Trial

text: amiss and picked up a second painting from the floor. "This is a
title: The Trial

text: counterpart to the first picture," said the painter. Perhaps it had been
title: The Trial

text: intended as a counterpart, but there was not the slightest difference to
title: The Trial

text: be seen between it and the first picture, there were the trees, there
title: The Trial

text: the grass and there the sunset. But this was of little importance to K.
title: The Trial

text: "They are beautiful landscapes," he said, "I'll buy them both and hang
title: The Trial

text: them in my office." "You seem to like this subject," said the painter,
title: The Trial

text: picking up a third painting, "good job I've still got another, similar
title: The Trial

text: picture here." The picture though, was not similar, rather it was
title: The Trial

text: exactly the same moorland landscape. The painter was fully exploiting
title: The Trial

text: this opportunity to sell off his old pictures. "I'll take this one too,"
title: The Trial

text: said K. "How much do the three paintings cost?" "We can talk about that
title: The Trial

text: next time," said the painter. "You're in a hurry now, and we'll still be
title: The Trial

text: in contact. And besides, I'm glad you like the paintings, I'll give you
title: The Trial

text: all the paintings I've got down here. They're all moorland landscapes,
title: The Trial

text: I've painted a lot of moorland landscapes. A lot of people don't like
title: The Trial

text: that sort of picture because they're too gloomy, but there are others,
title: The Trial

text: and you're one of them, who love gloomy themes." But K. was not in the
title: The Trial

text: mood to hear about the professional experiences of this painter cum
title: The Trial

text: beggar. "Wrap them all up!" he called out, interrupting the painter as
title: The Trial

text: he was speaking, "my servant will come to fetch them in the morning."
title: The Trial

text: "There's no need for that," said the painter. "I expect I can find a
title: The Trial

text: porter for you who can go with you now." And, at last, he leant over the
title: The Trial

text: bed and unlocked the door. "Just step on the bed, don't worry about
title: The Trial

text: that," said the painter, "that's what everyone does who comes in here."
title: The Trial

text: Even without this invitation, K. had shown no compunction in already
title: The Trial

text: placing his foot in the middle of the bed covers, then he looked out
title: The Trial

text: through the open door and drew his foot back again. "What is that?" he
title: The Trial

text: asked the painter. "What are you so surprised at?" he asked, surprised
title: The Trial

text: in his turn. "Those are court offices. Didn't you know there are court
title: The Trial

text: offices here. There are court offices in almost every attic, why should
title: The Trial

text: this building be any different? Even my studio is actually one of the
title: The Trial

text: court offices but the court put it at my disposal." It was not so much
title: The Trial

text: finding court offices even here that shocked K., he was mainly shocked
title: The Trial

text: at himself, at his own naïvety in court matters. It seemed to him that
title: The Trial

text: one of the most basic rules governing how a defendant should behave was
title: The Trial

text: always to be prepared, never allow surprises, never to look,
title: The Trial

text: unsuspecting, to the right when the judge stood beside him to his
title: The Trial

text: left—and this was the very basic rule that he was continually
title: The Trial

text: violating. A long corridor extended in front of him, air blew in from it
title: The Trial

text: which, compared with the air in the studio, was refreshing. There were
title: The Trial

text: benches set along each side of the corridor just as in the waiting area
title: The Trial

text: for the office he went to himself. There seemed to be precise rules
title: The Trial

text: governing how offices should be equipped. There did not seem to be many
title: The Trial

text: people visiting the offices that day. There was a man there, half
title: The Trial

text: sitting, half laying, his face was buried in his arm on the bench and he
title: The Trial

text: seemed to be sleeping; another man was standing in the half-dark at the
title: The Trial

text: end of the corridor. K. now climbed over the bed, the painter followed
title: The Trial

text: him with the pictures. They soon came across a servant of the court—K.
title: The Trial

text: was now able to recognise all the servants of the court from the gold
title: The Trial

text: buttons they wore on their civilian clothes below the normal
title: The Trial

text: buttons—and the painter instructed him to go with K. carrying the
title: The Trial

text: pictures. K. staggered more than he walked, his handkerchief pressed
title: The Trial

text: over his mouth. They had nearly reached the exit when the girls stormed
title: The Trial

text: in on them, so K. had not been able to avoid them. They had clearly seen
title: The Trial

text: that the second door of the studio had been opened and had gone around
title: The Trial

text: to impose themselves on him from this side. "I can't come with you any
title: The Trial

text: further!" called out the painter with a laugh as the girls pressed in.
title: The Trial

text: "Goodbye, and don't hesitate too long!" K. did not even look round at
title: The Trial

text: him. Once on the street he took the first cab he came across. He now had
title: The Trial

text: to get rid of the servant, whose gold button continually caught his eye
title: The Trial

text: even if it caught no-one else's. As a servant, the servant of the court
title: The Trial

text: was going to sit on the coach-box. But K. chased him down from there. It
title: The Trial

text: was already well into the afternoon when K. arrived in front of the
title: The Trial

text: bank. He would have liked to leave the pictures in the cab but feared
title: The Trial

text: there might be some occasion when he would have to let the painter see
title: The Trial

text: he still had them. So he had the pictures taken to his office and locked
title: The Trial

text: them in the lowest drawer of his desk so that he could at least keep
title: The Trial

text: them safe from the deputy director's view for the next few days.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: <h2 id="Chapter_Eight">Chapter Eight
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: Block, the businessman—Dismissing the lawyer
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: K. had at last made the decision to withdraw his defence from the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer. It was impossible to remove his doubts as to whether this was
title: The Trial

text: the right decision, but this was outweighed by his belief in its
title: The Trial

text: necessity. This decision, on the day he intended to go to see the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: anything. I see now that he's been neglecting me quite disgracefully."
title: The Trial

text: "There can be lots of good reasons why the first documents still aren't
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: was lots of Latin, which I can't understand, then pages and pages of
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: even so, and this is something I will say, at that time I couldn't see
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: been hoping for?" asked K. "That's a very sensible question," said the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: in these proceedings at all. But I didn't know that then. I'm a
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: asking—was simply unheard of and would do harm to both him and me. I
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: will. So I looked round for other lawyers. And before you say anything:
title: The Trial

text: none of them asked for a definite date for the main trial and none of
title: The Trial

text: them got one, and anyway, apart from one exception which I'll talk about
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: didn't mislead me about; but besides, I had no reason to regret turning
title: The Trial

text: to other lawyers. Perhaps you've already heard how Dr. Huld talks about
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: and he's right, they are contemptible. But when he talks about them and
title: The Trial

text: compares them with himself and his colleagues there's a small error
title: The Trial

text: running through what he says, and, just for your interest, I'll tell you
title: The Trial

text: about it. When he talks about the lawyers he mixes with he sets them
title: The Trial

text: apart by calling them the 'great lawyers'. That's wrong, anyone can call
title: The Trial

text: himself 'great' if he wants to, of course, but in this case only the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: that besides the petty lawyers there are also minor lawyers and great
title: The Trial

text: lawyers. This one and his colleagues are only minor lawyers, and the
title: The Trial

text: difference in rank between them and the great lawyers, who I've only
title: The Trial

text: ever heard about and never seen, is incomparably greater than between
title: The Trial

text: the minor lawyers and the despised petty lawyers." "The great lawyers?"
title: The Trial

text: asked K. "Who are they then? How do you contact them?" "You've never
title: The Trial

text: heard about them, then?" said the businessman. "There's hardly anyone
title: The Trial

text: who's been accused who doesn't spend a lot of time dreaming about the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: yourself be misled in that way. I don't know who the great lawyers are,
title: The Trial

text: and there's probably no way of contacting them. I don't know of any case
title: The Trial

text: I can talk about with certainty where they've taken any part. They do
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: efforts, they only defend those who they want to defend. And I don't
title: The Trial

text: suppose they ever take on cases that haven't already got past the lower
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: in bed and hear nothing more about it. But that, of course, would be the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: at that time?" asked K. "Not for very long," said the businessman, and
title: The Trial

text: smiled again, "you can't forget about them entirely, I'm afraid,
title: The Trial

text: especially in the night when these thoughts come so easily. But I wanted
title: The Trial

text: immediate results in those days, so I went to the petty lawyers."
title: The Trial

text: "Well look at you two sat huddled together!" called Leni as she came
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the businessman with affection but, at the same time, with
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: was of some value after all, he had experience at least, and he was
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the businessman, but did not continue with what he'd been saying. "Maybe
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: trying to press him.

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: was only Leni who answered. "He often sleeps here." "He sleeps here?"
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: they would leave together to discuss everything thoroughly and
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: night. You take it far too much for granted, what your friends do for
title: The Trial

text: you. Well, your friends, or at least I do, we like to do things for you.

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: yes, I am fond of her." Nonetheless, what he said, forgetting all the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: else's help I'd have to beg and show gratitude whenever I do anything."
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the businessman when, with the same rudeness as Leni, he said, "The
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: interesting than mine. And it's only in its early stages too, it
title: The Trial

text: probably hasn't progressed very far so the lawyer still likes to deal
title: The Trial

text: with him. That'll all change later on." "Yeah, yeah," said Leni, looking
title: The Trial

text: at the businessman and laughing. "He doesn't half talk!" she said,
title: The Trial

text: turning to face K. "You can't believe a word he says. He's as talkative
title: The Trial

text: as he is sweet. Maybe that's why the lawyer can't stand him. At least,
title: The Trial

text: he only sees him when he's in the right mood. I've already tried hard to
title: The Trial

text: change that but it's impossible. Just think, there are times when I tell
title: The Trial

text: him Block's here and he doesn't receive him until three days later. And
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: it all has to start all over again. That's why I let Block sleep here,
title: The Trial

text: it wouldn't be the first time Dr. Huld has wanted to see him in the
title: The Trial

text: night. So now Block is ready for that. Sometimes, when he knows Block is
title: The Trial

text: still here, he'll even change his mind about letting him in to see him."
title: The Trial

text: K. looked questioningly at the businessman. The latter nodded and,
title: The Trial

text: although he had spoken quite openly with K. earlier, seemed to be
title: The Trial

text: confused with shame as he said, "Yes, later on you become very dependent
title: The Trial

text: on your lawyer." "He's only pretending to mind," said Leni. "He likes to
title: The Trial

text: sleep here really, he's often said so." She went over to a little door
title: The Trial

text: and shoved it open. "Do you want to see his bedroom?" she asked. K.
title: The Trial

text: went over to the low, windowless room and looked in from the doorway.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: get into the bed you would need to climb over the bedpost. At the head
title: The Trial

text: of the bed there was a niche in the wall where, fastidiously tidy, stood
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: probably to do with the trial. "You sleep in the maid's room?" asked
title: The Trial

text: K., as he went back to the businessman. "Leni's let me have it,"
title: The Trial

text: answered the businessman, "it has many advantages." K. looked long at
title: The Trial

text: him; his first impression of the businessman had perhaps not been right;
title: The Trial

text: he had experience as his trial had already lasted a long time, but he
title: The Trial

text: had paid a heavy price for this experience. K. was suddenly unable to
title: The Trial

text: bear the sight of the businessman any longer. "Bring him to bed, then!"
title: The Trial

text: he called out to Leni, who seemed to understand him. For himself, he
title: The Trial

text: wanted to go to the lawyer and, by dismissing him, free himself from not
title: The Trial

text: only the lawyer but also from Leni and the businessman. But before he
title: The Trial

text: had reached the door the businessman spoke to him gently. "Excuse me,
title: The Trial

text: sir," he said, and K. looked round crossly. "You've forgotten your
title: The Trial

text: promise," said the businessman, stretching his hand out to K.
title: The Trial

text: imploringly from where he sat. "You were going to tell me a secret."
title: The Trial

text: "That is true," said K., as he glanced at Leni, who was watching him
title: The Trial

text: carefully, to check on her. "So listen; it's hardly a secret now anyway.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: that she shoved him away with her fists. Then, still with her hands
title: The Trial

text: balled into fists, she ran after K. who, however, had been given a long
title: The Trial

text: start. He was already inside the lawyer's room by the time Leni caught
title: The Trial

text: up with him. He had almost closed the door behind himself, but Leni held
title: The Trial

text: the door open with her foot, grabbed his arm and tried to pull him back.
title: The Trial

text: But he put such pressure on her wrist that, with a sigh, she was forced
title: The Trial

text: to release him. She did not dare go into the room straight away, and K.
title: The Trial

text: locked the door with the key.
title: The Trial

text: "I've been waiting for you a very long time," said the lawyer from his
title: The Trial

text: bed. He had been reading something by the light of a candle but now he
title: The Trial

text: laid it onto the bedside table and put his glasses on, looking at K.
title: The Trial

text: sharply through them. Instead of apologising K. said, "I'll be leaving
title: The Trial

text: again soon." As he had not apologised the lawyer ignored what K. said,
title: The Trial

text: and replied, "I won't let you in this late again next time." "I find
title: The Trial

text: that quite acceptable," said K. The lawyer looked at him quizzically.
title: The Trial

text: "Sit down," he said. "As you wish," said K., drawing a chair up to the
title: The Trial

text: bedside table and sitting down. "It seemed to me that you locked the
title: The Trial

text: door," said the lawyer. "Yes," said K., "it was because of Leni." He
title: The Trial

text: had no intention of letting anyone off lightly. But the lawyer asked
title: The Trial

text: him, "Was she being importunate again?" "Importunate?" asked K. "Yes,"
title: The Trial

text: said the lawyer, laughing as he did so, had a fit of coughing and then,
title: The Trial

text: once it had passed, began to laugh again. "I'm sure you must have
title: The Trial

text: noticed how importunate she can be sometimes," he said, and patted K.'s
title: The Trial

text: hand which K. had rested on the bedside table and which he now snatched
title: The Trial

text: back. "You don't attach much importance to it, then," said the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: when K. was silent, "so much the better. Otherwise I might have needed
title: The Trial

text: to apologise to you. It is a peculiarity of Leni's. I've long since
title: The Trial

text: forgiven her for it, and I wouldn't be talking of it now, if you hadn't
title: The Trial

text: locked the door just now. Anyway, perhaps I should at least explain this
title: The Trial

text: peculiarity of hers to you, but you seem rather disturbed, the way
title: The Trial

text: you're looking at me, and so that's why I'll do it, this peculiarity of
title: The Trial

text: hers consists in this: Leni finds most of the accused attractive. She
title: The Trial

text: attaches herself to each of them, loves each of them, even seems to be
title: The Trial

text: loved by each of them; then she sometimes entertains me by telling me
title: The Trial

text: about them when I allow her to. I am not so astonished by all of this as
title: The Trial

text: you seem to be. If you look at them in the right way the accused really
title: The Trial

text: can be attractive, quite often. But that is a remarkable and to some
title: The Trial

text: extent scientific phenomenon. Being indicted does not cause any clear,
title: The Trial

text: precisely definable change in a person's appearance, of course. But
title: The Trial

text: it's not like with other legal matters, most of them remain in their
title: The Trial

text: usual way of life and, if they have a good lawyer looking after them,
title: The Trial

text: the trial doesn't get in their way. But there are nonetheless those who
title: The Trial

text: have experience in these matters who can look at a crowd, however big,
title: The Trial

text: and tell you which among them is facing a charge. How can they do that,
title: The Trial

text: you will ask? My answer will not please you. It is simply that those who
title: The Trial

text: are facing a charge are the most attractive. It cannot be their guilt
title: The Trial

text: that makes them attractive as not all of them are guilty—at least
title: The Trial

text: that's what I, as a lawyer, have to say—and nor can it be the proper
title: The Trial

text: punishment that has made them attractive as not all of them are
title: The Trial

text: punished, so it can only be that the proceedings levelled against them
title: The Trial

text: take some kind of hold on them. Whatever the reason, some of these
title: The Trial

text: attractive people are indeed very attractive. But all of them are
title: The Trial

text: attractive, even Block, pitiful worm that he is." As the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: finished what he was saying, K. was fully in control of himself, he had
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: himself the view he had already formed: that the lawyer was trying to
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: observations, and thus distract him from the main question of what he
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: better, "I wanted to tell you that I'm withdrawing my representation

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: "everything has been well thought out and probably even for too long.
title: The Trial

text: The decision is final." "Then allow me to say a few words," said the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer, throwing the bed cover to one side and sitting on the edge of
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: to pass him a blanket from the couch. K. passed him the blanket and
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: his legs. "Your uncle is my friend and in the course of time I've become
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: fully, which he would rather have avoided, and he was aware that it also
title: The Trial

text: confused him even though it could never make him reverse his decision.
title: The Trial

text: "Thank you for feeling so friendly toward me," he said, "and I also
title: The Trial

text: realise how deeply involved you've been in my case, as deeply as
title: The Trial

text: possible for yourself and to bring as much advantage as possible to me.
title: The Trial

text: Nonetheless, I have recently come to the conviction that it is not
title: The Trial

text: enough. I would naturally never attempt, considering that you are so
title: The Trial

text: much older and more experienced than I am, to convince you of my
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: important enough and it is my belief that my trial needs to be
title: The Trial

text: approached with much more vigour than has so far been the case." "I
title: The Trial

text: see," said the lawyer, "you've become impatient." "I am not impatient,"
title: The Trial

text: said K., with some irritation and he stopped paying so much attention to
title: The Trial

text: his choice of words. "When I first came here with my uncle you probably
title: The Trial

text: noticed I wasn't greatly concerned about my case, and if I wasn't
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: was always, without cease, waiting for you to do something, getting more
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the court from you that I probably could not have got anywhere else, but
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: any importance ever happens. So many litigants, at the same stage in
title: The Trial

text: their trials, have stood before me just like you are now and spoken in
title: The Trial

text: that I expected better judgement from you than from the others,

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial
