title: The Trial

text: able to distinguish himself with it, either for K.'s sake or—and this
title: The Trial

text: possibility could never be excluded—for his friends at the court. It
title: The Trial

text: was not possible to learn anything by looking at him, even though K. was
title: The Trial

text: scrutinizing him quite brazenly. It could almost be supposed he was
title: The Trial

text: deliberately hiding his thoughts as he waited to see what effect his
title: The Trial

text: words would have. But he clearly deemed K.'s silence to be favourable
title: The Trial

text: for himself and he continued, "You will have noticed the size of my
title: The Trial

text: office, but that I don't employ any staff to help me. That used to be
title: The Trial

text: quite different, there was a time when several young lawyers were
title: The Trial

text: working for me but now I work alone. This is partly to do with changes
title: The Trial

text: in the way I do business, in that I concentrate nowadays more and more
title: The Trial

text: on matters such as your own case, and partly to do with the ever deeper
title: The Trial

text: understanding that I acquire from these legal matters. I found that I
title: The Trial

text: could never let anyone else deal with this sort of work unless I wanted
title: The Trial

text: to harm both the client and the job I had taken on. But the decision to
title: The Trial

text: do all the work myself had its obvious result: I was forced to turn
title: The Trial

text: almost everyone away who asked me to represent them and could only
title: The Trial

text: accept those I was especially interested in—well there are enough
title: The Trial

text: creatures who leap at every crumb I throw down, and they're not so very
title: The Trial

text: far away. Most importantly, I became ill from over-work. But despite
title: The Trial

text: that I don't regret my decision, quite possibly I should have turned
title: The Trial

text: more cases away than I did, but it did turn out to be entirely necessary
title: The Trial

text: for me to devote myself fully to the cases I did take on, and the
title: The Trial

text: successful results showed that it was worth it. I once read a
title: The Trial

text: description of the difference between representing someone in ordinary
title: The Trial

text: legal matters and in legal matters of this sort, and the writer
title: The Trial

text: expressed it very well. This is what he said: some lawyers lead their
title: The Trial

text: clients on a thread until judgement is passed, but there are others who
title: The Trial

text: immediately lift their clients onto their shoulders and carry them all
title: The Trial

text: the way to the judgement and beyond. That's just how it is. But it was
title: The Trial

text: quite true when I said I never regret all this work. But if, as in your
title: The Trial

text: case, they are so fully misunderstood, well, then I come very close to
title: The Trial

text: regretting it." All this talking did more to make K. impatient than to
title: The Trial

text: persuade him. From the way the lawyer was speaking, K. thought he could
title: The Trial

text: hear what he could expect if he gave in, the delays and excuses would
title: The Trial

text: begin again, reports of how the documents were progressing, how the mood
title: The Trial

text: of the court officials had improved, as well as all the enormous
title: The Trial

text: difficulties—in short all that he had heard so many times before would
title: The Trial

text: be brought out again even more fully, he would try to mislead K. with
title: The Trial

text: hopes that were never specified and to make him suffer with threats that
title: The Trial

text: were never clear. He had to put a stop to that, so he said, "What will
title: The Trial

text: you undertake on my behalf if you continue to represent me?" The lawyer
title: The Trial

text: quietly accepted even this insulting question, and answered, "I should
title: The Trial

text: continue with what I've already been doing for you." "That's just what I
title: The Trial

text: thought," said K., "and now you don't need to say another word." "I will
title: The Trial

text: make one more attempt," said the lawyer as if whatever had been making
title: The Trial

text: K. so annoyed was affecting him too. "You see, I have the impression
title: The Trial

text: that you have not only misjudged the legal assistance I have given you
title: The Trial

text: but also that that misjudgement has led you to behave in this way, you
title: The Trial

text: seem, although you are the accused, to have been treated too well or, to
title: The Trial

text: put it a better way, handled with neglect, with apparent neglect. Even
title: The Trial

text: that has its reason; it is often better to be in chains than to be free.
title: The Trial

text: But I would like to show you how other defendants are treated, perhaps
title: The Trial

text: you will succeed in learning something from it. What I will do is I will
title: The Trial

text: call Block in, unlock the door and sit down here beside the bedside
title: The Trial

text: table." "Be glad to," said K., and did as the lawyer suggested; he was
title: The Trial

text: always ready to learn something new. But to make sure of himself for any
title: The Trial

text: event he added, "but you do realise that you are no longer to be my
title: The Trial

text: lawyer, don't you?" "Yes," said the lawyer. "But you can still change
title: The Trial

text: your mind today if you want to." He lay back down in the bed, pulled the
title: The Trial

text: quilt up to his chin and turned to face the wall. Then he rang.
title: The Trial

text: Leni appeared almost the moment he had done so. She looked hurriedly at
title: The Trial

text: K. and the lawyer to try and find out what had happened; she seemed to
title: The Trial

text: be reassured by the sight of K. sitting calmly at the lawyer's bed. She
title: The Trial

text: smiled and nodded to K., K. looked blankly back at her. "Fetch Block,"
title: The Trial

text: said the lawyer. But instead of going to fetch him, Leni just went to
title: The Trial

text: the door and called out, "Block! To the lawyer!" Then, probably because
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer had turned his face to the wall and was paying no attention,
title: The Trial

text: she slipped in behind K.'s chair. From then on, she bothered him by
title: The Trial

text: leaning forward over the back of the chair or, albeit very tenderly and
title: The Trial

text: carefully, she would run her hands through his hair and over his
title: The Trial

text: cheeks. K. eventually tried to stop her by taking hold of one hand, and
title: The Trial

text: after some resistance Leni let him keep hold of it. Block came as soon
title: The Trial

text: as he was called, but he remained standing in the doorway and seemed to
title: The Trial

text: be wondering whether he should enter or not. He raised his eyebrows and
title: The Trial

text: lowered his head as if listening to find out whether the order to
title: The Trial

text: attend the lawyer would be repeated. K. could have encouraged him to
title: The Trial

text: enter, but he had decided to make a final break not only with the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer but with everything in his home, so he kept himself motionless.
title: The Trial

text: Leni was also silent. Block noticed that at least no-one was chasing
title: The Trial

text: him away, and, on tiptoe, he entered the room, his face was tense, his
title: The Trial

text: hands were clenched behind his back. He left the door open in case he
title: The Trial

text: needed to go back again. K. did not even glance at him, he looked
title: The Trial

text: instead only at the thick quilt under which the lawyer could not be seen
title: The Trial

text: as he had squeezed up very close to the wall. Then his voice was heard:
title: The Trial

text: "Block here?" he asked. Block had already crept some way into the room
title: The Trial

text: but this question seemed to give him first a shove in the breast and
title: The Trial

text: then another in the back, he seemed about to fall but remained
title: The Trial

text: standing, deeply bowed, and said, "At your service, sir." "What do you
title: The Trial

text: want?" asked the lawyer, "you've come at a bad time." "Wasn't I
title: The Trial

text: summoned?" asked Block, more to himself than the lawyer. He held his
title: The Trial

text: hands in front of himself as protection and would have been ready to run
title: The Trial

text: away any moment. "You were summoned," said the lawyer, "but you have
title: The Trial

text: still come at a bad time." Then, after a pause he added, "You always
title: The Trial

text: come at a bad time." When the lawyer started speaking Block had stopped
title: The Trial

text: looking at the bed but stared rather into one of the corners, just
title: The Trial

text: listening, as if the light from the speaker were brighter than Block
title: The Trial

text: could bear to look at. But it was also difficult for him to listen, as
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer was speaking into the wall and speaking quickly and quietly.
title: The Trial

text: "Would you like me to go away again, sir?" asked Block. "Well you're
title: The Trial

text: here now," said the lawyer. "Stay!" It was as if the lawyer had not done
title: The Trial

text: as Block had wanted but instead threatened him with a stick, as now
title: The Trial

text: Block really began to shake. "I went to see," said the lawyer, "the
title: The Trial

text: third judge yesterday, a friend of mine, and slowly brought the
title: The Trial

text: conversation round to the subject of you. Do you want to know what he
title: The Trial

text: said?" "Oh, yes please," said Block. The lawyer did not answer
title: The Trial

text: immediately, so Block repeated his request and lowered his head as if
title: The Trial

text: about to kneel down. But then K. spoke to him: "What do you think you're
title: The Trial

text: doing?" he shouted. Leni had wanted to stop him from calling out and so
title: The Trial

text: he took hold of her other hand. It was not love that made him squeeze it
title: The Trial

text: and hold on to it so tightly, she sighed frequently and tried to
title: The Trial

text: disengage her hands from him. But Block was punished for K.'s outburst,
title: The Trial

text: as the lawyer asked him, "Who is your lawyer?" "You are, sir," said
title: The Trial

text: Block. "And who besides me?" the lawyer asked. "No-one besides you,
title: The Trial

text: sir," said Block. "And let there be no-one besides me," said the lawyer.
title: The Trial

text: Block fully understood what that meant, he glowered at K., shaking his
title: The Trial

text: head violently. If these actions had been translated into words they
title: The Trial

text: would have been coarse insults. K. had been friendly and willing to
title: The Trial

text: discuss his own case with someone like this! "I won't disturb you any
title: The Trial

text: more," said K., leaning back in his chair. "You can kneel down or creep
title: The Trial

text: on all fours, whatever you like. I won't bother with you any more." But
title: The Trial

text: Block still had some sense of pride, at least where K. was concerned,
title: The Trial

text: and he went towards him waving his fists, shouting as loudly as he dared
title: The Trial

text: while the lawyer was there. "You shouldn't speak to me like that, that's
title: The Trial

text: not allowed. Why are you insulting me? Especially here in front of the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer, where both of us, you and me, we're only tolerated because of
title: The Trial

text: his charity. You're not a better person than me, you've been accused of
title: The Trial

text: something too, you're facing a charge too. If, in spite of that, you're
title: The Trial

text: still a gentleman then I'm just as much a gentleman as you are, if not
title: The Trial

text: even more so. And I want to be spoken to as a gentleman, especially by
title: The Trial

text: you. If you think being allowed to sit there and quietly listen while I
title: The Trial

text: creep on all fours as you put it makes you something better than me,
title: The Trial

text: then there's an old legal saying you ought to bear in mind: If you're
title: The Trial

text: under suspicion it's better to be moving than still, as if you're still
title: The Trial

text: you can be in the pan of the scales without knowing it and be weighed
title: The Trial

text: along with your sins." K. said nothing. He merely looked in amazement at
title: The Trial

text: this distracted being, his eyes completely still. He had gone through
title: The Trial

text: such changes in just the last few hours! Was it the trial that was
title: The Trial

text: throwing him from side to side in this way and stopped him knowing who
title: The Trial

text: was friend and who was foe? Could he not see the lawyer was deliberately
title: The Trial

text: humiliating him and had no other purpose today than to show off his
title: The Trial

text: power to K., and perhaps even thereby subjugate K.? But if Block was
title: The Trial

text: incapable of seeing that, or if he so feared the lawyer that no such
title: The Trial

text: insight would even be of any use to him, how was it that he was either
title: The Trial

text: so sly or so bold as to lie to the lawyer and conceal from him the fact
title: The Trial

text: that he had other lawyers working on his behalf? And how did he dare to
title: The Trial

text: attack K., who could betray his secret any time he liked? But he dared
title: The Trial

text: even more than this, he went to the lawyer's bed and began there to make
title: The Trial

text: complaints about K. "Dr. Huld, sir," he said, "did you hear the way this
title: The Trial

text: man spoke to me? You can count the length of his trial in hours, and he
title: The Trial

text: wants to tell me what to do when I've been involved in a legal case for
title: The Trial

text: five years. He even insults me. He doesn't know anything, but he insults
title: The Trial

text: me, when I, as far as my weak ability allows, when I've made a close
title: The Trial

text: study of how to behave with the court, what we ought to do and what the
title: The Trial

text: court practices are." "Don't let anyone bother you," said the lawyer,
title: The Trial

text: "and do what seems to you to be right." "I will," said Block, as if
title: The Trial

text: speaking to himself to give himself courage, and with a quick glance to
title: The Trial

text: the side he knelt down close beside the bed. "I'm kneeling now, Dr.
title: The Trial

text: Huld, sir," he said. But the lawyer remained silent. With one hand,
title: The Trial

text: Block carefully stroked the bed cover. In the silence while he did so,
title: The Trial

text: Leni, as she freed herself from K.'s hands, said, "You're hurting me.
title: The Trial

text: Let go of me. I'm going over to Block." She went over to him and sat on
title: The Trial

text: the edge of the bed. Block was very pleased at this and with lively,
title: The Trial

text: but silent, gestures he immediately urged her to intercede for him with
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer. It was clear that he desperately needed to be told something
title: The Trial

text: by the lawyer, although perhaps only so that he could make use of the
title: The Trial

text: information with his other lawyers. Leni probably knew very well how
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer could be brought round, pointed to his hand and pursed her
title: The Trial

text: lips as if making a kiss. Block immediately performed the hand-kiss and,
title: The Trial

text: at further urging from Leni, repeated it twice more. But the lawyer
title: The Trial

text: continued to be silent. Then Leni leant over the lawyer, as she
title: The Trial

text: stretched out, the attractive shape of her body could be seen, and,
title: The Trial

text: bent over close to his face, she stroked his long white hair. That now
title: The Trial

text: forced him to give an answer. "I'm rather wary of telling him," said
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer, and his head could be seen shaking slightly, perhaps so that
title: The Trial

text: he would feel the pressure of Leni's hand better. Block listened
title: The Trial

text: closely with his head lowered, as if by listening he were breaking an
title: The Trial

text: order. "What makes you so wary about it?" asked Leni. K. had the feeling
title: The Trial

text: he was listening to a contrived dialogue that had been repeated many
title: The Trial

text: times, that would be repeated many times more, and that for Block alone
title: The Trial

text: it would never lose its freshness. "What has his behaviour been like
title: The Trial

text: today?" asked the lawyer instead of an answer. Before Leni said
title: The Trial

text: anything she looked down at Block and watched him a short while as he
title: The Trial

text: raised his hands towards her and rubbed them together imploringly.
title: The Trial

text: Finally she gave a serious nod, turned back to the lawyer and said,
title: The Trial

text: "He's been quiet and industrious." This was an elderly businessman, a
title: The Trial

text: man whose beard was long, and he was begging a young girl to speak on
title: The Trial

text: his behalf. Even if there was some plan behind what he did, there was
title: The Trial

text: nothing that could reinstate him in the eyes of his fellow man. K. could
title: The Trial

text: not understand how the lawyer could have thought this performance would
title: The Trial

text: win him over. Even if he had done nothing earlier to make him want to
title: The Trial

text: leave then this scene would have done so. It was almost humiliating even
title: The Trial

text: for the onlooker. So these were the lawyer's methods, which K.
title: The Trial

text: fortunately had not been exposed to for long, to let the client forget
title: The Trial

text: about the whole world and leave him with nothing but the hope of
title: The Trial

text: reaching the end of his trial by this deluded means. He was no longer a
title: The Trial

text: client, he was the lawyer's dog. If the lawyer had ordered him to crawl
title: The Trial

text: under the bed as if it were a kennel and to bark out from under it, then
title: The Trial

text: he would have done so with enthusiasm. K. listened to all of this,
title: The Trial

text: testing it and thinking it over as if he had been given the task of
title: The Trial

text: closely observing everything spoken here, inform a higher office about
title: The Trial

text: it and write a report. "And what has he been doing all day?" asked the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer. "I kept him locked in the maid's room all day," said Leni, "so
title: The Trial

text: that he wouldn't stop me doing my work. That's where he usually stays.
title: The Trial

text: From time to time I looked in through the spyhole to see what he was
title: The Trial

text: doing, and each time he was kneeling on the bed and reading the papers
title: The Trial

text: you gave him, propped up on the window sill. That made a good impression
title: The Trial

text: on me; as the window only opens onto an air shaft and gives hardly any
title: The Trial

text: light. It showed how obedient he is that he was even reading in those
title: The Trial

text: conditions." "I'm pleased to hear it," said the lawyer. "But did he
title: The Trial

text: understand what he was reading?" While this conversation was going on,
title: The Trial

text: Block continually moved his lips and was clearly formulating the answers
title: The Trial

text: he hoped Leni would give. "Well I can't give you any certain answer to
title: The Trial

text: that of course," said Leni, "but I could see that he was reading
title: The Trial

text: thoroughly. He spent all day reading the same page, running his finger
title: The Trial

text: along the lines. Whenever I looked in on him he sighed as if this
title: The Trial

text: reading was a lot of work for him. I expect the papers you gave him were
title: The Trial

text: very hard to understand." "Yes," said the lawyer, "they certainly are
title: The Trial

text: that. And I really don't think he understood anything of them. But they
title: The Trial

text: should at least give him some inkling of just how hard a struggle it is
title: The Trial

text: and how much work it is for me to defend him. And who am I doing all
title: The Trial

text: this hard work for? I'm doing it—it's laughable even to say it—I'm
title: The Trial

text: doing it for Block. He ought to realise what that means, too. Did he
title: The Trial

text: study without a pause?" "Almost without a pause," answered Leni. "Just
title: The Trial

text: the once he asked me for a drink of water, so I gave him a glassful
title: The Trial

text: through the window. Then at eight o'clock I let him out and gave him
title: The Trial

text: something to eat." Block glanced sideways at K., as if he were being
title: The Trial

text: praised and had to impress K. as well. He now seemed more optimistic, he
title: The Trial

text: moved more freely and rocked back and forth on his knees. This made his
title: The Trial

text: astonishment all the more obvious when he heard the following words from
title: The Trial

text: the lawyer: "You speak well of him," said the lawyer, "but that's just
title: The Trial

text: what makes it difficult for me. You see, the judge did not speak well of
title: The Trial

text: him at all, neither about Block nor about his case." "Didn't speak well
title: The Trial

text: of him?" asked Leni. "How is that possible?" Block looked at her with
title: The Trial

text: such tension he seemed to think that although the judge's words had been
title: The Trial

text: spoken so long before she would be able to change them in his favour.
title: The Trial

text: "Not at all," said the lawyer. "In fact he became quite cross when I
title: The Trial

text: started to talk about Block to him. 'Don't talk to me about Block,' he
title: The Trial

text: said. 'He is my client,' said I. 'You're letting him abuse you,' he
title: The Trial

text: said. 'I don't think his case is lost yet,' said I. 'You're letting him
title: The Trial

text: abuse you,' he repeated. 'I don't think so,' said I. 'Block works hard
title: The Trial

text: in his case and always knows where it stands. He practically lives with
title: The Trial

text: me so that he always knows what's happening. You don't always find such
title: The Trial

text: enthusiasm as that. He's not very pleasant personally, I grant you, his
title: The Trial

text: manners are terrible and he's dirty, but as far as the trial's concerned
title: The Trial

text: he's quite immaculate.' I said immaculate, but I was deliberately
title: The Trial

text: exaggerating. Then he said, 'Block is sly, that's all. He's accumulated
title: The Trial

text: plenty of experience and knows how to delay proceedings. But there's
title: The Trial

text: more that he doesn't know than he does. What do you think he'd say if he
title: The Trial

text: learned his trial still hasn't begun, if you told him they haven't even
title: The Trial

text: rung the bell to announce the start of proceedings?' Alright Block,
title: The Trial

text: alright," said the lawyer, as at these words Block had begun to raise
title: The Trial

text: himself on his trembling knees and clearly wanted to plead for some
title: The Trial

text: explanation. It was the first time the lawyer had spoken any clear words
title: The Trial

text: directly to Block. He looked down with his tired eyes, half blankly and
title: The Trial

text: half at Block, who slowly sank back down on his knees under this gaze.
title: The Trial

text: "What the judge said has no meaning for you," said the lawyer. "You
title: The Trial

text: needn't be frightened at every word. If you do it again I won't tell you
title: The Trial

text: anything else at all. It's impossible to start a sentence without you
title: The Trial

text: looking at me as if you were receiving your final judgement. You should
title: The Trial

text: be ashamed of yourself here in front of my client! And you're destroying
title: The Trial

text: the trust he has for me. Just what is it you want? You're still alive,
title: The Trial

text: you're still under my protection. There's no point in worrying!
title: The Trial

text: Somewhere you've read that the final judgement can often come without
title: The Trial

text: warning, from anyone at any time. And, in the right circumstances,
title: The Trial

text: that's basically true, but it's also true that I dislike your anxiety
title: The Trial

text: and fear and see that you don't have the trust in me you should have.
title: The Trial

text: Now what have I just said? I repeated something said by one of the
title: The Trial

text: judges. You know that there are so many various opinions about the
title: The Trial

text: procedure that they form into a great big pile and nobody can make any
title: The Trial

text: sense of them. This judge, for instance, sees proceedings as starting at
title: The Trial

text: a different point from where I do. A difference of opinion, nothing
title: The Trial

text: more. At a certain stage in the proceedings tradition has it that a sign
title: The Trial

text: is given by ringing a bell. This judge sees that as the point at which
title: The Trial

text: proceedings begin. I can't set out all the opinions opposed to that
title: The Trial

text: view here, and you wouldn't understand it anyway, suffice it to say
title: The Trial

text: that there are many reasons to disagree with him." Embarrassed, Block
title: The Trial

text: ran his fingers through the pile of the carpet, his anxiety about what
title: The Trial

text: the judge had said had let him forget his inferior status towards the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer for a while, he thought only about himself and turned the judge's
title: The Trial

text: words round to examine them from all sides. "Block," said Leni, as if
title: The Trial

text: reprimanding him, and, taking hold of the collar of his coat, pulled him
title: The Trial

text: up slightly higher. "Leave the carpet alone and listen to what the
title: The Trial

text: lawyer is saying."
title: The Trial

text: This chapter was left unfinished.

title: The Trial
The Trial

text: In the Cathedral
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: A very important Italian business contact of the bank had come to visit
title: The Trial

text: the city for the first time and K. was given the task of showing him
title: The Trial

text: some of its cultural sights. At any other time he would have seen this
title: The Trial

text: job as an honour but now, when he was finding it hard even to maintain
title: The Trial

text: his current position in the bank, he accepted it only with reluctance.
title: The Trial

text: Every hour that he could not be in the office was a cause of concern
title: The Trial

text: for him, he was no longer able to make use of his time in the office
title: The Trial

text: anything like as well as he had previously, he spent many hours merely
title: The Trial

text: pretending to do important work, but that only increased his anxiety
title: The Trial

text: about not being in the office. Then he sometimes thought he saw the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director, who was always watching, come into K.'s office, sit at
title: The Trial

text: his desk, look through his papers, receive clients who had almost
title: The Trial

text: become old friends of K., and lure them away from him, perhaps he even
title: The Trial

text: discovered mistakes, mistakes that seemed to threaten K. from a
title: The Trial

text: thousand directions when he was at work now, and which he could no
title: The Trial

text: longer avoid. So now, if he was ever asked to leave the office on
title: The Trial

text: business or even needed to make a short business trip, however much an
title: The Trial

text: honour it seemed—and tasks of this sort happened to have increased
title: The Trial

text: substantially recently—there was always the suspicion that they wanted
title: The Trial

text: to get him out of his office for a while and check his work, or at
title: The Trial

text: least the idea that they thought he was dispensable. It would not have
title: The Trial

text: been difficult for him to turn down most of these jobs, but he did not
title: The Trial

text: dare to do so because, if his fears had the slightest foundation,
title: The Trial

text: turning the jobs down would have been an acknowledgement of them. For
title: The Trial

text: this reason, he never demurred from accepting them, and even when he
title: The Trial

text: was asked to go on a tiring business trip lasting two days he said
title: The Trial

text: nothing about having to go out in the rainy autumn weather when he had a
title: The Trial

text: severe chill, just in order to avoid the risk of not being asked to go.
title: The Trial

text: When, with a raging headache, he arrived back from this trip he learned
title: The Trial

text: that he had been chosen to accompany the Italian business contact the
title: The Trial

text: following day. The temptation for once to turn the job down was very
title: The Trial

text: great, especially as it had no direct connection with business, but
title: The Trial

text: there was no denying that social obligations towards this business
title: The Trial

text: contact were in themselves important enough, only not for K., who knew
title: The Trial

text: quite well that he needed some successes at work if he was to maintain
title: The Trial

text: his position there and that, if he failed in that, it would not help
title: The Trial

text: him even if this Italian somehow found him quite charming; he did not
title: The Trial

text: want to be removed from his workplace for even one day, as the fear of
title: The Trial

text: not being allowed back in was too great, he knew full well that the fear
title: The Trial

text: was exaggerated but it still made him anxious. However, in this case it
title: The Trial

text: was almost impossible to think of an acceptable excuse, his knowledge
title: The Trial

text: of Italian was not great but still good enough; the deciding factor was
title: The Trial

text: that K. had earlier known a little about art history and this had
title: The Trial

text: become widely known around the bank in extremely exaggerated form, and
title: The Trial

text: that K. had been a member of the Society for the Preservation of City
title: The Trial

text: Monuments, albeit only for business reasons. It was said that this
title: The Trial

text: Italian was an art lover, so the choice of K. to accompany him was a
title: The Trial

text: matter of course.
title: The Trial

text: It was a very rainy and stormy morning when K., in a foul temper at the
title: The Trial

text: thought of the day ahead of him, arrived early at seven o'clock in the
title: The Trial

text: office so that he could at least do some work before his visitor would
title: The Trial

text: prevent him. He had spent half the night studying a book of Italian
title: The Trial

text: grammar so that he would be somewhat prepared and was very tired; his
title: The Trial

text: desk was less attractive to him than the window where he had spent far
title: The Trial

text: too much time sitting of late, but he resisted the temptation and sat
title: The Trial

text: down to his work. Unfortunately, just then the servitor came in and
title: The Trial

text: reported that the director had sent him to see whether the chief clerk
title: The Trial

text: was already in his office; if he was, then would he please be so kind
title: The Trial

text: as to come to his reception room as the gentleman from Italy was
title: The Trial

text: already there. "I'll come straight away," said K. He put a small
title: The Trial

text: dictionary in his pocket, took a guide to the city's tourist sites
title: The Trial

text: under his arm that he had compiled for strangers, and went through the
title: The Trial

text: deputy director's office into that of the director. He was glad he had
title: The Trial

text: come into the office so early and was able to be of service
title: The Trial

text: immediately, nobody could seriously have expected that of him. The
title: The Trial

text: deputy director's office was, of course, still as empty as the middle
title: The Trial

text: of the night, the servitor had probably been asked to summon him too
title: The Trial

text: but without success. As K. entered the reception room two men stood up
title: The Trial

text: from the deep armchairs where they had been sitting. The director gave
title: The Trial

text: him a friendly smile, he was clearly very glad that K. was there, he
title: The Trial

text: immediately introduced him to the Italian who shook K.'s hand
title: The Trial

text: vigorously and joked that somebody was an early riser. K. did not quite
title: The Trial

text: understand whom he had in mind, it was moreover an odd expression to use
title: The Trial

text: and it took K. a little while to guess its meaning. He replied with a
title: The Trial

text: few bland phrases which the Italian received once more with a laugh,
title: The Trial

text: passing his hand nervously and repeatedly over his blue-grey, bushy
title: The Trial

text: moustache. This moustache was obviously perfumed, it was almost tempting
title: The Trial

text: to come close to it and sniff. When they had all sat down and begun a
title: The Trial

text: light preliminary conversation, K. was disconcerted to notice that he
title: The Trial

text: understood no more than fragments of what the Italian said. When he
title: The Trial

text: spoke very calmly he understood almost everything, but that was very
title: The Trial

text: infrequent, mostly the words gushed from his mouth and he seemed to be
title: The Trial

text: enjoying himself so much his head shook. When he was talking in this
title: The Trial

text: way his speech was usually wrapped up in some kind of dialect which
title: The Trial

text: seemed to K. to have nothing to do with Italian but which the director
title: The Trial

text: not only understood but also spoke, although K. ought to have foreseen
title: The Trial

text: this as the Italian came from the south of his country where the
title: The Trial

text: director had also spent several years. Whatever the cause, K. realised
title: The Trial

text: that the possibility of communicating with the Italian had been largely
title: The Trial

text: taken from him, even his French was difficult to understand, and his
title: The Trial

text: moustache concealed the movements of his lips which might have offered
title: The Trial

text: some help in understanding what he said. K. began to anticipate many
title: The Trial

text: difficulties, he gave up trying to understand what the Italian
title: The Trial

text: said—with the director there, who could understand him so easily, it
title: The Trial

text: would have been pointless effort—and for the time being did no more
title: The Trial

text: than scowl at the Italian as he relaxed sitting deep but comfortable in
title: The Trial

text: the armchair, as he frequently pulled at his short, sharply tailored
title: The Trial

text: jacket and at one time lifted his arms in the air and moved his hands
title: The Trial

text: freely to try and depict something that K. could not grasp, even though
title: The Trial

text: he was leaning forward and did not let the hands out of his sight. K.
title: The Trial

text: had nothing to occupy himself but mechanically watch the exchange
title: The Trial

text: between the two men and his tiredness finally made itself felt, to his
title: The Trial

text: alarm, although fortunately in good time, he once caught himself nearly
title: The Trial

text: getting up, turning round and leaving. Eventually the Italian looked at
title: The Trial

text: the clock and jumped up. After taking his leave from the director he
title: The Trial

text: turned to K., pressing himself so close to him that K. had to push his
title: The Trial

text: chair back just so that he could move. The director had, no doubt, seen
title: The Trial

text: the anxiety in K.'s eyes as he tried to cope with this dialect of
title: The Trial

text: Italian, he joined in with this conversation in a way that was so
title: The Trial

text: adroit and unobtrusive that he seemed to be adding no more than minor
title: The Trial

text: comments, whereas in fact he was swiftly and patiently breaking into
title: The Trial

text: what the Italian said so that K. could understand. K. learned in this
title: The Trial

text: way that the Italian first had a few business matters to settle, that
title: The Trial

text: he unfortunately had only a little time at his disposal, that he
title: The Trial

text: certainly did not intend to rush round to see every monument in the
title: The Trial

text: city, that he would much rather—at least as long as K. would agree, it
title: The Trial

text: was entirely his decision—just see the cathedral and to do so
title: The Trial

text: thoroughly. He was extremely pleased to be accompanied by someone who
title: The Trial

text: was so learned and so pleasant—by this he meant K., who was occupied
title: The Trial

text: not with listening to the Italian but the director—and asked if he
title: The Trial

text: would be so kind, if the time was suitable, to meet him in the cathedral
title: The Trial

text: in two hours' time at about ten o'clock. He hoped he would certainly be
title: The Trial

text: able to be there at that time. K. made an appropriate reply, the Italian
title: The Trial

text: shook first the director's hand and then K.'s, then the director's again
title: The Trial

text: and went to the door, half turned to the two men who followed him and
title: The Trial

text: continuing to talk without a break. K. remained together with the
title: The Trial

text: director for a short while, although the director looked especially
title: The Trial

text: unhappy today. He thought he needed to apologise to K. for something and
title: The Trial

text: told him—they were standing intimately close together—he had thought
title: The Trial

text: at first he would accompany the Italian himself, but then—he gave no
title: The Trial

text: more precise reason than this—then he decided it would be better to
title: The Trial

text: send K. with him. He should not be surprised if he could not understand
title: The Trial

text: the Italian at first, he would be able to very soon, and even if he
title: The Trial

text: really could not understand very much he said it was not so bad, as it
title: The Trial

text: was really not so important for the Italian to be understood. And
title: The Trial

text: anyway, K.'s knowledge of Italian was surprisingly good, the director
title: The Trial

text: was sure he would get by very well. And with that, it was time for K. to
title: The Trial

text: go. He spent the time still remaining to him with a dictionary, copying
title: The Trial

text: out obscure words he would need to guide the Italian round the
title: The Trial

text: cathedral. It was an extremely irksome task, servitors brought him the
title: The Trial

text: mail, bank staff came with various queries and, when they saw that K.
title: The Trial

text: was busy, stood by the door and did not go away until he had listened to
title: The Trial

text: them, the deputy director did not miss the opportunity to disturb K. and
title: The Trial

text: came in frequently, took the dictionary from his hand and flicked
title: The Trial

text: through its pages, clearly for no purpose, when the door to the
title: The Trial

text: ante-room opened even clients would appear from the half-darkness and
title: The Trial

text: bow timidly to him—they wanted to attract his attention but were not
title: The Trial

text: sure whether he had seen them—all this activity was circling around K.
title: The Trial

text: with him at its centre while he compiled the list of words he would
title: The Trial

text: need, then looked them up in the dictionary, then wrote them out, then
title: The Trial

text: practised their pronunciation and finally tried to learn them by heart.
title: The Trial

text: The good intentions he had had earlier, though, seemed to have left him
title: The Trial

text: completely, it was the Italian who had caused him all this effort and
title: The Trial

text: sometimes he became so angry with him that he buried the dictionary
title: The Trial

text: under some papers firmly intending to do no more preparation, but then
title: The Trial

text: he realised he could not walk up and down in the cathedral with the
title: The Trial

text: Italian without saying a word, so, in an even greater rage, he pulled
title: The Trial

text: the dictionary back out again.
title: The Trial

text: At exactly half past nine, just when he was about to leave, there was a
title: The Trial

text: telephone call for him, Leni wished him good morning and asked how he
title: The Trial

text: was, K. thanked her hurriedly and told her it was impossible for him to
title: The Trial

text: talk now as he had to go to the cathedral. "To the cathedral?" asked
title: The Trial

text: Leni. "Yes, to the cathedral." "What do you have to go to the cathedral
title: The Trial

text: for?" said Leni. K. tried to explain it to her briefly, but he had
title: The Trial

text: hardly begun when Leni suddenly said, "They're harassing you." One
title: The Trial

text: thing that K. could not bear was pity that he had not wanted or
title: The Trial

text: expected, he took his leave of her with two words, but as he put the
title: The Trial

text: receiver back in its place he said, half to himself and half to the
title: The Trial

text: girl on the other end of the line who could no longer hear him, "Yes,
title: The Trial

text: they're harassing me."
title: The Trial

text: By now the time was late and there was almost a danger he would not be
title: The Trial

text: on time. He took a taxi to the cathedral, at the last moment he had
title: The Trial

text: remembered the album that he had had no opportunity to give to the
title: The Trial

text: Italian earlier and so took it with him now. He held it on his knees
title: The Trial

text: and drummed impatiently on it during the whole journey. The rain had
title: The Trial

text: eased off slightly but it was still damp, chilly and dark, it would be
title: The Trial

text: difficult to see anything in the cathedral but standing about on cold
title: The Trial

text: flagstones might well make K.'s chill much worse. The square in front
title: The Trial

text: of the cathedral was quite empty, K. remembered how even as a small
title: The Trial

text: child he had noticed that nearly all the houses in this narrow square
title: The Trial

text: had the curtains at their windows closed most of the time, although
title: The Trial

text: today, with the weather like this, it was more understandable. The
title: The Trial

text: cathedral also seemed quite empty, of course no-one would think of
title: The Trial

text: going there on a day like this. K. hurried along both the side naves
title: The Trial

text: but saw no-one but an old woman who, wrapped up in a warm shawl, was
title: The Trial

text: kneeling at a picture of the Virgin Mary and staring up at it. Then, in
title: The Trial

text: the distance, he saw a church official who limped away through a
title: The Trial

text: doorway in the wall. K. had arrived on time, it had struck ten just as
title: The Trial

text: he was entering the building, but the Italian still was not there. K.
title: The Trial

text: went back to the main entrance, stood there indecisively for a while,
title: The Trial

text: and then walked round the cathedral in the rain in case the Italian was
title: The Trial

text: waiting at another entrance. He was nowhere to be found. Could the
title: The Trial

text: director have misunderstood what time they had agreed on? How could
title: The Trial

text: anyone understand someone like that properly anyway? Whatever had
title: The Trial

text: happened, K. would have to wait for him for at least half an hour. As
title: The Trial

text: he was tired he wanted to sit down, he went back inside the cathedral,
title: The Trial

text: he found something like a small carpet on one of the steps, he moved it
title: The Trial

text: with his foot to a nearby pew, wrapped himself up tighter in his coat,
title: The Trial

text: put the collar up and sat down. To pass the time he opened the album
title: The Trial

text: and flicked through the pages a little but soon had to give up as it
title: The Trial

text: became so dark that when he looked up he could hardly make out anything
title: The Trial

text: in the side nave next to him.
title: The Trial

text: In the distance there was a large triangle of candles flickering on the
title: The Trial

text: main altar, K. was not certain whether he had seen them earlier.
title: The Trial

text: Perhaps they had only just been lit. Church staff creep silently as
title: The Trial

text: part of their job, you don't notice them. When K. happened to turn
title: The Trial

text: round he also saw a tall, stout candle attached to a column not far
title: The Trial

text: behind him. It was all very pretty, but totally inadequate to illuminate
title: The Trial

text: the pictures which were usually left in the darkness of the side
title: The Trial

text: altars, and seemed to make the darkness all the deeper. It was
title: The Trial

text: discourteous of the Italian not to come but it was also sensible of him,
title: The Trial

text: there would have been nothing to see, they would have had to content
title: The Trial

text: themselves with seeking out a few pictures with K.'s electric pocket
title: The Trial

text: torch and looking at them one small part at a time. K. went over to a
title: The Trial

text: nearby side chapel to see what they could have hoped for, he went up a
title: The Trial

text: few steps to a low marble railing and leant over it to look at the altar
title: The Trial

text: picture by the light of his torch. The eternal light hung disturbingly
title: The Trial

text: in front of it. The first thing that K. partly saw and partly guessed at
title: The Trial

text: was a large knight in armour who was shown at the far edge of the
title: The Trial

text: painting. He was leaning on his sword that he had stuck into the naked
title: The Trial

text: ground in front of him where only a few blades of grass grew here and
title: The Trial

text: there. He seemed to be paying close attention to something that was
title: The Trial

text: being played out in front of him. It was astonishing to see how he stood
title: The Trial

text: there without going any closer. Perhaps it was his job to stand guard.
title: The Trial

text: It was a long time since K. had looked at any pictures and he studied
title: The Trial

text: the knight for a long time even though he had continually to blink as
title: The Trial

text: he found it difficult to bear the green light of his torch. Then when
title: The Trial

text: he moved the light to the other parts of the picture he found an
title: The Trial

text: interment of Christ shown in the usual way, it was also a comparatively
title: The Trial

text: new painting. He put his torch away and went back to his place.
title: The Trial

text: There seemed to be no point in waiting for the Italian any longer, but
title: The Trial

text: outside it was certainly raining heavily, and as it was not so cold in
title: The Trial

text: the cathedral as K. had expected he decided to stay there for the time
title: The Trial

text: being. Close by him was the great pulpit, there were two plain golden
title: The Trial

text: crosses attached to its little round roof which were lying almost flat
title: The Trial

text: and whose tips crossed over each other. The outside of the pulpit's
title: The Trial

text: balustrade was covered in green foliage which continued down to the
title: The Trial

text: column supporting it, little angels could be seen among the leaves,
title: The Trial

text: some of them lively and some of them still. K. walked up to the pulpit
title: The Trial

text: and examined it from all sides, its stonework had been sculpted with
title: The Trial

text: great care, it seemed as if the foliage had trapped a deep darkness
title: The Trial

text: between and behind its leaves and held it there prisoner, K. lay his
title: The Trial

text: hand in one of these gaps and cautiously felt the stone, until then he
title: The Trial

text: had been totally unaware of this pulpit's existence. Then K. happened
title: The Trial

text: to notice one of the church staff standing behind the next row of pews,
title: The Trial

text: he wore a loose, creased, black cassock, he held a snuff box in his
title: The Trial

text: left hand and he was watching K. Now what does he want? thought K. Do I
title: The Trial

text: seem suspicious to him? Does he want a tip? But when the man in the
title: The Trial

text: cassock saw that K. had noticed him he raised his right hand, a pinch
title: The Trial

text: of snuff still held between two fingers, and pointed in some vague
title: The Trial

text: direction. It was almost impossible to understand what this behaviour
title: The Trial

text: meant, K. waited a while longer but the man in the cassock did not stop
title: The Trial

text: gesturing with his hand and even augmented it by nodding his head. "Now
title: The Trial

text: what does he want?" asked K. quietly, he did not dare call out loud
title: The Trial

text: here; but then he drew out his purse and pushed his way through the
title: The Trial

text: nearest pews to reach the man. He, however, immediately gestured to
title: The Trial

text: turn down this offer, shrugged his shoulders and limped away. As a child
title: The Trial

text: K. had imitated riding on a horse with the same sort of movement as
title: The Trial

text: this limp. "This old man is like a child," thought K., "he doesn't have
title: The Trial

text: the sense for anything more than serving in a church. Look at the way
title: The Trial

text: he stops when I stop, and how he waits to see whether I'll continue."
title: The Trial

text: With a smile, K. followed the old man all the way up the side nave and
title: The Trial

text: almost as far as the main altar, all this time the old man continued to
title: The Trial

text: point at something but K. deliberately avoided looking round, he was
title: The Trial

text: only pointing in order to make it harder for K. to follow him.
title: The Trial

text: Eventually, K. did stop following, he did not want to worry the old man
title: The Trial

text: too much, and he also did not want to frighten him away completely in
title: The Trial

text: case the Italian turned up after all.
title: The Trial

text: When he entered the central nave to go back to where he had left the
title: The Trial

text: album, he noticed a small secondary pulpit on a column almost next to
title: The Trial

text: the stalls by the altar where the choir sat. It was very simple, made
title: The Trial

text: of plain white stone, and so small that from a distance it looked like
title: The Trial

text: an empty niche where the statue of a saint ought to have been. It
title: The Trial

text: certainly would have been impossible for the priest to take a full step
title: The Trial

text: back from the balustrade, and, although there was no decoration on it,
title: The Trial

text: the top of the pulpit curved in exceptionally low so that a man of
title: The Trial

text: average height would not be able stand upright and would have to remain
title: The Trial

text: bent forward over the balustrade. In all, it looked as if it had been
title: The Trial

text: intended to make the priest suffer, it was impossible to understand why
title: The Trial

text: this pulpit would be needed as there were also the other ones available
title: The Trial

text: which were large and so artistically decorated.
title: The Trial

text: And K. would certainly not have noticed this little pulpit if there had
title: The Trial

text: not been a lamp fastened above it, which usually meant there was a
title: The Trial

text: sermon about to be given. So was a sermon to be given now? In this
title: The Trial

text: empty church? K. looked down at the steps which, pressed close against
title: The Trial

text: the column, led up to the pulpit. They were so narrow they seemed to be
title: The Trial

text: there as decoration on the column rather than for anyone to use. But
title: The Trial

text: under the pulpit—K. grinned in astonishment—there really was a priest
title: The Trial

text: standing with his hand on the handrail ready to climb the steps and
title: The Trial

text: looking at K. Then he nodded very slightly, so that K. crossed himself
title: The Trial

text: and genuflected as he should have done earlier. With a little swing,
title: The Trial

text: the priest went up into the pulpit with short fast steps. Was there
title: The Trial

text: really a sermon about to begin? Maybe the man in the cassock had not
title: The Trial

text: been really so demented, and had meant to lead K.'s way to the
title: The Trial

text: preacher, which in this empty church would have been very necessary.
title: The Trial

text: And there was also, somewhere in front of a picture of the Virgin Mary,
title: The Trial

text: an old woman who should have come to hear the sermon. And if there was
title: The Trial

text: to be a sermon why had it not been introduced on the organ? But the
title: The Trial

text: organ remained quiet and merely looked out weakly from the darkness of
title: The Trial

text: its great height.
title: The Trial

text: K. now considered whether he should leave as quickly as possible, if he
title: The Trial

text: did not do it now there would be no chance of doing so during the
title: The Trial

text: sermon and he would have to stay there for as long as it lasted, he had
title: The Trial

text: lost so much time when he should have been in his office, there had
title: The Trial

text: long been no need for him to wait for the Italian any longer, he looked
title: The Trial

text: at his watch, it was eleven. But could there really be a sermon given?
title: The Trial

text: Could K. constitute the entire congregation? How could he when he was
title: The Trial

text: just a stranger who wanted to look at the church? That, basically, was
title: The Trial

text: all he was. The idea of a sermon, now, at eleven o'clock, on a workday,
title: The Trial

text: in hideous weather, was nonsense. The priest—there was no doubt that
title: The Trial

text: he was a priest, a young man with a smooth, dark face—was clearly
title: The Trial

text: going up there just to put the lamp out after somebody had lit it by
title: The Trial

text: mistake.
title: The Trial

text: But there had been no mistake, the priest seemed rather to check that
title: The Trial

text: the lamp was lit and turned it a little higher, then he slowly turned
title: The Trial

text: to face the front and leant down on the balustrade gripping its angular
title: The Trial

text: rail with both hands. He stood there like that for a while and, without
title: The Trial

text: turning his head, looked around. K. had moved back a long way and leant
title: The Trial

text: his elbows on the front pew. Somewhere in the church—he could not have
title: The Trial

text: said exactly where—he could make out the man in the cassock hunched
title: The Trial

text: under his bent back and at peace, as if his work were completed. In the
title: The Trial

text: cathedral it was now very quiet! But K. would have to disturb that
title: The Trial

text: silence, he had no intention of staying there; if it was the priest's
title: The Trial

text: duty to preach at a certain time regardless of the circumstances then
title: The Trial

text: he could, and he could do it without K.'s taking part, and K.'s
title: The Trial

text: presence would do nothing to augment the effect of it. So K. began
title: The Trial

text: slowly to move, felt his way on tiptoe along the pew, arrived at the
title: The Trial

text: broad aisle and went along it without being disturbed, except for the
title: The Trial

text: sound of his steps, however light, which rang out on the stone floor
title: The Trial

text: and resounded from the vaulting, quiet but continuous at a repeating,
title: The Trial

text: regular pace. K. felt slightly abandoned as, probably observed by the
title: The Trial

text: priest, he walked by himself between the empty pews, and the size of
title: The Trial

text: the cathedral seemed to be just at the limit of what a man could bear.
title: The Trial

text: When he arrived back at where he had been sitting he did not hesitate
title: The Trial

text: but simply reached out for the album he had left there and took it with
title: The Trial

text: him. He had nearly left the area covered by pews and was close to the
title: The Trial

text: empty space between himself and the exit when, for the first time, he
title: The Trial

text: heard the voice of the priest. A powerful and experienced voice. It
title: The Trial

text: pierced through the reaches of the cathedral ready waiting for it! But
title: The Trial

text: the priest was not calling out to the congregation, his cry was quite
title: The Trial

text: unambiguous and there was no escape from it, he called "Josef K.!"
title: The Trial

text: K. stood still and looked down at the floor. In theory he was still
title: The Trial

text: free, he could have carried on walking, through one of three dark
title: The Trial

text: little wooden doors not far in front of him and away from there. It
title: The Trial

text: would simply mean he had not understood, or that he had understood but
title: The Trial

text: chose not to pay attention to it. But if he once turned round he would
title: The Trial

text: be trapped, then he would have acknowledged that he had understood
title: The Trial

text: perfectly well, that he really was the Josef K. the priest had called
title: The Trial

text: to and that he was willing to follow. If the priest had called out
title: The Trial

text: again K. would certainly have carried on out the door, but everything
title: The Trial

text: was silent as K. also waited, he turned his head slightly as he wanted
title: The Trial

text: to see what the priest was doing now. He was merely standing in the
title: The Trial

text: pulpit as before, but it was obvious that he had seen K. turn his head.
title: The Trial

text: If K. did not now turn round completely it would have been like a child
title: The Trial

text: playing hide and seek. He did so, and the priest beckoned him with his
title: The Trial

text: finger. As everything could now be done openly he ran—because of
title: The Trial

text: curiosity and the wish to get it over with—with long flying leaps
title: The Trial

text: towards the pulpit. At the front pews he stopped, but to the priest he
title: The Trial

text: still seemed too far away, he reached out his hand and pointed sharply
title: The Trial

text: down with his finger to a place immediately in front of the pulpit. And
title: The Trial

text: K. did as he was told, standing in that place he had to bend his head a
title: The Trial

text: long way back just to see the priest. "You are Josef K.," said the
title: The Trial

text: priest, and raised his hand from the balustrade to make a gesture whose
title: The Trial

text: meaning was unclear. "Yes," said K., he considered how freely he had
title: The Trial

text: always given his name in the past, for some time now it had been a
title: The Trial

text: burden to him, now there were people who knew his name whom he had
title: The Trial

text: never seen before, it had been so nice first to introduce yourself and
title: The Trial

text: only then for people to know who you were. "You have been accused,"
title: The Trial

text: said the priest, especially gently. "Yes," said K., "so I have been
title: The Trial

text: informed." "Then you are the one I am looking for," said the priest. "I
title: The Trial

text: am the prison chaplain." "I see," said K. "I had you summoned here,"
title: The Trial

text: said the priest, "because I wanted to speak to you." "I knew nothing of
title: The Trial

text: that," said K. "I came here to show the cathedral to a gentleman from
title: The Trial

text: Italy." "That is beside the point," said the priest. "What are you
title: The Trial

text: holding in your hand? Is it a prayer book?" "No," answered K., "it's an
title: The Trial

text: album of the city's tourist sights." "Put it down," said the priest. K.
title: The Trial

text: threw it away with such force that it flapped open and rolled across
title: The Trial

text: the floor, tearing its pages. "Do you know your case is going badly?"
title: The Trial

text: asked the priest. "That's how it seems to me too," said K. "I've
title: The Trial

text: expended a lot of effort on it, but so far with no result. Although I do
title: The Trial

text: still have some documents to submit." "How do you imagine it will end?"
title: The Trial

text: asked the priest. "At first I thought it was bound to end well," said
title: The Trial

text: K., "but now I have my doubts about it. I don't know how it will end. Do
title: The Trial

text: you know?" "I don't," said the priest, "but I fear it will end badly.
title: The Trial

text: You are considered guilty. Your case will probably not even go beyond a
title: The Trial

text: minor court. Provisionally at least, your guilt is seen as proven."
title: The Trial

text: "But I'm not guilty," said K., "there's been a mistake. How is it even
title: The Trial

text: possible for someone to be guilty? We're all human beings here, one
title: The Trial

text: like the other." "That is true," said the priest, "but that is how the
title: The Trial

text: guilty speak." "Do you presume I'm guilty too?" asked K. "I make no
title: The Trial

text: presumptions about you," said the priest. "I thank you for that," said
title: The Trial

text: K. "but everyone else involved in these proceedings has something
title: The Trial

text: against me and presumes I'm guilty. They even influence those who
title: The Trial

text: aren't involved. My position gets harder all the time." "You don't
title: The Trial

text: understand the facts," said the priest, "the verdict does not come
title: The Trial

text: suddenly, proceedings continue until a verdict is reached gradually."
title: The Trial

text: "I see," said K., lowering his head. "What do you intend to do about
title: The Trial

text: your case next?" asked the priest. "I still need to find help," said
title: The Trial

text: K., raising his head to see what the priest thought of this. "There are
title: The Trial

text: still certain possibilities I haven't yet made use of." "You look for
title: The Trial

text: too much help from people you don't know," said the priest
title: The Trial

text: disapprovingly, "and especially from women. Can you really not see
title: The Trial

text: that's not the help you need?" "Sometimes, in fact quite often, I could
title: The Trial

text: believe you're right," said K., "but not always. Women have a lot of
title: The Trial

text: power. If I could persuade some of the women I know to work together
title: The Trial

text: with me then I would be certain to succeed. Especially in a court like
title: The Trial

text: this that seems to consist of nothing but woman-chasers. Show the
title: The Trial

text: examining judge a woman in the distance and he'll run right over the
title: The Trial

text: desk, and the accused, just to get to her as soon as he can." The
title: The Trial

text: priest lowered his head down to the balustrade, only now did the roof
title: The Trial

text: over the pulpit seem to press him down. What sort of dreadful weather
title: The Trial

text: could it be outside? It was no longer just a dull day, it was deepest
title: The Trial

text: night. None of the stained glass in the main window shed even a flicker
title: The Trial

text: of light on the darkness of the walls. And this was the moment when the
title: The Trial

text: man in the cassock chose to put out the candles on the main altar, one
title: The Trial

text: by one. "Are you cross with me?" asked K. "Maybe you don't know what
title: The Trial

text: sort of court it is you serve." He received no answer. "Well, it's just
title: The Trial

text: my own experience," said K. Above him there was still silence. "I didn't
title: The Trial

text: mean to insult you," said K. At that, the priest screamed down at K.:
title: The Trial

text: "Can you not see two steps in front of you?" He shouted in anger, but it
title: The Trial

text: was also the scream of one who sees another fall and, shocked and
title: The Trial

text: without thinking, screams against his own will.
title: The Trial

text: The two men, then, remained silent for a long time. In the darkness
title: The Trial

text: beneath him, the priest could not possibly have seen K. distinctly,
title: The Trial

text: although K. was able to see him clearly by the light of the little
title: The Trial

text: lamp. Why did the priest not come down? He had not given a sermon, he
title: The Trial

text: had only told K. a few things which, if he followed them closely, would
title: The Trial

text: probably cause him more harm than good. But the priest certainly seemed
title: The Trial

text: to mean well, it might even be possible, if he would come down and
title: The Trial

text: co-operate with him, it might even be possible for him to obtain some
title: The Trial

text: acceptable piece of advice that could make all the difference, it
title: The Trial

text: might, for instance, be able to show him not so much to influence the
title: The Trial

text: proceedings but how to break free of them, how to evade them, how to
title: The Trial

text: live away from them. K. had to admit that this was something he had had
title: The Trial

text: on his mind quite a lot of late. If the priest knew of such a
title: The Trial

text: possibility he might, if K. asked him, let him know about it, even
title: The Trial

text: though he was part of the court himself and even though, when K. had
title: The Trial

text: criticised the court, he had held down his gentle nature and actually
title: The Trial

text: shouted at K.
title: The Trial

text: "Would you not like to come down here?" asked K. "If you're not going
title: The Trial

text: to give a sermon come down here with me." "Now I can come down," said
title: The Trial

text: the priest, perhaps he regretted having shouted at K. As he took down
title: The Trial

text: the lamp from its hook he said, "to start off with I had to speak to
title: The Trial

text: you from a distance. Otherwise I'm too easily influenced and forget my
title: The Trial

text: duty."
title: The Trial

text: K. waited for him at the foot of the steps. While he was still on one
title: The Trial

text: of the higher steps as he came down them the priest reached out his
title: The Trial

text: hand for K. to shake. "Can you spare me a little of your time?" asked
title: The Trial

text: K. "As much time as you need," said the priest, and passed him the
title: The Trial

text: little lamp for him to carry. Even at close distance the priest did not
title: The Trial

text: lose a certain solemnity that seemed to be part of his character. "You
title: The Trial

text: are very friendly towards me," said K., as they walked up and down
title: The Trial

text: beside each other in the darkness of one of the side naves. "That makes
title: The Trial

text: you an exception among all those who belong to the court. I can trust
title: The Trial

text: you more than any of the others I've seen. I can speak openly with you."
title: The Trial

text: "Don't fool yourself," said the priest. "How would I be fooling myself?"
title: The Trial

text: asked K. "You fool yourself in the court," said the priest, "it talks
title: The Trial

text: about this self-deceit in the opening paragraphs to the law. In front of
title: The Trial

text: the law there is a doorkeeper. A man from the countryside comes up to
title: The Trial

text: the door and asks for entry. But the doorkeeper says he can't let him in
title: The Trial

text: to the law right now. The man thinks about this, and then he asks if
title: The Trial

text: he'll be able to go in later on. 'That's possible,' says the doorkeeper,
title: The Trial

text: 'but not now.' The gateway to the law is open as it always is, and the
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper has stepped to one side, so the man bends over to try and
title: The Trial

text: see in. When the doorkeeper notices this he laughs and says, 'If you're
title: The Trial

text: tempted give it a try, try and go in even though I say you can't.
title: The Trial

text: Careful though: I'm powerful. And I'm only the lowliest of all the
title: The Trial

text: doormen. But there's a doorkeeper for each of the rooms and each of
title: The Trial

text: them is more powerful than the last. It's more than I can stand just to
title: The Trial

text: look at the third one.' The man from the country had not expected
title: The Trial

text: difficulties like this, the law was supposed to be accessible for
title: The Trial

text: anyone at any time, he thinks, but now he looks more closely at the
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper in his fur coat, sees his big hooked nose, his long thin
title: The Trial

text: tartar-beard, and he decides it's better to wait until he has
title: The Trial

text: permission to enter. The doorkeeper gives him a stool and lets him sit
title: The Trial

text: down to one side of the gate. He sits there for days and years. He tries
title: The Trial

text: to be allowed in time and again and tires the doorkeeper with his
title: The Trial

text: requests. The doorkeeper often questions him, asking about where he's
title: The Trial

text: from and many other things, but these are disinterested questions such
title: The Trial

text: as great men ask, and he always ends up by telling him he still can't
title: The Trial

text: let him in. The man had come well equipped for his journey, and uses
title: The Trial

text: everything, however valuable, to bribe the doorkeeper. He accepts
title: The Trial

text: everything, but as he does so he says, 'I'll only accept this so that
title: The Trial

text: you don't think there's anything you've failed to do.' Over many years,
title: The Trial

text: the man watches the doorkeeper almost without a break. He forgets about
title: The Trial

text: the other doormen, and begins to think this one is the only thing
title: The Trial

text: stopping him from gaining access to the law. Over the first few years he
title: The Trial

text: curses his unhappy condition out loud, but later, as he becomes old, he
title: The Trial

text: just grumbles to himself. He becomes senile, and as he has come to know
title: The Trial

text: even the fleas in the doorkeeper's fur collar over the years that he has
title: The Trial

text: been studying him he even asks them to help him and change the
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper's mind. Finally his eyes grow dim, and he no longer knows
title: The Trial

text: whether it's really getting darker or just his eyes that are deceiving
title: The Trial

text: him. But he seems now to see an inextinguishable light begin to shine
title: The Trial

text: from the darkness behind the door. He doesn't have long to live now.
title: The Trial

text: Just before he dies, he brings together all his experience from all this
title: The Trial

text: time into one question which he has still never put to the doorkeeper.
title: The Trial

text: He beckons to him, as he's no longer able to raise his stiff body. The
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper has to bend over deeply as the difference in their sizes has
title: The Trial

text: changed very much to the disadvantage of the man. 'What is it you want
title: The Trial

text: to know now?' asks the doorkeeper, 'You're insatiable.' 'Everyone wants
title: The Trial

text: access to the law,' says the man, 'how come, over all these years,
title: The Trial

text: no-one but me has asked to be let in?' The doorkeeper can see the man's
title: The Trial

text: come to his end, his hearing has faded, and so, so that he can be heard,
title: The Trial

text: he shouts to him: 'Nobody else could have got in this way, as this
title: The Trial

text: entrance was meant only for you. Now I'll go and close it.'"
title: The Trial

text: "So the doorkeeper cheated the man," said K. immediately, who had been
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: exactly as it was written. There's nothing in there about cheating."
title: The Trial

text: "But it's quite clear," said K., "and your first interpretation of it
title: The Trial

text: was quite correct. The doorkeeper gave him the information that would
title: The Trial

text: release him only when it could be of no more use." "He didn't ask him
title: The Trial

text: before that," said the priest, "and don't forget he was only a
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper, and as doorkeeper he did his duty." "What makes you think
title: The Trial

text: he did his duty?" asked K., "He didn't. It might have been his duty to
title: The Trial

text: keep everyone else away, but this man is who the door was intended for
title: The Trial

text: and he ought to have let him in." "You're not paying enough attention
title: The Trial

text: to what was written and you're changing the story," said the priest.
title: The Trial

text: "According to the story, there are two important things that the
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper explains about access to the law, one at the beginning, one
title: The Trial

text: at the end. At one place he says he can't allow him in now, and at the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: statements contradicted the other you would be right and the doorkeeper
title: The Trial

text: would have cheated the man from the country. But there is no
title: The Trial

text: contradiction. On the contrary, the first statement even hints at the
title: The Trial

text: second. You could almost say the doorkeeper went beyond his duty in
title: The Trial

text: that he offered the man some prospect of being admitted in the future.
title: The Trial

text: Throughout the story, his duty seems to have been merely to turn the
title: The Trial

text: man away, and there are many commentators who are surprised that the
title: The Trial

text: doorkeeper offered this hint at all, as he seems to love exactitude and
title: The Trial

text: keeps strict guard over his position. He stays at his post for many
title: The Trial

text: years and doesn't close the gate until the very end, he's very
title: The Trial

text: conscious of the importance of his service, as he says, 'I'm powerful,'
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: the doormen,' he's not talkative, as through all these years the only
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: duty goes he can be neither ruffled nor begged, as it says about the
title: The Trial

text: man that, 'he tires the doorkeeper with his requests,' even his
title: The Trial

text: external appearance suggests a pedantic character, the big hooked nose
title: The Trial

text: and the long, thin, black tartar-beard. How could any doorkeeper be
title: The Trial

text: more faithful to his duty? But in the doorkeeper's character there are
title: The Trial

text: also other features which might be very useful for those who seek entry
title: The Trial

text: to the law, and when he hinted at some possibility in the future it
title: The Trial

text: always seemed to make it clear that he might even go beyond his duty.
title: The Trial

text: There's no denying he's a little simple-minded, and that makes him a
title: The Trial

text: little conceited. Even if all he said about his power and the power of
title: The Trial

text: the other doorkeepers and how not even he could bear the sight of
title: The Trial

text: them—I say even if all these assertions are right, the way he makes
title: The Trial

text: them shows that he's too simple and arrogant to understand properly.
title: The Trial

text: The commentators say about this that, 'correct understanding of a matter
title: The Trial

text: and a misunderstanding of the same matter are not mutually exclusive.'
title: The Trial

text: Whether they're right or not, you have to concede that his simplicity
title: The Trial

text: and arrogance, however little they show, do weaken his function of
title: The Trial

text: guarding the entrance, they are defects in the doorkeeper's character.
title: The Trial

text: You also have to consider that the doorkeeper seems to be friendly by
title: The Trial

text: nature, he isn't always just an official. He makes a joke right at the
title: The Trial

text: beginning, in that he invites the man to enter at the same time as
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: sessions, accepting the gifts, his politeness when he puts up with the
title: The Trial

text: man cursing his fate even though it was the doorkeeper who caused that
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

text: last question. There's no more than some slight impatience—the
title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial

title: The Trial
