text: everything as true, you only have to accept it as necessary."
title: The Trial

text: "Depressing view," said K. "The lie made into the rule of the world."
title: The Trial

text: K. said that as if it were his final word but it was not his
title: The Trial

text: conclusion. He was too tired to think about all the ramifications of
title: The Trial

text: the story, and the sort of thoughts they led him into were not familiar
title: The Trial

text: to him, unrealistic things, things better suited for officials of the
title: The Trial

text: court to discuss than for him. The simple story had lost its shape, he
title: The Trial

text: wanted to shake it off, and the priest who now felt quite compassionate
title: The Trial

text: allowed this and accepted K.'s remarks without comment, even though his
title: The Trial

text: view was certainly very different from K.'s.
title: The Trial

text: In silence, they carried on walking for some time, K. stayed close
title: The Trial

text: beside the priest without knowing where he was. The lamp in his hand
title: The Trial

text: had long since gone out. Once, just in front of him, he thought he
title: The Trial

text: could see the statue of a saint by the glitter of the silver on it,
title: The Trial

text: although it quickly disappeared back into the darkness. So that he would
title: The Trial

text: not remain entirely dependent on the priest, K. asked him, "We're now
title: The Trial

text: near the main entrance, are we?" "No," said the priest, "we're a long
title: The Trial

text: way from it. Do you already want to go?" K. had not thought of going
title: The Trial

text: until then, but he immediately said, "Yes, certainly, I have to go. I'm
title: The Trial

text: the chief clerk in a bank and there are people waiting for me, I only
title: The Trial

text: came here to show a foreign business contact round the cathedral."
title: The Trial

text: "Alright," said the priest offering him his hand, "go then." "But I
title: The Trial

text: can't find my way round in this darkness by myself," said K. "Go to your
title: The Trial

text: left as far as the wall," said the priest, "then continue alongside the
title: The Trial

text: wall without leaving it and you'll find a way out." The priest had only
title: The Trial

text: gone a few paces from him, but K. was already shouting loudly, "Please,
title: The Trial

text: wait!" "I'm waiting," said the priest. "Is there anything else you want
title: The Trial

text: from me?" asked K. "No," said the priest. "You were so friendly to me
title: The Trial

text: earlier on," said K., "and you explained everything, but now you
title: The Trial

text: abandon me as if I were nothing to you." "You have to go," said the
title: The Trial

text: priest. "Well, yes," said K., "you need to understand that." "First, you
title: The Trial

text: need to understand who I am," said the priest. "You're the prison
title: The Trial

text: chaplain," said K., and went closer to the priest, it was not so
title: The Trial

text: important for him to go straight back to the bank as he had made out, he
title: The Trial

text: could very well stay where he was. "So that means I belong to the
title: The Trial

text: court," said the priest. "So why would I want anything from you? The
title: The Trial

text: court doesn't want anything from you. It accepts you when you come and
title: The Trial

text: it lets you go when you leave."
title: The Trial

text: <hr class="chap x-ebookmaker-drop" />
title: The Trial

text: <div class="chapter">
title: The Trial

text: <h2 id="Chapter_Ten">Chapter Ten
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: End
title: The Trial
The Trial

text: The evening before K.'s thirty-first birthday—it was about nine
title: The Trial

text: o'clock in the evening, the time when the streets were quiet—two men
title: The Trial

text: came to where he lived. In frock coats, pale and fat, wearing top hats
title: The Trial

text: that looked like they could not be taken off their heads. After some
title: The Trial

text: brief formalities at the door of the flat when they first arrived, the
title: The Trial

text: same formalities were repeated at greater length at K.'s door. He had
title: The Trial

text: not been notified they would be coming, but K. sat in a chair near the
title: The Trial

text: door, dressed in black as they were, and slowly put on new gloves which
title: The Trial

text: stretched tightly over his fingers and behaved as if he were expecting
title: The Trial

text: visitors. He immediately stood up and looked at the gentlemen
title: The Trial

text: inquisitively. "You've come for me then, have you?" he asked. The
title: The Trial

text: gentlemen nodded, one of them indicated the other with the top hand now
title: The Trial

text: in his hand. K. told them he had been expecting a different visitor. He
title: The Trial

text: went to the window and looked once more down at the dark street. Most
title: The Trial

text: of the windows on the other side of the street were also dark already,
title: The Trial

text: many of them had the curtains closed. In one of the windows on the same
title: The Trial

text: floor where there was a light on, two small children could be seen
title: The Trial

text: playing with each other inside a playpen, unable to move from where
title: The Trial

text: they were, reaching out for each other with their little hands. "Some
title: The Trial

text: ancient, unimportant actors—that's what they've sent for me," said K.
title: The Trial

text: to himself, and looked round once again to confirm this to himself.
title: The Trial

text: "They want to sort me out as cheaply as they can." K. suddenly turned
title: The Trial

text: round to face the two men and asked, "What theatre do you play in?"
title: The Trial

text: "Theatre?" asked one of the gentlemen, turning to the other for
title: The Trial

text: assistance and pulling in the corners of his mouth. The other made a
title: The Trial

text: gesture like someone who was dumb, as if he were struggling with some
title: The Trial

text: organism causing him trouble. "You're not properly prepared to answer
title: The Trial

text: questions," said K. and went to fetch his hat.
title: The Trial

text: As soon as they were on the stairs the gentlemen wanted to take K.'s
title: The Trial

text: arms, but K. said "Wait till we're in the street, I'm not ill." But
title: The Trial

text: they waited only until the front door before they took his arms in a
title: The Trial

text: way that K. had never experienced before. They kept their shoulders
title: The Trial

text: close behind his, did not turn their arms in but twisted them around
title: The Trial

text: the entire length of K.'s arms and took hold of his hands with a grasp
title: The Trial

text: that was formal, experienced and could not be resisted. K. was held
title: The Trial

text: stiff and upright between them, they formed now a single unit so that if
title: The Trial

text: any one of them had been knocked down all of them must have fallen.
title: The Trial

text: They formed a unit of the sort that normally can be formed only by
title: The Trial

text: matter that is lifeless.
title: The Trial

text: Whenever they passed under a lamp K. tried to see his companions more
title: The Trial

text: clearly, as far as was possible when they were pressed so close
title: The Trial

text: together, as in the dim light of his room this had been hardly
title: The Trial

text: possible. "Maybe they're tenors," he thought as he saw their big double
title: The Trial

text: chins. The cleanliness of their faces disgusted him. He could see the
title: The Trial

text: hands that cleaned them, passing over the corners of their eyes,
title: The Trial

text: rubbing at their upper lips, scratching out the creases on those chins.
title: The Trial

text: When K. noticed that, he stopped, which meant the others had to stop
title: The Trial

text: too; they were at the edge of an open square, devoid of people but
title: The Trial

text: decorated with flower beds. "Why did they send you, of all people!" he
title: The Trial

text: cried out, more a shout than a question. The two gentleman clearly knew
title: The Trial

text: no answer to give, they waited, their free arms hanging down, like
title: The Trial

text: nurses when the patient needs to rest. "I will go no further," said K.
title: The Trial

text: as if to see what would happen. The gentlemen did not need to make any
title: The Trial

text: answer, it was enough that they did not loosen their grip on K. and
title: The Trial

text: tried to move him on, but K. resisted them. "I'll soon have no need of
title: The Trial

text: much strength, I'll use all of it now," he thought. He thought of the
title: The Trial

text: flies that tear their legs off struggling to get free of the flypaper.
title: The Trial

text: "These gentleman will have some hard work to do."
title: The Trial

text: Just then, Miss Bürstner came up into the square in front of them from
title: The Trial

text: the steps leading from a small street at a lower level. It was not
title: The Trial

text: certain that it was her, although the similarity was, of course, great.
title: The Trial

text: But it did not matter to K. whether it was certainly her anyway, he
title: The Trial

text: just became suddenly aware that there was no point in his resistance.
title: The Trial

text: There would be nothing heroic about it if he resisted, if he now caused
title: The Trial

text: trouble for these gentlemen, if in defending himself he sought to enjoy
title: The Trial

text: his last glimmer of life. He started walking, which pleased the
title: The Trial

text: gentlemen and some of their pleasure conveyed itself to him. Now they
title: The Trial

text: permitted him to decide which direction they took, and he decided to
title: The Trial

text: take the direction that followed the young woman in front of them, not
title: The Trial

text: so much because he wanted to catch up with her, nor even because he
title: The Trial

text: wanted to keep her in sight for as long as possible, but only so that
title: The Trial

text: he would not forget the reproach she represented for him. "The only
title: The Trial

text: thing I can do now," he said to himself, and his thought was confirmed
title: The Trial

text: by the equal length of his own steps with the steps of the two others,
title: The Trial

text: "the only thing I can do now is keep my common sense and do what's
title: The Trial

text: needed right till the end. I always wanted to go at the world and try
title: The Trial

text: and do too much, and even to do it for something that was not too
title: The Trial

text: cheap. That was wrong of me. Should I now show them I learned nothing
title: The Trial

text: from facing trial for a year? Should I go out like someone stupid?
title: The Trial

text: Should I let anyone say, after I'm gone, that at the start of the
title: The Trial

text: proceedings I wanted to end them, and that now that they've ended I want
title: The Trial

text: to start them again? I don't want anyone to say that. I'm grateful they
title: The Trial

text: sent these unspeaking, uncomprehending men to go with me on this
title: The Trial

text: journey, and that it's been left up to me to say what's necessary."
title: The Trial

text: Meanwhile, the young woman had turned off into a side street, but K.
title: The Trial

text: could do without her now and let his companions lead him. All three of
title: The Trial

text: them now, in complete agreement, went over a bridge in the light of the
title: The Trial

text: moon, the two gentlemen were willing to yield to each little movement
title: The Trial

text: made by K. as he moved slightly towards the edge and directed the group
title: The Trial

text: in that direction as a single unit. The moonlight glittered and
title: The Trial

text: quivered in the water, which divided itself around a small island
title: The Trial

text: covered in a densely-piled mass of foliage and trees and bushes.
title: The Trial

text: Beneath them, now invisible, there were gravel paths with comfortable
title: The Trial

text: benches where K. had stretched himself out on many summer's days. "I
title: The Trial

text: didn't actually want to stop here," he said to his companions, shamed by
title: The Trial

text: their compliance with his wishes. Behind K.'s back one of them seemed
title: The Trial

text: to quietly criticise the other for the misunderstanding about stopping,
title: The Trial

text: and then they went on. They went on up through several streets where
title: The Trial

text: policemen were walking or standing here and there; some in the distance
title: The Trial

text: and then some very close. One of them with a bushy moustache, his hand
title: The Trial

text: on the grip of his sword, seemed to have some purpose in approaching
title: The Trial

text: the group, which was hardly unsuspicious. The two gentlemen stopped,
title: The Trial

text: the policeman seemed about to open his mouth, and then K. drove his
title: The Trial

text: group forcefully forward. Several times he looked back cautiously to see
title: The Trial

text: if the policeman was following; but when they had a corner between
title: The Trial

text: themselves and the policeman K. began to run, and the two gentlemen,
title: The Trial

text: despite being seriously short of breath, had to run with him.
title: The Trial

text: In this way they quickly left the built up area and found themselves in
title: The Trial

text: the fields which, in this part of town, began almost without any
title: The Trial

text: transition zone. There was a quarry, empty and abandoned, near a
title: The Trial

text: building which was still like those in the city. Here the men stopped,
title: The Trial

text: perhaps because this had always been their destination or perhaps
title: The Trial

text: because they were too exhausted to run any further. Here they released
title: The Trial

text: their hold on K., who just waited in silence, and took their top hats
title: The Trial

text: off while they looked round the quarry and wiped the sweat off their
title: The Trial

text: brows with their handkerchiefs. The moonlight lay everywhere with the
title: The Trial

text: natural peace that is granted to no other light.
title: The Trial

text: After exchanging a few courtesies about who was to carry out the next
title: The Trial

text: tasks—the gentlemen did not seem to have been allocated specific
title: The Trial

text: functions—one of them went to K. and took his coat, his waistcoat, and
title: The Trial

text: finally his shirt off him. K. made an involuntary shiver, at which the
title: The Trial

text: gentleman gave him a gentle, reassuring tap on the back. Then he
title: The Trial

text: carefully folded the things up as if they would still be needed, even
title: The Trial

text: if not in the near future. He did not want to expose K. to the chilly
title: The Trial

text: night air without moving though, so he took him under the arm and
title: The Trial

text: walked up and down with him a little way while the other gentleman
title: The Trial

text: looked round the quarry for a suitable place. When he had found it he
title: The Trial

text: made a sign and the other gentleman escorted him there. It was near the
title: The Trial

text: rockface, there was a stone lying there that had broken loose. The
title: The Trial

text: gentlemen sat K. down on the ground, leant him against the stone and
title: The Trial

text: settled his head down on the top of it. Despite all the effort they
title: The Trial

text: went to, and despite all the co-operation shown by K., his demeanour
title: The Trial

text: seemed very forced and hard to believe. So one of the gentlemen asked
title: The Trial

text: the other to grant him a short time while he put K. in position by
title: The Trial

text: himself, but even that did nothing to make it better. In the end they
title: The Trial

text: left K. in a position that was far from the best of the ones they had
title: The Trial

text: tried so far. Then one of the gentlemen opened his frock coat and from a
title: The Trial

text: sheath hanging on a belt stretched across his waistcoat he withdrew a
title: The Trial

text: long, thin, double-edged butcher's knife which he held up in the light
title: The Trial

text: to test its sharpness. The repulsive courtesies began once again, one of
title: The Trial

text: them passed the knife over K. to the other, who then passed it back over
title: The Trial

text: K. to the first. K. now knew it would be his duty to take the knife as
title: The Trial

text: it passed from hand to hand above him and thrust it into himself. But
title: The Trial

text: he did not do it, instead he twisted his neck, which was still free,
title: The Trial

text: and looked around. He was not able to show his full worth, was not able
title: The Trial

text: to take all the work from the official bodies, he lacked the rest of
title: The Trial

text: the strength he needed and this final shortcoming was the fault of
title: The Trial

text: whoever had denied it to him. As he looked round, he saw the top floor
title: The Trial

text: of the building next to the quarry. He saw how a light flickered on and
title: The Trial

text: the two halves of a window opened out, somebody, made weak and thin by
title: The Trial

text: the height and the distance, leant suddenly far out from it and
title: The Trial

text: stretched his arms out even further. Who was that? A friend? A good
title: The Trial

text: person? Somebody who was taking part? Somebody who wanted to help? Was
title: The Trial

text: he alone? Was it everyone? Would anyone help? Were there objections that
title: The Trial

text: had been forgotten? There must have been some. The logic cannot be
title: The Trial

text: refuted, but someone who wants to live will not resist it. Where was the
title: The Trial

text: judge he'd never seen? Where was the high court he had never reached? He
title: The Trial

text: raised both hands and spread out all his fingers.
title: The Trial

text: But the hands of one of the gentleman were laid on K.'s throat, while
title: The Trial

text: the other pushed the knife deep into his heart and twisted it there,
title: The Trial

text: twice. As his eyesight failed, K. saw the two gentlemen cheek by cheek,
title: The Trial

text: close in front of his face, watching the result. "Like a dog!" he said,
title: The Trial

text: it was as if the shame of it should outlive him.
title: The Trial

title: The Trial
